site_title: Pertamina to go solo on Balongan refinery
summary: Indonesian state-owned energy company Pertamina will proceed with a $1.2 billion upgrade of its Balongan refinery alone, after initially planning to partner with Saudi Aramco. The upgrade aims to double the refinery's crude capacity to 240,000 barrels per day and enable it to process medium crude with a sulphur content of 0.4-0.5%. The project's completion is set for 2020, and Pertamina is still considering partnering with Aramco for the second stage.

site_title: Sony takes US$1b writedown on movie business
summary: Sony Corp is writing down the value of its movie business by nearly $1.4 billion due to weaker film profits caused by online streaming services reducing demand for movie DVDs. The company has been slashing costs to end years of losses and expects profits to improve from its turnaround plan, including bolstering income from intellectual property and strengthening markets outside the US. This is the third writedown for Sony, with most of the writedown relating to goodwill from its 1989 acquisition of Columbia Pictures.

site_title: Singapore shares open 0.1% up on Wednesday
summary: Singapore stocks opened 0.1% higher on Wednesday, amid risk-off sentiment due to concerns over US trade policy isolationism. The Straits Times Index rose 3.24 points to 3,050.04 with 74.7 million shares changing hands. Gainers outnumbered losers 66 to 51, driven by a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data.

site_title: IPOS to lower patent, trademark protection application fees from April 1
summary: The Intellectual Property Office of Singapore (IPOS) will lower application fees for patents and trademarks starting April 1, with a 30% discount for trademark applications using a pre-approved list of goods and services. However, patent renewal fees will be raised for the first time in about a decade to discourage IP hoarding, except for patents offered for licensing, which will still receive a 50% discount.

site_title: US: Weak earnings, Trump fears pressure stocks
summary: US stocks retreated on Tuesday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average falling 0.5% due to disappointing earnings from ExxonMobil and uncertainty over President Trump's growth agenda. Other companies, such as JPMorgan Chase, Goldman Sachs, and Caterpillar, also dropped. Analysts cite skepticism about Trump's agenda following recent controversies, including the immigration executive order. The S&P 500 slipped 0.1% and the Nasdaq Composite Index finished up slightly.

site_title: Japan to offer US job boost to Trump: Kyodo
summary: Japan's Prime Minister Shinzo Abe will propose plans to create hundreds of thousands of jobs in the US when meeting President Donald Trump on February 10. Japan is putting together an investment package focused on projects like high-speed rail construction and shale oil development, aiming to translate into new US jobs. The proposal comes amid concerns over trade and security following Trump's election campaign, including his threat to pull US troops from the region and his criticism of Japan's auto industry.

site_title: China's second aircraft carrier 'taking shape', says report
summary: China's second aircraft carrier, The Shandong, is reportedly "taking shape" after two years and nine months of construction, according to local media. Construction began in 2014 in the northeastern port of Dalian. The carrier is China's first indigenous aircraft carrier, following the refitted Liaoning, which was bought from Ukraine in 1998. The Shandong's launch would further increase Beijing's military assertiveness, particularly in the South China Sea, where it has tested weapons and equipment in recent exercises.

site_title: Singapore-Delaware cross-border insolvency guidelines implemented, more jurisdictions to come
summary: Singapore and the US have implemented cross-border insolvency guidelines between the Supreme Court and the Delaware bankruptcy court, enhancing cooperation and communication for insolvency proceedings. This move is expected to be followed by other jurisdictions. The guidelines aim to streamline and standardize cross-border insolvency cases, making it easier for companies to navigate complex international insolvency proceedings.

site_title: San Francisco sues Trump for targeting sanctuary cities
summary: San Francisco filed a lawsuit against Donald Trump, challenging his executive order to withhold federal funds from sanctuary cities. The city claims the order is unconstitutional and un-American, and seeks an injunction to prevent the funds from being withheld. The lawsuit, the first of its kind, argues that sanctuary cities, which protect undocumented immigrants, are not harboring criminals but rather offering protection to those who contribute to the community. The city, which receives over $1.2 billion in federal funding annually, is defending its residents and the rule of law.

site_title: Trump economic adviser bashes Germany on currency: report
summary: US President Donald Trump's economic adviser, Peter Navarro, has publicly criticized Germany for exploiting the undervalued euro to gain a trade advantage, echoing Trump's stance on China's currency manipulation. Navarro stated Germany "continues to exploit other countries" and that the US should take advantage of devaluation as a trade strategy. This criticism comes as the US and EU are in talks for a trade deal, with Navarro also declaring the Trans-Atlantic Trade and Investment Partnership "dead."

images.alt_text: A top economic adviser to US President Donald Trump bashed Germany for exploiting an undervalued euro to take advantage of its trading partners, the Financial Times reported Tuesday.

site_title: Indonesia inflation rate picks up to 3.49% in Jan
summary: Indonesia's inflation rate rose to 3.49% in January, exceeding expectations of 3.11%. The increase was mainly driven by higher prices of processed food and drinks, as well as cigarettes. Core inflation, which strips out volatile food prices, also increased to 3.35% from 3.07% in December, the highest annual pace since July. This rate is above Indonesia's central bank target of 3-5% for the year.

images.alt_text: Indonesia's annual inflation rate accelerated in January, mainly due to increases in the prices of processed food and drinks as well as cigarettes, the statistics bureau said on Wednesday.

site_title: Apple reports blockbuster quarter as iPhone sales top estimates
summary: Apple reported a strong quarterly earnings, with iPhone sales topping estimates at 78.29 million units, driven by demand for the latest iPhone 7. Revenue rose 3.3% to $78.35 billion, but the company's struggles in the smartphone market, particularly in Greater China, were highlighted. Apple forecast revenue of $51.5-$53.5 billion for the current quarter, below analyst expectations. The company's services business saw a 18.4% growth in revenue, while net income fell to $17.89 billion.

site_title: 'Tooth fairy' or 'disaster'? UK's Brexit gamble on Trump
summary: UK Prime Minister Theresa May's gamble on a trade deal with US President Donald Trump is turning into a diplomatic headache. Trump's recent travel ban and May's initial reluctance to condemn it sparked protests and raised concerns about her reliance on the US leader. The visit to the White House, where they held hands, has also been criticized, with some calling it a "political risk." Experts warn that any trade deal may not boost Britain's economy, and May's approval ratings will ultimately determine the success of her strategy.

images.alt_text: Mr Trump's rejection of the European Union and his enthusiasm for a swift post-Brexit trade deal with Britain appeared to boost Mrs May, demonstrating that she had other options if EU leaders offered an unattractive deal.

site_title: Volvo profit beats forecast, raises European outlook
summary: Volvo reported stronger-than-expected quarterly core earnings, beating forecasts, and raised its European outlook for the year. The company's adjusted operating profit rose to 5.66 billion Swedish crowns ($646.5 million), exceeding analyst expectations. Volvo also reported a 10% year-on-year increase in truck orders, a 3% decline for analysts, and raised its forecast for European heavy-duty truck sales to 300,000 vehicles. The company's shares have risen 46% over the past year. Volvo also announced a review of its construction arm, which could be a potential spin-off.

site_title: Indonesian central bank to use variable rates for auctions
summary: Indonesia's central bank, Bank Indonesia, will accept variable rates in its auctions starting February 1, aiming to strengthen its monetary operations and ensure market liquidity reflects market rates. This move aims to encourage banks to lower their lending rates more quickly in line with the benchmark rate cuts. The change is a response to last year's tight liquidity and slow rate cuts by banks, which were partly due to concerns over potential bad debts. Bankers welcome the measure, expecting it to bring down auction rates in the short term.

site_title: South Korea Jan exports surge at fastest rate in nearly 5 years, top forecasts
summary: South Korea's exports surged 11.2% in January, the largest jump since 2012, beating expectations and offering hope for policymakers amid trade uncertainties. The country's trade surplus rose to $3.2 billion, driven by a 13.5% increase in shipments to China and the European Union. However, manufacturing activity contracted for a sixth straight month, with the Nikkei/Markit Purchasing Managers' Index falling to 49.0. The country's consumer sentiment also plummeted to multi-year lows due to a political scandal involving President Park Geun-Hye.

images.alt_text: South Korean exports rose in January for a third consecutive month and at the fastest pace in nearly five years, preliminary data showed on Wednesday, handsomely beating expectations.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks end higher as yen buying on Trump fizzles
summary: Tokyo stocks closed higher on Wednesday, as investors sought bargains after two days of losses. The Nikkei 225 gained 0.56% and the Topix index rose 0.40%. A rise in the yen's value, sparked by Donald Trump's comments, failed to dampen investor sentiment. The rally marked a bounce-back from previous losses, with traders shrugging off new Trump threats.

site_title: Fed to hold rates steady to reassess outlook: Decision-day guide
summary: The Federal Reserve is expected to hold interest rates steady at its meeting on Wednesday, reassessing the US economy's outlook after President Trump's election. Household and business sentiment indicators have jumped, but actual economic activity has yet to catch up. Fed officials will review recent reports on economic growth, employment, and inflation, potentially updating the statement's opening paragraph and language on business investment and economic risks. The decision is seen as cautious, with investors anticipating a less than 15% probability of a rate hike in the near future.

site_title: As climate change accelerates, floating cities look like less of a pipe dream
summary: A non-profit organization, the Seasteading Institute, is moving forward with a plan to build a city of floating islands in the South Pacific to address climate change. The project, which aims to provide sustainable living solutions for those threatened by rising sea levels, has raised $2.5 million from donors and is expected to start construction in French Polynesia next year. The pilot islands will cost $10-50 million and house a few dozen people, with the initial residents likely being middle-income buyers from the developed world.

site_title: Only a third of Americans think Trump's travel ban will make them more safe: poll
summary: A Reuters/Ipsos poll found that only 31% of Americans believe President Trump's travel ban makes them feel "more safe." The ban, which suspended admission of citizens from seven Muslim countries and all refugees for 120 days, received support from roughly one in two Americans, but divisions existed along party lines. Many critics, including Republican lawmakers, argued that the ban could backfire and give terrorist organizations a new recruitment message.

site_title: US consumer confidence retreats in January
summary: US consumer confidence retreated to 111.8 in January, down from a 15-year high of 113.3 in December, amid a less optimistic outlook for business and jobs. The expectations index fell nearly seven points to 99.8. Despite this, consumers remain confident in the economy's expansion, with 27% viewing jobs as plentiful and 29% labeling business conditions as "good". The outlook for six months out worsened, with fewer expecting income increases.

images.alt_text: US consumer confidence retreated in January after hitting a 15-year high in December, amid a less optimistic outlook for business and jobs, the Conference Board said Tuesday.

site_title: Trump names conservative judge Gorsuch as US Supreme Court pick
summary: President Donald Trump nominated 49-year-old federal appeals court judge Neil Gorsuch for a lifetime job on the US Supreme Court, aiming to restore the court's conservative majority. Gorsuch, a conservative intellectual, faces a potentially contentious confirmation battle in the US Senate after Republicans refused to consider Democratic President Barack Obama's nominee last year. The choice is seen as a significant departure from recent Supreme Court nominations, and Gorsuch is considered a mainstream judge who should easily be confirmed by the Senate.

images.alt_text: Mr Gorsuch is the youngest nominee to the nation's highest court in more than a quarter century, and he could influence the direction of the court for decades.

site_title: New Zealand PM calls national election for Sept 23
summary: New Zealand Prime Minister Bill English announced a national election for September 23, calling for a fourth consecutive term for his centre-right National Party. The election was initially due in September this year, and a poll shows the National Party is more than 6% ahead of the Labour Party and The Greens. English plans to campaign on the government's economic record, which includes a forecasted budget surplus of NZ$8.5 billion by 2020/21. The election comes as New Zealand faces potential economic risks, including US protectionism and concerns about an overheated housing market.

images.alt_text: New Zealand Prime Minister Bill English called an election on Wednesday for Sept 23 after taking over as premier in December following the unexpected resignation of his predecessor, John Key.

site_title: Trump looms over EU's Malta summit
summary: US President Donald Trump's policies pose an existential threat to Europe, according to EU President Donald Tusk, who ranked Trump as one of the biggest threats to the bloc in its 60-year history. The EU leaders will discuss Trump's commitment to the transatlantic alliance, migration, and the aftermath of Britain's vote to leave the EU. The summit in Malta will also focus on unity amid concerns about Trump's unpredictability, with the EU considering steps to boost European integration and address the humanitarian crisis in Libya.

site_title: Malaysia: Markets closed for public holiday
summary: Malaysia's financial markets are closed on Wednesday for Federal Territory Day and will resume trading on Thursday, Feb 2. This article is not related to Malaysia's markets closure.

site_title: 'Rent-a-monk' business thrives as Japan loses temple ties
summary: A Japanese company, Minrevi, offers a "rent-a-monk" service, where customers can hire Buddhist monks for funeral ceremonies at a fixed price. The service has gained popularity as more Japanese people lose ties to local temples and faith in the opaque donation system. Minrevi claims to provide a platform for customers to connect with monks, but critics argue that it commodifies donations and undermines the spiritual aspect of Buddhism. The company's demand has spiked since its launch in 2013, with over 700 monks on its roster, and is expected to grow by 20% this year.

site_title: Asia: Shares fall after US dollar slips to 12-week low
summary: Asian stocks fell for a second day, led by Japan and Hong Kong, after the US dollar hit a 12-week low. The dollar's decline, attributed to President Trump's comments on the euro, led to a drop in oil prices and a flat gold price. Apple shares jumped 3% after beating earnings estimates. The US dollar remained near its lowest level since November, and investors are awaiting the Federal Reserve's interest-rate decision.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks open with losses
summary: Hong Kong stocks opened in negative territory, easing 0.64% to 23,211.88 on Wednesday, as investors played catch-up with a sell-off across global markets following an extended holiday weekend. Mainland Chinese markets were closed.

site_title: Australia home prices off to flying start in January, Sydney soars
summary: Australian home prices surged in January, rising 0.7% in the combined capital cities, driven by Sydney's 1% gain. Annual growth stands at 10.7%, despite the Reserve Bank of Australia's efforts to slow the market with tighter lending rules. Home prices in Sydney have almost doubled since 2009, making them unaffordable for first-time buyers. The divergence in growth between houses and apartments continues, with houses rising 11.1% and units 8.0% annually.

site_title: India puts 1.8m on notice for potential tax evasion
summary: India has issued notices to 1.8 million citizens for potential tax evasion amid the country's cash crisis following the demonetization of high-value banknotes. The move is part of "operation clean money" aimed at rooting out corruption and undeclared income. The initial phase of the operation flagged accounts with large suspicious cash deposits made between November 9 and December 30, 2016. The government has defended the scheme, urging Indians to switch to non-cash payment methods and accusing those who oppose it of being tax evaders.

site_title: What controversy? Trump's Republican base still on his side
summary: Despite nationwide protests and criticism from officials, a majority of Trump's Republican base remains supportive of his policies. According to a recent poll, over 80% of Republicans approve of Trump's initial performance, while nearly three-quarters believe banning travelers from Muslim-majority countries is necessary to prevent terrorism. Many Republicans, including some who consider themselves independents, express satisfaction with Trump's actions, citing his commitment to conservative reforms and his ability to "change business as usual" in Washington.

site_title: China factory sector grows slightly more than expected in January: official PMI
summary: China's manufacturing sector expanded slightly more than expected in January, with the official Purchasing Managers' Index (PMI) standing at 51.3, above the 50-point mark separating growth from contraction. This marked a slight increase from the previous month's 51.4, but at the same pace as December. Analysts had predicted a reading of 51.2, citing higher sales prices and a construction boom driving demand. The data suggests a modest expansion in China's industrial sector, but it does not indicate a significant improvement in growth.

site_title: Fragrance eyes Liverpool property, forms UK unit
summary: Fragrance Group, a Singapore-based real-estate and hospitality company, has set up a UK subsidiary to acquire a property in Liverpool. The £1 million unit is competing in a tender exercise for a 4,570 sqm property in the city centre. The property, a historical building with French and Italian Renaissance architecture, could be used for various purposes including hotels, residential, and leisure space. The acquisition is not expected to impact Fragrance Group's net tangible assets or earnings per share for the current financial year ending Dec 31, 2017.

site_title: 'Abduction' of China tycoon sparks fear in Hong Kong
summary: China tycoon Xiao Jianhua, a billionaire with ties to President Xi Jinping, was reportedly abducted from Hong Kong by mainland security agents. A newspaper advert attributed to Xiao pledged loyalty to China, sparking fears of Beijing's meddling. Xiao, a Canadian citizen, denies the abduction, claiming he was being treated for an illness overseas. The incident raises concerns about Hong Kong's autonomy and rule of law, with critics suggesting China's anti-corruption campaign has been used to target opponents.

site_title: Australia: Shares gain on mining stocks, NZ steady
summary: Australian shares rose 0.57% on Wednesday, driven by gains in mining and oil stocks as the US dollar faltered against a basket of currencies. Key performers included Fortescue Metals Group, BHP Billiton, and Newcrest Mining, while Westpac Banking Corp and AMP Limited also saw gains. New Zealand's benchmark index ended flat, despite strong property data and a surge in unemployment that may reduce the likelihood of a rate hike.

site_title: Bigger land holdings key to preventing farmer suicides in India: activists
summary: India's farming policy overhaul is key to preventing farmer suicides, campaigners say. Tens of thousands of farmers have died by suicide in the past decade due to drought, lower global commodity prices, and debt. Over half of farming households are in debt, with small and marginal farmers, who own less than 2 hectares of land, being the most affected. Activists are demanding a policy to pool land, increase holdings, and provide subsidies, fertiliser support, and better crop insurance to improve yields and prevent crop failures.

site_title: Australia shares rise as weaker US dollar boosts miners; NZ falls
summary: Australia's shares rose 0.36% on Wednesday, driven by gains in basic materials and energy stocks, as a weaker US dollar boosted miners. The S&P/ASX 200 index gained 19.989 points to 5,640.9. Fortescue Metals rose 4.7% and BHP Billiton gained 1.4% after brokerages upgraded the company's target price. Meanwhile, New Zealand's benchmark index fell 0.2% for the third straight session.

site_title: Trump fires Attorney-General, swears in another
summary: US President Donald Trump fired acting Attorney-General Sally Yates, citing her refusal to enforce a legal order banning entry to the US from seven predominantly-Muslim nations. Yates was replaced by Dana Boente, an Obama appointee, who instructed the department's lawyers to defend the order. The move intensified a three-day drama over the ban, with protests and legal challenges mounting. Senate Minority Leader Chuck Schumer vowed to block Trump's nominee for Attorney-General, Jeff Sessions, citing concerns over his independence from the White House.

site_title: Johnny Depp almost ruined by lavish spending: lawsuit
summary: Johnny Depp's lavish spending nearly led to financial ruin, with estimated costs of $75 million on 14 homes, $18 million on a yacht, and $700,000 a month on luxuries. The Management Group (TMG) sued Depp for an unpaid loan, accusing him of mismanaging his finances and concealing his overspending. Depp filed a $25 million counter-suit, claiming TMG mismanaged his finances. TMG alleges Depp was bailed out by the company after his bank demanded repayment, and is now owed $4.2 million.

site_title: Allianz's US$2t job: Meet the woman in charge of Pimco
summary: Jackie Hunt, a 48-year-old South African, has taken over as the head of Allianz's asset management and US life insurance divisions. Under her watch, Pimco, a $1.47 trillion asset manager, reported its first net inflows since 2013. Hunt, a trained accountant with little background in money management, attributes the revival to the efforts of her predecessors, not herself. She aims to oversee the strategic direction of asset managers and align them with the group's goals. Hunt's appointment is seen as a strategic move to consolidate the industry, as fees decline and investors shift to low-cost passive strategies.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open lower as yen soars
summary: Tokyo stocks opened lower on February 1, 2017, as the yen surged against the dollar following US President Donald Trump's claim that Japan devalued its currency for trade benefits. The Nikkei 225 fell 0.54% and the Topix index dropped 0.83%. This move came despite a 5-day rally in Singapore stocks and a strong start to the week for the US S&P 500 and Nasdaq.

site_title: Trump Tower has rental bargains, if you can get past security
summary: The luxury apartment market in Manhattan, including Trump Tower, is experiencing a slowdown due to increased competition from new condo towers and wealthy investors. The median asking rent for units listed for lease has dropped 5.9% compared to last year, with 42% of luxury apartments in Midtown having reduced their prices. Trump Tower, home to President Trump's family, is also facing reduced prices, with the median asking rent now at $8,000 per month, down from $8,500. Despite the challenges, some brokers believe the building's security features and prime location remain attractive to potential renters.

images.alt_text: Trump Tower's location on Fifth Avenue between 56th and 57th streets puts it in a prime spot in one of the world's busiest shopping districts and two blocks from Central Park.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Fragrance, Ezra, Ascendas India Trust
summary: Fragrance Group set up a UK subsidiary to bid on a Liverpool property, while Ezra Holdings faces one-time writedowns from a joint venture. Ascendas India Trust's third-quarter earnings rose due to new income from IT parks and rental increases. Stocks to watch include these companies as they may influence trading on Wednesday.

site_title: German police arrest three suspected jihadists
summary: German police arrested three suspects, aged 21, 31, and 45, suspected of trying to reach foreign "war zones" to train for an attack. The suspects may be linked to the Islamic State group and had planned to travel to Syria or Iraq. At least two of the arrested individuals lived in Berlin and frequented the same mosque attended by a Tunisian man suspected of a deadly Christmas market attack. The investigation found no concrete plans to carry out an attack in Germany.

images.alt_text: German police said they arrested three people in Berlin on Tuesday suspected of trying to reach foreign "war zones" in order to train to carry out an attack.

site_title: Turnbull warns of tougher times for Aussies as popularity wanes
summary: Australian Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull warns of tougher economic times for the nation, citing a decline in GDP and rising jobless figures. His government faces mounting signs of fiscal weakness, and Turnbull's popularity is declining, with a recent poll showing the opposition Labor party leading the coalition by 52-48. Turnbull will use a speech to outline his government's plans to cut company taxes and promote free trade, but faces questions about his ability to push through his legislative agenda.

images.alt_text: Australian Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull is warning that tougher economic times loom for the nation, even as voters signal their discontent with his government.

site_title: Amazon pumping nearly US$1.5b into US air freight hub
summary: Amazon is investing nearly $1.5 billion to build its first air freight hub in northern Kentucky, creating over 2,000 jobs. The hub will be a central location for moving goods, allowing the company to decrease its dependence on shipping companies and control its supply chain and costs. This investment follows Amazon's growth in cargo transport, including dedicated cargo planes and investments in trailers for trucking goods and ocean freight forwarders. The hub is expected to support fast, free deliveries to Prime subscribers.

site_title: Indian budget to try and ease pain from cash crunch
summary: Indian Finance Minister Arun Jaitley is expected to present a budget that will boost spending and ease the impact of the government's crackdown on "black money" on the economy. The move aims to lift growth, which is forecasted to dip to 6.5% in the current fiscal year, before picking up in the coming year. The budget is seen as a response to the cash crunch caused by the government's surprise decision to scrap high-value banknotes worth 86% of India's cash in circulation. The government is pencilling in a federal fiscal deficit of 3.3% of GDP for 2017/18, higher than the 3% pledged earlier.

images.alt_text: Indian Finance Minister Arun Jaitley (pictured) will likely boost spending and ease back on cutting the deficit when he presents his fourth budget on Wednesday, as he seeks to lift growth hit by the government's drive to purge the economy of "black money".

site_title: UK house price growth weakest since Nov 2015: Nationwide
summary: UK house prices rose 0.2% in January, the weakest annual growth since November 2015, according to Nationwide. This brings the annual increase to 4.3%, down from 4.5% in December. The slowdown is attributed to uncertain economic prospects and pressure on households due to rising consumer price inflation. Economists had expected a slight increase in annual growth to 4.4%. The outlook for the housing market remains clouded, with Nationwide economist Robert Gardner citing uncertainty surrounding economic prospects.

images.alt_text: Annual house price inflation fell to its weakest level since November 2015 last month, and the outlook remains clouded due to uncertain economic prospects, mortgage lender Nationwide said on Wednesday.

site_title: Nintendo plans to release 2 or 3 mobile games every year
summary: Nintendo plans to release 2-3 mobile games annually, down from previous expectations, amid a one-third cut to its full-year operating profit outlook. The company also announced 70 game developers are creating 100 titles for its Switch console, launched in March. This move follows the company's disappointment with investors.

site_title: New Zealand dollar falls after jobless rate climbs, Australian dollar weaker
summary: The New Zealand dollar fell to a 10-week low of US$0.7280 after the country's jobless rate rose to 5.2% in the December quarter, with wage growth remaining sluggish. The Reserve Bank of New Zealand is unlikely to raise interest rates this year due to weak wage growth. Meanwhile, the Australian dollar eased 0.3% to US$0.7560, after three straight sessions of gains. The currencies have surged 5.5% each against the US dollar in January, driven by risk aversion and US President Donald Trump's policies.

site_title: Dissident US diplomats defy Trump on travel ban
summary: US diplomats have defied President Donald Trump's travel ban, submitting a "dissent memo" opposing the policy. The memo, leaked to the public, argues that the ban is a betrayal of American values and will not make the country safer. The diplomats claim the ban will harm 200 million legitimate travelers and will not prevent a small number of potential terrorists from entering the US. The move is seen as unprecedented, as the State Department's internal "dissent channel" was last used in June 2016.

images.alt_text: A group of US diplomats declared their opposition to President Donald Trump's travel ban Tuesday, despite the White House warning that they should get behind his agenda or resign.

site_title: Europe: Shares end January lower as Trump rally fades
summary: European shares ended January 0.4% lower, falling to a one-week low, as investors became more realistic about US President Donald Trump's policies, despite solid economic data. The Stoxx 600 index fell 0.7% on Tuesday, marking its biggest one-day loss since before Trump's election. Despite this, investors remain bullish on European equities, citing signs of an economic recovery and attractive valuations. Credit Suisse lifted its year-end target for the Euro Stoxx 50 index to 3,450 points, citing earnings prospects and solid growth.

site_title: Mexican economy grew 2.3% in 2016
summary: Mexico's economy grew 2.3% in 2016, exceeding analyst forecasts but slower than the previous year. This follows a 2.5% expansion in 2015. The economy slowed to 0.6% growth in the fourth quarter, down from 1.0% in the previous quarter. The growth was partly driven by concerns over Donald Trump's presidency and potential renegotiation of the North American Free Trade Agreement. The central bank had downgraded its 2017 growth forecast to 1.5-2.5%.

site_title: Japan's top currency official rejects Trump devaluation claims
summary: Japan's top currency official, Masatsugu Asakawa, rejects US President Donald Trump's claims that Japan manipulates its currency to devalue it. Asakawa stated that Japan's monetary policy aims to end deflation, not affect currency rates. The dollar fell to 112.08 yen after Trump and trade adviser Peter Navarro criticized Japan's currency policy, which could hurt Japan's export-reliant economy. Asakawa declined to comment on Trump's intentions, but noted that Japan hasn't intervened in currency markets recently.

images.alt_text: Japan's top currency official said on Wednesday that foreign-exchange rates were decided by markets and were not being manipulated, after US President Donald Trump took aim at the currency policies of Japan and other trading partners.

site_title: US dollar set for worst Jan in 30 years after Trump, Navarro comments
summary: The US dollar is expected to have its worst January in 30 years due to comments from President Donald Trump and his trade adviser Peter Navarro. Trump stated that currency devaluation by other countries, including the euro, increases drugmakers' outsourcing of production to the US. The euro gained over 1% against the US dollar, while the US dollar plunged against the Japanese yen, hitting its lowest since November 30. The US dollar index is set to decline about 2.6% for the month, its largest decline since March 2016.

site_title: Fed likely to hold rates as it awaits Trump economic plan details
summary: The US Federal Reserve is expected to keep interest rates unchanged on Wednesday, awaiting details on President Donald Trump's economic plans. Despite the US economy nearing full employment, policymakers are uncertain due to the lack of clarity on Trump's policies, which could lead to higher inflation. The Fed has forecast three rate increases this year, but economists predict no rate hike at this meeting. A press conference is not scheduled, and the policy decision will be released at 2pm EST.

site_title: Japan hotel to remove books denying Nanjing Massacre
summary: A Japanese hotel chain, APA Group, has agreed to remove books denying the Nanjing Massacre from rooms at a hotel hosting athletes at the 2017 Sapporo Asian Winter Games. The books, written by the hotel's president, contain revisionist views on history and are placed in every room. China has called for a boycott, and the hotel had initially refused to remove the books. Organizers of the games had requested the removal of the material, and the hotel has now agreed to comply. The move aims to create a welcoming environment for athletes.

site_title: New Zealand jobless rises, wage growth low as workers flood market
summary: New Zealand's jobless rate rose to 5.2% in the fourth quarter, up from an eight-year low of 4.8%, as more people flooded the workforce. Wage growth remained sluggish at 0.4% quarterly and 1.6% annual. The Reserve Bank of New Zealand is unlikely to hike interest rates due to strong labor demand and muted wage growth. Record levels of migration have expanded the workforce faster than job creation, contributing to the moderation in inflation. The next policy announcement is set for Feb 9, with rates expected to remain at 1.75%.

images.alt_text: New Zealand's jobless rate jumped and wage growth stayed sluggish as more people flooded the workforce in the fourth quarter, suggesting interest rates can remain at record lows even as the economy hums along.

site_title: EU clears final hurdle for end of mobile roaming charges
summary: The European Union has agreed to cap wholesale roaming charges, paving the way for the abolition of roaming fees in June 2017. The caps, which will decrease from 7.7 euros to 2.5 euros per gigabyte, are the final hurdle for a decade-long effort to allow EU citizens to use their phones abroad without extra charges. The deal must still be confirmed by the European Parliament and member states, but it follows a surge in anti-EU sentiment following Britain's Brexit vote. The EU aims to demonstrate its commitment to ordinary citizens.

site_title: Canon profit hit by slower sales in emerging economies
summary: Canon reported a 31.6% decline in full-year profit in 2016 due to a slowdown in emerging markets and the impact of a stronger yen. The company blamed a decline in demand for lower-end black-and-white printers and a shortage of components caused by supply chain disruptions. Despite this, Canon forecasts a 12.8% rise in net profit and 11.4% hike in operating profit for 2017, driven by growing demand in the US and some emerging economies.

site_title: China trade cost 3.4m US jobs in 2001-2015: report
summary: A report by the Economic Policy Institute (EPI) found that the US-China trade deficit between 2001 and 2015 cost 3.4 million US jobs, primarily in the manufacturing sector. The trade deficit quadrupled to $483.2 billion during this period, with computers and electronic parts suffering the most job losses. However, some experts argue that the report's correlation between trade deficit and job losses is flawed, suggesting that trade affects job composition rather than creation or destruction.

site_title: Nomura's Q3 profit doubles on strong fixed income business
summary: Nomura Holdings Inc reported a 99% increase in its third-quarter profit to 70.3 billion yen, driven by a surge in trading of bonds and currencies following Donald Trump's US presidential election victory. The wholesale division's pre-tax profit nearly doubled to 47.4 billion yen, while the retail arm's pre-tax profit fell 7% to 25.9 billion yen. The results mirror those of Wall Street investment banks and put Nomura on track to achieve a 50 billion pre-tax profit target for the full year.

site_title: Daimler to supply self-driving cars for Uber
summary: Daimler, the German auto giant, has partnered with Uber to supply self-driving cars for the US ride-hailing company. The agreement, announced Tuesday, aims to introduce self-driving Mercedes-Benz vehicles on Uber's global network in the coming years. Daimler will build and operate the vehicles, but financial details were not disclosed. This partnership comes as both companies compete to establish themselves in the autonomous driving market, with Uber also working with Volvo Cars to develop self-driving cars for sale by 2021.

site_title: Allied leaders extend a hand to US at their peril
summary: British Prime Minister Theresa May faces backlash for her handling of US President Donald Trump's executive order halting Syrian refugee entrance and most citizens from seven predominantly Muslim countries. The order was signed hours after May left Washington, sparking criticism among her own members of Parliament and protesters outside Downing Street. Despite May's efforts to distance herself from the issue, the US president has turned on her, drawing parallels with other Western leaders who have faced similar repercussions. Merkel is the exception, having reminded Trump of Washington's obligations under the Geneva Conventions.

site_title: Nintendo results underscore need for Switch console to succeed
summary: Nintendo reported a quarterly profit of 64.7 billion yen (S$811.4 million), exceeding analysts' average projection, thanks to a weaker yen and brisk holiday sales. However, revenue fell 21% and the company's 3DS handheld device sales are slowing. The new Switch console, set to launch in March, is crucial to Nintendo's success, with the company expecting to sell 2 million units by the end of March and analysts predicting 10-11 million units in the 12 months after that.

site_title: Ban Ki-moon says will not run for South Korea presidency
summary: Former UN Secretary-General Ban Ki-moon announced he will not run for South Korea's presidency, citing "slander" and "personality slaughter." Despite being widely expected to join the ruling party, Ban's support in public opinion polls declined rapidly due to corruption allegations against his relatives and a series of public gaffes. Ban, a career diplomat, never joined a South Korean political party but served as foreign minister under President Roh Moo-Hyun from 2004 to 2006. He withdrew from politics, saying his "pure patriotism and aspirations" had been damaged.

site_title: Brazil to let foreigners buy airlines, agricultural land
summary: Brazilian President Michel Temer plans to propose legislation to allow 100% foreign ownership of airlines and agricultural land, aiming to boost the economy. The airline bill will require foreign investors to expand regional flight services, while the agricultural land bill will require 10% of purchases to benefit landless farmers. Foreign companies can currently hold up to 20% stake in Brazilian airlines, with US carrier Delta Air Lines holding a 9.48% stake in Gol Linhas Aéreas. The move aims to attract investors to Brazil's struggling airline industry and expanding agribusiness sector.

site_title: ICA warns of fake website
summary: The Immigration and Checkpoints Authority (ICA) of Singapore warned the public to avoid a fake website (www.ica.sgov.asia) attempting to capture visa application and passport numbers. The ICA advised using the official website (www.ica.gov.sg) for all immigration matters, stating it takes a serious view of fake websites that undermine public trust. No data has been compromised, and a police report has been made. This is the ICA's first report of a fake website this year, following previous reports of similar sites in 2015 and 2016.

site_title: SembMarine's possible FLNG contract win fails to stir market
summary: Sembcorp Marine's potential billion-dollar liquefied natural gas plant contract did not significantly impact the market, despite being identified as a frontrunner by China-based Poly-GCL Petroleum Holdings. The company's order book is expected to receive a boost, but analysts also note possible impairment risks. UOB Kay Hian maintained its hold call on Sembcorp Marine, citing weaker earnings and potential impairment charges, with a target price of S$1.61.

site_title: US policy driving lobbyists indercover: 2 watchdog groups
summary: US lobbyists have decreased in transparency, with the lowest number of registered lobbyists in 18 years, according to watchdog groups. This drop is attributed to the practice of lobbyists working undercover, not a reduction in their numbers. The National Institute For Lobbying & Ethics calls for reforms to make more people register, proposing a change from spending 20% of time lobbying to 10 hours within a three-month window. The goal is to increase transparency and align with the standard that voters have a right to know who is influencing lawmakers.

images.alt_text: On Saturday, Mr Trump signed an executive order implementing a five-year ban on members of his administration working as lobbyists.

site_title: Bond markets set for a taste of the '60s as inflation rises
summary: Inflation is rising globally, with bond markets potentially mirroring the 1960s, a period of high inflation under US President Richard Nixon. Historian Paul Schmelzing notes that US bonds lost 36% in real price terms between 1965 and 1970, and annual consumer price inflation more than tripled to 5.9% from 1.6%. With inflation expectations rising, bond yields may double-digit losses, and a "perfect storm" for fixed income assets could occur, driven by steepening yield curves, sudden selloffs, and rising interest rates.

site_title: Five new members appointed to EDB board
summary: The Singapore Economic Development Board (EDB) has appointed five new board members, effective Wednesday, following the completion of terms by three existing members. The new board will have 15 members, with Dr. Beh Swan Gin continuing as chair. The Ministry of Trade and Industry (MTI) thanked the outgoing members for their contributions.

images.alt_text: Mr Loh Chin Hua, Chief Executive Officer of Keppel Corporation.The Ministry of Trade and Industry (MTI) on Tuesday announced the appointment of five new board members to the Singapore Economic Development Board (EDB).

site_title: Kuwaitis seek roots in upmarket tents under the stars
summary: Kuwaitis are embracing their Bedouin heritage by living in luxury tents under the stars for the winter months. The practice, inspired by their desert-dwelling ancestors, has become a popular activity among locals and foreigners, with over 20 camps set up across the country. The camps offer modern amenities, including TVs, kitchens, and running water, and can cost upwards of $463 per day. Many Kuwaitis see this as a way to reconnect with their roots and enjoy a unique desert experience, with some even commuting to their offices each morning.

images.alt_text: Men watching TV, playing games and drinking tea at a tent in a winter camp in al-Julaia.

site_title: Fitbit cutting 6% of workforce
summary: Fitbit is cutting 110 jobs, or 6% of its workforce, amid declining demand for its fitness trackers. The company expects to report fourth-quarter results that will not meet analysts' estimates, with revenue of $572-580 million. Fitbit forecasts 2017 revenue of $1.5-1.7 billion, down from analysts' estimates of $2.38 billion. The company's shares have fallen 14% to $6.17, the lowest intraday price ever. Fitbit plans to diversify its revenue stream through new smartwatch products and acquisitions, but faces a challenging year ahead.

site_title: STI one of Asia's top performers so far this year
summary: Singapore stocks retreated on January 31, despite a 4% monthly gain in January, following a decline in the US Dow Jones this week. The Straits Times Index (STI) ended the month with a 5.8% gain, outpacing other Asian markets. Analysts attributed the strong performance to expectations of higher US growth and rising interest rates, as well as favorable corporate earnings and crude oil prices. However, investors may take profits in February, with Q4 earnings reports and the US Federal Open Market Committee meeting to be closely watched.

images.alt_text: Singapore stocks chalked up handsome gains through January, but pulled back on the last day of the month as the Trump trade turned into a Trump rout.

site_title: Dollar heads for worst January in a decade
summary: The dollar is on track for its worst January in over a decade, following comments by President Trump's trade adviser, Peter Navarro, that Germany's currency is "grossly undervalued." This drove the euro 0.6% higher and sparked a broader decline in the dollar, which has fallen 1% this week against the yen. The dollar's decline is attributed to concerns over the new administration's trade policies and a push to encourage repatriation of corporate capital to the US.

site_title: Quotation of taxable book-entry Singapore Government Bonds
summary: Singapore Government Bonds quotation: The Singapore Government Bonds quotation is not mentioned in the provided articles. NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer was 9.8 times oversubscribed, while companies such as Creative Technology and DBS are discussing their financial outlook. Indonesia detained a Trafigura employee in a graft case, and MAS and PBOC are planning to deepen cooperation in green and transition finance. Singapore stocks experienced a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data, with OCBC's incoming CEO, Tan Teck Long, set to take the reins.

site_title: A former Goldman employee's long, strange legal odyssey
summary: A former Goldman Sachs programmer, Sergey Aleynikov, has been embroiled in a long and complex legal battle since his arrest in 2009 for stealing confidential source code. Despite multiple convictions and appeals, Aleynikov continues to face charges, including a recent reinstatement of his 2015 state court conviction. The case has raised questions about the interpretation of statutes and the application of laws to digital information. Aleynikov has also pursued claims against Goldman Sachs for unpaid legal fees and the FBI for alleged malicious prosecution, with an appeal to the New York Court of Appeals pending.

site_title: Dropbox targets deep-pocketed businesses to increase revenue
summary: Dropbox has unveiled two new products, file sync and content collaboration tools, to expand its offerings and boost revenue. The company, now 10 years old, aims to become a business-focused company and has seen a surge in business accounts, with 200,000 of its 500 million users paying customers. Dropbox expects to surpass $1 billion in annual revenue, surpassing its current valuation of $10 billion. The company's CEO, Drew Houston, says the new products are part of a years-long effort to build up its business offerings.

site_title: US airlines tumble amid fear Trump travel ban will spread
summary: US airlines plummeted 4.3% in the largest intraday drop in three months due to concerns over President Donald Trump's travel ban from seven predominantly Muslim nations. Analysts fear the ban could lead to more restrictions on flights and retaliation from other nations. The Bloomberg US Airlines Index fell, with American Airlines Group Inc dropping 6.6% and Delta Air Lines experiencing a computer failure that canceled flights. Despite concerns, some analysts believe the impact will be limited, and demand for travel may not be significantly affected.

site_title: Toyota, Target, Best Buy among giants mounting campaign against import tax
summary: Major US companies, including Toyota, Target, and Best Buy, are urging lawmakers to reconsider a proposed 20% tax on imported goods, citing potential harm to consumers, profits, and jobs. The companies claim the tax would increase costs for consumers, leading to decreased demand and job losses. Industry groups, including the American International Automobile Dealers Association, are also opposing the proposal, which they say would disproportionately affect US businesses. The move comes as President Trump considers a "big border tax" on Mexican imports to fund a wall.

site_title: Big changes underway in bunker business
summary: Singapore leads the world in regulating the marine fuel business, with the Maritime and Port Authority of Singapore (MPA) issuing 51 bunker survey licences and mandating the use of approved mass flow meter systems for bunker deliveries. The MPA aims to raise standards and improve service quality, but experts predict increased competition and low margins for physical bunker suppliers, potentially leading to rationalisation and consolidation in the industry.

site_title: UK asylum seekers housing is vermin-infested
summary: UK lawmakers have criticized the country's asylum seeker housing, citing vermin infestations, dirty conditions, and inadequate support. A report by the Home Affairs Committee found that some accommodations provided to asylum seekers are "a disgrace," with children living in infested conditions and pregnant women and rape victims lacking support. The committee urges the Home Office to improve standards, inspect accommodations regularly, and ensure adequate funding. The Home Office claims it is committed to providing safe and secure accommodation, but critics say the current system is unacceptable.

site_title: Tokyo smokers face tighter rules ahead of 2020 Olympics
summary: Tokyo is set to become smoke-free by the time it hosts the 2020 Summer Olympics, with the International Olympic Committee requiring "tobacco-free" games. Japan's health minister aims to submit a bill to parliament to ban smoking in public places, despite opposition from restaurant management organizations. Smoking rates have fallen in Japan due to increased health awareness and higher cigarette prices, but the country still struggles with passive smoking, with 30% of men and 7.9% of women smoking. The health minister prioritizes the health impact, calling Japan's current measures "among the world's worst."

site_title: US-UK trade key to making relations great again
summary: UK Prime Minister Theresa May met with US President Donald Trump, marking a new chapter in the "special relationship". The two leaders discussed a potential US-UK trade treaty, with both wanting a constructive partnership. The meeting aimed to build on demographics, religion, culture, law, politics, and economics. A trade deal could be a boon for Trump, while a win for May's post-Brexit ambitions. However, areas of potential disagreement, such as tariffs and financial regulations, lie ahead, and Trump's "America First" policy may impact UK interests.

site_title: US visa row throws spanner in the works for Iran's investment drive and aircraft deals
summary: US visa bans may further weaken Iran's efforts to attract foreign investors, particularly for deals on Western aircraft, amid hardening rhetoric in Tehran and Washington. The US administration of President Donald Trump can veto the sale of planes to Iran due to widespread US parts used in the aircraft, and European banks are reluctant to finance deliveries due to fear of backlash against their US operations. Iran's President Hassan Rouhani's efforts to boost the economy have been hindered by uncertainty, with foreign investors wary of working with Iran due to US punishments.

site_title: Commodities broker OTC Global Holdings opens Singapore office
summary: OTC Global Holdings, the world's largest independent institutional commodities broker, has opened a new office in Singapore to expand its market share in the Asian market. The office will replicate its North American and European offerings, broking European and Asian crude swaps, distillate swaps, and physical fuel broking. Led by Neil Grierson, the office aims to strengthen its position in the competitive Singapore oil swaps market, leveraging its unique competitive advantage.

site_title: UK economy looks robust, but Brexit storm will hit
summary: The UK economy appears robust despite Brexit concerns, with a 1% expansion in the second half of 2016. Household spending and consumer confidence drove this growth, as well as car sales and forward purchases of big-ticket items. However, business confidence suggests firms are optimistic about the impact of Brexit, and real-wage growth is expected to stagnate due to rising import prices. The UK's departure from the EU's single market and customs union may lead to economic damage, including a decline in exports, investment, and skilled workers, ultimately affecting living standards.

site_title: Tech firms meet on legal challenge to Trump immigration order
summary: Tech companies, including Google, Airbnb, and Netflix, are set to meet to discuss filing an amicus brief in support of a lawsuit challenging US President Donald Trump's immigration order restricting immigration from seven Muslim-majority countries. The industry is opposed to the ban, citing its impact on talent and business. If they decide to file, it would be the clearest corporate opposition to the ban, following declarations by Amazon and Expedia. The tech companies aim to provide arguments or information to the judge in support of the lawsuit.

site_title: Singapore gaming revenues likely flat in 2017: Fitch
summary: Singapore's total gambling revenues are expected to remain flat at around US$4 billion in 2017 due to a weak high-roller segment, despite a 12.5% gain in Chinese visitors. The two integrated resorts, Marina Bay Sands and Resorts World Sentosa, face heightened competition from regional casinos. Fitch Ratings notes that a few positives include a low gaming tax rate and a duopoly structure, but also highlights risks such as limited expansion and a high reliance on high-rollers.

site_title: Bolstering Singapore's fintech capabilities in Budget 2017
summary: Singapore's government has bolstered the country's fintech capabilities in the 2017 budget, aiming to keep the fintech ecosystem vibrant. The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has set up a regulatory sandbox framework, organized the Singapore FinTech Festival, and launched the FinTech Office to develop the sector. The government has also committed $225 million in funding over five years to attract financial institutions to set up innovation labs. To maintain its position as a top fintech hub, Singapore needs to attract new technologies, talent, and promote the sharing of risks and rewards between corporates and fintech players.

site_title: EU urged to put curbs on lawmakers taking lobbying jobs
summary: Transparency International urges the EU to restrict lawmakers from taking lobbying jobs immediately after leaving office, citing concerns over conflicts of interest. At least 171 out of 485 departing MEPs found new jobs outside public service, with nearly a third working for EU-registered lobbyists. The group recommends extending "cooling off" periods and establishing a powerful ethics supervisor to prevent scandals. EU Commission President Jean-Claude Juncker proposes extending approval periods for former officials, but Transparency International calls for more stringent measures to address the issue.

site_title: In Yates versus Trump, the Constitution wins
summary: US President Donald Trump's firing of Acting Attorney General Sally Yates on January 31, 2017, was deemed a "Monday night massacre" by the media, mirroring the infamous firing of special prosecutor Archibald Cox by President Richard Nixon in 1973. Trump's action was seen as a self-destructive move, revealing a president who believes he can circumvent government institutions. Yates' defiant public statement asserting the lawfulness of the executive order sparked a confrontation, highlighting the tension between the president's authority and the institution's commitment to the rule of law.

site_title: Snap selects New York Stock Exchange for IPO: source
summary: Snap Inc, the owner of Snapchat, has chosen the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) for its initial public offering (IPO), reportedly aiming for a valuation of $25 billion. This decision comes after Nasdaq Inc, which had also vied to host the listing, and represents a shift in favor of NYSE, which has previously won high-profile tech IPOs, including Twitter's 2013 listing. The NYSE's prestige and lower annual fees may help it land more business in the coming years.

site_title: German carmakers resigned to post-Brexit tariffs, say auto execs
summary: German car executives have resigned to post-Brexit tariffs, citing the potential costs and complications for the industry. BMW, GM, and Ford, which have UK plants, fear trade barriers would bring large costs, with tariffs of up to 10% on complete vehicles and 3.7% on components. Chancellor Angela Merkel's stance on EU control over immigration has also led to concerns that the UK's departure could lead to further EU fragmentation. Industry leaders warn of costly supply-chain upheaval and potential impact on consumer prices.

site_title: Trump's first week: is there a method in the madness?
summary: President Trump's first week in office has sparked controversy and raised concerns among Washington's educated and liberal elite. Despite initial skepticism about his campaign strategy, Trump's policies, including a travel ban on certain Muslim countries, a wall on the US-Mexico border, and executive orders on refugees and the Keystone XL pipeline, have been met with criticism from world leaders and international allies. The move has led to a perception that Trump is disregarding traditional diplomatic channels and creating chaos at the White House, with many predicting growing tensions between the administration and Congress and the media.

site_title: US travellers with nut allergies clash with airlines
summary: US travelers with severe nut allergies are facing increased tensions with airlines over the serving of peanuts on flights. Despite some airlines, like Jet Blue and Southwest, taking steps to accommodate passengers with allergies, many families with severe nut allergies are being removed from flights after inquiring about nut serving policies. The US Department of Transportation is investigating complaints against American Airlines, which has a policy of not allowing passengers to preboard to clean seats and tray tables due to nut allergies. The issue highlights inconsistent enforcement of airline policies and the need for clearer guidelines for passengers with severe food allergies.

site_title: JLL argues for a new property tax in place of ABSD
summary: Real estate consultancy JLL has proposed replacing Singapore's additional buyer's stamp duty (ABSD) with an annual property tax on non-owner occupied units. The "property tax" would be over the current property tax. However, other analysts argue removing ABSD would increase market volatility due to the presence of "hot money" on the sidelines. The proposal comes ahead of Budget 2017, which may influence the government's decision on the country's property tax regime.

site_title: Private equity firms muscle into Constellation Software's backyard
summary: Constellation Software, Canada's largest software company, has been struggling to maintain its rapid growth. The company, which has built its empire by acquiring vulnerable tech startups, has lost an $80 million acquisition to a US private equity fund. Analysts believe the company's size has made it less equipped to deal with nimbler competitors, and the roll-up model is losing credibility. Constellation is trying to adapt by forming a joint venture with a Japanese software investor, but the company's decline is raising concerns about its ability to compete with new rivals.

site_title: Under Armour debuts 'Made in the US' gear
summary: Under Armour launched its 'Made in the US' gear on Monday, marking a significant shift in the company's manufacturing strategy. The debut products, a black sports bra and matching leggings, were designed and produced in the US, a milestone in the company's efforts to reduce its reliance on China. This move comes as the US shoe industry faces tariffs and supply chain disruptions. The launch is seen as a strategic move to reposition Under Armour as a domestic brand.

images.alt_text: An Under Armour Inc store in Chicago. The firm's experiment might end up drawing particularly close observation from retailers and Washington alike to see if it can be a blueprint for similar initiatives.

site_title: Rio Tinto unit born in Death Valley retooled for lithium battery boom
summary: Rio Tinto's Serbian lithium deposit, Jadar, is poised to supply about 10% of global demand for lithium, a key component in electric car batteries and mobile devices. The project, which began in 1872 as a borates mining operation, could triple sales to $6 billion annually by 2025 and make Rio a top-three lithium producer. The deposit's unique combination of borates and lithium, known as jadarite, is also expected to provide a low-cost supply of borates, which have expanded their uses beyond laundry soap.

site_title: Walgreens, Rite Aid cut merger deal price, may sell more stores
summary: Walgreens and Rite Aid have cut the price of their proposed merger from $9.4 billion to $6.84 billion to $7.37 billion, down from $9 a share. The deal now includes a 1,200-store divestment requirement to gain regulatory approval. Walgreens will pay $6.50 to $7 a share for Rite Aid, and the company no longer expects a benefit from the acquisition in its fiscal year. The deal has been extended to July 31, and the companies may sell more stores to clear regulatory hurdles.

site_title: Bishan DBSS flat sold for record S$1.18m
summary: A five-room flat at Natura Loft, an HDB Design, Build and Sell Scheme project in Bishan, was sold for a record S$1.18 million, or S$914 per square foot, making it the third HDB resale transaction in 2017 to cross a million dollars. This record price is seen as contradictory to calls to relax residential cooling measures, and may be attributed to the flat's high floor, spacious layout, and proximity to amenities. Resale prices have risen for the second year in a row, with 20,813 transactions in 2016, the highest in four years.

images.alt_text: Resale volume for HDB flats rose for the second year in a row - by 7.8 per cent in 2016 to 20,813 transactions, according to official data. The pick-up in volume, which was the highest in four years, could be attributed to the gradually stabilising prices. Resale prices last year stayed flat, falling slightly by 0.1 per cent from the year before.

site_title: Microsoft sells US$17b in second bond deal in six months
summary: Microsoft sold $17 billion in bonds in its second multibillion-dollar offering in six months, with ample demand and lower borrowing rates. The company received at least twice as many orders as bonds to sell, and refinanced debt maturing soon. Microsoft plans to use the proceeds to refinance commercial paper sold to support its LinkedIn takeover. The move comes amid uncertainty over a potential repatriation tax holiday for US corporations, with Moody's Investors Service maintaining a negative outlook on Microsoft's debt.

site_title: US Chamber of Commerce borrows from Trump's populist playbook
summary: The US Chamber of Commerce, led by CEO Diana Conley, has taken a populist approach similar to President Trump's by launching a nationwide "listening tour" to gather the views of small business owners. This move comes after the chamber previously criticized Trump. The chamber's efforts are seen as a way to improve its relationship with the new President.

images.alt_text: Tom Donohue, one of the most influential men in Washington, had been critical of Mr Trump before the election.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Brokers from BS Group Research and CBC Investment Research have maintained their "buy" ratings on Mapletree Greater China Commercial Trust and Sembcorp Industries, respectively, citing the strength of their core assets and attractive yields. BS Group Research expects MAGIC's portfolio to shine through despite headwinds, while CBC Investment Research remains positive on Sembcorp Industries due to its long-term prospects and efficient power plants.

site_title: Trump trade to reverse by mid-year: HSBC strategist
summary: HSBC's Asia-Pacific equity strategy head, Herald van der Linde, predicts that the "Trump trade" will reverse by mid-year due to structural issues and debt-laden global economy. He expects US bond yields to hit 2016 lows, with yields predicted to be 1.35% by the end of the year. Van der Linde attributes the current euphoria to unrealistic expectations of Trump's policy, which he believes won't generate growth as expected, leading to a shift from equities to bonds and a potential rotation into emerging markets.

site_title: India says cash ban hits growth; lowers forecast
summary: India's government lowered its economic growth forecast to 7.1% for the 2016-17 fiscal year, citing the negative impact of demonetization, which removed high-value bank notes from circulation. The move has hit sectors like real estate and farming, but could boost tax revenues in the long run. The government expects cash supplies to be replenished by the end of March, with growth projected to revert to normal in 2017-18.

site_title: 'America First' doctrine would change geopolitical map
summary: US President Donald Trump's "America First" doctrine is shifting the global geopolitical landscape, with traditional allies reassessing their relationships. China is capitalizing on the void, offering itself as a champion of global engagement and investing heavily in Europe. Trump's trade policies, including tariffs on Mexican and Chinese imports, are provoking a potential trade war that could damage global growth and eliminate jobs. Allies are looking to China as a new source of trade and investment, while experts warn of severe economic damage if the US ruptures its trade relationships with China and Mexico.

site_title: South Korea, US defence chiefs back deployment of anti-missile system
summary: South Korea's defense chief and US Defense Secretary James Mattis reaffirmed plans to deploy a US anti-missile system, known as Thaad, this year despite protests from China. The move aims to counter growing threats from North Korea, which has been conducting atomic and missile tests. Mattis and his South Korean counterpart, Han Min-Koo, agreed on the need to push ahead with the deployment, citing concerns over North Korea's potential armed provocations. The deployment plan has been met with opposition from China and some South Korean politicians, but Mattis and Han vowed to proceed with the plan.

site_title: Japan's 'unresolved' disaster sways atomic opposition icon
summary: Japan's former gubernatorial candidate Ryuichi Yoneyama, a doctor and native of Niigata, has shifted his stance on nuclear power after the 2011 Fukushima Dai-Ichi disaster. Yoneyama, who previously supported nuclear power, now opposes the restart of the Kashiwazaki-Kariwa plant in Niigata due to concerns over the disaster's unresolved issues. He plans to investigate the events leading to the triple meltdown and won't support the plant's restart until an investigation is complete. Yoneyama's position is seen as a significant shift in the country's nuclear policy, with the government aiming to increase nuclear power's share in the energy mix to 22% by 2030.

site_title: Philippine central bank contenders pledge stronger monetary tools
summary: Philippine central bank contenders, Deputy Governors Nestor Espenilla and Diwa Guinigundo, pledge to strengthen monetary tools to address global uncertainties and assess financial market risks. They advocate for sharper surveillance and analysis of economic and financial variables, including data on household and corporate debt, and enhancing monitoring of funds flow. They also propose easing foreign exchange rules and phasing out high reserve requirements for banks to reduce black market trades and promote financial market structural reforms.

site_title: Bank lending ends 2016 with 2.9% gain in December
summary: Singapore bank lending ended 2016 with a 2.9% gain in December, driven by a 16.9% year-on-year jump in lending to financial firms. Business lending, particularly to the construction sector, contributed to the growth, reversing a contraction in November. Consumer loans also rose, with housing loans increasing 4% in December. This growth marks the first increase in business lending since February 2015 and follows consecutive contractions from October 2015 to September 2016.

images.alt_text: A last burst in bank lending in the final month of 2016 led to a 2.9 per cent growth in December from a year ago, higher than the 1.1 per cent registered in November, preliminary data from the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) on Tuesday showed.

site_title: The day Harvard stopped being a hedge fund
summary: Harvard Management Co, the endowment manager of Harvard University, has announced significant changes in response to its $2 billion loss last year. The company is cutting half of its 230 employees and outsourcing the management of most of its $37 billion portfolio. The moves are seen as a shift towards a simpler and cheaper approach, following the advice of investing luminaries such as Charles Ellis and Jack Bogle. The changes also reflect a broader trend among endowments and pension funds to re-evaluate alternative investments and avoid costly hubris.

site_title: At 74, Court still outspoken about her prowess
summary: Margaret Court, 74, remains outspoken about her record 24 Grand Slam singles titles from 1960 to 1973, with Serena Williams closing in on her mark. Court believes Williams deserves to break her record and has praised her serve, but also thinks the modern game is less exciting. The Australian tennis legend is also unafraid to speak her mind on social issues, including her opposition to homosexuality, which has led to controversy in the tennis world. As Williams continues to chase Court's record, the tennis world is divided between appreciating the past and embracing the present.

site_title: US police use DNA to solve murder after 41 years
summary: The Los Angeles County Sheriff's Department has solved a 41-year-old murder case using DNA technology. Karen Klaas, the 32-year-old ex-wife of singer Bill Medley, was strangled and sexually assaulted in 1976. After nearly four decades, investigators identified her killer as Kenneth Troyer, a man who escaped from prison in 1982 and was later shot and killed by police. The breakthrough came after a familial DNA search was conducted last year, which matched Troyer's DNA with that of a relative. The case is the second in the US to be solved using familial DNA, and officials say it will be used as a model for solving other cold cases.

site_title: Japanese duo warn of impairments on stakes in Emas Chiyoda Subsea
summary: Japanese companies Chiyoda Corp and NYK Line have issued warnings of one-time writedowns against their stakes in Emas Chiyoda Subsea (ECS), a joint venture with Singapore-listed Ezra Holdings. NYK Line reported an extraordinary loss of about 13 billion yen due to a reassessment of its stockholdings in ECS. Chiyoda expects a downward revision to its fiscal year forecast due to a downgrading of its 35% stake in ECS, with estimated total risk exposure of 38 billion yen.

site_title: BOJ meets ahead of potential currency market friction
summary: The Bank of Japan (BOJ) maintained its monetary policy stable, keeping interest rates and inflation forecasts unchanged, amid concerns of potential currency market friction triggered by US President Donald Trump's policies. The BOJ governor, Haruhiko Kuroda, emphasized that the central bank's policy is focused on achieving 2% annual inflation by 2019, and not directly targeting currency rates. Analysts predict upward pressure on the dollar, potentially heightening the perception of Japan manipulating its currency, but Kuroda downplayed this risk. The BOJ also extended its loan programs to boost lending to industries with growth potential.

images.alt_text: "We do not directly target currency rates in guiding monetary policy," said Mr Kuroda.

site_title: Citi plans to exit mortgage servicing by end of 2018
summary: Citigroup plans to exit its mortgage-servicing business by the end of 2018, selling its servicing rights to New Residential Investment Corp for $950 million. The deal, expected to be completed in the first half of 2017, aims to simplify operations, reduce expenses, and improve returns on capital. This move follows Citigroup's agreement to pay $28.8 million to settle allegations of misleading borrowers and its decline in mortgage-servicing rights from $6.5 billion in 2009 to $1.6 billion last year.

site_title: India unveils budget for recovery after cash crunch
summary: India's Finance Minister Arun Jaitley unveiled the country's budget, highlighting the economy's resilience despite a cash crunch caused by Prime Minister Narendra Modi's high-value banknote scrapping. The government expects the cash crunch to be fully cleared by April. A private manufacturing survey showed business is returning to normal, indicating the worst of the impact is wearing off. Jaitley described India as a "bright spot" in the world economy, and the country is seen as an engine of global growth.

site_title: India's affordable housing plan won't fix homelessness: campaigners
summary: India's government aims to provide housing for all by 2022, but campaigners say the affordable housing plan won't fix homelessness. Despite subsidies and incentives, only 2,776 houses were built in urban areas from 2015-2016, while evictions left thousands homeless. Advocates argue that cheaper loans won't solve the issue, and more allocations for homeless shelters and social rental housing are needed. The federal scheme aims to create 20 million urban and 30 million rural homes, but experts expect the pace of implementation to be slow, and India's social sector spending lags behind other developing nations.

site_title: Hackers use new tactic at Austrian hotel: locking the doors
summary: Hackers at a fully booked Austrian hotel, the Romantik Seehotel Jaegerwirt, locked out guests by infiltrating the hotel's electronic key system, causing panic and confusion. The hackers demanded a ransom of 2 bitcoins ($1,800) to unlock the system, and the hotel eventually paid the ransom to avoid further inconvenience. This attack is believed to be a novel example of ransomware, a type of software that encrypts files and demands a ransom in exchange for the decryption key.

site_title: China not ready to displace US as global leader
summary: China's leader Xi Jinping has stated that the country is not ready to displace the US as the global leader, despite China's growing economic power. China has become the world's second-largest economy and has launched its first aircraft carrier and overseas military base, but it prefers to focus on "responsibility" rather than "leadership". The US has taken a protectionist course under President Trump, which China sees as creating a vacuum that China is not yet ready to fill. China is willing to continue to promote globalisation, but it is not interested in replacing the US as the world leader.

site_title: US college endowments lose 1.9% in worst showing since 2009
summary: US college endowments suffered a 1.9% loss in 2016-2017, the largest decline since the 2008-2009 financial crisis, due to global stock, hedge fund, and natural resource losses. The 10-year average return fell to 5% below expected median returns of 7.4%. Despite this, 74% of respondents increased spending from their endowments, with an average rate of 4.3%. Weaker schools were affected by larger allocations to riskier investments, including hedge funds.

site_title: UOB Kay Hian sees 36% fall in SIA Q3 net profit, 2-4% rise for SATS (Amended)
summary: UOB Kay Hian forecasts Singapore Airlines' Q3 net profit to decline 36% due to weakened passenger loads on Southwest Pacific and Europe routes, despite a 4.8% year-on-year increase in passenger throughput at Changi Airport. In contrast, groundhandler SATS is expected to see a 2-4% year-on-year rise in net profit. Higher staff costs are also forecasted to lower SATS' profit before tax by 3.5%. Analysts note that SIA's competitiveness may be at risk, but competition from Middle Eastern airlines may abate, and associated companies' losses may narrow.

site_title: Companies tell staff to stay put in the US after Trump ban triggers chaos at airports
summary: US President Donald Trump's travel ban has triggered chaos for companies with staff from predominantly Muslim nations, causing employees to cancel international travel plans. The 90-day ban affects citizens from Iran, Iraq, Libya, Somalia, Sudan, Syria, and Yemen, with some companies identifying affected employees and advising them not to travel. Companies such as Deloitte, McKinsey, and Google have issued warnings, with Google extending the no-foreign-travel recommendation to permanent-resident employees and those with dual citizenship. The ban has also affected dual citizens, with some altering travel plans due to uncertainty over border checks.

site_title: Australian firms' sales, profits up sharply in Dec: poll
