summary: Australian businesses reported a sharp increase in sales and profits in December, with a 5-point jump in the National Australia Bank's business conditions index to +11, its highest level since mid-2016. Sales doubled to +20 and profits rose eight points to +14, driven by a five-point rise in forward orders and steady employment. However, Riki Polygenis, NAB's head of economics, cautioned that the rebound might be temporary, citing a slowdown in the economy that could lead to two more interest rate cuts in 2017.

site_title: New buildings, rent increases lift Ascendas India Trust's Q3 DPU
summary: Ascendas India Trust reported a 5% increase in distribution per unit (DPU) to 1.42 Singapore cents for the third quarter of 2016, driven by new building acquisitions and rental increases. Total property income rose 5% to S$39.3 million, while net property income rose 7% to S$26.4 million. Occupancy remained at 97%, with the newly acquired CyberVale 3 at 61% occupancy. The trust is developing a new building in Hyderabad and expects to acquire a forward purchase of an IT special economic zone in Pune.

site_title: Philippines narcotics agency takes over drugs war after Duterte slams police
summary: The Philippines' President Rodrigo Duterte has transferred the lead role of the country's anti-narcotics agency to the Philippine Drugs Enforcement Agency (PDEA) after criticizing the national police for corruption and taking them off the job. Over 7,600 people have been killed in the war on drugs since Duterte took office, with many disputed circumstances surrounding the killings. The move comes after Duterte accused the police of being "corrupt to the core" and estimated 40% of the force were dishonest.

site_title: Deutsche to pay US$425m over Russian trades
summary: Deutsche Bank has agreed to pay $425 million to New York's banking regulator over a "mirror trading" scheme that moved $10 billion out of Russia between 2011 and 2015. The scheme involved clients buying stocks in Moscow and related parties selling the same stocks through Deutsche's London branch. The bank's deficient anti-money laundering controls and know-your-customer policies failed to detect and stop the scheme for years. Deutsche is also required to retain an independent monitor to review its compliance programs, and is cooperating with other regulators and law enforcement authorities with ongoing investigations.

site_title: US dollar drops after Trump adviser sees euro undervalued
summary: The US dollar dropped to a session low after Trump adviser Peter Navarro stated that the euro was "grossly undervalued," pushing the euro-dollar to a fresh high. This move led to a decline in the Bloomberg dollar index by approximately 0.4%, with foreign exchange flows favoring the euro and yen. The drop in the dollar's value is attributed to heightened uncertainty among US businesses following the Trump administration's immigration order and border wall spat with Mexico, potentially ending the "Trump reflation trade" in FX.

images.alt_text: The US dollar was holding near its session low after dropping quickly at the start of US trading after Trump adviser Peter Navarro called the euro "grossly undervalued," pushing euro-dollar to a fresh high while sending the greenback to new lows against the yen and other peers.

site_title: SAF begins checks on returned Terrex vehicles
summary: The Singapore Armed Forces (SAF) began inspecting nine returned Terrex infantry carrier vehicles on January 31, 2017, following their seizure by Hong Kong Customs on November 23. The vehicles, designed and made in Singapore, were on board a container ship operated by APL, which failed to provide proper permits. The inspection, led by Chief of Army Major-General Melvyn Ong, aims to ensure the serviceability and maintenance of the vehicles, which are expected to take a few days to complete.

site_title: Google employees rally in thousands against Trump immigration ban
summary: Thousands of Google employees, including CEO Sundar Pichai and co-founder Sergey Brin, protested against President Donald Trump's immigration ban, citing concerns over the impact on their own immigration status. Over 2,000 employees participated across multiple offices, with many expressing relief after a federal judge temporarily blocked the order. Google had initially advised some employees to return to the US, but later helped them after a court order was issued, highlighting the company's commitment to supporting its employees. The protest highlights rising tension between the tech industry and the Trump administration.

site_title: Japan ready to invest in the US: govt document
summary: Japan is planning to invest in the US, with a focus on creating US jobs and infrastructure development, according to a government document. Prime Minister Shinzo Abe is set to meet with President Donald Trump on February 10, with discussions centered on a two-way trade deal. The plan includes five areas, including infrastructure, and aims to create hundreds of thousands of jobs. Japanese automakers, such as Toyota and Honda, have already committed to investing in the US, with plans to create jobs and produce US-made products.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Jumbo Group's CEO Ang Kiam Meng is handing over the chairmanship to Tan Cher Liang to focus on growth. Ang will become executive director and group CEO, while Tan will be independent chairman. The move comes after Jumbo reported a 46.3% profit increase. Meanwhile, China Medical International Group appointed Albert Tan Tiong Heng as CFO, replacing Tan Kei Teck who is leaving for other opportunities.

site_title: US home prices increase faster than expected in November
summary: US single-family home prices rose 5.3% in November, exceeding expectations of a 5.1% increase. This is the fastest pace of growth since the survey began in 2009. Rising mortgage rates and potential economic growth may push prices higher. The S&P CoreLogic Case-Shiller composite index of 20 metropolitan areas also showed a 0.9% increase on a seasonally adjusted basis, outpacing expectations. This is the third consecutive month of year-over-year price gains, with prices rising twice as fast as inflation.

site_title: Trump expected to make supreme court pick from two finalists
summary: US President Donald Trump is set to announce his Supreme Court nomination, choosing between two finalists: Neil Gorsuch and Thomas Hardiman. Both judges are conservative Republican appointees with a decade-long record on the federal bench, and their selection would restore the court's ideological balance. Trump's announcement comes amid controversy over his travel ban and may lead to a showdown with congressional Democrats, who would need a super-majority vote to block the nomination.

site_title: Trumpism ruffles feathers in markets
summary: The Singapore stock market experienced a decline of 18.05 points, or 0.59%, on its first trading day after the Lunar New Year weekend, following a shaky start to the US markets due to President Donald Trump's immigration ban. The benchmark Straits Times Index (STI) closed at 3,046.80, with losers outnumbering gainers 215 to 192. Regional markets also fell, with Tokyo and Australia's markets closing down. Investors are cautious about the Trump administration's impact on the global economy, with geopolitical risks and uncertainty expected to prevail.

site_title: US: Stocks fall again; UPS, Under Armour plunge
summary: US stocks fell on Tuesday due to anxiety over the Trump administration's immigration and trade policies, as well as disappointing earnings reports from companies like UPS and Under Armour. The Dow Jones Industrial Average dropped 0.4%, while the S&P 500 lost 0.3% and the Nasdaq Composite Index shed 0.4%. Under Armour plummeted 24.8% after missing earnings expectations and announcing a CFO's departure, while UPS fell 6.6% after reporting a fourth-quarter loss. The decline was a continuation of Monday's action, which was sparked by President Trump's travel ban.

site_title: Pfizer quarterly profit misses estimates
summary: Pfizer Inc reported a lower-than-expected quarterly profit of $775 million, or 13 cents per share, due to lower demand for products set to go off patent. The company's revenue slipped 3% to $13.63 billion, missing analyst estimates. Despite this, Pfizer forecast adjusted profit of $2.50-$2.60 per share and revenue of $52-$54 billion in 2017, slightly above analyst expectations.

site_title: NWTO warns Trump immigration order could hurt US travel demand
summary: The US travel ban on citizens of seven Muslim-majority countries has raised concerns over its impact on US travel demand, according to the UN World Tourism Organization. The ban, implemented by President Trump, has led to widespread criticism and protests, with the UNWTO warning it may worsen security risks and affect the country's image among visitors worldwide. The travel industry has also urged the Trump administration to reconsider the ban, citing its significant contribution to the US economy. The ban has sparked a backlash in Asia, with companies seeking to capitalize on the restrictions.

site_title: Questions surround P99's valuation of former UE unit
summary: P99 Holdings is set to acquire UES Holdings, a Singapore-based environmental engineering firm, through a reverse takeover. The acquisition price of S$65 million is significantly higher than the S$16 million paid by United Engineers to Giant Maze Limited in September last year. The valuation of UESH has raised questions, with some suggesting that United Engineers may have undervalued the firm. An independent valuer will be appointed to assess the value of UESH, and if the result is lower than S$58.5 million, the consideration amount will be adjusted.

site_title: ExxonMobil Q4 earnings dive on low oil prices
summary: ExxonMobil reported a 39.6% drop in Q4 net income to $1.7 billion, largely due to low oil and natural gas prices. The company's full-year earnings fell by more than half to $7.8 billion. A $2 billion asset downgrade was recorded, mainly due to impairments in the Rocky Mountains region. Despite this, ExxonMobil's downstream business generated $1.2 billion in earnings, and chemicals earned $872 million. CEO Darren Woods attributed the results to the prolonged downturn in commodity prices and impairment charges.

site_title: Lufthansa, pilots await proposal from mediator in pay talks
summary: Lufthansa's pay talks with its pilots' union, Vereinigung Cockpit, have ended without a deal. The two sides held two weeks of talks led by mediator Gunter Pleuger, but failed to reach an agreement. The mediator will propose a solution by Feb 10, and the pilots will then discuss how to respond. Lufthansa pilots have been on strike 15 times since 2014 over pay and early retirement issues, costing the airline hundreds of millions of euros in lost profits. The pilots had requested a 3.7% annual pay increase over five years, while Lufthansa proposed a 4.4% increase in two instalments.

site_title: Equis expands into Australia with A$400m solar investment
summary: Equis Energy, Asia's largest independent renewable-energy developer and investor, has expanded into Australia with two solar projects costing A$400 million, totaling 200 megawatts of generation capacity. The projects will be among Australia's lowest-cost solar projects and will enable the use of large-scale battery-storage solutions. Equis has signed a power-purchase agreement to supply solar power to Snowy Hydro Limited for 22 years, providing stable power and reducing greenhouse gas emissions. The group plans to develop an additional 1,000 megawatt of large-scale solar projects in Australia.

site_title: Feb 6 is last day of trading for Aztech Group
summary: Aztech Group's shares on the Singapore Exchange (SGX) will be suspended from trading on Feb 7, 2017, after the final day of trading on Feb 6. The group's co-founder, Michael Mun Hong Yew, is voluntarily delisting the company through his special-purpose vehicle AVS Investments. An exit cash offer of 42 Singapore cents per share remains open until Feb 13, with 75.12% of the company's share capital accepted as of Jan 31.

site_title: Jumbo CEO relinquishes chairmanship to lead independent director
summary: Jumbo Group CEO Ang Kiam Meng is stepping down as chairman to focus on the company's growth, handing over the role to independent director Tan Cher Liang. Ang will remain as executive director and CEO. The change comes after Jumbo reported a 46.3% increase in 12-month profit to S$15.5 million in 2016. Tan, co-founder of Boardroom, will lead the board as independent chairman, marking a significant shift in the company's leadership.

site_title: UK finance hails new opportunities despite Brexit uncertainty
summary: UK finance officials say Brexit presents opportunities despite uncertainty. They advocate for a "mutual market access" trading deal with the EU, allowing financial firms to operate freely, rather than passporting rights. This would enable the UK to remain a leading financial centre globally. Industry officials believe new free trade deals and negotiations for market access will be key, with established markets being more lucrative opportunities. The UK government is urged to prioritize market access and regulatory flexibility to secure new business.

site_title: Trump to meet Novartis CEO, other pharma bosses on Tuesday
summary: US President Donald Trump will meet with Novartis CEO Joe Jimenez and other pharmaceutical executives at the White House on Tuesday. The meeting comes after Trump has accused drugmakers of "getting away with murder" on prices. Jimenez plans to discuss outcomes-based pricing models and replacing former President Barack Obama's Affordable Care Act. The meeting is part of Trump's efforts to roll back Obama's healthcare legislation and reduce medicine prices.

site_title: Tough trade weakens hand of UK retailers as refinancing looms
summary: UK retailers face significant challenges as a weakening pound and deteriorating credit outlooks threaten their ability to refinance debt. Matalan and House of Fraser have seen their credit ratings downgraded, with Matalan at high-yield territory and House of Fraser's outlook changed to negative. Retail sales have fallen at the fastest pace in almost five years, with import costs rising and shoppers' purchasing power under pressure, making refinancing a difficult task.

site_title: Employment costs in US rise less than forecast on benefits
summary: US employment costs rose 0.5% in the fourth quarter, less than forecast, driven by steady wage growth and the smallest advance in benefits in over a year. Wages and salaries increased 0.5% for the second consecutive quarter, while benefits costs eased to 0.4%. The labor market faces a shortage of qualified workers, and sustained wage growth could boost consumer spending and push inflation closer to the Federal Reserve's goal.

site_title: Opec achieves 82% of pledged oil output cut in January
summary: Opec has achieved 82% of its pledged oil output cut in January, surpassing expectations. The 11 Opec member countries agreed to cut their output by 1.20 million barrels per day to prop up oil prices and address a supply glut. According to a Reuters survey, the countries have cut output by 958,000 barrels per day, exceeding the 82% compliance target. This marks the first supply cut deal by Opec in eight years, implemented to stabilize the oil market.

images.alt_text: Opec's oil output is set to fall by more than one million barrels per day (bpd) this month, a Reuters survey found on Tuesday, pointing to a strong start by the exporter group in implementing its first supply cut deal in eight years.

site_title: India's economy to grow 6.75-7.5% in 2017/18: Newsrise
summary: India's economy is expected to grow 6.75-7.5% in the 2017/18 fiscal year, according to the finance ministry's Economic Survey. A high oil price exceeding $65 a barrel could negatively impact Asia's third-largest economy. The Economic Survey is set to be released ahead of Finance Minister Arun Jaitley's annual budget.

site_title: Deutsche Bank fined for US$10 billion sham Russian trades
summary: Deutsche Bank has agreed to pay a total of $10 billion for organizing sham trades that could have been used to launder money out of Russia. The bank was fined $630 million by US and British regulators for failing to properly monitor the trades, which involved buying and selling securities in a way that had no economic purpose. The scheme, which occurred between 2011 and 2015, could have been used to transfer over $10 billion out of Russia, and regulators criticized the bank for its lack of controls and oversight.

site_title: Citi reshuffles top bankers in client relationship focus
summary: Citi is reshuffling its top bankers to focus on client relationships, with several senior investment bankers moving to client-focused roles. David Head will lead the financial institutions group globally, while Brad Coleman will become chairman of global asset managers. Christian Anderson and Anthony Diamandakis will co-head global asset managers. The bank is also reorganizing its technology and media teams, combining them into a single "Communications Group" led by Gordon Kroft. Christina Mohr will become Vice Chairman to develop C-suite relationships. The changes take effect on Wednesday.

site_title: German unemployment falls to record low as economy gathers pace
summary: Germany's unemployment rate dropped to a record low of 5.9% in January, with 2.61 million people out of work. This marks the lowest level since reunification. Economists had forecast no change, but the actual decline was 26,000. The German economy expanded by 0.5% in the fourth quarter, indicating continued job creation momentum. This strengthens the euro area's recovery, where joblessness remains high and inflation is pushed up by energy prices.

site_title: Market capitalisation
summary: NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer was oversubscribed 9.8 times, exceeding expectations. US stocks opened lower due to fresh tariffs on Canada by the Trump administration. Creative Technology warned of potential revenue shortfall and similar operating loss in H2 compared to H1. London's Heathrow plans to increase fees for a £10 billion upgrade. Indonesia detained a Trafigura employee in a 285 trillion rupiah graft case. OCBC announced Tan Teck Long as its new CEO, replacing a former DBS veteran. MAS and PBOC will deepen cooperation in green and transition finance.

site_title: EU's Tusk says Trump administration statements 'worrying'
summary: EU chief Donald Tusk expressed concern over "worrying" statements from the Trump administration, labeling them as a threat to the bloc's unity. Tusk stated that the EU must take "spectacular steps" to stay together and capitalize on US isolationism to boost trade. The EU is facing threats from China, Russia, radical Islam, and the US administration, which is questioning 70 years of American foreign policy. EU leaders will discuss migration and the future of the bloc after Brexit at a summit in Malta.

site_title: Under Armour tumbles after fourth-quarter sales miss estimates
summary: Under Armour's fourth-quarter sales fell short of estimates, with revenue rising 12% to $1.31 billion, missing the average analyst forecast of $1.41 billion. The disappointing results reinforce doubts about the company's ability to maintain rapid growth, following a 30% drop in shares in 2016 and a class A share price decline of 18% in early trading. The stock's high short interest rate also suggests investor skepticism.

images.alt_text: Under Armour Inc tumbled in early trading after fourth-quarter sales missed analysts' estimates, reinforcing investors' doubts that the sports-apparel maker can maintain its rapid growth.

site_title: Canon profit hit by slower sales in emerging economies
summary: Canon's full-year profits declined by nearly a third due to slower sales in emerging economies, mainly caused by economic slowdowns in countries such as China and India. The camera and copy machine maker also faced challenges from a stronger yen, which reduced competitiveness abroad. Despite this, Canon forecasts a rebound in net profit for 2017, driven by increased demand for office equipment in the US and some emerging economies, with predicted sales growth of 17.6% to 4 trillion yen.

site_title: Nintendo nine-month profit soars on baseball sale
summary: Nintendo's nine-month net profit soared 153.9% to 102.97 billion yen due to a special gain from selling a stake in the Seattle Mariners baseball team. However, overall sales and operating profit declined 26.9% and 38.1%, respectively, due to struggling Wii U console sales. The company now focuses on the March release of the Nintendo Switch console to boost growth. A lower yen also contributed to a foreign exchange gain, but annual forecasts were revised downward, with operating profit forecasted at 20 billion yen and annual sales at 470 billion yen.

site_title: IndiGo owner posts record fall in quarterly net profit on high fuel costs
summary: InterGlobe Aviation, the owner of India's largest airline IndiGo, reported a record fall in quarterly net profit to 4.87 billion rupees due to high fuel costs. Fuel costs rose 43% to 16.71 billion rupees, mainly due to a 16% increase in global oil prices. Despite this, the company's total income from operations rose 16% to 49.86 billion rupees. IndiGo plans to increase its fleet to 133 aircraft by the end of March. The airline's available seat kilometre is expected to increase by 25% in the January-March quarter.

site_title: Japan eyes US job, investment initiative ahead of Abe-Trump summit
summary: Japan is preparing for a summit with US President Donald Trump, aiming to demonstrate its willingness to create US jobs and invest in the country. A proposed "US-Japan Growth and Employment Initiative" lists infrastructure and five other areas, including buying dollar-denominated infrastructure bonds. Japanese officials estimate several hundred thousand jobs could result from the initiative, which could also address Trump's concerns about unfair trade practices. The automotive trade is a key focus, with Trump seeking progress on a two-way trade deal.

site_title: Mastercard declines as revenue misses analysts' estimates
summary: Mastercard Inc reported fourth-quarter revenue that missed analysts' estimates, falling 2.8% to $106.20 per share. Revenue grew 9.5% to $2.76 billion, but operating expenses declined 1.2%. The company attributed revenue growth to rebates and incentives, but expects "low double-digit" revenue growth for the year. This follows American Express's 8.2% drop in fourth-quarter profit and Visa's upcoming earnings report.

images.alt_text: Mastercard Inc, the second-largest payments network, fell in early trading after fourth-quarter revenue missed analysts' estimates.

site_title: EU warns Iran not to 'deepen mistrust' with missile tests
summary: The European Union warned Iran against continuing ballistic missile tests, which could deepen mistrust between the two nations. The EU reiterated its concern over Iran's missile program, calling on Tehran to refrain from activities that could lead to increased tensions. The warning comes as the US requests emergency talks at the UN Security Council on Iran's recent missile test, amid ongoing tensions over the US's stance on the 2015 nuclear deal.

images.alt_text: The EU on Tuesday warned Iran against stoking mistrust by continuing ballistic missile tests, after Tehran told the new US administration not to use the issue as a pretext to create fresh tensions.

site_title: Fragrance sets up UK unit for Liverpool property purchase
summary: Fragrance Group has established a UK subsidiary, Fragrance UK-Liverpool, to acquire a property in Liverpool's city centre. The £1 million investment company aims to purchase a 4,570 sqm historical building with 11,494 sqm of floor area. The acquisition is not expected to significantly impact the company's net tangible assets or earnings per share for the 2017 financial year. Fragrance shares rose 0.4 Singapore cents to 17.5 cents apiece following the announcement.

site_title: Gold rises as Trump policy fuels safe-haven demand
summary: Gold prices surged 0.6% to $1,202.08 per ounce, reaching its highest in about a week, amid safe-haven demand following US President Donald Trump's tough stance on immigration. A weaker US dollar also supported bullion, while traders await the US Federal Reserve's two-day meeting for interest rate clues. Asian shares fell as investors took notice of Trump's travel ban, driving risk aversion and gold prices higher.

site_title: French growth picks up in 4th quarter
summary: France experienced modestly accelerating growth in the fourth quarter, with a 0.4% rise in gross domestic product. This brought 2016 growth to 1.1%, short of the government's target of 1.4%. Despite this, unemployment declined for the first time since 2007, and jobless numbers fell to 3.5 million. The government forecasts 1.5% growth for 2017, but economists are doubtful due to a stronger euro, higher oil prices, and likely interest rate rises.

site_title: India says cash ban hits growth
summary: India's government acknowledged the adverse impact of demonetization on the economy, lowering its growth forecast for 2016-17 to 7.1% from 7.6%. The move, which withdrew high-value bank notes from circulation, has led to job losses, reduced demand, and increased uncertainty. Despite initial queues, restrictions on cash withdrawals have eased, and the government expects cash supplies to be fully replenished by March. Growth is projected to return to 6.75-7.5% in 2017-18, with potential long-term benefits in reducing corruption and tax evasion.

site_title: Europe: Stock markets ahead at open
summary: Europe's main stock markets rose 0.1% at the start of trade on Tuesday, with the FTSE 100 reaching 7,128.39 points. The eurozone's DAX 30 index and Paris CAC 40 also edged higher, driven by gains in mining and healthcare sectors. US stocks continued their rally, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq reaching fresh records despite uncertainty over US-EU trade talks and tariffs.

site_title: Eurozone growth and inflation surge, adding to pressure on ECB
summary: The eurozone's economy experienced a surge in growth, inflation rose to 1.8%, and unemployment dipped to a 7-year low in December, exceeding forecasts. This solid growth data puts pressure on the European Central Bank to scale back its stimulus measures as it approaches its target inflation rate of below 2%. Despite this, the ECB's chief Mario Draghi is cautious, citing that the recovery is still too weak to create all the needed jobs. This news comes as the EU's Economic Affairs Commissioner Pierre Moscovici warned that the recovery is solid but still too weak.

site_title: Canon sees first profit gain in 3 years after medical unit acquisition
summary: Canon Inc has reported its first profit gain in three years, driven by earnings from a medical equipment unit it acquired from Toshiba Corp last year. The company forecasts a 11.4% increase in full-year operating profit to 255 billion yen (US$2.3 billion), as it diversifies its business amid declining demand for cameras and printers. The fourth-quarter operating profit fell 25.1% due to a strengthened yen following Britain's Brexit vote.

site_title: H&M profit surprise lifts shares, to review store mix
summary: H&M surprised investors with a 1% increase in quarterly profit, lifting shares to a one-month high. The company will review its store mix and invest more in e-commerce, with plans to open 430 new stores this year. H&M aims for 10-15% annual local-currency sales growth, including online sales, and expects to meet this target by the end of the year. The company is also expanding its online presence, with plans to roll out e-commerce in six more markets.

site_title: Fed likely to keep rates steady as it awaits Trump economic plan
summary: The US Federal Reserve is expected to keep interest rates steady on Wednesday, awaiting clearer details on President Donald Trump's economic policies. The Fed has expressed concerns over potential inflation due to Trump's infrastructure spending and tax cuts, but economists predict no rate increase this week. The central bank's decision comes a week after Chair Janet Yellen warned of a "nasty surprise" on inflation. Investors expect an interest rate rise in June, and the Fed's benchmark rate is currently between 0.50% and 0.75%.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close sharply lower
summary: Tokyo stocks closed sharply lower on Tuesday, tracking a global sell-off due to Donald Trump's immigration crackdown. The Nikkei 225 index fell 1.69% to 19,041.34, while the Topix index dropped 1.43% to 1,521.67. A stronger yen also hammered exporters, contributing to the decline.

site_title: Services sector's outlook gloomy for H1, manufacturers marginally upbeat
summary: Singapore's services sector expects a gloomy outlook for the first half of 2017, with 14% of firms anticipating worse business conditions compared to the second half of 2016. In contrast, manufacturers are marginally upbeat, with 2% expecting a better business situation in the first half. The electronics cluster was the most optimistic within the manufacturing sector.

site_title: Shell sells US$4.7b of fields as disposal push accelerated
summary: Royal Dutch Shell Plc sold US$4.7 billion of North Sea and Thai fields to reduce debt and meet disposal targets. The deal includes the sale of half its North Sea oil and gas assets to Chrysaor Holdings Ltd for US$3.8 billion and a stake in a Thai gas field to Kuwait Petroleum Corp for US$900 million. Shell aims to hit its $30 billion divestment program to maintain dividend payouts and stave off credit rating reviews. The company has US$78 billion of net debt and is seeking to simplify its portfolio following the acquisition of BG Group.

site_title: Trump fires acting US attorney general after she refuses to enforce immigration ban
summary: US President Donald Trump fired Acting US Attorney General Sally Yates after she refused to enforce his immigration ban. Yates had ordered Justice Department lawyers not to enforce the ban, citing concerns it was unlawful. Trump replaced her with Dana Boente, US attorney for the Eastern District of Virginia. Yates had expressed doubts about the executive order, which barred travellers from seven Muslim-majority nations.

site_title: So bad, they're good: Madrid celebrates worst movies ever
summary: Madrid's CutreCon trash film festival drew 3,500 attendees to celebrate the worst movies ever made, including the infamous Troll 2, which has a 6% rating on Rotten Tomatoes. The festival's popularity stems from nostalgia for low-quality VHS films, dissatisfaction with mainstream cinema, and a desire to laugh and let off steam. Researchers have identified two types of trash films: unintentionally bad and those deliberately made to be awful, with cult status often following. The festival's success highlights the appeal of "so bad they're good" cinema, where fans appreciate the irony and fun in watching intentionally terrible films.

site_title: US dollar slips amid Trump's hardening policy defence, yen benefits
summary: The US dollar slipped 0.2% to 113.570 yen against the Japanese currency, amid President Donald Trump's hardening defense of his immigration policies, including a temporary ban on refugees and people from seven Muslim-majority countries. The dollar's weakness was exacerbated by Trump's firing of Acting US Attorney General Sally Yates and the Bank of Japan's decision to maintain monetary policy unchanged. The euro and Australian dollar rose, while the New Zealand dollar remained flat, as investors sought safe-haven assets amidst rising tensions.

site_title: Hong Kong, Shanghai and Taipei markets closed for holidays
summary: Hong Kong, Shanghai, and Taipei financial markets are closed on Tuesday for public holidays. No trading or market updates are available.

site_title: Australia, NZ: Shares slip as Trump immigration policy dents confidence
summary: Australian and New Zealand shares fell on Tuesday, following a global selloff in equity markets after US President Donald Trump's immigration curbs. The S&P/ASX 200 index dropped 40.6 points, or 0.72%, to 5,620.9, while New Zealand's benchmark S&P/NZX 50 index fell 0.49% to 7,050.76. The losses were attributed to investor confidence dented by Trump's executive order, which barred Syrian refugees and suspended entry for citizens of seven countries, and lower oil prices.

site_title: EU set to meet green energy goal; UK trails: document
summary: The European Union is on track to meet its goal of renewable energy supplying 20% of its energy by 2020, according to a report by the European Commission. The EU's renewable energy accounted for 16.4% of overall consumption in 2015. However, Britain, Ireland, and Luxembourg are lagging behind. The EU aims to cut greenhouse gas emissions by 40% by 2030 and increase renewable energy to at least 27% by then. The EU has seen significant savings in fossil fuel imports, with an estimated 16 billion euros saved in 2015, and is seeking to decrease dependence on Russian energy imports.

site_title: Smoking costs US$1.4t in health care, labour loss: study
summary: A study by the World Health Organization and the American Cancer Society found that smoking costs the world economy over $1.4 trillion annually, with nearly 20% of healthcare spending attributed to the habit. The economic burden is particularly high in developing countries, where 40% of the costs are borne. The study estimates that diseases caused by smoking account for 12% of deaths among working-age adults aged 30-69. Implementing stronger tobacco control measures is crucial to addressing these costs and achieving the UN's Sustainable Development Goal to cut premature deaths by a third by 2030.

site_title: Thai Dec factory output up 0.54%, below forecast
summary: Thailand's industrial output rose 0.54% in December, below forecast, for a second consecutive month, driven by stronger demand for steel, electronics, and rubber. Industrial goods accounted for 80% of total exports, which increased 6.2% in December. This modest growth suggests the economic recovery remains fragile, with capacity utilization falling to 63.26%. The central bank has maintained forecasts for flat exports and 3.2% GDP growth for 2017.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Bank lending in Singapore rose 1.1% in December 2016, surpassing the 0.4% growth in November. The services sector expects worse business conditions for January to June 2017, with 14% of firms anticipating a decline. The Singapore Economic Development Board (EDB) welcomed five new board members, while Fitch Ratings predicts gaming revenues will remain flat at US$4 billion in 2017. The STI closed 18 points lower on its first trading day after the Chinese New Year weekend.

images.alt_text: Bank lending in Singapore rose 1.1 per cent in December 2016 from the month before, compared to the 0.4 per cent growth in November, preliminary data from the Monetary Authority of Singapore on Tuesday showed. The lift was mainly from stronger business lending.

site_title: Commodities broker OTC Global Holdings opens Singapore office
summary: Commodities broker OTC Global Holdings has opened a new office in Singapore as part of its expansion into the Asian market. The office, OTC Asia, will replicate the company's North American and European offerings, broking European and Asian crude swaps, distillate swaps, and physical fuel broking. The company plans to eventually expand into the US domestic grade crude swaps business from Singapore. Led by Neil Grierson, the office aims to strengthen its position in the competitive Singapore oil swaps market despite challenges posed by consolidation in the brokerage space.

site_title: Top government lawyer defies Trump on immigration order
summary: US Attorney General Sally Yates defied President Donald Trump's travel restrictions targeting seven Muslim-majority nations, stating she wasn't convinced the order was lawful. The Justice Department will not defend the order, citing its obligation to seek justice and stand for what is right. Trump's directive has led to chaos at airports, with federal judges blocking deportations and over 735 people being pulled aside for questioning. The US government faces international criticism, with allies expressing concern and protests erupting in cities worldwide.

site_title: Mexico sees signs of US change on wall payment
summary: Mexico's top official says US President Donald Trump is taking a more flexible view on how to pay for the planned border wall, with meetings between officials possibly taking place soon. Trump wants Mexico to pay for the wall, but Mexico has refused. Recent phone calls between Trump and Mexican President Enrique Pena Nieto have eased tensions, with Videgaray expressing confidence that the White House is modifying its view on wall payment.

images.alt_text: A border patrol agent driving along the US- Mexico border crossing on Jan 26, 2017.There are signs the US government is taking a more flexible view of how to pay for its planned border wall with Mexico, and new meetings to craft future bilateral relations could take place soon, a top Mexican official said on Monday.

site_title: Cathay Pacific to cut emissions with switch to biofuel
summary: Cathay Pacific plans to switch to biofuels made from landfill rubbish on select long-haul flights, aiming to cut emissions by 80% starting in 2019. The airline will use a combination of conventional jet fuel and biofuels on flights from the US to Hong Kong. Cathay has invested in sustainable biofuel developer Fulcrum BioEnergy and hopes to reduce its carbon footprint. This move comes as the airline faces volatile oil prices and hedging losses.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong flag carrier Cathay Pacific will switch to biofuels made from landfill rubbish on select long haul flights, reports said Tuesday, in an effort to cut harmful emissions.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open flat on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened flat on Tuesday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index up 0.160 points to 1686.450. Trading volume was 25.94 million lots worth RM6.08 million. Losers outnumbered gainers 44 to 42.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open lower on Trump immigration woe
summary: Tokyo stocks opened lower on January 31, 2017, following global market volatility due to the Trump administration's immigration crackdown. The Nikkei 225 fell 1.16% to 19,143.23, and the Topix index declined 1.14% to 1,526.14. The market reaction was a result of concerns about potential economic impacts and trade tensions.

site_title: Indonesia VP says Trump's policy can raise "suspicion" toward Muslims: media
summary: Indonesia's Vice President Jusuf Kalla stated that US President Donald Trump's immigration policy can raise "suspicion" toward Muslims, particularly given Indonesia's large Muslim population. The policy, which bans refugees from seven countries and restricts citizens from those countries, does not directly affect Indonesia. Kalla's comments were made in response to Trump's executive order, which was issued last week.

images.alt_text: US President Donald Trump's immigration policy can raise "suspicion" toward Muslims, Indonesia's vice president said on Tuesday, media reported.

site_title: Weak spending dampens Japan recovery hopes
summary: Japan's household spending fell 0.3% in December for the 10th consecutive month, further dampening the nation's faltering growth plan. Despite a tight job market, inflation remains below target. The Bank of Japan blames external factors for failing to achieve a two% inflation goal, now expected by March 2019, four years later than planned. Weak spending, which accounts for 60% of GDP, continues to slow the economy, with deflation discouraging consumption and investment.

site_title: Singapore's gaming revenues likely flat this year: Fitch
summary: Fitch Ratings predicts Singapore's gaming revenues will remain flat at approximately US$4 billion in 2017 due to a weak high roller or VIP segment. Despite a 12.5% gain in Chinese visitors, the VIP segment's contraction in 2016 continued to impact gaming revenues. The two casinos will face added competitive pressure from Macau and the Philippines, and there is a low risk of the Singapore government awarding additional gaming licenses.

site_title: South Korea, US defence chiefs back anti-missile system
summary: South Korea and the US have reaffirmed their plan to deploy a US anti-missile system, known as THAAD, this year, despite Chinese protests. Defence chiefs James Mattis and Han Min Koo expressed grave concern over North Korea's growing threats and agreed to push ahead with the deployment. The move has sparked angry protests in South Korea and has raised worries among allies Japan and South Korea. The deployment plan has been infuriating China, which fears it will undermine its own ballistic capabilities. The US Defence Secretary will visit South Korea and Japan this month.

site_title: BOJ set to hold fire, seek to dispel tapering fears
summary: The Bank of Japan (BOJ) is set to maintain its massive monetary stimulus, guiding short-term rates at minus 0.1% and the 10-year bond yield to around zero%, to dispel fears of tapering its asset-buying program. BOJ Governor Haruhiko Kuroda will reassure markets that any reversal of ultra-loose policies is some time off, amid rising global bond yields and concerns about US President Donald Trump's protectionist trade stance. The central bank will also review its growth and price forecasts, with minor upward revisions to growth estimates expected.

site_title: South Korea Jan exports seen rising for third month, inflation to pick up: poll
summary: South Korea's January exports are expected to rise 8.7% from last year, driven by strong demand in semiconductors and rising global commodity prices. Imports are also forecast to increase 8.5% year-over-year. Inflation is expected to pick up to 1.5% due to higher fresh food prices and public utility price hikes. Despite potential hurdles from US protectionist measures and geopolitical tensions, exports are expected to continue growing for at least a few more months.

site_title: Australia business conditions jump sharply in Dec: survey
summary: Australian business conditions surged in December, with a 5-point increase to +11, according to National Australia Bank's survey. Sales and profits also saw significant jumps, with sales doubling to +20 and profits rising eight points to +14. Western Australia saw the largest improvement, while employment held steady. However, economists remain cautious, citing a potential slowdown in the economy and the need for further interest rate cuts. Despite this, the Reserve Bank of Australia has been optimistic on the economic outlook and has already cut rates in August and May.

site_title: Stocks to watch: SembMarine, Keppel Corp, International Healthway Corp
summary: SembCorp Marine is in final talks with Chinese conglomerates Poly Group and GCL Group for a floating liquefaction plant supply for Ethiopia's potential liquefied natural gas export project. Keppel Corp agreed to sell its entire stake in GE Keppel Energy Services for S$24.6 million. International Healthway Corp converted its trading halt to a voluntary suspension after appointing a new board, citing a need for more time to assess its current state.

site_title: Australia, US agree to deal exempting Australian citizens from travel ban
summary: Australia and the US have agreed on an exemption allowing Australian citizens to travel to the US without restrictions. The agreement, announced by Australian Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull, comes after US President Donald Trump's executive order banned citizens from seven Muslim-majority nations from entering the US. Australian passport holders will be able to travel to the US in the same way as before the order. The agreement also paves the way for the US to resettle an unspecified number of refugees held in Australian processing centres in Papua New Guinea and Nauru.

site_title: Deutsche Bank fined nearly US$630m over Russia money laundering
summary: Deutsche Bank was fined nearly $630 million by New York and British authorities for allegedly laundering $10 billion in Russian money. The scheme involved mirror trades among the bank's offices in Moscow, London, and New York. The US Justice Department is also investigating the matter. The fines, totaling $425 million from New York and $204 million from Britain, were imposed due to pervasive weaknesses in the bank's internal safeguards for money laundering and client risk. The bank must hire an outside monitor to review its internal compliance measures.

site_title: Asia: Stocks fall, US dollar holds losses on Trump ban
summary: Asian stocks fell on Tuesday, following a decline in US stocks, amid concerns over Donald Trump's potential isolationist policies. The US dollar lost ground against most peers, while gold and the yen gained. The Bank of Japan is expected to keep interest rates steady, and the Federal Reserve will make a policy decision on Wednesday. The yen rose after Trump fired the acting attorney general, and oil prices fell. The selling of riskier assets was the biggest market rebuke yet to the new administration's preferences, weighing on the US dollar.

site_title: Australia shares fall as Trump's travel ban spooks markets; NZ down
summary: Australian and New Zealand shares fell on Tuesday as US President Donald Trump's immigration policy sapped investor confidence, with the S&P/ASX 200 index down 0.7% and New Zealand's benchmark S&P/NZX 50 index declining 0.7%. The US dollar also dropped, and major US stock indexes posted their largest declines so far in 2017. The global selloff was sparked by Trump's executive order on refugees and travellers from seven Muslim-majority countries, with markets spooked by the new administration's protectionism and tough stance on immigration.

site_title: Pentagon to seek Iraqi reprieve from travel ban
summary: The US Defense Department plans to lobby for Iraqi nationals who worked with the US military, potentially exempting them from President Trump's travel ban. The Pentagon is compiling a list of names of Iraqis who supported the US military, including fighters and translators. The ban, which restricts entry to the US for 90 days for citizens of Iraq and six other countries, has sparked international criticism and outrage in Iraq. The Defense Department aims to ensure that those who have demonstrated commitment to fight alongside the US are known to the services responsible for authorizing entry.

site_title: Snapchat parent to offer shares on NYSE: reports
summary: Snapchat's parent company, Snap Inc, is set to debut as a public company on the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE), according to reports. The company has chosen to avoid the tech-heavy Nasdaq, where Apple, Amazon, and Google-parent Alphabet are traded. Snap's initial public offering (IPO) is expected to value the company between $20 billion and $25 billion, making it the biggest-ticket Wall Street debut since Alibaba in 2014. The IPO is anticipated to be a bellwether for other hot startups, and the company is expected to file paperwork later this week.

site_title: Quebec mosque shooting suspect charged with murdering 6 people
summary: A 27-year-old French-Canadian university student, Alexandre Bissonnette, was charged with the premeditated murder of six people and five attempted murders in a shooting at a Quebec City mosque on Sunday. The victims included a butcher, university professor, pharmacist, and accountant. The government of Guinea reported two of its citizens were among the dead. Canadian authorities consider the attack a lone wolf situation, while US government security experts believe the gunman was motivated by hatred for Muslims. Prime Minister Justin Trudeau called the attack a terrorist act, vowing to defend and stand with Canada's Muslim community.

site_title: White House 'aware' of Iran missile test
summary: The White House confirmed it is aware of Iran's recent missile test, but declined to offer details or criticism. The test, which could be in violation of UN resolutions, may lead to sanctions. Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu publicly condemned the test, calling it a "flagrant violation" of UN rules, and threatened to renew sanctions in a meeting with US President Donald Trump on February 15. The move could severely test the durability of the nuclear deal between Iran and the US.

site_title: Trump expected to sign cyber security executive order Tuesday: source
summary: President Donald Trump is expected to sign a cyber security executive order on Tuesday, marking his first action to address the issue. The order will commission reviews of the government's offensive and defensive cyber capabilities, audit federal agencies' cyber capabilities, and review protections for critical infrastructure. It will also seek input on improving cyber security measures and giving the private sector incentives to adopt strong security measures. The move follows Trump's campaign focus on cyber security and his acknowledgment of Russia's involvement in the hacking of Democratic emails during the 2016 election.

images.alt_text: President Donald Trump is expected to sign an executive order on cyber security on Tuesday, two sources familiar with the situation said, marking the first action to address what he has called a top priority of his administration.

site_title: 'Trump & Dump' program aims to profit off Trump tweets to save puppies
summary: A tech company, T3, has developed an "artificial intelligence program" called "Trump & Dump" that uses President Donald Trump's tweets to execute quick stock trades. The program identifies tweets with positive or negative sentiment and executes trades within seconds. The company donates the earnings from successful trades to an animal welfare group, the ASPCA. The program has yielded significant winnings on two occasions and a slight loss on a third. The T3 company has described the program as a way to "save puppies" while profiting from Trump's tweets.

images.alt_text: Techies have devised a program to execute quickfire stock trades to take advantage of President Donald Trump's Twitter habit of blackballing individual companies.

site_title: Europe: Shares slip on weaker commodities, M&A optimism limits losses
summary: European shares ended lower on Monday, falling 1.1% due to losses in commodities-related stocks and financials, despite merger and acquisition optimism. Vodafone rose 1.3% after talks of a potential merger with Idea in India. The Stoxx 600 is still up 0.3% for the month, with concerns over US President Donald Trump's travel ban dampening investor mood.

site_title: Australia, NZ dollars steady, on track for strong month
summary: The Australian and New Zealand dollars remained steady, with the Australian dollar rising 0.1% to US$0.7561 and the New Zealand dollar holding at US$0.7286, both on track for their best monthly performance since early 2016. The currencies have been trapped in a tight 75-76 US cent band over the last 10 sessions.

site_title: Obama rejects faith-based discrimination amid travel ban uproar
summary: Former US President Barack Obama has expressed his opposition to faith-based discrimination, specifically in response to President Donald Trump's travel ban targeting seven Muslim-majority countries. In a statement, Obama's spokesman Kevin Lewis said the president "fundamentally disagrees" with discriminating against individuals based on their faith or religion. The statement came amid protests across the country and criticism of the travel ban, which has detained over 100 travellers and blocked hundreds more abroad.

images.alt_text: Former US president Barack Obama expressed his objections Monday to any faith-based discrimination, in an apparent dig at his successor Donald Trump's ban on nationals of seven Muslim-majority countries entering the country.

site_title: Bank lending in Singapore up 1.1% in Dec
summary: Bank lending in Singapore increased 1.1% in December 2016, driven by stronger business lending, according to preliminary data from the Monetary Authority of Singapore. Business loans rose 1.7% to S$367 billion, while consumer loans grew 0.3% to S$250 billion. This follows a 0.4% growth in November.

site_title: Oil slips as more US drilling revives glut concerns
summary: Oil prices fell on Monday as US drilling activity increased, raising concerns about the effectiveness of global production cuts aimed at reducing the supply glut. US crude prices dropped 54 cents to $52.63 a barrel, while global benchmark Brent crude fell 29 cents to $55.23 a barrel. Despite OPEC's output cuts, analysts predict only 75% of the targeted reduction will be met, and US shale production may temper price gains, keeping oil prices below $60 a barrel in 2018.

site_title: UK consumers slow their borrowing in December ahead of expected Brexit pinch
summary: British consumers slowed their borrowing in December, with consumer credit rising £1.1 billion, down from a £2 billion increase in November. This marks the first time in five months that borrowing has slowed. The slowdown comes ahead of expected economic challenges due to the Brexit vote, which is pushing up inflation. The slower borrowing pace is an early sign that households may be reining in spending.

site_title: GM, Honda announce fuel cell venture in Michigan
summary: General Motors and Honda announced a joint venture to produce hydrogen fuel cell systems in Michigan, with production expected to begin around 2020. The venture, which will create nearly 100 new jobs, will invest $85 million each from GM and Honda. Fuel cell vehicles can operate on renewable hydrogen, producing only water vapor as emissions. This marks a significant step forward for fuel cell technology, which has been under study for 20 years. The partnership aims to bring fuel cells closer to mainstream propulsion applications.

site_title: Protests as UK stands firm on Trump invite
summary: British Prime Minister Theresa May has refused to cancel a planned state visit by US President Donald Trump, despite widespread protests and over 1.5 million signatures on a petition calling for the visit to be cancelled. May stated that the UK values its relationship with the US, but takes a different approach on Trump's policies, particularly the travel ban. Protests took place across the UK, with chants of "Shame on you Theresa May" and "No to racism, no to Trump."

images.alt_text: British Prime Minister Theresa May on Monday refused to back down on inviting US President Donald Trump for a glitzy state visit, despite a petition gaining more than 1.5 million signatures and protesters rallying across the country.

site_title: Trump to announce Supreme Court pick Tuesday
summary: US President Donald Trump plans to announce his Supreme Court nominee on Tuesday, aiming to shift the bench to a conservative majority on key issues like abortion and gun control. The vacancy was left by Antonin Scalia's sudden death, and Trump's choice is expected to face a bruising battle with Democrats. The nominee is likely to be a conservative, with names such as Neil Gorsuch, William Pryor, and Thomas Hardiman being tipped as frontrunners. The Senate confirmation process will be highly politicized, with Republicans needing 60 votes to confirm a nominee, and Trump's choice may struggle to win over some Democratic votes.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close lower on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index closed lower on Tuesday, down 14.820 points to 1671.540, with a 1.159 billion lots traded at RM1.612 billion. Losers outnumbered gainers 367 to 354.

site_title: Singapore shares open 0.3% down on Tuesday
summary: Singapore stocks opened 0.3% lower on Tuesday, with the Straits Times Index losing 10.5 points to 3,054.35, following the US's travel ban that raised concerns over possible economic harm. Losers outnumbered gainers 82 to 52, and about 120.4 million shares changed hands.

site_title: US: Wall Street falls the most this year as Trump honeymoon sours
summary: US stock indexes fell 0.61% on Monday, marking the largest drop this year, amid concerns over a curb on immigration ordered by President Donald Trump. The ban on immigration from seven Muslim-majority countries and the halt on refugee entries led to protests and worries about the impact on the economy. Technology stocks, particularly those with foreign talent, were hit the hardest, with the Nasdaq Composite falling 0.83%. The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 122.65 points, while the S&P 500 lost 13.79 points.

site_title: Brazilian ex-billionaire Batista surrenders to Rio police
summary: Brazilian ex-billionaire Eike Batista, once the country's wealthiest person, has surrendered to Rio police to face corruption charges. He was charged with paying a $16.5 million bribe to ex-Rio de Janeiro state governor Sergio Cabral. Batista, 60, flew in from New York, shaved his head, and was sent to a crowded prison before transferring to a larger facility. His surrender marks a new landmark in Brazil's sprawling corruption scandals, including former President Luiz Inacio Lula da Silva. Batista's downfall comes as the judiciary pursues a massive bribery and embezzlement case centered on state oil company Petrobras.

site_title: Former New York fund analyst convicted of insider trading
summary: A former New York fund analyst, John Afriyie, has been convicted of insider trading by a federal jury in Manhattan. Afriyie, 29, was found guilty of securities fraud and wire fraud for misusing secret information about a deal involving MSD Capital, a company founded by Michael Dell. Afriyie made approximately $2.6 million through insider trading and re-investing his profits. The conviction is the latest in a wave of insider trading cases by the Manhattan US Attorney's office, which has secured 85 convictions since 2009.

site_title: Social media for politicians a double-edged sword
summary: US President Donald Trump's reliance on Twitter to converse with the American people has raised concerns about the sanctity of official messages and the potential for hacking and fake news. Observers argue that social media is a double-edged sword, offering instant reach but lacking a filter. Trump's use of Twitter for policy announcements and personal opinions has been criticized, with some warning that it may compromise his ability to make informed decisions. Experts also highlight the need for context and balance in evaluating his messages.

site_title: Oil prices dip as rising US output offsets Opec-led cuts
summary: Oil prices dropped to $55.16 per barrel on Tuesday, down 7 cents from their last close, as rising US drilling activity offset Opec-led output cuts. Since January, Brent crude futures have lost over 5.5% in value. The decline in oil prices is attributed to the US's increasing production, which has offset the production cuts made by Opec and other producers.

site_title: Washington state to sue over travel ban, pressures on Trump grow
summary: US President Donald Trump's travel ban, targeting seven Muslim-majority countries, has sparked widespread criticism and opposition. Washington state has announced a lawsuit against the order, with Attorney General Bob Ferguson citing constitutional claims. The ban has also drawn criticism from allies, including British Foreign Secretary Boris Johnson and former President Barack Obama. Protests erupted at US airports over the weekend, and several state attorneys general are considering legal action. The US stock market suffered its biggest drop of 2017, with investors citing concerns over the ban's impact on immigration.

site_title: Asia targets tourism, education boost from Trump travel ban
summary: US President Donald Trump's travel ban has prompted Asia to capitalize on tourism and education ties with Muslim-majority countries. Companies in Malaysia, such as AirAsia, are seizing the opportunity to attract tourists and students. The 120-day refugee ban and indefinite ban on Syrian refugees are expected to drive up travel to ASEAN countries. The Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) is seen as a potential beneficiary of the travel restrictions. Malaysia's tourism industry is likely to benefit from increased interest in the region.

site_title: US dollar drops vs yen as investors react to Trump executive actions
summary: The US dollar fell over 1% against the Japanese yen on Monday following President Donald Trump's executive orders on immigration, drawing criticism and protests. The dollar's decline was attributed to concerns about trade risks and the potential economic impact of Trump's protectionist policies. The euro also fell, while the Mexican peso rose to its highest level of 2017 against the US dollar. The dollar's decline was seen as a reaction to the negative headlines surrounding Trump's executive orders, overshadowing initial expectations for a stronger dollar in 2017.

site_title: Fortescue sees iron ore demand boost as China closes steel mills
summary: Australia's Fortescue Metals Group expects a boost in iron ore demand due to China's closure of steel mills, maintaining its forecast for record shipments this year. Despite a slight dip in exports to China in the quarter to Dec 31, Fortescue's production is still on track to meet its guidance of 165-170 million tonnes. Iron ore prices rebounded in 2016, defying analyst forecasts, and Fortescue expects this trend to continue. The company's forecast suggests a strong start to 2017 for the iron ore market.

site_title: Social media battle lines drawn on Turkish vote for Erdogan's sweeping powers
summary: Turkish President Tayyip Erdogan is pushing for sweeping new powers that would give him control over the country's government, sparking a divisive debate. Opponents fear a lurch towards authoritarianism, while supporters see the move as a guarantee of stability. Erdogan's supporters have taken to social media to promote the "Yes" campaign, while opponents are largely fighting back online, with many using hashtags and social media to express their opposition. The referendum, expected to be held in April, is seen as a test of Erdogan's popularity and the future of Turkey's democracy.

site_title: Opec convinces investors its oil output cuts are real
summary: Opec has successfully persuaded investors that it is implementing production cuts, with oil shipments from the organization plummeting this month. Saudi Arabia has reported that over 80% of its targeted 1.8 million barrel reduction has been implemented, and other producers, including Russia, are also curbing output. This has led to a surge in optimism among money managers, with West Texas Intermediate oil prices rising 1.3% to $53.18 a barrel. The Opec-engineered price rally has also spurred a surge in US shale drilling, but US crude production is expected to rise in 2017.

images.alt_text: Opec will reduce supply by 900,000 barrels a day in January, the first month of the accord's implementation, which is about 75 per cent of the cut that the producer group has agreed to make.

site_title: UK under pressure to cancel Trump state visit
summary: Over 1 million people in the UK have signed a petition calling for the country to cancel a planned state visit by US President Donald Trump, citing his executive order on refugees and his "well-documented misogyny and vulgarity". The petition was sparked by Trump's ban on travellers from mainly Muslim countries, with opposition parties and some Conservative MPs urging the government to reconsider the visit. Despite Prime Minister Theresa May's announcement that the visit will go ahead, the move has drawn criticism from various quarters, including Labour leader Jeremy Corbyn and Conservative Muslim peer Sayeeda Warsi.

images.alt_text: Mr Trump (left) with Ms May outside of the White House in Washington, DC, on Jan 27. The UK PM's closeness to the erratic billionaire has drawn fire at home.

site_title: The bane and perils of Twitter diplomacy from the White House
summary: The Trump administration's foreign policy is marked by confusion and chaos, with the president's tweets and top aides' statements creating a disjointed and provocative image towards China. Despite Trump's campaign promise of a "America First" approach, his views on major issues like climate change and military alliances lack coherence. The administration's conflicting messages, including Rex Tillerson's statement on blocking China's access to the South China Sea, have raised concerns about the potential for military conflict. The lack of a clear policy towards China has left the world waiting for a unified approach from the new administration.

site_title: Emirates changes pilot, crew rosters on US flights after Trump order
summary: Emirates has changed pilot and flight attendant rosters on flights to the US following the Trump travel ban on seven Muslim-majority countries. The airline, which flies daily to 11 US cities, made the adjustments to comply with the new requirements. Despite the changes, US flights continue to operate to schedule. Other airlines, including Lufthansa and Etihad Airways, have also taken steps to comply with the ban, which applies to pilots and flight attendants from the affected countries. The ban has created uncertainty for airlines and travelers, with concerns that it could dampen travel demand and impact global economic activity.

site_title: Say goodbye to ATMs and hello to robo-advisers
summary: Robo-advisers and fintech innovations are transforming the financial industry, with the integration of APIs and AI set to revolutionize banking and financial transactions. Traditional banks will evolve to offer customized services, while physical ATMs will disappear as online banking becomes seamless. Artificial intelligence will play a key role in detecting and preventing financial fraud, and start-ups will seize opportunities created by industry restructuring. The future of finance will be more integrated, cashless, and efficient, with instant cross-border transactions and automated services, but may require infrastructure and education to become a reality.

site_title: Sales of most luxury cars hit 2016 speed bump
summary: Sales of luxury cars in Singapore hit a 2016 speed bump in 2016, with most brands experiencing slower growth due to the economic slowdown. Mercedes-Benz remained the most popular luxury brand, with 6,444 units registered, a 19.2% rise. Infiniti and Jaguar were the top-performing luxury brands, with Infiniti posting a 47.7% surge to 328 units and Jaguar achieving a record year with 555 units sold. Other luxury brands like BMW, Lexus, and Audi also saw growth, while Porsche and Maserati suffered negative growth due to parallel imports.

images.alt_text: Infiniti (pictured) and Jaguar were the two best luxury performers as total car registrations in 2016 rose 52 per cent to 87,504. Both brands are represented by Wearnes Automotive.

site_title: Allianz considers takeover of Australia's QBE: source
summary: German insurer Allianz has reportedly made an informal approach to Australian peer QBE Insurance, considering a potential takeover deal. Allianz has floated an offer of A$15.00 per share, valuing QBE at A$20 billion. QBE shares rose 4.7% on the news, but the company denied discussions with Allianz. Analysts believe QBE could reach A$15 per share on its own through cost savings and claims management. Allianz chief executive Oliver Baete has stated that the company is looking for acquisitions but faces challenges in finding attractive targets at reasonable prices.

site_title: Fresh Sino-Indian tensions roil geopolitics in Asia
summary: Sino-Indian tensions escalate, with China refusing to lift a hold on Pakistan-based Jaish-e-Mohammad chief Masood Azhar, accused of terrorism against India. India tests long-range ballistic missiles in response. China's US$46 billion investment in the China-Pakistan Economic Corridor (CPEC) troubles India, which views it as an attempt to create new realities on the ground. India reevaluates its China policy, strengthening partnerships with like-minded countries and bolstering its military capabilities. A significant shift in India's Tibet policy sees the government openly welcoming the Dalai Lama, sparking Chinese opposition.

images.alt_text: Faced with an intransigent China, India under the centre-right government led by Narendra Modi is busy revaluating its China policy.

site_title: Swiss tax break for MNCs set to go in Feb 12 referendum
summary: Switzerland is set to vote on a tax reform referendum on February 12, which could impact multinational companies (MNCs) with a potential $40 million investment in its Swiss factory. The current tax break, which attracts thousands of companies, is set to expire, and the new regime's impact on MNCs is uncertain. The government aims to balance abolishing the tax break with new measures to keep Switzerland competitive, but critics argue it will lead to lower tax revenue and higher personal taxes for citizens. The outcome of the referendum is uncertain, with many voters expressing confusion about the issues.

site_title: Venezuela names new leaders at oil company
summary: Venezuelan President Nicolas Maduro has created an executive vice-president post and named new vice-presidents to lead PDVSA, the country's state oil company. Eulogio Del Pino remains PDVSA president, while Maribel Parra and Simon Zerpa take up new roles in finance and exploration, respectively. The shake-up aims to root out corruption, which has plagued the industry. Maduro's move follows years of heavy social spending, slumping crude production, and chronic payment disputes with suppliers, as Venezuela battles triple-digit inflation and a severe recession.

site_title: Scaramucci scores millions from a buyer with mystery investors
summary: Anthony Scaramucci sold his 45% stake in SkyBridge Capital to RON Transatlantic and HNA Group for $180 million or more, valuing the asset manager at $180 million or more depending on performance. The deal, which closed in about three months, includes all of Scaramucci's interest in the company. RON Transatlantic's investors remain unknown, sparking concerns about the lack of transparency. Scaramucci has agreed to recuse himself from any matter related to his SkyBridge interest and has filed all required ethics disclosures for his White House role.

site_title: Kuwait stocks extend world-topping rally to an 18th day
summary: Kuwait stocks continued their winning streak, advancing 1.3% to 6,943.24, for an 18th consecutive day, the longest rally in over a decade. The country's move to sell dollar bonds is seen as a step to shore up public finances. Gulf markets largely ignored a US travel ban on seven mainly Muslim countries. Other markets, such as Saudi Arabia and Israel, also saw gains, while Turkey's lira weakened after a rating cut.

site_title: Trump upends White House establishment in just 7 days
summary: President Donald Trump has significantly altered the US foreign policy landscape in his first week, sparking widespread concern. Trump's immigration executive order has been met with criticism from allies, including Mexico and Britain, while his silence on Ukraine issues has raised eyebrows. The rush for change has led to a sense of disarray, with many career diplomats resigning and a lack of transition planning. Establishment Republicans have also voiced concerns, warning that the "America First" approach could lead to a power vacuum and accelerate a sense of isolationism.

site_title: Tough business for global firms under Trump
summary: US President Donald Trump's executive order banning citizens of seven Muslim-majority countries from entering the US has sparked widespread concern among global companies, including Toyota, Google, and Goldman Sachs. The order has caused confusion and chaos, with border agents and airlines unsure how to interpret the rules. Executives have been advised to speak out and risk drawing fire from the president, while staying silent and facing criticism from employees and activists. The decision has also highlighted the delicate balance that business leaders will have to strike, with some praising Trump's promises to overhaul corporate taxes and invest in infrastructure.

images.alt_text: US President Donald Trump vowed to end business as usual in Washington. Global companies are now learning just what that means.

site_title: Changi Airport handled record 58.7m passengers in 2016
summary: Changi Airport in Singapore handled a record 58.7 million passengers in 2016, a 5.9% increase, driven by growth from South East Asia, North East Asia, and Oceania. Cargo throughput reached a new high of 1.97 million tonnes, while aircraft movements rose 4.1%. China became the airport's third-largest country market, with a 15% increase in traffic. Changi's busiest routes remained unchanged, with Jakarta holding the top spot, while the airport expects to continue growing its long-haul routes and connectivity within the region.

site_title: Uber under fire for profiting from taxi strike against refugee ban
summary: Uber faced backlash for continuing to operate while taxis struck in opposition to President Donald Trump's refugee ban. The strike, organized by the New York Taxi Workers Alliance, aimed to protest the ban's impact on drivers from affected countries. After hundreds of Twitter users rallied against Uber using the #DeleteUber hashtag, rival Lyft pledged $1 million to the ACLU and continued to operate, giving rides during the strike. Uber responded with a $3 million fund to assist drivers and reiterated its commitment to working with the Trump administration, but many customers remained dissatisfied.

images.alt_text: Uber CEO Travis Kalanick is a member of Mr Trump's economic advisory group and has repeatedly pledged to work with the president. His bid to mollify customers failed to convince those aggrieved.

site_title: Insead retains top spot in FT's global MBA rankings
summary: INSEAD has retained its top spot in The Financial Times' global MBA rankings for the second consecutive year, followed by Stanford, Wharton, Harvard, and Cambridge. Nanyang Technological University's (NTU) Nanyang Business School and National University of Singapore (NUS) Business School have both improved their rankings. NTU's Nanyang Business School ranked 24th, while NUS Business School ranked 26th, with average weighted annual salaries of US$126,218 and US$131,760 respectively.

site_title: Sabah shipwreck search area expanded
summary: Malaysia expands search area for five Chinese tourists and one crew member missing from a catamaran that sank off eastern Malaysia's Borneo island. The search area has been increased from 400 to 1,500 nautical square miles due to the possibility of the missing individuals drifting further. A total of 100 officers and a C130 aircraft are involved in the mission, with a helicopter from Brunei assisting the search. The survivors were found alive on Sunday, with three Chinese passengers confirmed dead, and 20 Chinese tourists rescued.

site_title: Duterte accuses US of building 'permanent' arsenal in the Philippines
summary: Philippine President Rodrigo Duterte accused the US of building permanent arms depots in the country, threatening to scrap a security treaty between them. The US had given the green light to build warehouses and runways under a 2014 agreement, which Duterte deemed a "dangerous breach" of a defense deal. Duterte warned that if US arsenals were built in the Philippines, he would consider reviewing treaties and potentially abrogating them, putting regional stability at risk.

site_title: Shooting at Quebec City mosque during Sunday night prayers leaves 6 dead, 8 wounded
summary: A gunman opened fire at a Quebec City mosque during Sunday night prayers, killing six people and wounding eight others. Two suspects have been arrested, but police have not released details about them. Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau condemned the attack as a "terrorist attack on Muslims" and pledged to increase security measures at mosques. The incident has raised concerns about Islamophobia in Quebec, where there have been previous incidents of hate crimes and vandalism against the Muslim community.

site_title: Airbnb offers free housing to refugees and others not allowed into the US
summary: Airbnb CEO Brian Chesky tweeted that the company will offer free housing to refugees and individuals banned from the US, in response to President Trump's executive order. The order temporarily bans refugees from several Muslim-majority countries and suspends Syrian refugee entry indefinitely. Chesky stated that Airbnb will provide housing to those affected, with further details to be announced later. The company's move is seen as a show of support for refugees, following Chesky's earlier statement that singling out countries and refugees was "not right".

site_title: Euro-area economic confidence highest since 2011
summary: The European Commission reported a six-year high in euro-area economic confidence, with an index of executive and consumer sentiment rising to 108.2 in January, the highest since 2011. This comes as the European Central Bank considers quantitative easing amid signs of stronger growth and inflation. However, officials caution that underlying price pressures remain weak and there are risks to the economic outlook, with global growth threatened by protectionist trade policies and uncertainty surrounding elections in major economies.

site_title: India's post-demonetisation budget must be pro-growth
summary: India's upcoming budget is expected to provide a boost to consumption, drive employment, and simplify taxation. Following demonetization, the government aims to address economic distortions, while the International Monetary Fund predicts above 7% growth for the current and coming years. The budget should include measures to revamp public-private partnerships, reduce corporate tax rates, and improve the business climate. Key areas to focus on include agriculture, rural infrastructure, and digital payments, with a focus on healthcare, education, and infrastructure development to sustain growth.

site_title: Consumer spending solidly up in December
summary: US consumer spending rose 0.5% in December, exceeding expectations, driven by increased motor vehicle purchases and services. This solid increase in domestic demand suggests sustained economic growth in early 2017. Rising wages and inflation pressures may prompt the Federal Reserve to lift interest rates at least three times this year, despite no rate hike expected at this week's meeting.

site_title: Miss France rules the Universe
summary: France won its first Miss Universe crown in 64 years with dental surgery student Iris Mittenaere, 24, beating 85 contestants at the event in the Philippines. Mittenaere spoke out on global issues, including the refugee crisis and migration, advocating for a balance between borders and globalisation. The pageant, hosted by the Philippines, drew criticism for whitewashing the country's human rights record and environmental concerns.

site_title: Google aggressively woos Republicans in post-Obama era
