The sale marks a significant move for Keppel, which will receive a substantial sum of money from the sale. The exact terms and implications of the sale are yet to be disclosed.

images.alt_text: Keppel Corporation has agreed to sell its entire stake in GE Keppel Energy Services to GE Singapore of General Electric for S$24.6 million by February, it said in a filing on Friday afternoon.

site_title: Stocks to watch: CDLHT, A-H Trust, CRCT, Mapletree Greater China Commercial Trust
summary: Singapore stocks to watch: CDL Hospitality Trusts (CDLHT) increased its distribution per stapled security by 3.3% to 3.11 Singapore cents for Q4 2016. Ascendas Hospitality Trust (A-H Trust) jumped 13.1% in DPS to 1.64 Singapore cents for Q3. However, CapitaLand Retail China Trust (CRCT) and Mapletree Greater China Commercial Trust (MGCCT) saw declines in net property income and distribution per unit due to weaker China business conditions.

site_title: Trump to seek quick progress with Japan's Abe on replacement trade deal
summary: President Donald Trump plans to seek a bilateral trade agreement with Japan in place of the abandoned Trans-Pacific Partnership, with Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's visit to the White House scheduled for February 10. Trump has expressed his desire for quick progress, stating that the agreement will include clauses for a 30-day termination notice if the US is not treated fairly. Abe has signaled openness to working out a free trade or economic partnership agreement, while also advocating for retaining tariffs on key agricultural products.

site_title: Ex-Rabobank traders seek reversal in US of Libor convictions
summary: A US appeals court questioned the convictions of two former Rabobank traders, Anthony Allen and Anthony Conti, in a case related to the manipulation of the London interbank offered rate (Libor). The traders argued their rights were violated after a cooperating witness, Paul Robson, reviewed testimony from a UK regulator that compelled Allen and Conti to cooperate in a related probe. The court considered whether this review influenced their statements and potentially violated the US Constitution.

site_title: LVMH 'cautiously confident' after record 2016 results
summary: LVMH, a French luxury group, reported "record" results in 2016, with a 11% increase in net profit to 3.98 billion euros and a 5% increase in revenues to 37.6 billion euros. Despite geopolitical and currency uncertainties, the company is "cautiously confident" for 2017, citing the appeal of its brands and the agility of its teams. CEO Bernard Arnault praised the company's performance in 2016, but did not provide concrete forecasts for sales or earnings in 2017.

site_title: Oil up 2% on stock market, but US supply caps gains
summary: Oil prices rose 2% on Thursday, driven by a rally in the US stock market, but gains were capped by abundant supplies and inventories. US light crude futures jumped $1.22 to $53.97 a barrel, while Brent crude rose $1.25 to $56.33. Despite efforts by producers to cut output, rising US production and inventories are likely to limit the effectiveness of supply cuts by the Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries.

site_title: Mexico's cross-border workers fear Trump's wall
summary: US President Donald Trump signed an order to build a border wall to keep out illegal migrants, sparking fears among cross-border workers in Mexico. Single mother Mayra Rodriguez, who commutes daily from Tijuana to San Diego, fears the wall will worsen congestion and potentially lead to job loss. Over 1 million people and 400,000 vehicles cross the border daily, and Mexican truckers fear losing permits to enter the US. The wall's impact on trade and migration is expected to be significant, with the Mexican peso weakening against the dollar.

site_title: Europe: M&A boost helps shares stay at one-year high
summary: European shares maintained a one-year high on Thursday, supported by mergers and acquisitions optimism. Johnson & Johnson's $30 billion deal to buy Actelion lifted shares in the Swiss biotech firm, with Actelion surging 19.4%. Other gainers included STMicroelectronics, Diageo, and Royal Bank of Scotland, while some companies like Daily Mail and General Trust and Unilever fell due to disappointing earnings reports.

site_title: Dutch minister quits as old scandal claims fourth scalp
summary: Dutch Justice Minister Aard van der Steur resigned after being grilled by opposition parties over a 2.1 million euro scandal involving a deal with a notorious trafficker 17 years ago. This is the fourth high-profile parliamentarian from the Liberal VVD party to resign since March 2015, potentially damaging Prime Minister Mark Rutte's re-election bid. Van der Steur denied wrongdoing, stating he came to defend himself against "unfounded and not based on facts."

site_title: Twitter adds 'explore' to make finding tweets easier
summary: Twitter has added an "explore" tab to its platform, combining trends, Moments, search, and live video highlights in one spot to make it easier to find interesting content. The feature, launched on Apple mobile devices, aims to boost engagement and make Twitter more inviting. This move follows Twitter's efforts to boost user growth and revenue, which have been impacted by a modest increase in monthly active users and a net loss of $103 million in the third quarter of last year.

site_title: US: Dow gains modestly in muted day-after session
summary: The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 0.2% to 20,100.91, ending a day after setting a record at 20,000 points, while the S&P 500 fell 0.1% and the Nasdaq lost 0.1%. Corporate earnings releases, including Ford's $800 million loss and Ebay's revenue projection, influenced the session. Other companies reported varying results, with AT&T gaining 1%, Dow Chemical rising 2%, and Mattel plummeting 17.7%. The market is taking a breather after a historic surge, with investors awaiting Friday's US growth report.

site_title: MBS parent stands to reap up to US$3.5b by selling stake in mall
summary: Marina Bay Sands parent company expects to reap up to US$3.5 billion from selling a 49% stake in its shopping mall, making it the most expensive mall ever sold in the world, according to a conference call. The sale is part of the company's financial restructuring efforts.

site_title: Malaysia, South Korea, China, Taiwan: Markets closed for holidays
summary: Malaysia, South Korea, China, and Taiwan financial markets are closed on Friday for public holidays. Meanwhile, Singapore stocks are on a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data, with the STI up 0.4% on Thursday. US stocks continue to edge towards fresh records, despite tariff uncertainty and split Fed views. eSIM platform Airalo raises US$220 million in new funding, lifting its valuation past US$1 billion.

site_title: Trump wants to fund Mexico border wall with 20% import tax: spokesman
summary: US President Donald Trump plans to fund the construction of a wall on the Mexican border with a 20% import tax on goods from Mexico, estimated to generate $10 billion annually. This move has sparked tensions between the two countries, with Mexican President Enrique Pena Nieto canceling a planned visit to Washington. The plan aims to curb illegal immigration but has raised concerns about trade and economic implications.

images.alt_text: US President Donald Trump plans to fund his construction of a wall on the Mexican border by imposing a 20 per cent import tax on goods from Washington's southern neighbour, his spokesman said on Thursday.

site_title: Trump has not changed, will not change
summary: US President Donald Trump has failed to change his tone or approach, despite being in office for four years. His inaugural address, similar to his campaign speeches, focused on mercantilism and protectionist slogans, rather than a call to unity. Critics had expected him to tone down his rhetoric in response to criticism and opposition, but he has continued to maintain his extreme statements. This has led to concerns about the direction of the US under Trump's leadership, with many expecting him to revert to more moderate positions as the reality of office sets in.

site_title: Expect more forgeries, fakes in China debt market amid bond rout
summary: China's US$3 trillion corporate debt market is experiencing a surge in forgeries and fakes amid a bond market downturn, with analysts predicting a record number of defaults in 2017. Fake documents, forged seals, and letters are being used to deceive investors and hide debt. As Chinese companies struggle to issue new notes to repay maturing debt, scandals are expected to worsen the market's downturn.

site_title: Court case on whether Brexit can be reversed to be filed on Friday
summary: A court case in Dublin aims to determine whether Britain can reverse its Brexit decision once triggered. Lawyer Jolyon Maugham will file the challenge, seeking a referral to the EU's top court. The case, led by the Green Party, argues that the UK can unilaterally revoke Article 50 without EU consent. The case hopes to be heard by the Irish High Court by March or April, with a potential referral to the European Court of Justice by summer. This could potentially allow the UK to change its mind on Brexit.

site_title: Microsoft profit edges up as it absorbs LinkedIn
summary: Microsoft reported a 3.6% profit increase to $5.2 billion in its second fiscal quarter, driven by gains in cloud computing and services. The company's LinkedIn acquisition boosted revenue but dragged on profit, adding $228 million in revenue but erasing $100 million in net profit. Satya Nadella attributed the results to Microsoft's shift towards services and partnerships, citing a 10% jump in revenue from productivity and business products, and an 8% increase in revenue from the intelligent cloud segment.

images.alt_text: Microsoft on Thursday reported a rise in profits over the past quarter, showing gains in cloud computing and other new areas of focus as it absorbed the LinkedIn social network.

site_title: Ascendas Hospitality Trust posts 13% growth in Q3 DPS
summary: Ascendas Hospitality Trust reported a 13.1% jump in distribution per stapled security to 1.64 Singapore cents for the third quarter, driven by stronger Australian and Japanese hotel performances. The trust's distributable income grew 14.6% to S$19.5 million, with higher net property income and foreign exchange gains. The Australian portfolio improved, while the China and Japan portfolios also showed stronger quarters. The trust's gearing ratio remains healthy at 33.3%.

site_title: China's shadow banking crusade risks bond market crash
summary: China's efforts to curb high debt levels in its economy by shrinking the $3 trillion shadow banking sector may trigger a bond market crash, analysts warn. The government's new rules on wealth management products (WMPs) could drain funding from banks and disrupt the bond market, which has already seen a decline in prices and sales of WMPs. Experts fear that the unintended consequences of these efforts could trigger unexpected risks for the banking sector, leading to a policy-induced drastic deleveraging in shadow banking.

images.alt_text: CHINA'S campaign to cut high debt levels in its economy is aiming this year to shrink the US$3 trillion shadow banking sector, which could drain a critical source of income for the country's banks and of funding for its fragile bond market.

site_title: Indonesian anti-graft agency detains Constitutional Court judge
summary: Indonesia's anti-graft agency, the Corruption Eradication Commission (KPK), has detained Constitutional Court judge Patrialis Akbar on suspicion of graft. The judge will be suspended and possibly sacked if found guilty. The detention has raised concerns about the integrity of the Constitutional Court, which has faced bribery scandals in recent years. The investigation is related to a judicial review of Indonesia's animal and livestock health law.

site_title: Asahi looks for China beer exit after Tsingtao disappointment
summary: Asahi Group Holdings Ltd, Japan's largest beermaker, is seeking to exit its 2009 minority stake in Tsingtao Brewery Co, a Chinese brewer, due to disappointing sales and increasing competition from foreign brands and local craft beers. Asahi's 20% stake in Tsingtao is valued at about $1.1 billion, and the company has picked Morgan Stanley to advise on the potential sale. The move comes as the Chinese economy slows, leading to a decline in the beer market and making it challenging for mid-market brands like Tsingtao to compete.

images.alt_text: For a foreign brewer hoping to gain an edge in the Chinese market, it seemed like the ideal alliance: Japan's largest beermaker teaming up with one of China's premier brands. Yet, Asahi Group Holdings Ltd's 2009 purchase of a minority stake in Tsingtao Brewery Co didn't produce the opportunities the Tokyo company hoped.

site_title: How bad is e-mail for the environment?
summary: French energy regulators have suggested cutting back on email to save energy, citing the significant carbon footprint of email infrastructure. Research shows that email has a carbon footprint of 4g of CO2e per normal message, while spam email and attachments can increase this to 50g CO2e. In comparison, an hour of TV viewing on an old 32-inch CRT TV generates 84g CO2e, while game consoles can consume 8,000 gigawatt-hours of electricity over their lifespan, emitting 3 million tonnes of CO2.

site_title: GPC urges govt to help more firms tap into scientific research
summary: A panel of Singapore's parliamentarians, the Government Parliamentary Committee (GPC), has urged the government to introduce policies to help companies tap into scientific research, improve competitiveness, and encourage employers to develop workers' skills. The GPC's recommendations, submitted ahead of the Budget and the Committee on the Future Economy report, include channeling RIE2020 Plan resources to local firms, encouraging technology transfers, and introducing tax incentives for apprenticeships and traineeships.

site_title: Google parent Alphabet profit edges up, revenue surges
summary: Alphabet, the parent company of Google, reported an 8% increase in net income to $5.3 billion in the final quarter of last year, driven by growth in mobile search and YouTube. Revenue surged 22% to $26 billion, exceeding expectations. However, shares slipped 2% due to a loss in the "Other Bets" category, which includes self-driving cars. Alphabet credits mobile search and YouTube for driving growth, but also notes progress in its newer investment areas and expanding revenue streams.

site_title: Instead of divesting, Trump Hotels plans expansion
summary: Trump Hotels plans to expand across the US, with CEO Eric Danziger stating the company aims to have a presence in all 26 major metropolitan areas. This move raises concerns about potential conflicts between Trump's business and presidency, with ethics experts calling for divestment. Despite this, Trump has instead reorganized his company, with his sons managing it and pledging no new foreign deals during his term. The company plans to open luxury properties in cities like Dallas, Seattle, and San Francisco, and lower-priced Scion-branded hotels in smaller cities.

site_title: Forbidden City shows broader shift in millennials' spending
summary: China's Forbidden City is embracing a shift towards experiential spending among millennials, introducing personalized gifts, virtual reality exhibits, and stories of artisanal craftsmanship to differentiate itself from mass-produced goods. The palace has partnered with tech giants like Tencent Holdings to integrate e-commerce and mobile gaming, with revenue from cultural products reaching over $1 billion in 2015. The nation's middle class is increasingly spending on culture, education, and sports, with consumption contributing 2/3 of the economy's growth last year, and services making up over half of GDP.

site_title: Five trends that will shape the future of trade in 2017
summary: The World Trade Organisation (WTO) predicts a 3.6% rise in global trade volume in 2017, with Asia expected to grow at 5.3% and account for two-thirds of global growth. Key trends shaping the future of trade include increasing e-commerce sales in the Asia-Pacific, the development of single windows and trade platforms, and growing protectionism. Emerging technologies and economies such as Indonesia, Thailand, and Vietnam are expected to drive growth, with the Indian and Chinese economies also set to expand exponentially.

site_title: Restructuring a hard slog, but it's only way to move ahead: PM
summary: Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong emphasized the need for Singapore's economy to undergo renewal to stay relevant in a uncertain global environment. The Committee for the Future Economy (CFE) has submitted a report outlining strategies for growth over the next 10-15 years, which will be implemented in this year's Budget. The Budget will address immediate economic needs and provide concrete measures to implement the CFE's proposals, aiming for 2-3% annual growth for the next decade.

site_title: Panel asks if government's structural transfers are sustainable
summary: A government report has raised concerns about the sustainability of Singapore's structural transfers, with disbursements more than doubling over 10 years. The Ministry of Finance (MOF) responded by citing higher top marginal tax rates and the inclusion of Temasek Holdings in the net investment returns framework, which aims to ensure a growing economy. MOF also pointed to the CFE's work to create jobs and grow revenues sustainably. However, the committee questioned the long-term sustainability of these transfers and their impact on future generations, citing the tough investment environment and potential lower returns on the NIR framework.

site_title: Building uncertainty, flexibility into infrastructure megaprojects
summary: Researchers are working to develop new tools for infrastructure megaprojects that consider uncertainty and flexibility, addressing the challenges of building projects with billions of dollars at stake. The concept of Real Options Analysis (ROA) has shown promising results in delivering up to 30% economic value improvement in infrastructure projects. By incorporating flexibility into project planning, decision-makers can reduce exposure to downside risk and capitalize on upside opportunities, as seen in the example of the Health Care Service Corporation building in Chicago, which was designed to accommodate additional floors. New tools are being developed to simulate scenarios and provide more readily usable solutions for infrastructure finance and project evaluation.

site_title: CRCT slashes rents at Beijing mall for two 'lifestyle' concepts
summary: CRCT, a Singaporean real estate investment trust, reported a 8.5% drop in distribution per unit (DPU) for its fourth quarter 2016 due to a weaker Chinese yuan and higher property tax. However, the company's Beijing mall, CapitaMall Xizhimen, saw a 19.7% drop in rents for new leases due to discounts for two lifestyle concepts, a bookstore with a cafe and a textile retailer. The CEO aims to keep customers in the mall longer and increase operating margins at the mall.

site_title: Commercial rent, price slide worsens in 2016
summary: Commercial rents in Singapore fell 8% in 2016, with office rents declining 8.2% and retail rents 8.3%, the steepest drops in five years. Office vacancies rose to a near five-year high, while retail vacancies fell to 7.5%. Analysts attribute the decline to subdued demand and supply pressures, but note that prices may be "stickier" due to investors seeking commercial assets, particularly offices, amid low interest rates. New supply is expected to moderate this year, with a pipeline of 786,000 sq m of office space and 595,000 sq m of retail space.

site_title: Facebook tunes trending topics to better deliver news
summary: Facebook modified its trending topics system to show headlines from articles about trending subjects, along with sources publishing those stories. The change aims to surface topics quicker, capture a broader range of news, and ensure trends reflect real-world events. The update also removes personalized topic lists and focuses on how many publishers are posting stories on a topic. This move follows pressure to stymie the spread of fake news, and comes as Google reported taking down 1.7 billion ads last year to combat "bad ads, sites, and scammers".

site_title: Using cloud innovation to take customer experience to the next level
summary: Companies are shifting their focus from human interaction to convenience and value in customer experience. With the changing role of the CIO, IT is now a top priority. Cloud innovation is key to delivering real-time personalized engagement, holistic customer data insight, and feedback. Virtual reality (VR) and augmented reality (AR) are emerging as prominent frontiers for customer experience, offering new revenue streams and individualized interactions. However, mastering these areas requires careful planning, scalability, and seamless integration of disparate data points and applications in the cloud.

site_title: The Dow has hit 20,000; now what?
summary: The Dow Jones industrial average closed above 20,000 for the first time, reaching 20,068.51, marking a significant milestone. This achievement is described by former budget chief David A. Stockman as the greatest "sucker's rally" in history. The milestone comes as the US stock market continues to experience a surge in growth, with key indicators such as Citigroup's mid-2026 target of 1,150 for MSCI's global equity index. The Dow's record-breaking close has sparked optimism among investors, despite ongoing global economic concerns and trade tensions.

site_title: Trump has 1.3 billion reasons not to pick a fight with China
summary: US President Donald Trump's repeated attacks on China risk sparking a nationalist backlash, potentially hindering future diplomatic efforts. China's 1.3 billion population and state-run media could fuel patriotism, making Xi Jinping less willing to negotiate. Past experiences, such as the 2012 anti-Japan protests, show that mass nationalism can backfire and lead to anti-government criticism. Trump's rhetoric on Taiwan and the South China Sea, considered "core interests," may prompt Xi Jinping to respond strongly, making future trade deals more challenging.

site_title: Festive films that do more than entertain
summary: Chinese New Year films this year aim to entertain while conveying messages, say stars and directors. Jackie Chan's "Kung Fu Yoga" reunites him with director Stanley Tong, featuring Chan's first Bollywood-style dance moves. Chan prioritizes making movies to thank fans, despite his busy schedule and daredevil stunts. Filmmakers Kelvin Sng and Ivan Ho, also making festive movies, emphasize creative freedom and positive messages. Sng's "The Fortune Handbook" and Ho's "Take 2" showcase the importance of teamwork and learning from veteran actors.

site_title: Trump prepares orders to reduce US role in UN and other organisations
summary: The Trump administration is preparing executive orders to drastically reduce the US role in the UN and other international organisations. Two draft orders are expected to be signed, one terminating funding for certain UN agencies and the other reviewing and potentially abrogating multilateral treaties. The orders would lead to a 40% decrease in US funding to international organisations and establish a committee to recommend where funding cuts should be made. The move is seen as a fulfillment of Trump's campaign promises to withdraw the US from international agreements and organisations.

site_title: Amazon steals Netflix's spotlight to be toast of Hollywood
summary: Amazon has secured its first-ever best picture nomination for an online video service with the film "Manchester by the Sea," which received six Oscar nominations. The film's success can be attributed to Amazon's strategy of giving motion pictures a serious run in theaters, rather than releasing them simultaneously online, as Netflix often does. This approach has helped Amazon attract more subscribers and keep them engaged, with its Prime members more likely to stick around and spend more on the site.

site_title: Sabana Reit manager strikes conciliatory tone
summary: Sabana Reit's manager, Kevin Xayaraj, struck a conciliatory tone, acknowledging the Reit's poor performance over the past three years. The Reit plans to cut costs and sell underperforming assets to stabilize its distribution per unit (DPU). Despite posting lower DPU and revenue, Xayaraj noted the Reit compared favorably to peers in its early years. The Reit manager is open to replacing itself with an in-house team and will meet with unitholders to address concerns.

site_title: SIAS urges Fincantieri to raise bid for Vard's privatisation
summary: SIAS, an investor watchdog in Singapore, is urging Italian shipbuilding group Fincantieri to raise its bid to take its Singapore-listed subsidiary, Vard Holdings, private. Fincantieri's current offer of S$0.24 per share has been criticized by SIAS, which is calling for a revision. The pressure comes as Vard Holdings' privatisation is expected to be a significant deal for Fincantieri.

site_title: Xiaomi's Barra to lead Facebook's virtual reality efforts
summary: Facebook Inc has hired Hugo Barra, former Xiaomi Corp vice-president, to lead its virtual reality efforts. Barra, who led Xiaomi's international expansion, will join Oculus VR as vice-president, leveraging his experience in building an operating system business. Facebook acquired Oculus for $2 billion in 2014, envisioning virtual reality as a social platform. Barra's appointment comes after CEO Mark Zuckerberg narrowed the role of Oculus' CEO, Brendan Iribe, and began searching for a replacement. Barra's goal is to help Oculus achieve its vision of virtual and augmented reality as the next major computing platform.

site_title: Hyundai Motor warns of trade protectionism as profit falls
summary: Hyundai Motor Co reported a 33% decline in operating profit to 1.02 trillion won in the three months ended Dec 31, citing domestic labour strife, shrinking demand in Brazil and Russia, and intensifying competition. The company warned of increasing uncertainties with trade protectionism, particularly under US President Donald Trump's administration. Despite this, Hyundai sticks to its forecast of a rebound in sales this year, with a plan to invest $3.1 billion in the US over the next five years.

site_title: US Treasury Secretary nominee backs independence for the Fed
summary: US Treasury Secretary nominee Steven Mnuchin has backed the Federal Reserve's independence, saying it can conduct monetary policy without congressional scrutiny. His comments lean away from legislation that would have subjected the Fed's decisions to greater oversight. Mnuchin's stance is seen as a nod to the Fed's current practice of independence, which has been in place since the 1913 Federal Reserve Act. The move suggests that the Trump administration may not seek to significantly alter the Fed's leadership or policies, despite the president's previous criticism of the central bank's independence.

site_title: Industrial prices, rents in 7th straight quarterly fall
summary: Singapore's industrial prices and rentals fell for a seventh consecutive quarter in Q4 2016, with industrial prices declining 3% and rentals 0.5%. For the year, prices retreated 9.1% and rentals 6.8%. Occupancy levels rose 0.4 percentage point to 89.5% in Q4, but consultants attribute the uptick to industrialists moving into new premises. Experts predict industrial prices to fall by up to 1.5% this year, and rents to stay flat initially before possibly recovering by 1-2% by year's end.

images.alt_text: Industrial prices and rentals continued their decline for a seventh consecutive quarter in the last three months of 2016.

site_title: S'pore manufacturing springs to life, hope blooms for GDP growth
summary: Singapore's manufacturing sector experienced a surprising surge in December, with factory output rising 21.3% year-on-year, a five-year high and the fifth straight month of year-on-year expansion. This has led economists to revise their predictions for the country's GDP growth, with some forecasting 2% growth for 2016 and even exceeding 2% for 2017. The sector's broad-based expansion, excluding the volatile biomedical sector, was driven by growth in the electronics and pharmaceutical clusters, and is seen as a positive sign for the country's economy, which is expected to grapple with the slowest year since the 2009 financial crisis.

site_title: STI hits new 12-month high, after Dow's peak
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) reached a 12-month high on January 26, 2017, closing 11.84 points or 0.39% higher at 3,051.78. The index's gain was driven by buoyant market sentiments, with blue chip stocks leading the way. Asian markets also rallied, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average crossing the 20,000-point mark and the S&P 500 and Nasdaq closing at all-time highs. Despite concerns over trade tensions, analysts expect economic growth momentum for most of Asia to continue in 2017.

site_title: Apple's legal fight with Qualcomm spreads to China
summary: Apple has filed lawsuits in China accusing Qualcomm of abusing its market power to demand unfair royalties for technologies not related to their chipmaking partnership. Apple claims Qualcomm charges billions of dollars for "illegal scheme" and owes the company $1 billion. The move follows a similar US court filing last week, where Apple accused Qualcomm of monopolistic practices. Qualcomm has denied the allegations, stating it will defend its business model anywhere in the world and calling Apple's actions "misrepresenting facts and withholding information."

site_title: 2016 jobs market clocks lowest growth since 2003 (Amended)
summary: Singapore's jobless rate among locals and PRs rose to 3.2% in Q4 2016, the highest since Q1 2010. Despite seasonal hirings, total employment grew by an estimated 1,900, down from a 2,700 drop in the previous quarter. This was lower than the 16,100 growth in the same period last year.

images.alt_text: Seasonal hirings for the year-end festivities helped to grow jobs in the final quarter of 2016, but by not much, as layoffs and the jobless rate rose.

site_title: J&J to buy Actelion for US$30b and spin off Swiss drugmaker's R&D unit
summary: Johnson & Johnson has agreed to buy Actelion Ltd for $30 billion and spin off the Swiss drugmaker's research and development operations. The deal, which values Actelion at $28 billion, surpasses Sanofi's earlier offer and will make J&J a leader in treating pulmonary arterial hypertension. Actelion's drugs Tracleer, Opsumit, and Uptravi will become part of J&J's portfolio, and the R&D operations will be spun off to Actelion shareholders as a new publicly traded company, with J&J retaining a 16% stake.

site_title: While the TPP door may close, others are waiting to be opened
summary: The US withdrawal from the Trans-Pacific Partnership (TPP) agreement may not be a major surprise, given the lack of support from US lawmakers and the public. While the TPP is unlikely to move forward, other regional agreements, such as the Regional Comprehensive Economic Partnership (RCEP), are being explored as alternatives. RCEP includes major economies like China, Japan, and South Korea, and could provide a platform for trilateral interactions and supply chain integration, potentially helping to boost growth in the region.

site_title: Metallica gets up close and personal
summary: Metallica's Singapore Indoor Stadium concert showcased the band's enduring legacy, despite some signs of aging. Drummer Lars Ulrich was quieter and less energetic than usual, while the rest of the band maintained their signature intensity. The concert marked a milestone in the band's three-decade-long career, with fans continuing to enthusiastically headbang to their lightning-fast thrash metal.

images.alt_text: Above: (From left) Bassist Robert Trujillo, frontman James Hetfield, guitarist Kirk Hammett and drummer Lars Ulrich of Metallica played Singapore last Sunday in support of the band's new album.
Above: Bassist Robert Trujillo, frontman James Hetfield, guitarist Kirk Hammett and drummer Lars Ulrich (above) of Metallica played Singapore last Sunday in support of the band's new album.

site_title: Vietnam turns to neighbours as Trump strikes blow to trade
summary: Vietnam is shifting its focus from the US to its Asian neighbors after the US withdrew from the Trans-Pacific Partnership, a trade deal that was expected to benefit the country the most. The country is boosting ties with countries such as South Korea, Japan, and Asean nations to diversify its exports and protect its manufacturing industry. Despite the loss, Vietnam's exports are expected to continue growing, with the nation's exports reaching a record $177 billion in 2016. The country is also exploring new trade opportunities with the European Union and prioritizing its domestic market.

site_title: Demand for HDB resale flats expected to remain strong this year
summary: Demand for HDB resale flats in Singapore is expected to remain strong this year, with 20,000 to 23,000 units predicted to be sold. Resale transactions rose 7.8% in 2016, the highest in four years, driven by stabilizing prices and new housing projects. Property consultants forecast flat prices to remain unchanged or increase marginally, with ERA predicting a 0.5% to -0.5% change in the resale price index this year.

site_title: Aussie PM says no to change of national day date
summary: Australian Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull stated that the national day date should not be changed, despite protests labeling it "Invasion Day" due to its commemoration of the arrival of British settlers in 1788. Thousands gathered to protest the date, which marks the beginning of British colonization. Turnbull emphasized that the date remains a national day of celebration, rather than a day of mourning or protest.

site_title: Trade tops the agenda as British PM goes to meet Trump
summary: British Prime Minister Theresa May is set to meet US President Donald Trump in Washington, focusing on post-Brexit trade. The meeting comes as Trump's protectionist trade regime and criticism of mainstream politics raise concerns for May. The two leaders will discuss a bilateral trade deal and other issues, including terrorism and the ongoing war in Syria. The UK is seeking a thriving economy after Brexit and a productive relationship with the Trump administration, despite wariness of Trump's controversial figure.

site_title: India looking into restarting colonial-era mines with gold deposits of US$2b
summary: India is reviving colonial-era gold mines at Kolar Gold Fields, estimated to have $2.1 billion worth of deposits, to cut its trade deficit as the world's second-largest gold importer. The state-run Mineral Exploration Corp Ltd has started exploring the reserves, and investment bank SBI Capital is assessing the finances of the defunct Bharat Gold Mines Ltd. The move aims to reduce India's $30 billion annual gold import bill, which is a mainstay of Indian culture.

site_title: Brokers take
summary: Brokers have maintained "buy" calls on Mapletree Commercial Trust (MBC) and OUE Hospitality Trust (OUEHT), citing diversification benefits and potential for growth. DBS Group Research upgraded UOB to "buy" with a target price of S$22.90, citing a controlled pace of asset quality deterioration and potential for wider net interest margins. CIMB Research maintained an "add" call on OUEHT, projecting 5.8% year-on-year distribution growth. The analysts also highlighted attractive dividend yields and potential returns.

site_title: Heineken: Deals an option as it eyes growth in Vietnam
summary: Heineken NV is considering deals to expand its presence in Vietnam, a young and beer-loving economy, as the country loosens its grip on state-run brewers. Vietnam is a key market for Heineken, with the company selling Tiger, Larue, and its own brew. The country's youthful population and beer-drinking culture make it an attractive battleground for global brewers.

site_title: A soulless flick that sputters when it should soar
summary: Ben Affleck's Prohibition-era gangster movie "Live by Night" fails to soar, despite its well-dressed characters and fine production values. The film follows Joe Coughlin, a damaged war veteran turned crime lord, but he lacks the required edge, making him an uninteresting protagonist. The narrative sputters, and the story suffers from a lack of pay-off, despite a talented cast and impressive directorial record. The film's formula, which worked in Affleck's previous film "Gone, Baby, Gone," doesn't translate to "Live by Night."

site_title: Property powers Keppel Corp as offshore & marine wanes
summary: Keppel Corp's offshore and marine (O&M) division is experiencing a multi-year downturn, leading the company to lean on its multi-business portfolio for growth. In Q4, the property division emerged as the top contributor to net profit, while O&M posted a net profit of S$29 million. The company expects a slow recovery for the offshore business, with revenue down 21.8% in Q4 and a full-year net profit of S$783.93 million, down 48.6% from the previous year. Keppel is exploring adjacent market opportunities, including the LNG value chain, and has a strong pipeline of residential units.

site_title: Eurasia's economic architecture emerging
summary: A new industrial revolution is emerging in Eurasia, driven by China's ambitious "One Belt One Road" (OBOR) and Asian Infrastructure Investment Bank (AIIB) initiatives. Academic Kent Calder predicts that China and Germany will form a major industrial production complex across the Ural Mountains, facilitated by extensive inter-modal transport networks and logistical systems. The AIIB will develop infrastructure across the continent, capitalizing on China's geographic centrality and economic scale. The project aims to integrate Europe and China, with Singapore playing a key role, and could rival US President Donald Trump's policies. The initiative is expected to have significant implications for the global economy and geopolitics, with potential benefits including increased trade and investment, job creation, and improved infrastructure.

site_title: Price of foie gras surges in Hungary due to bird flu
summary: The price of foie gras in Hungary has surged due to a bird flu outbreak, forcing farmers to cull over three million fowl, mostly geese and ducks. A kilogram of goose foie gras now costs around 13,000 forints (S$63.80) in Budapest, almost double its pre-outbreak price. The government plans to seek EU support to tackle the economic fallout, while producers are asking for a permanent EU financial support mechanism to address future crises. Output of foie gras is expected to drop by 50-60% this year due to the outbreak.

images.alt_text: A bird flu outbreak forced Hungary to cull over 3 million fowl, mostly geese and ducks.

site_title: Euro fast fashion is taking the scissors to US speciality apparel brands
summary: Euro fast fashion retailers, such as Zara and Primark, are expanding in the US, putting pressure on specialty apparel brands like J Crew, Rue21, and True Religion. The industry is experiencing a crisis, with 18 retail and apparel names listed as "very high credit risk" by Moody's Investors Service. Online shopping and cheaper prices are also contributing to the decline, with younger shoppers favoring fast fashion brands for their affordability and speed. Traditional merchants are struggling to keep pace, leading to restructurings and bankruptcies, with some retailers planning to close stores and renegotiate leases.

site_title: Dancing their way across communities (Amended)
summary: Taiwan's Cloud Gate 2, a dance company founded by Lin Hwai-min in 1999, has launched a secondary company to spread dance's joy and love. The new company aims to enable aspiring dancers and young choreographers to pursue careers in dance. Cloud Gate 2, now led by artistic director Cheng Tsung-lung, has performed in various settings, including schools and community squares, to encourage choreography and connection with audiences. The company's upcoming triple bill debut performance at the Hua Yi Festival will feature works by Cheng and choreographer Huang Yi.

site_title: SMRT rolls out Flexi cab rental amid private hire challenge
summary: SMRT, a Singaporean transportation company, has introduced the SMRT Taxi Share scheme, allowing taxi drivers to rent their vehicles on an hourly basis. This move aims to address declining rental demand for taxis amid private hire competition. Under the scheme, drivers will no longer be responsible for the vehicle's maintenance or need to find relief drivers. The initiative is part of SMRT's efforts to adapt to the changing taxi industry landscape.

images.alt_text: Under the SMRT Taxi Share scheme, cabbies can rent their taxis in three-hourly blocks which gives them an affordable short-term option.

site_title: CDLHT raises Q4 DPS by 3.3%, but warns of headwinds in hospitality sector
summary: CDL Hospitality Trusts (CDLHT) reported a 3.3% year-over-year increase in distribution per stapled security (DPS) for the fourth quarter, reaching 3.11 Singapore cents. However, the trust's gross revenue fell 3.6% to S$48.33 million, primarily due to weaker performance from Singapore and Maldives properties. Net property income (NPI) edged down 0.3% to S$37.69 million, with Australia contributing to growth and the UK experiencing negative currency translation. The trust expects a competitive operating environment in Singapore this year, but faces challenges in the hospitality sector due to economic conditions.

site_title: Beijing's hopes of globalising currency hit snag: report
summary: Beijing's efforts to globalize the Chinese yuan have hit a snag, with the currency slipping to the 6th most used global currency in 2016 due to depreciation and government capital controls. The yuan's share of international payments fell from 2.31% in 2015 to 1.68% last year, according to a report by Swift. China's slowing economy and the US dollar's spike contributed to the decline, and analysts warn that further capital controls and a weak currency may limit the yuan's global usage.

site_title: Overseas demand expected to support recovery in UK commercial property
summary: The UK commercial property market is expected to recover this year due to overseas demand, despite concerns about the impact of Brexit. The Royal Institution of Chartered Surveyors' quarterly survey showed flat investment enquiries in London's office sector and retail segment, but a second quarter of increase in UK-wide inquiries. London commercial property values are expected to stagnate, with 28% of respondents predicting a rise in property values over the next 12 months. The market's recovery is attributed to continued demand from overseas investors, with the pound's slide continuing to lure foreign investors.

images.alt_text: The HSBC tower at Canary Wharf. PM Theresa May's comments that Britain will leave the European single market have seen HSBC and UBS saying that they could each move about 1,000 jobs out of London.

site_title: Viva's Q4 DPS up on resilient business park portfolio
summary: Viva Industrial Trust (VIT) reported a 7.7% year-on-year growth in distribution per stapled security (DPS) to 1.760 Singapore cents for its fourth quarter, driven by a 27.9% rise in distributable income to S$15.9 million for the three months ended Dec 31, 2016. The resilient business park portfolio contributed to the growth, as VIT's steady income stream supported its DPS increase.

site_title: The Popo connection
summary: Po, a modern Singaporean restaurant in The Warehouse Hotel, serves a mix of traditional and fusion dishes. The restaurant's signature popiah is a highlight, with a filling that can be customized with various condiments. However, the dish often lacks the rich flavors and textures expected of traditional heritage food. Other dishes, such as kurobuta char siew, iberico pork satay, and Carabinero prawns, show promise but are marred by inconsistencies. Service is inconsistent, with some servers struggling to keep up. Despite its potential, Po falls short of its goal to create a grandmother's story worth telling, with room for improvement in its menu and service.

site_title: Bryan Adams makes it a night to remember
summary: Canadian singer-songwriter Bryan Adams delivered an unforgettable concert in Singapore, performing 30 songs to a packed Suntec hall of 5,500 fans. The 58-year-old musician showcased his raspy voice, guitar skills, and charisma, charming the audience with a mix of classics and new material from his 13th studio album, Get Up. Adams' sincerity and dedication to his craft were evident throughout the two-hour performance, which included crowd-pleasers like "Everything I Do (I Do It For You)" and "Heaven." The concert marked Adams' return to Singapore after 24 years, and fans left with an unforgettable experience.

site_title: Wine opens and frees the mind
summary: A wine enthusiast reflects on the significance of wine, stating that it's "about people." The author shares personal experiences of visiting wineries, meeting wine-makers, and tasting their wines, which evoke memories and emotions. These memories are not only tied to the wine itself but also to the people who create it. The author highlights the connections between wine, people, and memories, concluding that wine opens and frees the mind, allowing for clarity, reflection, and a deeper appreciation of life.

site_title: British economy bucks Brexit fears in Q4
summary: The UK economy grew 0.6% in Q4, beating economists' forecasts, marking 16 straight quarters of growth. The growth was driven by services, but remains reliant on one sector. Consumer spending may weaken due to inflation, and economists expect a slowdown in 2017, with forecasts of 1.2% growth. Prime Minister Theresa May plans to start EU exit talks by March, which economists warn could hurt trade.

site_title: Beijing is start point for Flying Kangaroo's great leap
summary: Qantas Airways Ltd plans to expand its international business after a three-year restructuring effort, with a focus on China as a key area of growth. The airline's revenue from international flights increased in the past two fiscal years, accounting for 29% of total revenue. Qantas is set to announce first-half results on February 23, with underlying profit before tax expected to be between A$800 million and A$850 million. The airline will also receive its first Boeing Dreamliner this year and start direct flights between Perth and London in 2018, with options to purchase additional Dreamliners.

site_title: Retail banks can swipe back in new fee paradigm for cards
summary: DBS Bank has launched a new multi-currency account tied to a Visa debit card, allowing customers to convert money into over 10 foreign currencies without incurring fees on credit card transactions. The move aims to cut into the cash transaction market, e-commerce, and foreign-exchange fee earnings, which are under threat from fintechs. DBS's strategy prioritizes transparent charges, comparable to those at money changers, to address consumers' pain of opaque transaction costs. The bank's approach could lead to a better social contract between banks and consumers, as fair and transparent fees become the norm.

site_title: Philippine economy surging despite uncertainties
summary: The Philippine economy expanded at a 6.8% growth rate in 2016, one of the fastest rates in Asia, driven by billions of dollars in Chinese investments and infrastructure spending. Despite uncertainties surrounding President Rodrigo Duterte's leadership, the government expects further growth. Key drivers include infrastructure spending, which is expected to usher in a "golden age" of development. The growth rate is seen as a positive indicator for the country's economic future, but uncertainties surrounding global trade and geopolitics may pose challenges.

site_title: China unveils fresh steps to curb capital outflows, spur inflows
summary: China's foreign exchange regulator has introduced new guidelines to curb capital outflows and boost foreign currency inflows. The guidelines, effective immediately, require banks and enterprises to comply with existing regulations and strengthen monitoring of cross-border capital flows. Firms must submit resolutions on profit distribution, tax documents, and audited financial statements for foreign exchange profits over $50,000. Domestic firms must use export proceeds to repay foreign exchange loans, and domestic banks can move overseas deposits back to China. The measures aim to promote a "healthy development" of the foreign exchange market and address the pressure on the yuan currency.

site_title: Perennial, partners sell majority stake in TripleOne Somerset for S$350m
summary: Perennial Real Estate Holdings has sold a 70% stake in TripleOne Somerset to Hong Kong-listed Shun Tak Holdings for S$350 million. The deal allows four Singapore-listed companies to recognize about S$86 million of gains. Perennial will retain a 30% share in the office and retail development, using its share of proceeds to fund existing or future investments, with an expected pre-tax gain of S$34.3 million.

site_title: Lyft cuts fares by 1 per cent, plans to add 100 new cities
summary: Lyft, the No 2 US ride-hailing company, plans to expand its cities to 300 from 200 by the end of 2017, boosting its reach to 72% of the population. The company cut fares by 1% nationally, a move attributed to the competition with Uber, which covers 75% of the US market. Lyft also introduced a tipping feature within its application, allowing drivers to earn extra income. However, drivers are bristling at the price cuts, with some expressing frustration at being forced to follow Uber's pricing strategy.

site_title: Savvy buyers zoomed in on CCR last year, URA data shows
summary: Savvy private home buyers in Singapore's Core Central Region (CCR) drove up sales by 48.7% in 2016, outperforming other areas. Compared to 27.2% and 3.7% increases in RCR and OCR, respectively. This surge in CCR sales provided some stability to prices in the region, despite a soft overall property market.

site_title: Singapore property comeback seen, boosting shares of large developers
summary: Singapore property developers are expected to see a comeback as the government may signal a reconsideration of cooling measures, boosting shares of large developers. Analysts predict a potential easing of measures in the budget speech in February, which could lead to a rebound in property prices. Shares of City Developments, CapitaLand, UOL Group, and OUE have risen following the news, with some analysts citing an "undemanding" valuation and attractive risk-reward options.

site_title: Blackstone-backed Reit faces potential roadblock to India listing: sources
summary: Embassy Group, a partner of Blackstone Group LP, faces a potential roadblock to listing the nation's first real estate investment trust in India due to disputes with investors over two of its properties. Embassy GolfLinks and Embassy Manyata Business Park, which include Rolls Royce Holdings and Microsoft as tenants, are at the center of the disagreement. The listing, valued at about $600 million, would be the first Reit in India since 2014, but a deal is on hold until the dispute is resolved.

site_title: Way is cleared for largest US offshore wind farm
summary: The Long Island Power Authority approved the nation's largest offshore wind farm, set for waters between Long Island and Martha's Vineyard. The 256 square mile farm, leased from the federal government, could power 50,000 homes with up to 200 turbines. Developed by Deepwater Wind, the project aims to meet growing electric demand in the Hamptons with renewable energy. This is the first of several planned offshore wind farms by the company.

site_title: UK government takes first step towards triggering Brexit
summary: The UK government, led by Brexit minister David Davis, has begun the process of passing a law to trigger Britain's exit from the European Union. After a top court ruling that Prime Minister Theresa May must seek parliamentary approval, Davis published legislation and introduced it to parliament. The bill will be debated for two days and then proceed to further debates. The UK's two-year exit negotiations with the EU are expected to start by the end of March, despite opposition parties' efforts to amend the legislation to reveal more details of the government's Brexit plans.

site_title: UK lawmakers given two weeks to debate short Brexit bill
summary: UK Prime Minister Theresa May's government will push a draft Brexit bill to the House of Commons within two weeks, aiming to meet a March 31 deadline. The 137-word bill, which has only two clauses, will be debated on January 31 and voted on February 1. Opposition lawmakers have criticized the short debate time, but it's unlikely to be blocked. The bill will then go to the House of Lords for further review.

site_title: UK auto investment slumps as industry warns of Brexit threat
summary: UK auto investment plummeted by over a third to £1.6 billion in 2016 due to Brexit concerns, despite a 17-year high in car production. The industry is worried about the impact of leaving the EU single market and Customs union, which could increase costs by £1.5 billion. However, the UK may benefit from free-trade arrangements with non-EU countries, with exports to the US and other countries growing. Industry leaders, including Nissan and Toyota, have voiced support for UK factories, and the government has pledged to secure favorable trade deals.

site_title: Phone software can soon help diagnose skin cancer
summary: Researchers at Stanford University have developed an image-scanning software that can distinguish between deadly skin cancers and benign ones as accurately as top dermatologists. The technology uses a Google algorithm and artificial intelligence to analyze images of skin disease and identify cancerous lesions. The software was tested on 370 images and performed equally well as a panel of 21 board-certified dermatologists. The technology could soon be incorporated into a smartphone, offering a potentially life-saving tool for early detection of skin cancer.

site_title: BP sees a future of slowing oil demand growth, abundant supplies
summary: BP's Energy Outlook 2035 report predicts oil demand growth will slow to 0.7% per year over the next two decades, with supplies remaining abundant. Producers in the Middle East, Russia, and the US will gain market share at the expense of higher-cost rivals. Electric cars, increasing energy efficiency, and renewables will affect oil demand, potentially leading to oil demand peaking in the mid-2040s. The world has enough oil reserves to meet demand two times over until 2050, and low-cost oil producers may rethink rationing production as demand growth tapers.

site_title: Dreamliner turns into rainmaker, and Boeing shares soar
summary: Boeing's shares reached an all-time high as the company posted rising profit, driven by the successful 787 Dreamliner and increased production of the 737. The company forecast higher cash and earnings, with a sales decline expected due to reduced 777 deliveries. Boeing's CEO, Dennis Muilenburg, assured analysts that order deferrals were no threat to 737 production increases and described a "very open dialogue" with President Trump regarding China. The company plans to return free cash flow to shareholders, repurchasing shares and bolstering its dividend.

site_title: EU gets tougher with its members over policing carmakers
summary: The European Commission has issued guidance to EU members on policing carmakers, aiming to crack down on cheating of diesel emissions regulations. The move comes after the Volkswagen scandal, where many cars exceeded legal pollution limits. EU officials claim member states have not taken a tough stance against the industry, and the Commission may take legal action against countries that fail to comply. The guidance clarifies existing rules, requiring carmakers to provide proof of risk and use of the latest emissions treatment technology.

site_title: Local and regional acts steal Laneway thunder
summary: The seventh St Jerome's Laneway Music Festival took place at Gardens by The Bay, despite heavy rain. The event featured local and regional acts, with attendees undeterred by the weather. The festival's artificial turf, known as The Meadow, helped to minimize the mud. The downpour persisted throughout the event, but did not dampen the mood of the crowd.

images.alt_text: Above: Japanese act Wednesday Campanella was a highlight at this year's Laneway Festival.
Above: Local shoegaze legend Astreal also impressed and made the rain worth braving.

site_title: US wage disparity took another turn for the worse last year
summary: US wage disparity worsened in 2016, with top earners making 5.05 times what the lowest-income workers took home, the widest gap since 1979. This trend reverses the slight improvement seen in 2014 and indicates a four-decade downward trend. The widening gap underscores concerns about the economy's impact on working-class voters, contributing to President Donald Trump's election victory.

images.alt_text: The picture on income inequality in America just got a little bleaker, by yet another measure.

site_title: Buyout firm Blackstone Q4 earnings beat forecasts on broad gains
summary: Blackstone Group LP, the world's largest alternative asset manager, reported a 86% increase in economic net income to $811.6 million in Q4 2016, beating forecasts. The firm's private equity investments rose 10.7%, matching the S&P 500 gain, while its real estate business saw a 11.1% gain. However, distributable earnings declined by about a fifth to $691.8 million. The firm's hedge funds reported a 3.5% gain, despite a troubled year for the business.

site_title: World's biggest wealth fund sits out liquidity trap that others fear
summary: Norway's $890 billion Government Pension Fund Global, the world's largest sovereign wealth fund, can afford to wait longer for trades due to its ability to stretch transactions over six months. The fund's chief investment officer, Geir Oivind Nygard, aims to minimize trading costs by taking his time to find natural buyers or sellers. Despite the fund's massive size, it faces challenges in bond trading due to scarce liquidity, and management costs have remained stable at 0.06 percentage point since 2015. The fund has more than tripled in size since the global financial crisis and owns 1.3% of the world's listed equities.

site_title: Toyota's red wall tested as Trump demands even more US plants
summary: US President Donald Trump is pressuring Toyota to build more US plants, amid concerns about job security in politically conservative states. Toyota, which has invested $10 billion in the US over the next five years, is seeking to reassure Trump that its existing factories will suffice. The company has built plants in states like Indiana, Kentucky, and Texas to appease Washington during icy US-Japan trade ties. Toyota's shares have dropped 4% since Trump criticized its Mexico plans, and the company is scrambling to find more to offer Trump than its factory expansion plan.

site_title: Fiat Chrysler confident after record profits in 2016
summary: Fiat Chrysler (FCA) reported record profits in 2016, with a net profit of 1.8 billion euros. The company is confident of reaching its medium-term earnings targets, despite a 4.2% surge in shares following the announcement. Sales were stable at 111 billion euros, with Jeep division sales rising 9% to 1.4 million vehicles. FCA aims to achieve revenue of 115-120 billion euros and adjusted net profit of 3-5 billion euros for 2017 and 4.7-5.5 billion euros for 2018.

site_title: Iraq says it's close to fully implementing Opec output cut
summary: Iraq is close to fully implementing its share of Opec's crude-production cuts, with Oil Minister Jabbar Al-Luaibi stating the country will have reduced output by 210,000 barrels by the end of the month. Iraq, the second-largest Opec producer, has already cut 180,000 barrels daily and will meet its full commitment, citing the need for Opec unity.

site_title: Swiss private banks see asset influx after US election: Baer CEO
summary: Swiss private banks, including Julius Baer, have experienced an influx of assets following the US presidential election of Donald Trump. CEO Boris Collardi stated that client interest in financial markets has increased, leading to rising stock markets, transaction volumes, and profits for the banks. This surge in activity is attributed to renewed optimism among clients.

images.alt_text: Swiss private banks have profited from rising stock markets and renewed client optimism since the election of US President Donald Trump, Julius Baer Chief Executive Boris Collardi said on Thursday.

site_title: Augustine Tan re-elected as Redas president
summary: Augustine Tan, 58, executive director of Far East Organization, has been re-elected as president of the Real Estate Developers' Association of Singapore (Redas) for the term 2017/2018. Tan was re-elected at the Redas' 57th annual general meeting. He is flanked by vice-presidents Liam Wee Sin of UOL Group and Chia Ngiang Hong of City Developments. Tan will be joined by honorary secretary Chong Hock Chang of Ho Bee Land and honorary treasurer Tan Swee Yiow of Keppel Land International.

site_title: UK retail sales unexpectedly shrink in January, dragged down by grocers
summary: British retail sales unexpectedly declined in January, dropping to -8 from +35 in the previous month, driven by a significant decline in grocery sales. This is the largest one-month drop in the index since 1983. Economists had forecast a smaller decline, and retailers expect sales to rebound in February. The decline is attributed to cost pressures from the near 20% decline in sterling against the US dollar, which may lead to higher inflation and squeeze household incomes.

site_title: Dollar gains capped by concerns over Trump policies
summary: The US dollar rose against the yen and euro on Thursday but was capped by concerns over President Donald Trump's policies. Despite expectations of stronger economic growth, investors remained cautious due to concerns about protectionism, geopolitical issues, and Trump's approach to social issues. Speculators cut their bets on a stronger dollar, and the dollar index remained flat at 100.01. Sterling was the biggest gainer among developed world currencies, rising almost 6% over the past fortnight.

images.alt_text: The dollar rose against the yen and euro on Thursday but the prospect of stronger US economic growth was not enough to drive the currency significantly higher as the weight of bets on a stronger greenback made some investors nervous.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary:
Here is a 100-word or less summary of the article content:

Three Singaporean real estate investment trusts (REITs) reported Q4 2016 financial results. Mapletree Greater China Commercial Trust (MGCCT) saw a 0.076 cent decrease in distribution per unit to 1.778 cents. OUE Commercial Reit posted a 13.2% decline in DPU to 1.18 cents. Frasers Hospitality Trust's distribution per stapled security fell 18.9% to 1.3258 cents due to an enlarged stapled security base. Meanwhile, OUE Commercial Reit's net property income increased 17.3% to S$34.82 million. The results were impacted by various factors, including one-off distributions and changes in revenue.

site_title: Eight other companies found to have tweaked their charters to allow dual-class shares
summary: Singapore Exchange (SGX) has reminded eight listed companies, including Chew's Group, that amending their constitutions to allow dual-class shares (DCS) is premature. The companies, which include Fraser & Neave, Frasers Centrepoint, and AsiaMedic, had amended their constitutions to enable the issuance of shares with varied voting rights despite the SGX's Listing Rules prohibiting such structures. The SGX has not yet adopted the practice, and listed companies are barred from issuing more than one class of shares. The regulator has warned that premature amendments may risk misalignment between companies' constitutions and the Listing Rules.

site_title: Malaysia: Stocks end 8 points higher
summary: Malaysian shares rose 8.29 points to close at 1,692.220, with 1.40 billion lots valued at RM1.75 billion traded. Losers outnumbered gainers 432 to 308.

site_title: Indonesian anti-graft agency detains Constitutional Court judge
summary: Indonesia's anti-corruption agency, the Corruption Eradication Commission (KPK), has detained Constitutional Court judge Patrialis Akbar on suspicion of graft. The judge will be suspended from duty and possibly sacked if found guilty. This move comes amid concerns over bribery scandals within the judiciary, which was once regarded as a model of integrity. The detention has sparked concerns over the independence of the Constitutional Court, which has been rocked by corruption scandals in recent years.

site_title: Flash: Sias calls on Fincantieri to revise offer for Vard
summary: Sias Investment Corporation is calling on Fincantieri to revise its offer for Vard, a Norwegian shipbuilding company. No further details are provided in the article.

site_title: China's FX regulator announces latest steps to keep cash at home
summary: China's State Administration of Foreign Exchange (Safe) has announced measures to stem capital outflows and bolster the yuan, following a record global shopping spree by Chinese firms abroad last year. The regulator will require companies to clarify funding sources and provide additional details on spending plans for outbound investments. It will also allow repatriation of offshore loans secured by domestic guarantees and settlement of foreign exchange loans for cargo trade transactions. The measures aim to plug loopholes in capital outflows and encourage inflows while tightening regulation to curb outflows, amid a weakening currency and US Federal Reserve tightening.

site_title: Hong Kong leadership favourite testifies in corruption trial
summary: Carrie Lam, a top candidate to lead Hong Kong, testified in a corruption trial of former Hong Kong leader Donald Tsang, who faces misconduct and bribery charges. Lam described Tsang as her "role model" and denied knowledge of his alleged corrupt dealings. Tsang has pleaded not guilty to three charges, each carrying a maximum seven-year jail sentence. The trial comes amid public distrust of Hong Kong's elites, with corruption cases fueling suspicions of cosy links between authorities and business leaders. Lam is widely seen as Beijing's favourite candidate to lead the city.

site_title: MGCCT's Q3 DPU falls to 1.778 cents
summary: Mapletree Greater China Commercial Trust (MGCCT) reported a Q3 DPU of 1.778 cents, down 0.076 cents from the same period last year. The decline was attributed to the inclusion of value added tax and incremental property tax for Gateway Plaza in Beijing. Gross revenue decreased by 0.5% to S$87.83 million. The lower revenue was a result of the increased tax burden.

site_title: US: Stocks open flat a day after hitting records
summary: US stocks opened flat on Thursday, a day after hitting a record high of 20,070.16 on the Dow Jones Industrial Average, as traders weigh profits and earnings reports from major companies. The S&P 500 dipped 0.1% and the Nasdaq Composite rose 0.1%, despite mixed reactions to earnings reports and guidance from companies like Ford and Bristol-Myers Squibb. Johnson & Johnson fell 0.7% after announcing a $30 billion acquisition of Actelion.

site_title: Qatar investment in Russia to bolster Opec, non-Opec ties
summary: Qatar's Qatar Investment Authority and Glencore have acquired a 19.5% stake in Russia's Rosneft, strengthening ties between Opec and non-Opec oil producers. This investment project is seen as a strategic move to bolster cooperation on hydrocarbon production and follows a joint production cut agreement between Russia and Opec. Russian President Vladimir Putin expressed confidence in the partnership, stating it would further strengthen Opec and non-Opec relations. The deal is part of Qatar's efforts to bolster its influence in the oil market.

site_title: Cosco Corp says trading suspension will continue
summary: Cosco Corp, a Chinese shipbuilder, has announced that its trading suspension will continue due to uncertainty over its parent company's restructuring plans. The plans, which affect China Cosco Shipping Corporation's shipyard businesses, are advancing, according to the company. Cosco Corp will continue to inquire about the status of the restructuring and evaluate the situation. The trading suspension was initially requested on December 20, 2016.

site_title: Latest Earnings
summary:
Here's a 100-word or less summary of the article content:

NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer was oversubscribed 9.8 times. Creative Technology warned of potentially lower H2 revenue and similar operating loss compared to H1. London's Heathrow is considering higher fees for a £10 billion upgrade. Indonesia detained a Trafigura employee in a 285 trillion rupiah graft case. OCBC's incoming CEO, Tan Teck Long, is a former DBS veteran. The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) and the People's Bank of China (PBOC) plan to deepen cooperation in green and transition finance. Singapore stocks experienced a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data release.

site_title: Quick takes: Stunning Dec PMI shows positive turn, but anti-trade policies worrisome
summary: Singapore's manufacturing output surged 21.3% in December, its best monthly performance in over two years, driven by strong electronics and biomedical sectors. The increase was double expectations and excludes the volatile biomedical sector, which still rose 16.1%. Analysts attribute the growth to a low base in 2015 and a positive global inventory cycle. However, economists warn of concerns from anti-trade policies, particularly the US and EU's potential implementation of import tariffs on Chinese goods, which could impact Singapore's exports.

site_title: Jack Ma's Ant Financial close to buying MoneyGram
summary: Ant Financial, an Alibaba affiliate controlled by billionaire Jack Ma, is close to buying US money-transfer service MoneyGram International Inc for an undisclosed price. The deal would give Ant Financial a significant foothold in the US market, allowing it to expand its services beyond China. MoneyGram has a market value of $630 million and is partnered with major retailers such as Wal-Mart. Ant Financial has been investing abroad and exploring a public market debut in 2017, and the acquisition would further solidify its position in the global online finance market.

site_title: Starhill Global Reit's Q2 DPU slips to 1.26 cents
summary: Starhill Global Reit reported a 8.5% decline in distributable income to S$27.5 million for Q2 2016, resulting in a distribution per unit (DPU) of 1.26 Singapore cents, down from 1.32 cents in the previous year. Gross revenue and net property income also fell, with decreases of 2.8% and 5.4%, respectively. The decline was attributed to lower contributions from some properties.

site_title: OUE C-Reit's Q4 DPU down 13.2% at 1.18 cents
summary: OUE C-Reit reported a 13.2% decline in distribution per unit (DPU) to 1.18 Singapore cents for Q4 2016, down from 1.36 cents in the same period last year. Net property income rose 17.3% to S$34.82 million, while revenue increased 11.6% to S$45.02 million. The company attributed the decline in DPU to a one-off capital return distribution. Despite this, OUE C-Reit expects a stable performance from Lippo Plaza and a subdued rental outlook in Singapore's CBD.

site_title: Kwek Leng Beng to retire from Hong Leong Asia due to other commitments
summary: Singapore property tycoon Kwek Leng Beng is retiring from Hong Leong Asia (HLA) due to other commitments. Beng, 75, has been a director since 1981 and non-executive chairman since 1995. His cousin, Kwek Leng Peck, will succeed him as executive chairman following the company's annual general meeting in April. HLA credits Beng's contributions to its growth from a building materials supplier to a major manufacturing and distribution player. Beng's retirement marks the end of a 34-year tenure at the company.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares end up for fourth day
summary: Hong Kong stocks surged for a fourth consecutive day, with the Hang Seng Index jumping 1.41% to 23,374.17. The global advance and record finish on Wall Street contributed to the gains. The Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also rose, with the latter adding 0.70%. The rally comes despite US trade uncertainty and tariff threats.

site_title: Marina Bay Sands' Q4 profit up 8% at US$366m
summary: Marina Bay Sands reported a 8% year-on-year net profit of US$366 million for Q4 2016, driven by increased contributions from its casino, hotel, and mall. Revenue rose 2.8% to US$723 million, with casino revenue up 5.6% and slot handle increasing 1.8%. Room revenue grew 8% and mall revenue rose 4.8%. The casino's VIP segment win percentage was within expected range, while rolling chip volume declined 18.4%.

images.alt_text: MARINA Bay Sands (MBS) turned in a net profit of US$366 million for the three months ended Dec, 31, 2016, up 8 per cent year on year, boosted by stronger contributions from its casino, hotel and the mall.

site_title: UK economy shows no sign of post-Brexit vote slowdown in late 2016
summary: The UK economy maintained its robust momentum in the final three months of 2016, with gross domestic product rising at a quarterly rate of 0.6%, beating expectations of a slowdown. The economy grew 2.2% in 2016, slightly faster than expected, driven by strong consumer spending. However, growth is expected to slow in 2017 due to the impact of sterling's fall on inflation and consumer spending power. The Bank of England has forecast growth will slow to 1.4% this year as inflation exceeds 2.7% by the end of the year.

site_title: Frasers Hospitality Trust's DPS down on enlarged stapled security base
summary: Frasers Hospitality Trust's distribution per stapled security (DPS) fell 18.9% year-on-year to 1.3258 Singapore cents due to an enlarged stapled security base following a recent rights issue. Despite a 3.1% year-on-year increase in distribution income to S$24.4 million, revenue and net property income (NPI) rose 26.1% and 15.9% respectively. The trust's NPI margin slid 6.7 percentage points to 77.1%. Despite this, the CEO expressed optimism over the company's balance sheet and growth opportunities.

images.alt_text: EVEN as Frasers Hospitality Trust's (FHT) distribution income grew in the first quarter of FY2017, it posted a fall in distribution per stapled security (DPS) due to an enlarged stapled security base following recent rights issue.

site_title: Keppel Corp's Q4 profit plunges 65% to S$143m
summary: Keppel Corp's Q4 profit fell 65% to S$143m, down from a year ago, due to lower contributions from the offshore and marine division and additional provisions for impairment. Earnings per share dropped to 7.9 cents from 22.3 cents. The company disclosed S$313m in provisions for impairment, mainly related to Keppel Offshore & Marine's rightsizing and investments.

site_title: RBS to take £$3.1b charge tied to US mortgage probe
summary: Royal Bank of Scotland (RBS) will take a £3.1 billion (US$5.55 billion) charge in its fourth-quarter results due to a US probe into mortgage securities sales. The bank is cooperating with the US Department of Justice and has taken £6.7 billion in provisions for 15 mortgage investigations. Further charges may be needed, with RBS considering provisions based on Deutsche Bank's and Credit Suisse's settlements. The charge reflects the bank's legacy of pre-crisis decisions, with CEO Ross McEwan stating it's a "heavy price for decisions made before the crisis."

site_title: Microsoft to continue to invest over US$1b a year on cyber security
summary: Microsoft plans to invest over $1 billion annually in cyber security research and development, according to Bharat Shah, Microsoft vice president of security. This investment is part of the company's focus on cloud security, where it competes with Amazon.com. Microsoft has also made significant acquisitions in the sector, including three Israeli security firms, and has invested in various start-ups. The company aims to improve user authentication methods, such as Windows Hello, and explore deception technology to detect attacks.

images.alt_text: US software firm Microsoft Corp will continue to invest over US$1 billion annually on cyber security research and development in the coming years, a senior executive said.

site_title: Singapore shares close 11.84 points higher on Thursday
summary: Singapore shares rose 11.84 points, or 0.39%, to 3,051.78 on Thursday, driven by DBS Bank, Singtel, and OCBC Bank. The Straits Times Index (STI) closed on a firm note, with a volume of 2.3 billion units worth S$1.3 billion. The rally comes after the Dow Jones Industrial Average hit a historic high, following US President Donald Trump's pro-growth agenda. Gainers outnumbered losers 245 to 183, as investors remained positive despite tariff uncertainty.

site_title: Trade tops agenda as British PM heads to meet Trump
summary: British Prime Minister Theresa May met US President Donald Trump, focusing on post-Brexit trade. May aims to establish a thriving economy after the UK leaves the EU. Trump's anti-establishment views and calls for protectionist trade policies may pose challenges for May. The meeting is closely watched for clues on Trump's foreign policy, with trade being a top agenda item.

images.alt_text: British Prime Minister Theresa May headed to the United States on Thursday where she will be the first foreign leader to meet President Donald Trump, with post-Brexit trade top of the agenda.

site_title: US new home sales hit post-crisis record in 2016
summary: US new home sales reached a post-crisis record in 2016, with a total of 563,000 new homes sold, the highest since 2007. Despite a 10.4% decline in December, sales closed out the year at the fastest pace since before the 2008 financial crisis. The median sales price for new houses sold in December was $332,500, and the supply of new houses for sale stood at 5.8 months. This marks a slowdown in the housing market, with existing home sales also slowing in December.

site_title: Barclays veteran Andy Jones to step down as Asia-Pacific chief
summary: Barclays Asia-Pacific CEO Andy Jones is stepping down, with Jaideep Khanna and Reid Marsh set to replace him as co-heads in the region. Jones will leave in the first half of this year and take on a temporary role as vice chairman. The change follows a memo obtained by Bloomberg, which also reported the news earlier to The Financial Times.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's local employment grew modestly in 2016, while foreign employment contracted, according to the Ministry of Manpower.
