Manufacturing output surged 21.3% year-on-year in December, its best monthly performance in two years. Resident unemployment and redundancies increased, raising concerns. The Urban Redevelopment Authority reported a 0.5% decline in private home prices and a 11.1% office vacancy rate in 2016. The Singapore Stock Exchange closed 0.39% higher on Thursday, boosted by a pro-growth US agenda.

site_title: Credit Suisse said to consider Dublin expansion as Brexit nears
summary: Credit Suisse is exploring options to expand in Dublin as the UK moves closer to exiting the EU. The bank is considering Dublin and Frankfurt as locations for its back-office jobs, aiming to adapt to Brexit's implications. Credit Suisse's Dublin operation is its primary hub for servicing hedge funds in Europe, and the bank is seeking "passporting" rights to do business within the EU. The bank's executives are refining their analysis of various Brexit outcomes and exploring solutions, but have not yet chosen a preferred location.

site_title: China may be developing new long-range air-to-air missile
summary: China may be developing a long-range air-to-air missile with a potential range of 400 km, surpassing those used by Western air forces. The missile, reportedly carried by the J-11B fighter, could target early warning aircraft and aerial refueling aircraft. This development is part of China's ambitious military modernization program, overseen by President Xi Jinping. The missile's capabilities would significantly improve China's air defense, but the military has yet to confirm its existence.

site_title: Europe: Shares hit 1-year high on M&A deal
summary: European shares reached a one-year high on Thursday, driven by a US$30 billion deal between Johnson & Johnson and Swiss biotech firm Actelion. Actelion's shares surged 20% after the all-cash acquisition, giving J&J access to high-margin medicines for rare diseases. Positive earnings reports from STMicroelectronics and other companies also contributed to the market's gain, with the pan-European STOXX 600 index rising 0.6% and Germany's DAX reaching its highest level since May 2015.

site_title: Ericsson slashes dividend, posts loss in Q4
summary: Ericsson slashed its 2016 dividend by 73% to 1.00 Swedish crown, posting a Q4 operating loss of 300 million crowns. Sales were 65.2 billion crowns, above forecast, but gross margin was 26.1%, below mean forecast. The company attributed the weak network market and lower-than-expected operating income.

site_title: J&J to buy Actelion for US$30b, spin off research unit
summary: Johnson & Johnson agreed to buy Actelion Ltd for $30 billion and spin off its research unit to create a new publicly traded company. The deal, valued at $280 per share, will give J&J a leading position in treating rare high blood pressure. The purchase will also provide access to Actelion's life-threatening pulmonary arterial hypertension treatments. The R&D operations will be spun off to Actelion shareholders, with J&J retaining a 16% stake. The deal marks J&J's largest acquisition and comes after weeks of negotiations.

site_title: Sterling hits 6-week highs as traders eye GDP data
summary: Sterling reached a six-week high of US$1.2663 against the dollar, its strongest since Dec 14, as investors awaited UK GDP data showing a modest slowdown in the economy at the end of last year. The pound is on track for an almost four percent fortnightly rise, its strongest performance since 2009. Despite being 15 percent weaker against the dollar since the Brexit vote, sterling has been more modestly affected against the euro, with a 10 percent decline since the vote. Economists expect the GDP data to show 2.1 percent year-on-year growth.

site_title: Seoul: Won ends at 7 week high on broad US dollar weakness; stocks rise
summary: The South Korean won reached a 7-week high at 1,159.2 to the US dollar due to broad US dollar weakness. South Korean shares rose 0.8% to 2,083.59 points, with foreign investors buying 349.2 billion won worth of Kospi shares. This follows a strong performance in US stocks, which also contributed to the market's gain.

site_title: Unilever ends the year with sales growth below estimates
summary: Unilever reported lower-than-expected fourth-quarter sales, with underlying sales rising 2.2% compared to analysts' 2.8% average expectation. Full-year sales growth was 3.7%, below the 3.9% analysts predicted. The company attributed the decline to demonetization in India and an economic slowdown in Brazil, with growth expected to rebound in the second half of 2017.

site_title: Rickmers to take US$31.6m charge after selling vessel to pay down loan
summary: Rickmers Maritime Trust's manager has signed a memorandum of understanding to sell vessel Kaethe C Rickmers, expected to take a US$31.6 million impairment loss in Q4 2016. The sale proceeds will be used to pay secured vessel operating costs and partially prepay a senior loan facility. The vessel is secured by HSH Nordbank and DBS Bank.

site_title: Saudi builder Khodari says delayed projects at 312.7m riyals end-2016
summary: Saudi Arabian construction firm Abdullah Abdul Mohsin al-Khodari and Sons reported a total value of delayed projects as of Dec 31, 2016, at 312.7 million riyals (S$117.9 million). The company estimated its backlog of uncompleted work at 2.85 billion riyals, with a total contract value of 7.85 billion riyals. This marks a significant increase in the company's delayed projects, highlighting the challenges faced by the construction industry in Saudi Arabia.

site_title: URA private home price index slips 0.5% q-o-q in Q4 2016; rental index also slides
summary: The Urban Redevelopment Authority's private home price index fell 0.5% in Q4 2016, a smaller decline than the 1.5% drop in Q3 2016. For the year, prices dropped 3.1%, with landed properties decreasing by 4.5% and non-landed properties by 2.6%. The rental index also declined 1% quarter-over-quarter, with private home rentals falling 4% for the year. Sales of private homes increased, with 7,972 units sold in 2016, while resale transactions rose to 7,901.

site_title: Japan PM says free trade talks with US possible
summary: Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe has stated that free trade talks with the US are possible, following US President Donald Trump's withdrawal from the Trans-Pacific Partnership. Abe emphasized the importance of the Economic Partnership Agreement and Free Trade Agreement with the US, despite Trump's claim that the TPP would harm American jobs and investment. Abe's comments come as Japan continues to stress the US on the importance of the TPP.

images.alt_text: Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe said on Thursday it was possible Tokyo and Washington could hold bilateral free trade talks in the wake of US President Donald Trump's withdrawal from the Trans-Pacific Partnership (TPP) this week.

site_title: Singapore sees lowest total employment growth since 2003: MOM
summary: Singapore's total employment grew modestly in 2016, increasing by 16,400 or 0.4% to 4.07 million, the lowest growth since 2003. Local employment rose 10,700 or 0.5% in services sectors, while foreign employment contracted -2,500 or -0.2%. Redundancies increased to 19,000, and the unemployment rate rose to 2.2% in the fourth quarter.

images.alt_text: Local employment in Singapore grew modestly in 2016, while foreign employment contracted, the Ministry of Manpower said on Thursday.

site_title: China keeps 3% budget deficit goal for 2017 as debt risks grow: sources
summary: China's policymakers plan to maintain a 3% budget deficit target for 2017, as outlined at the Central Economic Work Conference in December. This goal aims to reduce debt risks while supporting economic growth through public-private partnership infrastructure projects. Despite this, there is room to increase fiscal stimulus if needed, according to sources. The decision underscores a focus on debt reduction and reform, following a year where government investment supported economic activity.

site_title: Seoul: Won jumps to 11-week high as US dollar slumps, stocks gain
summary: South Korea's won jumped to an 11-week high against the US dollar, reaching 1,158.9, amid uncertainty over US President Trump's fiscal policies and a slump in the US dollar. The won's gain was attributed to dollar-selling by local exporters and offshore investors buying Kospi shares, with the Korea Composite Stock Price Index (Kospi) rising 0.9%. Finance Minister Yoo Il-Ho advised monitoring the exchange rate, while market analysts expect the US Federal Reserve's policy meeting to impact the dollar.

site_title: New Zealand: Shares end higher supported by telecom stocks
summary: New Zealand's benchmark S&P/NZX 50 index rose 0.3% to a three-month high, driven by gains in telecommunications firms. Spark New Zealand led the way, closing 1.4% higher, while Air New Zealand fell 3.6%. The New Zealand dollar reached a ten-week high after inflation data showed an annual rate of 1.3%, slightly higher than economists' estimates. The Australian stock market was closed due to Australia Day.

site_title: Japan: Nikkei hits near 3-week high on Wall Street gains
summary: Japan's Nikkei share average surged 1.8% to 19,402.39, a near three-week high, driven by Wall Street gains and rising US yields. The broader Topix and JPX-Nikkei Index 400 also advanced, with the Nikkei reaching its highest closing level since January 6. The gains followed a strong showing on US stock markets, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq edging to fresh records despite ongoing US-EU trade talks.

site_title: Facebook hires Xiaomi's Barra to lead virtual reality efforts
summary: Facebook has hired Hugo Barra, former Xiaomi executive, to lead its virtual reality efforts as vice-president. Barra, who previously oversaw Xiaomi's international expansion, will utilize his experience in operating system development and hardware branding to help Oculus gain dominance in the competitive virtual reality market. This move comes just days after Barra's departure from Xiaomi.

images.alt_text: Facebook Inc hired Hugo Barra to lead its virtual reality efforts just days after he quit Chinese smartphone maker Xiaomi Corp.

site_title: Apple legal fight with Qualcomm spreads to China
summary: Apple has filed lawsuits in China accusing Qualcomm of illegally wielding monopoly power. The tech giant claims Qualcomm unfairly charges royalties for technologies it has nothing to do with. This move comes after Apple filed an antitrust suit against Qualcomm in the US last week. The Chinese lawsuits follow a similar pattern to the US case, alleging Qualcomm's practices stifle competition and harm consumers. Apple is seeking to stop Qualcomm's alleged monopolistic behavior and is referring to comments made when the US case was filed.

site_title: Flash: URA private home price index fall 0.5% q-o-q in Q4 2016; rental index eases 1%
summary: Singapore's private home price index fell 0.5% quarter-over-quarter in Q4 2016, while the rental index eased 1%. These results are in contrast to previous quarters.

site_title: Viva Industrial Trust's Q4 DPS up 7.7%
summary: Viva Industrial Trust reported a 7.7% year-on-year increase in distribution per stapled security to 1.760 Singapore cents for its fourth quarter ended Dec 31, 2016. The trust's distributable income rose 27.9% to S$15.9 million, driven by a 29.8% increase in gross revenue to S$25.57 million and a 31.7% rise in net property income to S$18.08 million.

site_title: China: Markets closed one week for Lunar New Year holiday
summary: China's stock and bond markets will be closed from January 27 to February 2 for the Lunar New Year holiday. Markets will resume trading on February 3.

site_title: Philippine Q4 GDP growth slows slightly to 6.6% y-o-y, tops expectations
summary: The Philippine economy grew 6.6% in the fourth quarter of 2016, slightly slower than expected. This brings the full-year growth to 6.8%. The September quarter saw an annual growth of 7.0%. Economists forecast 6.5% growth for the last three months of 2016, with a median forecast of 1.6% quarterly growth.

site_title: Asia: Markets rally further after Wall St records
summary: Asian markets rallied further on Thursday following another record close on Wall Street, with Tokyo leading the surge. The Dow hit a historic milestone, and investors regained optimism over President Donald Trump's pro-growth agenda. Earnings reports from big-name firms, including Boeing and United Technologies, also boosted the market. Asian markets closed higher, with Tokyo up 1.4%, Hong Kong adding 1.2%, and Shanghai gaining 0.3%.

site_title: Trump nominates businessman with Asia background as Navy secretary
summary: US President Donald Trump nominated Philip Bilden, a former military intelligence officer and private equity executive with Asia background, as the civilian head of the US Navy. Bilden's nomination aims to build up the US Navy to 350 ships to counter China's rapid rise as a military power in the Asia-Pacific. The move follows Trump's vow to prevent China from taking over territory in the South China Sea, potentially worsening tensions with China. Bilden's nomination must be confirmed by the US Senate, despite lacking government experience.

site_title: Trump campaign against bureaucracy alarms federal workers
summary: US President Donald Trump has signed an executive order instituting a 90-day hiring freeze for federal officials, except for the military. The move is part of his efforts to reduce the federal bureaucracy, citing "waste, fraud, and abuse." The freeze may affect tens of thousands of jobs, and is expected to have a significant impact on the 2.1 million-strong federal workforce. The measure has sparked concern among federal workers, with some describing it as "dumb" and "unnecessary." The White House claims the cost of providing health and retirement benefits is "unsustainable" and wants to "drain the swamp" of corruption in Washington.

site_title: Flash: HDB resale price index down 0.1 % q-o-q in Q4 2016
summary: The HDB resale price index in Singapore decreased by 0.1% on a quarterly basis in Q4 2016, marking a slight drop. However, the number of HDB resale flat transactions increased by 7.8% in 2016. This mixed trend indicates that while resale prices may be softening, there is still strong demand for HDB flats.

site_title: Number of HDB resale flat transactions up 7.8% in 2016
summary: The Housing & Development Board (HDB) reported a 7.8% increase in HDB resale flat transactions in 2016, with 20,813 cases. The resale flat price index dropped 0.1% for the full year. The number of resale applications registered dropped 9.1% to 5,012 cases in Q4 2016. HDB also saw a 1% increase in sublet flats to 52,941 as of the end of 2016. The board will offer approximately 17,000 new flats for sale in Build-To-Order exercises this year.

site_title: Industrial prices, rents continue decline in Q4, but occupancies inch up: JTC
summary: Singapore's industrial prices and rents declined 3% and 0.5% respectively in Q4 2016, with prices and rentals falling 9.1% and 6.8% for the full year. Occupancy levels rose 0.4 percentage points to 89.5% in Q4, but remain 1.1% lower than last year. The state industrial landlord, JTC, attributes the decline to increased supply, with 2.4 million sq m of new space expected to come online in 2017. This is likely to further pressure occupancy rates, prices, and rentals, reducing business costs for industrialists.

site_title: CapitaLand Retail China Trust to pay S$0.0237/unit as Q4 property income dips
summary: CapitaLand Retail China Trust reported a 1.5% dip in Q4 2016 property income to S$34.8 million, with a payout of 2.37 Singapore cents per unit. The full-year net property income declined 1% to S$139.7 million, and full-year income available for distribution fell 2.8% to S$86.7 million.

site_title: Quick takes: Unemployment rate for Singapore citizens lacklustre at 6-year high
summary: Singapore's headline unemployment rate for the fourth quarter of 2016 rose to 2.2% from 2.1% in September 2016. This marked a 6-year high. 5,300 workers were laid off in the fourth quarter, similar to a year ago. Local employment increased by 0.5%, while foreign employment (excluding foreign domestic workers) contracted by 0.2% for the first time since 2009.

site_title: NZ dollar rises on inflation data, Aussie flat in lean trade
summary: The New Zealand dollar rose to a 10-week high of US$0.7314 after the country's inflation data showed a 1.3% annual increase in the fourth quarter, meeting the central bank's target range for the first time in two years. This prompted a market reaction, with the currency and local interest rates increasing. The Australian dollar remained flat despite the neighboring country's national holiday. The stronger-than-expected inflation data was attributed to a "decent market reaction" with both the currency and local interest rates pushed higher.

site_title: Singapore shares open firmer, STI up 0.3%
summary: Singapore stocks opened higher, with the Straits Times Index advancing 0.3% to 3,048.98. The blue chips, particularly banks, led the way with gains of 0.7% each. OCBC and DBS Group Holdings rose 7 and 13 Singapore cents respectively. Gainers outnumbered losers 86 to 29, with 61.4 million shares changing hands. The rally follows a 5-day streak ahead of GDP data.

site_title: Office, retail rents down over 8% in 2016; office vacancies jump to 11.1%: URA (Amended)
summary: Office and retail rents in Singapore dropped 8% in 2016, the largest decline since 2009. Office vacancies rose to 11.1%, a four-year high since 2012, while retail vacancies fell to 7.5%. Office rents fell 1.8% in the fourth quarter, while retail rents declined 1.2%. The declines were steeper than the previous year, with office prices down 2.8% and retail prices down 5.4%.

site_title: Kia Motors Q4 profit slumps amid strikes
summary: Kia Motors reported a 25.7% decline in Q4 net profit to 320 billion won (S$390.6 million) due to labour strikes, which resulted in the loss of over 100,000 cars to missed production. The strikes significantly impacted the company's fourth-quarter profits.

site_title: Singapore's December factory output surges 21.3% year-on-year
summary: Singapore's manufacturing output surged 21.3% year-on-year in December, its best monthly performance in at least two years, according to data from the Economic Development Board. This exceeded market expectations, which had forecast a 9.5% year-on-year increase. Excluding the volatile biomedical sector, output rose 16.1%. The strong performance suggests a positive outlook for the country's manufacturing sector.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open flat on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened flat on Thursday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index up 0.390 point to 1684.850. A total of 63.07 million lots were traded, worth RM19.82 million. Gainers outnumbered losers 101 to 49.

site_title: Trump's call for probe of voter fraud sparks backlash
summary: US President Donald Trump announced his intention to investigate alleged voter fraud in the November 2016 election, despite no evidence of widespread fraud. Trump claimed 3-5 million illegal immigrants voted, a claim rejected by state officials and election experts. The move drew criticism from both Republicans and Democrats, who warned it could undermine voting rights and confidence in the new administration. Trump's attorney general nominee, Jeff Sessions, has faced criticism for his record on voting rights and race relations.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open higher after Dow closes above 20,000
summary: Tokyo stocks opened higher on January 26, 2017, after the Dow Jones closed above 20,000 points, boosting hopes for pro-growth US policies under President Donald Trump. The Nikkei 225 index rose 1.02% to 19,252.62, while the Topix index increased 1.03% to 1,537.29.

site_title: China eyes stabilising role in call with Germany's Merkel
summary: Chinese Premier Li Keqiang called for China and Germany to play a leading role in stabilizing international markets during a call with Chancellor Angela Merkel, citing "uncertain" global factors. China aims to send stable signals and jointly safeguard the international system through trade and investment liberalization. This comes amid a turbulent start to US President Donald Trump's term, marked by media feuds and trade curbs, including a border tax on cars. China also reaffirmed its support for European integration amidst Brexit pressure.

site_title: Flash: Retail rents slipped 1.2%, prices inched up 0.2% in Q4, says URA
summary: Retail rents in Singapore slipped 1.2% in Q4, while prices inched up 0.2%. This marks a reversal from the previous quarter, with office and retail rents down over 8% in 2016. Office vacancies increased to 11.1%. The URA report also noted that the benchmark for prime projects above S$3,000 psf is under test with a Q3 wave of condo launches.

site_title: Lyft cuts fares 1%, plans to add 100 new cities
summary: Lyft Inc, the No 2 US ride-hailing company, plans to expand its network to 300 cities by the end of 2016, cutting prices by 1% nationally. This move aims to attract more customers and increase its market share, which currently reaches 55% of the US population. Lyft's expansion begins with the addition of 40 cities, with the goal of increasing its coverage to 72% of the population. The company's efforts come as it competes with Uber, which covers over 75% of the US market.

site_title: Hong Kong equities open higher after Wall Street record
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose 0.48% to 23,160.35, extending a fourth-day rally, following a record close on Wall Street. The benchmark Shanghai Composite Index remained flat ahead of a Lunar New Year break. The rally comes despite US trade tensions and uncertainty.

site_title: Flash: Office rents fell 1.8%, prices down 0.6% in Q4, says URA
summary: Office rents in Singapore fell 1.8% and prices dropped 0.6% in Q4, according to the Urban Redevelopment Authority (URA). This marks a decline of over 8% in office rents for 2016, with office vacancies reaching 11.1%. The Q4 drop is attributed to a decrease in demand.

site_title: CDL Hospitality Trusts to pay S$0.0311/unit in Q4; net property income falls 0.3%
summary: CDL Hospitality Trusts reported a 0.3% decline in Q4 net property income to S$37.69 million, but distribution per unit increased 3.3% to 3.11 Singapore cents. The trust saw a 0.4% increase in full-year net property income to S$137.5 million. Despite the Q4 decline, the trust's distribution per unit rose for the second consecutive quarter.

site_title: South Korea to boost economic cooperation with China amid Thaad concerns
summary: South Korea plans to boost economic cooperation with China amid growing concerns over China's retaliation for South Korea's deployment of a US anti-missile system, known as Thaad. The government will expand communication and meetings with Chinese businesses and officials to resolve difficulties faced by South Korean companies in China. Finance Minister Yoo Il Ho is investigating whether China's recent rejections of South Korean charter flight applications are linked to the Thaad deployment. The move aims to improve economic ties and mitigate potential retaliation against South Korean celebrities and businesses in China.

site_title: Qantas CEO Joyce to expand international unit after turnaround
summary: Qantas CEO Alan Joyce plans to expand the airline's international unit after a three-year restructuring delivered record profits. The international division, previously losing money, is now profitable and ready for growth. Joyce attributes the turnaround to a cost-cutting strategy and sees significant opportunities in China, where a recent agreement between Australia and China aims to remove flight capacity restrictions. He believes there is "huge benefits" in China's growing market, particularly with the removal of restrictions. The expansion is expected to capitalize on the growth potential in China and other international markets.

site_title: China's HNA expands in Hong Kong with second land purchase
summary: HNA Group Co Ltd, owner of Hainan Airlines, has purchased a 7,318 square metre residential land site in Hong Kong for HK$5.53 billion ($1.009 billion). This is the conglomerate's second major land acquisition in the city in the last three months, following an HK$8.8 billion purchase in November. The transaction is one of the most expensive land deals in 2016, and marks HNA's expansion in Hong Kong's real estate market.

site_title: Perennial-led consortium sells 70% stake in TripleOne Somerset for S$350m
summary: Perennial Real Estate Holdings has sold a 70% stake in TripleOne Somerset to Shun Tak Holdings for S$350 million. Perennial will retain a 30% share, using the proceeds for future investments. Other vendors, including SingHaiyi Group, Boustead Projects, and BreadTalk Group, are also selling their stakes in the office and retail development.

site_title: India plans expansive budget despite growth, revenue worries
summary: India's finance minister Arun Jaitley is expected to present a budget on February 1, which may include borrowing more than initially planned due to revenue concerns from a national sales tax. The government aims to fund giveaways and higher public investment to revive the economy after abolishing high-value banknotes in November. A fiscal advisory panel recommends a widening of the budget deficit to 3% of GDP to free up funds for infrastructure projects, but ratings agency Standard & Poor's warns that slowing fiscal consolidation could delay India's chances of an upgrade due to high and rising debt levels.

site_title: Trump Hotels chain sees significant US expansion
summary: US President Donald Trump's luxury hotel chain, Trump Hotels, plans to expand primarily in the US market during his presidency. The chain's CEO, Eric Danziger, stated that the company aims to enter 26 major metropolitan areas, with a focus on domestic emphasis for the next four to eight years. This expansion comes despite Trump's refusal to divest from his businesses and President Trump's criticism of companies offshoring jobs. Trump Hotels currently has eight properties in the US, with a new, lower-priced Scion brand set to open in smaller cities this year.

site_title: New Pentagon chief to visit Japan, South Korea next month
summary: US Defense Secretary James Mattis plans to visit Japan and South Korea next month, marking his first trip as Pentagon chief. The trip, set to begin on February 1, aims to strengthen US alliances and security cooperation with both countries. Mattis will travel to South Korea first, followed by Tokyo on February 3, underscoring the US commitment to its enduring relationships with Japan and South Korea.

site_title: China's 2016 industrial profits rise most in 3 years on commodities recovery
summary: China's industrial profits rose 8.5% in 2016, the largest gain in three years, driven by a construction boom and rising commodity prices. The earnings recovery was uneven, with coal mining and steel production sectors seeing significant gains. State-owned firms' profits rose 1.7%, while their liabilities increased 10% year-on-year. The strong profit growth suggests a potential pick-up in industrial investment in 2017, but analysts expect China's overall economic growth to cool to around 6.5% this year.

images.alt_text: Profits for China's industrial firms rose 8.5 per cent in 2016, the most in three years, as a construction boom fuelled a months-long rally in prices of building materials from steel to cement, giving companies more flexibility to start chipping away at a mountain of debt.

site_title: Overseas demand drives further recovery in UK commercial property: Rics
summary: Demand from overseas investors is expected to support the UK commercial property market this year, despite Brexit concerns. The Royal Institution of Chartered Surveyors' survey found flat investment enquiries in London's office sector and retail segment, while the UK as a whole saw a second straight quarter of increased inquiries. London commercial property values are expected to stagnate, but overall UK property values are expected to rise, with 28% of respondents expecting a rise in property values over the next 12 months.

site_title: Ebay holiday-quarter revenue up 3.1%, shares jump
summary: Ebay Inc reported a 3.1% rise in quarterly holiday revenue, exceeding Wall Street expectations. The company's traditional marketplace business showed signs of improvement, with fixed-price goods making up a larger portion of listings. Shares surged over 8% in extended trading. Analysts consider it a turnaround process for the company, with decent metrics in the marketplace division. Earnings and revenue for the quarter were in line with expectations.

images.alt_text: EBay Inc reported a 3.1 per cent rise in quarterly revenue for the fourth-quarter holiday period, offering signs of improvement at the company's traditional marketplace business and sending shares up more than 8 per cent in extended trading on Wednesday.

site_title: US dollar slides to 7-week low on Trump concerns; sterling rallies
summary: The US dollar slid to a seven-week low against a basket of major currencies due to uncertainty surrounding President Donald Trump's economic policy. Sterling rallied to a six-week high against the US dollar, driven by hopes for a trade deal between Britain and the US. The US dollar has fallen 3% against the yen since the beginning of the year, while the Australian dollar fell to a six-day low against the greenback. The decline in the US dollar index was attributed to Trump's focus on immigration and national security rather than fiscal stimulus.

site_title: Oil little changed as traders weigh US inventory build, Opec cuts
summary: Oil prices rebounded on Wednesday, reversing earlier losses after US crude inventories rose 6.8 million barrels, exceeding analyst expectations. Despite a build in US inventories, oil prices found support from Opec's planned output cuts, which have reduced oversupply. US shale output is rising, but US crude production remains below its 2015 peak. Benchmark brent crude fell 2 cents to $55.42 per barrel, while US crude futures for March delivery rose 0.02 cent to $53.20 per barrel.

site_title: US Republicans gather with agenda - and Trump - on minds
summary: US Republican lawmakers gathered in Philadelphia for their winter retreat, focusing on policy goals and meeting with President Donald Trump, whose provocative first week in office has raised concerns among conservatives. Trump will address the gathering on Thursday, marking his first presidential speech outside the Washington region. British Prime Minister Theresa May is also set to attend, becoming the first foreign leader to meet Trump since his inauguration. The meeting aims to solidify policy goals amidst Trump's busy and provocative start to his presidency.

site_title: UK pay deals stay low even as inflation starts to bite
summary: British workers received subdued pay settlements of 1.9% in the three months to the end of 2016, narrowly ahead of a 1.6% rise in consumer prices. Many economists expect inflation to hit 3% later this year, eroding consumer spending power. Despite this, pay analysts XpertHR predict employers will feel pressure to provide real-terms pay increases as the year progresses. The private sector saw a 2% average pay award, while public sector pay rose 1%, with construction workers enjoying the highest pay awards of 2.5%.

site_title: What are the 'sanctuary cities' that Trump opposes?
summary: US President Donald Trump has vowed to crack down on "sanctuary cities" that protect undocumented immigrants, threatening to withhold federal funds from cities that refuse to cooperate with immigration officials. Approximately 300 cities, counties, or states, including New York and Los Angeles, have vowed to protect the estimated 11 million undocumented migrants in the US. Trump's decree aims to cut off funding from cities that refuse to assist immigration officials, potentially affecting billions of dollars in federal funds.

site_title: Trump moves ahead with wall, puts stamp on US immigration, security policy
summary: US President Donald Trump has ordered the construction of a US-Mexican border wall and punishment for cities shielding illegal immigrants, reshaping US immigration and national security policy. An executive order will block refugee entries from Syria and suspend immigrant entries from Muslim-majority countries, with permanent rules to be studied. Trump's aggressive move comes less than a week into his presidency, signaling a shift away from moderate positions.

site_title: Asia: Markets closed for holidays
summary: Asian financial markets closed on Thursday due to public holidays in Sydney, Taipei, and Mumbai. In contrast, Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) rose 0.4% as investors maintained a positive outlook despite US tariff uncertainty and split views among the Federal Reserve. The STI has been on a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data release.

site_title: US weighs cuts to global funding, pullout from treaties: NYT
summary: US President Donald Trump is considering drastic funding cuts to international organizations and a review of treaties, potentially leading to a US withdrawal. Two executive orders are being prepared, one targeting funding for UN agencies supporting the Palestinians, abortion, or circumventing sanctions, and another reviewing multilateral treaties unrelated to national security. The US is the UN's largest financial contributor, and funding cuts could severely impact peacekeeping operations. The orders suggest Trump intends to pursue his campaign promises of withdrawing the US from international organizations.

site_title: Los Angeles, promoting itself as a bargain, seeks 2024 Olympics
summary: Los Angeles city leaders have committed to hosting the 2024 Olympics with a budget-conscious plan that relies on existing venues and private financing. The City Council voted 13-0 to sign the final contract with Olympic organizers if Los Angeles is chosen by the International Olympic Committee. The city plans to use the Memorial Coliseum and other existing locations, with the IOC providing some $1.7 billion in funding. The estimated cost to host the games is $5.3 billion, with the city covering any financial shortfall. Los Angeles is competing against Paris and Budapest for the 2024 Summer Games.

site_title: Madonna denies Malawi adoption bid
summary: US pop superstar Madonna has denied applying to adopt two more Malawian children while visiting the country. An official at the High Court in Lilongwe had earlier confirmed the court was assessing her application. Madonna, who has previously adopted Malawian children David Banda in 2006 and Mercy James in 2009, set up children's charity Raising Malawi in 2006. The denial comes amid controversy surrounding her previous adoption bids.

site_title: US: Dow ends above 20,000 for first time, extending election rally
summary: The Dow Jones Industrial Average reached a milestone, ending above 20,000 points for the first time, extending its rally following US President Donald Trump's election. The Dow jumped 0.8% to 20,068.51, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Index also rose to new records. Analysts attribute the surge to Trump's pro-growth policies, including tax cuts and pipeline projects, and investors' optimism about his agenda. The rally follows a brief stall from mid-December, with stocks rising sharply after the election.

site_title: Japanese inflation gives BOJ buyer's remorse
summary: The Bank of Japan (BOJ) is facing buyer's remorse as Japan's inflation is not reaching its target of 2% as expected. Despite oil prices recovering and the yen weakening, core consumer inflation remains around zero. Analysts predict inflation will reach 1% or more later this year, but BOJ officials are concerned that the increase is due to external factors rather than economic growth. The central bank is unlikely to upgrade its inflation forecasts, which could lead to speculation about an early rate hike and a potential increase in bond yields.

site_title: Fragrance Group to buy Imperial Hotel in Blackpool for £12.8m
summary: Fragrance Group Limited has agreed to purchase the Imperial Hotel Blackpool in the UK for £12.8m. The historic four-star hotel, built in 1867, has hosted British prime ministers including Winston Churchill and Tony Blair, and features 180 bedrooms and nine suites. The acquisition is expected to have no material impact on Fragrance Group's financials. The hotel has undergone restoration works in the past, with Paramount Hotels and The Hotel Collection contributing to its revitalization. The sale marks a new chapter for the iconic Blackpool landmark.

site_title: Largest US offshore wind farm gets green light
summary: US authorities have approved the largest offshore wind farm, the South Fork Wind Farm, to be located near Long Island, capable of powering 50,000 households. Construction is set to begin by 2019 and will feature 15 turbines with a capacity of 90 megawatts. The project aims to tap into the area's potential for up to 1,000 megawatts of wind power, with New York Governor Andrew Cuomo committing to 2.4 gigawatts of offshore wind energy by 2030.

site_title: Most US doctors oppose repeal of Obamacare: survey
summary: Most US doctors oppose repealing the Affordable Care Act (Obamacare), with 15% supporting complete repeal and 74% favoring changes, such as creating a public option or increasing the use of health savings accounts. Primary care physicians are most opposed, with 38% of Trump supporters and no Democrats in favor of full repeal. Doctors overwhelmingly support parts of the law, including increased health insurance coverage, protections for pre-existing conditions, and tax credits for small businesses.

site_title: DuPont CEO gives investors confidence Dow deal is on track
summary: DuPont CEO Ed Breen provided reassurance to investors that the company's merger with Dow Chemical Co will be approved, addressing antitrust regulators' concerns about limiting innovation in agricultural pesticides. The deal, worth $72 billion, will close in June, three months later than anticipated, and involves selling assets and related research and development resources to address concerns. The European Union granted a 10-day extension to review the deal, and analysts believe the company can satisfy regulators.

images.alt_text: Mr Breen is eliminating 10 per cent of the workforce to cut expenses before the merger.

site_title: UK factory order books strongest since 2015, but costs growing, says CBI
summary: UK factory order books reached their strongest level since 2015, with a +5 balance in January, up from zero in December. The Confederation of British Industry's survey also found manufacturers are planning more investment and have the most optimism in nearly two years. However, rising costs due to the weakened pound are expected to have a detrimental impact on consumers. Economists predict a second quarterly upgrade to economic growth predictions by the Bank of England, driven by export optimism, but also expect factory gate inflation to rise to around 6% later this year.

site_title: China bans joint acquisition of listed firms by insurers
summary: China's insurance regulator banned insurers from jointly acquiring listed firms with investors from other industries, stepping up curbs on their investments to rein in risks. New rules require regulatory pre-approvals before insurers acquire a listed company, and limit an insurance company's investment in a single stock to 5% of its total assets. The move aims to curb risks in the industry, particularly from short-term, high-yield products and speculative stock investments. Regulators also instructed insurers to offer lower yields on products and refrain from front-loading sales.

site_title: Facebook tunes trending topics to better deliver news
summary: Facebook has modified its trending topics system to better deliver news, including showing headlines from articles about trending subjects along with their sources. The update aims to surface topics quicker, capture a broader range of news, and help ensure that trends reflect real-world events. The change also removes personalized topic lists, making them the same for everyone in a region. This move comes as Facebook seeks to address criticism over the spread of misinformation, particularly during the 2016 US presidential race.

site_title: US setting stage for Asia to pivot to China
summary: The US decision to boycott the Trans-Pacific Partnership (TPP) agreement, a major Asia-Pacific economic initiative, marks a significant shift in the region's economic landscape. China and Japan are now poised to create a new economic order, with the Regional Comprehensive Economic Partnership (RCEP) emerging as a potential successor to the TPP. The US withdrawal leaves America economically enfeebled, while Japan struggles to retain influence in the world. Analysts predict that Asia can grow without the US, and that the TPP's rules, which would have favored US businesses, will be replaced by looser rules under RCEP, potentially favoring China.

site_title: US federal debt projected to grow by nearly US$10t over next decade
summary: The US federal debt is projected to grow by nearly $10 trillion over the next decade, according to the Congressional Budget Office. The deficit is expected to increase in 2019 and beyond, reaching $1 trillion by 2023 and $1.4 trillion by 2027. President Trump's spending and tax cuts plans pose a challenge to House Republicans, who had previously aimed to control the deficit. Congressional leaders will have to balance their commitment to fiscal prudence with the demands of the new president, who wants $1 trillion in infrastructure work over 10 years.

site_title: Singapore property comeback seen boosting large developer stocks
summary: Singapore's home prices are expected to make a comeback after a three-year losing streak, boosting large developer stocks. Analysts predict the government may reconsider property cooling measures, signaling a potential rebound. Top picks for stocks include City Developments Ltd, CapitaLand Ltd, UOL Group Ltd, and OUE Ltd, which could benefit from the expected property market revival. The move could be announced in the February budget speech, according to Carmen Lee, head of research at OCBC.

images.alt_text: Singapore's home prices are set to make a comeback after a three-year losing streak. And analysts think property developer stocks are the best way to play that rebound.

site_title: China's banking regulator issues guidelines on outbound investment
summary: China's banking regulator issued guidelines to strengthen control over outbound investment, aiming to clamp down on cross-border capital outflows and questionable investments. The move is part of Beijing's efforts to regulate overseas investments. The guidelines follow recent rules to halt questionable investments and are part of a broader push to manage capital outflows.

site_title: US television icon Mary Tyler Moore dead at 80
summary: Legendary actress Mary Tyler Moore, known for her iconic portrayal of a single career woman in the 1970s sitcom "The Mary Tyler Moore Show," has died at 80 after battling diabetes for years and undergoing brain surgery in 2011. Moore's eponymous sitcom was named one of 17 shows that "changed television" by Time Magazine. She won numerous awards for her work, including multiple Emmy and Tony Awards, and was a passionate advocate for the Juvenile Diabetes Research Foundation. Moore is survived by her husband of over 33 years and friends.

site_title: Taiwan surprises as investment winner
summary: Taiwan has become a surprise investment winner under US President Donald Trump, with its currency rising against the greenback and local shares reaching a one-and-a-half-year high. Foreign investors have pumped $1.5 billion into local shares this month, driven by forecasts of a 20% increase in earnings per share and Taiwan's highest dividend yield of 3.9%. Analysts attribute the island's strength to Apple's potential iPhone orders and Taiwan's economic growth, despite concerns about a Trump presidency's impact on the territory's fragile relationship with China.

site_title: S'pore improves ranking further in survey on least corrupt nations
summary: Singapore has improved its ranking to 7th globally in the Corruption Perceptions Index 2016, moving up from 8th place the previous year. It remains the least corrupt nation in Asia, holding its position since at least the past five surveys. The index, compiled by Transparency International, assesses perceptions of corruption in 176 countries based on information gathered from independent institutions over 24 months.

site_title: Taiwan's Q4 GDP grows at its fastest pace in nearly 2 years, but momentum is slowing
summary: Taiwan's Q4 GDP grew at its fastest pace in nearly two years, driven by strong demand for technology products, but rising global trade protectionism threatens to slow momentum. The economy's trade-dependent nature makes it vulnerable to trade frictions, particularly between the US and China, its largest trading partners. Rising trade protectionism and slowing global growth may impact Taiwan's economic recovery.

site_title: How 'Team Trump' sees unemployment and why it matters
summary: US Treasury Secretary nominee Steven Mnuchin and White House Press Secretary Sean Spicer clarified that President Trump's skepticism on the official unemployment rate stems from its underestimation of labor market slack. This stance could influence fiscal policy proposals as the new administration takes office. The clarification comes as Team Trump continues to argue that weakness persists, despite the official unemployment rate being at a 16-year low. This stance could impact the administration's views on economic policy, particularly regarding tax cuts and spending. The issue remains a point of contention for the Trump administration.

site_title: Dow tops 20,000 as earnings feed rally; bonds fall
summary: The Dow Jones Industrial Average reached 20,000 for the first time, rising 152 points to 20,065, driven by strong corporate earnings and optimism about economic growth. Bonds fell as bond yields rose, boosting bank lending margins. Global equities also surged, with the MSCI All-Country World Index nearing its highest closing level since 2015. The rally is attributed to US President Donald Trump's pro-growth campaign promises and the clarity of his administration's policies.

site_title: Climate-ravaged corals recover poorly: study
summary: Climate change has ravaged coral reefs, with many remaining deeply damaged and unlikely to recover their original growth rates. A 16-year study in the Seychelles archipelago found that only a third of reefs were expanding, and many were struggling against invasive species. Qualitative changes, such as a shift in coral diversity, were also observed. The study highlights the sensitivity of coral reefs to temperature change and the devastating impact of climate change, with four reefs having less than 2% coral cover and likely to die out entirely.

site_title: Parallel importers sold nearly 10,000 Vezel in 2016
summary: The Honda Vezel sold nearly 10,000 units in Singapore in 2016, accounting for 11% of total new car registrations. This made it the top model for the second consecutive year, boosting parallel import sales to an 8-year high. The model's popularity, driven by private-hire companies, led to the Honda brand overtaking Toyota as Singapore's top make in 2016. The Vezel's strong sales also contributed to the overall increase in new car registrations, with 87,504 vehicles registered in 2016, up 52% from the previous year.

site_title: Japan's trade surplus in 2016 stirs fears of backlash by US
summary: Japan recorded its first trade surplus in six years in 2016, sparking concerns about a potential trade war with the US. The surplus was attributed to a decline in imports from the US, primarily motor vehicles. US President Donald Trump has accused Japan and China of unfair trade practices, targeting motor-vehicle trade with Japan. This announcement is seen as politically sensitive, given Tokyo's anxiety about becoming entangled in a trade war. The surplus was seen as a positive sign for Japan, but the ongoing tensions with the US remain a concern.

site_title: Trump revives pipelines thwarted under Obama
summary: US President Donald Trump has cleared the way for two major oil pipelines blocked under his predecessor Barack Obama, reviving the Keystone XL pipeline and expediting the Dakota Access pipeline. Trump signed a directive ordering an end to protracted environmental reviews, aiming to curb regulations that slow building projects. Environmental activists have denounced the decisions, calling Trump a "dangerous threat to our climate." The pipelines, which have sparked years of debate, are seen as symbolic tests of Trump's environmental policies, which have been modified or reversed since taking office.

site_title: Vietnamese flag their patriotism during new year
summary: Vietnamese citizens display patriotism during the Lunar New Year, known as Tet, by flying the communist flag, a tradition dating back to 1954. Authorities encourage flag-flying, with those who refuse facing trouble and social disapproval. While some comply out of fear, others express resentment towards being forced to participate. Flag-makers produce handmade banners, adhering to strict state regulations, and the tradition remains a show of nationalism in the tightly controlled country.

site_title: Keppel T&T Q4 profit falls 93% on lower fair value gain on data centres
summary: Keppel T&T reported a 93.1% decline in Q4 net profit to S$3.08 million, citing lower fair value gain on data centre investments and a 5.5% drop in revenue to S$49.7 million. The company attributed the decline to challenging trade and consumption conditions in Asia but remains optimistic about the data centre industry, which it expects to remain strong due to cloud computing and digitalisation. A final dividend of 4.5 Singapore cents per share was declared.

site_title: Strata industrial units continue to lose their lustre since 2012 peak
summary: Singapore's strata industrial units continue to decline in sales and value since 2012. The number of transactions has dropped by 20.7% from 2016, with new sales making up just 16% of total sales. Resale units now account for 84% of sales. Market watchers expect transactions to remain subdued, with only one potential industrial project launch this year. However, resale units may see a modest uptick in demand as prices rationalize. Institutional investors are also looking at industrial properties for higher yields, but the lack of new launches and higher borrowing costs may dampen overall demand.

site_title: Innovalues set for delisting after shareholders approve PE firm takeover
summary: Innovalues, a Singapore-based precision machine parts maker, is set to be delisted from the Singapore Exchange mainboard in March after shareholders approved a S$331.4 million takeover by private equity firm Northstar Advisors. The acquisition, via a scheme of arrangement, was approved by 95% of shareholders present and voting. The delisting follows the takeover, marking another company to leave the mainboard.

site_title: Jakarta reconsidering TPP plans, eyes bilateral pacts
summary: Indonesia is reconsidering its plans to join the Trans-Pacific Partnership (TPP) after the US abandoned the accord, with Vice-President Jusuf Kalla meeting with the US ambassador to discuss bilateral trade deals. Indonesia is instead focusing on discussions for bilateral trade agreements with the European Union and Australia, while monitoring the progress of the TPP. The country's investment board chairman, Thomas Lembong, expressed openness to discussing a potential replacement for the US in the TPP, while China has proposed a counter pact, the Free Trade Area of the Asia Pacific.

site_title: Fremantle's move to boycott Australia Day festivities sparks row
summary: Fremantle, Australia, has cancelled its Australia Day celebrations to highlight the plight of indigenous people, sparking a row. The city's leaders moved the party to Saturday, citing the need to promote reconciliation. The move has raised concerns about violence and potential backlash from those who oppose the changes. The decision may also impact reforms aimed at promoting national unity. The city's actions have sparked a heated debate, with some calling the move a "divisive" and "misguided" attempt to rewrite history.

site_title: Russian consumers reluctant to spend even though economy is on cusp of recovery
summary: Russian consumers remain reluctant to spend despite the economy's recovery, with retail sales contracting 3.7% for a record 24th month. Real wages rose for the fifth month in December, but disposable incomes fell 5.1% from a year earlier. Consumers are in "crisis deleveraging mode" and are acting thrifty, supporting deposit generation but constraining spending. The savings rate remains high, and the central bank plans to hold interest rates above inflation to encourage savers and promote economic growth.

site_title: Novartis mulls options including spinoff, IPO for Alcon unit
summary: Novartis is considering separating its embattled Alcon eye-care division, including a spinoff or initial public offering, after projecting flat or low single-digit sales growth in 2017. The division faces increasing competition from cheaper copycat drugs, particularly for its top-selling medicine Gleevec. Novartis is counting on newer medicines to offset the decline in Gleevec sales, and the company expects to provide an update on the review by the end of the year.

site_title: Xi pushes for clean, reformed military
summary: Chinese President Xi Jinping has urged the military to fight corruption and follow party orders on reform and training during a traditional visit before the Chinese New Year. He pressed for the purge of corrupt officials, including former vice-chairmen Guo Boxiong and Xu Caihou, and emphasized the importance of improving political awareness, reform, and combat readiness. Xi is overseeing a military modernization program, which includes culling 300,000 members and developing high-tech weapons, amid concerns over China's assertive moves in the South China Sea.

site_title: New 'home sweet home' for Syrians
summary: A Syrian family of pastry chefs, the Sakkas, have reopened their baklava shop, Damaskus Konditorei, in Berlin after four years as refugees. The family, who fled their home in Homs due to the Syrian war, were granted asylum in Germany and worked tirelessly to rebuild their business. Their traditional pastries, made with high-quality ingredients, have become a hit with both Syrian and German customers, providing a taste of home for those who have lost everything.

site_title: Milk could be hangover cure for ThaiBev
summary: Thai Beverage, a major beer manufacturer, may not meet expectations for a Chang beer revival due to a year-long mourning period and the launch of a new beer brand by a rival brewery. The company's stock had seen a significant rally in 2016, but the recent events may dampen investor hopes. The beer industry is experiencing a decline, with the "beer high" fading, according to analysts.

site_title: PLife Reit's Q4, FY DPU lower in absence of one-off gain
summary: Parkway Life Reit (PLife Reit) reported a 9.2% year-on-year decline in its fourth quarter distribution per unit (DPU) of 3.06 Singapore cents due to the absence of a one-off capital distribution gain from the divestment of Japan properties in 2014. Excluding the gain, DPU from recurring operations grew 2.3% year-on-year. Revenue and net property income also increased, driven by contributions from new nursing home acquisitions and appreciation of the Japanese yen. The Reit's gearing remains healthy at 36.3%, and its debt term to maturity has improved to 3.6 years.

site_title: Chinese billions fail to sway Taiwan's last allies in Africa
summary: Taiwan's last two African allies, Burkina Faso and Swaziland, have stated they will not switch allegiances to China in exchange for funding. Foreign Minister Alpha Barry of Burkina Faso confirmed the decision, despite China's efforts to woo the island's diplomatic partners. This move comes as Beijing tries to isolate Taiwan diplomatically, but Burkina Faso and Swaziland remain committed to maintaining ties with Taipei.

site_title: Trump set to unveil Mexico border wall plans in security push
summary: US President Donald Trump is set to unveil national security plans, including steps towards building a wall on the Mexican border and limiting refugee inflows, in a move to fulfill campaign promises. Trump tweeted "Big day planned on NATIONAL SECURITY tomorrow. Among many other things, we will build the wall!" on Tuesday night. The plans aim to address key security concerns, following Trump's election campaign rhetoric.

site_title: Sias to Sabana Reit: Address unitholders' concerns
summary: A Singapore investor watchdog group, Sias, has asked Sabana Reit to address unitholders' concerns, including the removal of the current manager, which could lead to a meeting and potential liquidation of the trust. Unitholders, led by Jerry Low, are dissatisfied with the Reit's performance, citing a 60-70% decline in value since IPO. Sias has called for a detailed plan to address concerns and avoid liquidation. If the proposal passes, a new manager would need to be approved by the authorities, and the trust's portfolio could be divested.

site_title: Walls may come up, but keep building doors and bridges
summary: US President Donald Trump signed orders to withdraw the US from the Trans-Pacific Partnership (TPP) pact, a 12-member Pacific Rim free-trade agreement. This move leaves the TPP as it stands unable to come into being and follows the UK's exit from the European Union. The demise of the TPP highlights the need for continued efforts to facilitate free trade in the Asia-Pacific region, where trade has accounted for much of growth. Regional free-trade agreements, such as the proposed Free Trade Area of the Asia Pacific (FTAAP), are crucial in preventing protectionism and fostering regional stability.

images.alt_text: On Monday, President Trump signed orders to withdraw the world's largest economy from the TPP. Now, the real work begins for Asean's 10 states - to muster the political will to push ahead in the lowering of barriers to trade flows.

site_title: EU-S'pore FTA faces potential legal hurdle that may shape Brexit deal
summary: A court ruling in Singapore's proposed free-trade agreement (FTA) with the European Union may impact the EU's future trade deals, including the UK's Brexit negotiations. The ruling could determine the number of layers of ratification required, potentially delaying or altering the pact. This could influence future trade relations between the UK and EU, with observers suggesting the EU-Singapore FTA may shape the UK's Brexit deal. The outcome could have broader implications for trade agreements between the EU, UK, and other countries.

site_title: STI drifts lower, but still up 5.5% for 2017
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) rose 2.01 points to 3,039.94, despite a 60-point rise in Dow futures, on a mild loss. The index is up 159 points or 5.5% for 2017, driven by improved trading volume and broker optimism. Noble Group topped the active list, while DBS reached a new 17-month high, followed by UOB, which was raised to a buy rating by RHB. Goldman Sachs forecasts China's growth to slow to 6.3% in 2017 due to unsustainable debt growth and uncertainty.

site_title: Dollar hits seven-week low on Trump worries
summary: The US dollar hit a seven-week low against a basket of currencies due to concerns over President Donald Trump's focus on protectionism and isolationism, rather than pro-growth policies. The dollar index fell 0.5% to 99.835, its lowest since December 8, as investors were disappointed by Trump's lack of detail on fiscal stimulus and worried about the impact on the US economy. The sterling jumped above $1.26 for the first time in six weeks on hopes for a trade deal between the US and UK.

site_title: Headhunters seek China banking specialists to buffer against crisis
summary: Hong Kong-based headhunting firm Sheffield Haworth reports that China's lenders are hiring staff to reinforce buffers against a financial crisis, amid concerns over rising bad loans, falling profitability, and tighter Basel III regulations. The firms are also training existing employees to handle Chinese language skills and expertise, as difficulty in finding bankers with these skills is forcing them to "re-tool" existing staff. Chinese lenders raised a record US$62.8 billion in US dollar bonds in 2016, and experts predict more debt issuance with equity characteristics to replenish capital this year.

site_title: US home sales drop as supply tumbles to 17-year low
summary: US home sales decreased 2.8% to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 5.49 million units in December, falling short of expectations. The supply of houses on the market dropped to a 17-year low of 1.65 million units, likely due to a lack of available properties. Rising home prices and mortgage rates may have also discouraged buyers. Despite this, the housing market recovery remained intact, and economists expect existing home sales to increase 1% this year.

site_title: S'pore to review emissions policy to discourage use of diesel vehicles: Masagos
summary: Singapore's government is reviewing its emissions policy to discourage diesel vehicle use, following global concerns over diesel emissions' health impact. A study commissioned by the Ministry for the Environment and Water Resources found electric vehicles and renewable diesel as promising alternatives. Diesel vehicles made up a fifth of Singapore's fleet in 2015, with major cities like Paris and Madrid banning them. The government will unveil its plans to tackle air pollution from diesel vehicles in March, considering factors such as infrastructure costs and user affordability.

site_title: Japan ends painful wait for local-born sumo grand champion
summary: Japan has finally achieved its long-awaited goal of producing a homegrown sumo grand champion, with 30-year-old Kisenosato being promoted to yokozuna after winning the Emperor's Cup. This marks the first time a Japanese-born wrestler has reached the highest rank since 1998, with Kisenosato taking 73 tournaments to achieve the milestone. The promotion is seen as a relief and a celebration of Kisenosato's humility and dedication to the sport, which has been plagued by scandals and dominated by foreigners in recent years.

site_title: Sundance turns lens on jihadism, Syrian civil war
summary: The Islamic State (IS) group's reign of terror in the Syrian city of Raqa is documented in the film "City of Ghosts," which premiered at the Sundance Film Festival. The documentary, directed by Matthew Heineman, follows the work of citizen journalists who risk their lives to document IS atrocities. The group, known as Raqa is Being Silently Slaughtered, has been able to capture the brutality and dysfunction of everyday life in the city despite IS's efforts to control the narrative. The film offers a rare glimpse into the human side of the conflict.

site_title: Year of the Rooster seen waking up China's demand for palm oil
summary: China's palm oil imports are expected to rise in 2017 as Asian production recovers from a 6.8 million-tonne decline due to El Nino in 2015-2016. The expected surge in supply will drive down prices, making it more competitive with other oils, and attracting Chinese buyers. Analysts predict imports may jump 10-15% in the first half and reach 5.1-5.2 million tonnes by the end of 2017, with prices potentially falling to RM2,200 per tonne by the fourth quarter.

site_title: Starbucks set to add three to board, making it more diverse
summary: Starbucks plans to add three new directors to its board, increasing its diversity to 29% female and 36% ethnic minority. The new directors include Rosalind Brewer, an African-American woman, Satya Nadella, an Indian-American, and Jorgen Vig Knudstorp, a Denmark-born executive chairman. The additions aim to create a board that reflects the company's values and mission, with a range of ages and backgrounds. The move comes after the company's founder and chairman, Howard Schultz, steps down as CEO in April, with Kevin Johnson taking over.

site_title: Americans are flipping houses like it's 2006
summary: Home flippers, who buy homes as a speculative bet on short-term price appreciation, accounted for 6.1% of US home sales in 2016, the highest share since 2006. This trend has made a comeback in cities affected by the foreclosure crisis, including Las Vegas, Tampa, and Fresno. While some experts consider this a cause for concern, others see flippers as providing a valuable service by investing in needed improvements that owner-occupiers might not have time for. The market's current state suggests that another housing market collapse is unlikely.

site_title: Corruption, social inequality behind rise of populism: report
summary: A report by Transparency International found that 69% of 176 countries scored below 50 on its corruption index, with zero being highly corrupt. The report linked the rise of populist politicians in 2016 to growing corruption and social inequality. Populist leaders often drew links between a "corrupt elite" and the marginalization of working people, but failed to address corruption once in office. The report called for greater controls on money laundering and the banning of secret companies to break the "vicious circle" between corruption and inequality.

images.alt_text: With a score of 10, Somalia remained the worst performer for the 10th year in the Transparency International report on corruption around the world. Denmark and New Zealand performed best, with scores of 90.

site_title: When regulation hurts the little guy
summary: US President Donald Trump has vowed to cut regulations by 75% and roll back the Dodd-Frank financial regulation bill, citing it as a "confused and bloated law" that makes Wall Street a bigger threat to the economy. This stance raises concerns about the impact on small-scale investors and businesses, who face complex and burdensome regulations. The article argues that over-regulation can lead to counterproductive effects, such as higher costs and reduced opportunities, and suggests that a more optimistic approach to regulation may be needed.

site_title: IPO of Asia's oldest bourse BSE over 40 times subscribed
summary: BSE Ltd, Asia's oldest bourse, received bids for over 40 times its shares in an initial public offering, with 433.8 million shares bid for compared to 10.8 million shares offered. Major investors included Caldwell India Holdings, Singapore Exchange Ltd, and George Soros's Quantum Fund. The bourse generates revenue from transactions, listings, and other sources, with 27% coming from transactions. This successful IPO comes after a rival stock exchange, the National Stock Exchange of India Ltd, also filed for an initial public offering.

images.alt_text: Bids were placed for 433.8m BSE shares compared with 10.8m shares on offer.

site_title: Microsoft victory in overseas email seizure case is upheld
summary: A US federal appeals court has upheld a landmark decision barring the US government from forcing Microsoft and other companies to turn over customer emails stored on servers outside the US. The 4-4 vote lets stand a July 14 decision that was seen as a victory for privacy advocates. The ruling could harm law enforcement efforts, with dissenting judges calling on the US Supreme Court or Congress to reverse it.

site_title: Millions on the move for China's New Year holiday
summary: Millions of migrant workers in China are traveling home for the Chinese New Year holiday, with thousands waiting in freezing conditions at Beijing Railway Station for tickets. The demand is so high that some people have spent days trying to secure seats, with many facing long and uncomfortable journeys. Chinese passengers are expected to make almost three billion trips during the 40-day period, with 2.5 billion journeys by road. The holiday, which falls on January 28, is a time for families to gather and celebrate the most important holiday on the Chinese calendar.

site_title: Japan not keen to bring China into the TPP fold
summary: Japan is unlikely to invite China to join the Trans-Pacific Partnership (TPP) due to concerns that it would boost Beijing's influence and water down the pact's rules. Japan had hoped the TPP would help anchor US security in Asia, but President Donald Trump's withdrawal from the deal has put this goal at risk. Australia and New Zealand are exploring ways to salvage the TPP, while China pushes its own Regional Comprehensive Economic Partnership (RCEP) with less ambitious trade rules.

site_title: China phonemakers leading charge in India
summary: Chinese smartphone brands, led by Vivo, have dominated India's market, taking four of the top five spots in the final quarter of 2016, according to a Counterpoint Research report. They captured a collective 46% of the market, with Samsung's share decreasing to 24% from 29% in the same period last year. Chinese brands are targeting India due to stagnant sales growth at home, and are incorporating features like large displays and powerful selfie-cameras to connect with local fans. Apple aims to increase its presence in India by setting up manufacturing facilities and retail stores.

site_title: Demonetisation report card for India still mixed but shows promise
summary: India's demonetisation report card is mixed, but shows promise. The move, which removed high-value currency notes from circulation, has led to increased tax collections and digital payment services. While some economists project a decline in GDP growth and employment, others see robust industrial activity and a surge in digital payment services. The Indian government has taken steps to address bottlenecks in the ATM network and has introduced innovative digital infrastructure initiatives. The success of demonetisation will depend on the government's next steps, with the upcoming budget expected to reveal more about its plans.

site_title: Multilateral trade accords are 'out', bilaterals are 'in'
summary: US President Donald Trump has signed a presidential memorandum withdrawing the US from the Trans-Pacific Partnership (TPP), a regional trade agreement among 12 Asia-Pacific countries. The move aligns with Trump's commitment to nationalist economic policies, which he has expressed during his presidential campaign and inauguration. The TPP's withdrawal has limited impact on the US economy, as it was already politically and legislatively dead on arrival. Trump views the move as a step towards implementing protectionist trade policies, including tougher negotiations with China and renegotiating the North American Free Trade Agreement (Nafta).

site_title: Trump's planned Bali hotel risks angering the gods, and the locals
summary: US President Donald Trump's planned Trump International Hotel and Tower Bali in Indonesia's Bali island is sparking controversy over its potential impact on local customs and the environment. The six-star resort, which includes a tower and golf course, is set to be built near a 16th-century temple and could require the purchase of nearby farmland. Locals, mostly Hindus, are worried about the project's height and proximity to the temple, citing concerns that it may anger the gods. The project's developers claim it will bring luxury to the island, but many are skeptical, citing concerns over the impact on the local culture and environment.

site_title: BHP hits record iron ore output amid price surge
summary: BHP Billiton has reported a record Australian iron ore production of 118 million tonnes in the second-half of 2016, a 4% increase from the same period in 2015, driven by a 28% surge in iron ore prices to US$55. The company's iron ore output rose 9% to 60 million tonnes in the December quarter. This success comes as BHP has reduced its petroleum output, citing falling prices. The miner is also awaiting the outcome of a settlement deal with prosecutors over the Samarco dam disaster.

site_title: GIC buys tower housing Deutsche Bank in New York
summary: Singapore's sovereign wealth fund GIC Pte Ltd acquired a 95% stake in the 47-story 60 Wall St tower in lower Manhattan for $1.04 billion, valuing it at $640 per square foot. Paramount Group Inc, a New York-based real estate investment trust, retained a 5% stake and will continue to manage the property. The deal, completed with a $575 million financing, comes as Deutsche Bank AG plans to overhaul its offices in the tower, which it bought in 2001 and sold to Paramount in 2007.

images.alt_text: Deutsche Bank plans to overhaul its offices at the US headquarters.

site_title: Rio Tinto nears exit from thermal coal with US$2.45b China deal
summary: Rio Tinto nears exit from thermal coal with a US$2.45 billion deal to sell most of its Australian coal mines to Yanzhou Coal Mining Co, a Chinese company. The sale includes Rio's largest Australian coal operation and leaves the company with only two producing coal mines. The deal, worth US$2.45 billion, includes an initial cash payment and annual installments, and is expected to be completed in the September quarter.

images.alt_text: Thermal coal prices surged last year after China introduced mining curbs. Australia's Newcastle coal, an Asian thermal benchmark, surged more than 80% in 2016, snapping five years of declines.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: M1's Q4 2016 results were in line with expectations, according to UOB Kay Hian Research. The company's chances of sharing a common radio access network and backhaul transmission with StarHub for 5G are high due to shared equipment vendors, Huawei and Nokia.

site_title: Acra to get new chief from April
summary: Singapore's Accounting and Corporate Regulatory Authority (Acra) will bid farewell to its current chief executive Kenneth Yap in April. Ong Khiaw Hong, the deputy commissioner of the Corporate and Services Group at the Inland Revenue Authority of Singapore, will succeed him as chief executive-designate and take over the post in May. Yap's tenure has seen Acra implement new regulatory regimes and guidelines, reducing business compliance costs and enhancing financial reporting. The Finance Ministry has praised Yap's leadership and contributions to Singapore's business environment.

site_title: Thai banks see 77b baht of savings with e-payments
summary: Thai banks expect to save 77 billion baht (S$3.1 billion) in the next 10 years due to the national digital-payment system PromptPay, which levies smaller transaction fees than traditional banks. Over 30 million PromptPay registrations are expected by the end of 2017, with fees capped at 10 baht for large transactions. Analysts predict a 5% cut in banks' fee income in the early period, but long-term benefits may outweigh costs. The rollout of PromptPay aims to promote cashless transactions and boost the country's digital economy.

site_title: Madonna in Malawi court to apply to adopt 2 more kids
summary: US pop superstar Madonna appeared in a Malawian court to apply for the adoption of two local children, following her previous adoptions of David Banda in 2006 and Mercy James in 2009. The court is reviewing her application, which was made amid tight security, and a ruling is pending. Madonna's visit to Malawi comes after a period of controversy surrounding her earlier adoptions and her charity work in the country.

site_title: Inflation strikes back - but it's not straightforward
summary: Inflation is returning as oil prices stop falling, but its impact is complex. Crude oil generates 5% of a developed economy's consumer price basket, while domestic labour costs account for 70%. As labour costs rise, firms may raise prices, but inflation varies by sector and can exacerbate inequality. Higher inflation in Germany and the US may contrast with subdued inflation in Greece. Investors must consider the implications of rising inflation indices on their portfolios, while inflation inequality could undermine living standards, particularly for lower-income groups.

site_title: Building a unicorn (billion-dollar) startup
summary: A study by Sage found that most unicorn founders are male, with 75% of successful billion-dollar startups founded by a male and a partner. The study highlights the common characteristics of these successful startups, but no specific ingredients or factors are mentioned.

site_title: Vietnam is still attractive to MNCs despite Trump's snub
summary: Vietnam remains an attractive destination for multinational corporations despite US President Donald Trump's withdrawal from the Trans-Pacific Partnership (TPP). The country's exports to the US increased by 15% to $38.5 billion in 2016, and it is on track to be the top exporter of goods to the US among the Association of Southeast Asian Nations. Multinationals such as Calvin Klein, Michael Kors, and Kenneth Cole continue to source products from Vietnam, citing the country's low wages and good access to ports. Vietnam plans to continue its reform process and fulfill trade agreement commitments, and foreign direct investment in the country reached a record $15.8 billion in 2016.

site_title: Alibaba adds US$7.5b to its market value
summary: Alibaba reported quarterly results beating estimates, with revenue mostly coming from its home market. The company raised its full-year sales forecast to 53% growth, driven by strong Chinese spending and expansion into cloud computing, entertainment, and search. Alibaba's digital entertainment platforms and cloud business are key contributors to its growth, and the company aims to accelerate its globalization this year. The company's shares rose 3.1% after the announcement, with net income climbing 38% to 17.2 billion yuan. Alibaba's expansion into traditional retail and its plans to attract small businesses in the US are also underway.

site_title: US home mortgage applications at highest since June
summary: US home mortgage applications surged to 243.2 in the week ended January 20, a 6.0% increase from the previous week, according to the Mortgage Bankers Association. Interest rates on 30-year fixed-rate conforming mortgages rose to 4.35%, the highest since June. This increase followed a four-week decline in rates. The refinance share of overall mortgage applications fell to 50.0%, its smallest since July 2015. US home borrowing costs rose in step with bond yields amid a renewed selloff in the US Treasuries market.

site_title: Abe's Trump problem: Get Japan to buy US cars
summary: Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe faces a challenge in convincing his citizens to buy American cars after President Donald Trump withdrew from the Trans-Pacific Partnership, citing Japan's failure to purchase US vehicles. Abe must consider a bilateral trade deal with the US, which could damage his approval rating and risk the wrath of the farm lobby. Japan has a large trade surplus with the US, but exports fewer American-made vehicles than imports.
