A deal could involve concessions on vehicles, with the goal of building trust between Abe and Trump.

site_title: Pace of consolidation key to India's ratings upgrade
summary: Standard & Poor's (S&P) has expressed concerns over India's high and rising debt levels, flagging the need for faster fiscal consolidation to boost its case for a ratings upgrade. The country's sovereign debt-to-GDP ratio stands at 66%, higher than desired. S&P advises the government to avoid an expansive fiscal policy, instead focusing on lowering debt accumulation and stock. The agency reaffirmed India's rating at "BBB-minus" with a "stable" outlook, citing the country's strong economic growth despite recent challenges.

site_title: China central bank official defends rapid use of foreign reserves to keep yuan steady
summary: A senior official at China's central bank has defended the rapid use of foreign exchange reserves to keep the yuan currency stable, citing benefits that outweigh drawbacks. Vice-governor Yi Gang stated that using reserves has maintained yuan stability and prevented market overshooting. China has spent $1 trillion in foreign reserves over two years, with the yuan falling 6.6% against the dollar last year. Yi Gang also highlighted the yuan's inclusion in the International Monetary Fund's Special Drawing Rights, which has increased its internationalization.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close higher on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's shares rose on Wednesday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index increasing 3.240 points to 1683.930. The market saw 1.303 billion lots traded at RM1.810 billion, with 409 gainers outnumbering 327 losers.

site_title: UK factory order books strongest since 2015, but costs growing
summary: British manufacturers have experienced their strongest orders since 2015, with a +5 industrial orders balance in January, according to the Confederation of British Industry. This marks a significant rise from zero in December and is the highest since April 2015. Despite this, costs are rising sharply due to the weaker pound, which has fallen 15.4% against the dollar since the Brexit vote. The Bank of England is expected to raise its economic growth predictions for this year.

images.alt_text: British manufacturers are enjoying their strongest orders in nearly two years but their costs are rising sharply following last year's Brexit vote which pushed down the value of sterling, a survey showed on Wednesday.

site_title: Saudi Aramco shelves plans for venture with Malaysia's Petronas -sources
summary: Saudi Aramco has shelved plans for a multi-billion-dollar refining and petrochemical joint venture with Malaysia's Petronas, according to industry sources. The reasons for the project's halt are unclear, and Aramco officials could not be immediately reached for comment. This decision comes after years of discussions between the two companies, but no further details have been provided.

site_title: A US$90b debt wave shows cracks in US property boom
summary: A $90 billion wave of maturing commercial mortgages in the US is exposing weaknesses in the real estate market. Delinquency rates are forecast to rise to 5.75% in 2017, up from several years of declines, due to maturing loans and increasing borrowing costs. Lenders are becoming more cautious, and property owners are struggling to secure fresh financing, particularly in suburban areas. The market is also facing challenges from e-commerce's impact on retail properties, with mall defaults expected to increase. While some high-profile buildings in major cities are doing well, the overall outlook is concerning, with S&P analysts predicting a 13% default rate for real estate loans.

site_title: Suntec Reit Q4 DPU falls 5.6%, net property income down 2.9%
summary: Suntec Reit reported a 5.6% decline in its distribution per unit (DPU) for the fourth quarter ended December 31, 2016, to 2.596 Singapore cents, lower than the previous year's DPU of 2.750 cents. Net property income fell 2.9% to S$66.1 million, primarily due to the divestment of Park Mall. Despite this, gross revenue rose 1.6% to S$88.9 million. The company's debt-to-asset ratio stood at 36.4% and its all-in financing cost was 2.28% for the quarter.

site_title: Trump calls on US carmakers to build more plants at home
summary: US President Donald Trump urged the CEOs of the Big Three US carmakers to build more cars in the country, pushing for jobs to be brought back to America. In a meeting with Mary Barra of General Motors, Mark Fields of Ford, and Sergio Marchionne of Fiat Chrysler Automobiles, Trump expressed his desire to cut regulations and taxes to make the US more attractive for businesses. The meeting came as carmakers have been expanding operations in the US, with Toyota announcing a $600 million investment in an Indiana plant.

images.alt_text: (From left) General Motors CEO Mary Barra, Fiat Chrysler's Sergio Marchionne and Ford's Mark Fields at a news conference outside the White House after Tuesday's meeting with Mr Trump.

site_title: MBC 1 acquisition boosts MCT's Q3 DPU
summary: Mapletree Commercial Trust (MCT) reported a 9.6% year-on-year increase in distribution per unit (DPU) to 2.28 Singapore cents for the third quarter ended Dec 31, 2016, driven by the accretive acquisition of Mapletree Business City 1 (MBC 1) in August 2016. The trust's four other buildings delivered healthy performance, with VivoCity's sales and shopper traffic up 2% and 6.7% year-on-year. Net property income increased 49% to S$84.4 million, and income available for distribution surged 48.2% to S$65.6 million.

site_title: Indonesia reconsidering TPP plans, eyes bilateral deals
summary: Indonesia is reconsidering its plans to join the Trans-Pacific Partnership (TPP) after the US abandoned the accord, and instead seeks bilateral economic cooperation with the US. Indonesian Vice President Jusuf Kalla discussed ways to increase trade with the US, while the country also explores bilateral deals with the European Union and Australia. Indonesia will continue to monitor the progress of the TPP and lead negotiations for the Regional Comprehensive Economic Partnership (RCEP), a Southeast Asian-backed trade agreement.

site_title: Update : Dow tops historic 20,000
summary: The Dow Jones Industrial Average surpassed 20,000 for the first time on January 25, 2017, amid a rally following US President Donald Trump's election victory. The Dow rose 97.59 points, or 0.49%, to 20,010.3. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also hit record intraday highs. The market continued its upward trend despite concerns over US trade policies.

site_title: China Merchants Bank tightens rules for mainlanders opening HK accounts
summary: China Merchants Bank will tighten rules for mainlanders opening Hong Kong accounts, requiring applicants to have an average of 5 million yuan in assets over the past three months, a 100-fold increase from the previous 50,000 yuan threshold. This move aims to curb capital outflows as Beijing steps up efforts to stabilize the yuan, which fell nearly 7% against the US dollar last year. The measure is part of a series of restrictions by Chinese banks to limit capital outflows, following similar measures by the forex watchdog and a ban on using yuan for investment purposes.

site_title: Once India's 'Garden City', Bangalore is now a garbage city
summary: Bangalore, once hailed as India's Garden City and Silicon Valley, has become a garbage city due to a trash crisis threatening its reputation. The city's rapid growth has overwhelmed its infrastructure and waste collection services, resulting in massive amounts of waste and stench. Residents are calling for systemic changes, while activists are promoting recycling and awareness about environmental impact. The municipality is implementing measures to enforce "garbage discipline," but critics argue that these are short-term solutions to a long-term problem.

site_title: Boeing Dreamliner turns into rainmaker, sending shares soaring
summary: Boeing's 787 Dreamliner has helped the company post rising profits after a decade of losses. The company's shares reached an all-time high, increasing 3.3% to $165.79, driven by the Dreamliner's emergence and higher output of its 737 single-aisle jet. Boeing forecasts higher cash and earnings this year, despite a sales decline due to fewer 777 wide-body aircraft deliveries. The company plans to return cash to investors through share repurchases and dividend increases, bolstering its dividend and reducing debt.

site_title: Innovalues shareholders give nod to firm's takeover by Northstar
summary: Innovalues shareholders have approved a takeover by private equity fund Northstar via a scheme of arrangement. The acquisition is expected to be completed by March, with Innovalues' shares delisted on March 17. The expected last day of trading is February 7. The move follows a High Court-directed shareholders' meeting where approximately 95% of shareholders voted in favor of the acquisition.

site_title: Cambridge trust optimistic about new sponsor
summary: Cambridge Industrial Trust (CIT) has appointed e-Shang Redwood, a Warburg Pincus unit, as its new sponsor, citing its experience in logistics and e-commerce. The trust's distribution per unit (DPU) fell 12.9% for FY16, largely due to property conversions and a decision to stop topping up capital for distributions. The new sponsor is expected to bring benefits to the trust, including leasing assistance and future funding opportunities. The trust will continue to focus on capital recycling, divestment, and expanding its portfolio, with a focus on second-tier cities outside of Singapore.

site_title: UK Supreme Court ruling complicates path to Brexit
summary: The UK Supreme Court ruled that the UK government needs an Act of Parliament to trigger Article 50, a key step in the Brexit process, in a landmark decision that complicates Prime Minister Theresa May's vision of a hard Brexit. The ruling, which was seen as a technical but significant development, could shape UK politics and potentially delay the triggering of Article 50 beyond the prime minister's end-March deadline. A cross-party group of MPs and Lords is now seeking to counter May's vision, with the potential for increased parliamentary involvement and softer Brexit terms, and some legislators are even pushing for a second public referendum.

images.alt_text: A demonstrator outside the Supreme Court in central London on Tuesday holding a cake with the EU flag on it, following the Supreme Court's judgement that parliamentary approval is needed before the UK government can begin Brexit negotiations.

site_title: Olympics: Bolt loses gold as IOC strip Jamaica of 2008 relay win
summary: Usain Bolt lost one of his Olympic gold medals after Jamaica was stripped of their 2008 relay win due to a doping scandal involving teammate Nesta Carter. Carter tested positive for methylhexanamine, a banned substance, in retested samples from the Beijing Games. The International Olympic Committee (IOC) ruled Carter and Jamaica disqualified, resulting in Bolt losing a gold medal. This decision follows the IOC's re-examination of hundreds of samples from the 2008 event, affecting Bolt's "triple triples" in Beijing, London, and Rio.

site_title: Thailand investment applications nearly triple in 2016
summary: Thailand saw a nearly tripling of investment applications in 2016 to $16.6 billion, surpassing the government's target. The majority of investments came from the automobile, chemicals, and electronics industries. This increase reflects a 196% rise from 2015, when the military government introduced new policies that led to a significant decline in submissions. Investment pledges are expected to rise by 3% in 2017.

site_title: US: Dow tops historic 20,000
summary: The Dow Jones Industrial Average surpassed 20,000 for the first time on January 25, 2017, following US President Donald Trump's signing of executive orders. The rally was fueled by investors' expectations of pro-growth policies and tax cuts from the new administration. The historic level was narrowly missed on January 6, as investors anticipated the administration's economic agenda. The Dow's surge resumed after Trump's inauguration on Friday.

site_title: Sabana Reit's Q4 DPU down to 0.88 cent on rights issue (Amended)
summary: Sabana Reit reported a Q4 DPU of 0.88 Singapore cents, down from 1.31 cents a year ago, due to a rights issue that issued 310.7 million new units. Full-year DPU fell to 4.17 cents, down from 5.99 cents in FY2015. Gross revenue and net property income also declined, with Q4 falling 8.2% and 14.7% year-over-year, respectively. The Reit aims to partially finance proposed acquisitions with the rights issue's S$80.2 million gross proceeds.

site_title: India to partly fill Mangalore strategic reserve with UAE oil
summary: India has signed a deal with the UAE's Abu Dhabi National Oil Co. to store 6 million barrels of oil at Mangalore, taking up half of the site's capacity as part of India's strategic reserve system. This move aims to hedge against energy security risks, with the facility expected to hold 10 days of India's average daily oil demand. The underground storage facility is part of a larger effort to secure India's oil needs, with the country importing most of its oil requirements.

site_title: MCT's Q3 DPU up 9.6% on acquistion of Mapletree Business City 1
summary: MAPLETREE Commercial Trust (MCT) reported a 9.6% year-on-year increase in distribution per unit (DPU) to 2.28 Singapore cents for Q3 FY2017, driven by the acquisition of Mapletree Business City 1. Income available for distribution surged 48.2% to S$65.6 million, with net property income and gross revenue also increasing by 49% and 47.4%, respectively.

site_title: Keppel T&T Q4 profit slumps 93.1% on lower fair value gain on data centre properties
summary: Keppel T&T reported a 93.1% slump in Q4 net profit to S$3.08 million, driven by a lower fair value gain on data centre properties and a 5.5% decline in revenue to S$49.7 million. The company attributed the decline to challenging trade and consumption conditions in Asia.

site_title: Singapore shares finish mixed; volume improves and STI still +5.5% for 2017
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) closed at 3,039.94, losing 2.01 points, but still up 5.5% for 2017. Volume improved to 1.9 billion units worth S$1.33 billion on Wednesday. Despite a 60-point rise in Dow futures, the STI failed to reach a fresh 15-month high. The close follow-up of US GDP data and ongoing US-EU trade talks may influence market sentiment.

site_title: Global uncertainty squeezes German business confidence
summary: German business confidence fell to 109.8 points in January, the lowest level since September, due to increasing geopolitical uncertainty. Firms expressed greater satisfaction with current conditions but less optimism about future outlooks. The main concern is the impact of US President Trump's trade sanctions, which could affect German exports. The German economy is expected to remain dependent on domestic demand in the year ahead, with the threat of Brexit and US tariffs exacerbating the uncertainty.

site_title: Hong Kong's Exchange Fund 2016 investment income at HK$61b
summary: Hong Kong's Exchange Fund reported a record investment income of HK$61 billion in 2016, a significant improvement from an adjusted HK$15.8 billion loss in 2015. The fund's performance was driven by a strong third quarter with an adjusted investment income of HK$47.1 billion. However, the fourth quarter saw a significant investment loss of HK$30 billion. The results reflect the fund's efforts to maintain the stability of the Hong Kong dollar.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong's Exchange Fund, which is used to back the Hong Kong dollar, posted investment income of HK$61 billion (S$11.222 billion) in 2016, the Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) said on Wednesday.

site_title: Dubai Airport sees tougher 2017 as growth slows again
summary: Dubai International Airport predicted 89 million travelers in 2017, a 6.4% gain, marking the weakest growth in 10 years. The airport, which outperformed European rivals, faces capacity constraints and slot limitations. Despite this, CEO Paul Griffiths remains confident of overtaking Atlanta Hartsfield-Jackson and Beijing Capital as the world's busiest hub. The airport's growth is attributed to its significant capacity, with 209 passengers per flight, and is expected to reach 118 million travelers annually by 2023.

site_title: Singapore ranks 7th in latest annual index of least corrupt countries
summary: Singapore ranks 7th in Transparency International's 2016 Corruption Perceptions Index, scoring 84 points, down from 85 in 2015. The country's corruption perception index has remained relatively stable despite the slight decrease. This ranking places Singapore among the least corrupt countries in the world.

site_title: ECB could 'soon' exit monetary stimulus: board member
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) may soon exit its monetary stimulus, according to German economist Sabine Lautenschlaeger. Rising consumer confidence and low unemployment rates in the eurozone suggest an improving economy, making it a suitable time to reduce support. Lautenschlaeger expressed optimism about exiting the stimulus, but no specific timeline was given. This development could signal a shift in the ECB's monetary policy, potentially impacting the eurozone economy and financial markets.

site_title: Japan's Line swings to full-year profit on higher ad revenue
summary: Japan's Line Corp reported a net profit of 7.56 billion yen for the year ended Dec 31, reversing a loss of 7.58 billion yen in the previous year. The company's profit was driven by growth in advertising revenue, but operating profit was lower than forecast due to increased costs and payment issues. Line's income primarily comes from ads, mobile games, and emoticon "stickers".

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's sovereign wealth fund GIC has acquired a 95% stake in 60 Wall Street, a US headquarters building for Deutsche Bank. The move marks a significant deal. Additionally, Singapore has improved its ranking to 7th in the annual least corrupt countries index. Meanwhile, Vietnam expressed surprise over the US's announcement of a potential tariff increase, and the Asian garment industry is bracing for potential higher US tariffs. China's GDP growth is expected to slow, and Citigroup has set a target for the MSCI's global equity index to reach 1,150 by mid-2026.

site_title: Oil market already starting to rebalance: Kuwait
summary: Kuwait Oil Minister Essam al-Marzouk stated that oil markets have started to rebalance due to producers complying with output cuts. The 1.8 million barrel per day reduction agreement, implemented in December, is showing encouraging signs of compliance. This rebalancing is expected to positively impact the market by the end of Q1 2017, with crude stocks returning to normal levels and prices recovering to encourage investments. Compliance with the cuts is seen as a guarantee for price recovery.

images.alt_text: Oil markets have already begun to rebalance after strong signs that producers are complying with output cuts, Kuwait Oil Minister Essam al-Marzouk said on Wednesday.

site_title: Rio Tinto sale to Yancoal resets mood for Australian coal mine deals
summary: Chinese-owned Yancoal has acquired Rio Tinto's Coal & Allied division for $2.45 billion, marking a significant shift in the Australian coal mining landscape. With coal prices in retreat, Asian buyers are expected to lead the way in acquiring assets valued at over $10 billion. Deals stalled last year due to rising coal prices, but with prices now falling, buyers and sellers are taking more realistic views on valuations, setting the stage for more big-ticket acquisitions.

site_title: Banks seen saving 77b baht in Thailand e-payment roll out
summary: Thailand's PromptPay digital-payment system is set to launch, expected to save commercial banks around 77 billion baht (S$3.1 billion) over the next 10 years by curbing cash transactions. The system, which levies lower transaction fees, is seen as a way to promote a digital economy and curb illicit financial flows. Analysts expect a 5% cut in banks' fee income in the early period, but long-term benefits may offset costs, benefiting most banks. Over 30 million registrations are expected by the end of 2017, with PromptPay transfers of less than 5,000 baht being free.

site_title: Acra to get new chief
summary: Singapore's Accounting and Corporate Regulatory Authority (Acra) will have a new chief executive, Ong Khiaw Hong, starting April 1. He is currently the deputy commissioner of the Corporate and Services Group at the Inland Revenue Authority of Singapore. Current Acra chief executive Kenneth Yap will return to the Singapore Legal Service in April, ending his 2-year tenure.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks up marginally, won reverses as US dollar bounce flags
summary: South Korea's won marginally rose against the US dollar, reversing early losses, as the dollar retreated late in the session. The won was quoted at 1,166.0 to the US dollar, almost unchanged from the previous day. Meanwhile, South Korean shares rose 0.1% to close at 2,066.94 points, with foreign investors buying 211.3 billion won worth of Kospi shares.

site_title: China's banking regulator issues guidelines on outbound investment
summary: China's banking regulator has issued guidelines to strengthen control and management of funding for outbound investment, aiming to clamp down on cross-border capital outflows and questionable investments. The China Banking Regulatory Commission instructed commercial banks to bolster risk and compliance management and improve anti-money laundering and anti-terrorist financing activities. These guidelines follow Beijing's efforts to regulate overseas investments and mitigate potential risks.

site_title: PetroChina warns net income dropped as much as 80% in 2016
summary: PetroChina Co reported a 80% drop in net income in 2016, blaming low international oil prices and domestic natural gas prices. The company's third-quarter profit had also dropped 77% in October. PetroChina expects global oil prices to rise in 2017, with Brent crude averaging $45 a barrel last year. The company plans to continue cost-cutting efforts.

site_title: Sterling steadies after Supreme Court turbulence
summary: The British pound steadied against major currencies on Wednesday after a day of significant volatility following a Supreme Court ruling that requires the government to go through parliament before starting Brexit talks. The pound jumped to five-week highs on Tuesday but then sank as low as US$1.2419, before trading above US$1.25. The court's ruling also stated the government does not need to go through regional assemblies to start Brexit talks, alleviating investor worries about Northern Ireland and Scotland's potential responses.

site_title: BHP lifts shale spending as oil gains lure drillers to add rigs
summary: BHP Billiton Ltd, the largest overseas investor in US shale, has boosted spending on its onshore oil and gas division to $165 million in the December quarter, a 53% increase from the previous quarter. The company also increased overall planned petroleum exploration spending by 17% to $820 million for fiscal 2017. This move follows a deals spree and positive drilling results in the Gulf of Mexico, as the oil industry prepares to raise spending for the first time in three years.

site_title: Indonesia attracts tepid foreign direct investment inflow in Q4
summary: Indonesia's foreign direct investment (FDI) slowed significantly in Q4 2016, with a 2.1% increase in rupiah terms and a 5% contraction in dollar terms. The country attracted $29.0 billion in FDI in 2016, down from $29.3 billion the previous year. Analysts attribute the decline to political tensions in Jakarta ahead of regional elections and concerns over emerging markets. Despite this, some analysts see the data as "relatively encouraging" and point to the need for more FDI to boost Indonesia's manufacturing sector and finance its current account deficit.

images.alt_text: Growth in foreign direct investment (FDI) slowed significantly in Indonesia in 2016's final quarter, which could dent efforts to boost the rate at which Southeast Asia's largest economy is expanding.

site_title: 16,300 SMEs tapped grants from Spring in 2016
summary: Spring Singapore provided funding support to 16,300 companies in 2016, despite a slowing economy, with 16,700 projects funded. This represents a decrease from 2015, when 22,000 companies received support for 22,000 projects. The agency's funding helped SMEs, but the trend may indicate a shift in economic conditions.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks clock up third day of gains
summary: Hong Kong shares rose for a third consecutive day, driven by a rally across Asian markets and a record close on Wall Street. The Hang Seng Index increased 0.43%, while the Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also rose. The gains come as concerns over Donald Trump's domestic policies ease.

site_title: Novartis to buy back US$5b in shares
summary: Swiss pharmaceutical giant Novartis announced a US$5 billion share buyback despite a 62% drop in net profit to US$6.7 billion in 2016. The company attributed the decline to competition from generics, but noted sales of new products helped absorb the loss. Novartis also announced a 2% increase in dividend to 2.75 Swiss francs per share and expects sales to remain stable in 2017. The company plans to explore options for its ophthalmological division Alcon, including a potential stock market listing.

site_title: Toyota to add 400 US jobs after Trump slams Mexico plan
summary: Toyota plans to invest $600 million and create 400 jobs at its US plant in Indiana, following criticism from President Trump over a planned factory in Mexico. The expansion aims to boost SUV production and increase competitiveness. The project, set to begin in 2019, is part of Toyota's localization strategy. The company also announced a $10 billion investment in the US over the next five years, demonstrating its commitment to continued US investment.

site_title: Profits fall again at South Korea's LG Electronics
summary: LG Electronics reported its second consecutive year of declining net profits in 2016, with a full-year profit of 126.3 billion won (S$155.26 million), down 50% from 2015. The company attributed the decline to weak smartphone sales. This marks the second consecutive year of profit slumps, following a 50% drop in 2015.

site_title: Australia shares end higher on materials and financials; NZ up
summary: Australian shares rose 0.4% to end at 5,671.50, driven by financial stocks and materials underpinned by higher commodity prices. This follows a broad US market rally led by financial and technology stocks. The S&P/ASX 200 index rose 21.40 points, while New Zealand shares were up, despite US trade tensions.

site_title: Banco Santander profit rises to 1.6b euros
summary: Banco Santander reported a 6.4-fold increase in fourth-quarter profit to 1.6 billion euros, beating analyst estimates of 1.48 billion euros. The bank's profit was driven by lower loan provisions and higher income from Brazil. Chairman Ana Botin expects emerging markets and consumer finance to offset low interest rates and regulatory costs in Europe. This marks a significant turnaround from the previous year's 25 million euros in profit, which was impacted by charges related to payment protection insurance.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares rise, boosted by US rally, weaker yen
summary: Tokyo shares rose 1.43% on Wednesday, boosted by a weaker yen and a record close on Wall Street. The benchmark Nikkei stock index rose to 19,057.50, while the Topix index added 1.01% to 1,521.58. The rally follows days of losses linked to US President Donald Trump's economic policies.

site_title: Hyundai Motor's profit skids for a 12th quarter, sedan discounts drag
summary: Hyundai Motor's profits fell 39% in the fourth quarter to 1 trillion won (S$1.219 billion) due to steep discounts on smaller sedans losing ground in the US and South Korea. The company's quarterly sales fell 0.9% to 24.5 trillion won, and operating profit dropped 33% from year-ago levels. Hyundai attributes the decline to growing trade protectionism and rising competition, with uncertainty expected to persist in the auto industry this year.

site_title: Gold prices slip on technicals; markets eye Trump policy
summary: Gold prices slipped 0.3-0.5% to $1,204.80 per ounce due to a technical correction following a 8% rally since mid-December, fueled by concerns over US President Donald Trump's protectionist trade policies. Analysts expect gold to test $1,185 during the Chinese Spring Festival due to market volatility. Despite Trump's recent policy moves, including the withdrawal from the Trans-Pacific Partnership and Keystone XL pipeline orders, gold remains an attractive investment option for those seeking protection from geopolitical and financial turmoil.

site_title: South Korea slowdown has further to run, due to politics and trade
summary: South Korea's economy is expected to continue slowing down due to ongoing presidential and corporate scandals, with the country's gross domestic product expanding just 0.4% in the three months through December. Consumer confidence is near an eight-year low, and a tepid 0.2% increase in private consumption is the main culprit. This marks the weakest quarter-on-quarter performance since June 2015. The slowdown is attributed to politics and trade, with no early end to the scandals in sight.

site_title: OUE Hospitality Trust's Q4 DPS falls to 1.36 cents
summary: OUE Hospitality Trust reported a 0.34 Singapore cent drop in distribution per stapled security (DPS) to 1.36 cents for the fourth quarter ended Dec 31, 2016. The trust's full-year DPS was 4.61 cents, 1.46 cents lower than the restated FY2015. Gross revenue rose 0.7% year-over-year to S$33.2 million in Q4, while net property income (NPI) increased 2.5% to S$29.56 million. The trust's counter closed at S$0.685 after the announcement.

images.alt_text: OUE Hospitality Trust (OUE H-Trust) on Wednesday reported a 0.34 Singapore cent fall in distribution per stapled security (DPS) to 1.36 Singapore cents for the fourth quarter ended Dec 31, 2016, on the back of an increase in stapled securities.

site_title: UBS says US dollar to 'roll over' amid Trump spending, tax cuts
summary: UBS predicts the US dollar will decline this year due to President Donald Trump's spending and tax cuts, which could lead to a twin deficit situation and negatively impact the currency. This decline is expected to benefit base and precious metals. Trump has started implementing his agenda, including infrastructure rebuilding and tax cuts, which UBS believes will increase debt and lead to economic challenges.

site_title: Europe: Stock markets advance at open
summary: European stock markets rose at the open on Wednesday, with London's FTSE 100 up 0.6% and Frankfurt's DAX 30 index gaining 0.7%. The Paris CAC 40 also added 0.7% to its close on Tuesday. The gains were driven by mining and healthcare stocks, with US-EU trade talks also in focus. Despite some uncertainty, investors remained positive, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq edging to fresh records in the US.

site_title: Nicole Kidman says Oscar nominations get more exciting as she ages
summary: Nicole Kidman expressed her excitement about being nominated for an Academy Award, stating that the experience becomes more thrilling as she ages. She was nominated for her role in the biographical drama "Lion" alongside other actresses including Viola Davis, Octavia Spencer, and Michelle Williams. The Oscar nominations were announced on Tuesday night, with Kidman attending a Giorgio Armani fashion show in Paris, where she was also seen with nominated actress Isabelle Huppert.

site_title: Three foreigners jailed in Taiwan over ATM heist
summary: Three eastern European men, Andrejs Peregudovs from Latvia, Mihail Colibaba from Romania, and Niklae Penkov from Moldova, were jailed for five years in Taiwan over a $2.6 million cyberheist that targeted the First Commercial Bank's ATM network in July. The suspects used malware to hack into the bank's system, withdrawing money from dozens of machines in three cities. They were also fined NT$600,000 and will be deported after completing their sentences. The attack was the first of its kind in Taiwan and is believed to be linked to a similar heist in Thailand last year.

site_title: EU calls for China to take 'concrete' steps in opening market
summary: The European Union is urging China to take concrete steps in opening its markets to global investment. Following Chinese President Xi Jinping's speech at the World Economic Forum in Davos, Switzerland, EU Ambassador Hans Dietmar Schweisgut stated that Xi's words must be translated into action. Xi called for "inclusive globalisation" and unity, warning against self-isolation. The EU's call comes amid a slowdown in China's GDP growth, raising pressure on policymakers.

site_title: Australia dollar slips 0.5% on soft inflation, NZD near 10-week high
summary: The Australian dollar dropped 0.5% to US$0.7535 after fourth-quarter inflation came in below expectations, with consumer prices rising 0.5% and underlying inflation at 0.4%. This underlines the risk that interest rates may decrease this year, rather than increase.

site_title: Australia inflation surprisingly subdued, rekindles rate cut hopes
summary: Australian consumer prices rose 0.5% in the fourth quarter, missing forecasts and keeping rate cut hopes alive. Core inflation stayed at all-time lows, and the annual pace increased to 1.5%. The Reserve Bank of Australia's target inflation band of 2-3% remains out of reach, with economists predicting another rate cut in May. The Australian dollar dropped, and market expectations of future interest rate changes remain uncertain.

site_title: How team Trump sees unemployment and why it matters
summary: US President-elect Donald Trump and his team have expressed skepticism over the official unemployment rate, citing its potential underestimation of labor market slack. Treasury Secretary nominee Steven Mnuchin and White House Press Secretary Sean Spicer have clarified that the official rate does not accurately reflect labor market health. The Trump administration is likely to focus on broader indicators of labor market strength, such as the U-5 rate, which includes both currently unemployed and those who have looked for work. This may inform their fiscal policy views, potentially supporting big government spending packages if labor market weakness persists.

site_title: Trump says to host India's Modi for US visit later this year: White House
summary: US President Donald Trump invited Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi to visit the US later this year, discussing economic and defense cooperation, as well as security in South and Central Asia. The two leaders resolved to stand together in the global fight against terrorism. The phone call marked the first time Trump has invited a foreign leader to visit the US since taking office.

site_title: Economists see BOJ stimulus on hold, focus on yield-curve target
summary: The Bank of Japan (BOJ) is expected to keep its stimulus unchanged at the next policy board meeting, with 42 economists surveyed predicting no change. Forecasts indicate a rise in tapering of asset purchases and tightening of interest rates, with 24 economists expecting the BOJ to cut its bond purchase target or drop it altogether. The 10-year bond yield target is also expected to be raised, but officials at the BOJ prefer to be late rather than early in raising it. The BOJ forecasts inflation will be 1.5% in the fiscal year starting in April.

site_title: Americans distrustful after hacking epidemic: survey
summary: A survey by the Pew Research Center found that nearly two-thirds of Americans have experienced data theft or fraud, leading to mistrust in institutions. 64% of respondents reported having personal data stolen, with 41% encountering fraudulent credit card charges. Americans are concerned about telecom firms, credit card companies, and social media sites, but have little confidence in the government's ability to protect their data. Many fail to take proactive security measures, such as using two-factor authentication or password management software, and neglect to install important updates on their devices.

site_title: Thai junta gives go-ahead to buy Chinese submarine and tanks
summary: Thailand's military government has approved 13.5 billion baht to purchase a Chinese submarine and 40 tanks, including 10 new ones and 30 auxiliary vehicles. The purchase, put on hold last year, is seen as part of strengthening relations with China. The submarine will enable the navy to study tactics and prepare for potential submarine warfare. This move comes after the US froze security aid following a 2014 coup, and China was the first major power to acknowledge Thailand's junta. The purchase is expected to be finalized this year.

images.alt_text: Thailand's military government has approved 13.5 billion baht (S$540 million) to buy a submarine from China after putting the purchase on hold last year, Thai officials said on Wednesday.

site_title: Americans are flipping houses like it's 2006
summary: Home flippers accounted for 6.1% of US home sales in 2016, the highest share since 2006, according to Trulia. This marks a comeback in cities affected by the foreclosure crisis, such as Las Vegas, Tampa, and Fresno. Eleven metropolitan areas reached 17-year highs in flip rates, with Memphis and Atlanta among the top. The resurgence of flipping is attributed to the cities' recovery from the foreclosure crisis, with investors seeking short-term gains in the housing market.

images.alt_text: A tactic that helped define the height of homebuying madness in the US in the years before the market collapsed is rearing its head again.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks track US gains at open
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose 0.28% in early trading on January 25, 2017, tracking a record close on Wall Street. The Hang Seng Index climbed to 23,013.68, while the Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index fell 0.16% and 0.12%, respectively.

site_title: Thai economy may grow faster than 3.4% this year: finance ministry
summary: Thailand's economy is expected to grow faster than initially forecasted at 3.4% this year, according to the finance ministry. Senior official Krisada Chinavicharana attributed the potential growth to increased government spending and improved exports. Additionally, better oil prices and global economic prospects are also expected to contribute to the growth.

site_title: Australia shares edge up on financials, materials; NZ slightly up
summary: Australian shares rose 0.3% to 5,666.20, driven by gains in materials and financials, while gold stocks fell. The ASX financial index gained 0.7% and the Big Four banks rose 0.6-1%. BHP Billiton and Rio Tinto also rose due to strong earnings reports. New Zealand's benchmark index gained marginally, supported by healthcare and industrial stocks.

site_title: Trump says he will 'send in the Feds' if Chicago doesn't end 'carnage'
summary: US President Donald Trump warned Chicago to address the city's 'carnage' of violence, stating he would "send in the Feds" if the situation doesn't improve. Trump's comments follow his inauguration speech, where he accused the Washington establishment of abandoning regular citizens. The city has struggled with poverty and crime, leading Trump to take action.

site_title: Seoul: Won slips as US dollar recovers; stocks steady
summary: The South Korean won decreased marginally to 1,166.3 won per US dollar due to the dollar's recovery. The won has been sensitive to the dollar's movement since January. Despite South Korea's economic growth retreating in the last quarter, the market remained steady, with shares like Samsung Electronics and Samsung SDI rising. The Korea Composite Stock Price Index (Kospi) remained at 2,066.58 points, and offshore investors purchased Kospi shares worth 55.2 billion won.

site_title: Taiwan: Markets closed for holiday
summary: Taiwan's financial markets were closed on January 25, 2017, for a public holiday. Meanwhile, in July 2025, Singapore stocks experienced a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data. The STI rose 0.4% on July 10, despite tariff uncertainty and split Fed views. Additionally, eSIM platform Airalo raised $220 million in new funding, lifting its valuation past $1 billion.

site_title: Asia: Markets track US surge as Trump fear eases
summary: Asian markets rose on Wednesday, following a record close on Wall Street, as investor concerns about Donald Trump's lack of domestic policies eased. Trump signed off on the Keystone XL pipeline and another oil pipeline deal, reversing Obama's decisions. The developments lifted markets, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq reaching all-time highs, and the dollar gaining against the yen. The dollar's gains were short-lived, with some analysts predicting a potential drop to 100 yen by the end of 2017.

site_title: US Senate confirms Haley as Trump's UN ambassador
summary: The US Senate voted almost unanimously to confirm Nikki Haley as the new UN ambassador, with 96 senators supporting her and 4 opposing. Haley, the 45-year-old South Carolina Governor, promised to press for UN reforms and fight for human rights, breaking from President Trump's positions. She is only the fourth confirmed member of Trump's Cabinet, joining Defense Secretary James Mattis, Homeland Security Secretary John Kelly, and Central Intelligence Agency Director Mike Pompeo.

site_title: Panama charges 17 people linked to Odebrecht bribe case
summary: Panama has charged 17 people, including businessmen and former government officials, with money laundering in connection with bribes paid by Brazilian construction firm Odebrecht SA. The bribes were paid between 2010 and 2014 to secure business contracts under former President Ricardo Martinelli's administration. Odebrecht verbally agreed to pay $59 million in payments for the bribes. The charges include three former officials from Martinelli's administration. The move is part of a larger investigation into corruption in Panama.

images.alt_text: Panama prosecutors said on Tuesday they had charged 17 people, including several businessmen and former government officials, with money laundering as part of the case of millions of dollars worth of bribes paid by Brazilian construction firm Odebrecht SA.

site_title: Trump's wall pledge sparks surge in Central American immigrants
summary: US President Donald Trump's pledge to build a border wall has sparked a surge in Central American immigrants attempting to cross into the US, with coyotes encouraging them to make the journey before the wall is constructed. This has led to a 33% increase in US Border Patrol detentions, with migrants paying up to $6,500 to be smuggled through Mexico. Coyotes are offering extended payment plans and accepting collateral, such as cars and properties, to facilitate the journey, as Trump's deportation and wall plans become more concrete.

images.alt_text: A view of the border line between Mexico and the US in Sonora state, Mexico. President Donald Trump's pledge to build a "big, beautiful, powerful wall" along the Mexican border is persuading more Central Americans to try to get into the US before he makes good on his promise.

site_title: China's Xi warns against overcapacity on visit to 2022 Winter Olympic venue
summary: Chinese President Xi Jinping warned northern province Hebei to reduce overcapacity, urging shuttered "zombie" factories to remain closed. The comments came during a visit to Zhangjiakou city, a 2022 Winter Olympics venue. China has been pushing to cut overcapacity, but a jump in steel prices has encouraged producers to ramp up production, potentially exacerbating a global steel glut. Xi's efforts aim to address the issue ahead of the Olympics.

site_title: US dollar drifts lower as rebound stalls amid lingering Trump woes
summary: The US dollar drifted lower against the yen and euro due to lingering concerns over US President Donald Trump's protectionist stance. The dollar fell 0.25% to 113.500 yen, after briefly reaching 114.00, and lost 0.3% against the euro. This reverses a 1% gain from the previous day, which saw the dollar bounce from an eight-week low. The decline is attributed to ongoing worries about Trump's policies, which may impact global trade and economic growth.

site_title: Vietnamese factories hum at full capacity despite Trump snub
summary: Vietnamese factories continue to operate at full capacity despite US President Donald Trump's cancellation of the Trans-Pacific Partnership, a trade agreement expected to boost Vietnam's GDP by 8% by 2030. NhaBe Garment Corp, a supplier to brands like Calvin Klein and Michael Kors, has seen exports more than double to $729 million and increased its factories from 17 to 35. The company remains committed to its production plans, with managing director Michael Laskau stating that all factories are filled. The cancellation has not deterred multinationals from investing in Vietnam.

site_title: Abe has a Trump problem: How to get Japan to buy US cars
summary: Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe faces a dilemma in convincing his citizens to buy American cars after President Donald Trump withdrew from the Trans-Pacific Partnership agreement, singling out Japan for failing to purchase US vehicles. Abe has given no indication he'd entertain a TPP without the US, and any retreat from the agreement could damage his approval rating. The US administration prefers a bilateral trade deal, but Japan's trade surplus with the US and lack of tariffs on US cars may hinder negotiations. The situation highlights the importance of vehicles in US-Japan trade relations.

images.alt_text: As Japan races to preserve US trade ties after President Donald Trump withdrew from a Pacific trade pact, Prime Minister Shinzo Abe faces a dilemma that has plagued Japanese leaders since the 1980s: How to convince his citizens to buy American cars?

site_title: Taiwan economy rallies thanks to electronics demand
summary: Taiwan's economy experienced its best performance in almost two years in the final quarter of 2016, with a 2.58% year-on-year growth rate, driven by strong demand for electronics. This was the third consecutive quarter of growth since the economy came out of recession in April-June 2016. The strong electronics sector offset a decline in mainland tourists, marking the fastest expansion since the first-quarter of 2015.

site_title: Woman at centre of South Korea scandal shouts out her innocence
summary: A woman at the center of South Korea's corruption scandal, Choi Soon-Sil, protested her innocence, shouting she was forced to confess while being questioned. She was indicted for meddling in state affairs through her friendship with impeached President Park Geun-Hye. The outgoing chief judge urged the Constitutional Court to wrap up the impeachment trial by March 13, raising questions about the verdict. Choi was pushed into an elevator by correctional officers after the protest, amid a highly charged atmosphere surrounding the country's ongoing corruption scandal.

site_title: Singapore shares open 15 points higher on Wed
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index rose 14.96 points, or 0.49%, to 3,056.91, driven by gains from DBS, Singtel, and Global Logistic Properties. The exchange saw 221.7 million shares worth S$208.4 million trade, with gainers outnumbering losers 124 to 50. This marks the 5th consecutive day of gains ahead of GDP data.

site_title: GIC buys billion-dollar US headquarters of Deutsche Bank on Wall Street
summary: Singapore's sovereign wealth fund GIC has acquired a 95% stake in 60 Wall Street, the US headquarters of Deutsche Bank, for $1.04 billion. The 47-storey skyscraper, valued at $640 per square foot, serves as Deutsche Bank's main US office. The deal marks a significant investment in the US financial sector by GIC.

site_title: Japan's annual exports up for first time in 15 months on global demand
summary: Japan's annual exports rose 5.4% year-on-year in December, the first increase in 15 months, driven by car parts and electronics shipments. The rise follows a 0.4% annual decline in November and an 8.4% increase in volume for a second straight month. The data is encouraging for the Bank of Japan, which is set to review its policy next week. However, concerns about US protectionism under President Trump have raised uncertainty over the outlook, particularly after the US formally withdrew from the Trans-Pacific Partnership trade deal.

site_title: China foreign minister says wants to manage disputes with US
summary: China's Foreign Minister Wang Yi stated that the country is willing to engage in dialogue with the US administration, but only on the basis of respecting each other's core interests, including the "one China" principle. This comes after US President Donald Trump expressed doubt on the principle before taking office. China views Taiwan as a wayward province to be brought under its control, while Taiwan is a democratic nation with no interest in being ruled by Beijing. Wang aims to manage disputes, increase trust, and promote healthy relations between China and the US.

site_title: Philippines Q3 annual GDP growth revised down slightly to 7.0%
summary: The Philippine economy's annual growth in the third quarter has been revised down to 7.0% from 7.1%, according to the statistics agency. Annual growth is now seen weaker at 6.5% due to the waning impact of election spending. The revised data follows a Reuters poll, which also predicted a weaker annual growth rate. The impact of election spending is expected to continue into the fourth quarter, with annual growth seen weaker at 6.5%.

site_title: Headhunters seek China bank experts as capital under strain
summary: Headhunters are seeking Chinese bank experts to help lenders bolster capital buffers as the financial system faces a potential crisis. Chinese lenders have raised a record $62.8 billion in US dollar bonds in 2016, but rating companies warn they need to sell more debt with equity characteristics to replenish capital. Rising bad loans, falling profitability, and Basel III regulations are straining bank capital, with 15 Chinese commercial banks planning to raise $65 billion in additional Tier 1 notes by 2018.

site_title: Trump expected to order temporary ban on refugees
summary: US President Donald Trump is expected to sign executive orders on Wednesday, including a temporary ban on most refugees and a suspension of visas for citizens of seven Middle Eastern and African countries. The ban will initially apply to most refugees except for religious minorities escaping persecution. The orders also include measures to tighten border security, such as directing the construction of a border wall with Mexico. Detractors may launch legal challenges to the moves, citing potential discrimination against Muslims.

images.alt_text: President Donald Trump is expected to sign executive orders starting on Wednesday that include a temporary ban on most refugees and a suspension of visas for citizens of Syria and six other Middle Eastern and African countries.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Suntec Reit, PLife Reit, Oceanus, Ascott Reit
summary: Suntec Reit announced a 5.6% drop in DPU to 2.596 cents for Q4 2016, while Parkway Life Reit's DPU grew 2.3% to 3.06 cents. Oceanus Group converted 76.4% of debt to equity to restructure, and Ascott Residence Trust maintained a "buy" call despite a 7% drop in DPU to 1.93 cents.

site_title: Panama suspends Panama Papers probe
summary: Panama has suspended its investigation into the Panama Papers, a leak of offshore company records that revealed leaders and celebrities using tax avoidance schemes. The probe was halted due to a legal challenge on constitutional grounds, and it now rests with the Supreme Court to decide whether to resume. The Panama Papers scandal exposed widespread tax avoidance and money laundering, linking prominent figures such as Russian President Vladimir Putin and Argentine President Mauricio Macri to unreported offshore companies.

site_title: Gap says Banana Republic head to leave, CEO to oversee brand
summary: Gap Inc announced that Banana Republic global president Andi Owen will leave the company in late February. CEO Art Peck will oversee the brand as it searches for Owen's replacement. The move comes as Banana Republic faces a seven-quarter sales decline. Gap has been trying to replicate Old Navy's success at its Gap and Banana Republic brands. The company previously shut 75 Old Navy and Banana Republic stores outside the US.

site_title: Europeans aren't taking advantage of low rates to manage debt
summary: Europeans are missing an opportunity to manage their debt due to low interest rates, with almost two-thirds failing to take advantage of the situation. A survey by ING found that only 11% of those who saved less due to low rates used that spare cash to clear a loan, and just 8% paid off part of their mortgage. Experts say the low rates were a chance for Europeans to sort out their debt, but they have not taken it, potentially leaving them vulnerable to rising interest rates.

site_title: Taiwan Q4 preliminary GDP growth at 2.58%, fastest in 7 quarters
summary: Taiwan's economy expanded 2.58% in Q4 2016, the fastest annual growth in 7 quarters, according to preliminary government figures. This growth rate was below the 3.1% median forecast. The full-year 2016 growth was 1.4%, slightly higher than the 0.72% of 2015. Despite this, the growth was still slower than the 4.01% in Q1 2015.

site_title: Rio Tinto sells Australia coal mines to China's Yancoal
summary: Rio Tinto has sold its majority stake in Australian coal mines to China-backed Yancoal in a deal worth up to $2.45 billion. The sale, part of Rio's divestment strategy, includes Coal & Allied mines in New South Wales. The deal, subject to regulatory approvals, is expected to be completed in the second half of 2017. Rio aims to boost its bottom line with the sale, following a 47% decline in underlying profits in the previous six months.

site_title: Mourning death of TTP, Canada to seek increased trade with China, Japan
summary: Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau announced plans to focus on trade with Japan and China after the US withdrawal from the Trans-Pacific Partnership. Trudeau emphasized Canada's strong historical trade ties with the US, citing millions of jobs on both sides of the border. He also signaled interest in a free trade agreement with China, following exploratory talks scheduled for next month. Trudeau's focus on Asia aims to ensure "good jobs and prosperity" for Canada, as he seeks to strengthen economic ties with growing economies in the region.

site_title: Oil prices rise as Opec output cuts drain stocks
summary: Oil prices rose on Tuesday as Opec's production cuts drained global stocks, with Brent futures gaining 21 cents to $55.44 per barrel and US West Texas Intermediate gaining 43 cents to $53.18 per barrel. The cuts, which began on January 1, have reduced output by 1.5 million barrels per day. However, increased US drilling may keep prices in check, and analysts expect a potential shift to border-adjusted corporate tax in the US could drive up prices further.

site_title: US dollar gains vs yen, euro with outlook seen positive still
summary: The US dollar strengthened against the yen and euro on Tuesday, reversing recent losses, as investors remain optimistic about the US economic outlook despite President Trump's trade protectionist rhetoric. The Federal Reserve is expected to implement 2-3 rate hikes in 2017, supporting dollar strength. Central banks in Europe and Japan are likely to maintain easing monetary policies, contributing to the dollar's gains.

images.alt_text: The US dollar firmed against the yen and euro on Tuesday, after several days of losses in the wake of President Donald Trump's inaugural speech promising more trade protectionism, with the US economic outlook still seen as better than that of Europe or Japan.

site_title: Oceanus in debt restructuring deal with key creditors
summary: Oceanus Group, a premium seafood supply chain manager, has entered into a debt restructuring deal with key creditors BW Investment, Ocean Wonder International, and Ocean King Group. The deal involves converting 76.4% of its total outstanding debt to equity, substantially improving its balance sheet. Approximately S$31.87 million of the outstanding debt will be transferred to a consortium of new investors and Oceanus management.

images.alt_text: Homegrown premium seafood supply chain manager Oceanus Group has entered into a binding term sheet with its key creditors in relation to a proposed debt restructuring.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened higher on Wednesday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index increasing 2.770 points to 1683.460. Gainers outnumbered losers 82 to 31, and volume reached 21.9 million lots worth RM13.28 million. This comes after a global stocks rally, with the US S&P 500 and Nasdaq reaching fresh records despite trade uncertainty.

site_title: Trump believes 'millions' voted illegally: White House
summary: US President Donald Trump believes that millions of people voted illegally in the November election, with estimates ranging from 3 to 5 million, according to White House spokesman Sean Spicer. However, there is no public evidence to support this claim, and the outcome of the election was confirmed by the electoral college. If proven, widespread illegal voting would be a major scandal undermining US democracy. Trump has cited studies suggesting non-citizens voted, but these have been disputed for flawed methodology. The White House has declined to launch an investigation into the claim.

site_title: New York City mayor seeks bigger reserves on Washington uncertainty
summary: New York City Mayor Bill de Blasio announced a record amount of money in reserve, aiming to hold $250 million annually for four years to offset potential federal funding cuts under President Donald Trump. The plan also seeks $1 billion in savings citywide, primarily through reduced debt service costs and lower agency expenditures. The proposed budget allocates $84.7 billion for fiscal 2018, with $1.1 billion in savings. However, officials still lack details on possible Washington changes to plan more precisely, with potential cuts to areas like Medicaid, police, education, and environmental protection.

site_title: Suntec Reit's Q4 DPU slips, S$800m Penang Rd project to be completed end 2019
summary: Suntec Reit reported a 5.6% decline in Q4 distribution per unit (DPU) to 2.596 cents, and a 4.9% decrease in distributable income to S$66.1 million. The company's full-year DPU and distributable income were in line with the previous year. Development works for the new Penang Road project, valued at S$800 million, began in December 2016 and is scheduled for completion by end 2019.

site_title: Nasty or nice? Study links personality to brain shape
summary: A study by the University of Cambridge found a correlation between brain shape and five main personality types, including neuroticism, extraversion, open-mindedness, agreeableness, and conscientiousness. Researchers analyzed brain scans of over 500 people aged 22-36 and discovered that neuroticism was linked to a thicker cortex and smaller folding in certain brain regions, while openness was associated with a thinner cortex and greater folding. The study suggests that brain shape may be an early indicator of mental health disorders, but its findings do not prove that brain shape determines personality.

site_title: Apple is trumping Trump in Taiwan with Asia's only currency gain
summary: Taiwan's currency and stock market have surged, with the Taiex reaching a 1.5-year high and the local dollar reaching its strongest level since October, driven by foreign investors' bets on Apple's iPhone orders. Analysts expect a 20% increase in earnings per share in the next 12 months, fueled by the tech giant's upgrade plans. Despite concerns over US protectionism and President Trump's stance on Taiwan, investors remain optimistic, citing Taiwan's economic growth and trade factors as reasons for its resilience.

images.alt_text: Taiwan is proving a surprising investment winner under Donald Trump.

site_title: South Korea Q4 GDP rise 0.4% q-o-q, slightly higher than expected
summary: South Korea's gross domestic product rose 0.4% in the final quarter of 2016, beating the median forecast of 0.3%. Private consumption grew 0.2% and construction investment declined 1.7%. The economy expanded 2.7% for the whole of 2016, edging up from a 2.6% gain in 2015. This slight growth exceeded expectations and suggests a stable economy, despite some sectors experiencing decline.

images.alt_text: South Korea's gross domestic product rose 0.4 per cent in the final quarter of 2016 from previous three months, when it gained 0.6 per cent, central bank estimates showed on Wednesday.

site_title: China energy firm expands in crisis-hit Brazil
summary: China's State Grid signed a $4.5 billion deal to buy a majority stake in Brazilian electricity giant CPFL, expanding its presence in the country. The purchase, worth 14.19 billion reals, aims to diversify State Grid's business portfolio and strengthen its position in Brazil's electricity sector. This deal comes as Chinese firms ramp up investments in Brazil, where local firms are selling off assets to weather the crisis, with Chinese companies currently holding $15.2 billion worth of investments in the country.

site_title: Parkway Life Reit Q4 DPU up 2.3%
summary: Parkway Life Reit (PLife Reit) reported a 2.3% increase in its distribution per unit (DPU) for Q4 2016 and 2.8% for the full year ended Dec 31, 2016. This excludes a one-off distribution from the divestment of seven Japan properties in December 2016. The Q4 DPU was 3.06 Singapore cents, while the FY DPU was 12.12 Singapore cents. The growth is attributed to the trust's successful divestment and rental income from its properties.

site_title: India's steel demand revival hinges on Modi's roads-to-rail spending
summary: India's steel demand is expected to revive due to the government's increased spending on infrastructure, housing, and road projects. Finance Minister Arun Jaitley will announce higher outlays for national highways, rural roads, railways, and low-cost housing, predicted to stimulate domestic steel demand. Steel mills in India, such as JSW Steel, Steel Authority of India Ltd, and Tata Steel, project a record output this year, driven by Prime Minister Narendra Modi's infrastructure push. Steel demand could expand by around 10% if all government projects are implemented.

site_title: UK women face high heels and make-up rules at work: report
summary: A UK parliamentary report found that many workplaces, despite being illegal, enforce strict dress codes targeting women, such as high heels, blonde hair, and make-up. The report, sparked by a PricewaterhouseCoopers incident, received over 150,000 signatures and found the current law is not fully effective in preventing discrimination. The committee called for the government to review and change the law, citing the pain and damage caused by these dress codes, and arguing that they must be applied equally to both men and women.

images.alt_text: High heels, blonde hair and make-up are among dress codes for women in the British workplace, despite gender discrimination being illegal, a parliamentary report released on Wednesday has found.

site_title: US: Stocks rally on renewed Trump optimism; Nasdaq, S&P hit records
summary: US stocks surged on renewed optimism about President Donald Trump's economic policies, pushing the Nasdaq and S&P 500 to fresh all-time highs. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 0.6% to 19,912.71, while the S&P 500 climbed 0.7% to 2,280.07. Investors bet on tax reductions and economic stimulus, despite mixed corporate earnings and lingering trade protectionism concerns. Trump's moves to revive pipeline projects and positive comments from House Speaker Paul Ryan on infrastructure spending also boosted investor confidence.

site_title: Microsoft victory in overseas data privacy case stands
summary: A federal appeals court has reaffirmed Microsoft's right to refuse a US government order to hand over data stored overseas in a case with significant privacy implications. The US had sought the contents of an email account stored in Ireland, but Microsoft handed over account information on US soil while keeping the email content off-limits. The court's decision is seen as a victory for digital rights activists, but some argue the implications of the case are unclear. The ruling emphasizes the need for Congress to modify the 1986 Store Communications Act to balance privacy, crime-fighting, and national security.

site_title: Europe: BT warning, poor earnings weigh on shares; Generali rallies
summary: Europe's earnings season started on a rocky note with profit warnings from BT Group and Aryzta, sending their shares sharply lower. BT lost a fifth of its market value due to an Italian accounting scandal, while Aryzta issued a profit warning. Despite this, the STOXX 600 index still gained 0.2% due to Italian financials and mining stocks. Generali rallied 8.2% after rumors of a potential bid from Intesa Sanpaolo.

site_title: Oil-dependent US states sliding into recession: S&P
summary: US oil-dependent states are sliding into recession due to crashing oil prices, according to a report by Standard & Poor's. Eight states, including North Dakota, Alaska, and West Virginia, are among the 10 weakest economies. Even if oil prices recover, state economies are unlikely to experience significant growth, with prices capped at around $60 a barrel. The decline in oil prices has led to reduced revenues and investments in infrastructure, causing budget gaps in some states, including Alaska's $900 million shortfall.

site_title: Trump to address joint session of US Congress on Feb 28
summary: US President Donald Trump will address a joint session of Congress on February 28, 2017, in response to an invitation from House Speaker Paul Ryan. This marks the first time a Republican president will address a joint session since 1955. Trump's speech will outline his agenda to tackle domestic and foreign challenges, including a potential repeal and replacement of the Affordable Care Act. The address is seen as an opportunity for Trump to repair relations with Congress and the nation, following his inauguration speech criticizing the Washington establishment.

site_title: Detained Terrex vehicles coming home
summary: Singapore's Ministry of Foreign Affairs announced that nine detained Terrex infantry carriers will be returned to the country after Hong Kong authorities completed their investigation. The vehicles had been detained since January 2017. The development follows a letter from Hong Kong Chief Executive Leung Chun-ying to Singapore's Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong informing him of the completion of the investigation. The return of the vehicles marks a positive outcome for Singapore.

site_title: Luxembourg to set bar high for UK firms seeking relocation
summary: Luxembourg's financial watchdog, the CSSF, has stated that UK firms seeking relocation ahead of the UK's exit from the EU must establish a substantial presence, including key decision-makers and functions, to maintain EU "passporting rights." Companies attempting a nominal presence will be rejected, and the CSSF will assess each application on a case-by-case basis, requiring relocation of staff, decision-makers, and key functions, as well as compliance with minimum capital requirements.

site_title: Head of world's biggest metals bourse quits
summary: Garry Jones, 58, stepped down as CEO of the London Metal Exchange after a 3-year tenure, aiming to modernize the 139-year-old exchange. He will serve as an adviser until the end of the year. Matthew Chamberlain, 34, will become interim CEO. The decision follows Jones' failure to attract high-frequency traders, a key goal during his tenure.

site_title: Meryl Streep breaks own record with 20th Oscar nomination
summary: Meryl Streep has been nominated for her 20th Academy Award, breaking her own record as the most nominated performer in Oscars history. At 67, she was recognized for her role in the comedy biopic "Florence Foster Jenkins." Streep surpasses Katharine Hepburn and Jack Nicholson, who are tied for second with 12 nominations each. This nomination solidifies her reign as the "queen of Hollywood."

site_title: Trump trademarks 2020 campaign slogan: 'Keep America Great'
summary: President Donald Trump has submitted an application to trademark his 2020 campaign slogan "Keep America Great" with and without an exclamation point, ahead of his swearing-in ceremony. The application, filed before Trump's inauguration, reflects his confidence in achieving his promise to "Make America Great Again." The trademark application is a step towards solidifying the slogan as a brand identity for Trump's future re-election efforts.

site_title: Hardline paper urges Beijing to fortify nuclear arsenal
summary: A Chinese newspaper, the Global Times, has urged Beijing to strengthen its nuclear arsenal to "force the US to respect it" following President Donald Trump's tough stance on trade and national security. The paper cited a leaked photo of a nuclear road-mobile missile system, the Dongfeng-41, with a payload of 10-12 warheads and a range of 14,000 km. This comes after US President Trump warned China that the US would "defend" American and international interests in the disputed South China Sea, and his nominee for secretary of state, Rex Tillerson, suggested blocking China's access to the islands.

site_title: S'pore turns to other regional trade deals as TPP crumbles
summary: Singapore is shifting focus to other regional trade deals after the collapse of the Trans-Pacific Partnership (TPP) due to US withdrawal. The Ministry of Trade and Industry (MTI) stated that the pact cannot take effect without US participation. Observers warn of long-term effects on Singapore's growth and financial stability as the US retreats from global trade. Singapore is urging other member states to shore up their internationalisation efforts, but risks remain for the city-state's growth and stability.

site_title: Goldman analyst urges Beijing to tighten monetary policy
summary: China's top-ranked economist, Song Yu, urges Beijing to tighten monetary policy amid signs of overheating, driven by quickening inflation and a real interest rate that has turned negative for the first time since 2011. With the economy showing steady growth but inflation rising, policymakers are in a bind between reining in price gains and stabilizing growth. Song calls for further market liberalization and reforms to boost potential growth, warning that China's reliance on administrative measures could hinder long-term stability.

site_title: The year of the pivot
summary: The global economy is experiencing a "pivot" from muddle-through to reflation, driven by rising business confidence and growth expectations in the US and other major economies. This is attributed to Donald Trump's election, which has revived "animal spirits" in the world's largest economy. Global economic growth is expected to accelerate modestly in 2017, with Asia ex-Japan leading the way. Inflation remains relatively benign, with two or three fed rate hikes expected between now and the end of 2017. A balanced allocation between bonds and equities, combined with an allocation to global macro strategies and gold, is expected to perform reasonably well.

site_title: Sprint to buy 33% stake in Jay Z's Tidal streaming platform
summary: Sprint Corp has agreed to buy a 33% stake in Jay Z's Tidal streaming platform, breathing new life into the service. The deal will allow Sprint to roll out Tidal content exclusives for its customers. Tidal, which has struggled to gain market dominance despite its star power, aims to expand its offerings and attract more subscribers. The partnership is expected to benefit Sprint's customers and enhance the streaming platform's appeal. The terms of the deal were not disclosed, but it is seen as a strategic move to boost Sprint's streaming services.

site_title: Citigroup to pay US$28.8m for misleading borrowers
summary: Citigroup has agreed to pay US$28.8 million to settle allegations by US regulators that two of its mortgage-servicing units misled borrowers about options to avoid foreclosure and payment deadlines. The Consumer Financial Protection Bureau accused the bank of failing to inform consumers of these options and misleading them about the impact of postponing payment deadlines on their ability to pay down debt. The settlement resolves accusations made by the CFPB in January 2017.

site_title: US$ wallows near 7-week lows as Trump trade fades
summary: The US dollar fell near 7-week lows on January 24, 2017, as investors lost confidence in President Donald Trump's economic policies. The dollar had surged 6% since Trump's election victory, but his lack of detail on stimulus and tax cuts fueled concerns about protectionism. The euro rebounded above US$1.07, while the dollar declined 3.5% against a basket of major currencies in the past three weeks. Experts warn that the "Trumpflation trade" is fading, and the dollar could lose another few percent if Trump's rhetoric continues to be protectionist.

site_title: Frasers Hospitality adds ninth property in Jakarta
summary: Frasers Hospitality Group has added its ninth property in Jakarta with the opening of Frasers Suites Kuningan, a 210-unit serviced residence in the city's Golden Triangle. The group aims to expand its presence in at least five other Indonesian cities, including Bali, Bandung, Medan, Surabaya, and Yogyakarta. This move follows steady occupancy rates of over 75% at its existing Jakarta properties, and the group plans to double its inventory in South-east Asia by 2019.

site_title: AirAsiaX gets FAA nod to fly to the US
summary: AirAsiaX, the long-haul unit of AirAsia, has received clearance from the FAA to fly to any US destination, including Hawaii, marking the first time an Asian budget airline has secured approval for scheduled passenger flights to the US. This milestone is a significant expansion for AirAsiaX, which has previously focused on Asia, Australasia, and the Middle East. The airline's CEO, Kamarudin Meranun, expressed excitement about entering the new market, citing the opportunity to explore new destinations beyond the Asia-Pacific region.

site_title: Eurozone starts year with solid economic growth: Poll
summary: The eurozone experienced solid economic growth in the first quarter of 2017, with a Eurozone Flash Composite Purchasing Managers' Index of 54.3, above the 50-point growth line. This suggests 0.4% first-quarter economic growth. The manufacturing industry saw its fastest expansion since April 2011, while services industry prices remained strong. European Central Bank policymakers are optimistic about inflation, which rose 1.1% in December, and the bank's quantitative easing efforts are expected to stimulate price rises. This positive outlook is a welcome development for policymakers.

site_title: US-China relations off to turbulent start
summary: US President Donald Trump has launched a trade war with China, threatening to impose 45% tariffs on Chinese goods and labeling China a currency manipulator. Beijing has responded with a strong stance, defending its sovereignty and saying a trade war will result in no winners. Analysts predict a full-blown trade war could cost China over 1% of GDP growth, with both countries suffering significant economic impacts. The US has also announced its withdrawal from the Trans Pacific Partnership, further escalating tensions.

site_title: Pakistan taking expensive gamble with China investment deal
summary: Pakistan's China-backed $54 billion economic corridor, CPEC, has sparked concerns over uneven distribution of benefits, misgivings over financing terms, and the risk of heavy borrowings. Balochistan, where the "crown jewel" Gwadar port is located, faces significant hurdles, including a water supply crisis. Pakistani economists voice concerns over the terms of financing from China, which may favor Chinese interests. The project's long-term consequences for Pakistan's economy remain uncertain, with some warning of a repeat of Sri Lanka's experience with unpayable Chinese loans.

site_title: Corporate digest (Amended)
summary: Roxy-Pacific Holdings has agreed to purchase five adjoining shophouses in Bukit Panjang, Singapore, for S$17 million. The properties, on a freehold residential site, have an estimated total land area of 10,256 sq ft and an existing plot ratio of 2.5. The acquisition will be paid for with internal funds and bank borrowings, and is done via its subsidiary RH Capital.

site_title: Morgan Stanley tells ETF issuers to pay up or risk being blocked
summary: Morgan Stanley has instructed some ETF issuers to pay a fee for transaction data or risk having future offerings blocked from its sales network. The plan aims to bolster brokerage revenue. The firm initially faced resistance from large fund providers, including BlackRock, and lowered fees in response.

site_title: Merkel defends refugee stance by attacking 'polarisation and populism'
summary: German Chancellor Angela Merkel defended her refugee policy, calling it a moral and legal obligation to offer asylum to those fleeing war and oppression. She criticized "polarisation and populism" in Europe, urging Europeans to stand by principles of offering protection to refugees. Merkel's comments came after being targeted by right-wing European leaders two days prior.

site_title: Trump's withdrawal from TPP creates vacuum that China is keen to fill
summary: US President Donald Trump's withdrawal from the Trans-Pacific Partnership (TPP) creates a vacuum that China is eager to fill, potentially damaging American prestige in Asia. China's leaders, led by President Xi Jinping, see the US pullout as an opportunity to promote globalisation and free trade, and China may use the TPP's failure to advocate for an alternative pact. The US withdrawal is expected to give China more leeway to position itself as an economic and military anchor in the Western Pacific, while the TPP's failure may also lead to China taking a leadership role in regional economic deals.

images.alt_text: US President Donald Trump's withdrawal from a long-planned Pacific trade pact creates a political and economic vacuum that China is eager to fill, potentially damaging American prestige in Asia.

site_title: These luxury home mainstays may be gone in 20 years
summary: Luxury real estate specialists predict four staple amenities may become obsolete in 20 years. These include doormen who know residents' favorite drivers, private cinemas, personal assistants, and smart home automation systems. As technology advances, these services may be replaced by AI-powered systems, making them less desirable and potentially redundant.
