Experts believe that what is considered a must-have today could become a fad in the future, with these amenities potentially disappearing from luxury homes in the next two decades.

site_title: Lloyds hit by cyber attack amid jitters in industry over hacking
summary: Lloyds Banking Group Plc was hit by a cyber attack, causing disruptions to online services for customers two weeks ago. The attack, a denial-of-service attack, aimed to cripple the online system by flooding it with traffic. Lloyds used geo-blocking and scrubbing techniques to defend its systems. This incident is among several recent outages at major banks, prompting lawmakers to call for increased spending on technology and closer supervision of computer systems. The Bank of England has identified cybercrime as a serious threat to the banking system.

site_title: The imperatives of corporate governance: A letter to CEOs
summary: BlackRock CEO Larry Fink wrote to CEOs of leading companies, urging them to adapt their strategies to the changing global environment. The past year's events, including Brexit, the Middle East upheaval, and US reflation, have upended assumptions on long-term value creation. Fink emphasizes the need for companies to understand these changes and balance short-termism with long-term growth. He advocates for government policy to support long-term investments, such as tax reform and infrastructure investment. BlackRock will engage with companies on their strategic frameworks, prioritizing board accountability for long-term value creation and employee well-being.

site_title: URA sets new design guidelines for public spaces
summary: The Urban Redevelopment Authority (URA) has introduced new design guidelines for public spaces in Singapore, requiring developers to provide minimum standards for building public areas, including accessibility and shade. The guidelines will apply to owners and developers of certain private developments and take effect from April 24, 2017. The aim is to incentivize developers to create high-quality public spaces, promoting community engagement and social activities. The guidelines also include recommendations for public seating and the need for developers to adopt them from project inception to management and use of the space.

site_title: SGX's brighter outlook tempered by competition
summary: SGX posted a 5.5% net profit increase to S$88.3 million for its second fiscal quarter, marking the exchange's best year-on-year gain in five quarters. The company expects the primary market to continue improving, with new listings expected to increase proceeds and deals. However, the competitive landscape remains a challenge, with SGX facing competition from other major exchanges, including Chicago and Hong Kong. Despite this, SGX's sector-focused strategy and efforts to diversify its business have helped attract new listings and improve market sentiment.

site_title: Pokemon Go unleashed on game-mad South Korea six months late
summary: Nintendo's popular game Pokémon Go was released in South Korea six months after its global launch, due to security concerns over Google Maps. The game, which relies on Google Maps, was launched after Niantic and Pokémon Korea worked around the limited Google Maps functions in the country. Despite initial hype, the game's popularity was not noticeable in Seoul due to freezing temperatures. The game was eventually available for download after a brief hitch, and South Korea remains the world's fourth-largest gaming market.

site_title: STI extends its 2017 gain to 2.1%
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) rose 16.47 points to 3,041.95, extending its 2017 gain to 2.1% despite a slide on Wall Street and slight weakness in Dow futures. Banks, led by DBS's 1.7% jump, drove the index's performance. Gains in Singtel, Wilmar International, and Hongkong Land also contributed to the index's firm finish.

site_title: Viz Branz seeking S$700m valuation in relisting: sources
summary: Viz Branz Pte, a Singapore-based coffee and cereal beverage maker, is seeking to relist on the Singapore Exchange with a valuation of at least S$700 million. The company aims to fund expansion with the proceeds from the stock offering, which would more than double its previous valuation of S$289 million. Viz Branz has expanded in China and Myanmar and boosted profit margins, and has distribution networks in several countries. The planned listing comes as Singapore's first-time share sales climbed four-fold last year to US$1.7 billion.

site_title: World Bank tips metal prices to shine, but precious metals to decline
summary: The World Bank forecasts metal prices to rise 11% in 2017 due to supply constraints, while oil prices are expected to rise to $55 per barrel. Precious metal prices, however, are projected to decline 7% as benchmark interest rates rise. Agricultural commodities prices are anticipated to rise slightly, with small increases in oils and raw materials. The forecast assumes compliance with Opec's production agreement, which could alter the path of commodity prices.

site_title: Three-month swap offer rate continues to tumble
summary: The three-month Singapore Interbank Offered Rate (SIBOR) has fallen to 0.737% due to the weakening US dollar, bringing relief to borrowers with loans pegged to it. The rate has tumbled 30 points from its one-month high of 1.04% on Dec 29. Analysts attribute the decline to the wavering US dollar strength, which is also causing the Singapore dollar to rally. The US dollar index has fallen to 100, and whether it holds above this level will determine if Singapore interest rates fall further.

site_title: DBS investors' dreams of Trump may face rude awakening
summary: DBS Group Holdings Ltd, Singapore's largest bank, has seen a 20% increase in value since the US election, despite neither the dollar nor US bond market being overly impressed. The bank's rally is unusual given Singapore's interest rates don't suggest a resurgence in pricing power. The Singapore dollar swap offer rate, which jumped after the election, is now heading lower. DBS's performance is attributed to the "Trump reflation trade," but the bank's own interest rates and market trends suggest a more cautious outlook.

site_title: China's efforts to stem capital outflows start to pay off
summary: China has seen its first net inflow of capital under the capital account since August 2015, with Chinese banks registering a $13.5 billion influx in December. This marks a turning point in efforts to stem capital outflows, which have been a major concern for the government since the yuan's devaluation in 2015. Tighter restrictions on companies' outbound investments and extra hurdles on transferring money overseas appear to be working, with foreign investment in Chinese securities reaching an 18-month high of $11.7 billion.

site_title: Nike, Ford caught in Trump's trade overhaul
summary: US President Donald Trump's trade overhaul has sent shockwaves through the global business community, with companies like Nike and Ford forced to rethink their supply chains and capital investments. Trump's decision not to join the Trans-Pacific Partnership and to renegotiate the North American Free Trade Agreement (Nafta) will likely lead to increased tariffs and costs for importers. Analysts predict that companies will reassess their strategies and consider alternative destinations for manufacturing, potentially leading to job losses and economic uncertainty.

site_title: Fire-prone Riau declares early emergency to combat haze
summary: Riau province in Indonesia declared a state of emergency to combat haze due to fire-prone conditions, following President Joko Widodo's call to prevent a repeat of 2015's severe smog. The 96-day emergency aims to take preventive steps, including aerial operations, air patrols, and community involvement, amid expected drier weather in 2017. The move comes after 2015's fires caused an estimated $23.4 billion in economic losses and strained ties with neighboring countries.

site_title: Supreme Court ruling on Brexit casts uncertainty over government negotiations
summary: The UK Supreme Court ruled that the government needs an Act of Parliament to trigger Article 50 and formally initiate Brexit, casting uncertainty over the government's negotiations. The court's decision, which upholds UK parliamentary sovereignty, forces Prime Minister Theresa May to introduce emergency legislation in Parliament to authorise the UK's departure from the EU by the end of March. The ruling sets clear limits on the government's executive powers and may impede the government's negotiating strategy, with opposition parties seeking amendments to the government's bill.

site_title: Surbana Jurong: Dismissal of 54 staff could have been better managed
summary: Surbana Jurong, a Singapore-based infrastructure consultancy, has admitted that the termination of 54 staff due to "poor performance" could have been better managed. The company is in "ongoing discussions" with unions to provide reasonable ex-gratia payments for the affected workers. Surbana Jurong's management acknowledged that the process could have been handled more sensitively and has committed to strengthening labor management relations with unions. The Ministry of Manpower has praised the company's commitment to resolving the matter amicably, but has emphasized the importance of fair, sensitive, and responsible treatment of employees.

images.alt_text: It was reported last week that Surbana Jurong group chief executive officer Wong Heang Fine had informed his employees via email that the company could not allow a small number of poor performers to affect the rest of the staff.

site_title: Samsung Galaxy Note 7 fiasco signals bigger problems at Korea Inc
summary: Samsung's Galaxy Note 7 debacle highlights the company's and South Korea's top-down culture, stifling innovation and burying problems. The incident occurred due to a combination of factors, including aggressive decisions in designing batteries and internal pressures to outdo rivals. Samsung's rigid management system and lack of accountability led to the company's failure to test and confirm battery problems before releasing the product. The incident raises concerns about the country's economy, with experts suggesting that a shake-up is long overdue to address the issues.

images.alt_text: Mr Koh says Samsung now feels a painful responsibility for failing to test and confirm that there were problems in the design and manufacturing of batteries before the Galaxy Note 7 was released.

site_title: S'pore business confidence up slightly in Q4 but still weak: survey
summary: Business confidence in Singapore rose slightly in Q4 2016 but remains weak, according to a joint survey by ACCA and IMA. Key concerns include declining income, shrinking order books, and staff cuts. The survey cited a slowdown in Singapore's labor force growth and a weak outlook for global demand for goods as major factors. Despite this, Reuter Chua, country head of ACCA Singapore, noted a potential global economic turnaround in 2017, driven by China's rebound and the US's partial recovery.

site_title: Business travellers being squeezed by 'basic economy' airlines
summary: Business travelers are facing increased costs and restrictions due to the rise of "basic economy" fares offered by airlines. These fares, which are designed to be cheaper, often come with added restrictions such as limited seat selection, checked bag fees, and no upgrades. Companies are trying to save money by opting for the cheapest options, but this is leaving business travelers, like Bevan Lindsey, with higher out-of-pocket expenses. Industry experts say that airlines are deliberately making these fares unattractive to business travelers in order to push them into paying for more expensive options.

site_title: Australia, New Zealand and Japan scramble to rescue TPP following US exit
summary: Australia, New Zealand, and Japan are scrambling to rescue the Trans-Pacific Partnership (TPP) after the US withdrawal, with Australia and New Zealand joining Japan in rescue initiatives. The US President's exit has raised concerns about the pact's future, with some analysts suggesting that China could fill the vacuum left by the US. However, Japan's Prime Minister Shinzo Abe is struggling to find common ground with other member nations on restructuring the pact, and analysts doubt his ability to keep the US engaged. The TPP's potential inclusion of China could revolutionize the regional trade regime, but modifying its provisions would require significant changes.

site_title: Even if just a transitional figure, Trump promises havoc
summary: US President Donald Trump's inaugural address marked a significant shift in American foreign policy, as he turned inward and expressed dissatisfaction with global leadership. He criticized the US's foreign entanglements, citing their impact on industry, military, and infrastructure. Trump also failed to mention the role of American business in globalization and the wealthy elite's avoidance of taxes. His pronouncements on alliances, particularly with NATO and Japan, were concerning, and his comments on China and Taiwan raise questions about the future of the US-China relationship. Trump's words suggest a world where the US is a victim, and his actions may lead to a period of isolation and "havoc."

site_title: SAP lifts multi-year outlook after posting in-line 2016 results
summary: SAP posted in-line 2016 results, with Q4 operating profit rising 4% to 2.37 billion euros. The company raised its 2017 sales and profit guidance, signaling higher revenue ambitions four years out. SAP's new cloud bookings jumped 40% and backlog for unbilled cloud services rose 47%. The company expects 2017 revenue of 23.2-23.6 billion euros, a modest rise, and operating profit of 6.8-7 billion euros. SAP also raised its 2020 total revenue outlook to 28-29 billion euros, up from 26-28 billion previously.

images.alt_text: SAP, Europe's most valuable technology firm, on Tuesday posted 2016 results on the lower side of analysts' expectations, while edging up its 2017 sales and profit guidance and signalling slightly higher revenue ambitions four years out.

site_title: Modi's rupee ban takes toll on businesses for third month
summary: Prime Minister Narendra Modi's November 2016 rupee ban has taken a toll on businesses for the third consecutive month. Many male breadwinners in rural villages have lost jobs due to reduced demand for motorcycles and scooters, leading to a decrease in income. This has resulted in families struggling to afford basic necessities like milk and vegetables. The ban has also affected marriages, with some couples having their weddings delayed or canceled due to financial constraints. The situation highlights the far-reaching impact of the rupee ban on the Indian economy and its people.

images.alt_text: Feeling the squeeze: As more businesses cut staff to grapple with reduced demand for goods and services, desperation is emerging all over India's biggest cities. The most economically damaging effect of PM Modi's demonetisation process is that India's poor are the hardest hit.

site_title: The birth and death of TPP
summary: The Trans-Pacific Partnership (TPP) has effectively ended with US President Donald Trump withdrawing from the agreement in 2017. This move paved the way for the Regional Comprehensive Economic Partnership (RCEP) to be formed, a massive free trade deal among 15 countries including Singapore. The TPP's demise has led to increased focus on the RCEP and its potential impact on the global economy, particularly in Singapore.

site_title: BOJ wary of 10-year bond yield target hike even if CPI reaches 1%
summary: Bank of Japan officials are hesitant to raise the 10-year bond yield target from zero percent, even if the Consumer Price Index reaches 1% this year, citing concerns about moving too quickly and avoiding previous policy exits that prolonged deflation. The BOJ will consider changes to its policy and inflation forecasts during its upcoming meeting on January 30-31. Governor Haruhiko Kuroda expects GDP growth of 1.5% and inflation of 1.5% for the fiscal year starting in April, but officials want to confirm the underlying inflation trend before making a decision.

site_title: IHC files police report against ousted executive director
summary: International Healthway Corporation (IHC) filed a police report against ousted executive director Lim Beng Choo, who was removed from her position following an extraordinary general meeting. The meeting saw the removal of the entire board of directors, including chairman Gerald Lim, Alviedo Rodolfo Jr San Miguel, and Leonard Chia. Lim Beng Choo was seen leaving the premises with her computer and documents at 8:20 pm on the day of the EGM. The Interim Transition Committee will review the company's affairs, and an internal audit by Data Management Corporation has been appointed to protect IHC's records and financial information.

site_title: Yahoo delays US$4.8b sale of core business to Verizon
summary: Yahoo has delayed its $4.8 billion sale to Verizon by several months due to "work required to meet closing conditions." The deal, originally set for this quarter, will now close in the next quarter. The delay comes amid disclosures of two huge data breaches, which have raised concerns among investors that Verizon may reconsider the deal or seek a lower price. Yahoo's earnings report showed a swing to profit, but the cyber attacks have raised concerns about the company's ability to keep up with its competitors.

site_title: Trips abroad replace Chinese New Year treks to grandma's
summary: Chinese travelers are increasingly opting for trips abroad over traditional domestic celebrations during the Chinese New Year holiday. With rising incomes and international flights, over 414 million Chinese are expected to travel during the week-long celebration, with 58.3 million flying and 174 destinations visited. This shift is driven by economic growth, disposable income increases, and the government's one-child policy restricting family sizes. Airlines are capitalizing on the trend, adding flights and services to meet demand, with China becoming the world's biggest source of overseas travelers.

site_title: Etihad CEO, CFO to quit as carrier struggles with investments
summary: Etihad Airways CEO James Hogan and CFO James Rigney will leave the airline in the second half of 2017 amid mounting losses from investments in Air Berlin and Alitalia. Hogan will stand down as group CEO and Rigney will quit to join him at an investment company. The airline is reviewing its operations and equity alliance, which has taken stakes in smaller airlines across Europe and Asia. Etihad is seeking a new CEO and CFO to oversee its operations and address the financial challenges facing the airline.

site_title: US protectionism might help emerging markets
summary: US President Donald Trump's protectionist moves may inadvertently benefit emerging markets by forcing them to implement structural reforms, such as reducing corruption and strengthening judicial systems, to boost domestic demand and productivity. This could lead to increased economic resilience and competitiveness for countries like China. While a trade war could initially hit investor appetite, Trump's planned fiscal stimulus and import curbs could spur inflation and interest rate increases, potentially benefiting emerging markets in the long run.

site_title: China raises medium-term lending rates in tightening signal
summary: China's central bank raised interest rates on medium-term loans to 3.1% and 2.95% to manage liquidity and curb leverage in the financial system. The move signals the PBOC's intent to avoid excess credit that fuels asset bubbles while keeping enough funding in the system. This is part of a broader effort by policymakers to strike a balance between controlling financial risk and maintaining funding supplies.

site_title: EU-Canada trade deal clears key hurdle as lawmakers defy sentiment
summary: EU lawmakers voted 25-15 in favor of the CETA free trade deal with Canada, defying rising anti-globalization sentiment. The deal, which enshrines high standards for international trade, now heads to a full session of the European Parliament on February 15. Boosters describe it as a new era of rules-based trade, while opponents claim it will lower health and environmental standards. The deal must also receive approval from the EU's 30-plus national and regional parliaments to take full effect.

site_title: Trump's first steps bode poorly for US leadership, competitiveness
summary: US President Donald Trump's first steps in office are raising concerns about the country's leadership and competitiveness. His administration has shown a disregard for truth, appointing a climate-change denier to head the EPA and removing climate change references from White House communications. Trump's foreign policy is also being questioned, with escalations in rhetoric on Taiwan and the South China Sea, and the abandonment of the Trans-Pacific Partnership trade agreement. Domestic policy is also at risk, with plans to dismantle the Affordable Care Act and Dodd-Frank Act, potentially exacerbating inequality and economic issues.

site_title: Scandal, gaffes mar ex-UN chief's return to Korea
summary: Former UN chief Ban Ki-moon's return to South Korea has been marred by a family corruption scandal and public gaffes, including a series of perceived PR mistakes. His brother, Ban Ki-sang, is facing bribery charges, and a Realmeter poll shows Ban Ki-moon's support slipping to 19.8% from 22.2% last week. Despite his efforts to distance himself from the scandal, Ban Ki-moon's campaign is struggling, and analysts say it's too early to count him out.

site_title: Condé Nast braces for consolidations this week ahead of annual meetings
summary: Condé Nast is set to undergo a major business consolidation this week, ahead of its annual meetings. The company is expected to reduce publishers, promote key executives, and restructure its digital business. The consolidation is led by chief business officer Jim Norton, who is tasked with slashing costs and evolving the company's digital business. The changes are seen as a response to declining print revenues, but there are also rumors of a potential sale by the Newhouse family, Condé Nast's owners, with Hearst being a possible suitor.

site_title: Japan launches first military communications satellite
summary: Japan has successfully launched its first military communications satellite to boost broadband capacity for its Self Defence Forces, bolstering its presence in the East China Sea amid growing Chinese military activity. The satellite, one of three planned X-band satellites, quadruples broadband capacity and unifies a fractured communications network. The move is part of Japan's efforts to counter Chinese influence in the region, following a surge in Chinese military activity near Japanese airspace, including the recent passage of China's aircraft carrier through the Pacific.

site_title: CIMB in talks to sell stake in brokerage business for US$200m: sources
summary: CIMB Group Holdings Bhd, Malaysia's second-largest lender, is in talks to sell a stake in its brokerage business to China Galaxy Securities Co for approximately US$200 million. The deal aims to cut costs, exit low-return businesses, and boost profitability. CIMB has already closed its Australian office and shed jobs in several countries last year. The planned stake sale is part of the bank's strategy to expand in selected areas and reach a deal by the end of March, pending final agreements.

site_title: Whirlpool to cut 500 EMEA jobs in dryer manufacturing unit
summary: Whirlpool Corp plans to restructure its EMEA dryer manufacturing operations, cutting about 500 jobs in the region. Production at its Amiens, France facility will cease in 2018, while its Yate, UK facility will focus on UK consumers. The company expects $88 million in restructuring costs and previously estimated $200 million in charges for 2016. The move aims to optimize operations and improve efficiency.

site_title: Emirates stokes ire of US airlines with flights through Greece
summary: Emirates has announced a new daily route linking Dubai and the New York area via Athens, sparking a dispute with US airlines over unfair subsidies. The route, set to launch on March 12, is Emirates' second to arrive in the US after touching down in Europe. US airlines, including Delta, American, and United, have urged the Trump administration to enforce Open Skies agreements and protect American jobs, citing billions of dollars in unfair state support for Emirates and other Gulf carriers. The move is seen as a challenge to US rivals, with the US home to the largest overseas Greek community.

site_title: World's largest private bank expects euro rally by mid-2017
summary: UBS Wealth Management predicts a 7% euro rally to US$1.15 in six months, citing undervaluation and faster inflation in the euro area. This contrasts with most forecasters, who expect a decline to US$1.03-$1.04. The euro has gained 2% this year, and UBS believes the European Central Bank's policy stance will shift towards a less dovish tone in the coming months, supporting the currency. The bank's global chief investment officer, Mark Haefele, also notes that the US dollar's movement may be limited by the Federal Reserve's interest rate decisions.

site_title: Keppel Reit's performance affected by difficult office market environment
summary: Keppel Reit reported a distributable income of S$48.7 million for Q4 2016, down from S$54 million in Q4 2015, due to the challenging Singapore office market. The trust's DPU fell to 1.48 cents, compared to 1.68 cents in Q4 2015. The Reit's full-year DPU was 6.37 cents, down from 6.80 cents in FY2015. The decline was attributed to the absence of contribution from a divested property and lower contribution from its Singapore property.

site_title: Xiaomi loses global ambassador as Google veteran exits
summary: Xiaomi is losing its global ambassador, Hugo Barra, a Google veteran who headed the company's global division. Barra plans to resign and return to Silicon Valley. He has been the global face of Xiaomi, a Chinese smartphone startup that gained international recognition for its innovative technology. Barra's departure marks a significant change for the company, which has been a symbol of China's growing tech prowess. The reasons behind Barra's resignation are not specified, but his return to Google suggests a possible return to his roots.

site_title: Pacific Radiance backs rights issue by Indonesian associate
summary: Pacific Radiance, a Singapore-listed offshore support vessel owner-operator, has backed an upcoming rights issue by its Jakarta-listed associate, Logindo Samudramakmur, to raise up to $10 million. The rights issue, which includes up to 1.63 billion new shares, aims to inject fresh equity into the struggling Indonesian company. Pacific Radiance's support for the rights issue demonstrates its commitment to its investment in Indonesia's oil and gas sector, despite the company's own cash flow challenges. The move is seen as a positive sign for Logindo's equity raising exercise.

site_title: Misuse of industrial space ever more widespread
summary: The misuse of industrial space has become widespread in Singapore, with unauthorized trades moving into industrial buildings. Businesses such as law firms, real estate agencies, and training providers are occupying units in industrial premises, often with office-like designs and proximity to transport nodes. This trend has raised concerns about enforcing planning rules, with views split on whether to take action. The misuse of industrial space is a growing issue in the city-state, with potential implications for its urban planning and development.

images.alt_text: The misuse of industrial space has become rampant, and with tenants having settled into units in new strata projects offering office-like designs and proximity to transport nodes, the trend has become even more conspicuous.

site_title: Ascott Reit Q4 DPU dips
summary: Ascott Reit, a Singapore-listed real estate investment trust, reported a 7% drop in its distribution per unit (DPU) to 1.93 cents for the fourth quarter ending Dec 31, 2016. Despite this, its balance sheet remains strong, with revenue, profit, and distributable income all increasing. The Reit's portfolio value dipped 1.1% to S$4.5 billion, mainly due to lower valuations in Britain and the US. Despite this, its balance sheet remains robust, with gearing at 39.8%. Analysts keep "buy" calls on the Reit, citing its strong performance and robust balance sheet.

images.alt_text: Ascott Reit's strong performance has been attributed to its acquisitions which include the Sheraton Tribeca New York Hotel.

site_title: 2017 - Another promising year for the semiconductor industry
summary: The semiconductor industry is expected to continue its positive momentum in 2017, driven by the increasing demand for intelligent and connected devices. Key trends include car digitization and electrification, expanding Internet of Things (IoT) devices, and the adoption of smart factories. Advances in microcontrollers, sensors, and connectivity products will improve advanced driver assistance systems, vehicle-to-vehicle and vehicle-to-infrastructure communications, and smart city management systems. These innovations will lead to significant growth in the semiconductor industry, driven by the need for efficient power and resource consumption.

site_title: MIT clocks 0.4% rise in Q3 DPU
summary: MIT Industrial Trust posted a 0.4% rise in distribution per unit (DPU) to 2.83 Singapore cents for Q3 2016, driven by higher rental rates and revenue from Hewlett-Packard's BTS development. Gross revenue grew 1.4% to S$84.45 million, while net property income rose 2.5% to S$63.43 million. The Reit's portfolio occupancy dipped to 92.1% due to lower occupancies in high-tech buildings and business park buildings.

site_title: Beijing, Washington drawing red lines over South China Sea
summary: The US and China have drawn red lines over the disputed South China Sea, with the US vowing to defend "international territories" and China asserting its "irrefutable" sovereignty over islands in the region. The White House signaled a shift in US policy, with White House spokesman Sean Spicer stating that the US will protect its interests in the South China Sea. China's Foreign Ministry spokeswoman Hua Chunying urged the US to respect facts and avoid harming the region's stability. The US's actions could risk an armed confrontation with China, an increasingly formidable nuclear-armed military power.

images.alt_text: China's Liaoning aircraft carrier and other vessels during a drill in the South China Sea. Mr Trump's aides have said that he plans a major naval build-up in East Asia to counter China's rise.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary:
Here is a 100-word or less summary of the article content:

Singapore Reits are showing promising signs. Keppel DC Reit is expected to deliver a 5% compound annual growth rate in distributions, with a "buy" target price of S$1.30. Bumitama Agri has posted its first quarterly yield recovery, lifting earnings estimates, with a "buy" target price of S$0.97. Frasers Logistics and Industrial Trust has a "buy" target price of S$1.06, with a focus on inorganic growth drivers. Analysts are optimistic about the Reits' financial capacity to acquire accretive assets and their growth potential. However, investors question the forward growth outlook for FLT.

site_title: Instagram becomes art marketing tool
summary: Instagram has become a significant tool for the art market, particularly among younger buyers. Galleries, auctioneers, and dealers are using the platform to showcase available pieces, with many collectors reaching out to purchase art after seeing it on Instagram. This shift is attributed to the platform's influence on transactions, with Matt Carey-Williams from Phillips auction house stating that Instagram often sparks conversations about specific art pieces. As a result, Instagram has become a crucial marketing channel for the art market, bridging the gap between buyers and sellers.

site_title: US cities riding high on millennial boom, but for how long?
summary: US cities are experiencing a millennial boom, but it's expected to peak and potentially reverse as the generation ages. Cities like Philadelphia, San Francisco, and New York are seeing a slowdown in apartment rent growth, with some areas experiencing declines. Demographers predict that the growth in demand for urban living will stall as the number of young professionals peaks and the outflow of mid-30s couples to the suburbs resumes. The future of urban areas will depend on whether millennials choose to stay or move to the suburbs, affecting city budgets, gentrification, and the US landscape.

site_title: Samsung Elec forecasts higher earnings in 2017 but warns of political risks
summary: Samsung Electronics forecasts higher earnings in 2017, despite challenges from political uncertainty, with a 50% surge in Q4 profit. The company attributes its growth to the booming chip market, which is expected to drive growth and give the mobile business breathing space. However, analysts warn of uncertainty over the performance of new premium smartphones and the fallout from a graft scandal involving Samsung Group scion Jay Y Lee. The company plans to buy back 9.3 trillion won worth of shares and return 50% of its free cash flow to investors.

site_title: China tops list of 'grey swan' global risks: State Street report
summary: China's economic growth and control of its currency and financial markets are at risk, according to a State Street Global Advisors report. China's willingness to play by global rules could quickly unravel if it stops defending the yuan, allowing it to depreciate faster. The report also warns of election surprises in Europe, which could push the European Union closer to a break-up, and emerging markets being squeezed by the stronger US dollar and higher US interest rates.

site_title: Seafarer kidnappings on the rise
summary: Piracy incidents on the world's seas decreased in 2016, with 191 reported incidents, a significant drop from 2015. However, kidnappings increased, with 62 people taken hostage in 15 separate incidents, mostly in West Africa and the Sulu Sea. The International Maritime Bureau (IMB) advises charterers to avoid the Sulu Sea and urges governments to investigate and punish kidnappers. Despite the decline in piracy, the IMB warns that certain shipping routes remain dangerous and crew kidnappings are a growing concern.

site_title: Gulf Arab states expect 'a strong' President Trump to counter Iran
summary: Gulf Arab states are optimistic about President-elect Donald Trump's ability to counter Iran's influence in the Middle East, despite concerns about his short temper and Twitter habits. Trump's hawkish stance on Iran and his "peace through strength" approach may lead to a stronger US presence in the region, potentially undermining Iranian support for paramilitary allies in Syria, Iraq, Yemen, and Lebanon. Trump's administration is expected to prioritize defeating "radical Islamic terror groups" and developing a missile defense system to protect against Iranian and North Korean attacks. However, some worry that Trump's policies may exacerbate tensions and lead to instability in the region.

site_title: Collective ambition important for business growth: study
summary: A study by Aon Hewitt found that collective ambition is key to driving business growth. High-performing companies unite leadership around a common goal, using unique annual and long-term incentive plans to empower teams and drive growth. These companies typically use one or two metrics, such as profit, and provide higher maximum award payouts for achieving performance targets. Long-term incentive plans, like stock options, also contribute to growth. The study emphasizes the importance of reviewing company goals and growth plans annually and linking them to concrete measures.

site_title: M1's Q4 net profit down 27.1% to S$31.8m
summary: M1, a Singaporean telecommunications company, reported a 27.1% drop in Q4 net profit to S$31.8 million, from S$43.6 million in the same period last year. Despite a 1.9% growth in revenue to S$313.9 million, the decline in net profit was attributed to the disruption of traditional telecommunication services by OTT services.

site_title: Trump tells automakers he'll ease environmental regulations
summary: US President Donald Trump met with executives of the three biggest US automakers, Ford, Fiat Chrysler, and General Motors, telling them that environmental regulations are "out of control" and promising to ease them. Trump expressed his desire to reduce regulations, which may indicate a willingness to scale back federal fuel-economy demands. He also vowed to simplify the process for oil companies and other businesses to operate in the US. The meeting comes as the administration plans to tackle trade, regulatory, and tax reforms.

site_title: Banks battle it out to finance US$1.1b Cerba buyout
summary: Banks are competing to secure a mandate for a $1.1 billion debt financing backing the acquisition of European medical laboratory services operator Cerba by Partners Group and PSP Investments. JP Morgan, Natixis, BNP Paribas, Credit Agricole, and Credit Suisse initially provided a staple financing package, but more banks are trying to secure a role on the deal. The final bank lineup is expected to be announced in the coming days, with banks competing to offer the most attractive terms and pricing.

site_title: Dwarf galaxies shed light on dark matter
summary: Researchers have discovered seven clusters of dwarf galaxies, each 10-1,000 times smaller than the Milky Way, using the Sloan Digital Sky Survey. The clusters, found 200-650 million light years away, are gravitationally bound and are expected to merge to form one larger galaxy. This discovery supports a leading theory about galaxy formation and sheds light on the role of dark matter in binding galaxies together. The findings provide insight into how structures such as galaxies formed in the early Universe and could help explain the formation of larger galaxies like the Milky Way.

site_title: 'La La Land' leads Oscar nominations with 14 nods
summary: "La La Land" led the 89th Oscar nominations with 14 nods, including best picture, actor, actress, and director. "Arrival" and "Moonlight" tied for second place with 8 nominations. The Oscars will be awarded on February 26 in Hollywood. This year's ceremony marks a shift towards a more diverse and inclusive film industry, with "Moonlight" being the first film with an all-black cast to receive a best picture nomination since 1947.

site_title: Rio hastens coal retreat with US$2.45b sale of mines
summary: Rio Tinto agreed to sell its Australian thermal coal assets to Yancoal Australia Ltd for up to $2.45 billion, marking the company's acceleration of its move away from coal. The sale includes Rio's biggest producing mine in the Hunter Valley and will be subject to Australian government approval. This move follows Rio's efforts to shed non-iron ore and aluminum assets since 2013, with the coal business contributing less than 10% of its $34.8 billion in sales last year.

site_title: Time for a review of rules on industrial space usage
summary: Singapore's urban planners are reviewing rules on industrial space usage due to a shift in the manufacturing landscape. The 60-40 rule, which requires at least 60% of gross space to be used for industrial activity, may be too restrictive, with some arguing it should be flipped to allow for more ancillary services. The review comes as the city-state faces a rise in misused industrial space, with unauthorised users often SMEs, and a need to accommodate emerging industries such as R&D and e-commerce. The government is considering updates to zoning, allowable uses, and the 60-40 rule to ensure Singapore's real estate can support future business needs.

site_title: US:Wall St edges higher as earnings gather pace
summary: US stocks edged higher on Tuesday as investors assessed quarterly earnings, seeking clarity on President Donald Trump's economic policies. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 0.02%, the S&P 500 increased 0.12%, and the Nasdaq Composite rose 0.31%. Earnings are estimated to have risen 6.6% for S&P 500 companies, with profits expected to justify market valuations. Despite Trump's recent warnings on trade deals, stocks remain positive, with Fiat Chrysler rising 4.4% and GM and Ford's stock slightly higher.

site_title: Wanted: Sponsors for Singapore's first bike-sharing scheme
summary: The Land Transport Authority (LTA) in Singapore is seeking corporate sponsors for its first bike-sharing scheme, set to pilot in three districts by the end of 2017. Lagardere Sports and The X Collective have been appointed as official sponsorship and marketing consultants. The fully self-service scheme aims to promote cycling as a mode of transportation in the city-state.

site_title: Ascendas Reit's DPU for Q3 FY2017 rises to 3.993 Singapore cents
summary: Ascendas Reit posted a year-on-year rise of 0.047 Singapore cent in distribution per unit (DPU) to 3.993 Singapore cents for Q3 FY2017, despite an increase in units in issue. Gross revenue rose 7.6% to S$208.6 million, driven by Australian portfolio acquisitions, while net property income increased 9% to S$155 million. The Reit's counter fell one Singapore cent to close at S$2.400 after the announcement.

site_title: Norway home building set for 38-year high, price drop possible
summary: Norway is expected to build around 38,000 homes this year, the highest since 1979, driven by low credit and soaring house prices. Following a 12.8% year-over-year surge in December, prices may level out in 2017 or 2018 but could also drop due to supply matching demand. Experts warn of a possible price shock and a potential 20% price drop over four years if interest rates rise. This marks the first time in years that home building has exceeded household growth, raising concerns about a potential housing market correction.

site_title: Magnus Bocker is next SIAS honorary chairman
summary: Magnus Bocker, former CEO of Singapore Exchange, has been appointed as the fourth honorary chairman of SIAS (Securities Investors Association Singapore), effective February 1, 2017. This three-year appointment aims to promote investor education and advocacy in Singapore. Bocker replaces Tan Sri Wan Datu 'Abd. Rahim Kajai, whose term ended in 2016.

site_title: US existing home sales fall as supply hits 17-year low
summary: US existing home sales declined 2.8% in December to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 5.49 million units, missing economists' forecasts of a 1.1% drop. This marked the lowest supply of houses on the market in 17 years, since 1999. The sales pace was revised up to 5.65 million units in November, the highest since February 2007. Despite the decline, sales increased to 5.45 million units in 2016, the highest since 2006.

site_title: New Formula One Boss frowns on Ecclestone's far-flung dealmaking
summary: Chase Carey, the new CEO of Formula One, has vowed to end the practice of signing lucrative deals with deep-pocketed nations with little history in auto racing. Carey aims to focus on key markets like the US and Europe, rather than pursuing "deal of the day" mentality. He plans to boost interest in the sport by hosting events in destination cities like New York and Los Angeles, and expand the sport's digital media presence. Carey also plans to explore direct sales to internet streaming outlets, including Amazon, to bypass traditional television broadcasters.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close higher on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 9.380 points to 1680.690 on Tuesday, with a total volume of 1.560 billion lots worth RM2.025 billion. Gainers outnumbered losers 416 to 353.

site_title: CIMB said in talks to sell US$200m stake in brokerage arm
summary: CIMB Group Holdings Bhd, Malaysia's second-largest lender, is in talks to sell a US$200 million stake in its brokerage arm to China Galaxy Securities Co. The deal aims to cut costs, exit low-return businesses, and boost profitability. CIMB is exploring a 50-50 joint venture with Galaxy Securities to cover institutional and retail brokerage, equity research, and associated securities businesses. The planned stake sale is part of CIMB's strategy to expand in selected areas and reach a deal by the end of March.

site_title: Kingfisher tycoon Vijay Mallya charged in loan default case -CBI
summary: Vijay Mallya, Indian liquor and aviation tycoon, has been charged by the Central Bureau of Investigation (CBI) with misappropriating a 9 billion rupee loan ($132 million) granted by a government-owned bank. The loan was for his defunct Kingfisher airline, which owed around $1.4 billion to banks. The CBI's action may pave the way for a formal extradition process from Britain, where Mallya has been living in "forced exile" since March 2016.

site_title: Most Indian firms under-hedged, vulnerable to FX risk
summary: Most Indian companies with overseas debt have inadequate foreign currency hedging, making them vulnerable to sharp rupee movements. A study by India Ratings found that 54 of 100 companies with 19.5 trillion rupees in foreign debt are at risk, with only 35% of their balance sheets hedged. A 10% rupee depreciation could significantly weaken the credit profiles of 42 companies holding 8.9 trillion rupees in foreign currency debt, potentially impacting their margins, borrowing costs, and credit ratings.

site_title: Chasen bags contracts worth S$20.6m in FY2017
summary: Chasen Holdings secured contracts worth S$20.6 million for FY2017, including a US$12 million job in the US, a S$2 million contract in Singapore, and an RM5 million job in Malaysia. Works on the projects are expected to be completed between March and July 2017. The group aims to improve revenue and streamline administration to cut costs and increase profitability.

site_title: Demand for cobalt being powered by boom in electric cars
summary: Cobalt prices surged 50% last year due to the global boom in electric vehicles, with demand expected to increase 16% annually through 2022. The metal is essential for lithium-ion batteries and is now in high demand from manufacturers like Tesla and Volkswagen. Prices may exceed $18 per pound and potentially rise above $20, driven by a production deficit and increased trading on the London Metal Exchange. The industry is expanding output, but concerns remain about human rights abuses in the Democratic Republic of Congo, which supplies 63% of global cobalt.

images.alt_text: Cobalt nuggets from a mine in Zambia. Global demand for the metal exceeded output in 2016 for the first time in seven years and increased purchases by fund managers this year will likely widen the production deficit.

site_title: 3M exceeds earnings estimates as sales grow in industrial unit
summary: 3M Co. reported a fourth-quarter profit of $1.88 per share, beating analysts' estimates of $1.87 per share. The company's industrial unit saw a sales boost, helping to offset a challenging year marked by a strong US dollar and a downturn in the consumer-electronics market. With two-thirds of revenue coming from overseas, 3M is focusing on reducing US expenses and strengthening its business in Europe and Latin America.

images.alt_text: 3M Co's fourth-quarter profit narrowly beat analysts' estimates as the maker of Post-it notes boosted sales in its industrial operation.

site_title: Roxy-Pacific buys five shophouses for S$17m
summary: Roxy-Pacific Holdings agreed to acquire five adjoining shophouses on Upper Bukit Timah Road for S$17 million, totaling a 10,256 sq ft freehold residential site with a plot ratio of 2.5 under Singapore's 2014 land use master plan. The acquisition will be funded with internal funds and bank borrowings via its unit RH Capital.

images.alt_text: PROPERTY developer Roxy-Pacific Holdings has agreed to acquire five adjoining two-storey shophouses on Upper Bukit Timah Road for S$17 million in total, it said in a Singapore Exchange filing on Tuesday.

site_title: Teho issues Writ of Summons against two vendors, seeks S$1.26m in damages
summary: Teho International, a Catalist-listed oil and gas company, has issued a Writ of Summons in the High Court of Singapore against two vendors for non-compliance with a contract. The company is seeking damages of S$1.26 million, along with costs, due to the vendors' failure to meet certain contractual obligations under a sale and purchase agreement and deed of indemnity. The matter concerns shares in TIEC Holdings Pte Ltd.

site_title: Toshiba board to approve plans to split off chip business on Friday
summary: Toshiba's board will approve plans to split off its chip business into a separate company on Friday, aiming to raise over $2.5 billion by selling a 20% stake. The move is part of efforts to offset a potential $500 billion to $700 billion writedown for its US nuclear business. The chip business is valued at $1 trillion to $1.5 trillion. Toshiba is also considering selling other businesses to address its financial struggles.

site_title: Billionaire banker seeks solace in bonds as share sale stymied
summary: Billionaire banker Rana Kapoor of Yes Bank Ltd has signaled a shift in strategy, considering annual bond sales to bolster capital, after a US$1 billion share sale faltered in September. The bank's third-quarter profit beat estimates, and strong investor interest in a US$441 million perpetual bond sale has given Kapoor confidence in similar transactions. The sale bolstered the lender's capital adequacy ratio by 150 basis points, and Kapoor stated that there is no pressing need to raise capital through a share sale now. The bank's loans grew 39% in the December quarter, and further growth will require an equity capital boost.

site_title: Cosco Corp's yard unit gets wind farm support vessel deal (Amended)
summary: Cosco Corp's subsidiary Cosco Nantong has secured a contract from Hong Kong-based Everbright International Offshore to build a multi-purpose wind farm support unit. The newbuild is expected to be delivered in the fourth quarter of 2018. The contract value remains confidential, but an option for a second unit is available.

site_title: China's Alibaba quarterly revenue surges 54% to 53.25b yuan
summary: China's Alibaba reported a 54% year-over-year surge in quarterly revenue to 53.25 billion yuan (S$11 billion), driven by rapid growth in Chinese online shopping. Net income attributable to ordinary shareholders rose 43% to 17.9 billion yuan. The results are seen as a benchmark for China's consumer sector, indicating a strong economy. Alibaba's rapid growth is attributed to China's increasing online shopping habits.

site_title: China says it will not back down on S China Sea: Beijing
summary: China has reaffirmed its claims to the South China Sea, stating it will not back down despite US vows to defend international interests in the disputed waters. China's foreign ministry spokeswoman Hua Chunying said the country has "indisputable sovereignty" over the islands and will "firmly safeguard its rights and interests." The US, under the Trump administration, has vowed to protect its interests in the region, with White House spokesman Sean Spicer saying the US will defend "international interests from being taken over by one country."

site_title: Koh Poh Tiong appointed independent director of Bukit Sembawang Estates
summary: Koh Poh Tiong, 70, has been appointed as an independent director of Bukit Sembawang Estates, a Singaporean residential property developer. Koh, a veteran in the food and beverage industry, previously served as CEO of Asia Pacific Breweries from 1993 to 2008. He also chairs the National Kidney Foundation and currently serves on several other company boards. The appointment comes as Bukit Sembawang Estates continues to focus on its Yio Chu Kang land bank.

site_title: Court ruling will not change Brexit timetable: Downing St
summary: Britain will trigger Article 50 to start Brexit talks by the end of March, despite a Supreme Court ruling requiring parliamentary approval. The government will introduce emergency legislation to approve the start of Brexit, with Brexit minister David Davis set to make a statement to parliament. The ruling does not change the planned timeline, which was backed by a six-to-one margin in parliament. The government respects the Supreme Court's decision and will set out its next steps to parliament. The two-year Brexit process will begin after the trigger is pulled.

site_title: Hong Kong to return 9 SAF Terrex vehicles to Singapore
summary: Hong Kong authorities will release nine Singapore Armed Forces (SAF) armoured vehicles, known as Terrex Infantry Carrier Vehicles, that were detained since last November. The vehicles were returned after Hong Kong's Chief Executive Leung Chun Ying completed an investigation and informed Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong that the vehicles would be released to the Singapore Government through a carrier. The decision marks the end of a standoff between the two territories over the vehicles' ownership.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's business confidence remains weak in Q4, increasing slightly from previous quarters, according to a joint survey. The country is shifting focus to other regional trade initiatives after the US withdrew from the TPP. Meanwhile, Vietnam is surprised by a US tariff announcement and seeks a lower rate, while the Asian garment industry braces for higher tariffs. China's GDP growth is expected to slow, putting pressure on policymakers.

site_title: China regulator lowers insurers' caps on stock investment
summary: China's insurance regulator has lowered caps on insurers' stock investments, restricting funds to 5% of total assets in a single stock and 30% in equities. The rules, reinstated ahead of the 2015 stock market crash, aim to control risk and prevent investment concentration. Insurers have invested 1.2 trillion yuan in stocks, accounting for 10% of their assets. The regulator gave insurers two years or more to adjust their investment allocations. The move is part of a series of measures to limit risk and tighten compliance management systems.

site_title: Singapore says TPP cannot come into effect, turns to other regional trade initiatives
summary: Singapore has ruled out the implementation of the Trans-Pacific Partnership (TPP) due to the US' withdrawal from the agreement. With the US' participation no longer guaranteed, the agreement cannot come into effect. Instead, Singapore plans to focus on other regional trade initiatives, including the Regional Comprehensive Economic Partnership and a free trade area of the Asia-Pacific. The country will engage in discussions with other TPP members to reassess the benefits and determine the best course of action.

site_title: Amazon said to settle EU antitrust probe over e-books clauses
summary: Amazon is set to settle a 19-month EU antitrust probe over e-book deals with publishers by changing clauses that required publishers to offer terms as good as or better than those signed with other e-book distributors. The European Commission will publish details of the offer and seek publisher feedback before deciding whether to close the case without fines or declare Amazon breached antitrust rules. This settlement avoids potential fines, with the exact terms of the agreement remaining confidential.

images.alt_text: Amazon.com Inc is set to dodge antitrust fines from a European Union probe into its e-book deals with publishers, according to two people familiar with the company's bid to settle the 19-month investigation.

site_title: Keppel Reit reports DPU of 1.48 cents for Q4, 6.37 cents for full year
summary: Keppel Reit reported a DPU of 1.48 cents for Q4 2016 and 6.37 cents for the full year 2016. The distribution yield was 6.2% for the year. The company maintained a high tenant retention rate of 95% and portfolio occupancy rate of 99.2%. However, its rent reversion rate was -9% for FY 2016, attributed to a challenging global economic environment. Keppel Reit was cautious about prospects for 2017, expecting continued dampening effects on the Singapore office leasing market.

images.alt_text: KEPPEL Reit announced on Tuesday a distribution per unit (DPU) of 1.48 Singapore cents for the fourth quarter of 2016, bringing the total DPU for the full year to 6.37 Singapore cents.

site_title: Trading plunges at China's Bitcoin exchanges after fees levied
summary: China's bitcoin exchanges, including OkCoin, Huobi, and BTC China, have started charging transaction fees, causing trading volumes to plummet. The one-hour volume at OkCoin fell 89% to 1,026 bitcoins, while Huobi and BTC China saw declines of 92% and 82% respectively. The fees aim to suppress speculation and prevent big price swings, following on-site inspections by the Chinese central bank that found several violations. The move may end the automated trading system that relied on the lack of fees.

site_title: Singapore shares close higher on Tuesday; STI now up 2.1% for 2017
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) rose 16.47 points to 3,041.95, bringing its 2017 gain to 2.1%. The index received a boost from improved turnover and a 248-178 rise-fall ratio. This comes despite a Wall Street slide, slight Dow futures weakness, and an indifferent Hong Kong session.

site_title: Trump's exit from Pacific trade deal opens door for Germany
summary: Germany's Vice Chancellor Sigmar Gabriel said the US withdrawal from the Trans-Pacific Partnership (TPP) would create opportunities for trade with Asia and South America, citing the US economy's lack of competitiveness. Gabriel criticized US President Donald Trump's trade policies, including a threatened 35% tariff on German cars. Germany's exports to the US account for only 10% of its total exports, with 60% going to European countries. The European Union is considering expanding trade with China and other countries, and a free trade agreement with Canada is expected to be approved.

site_title: BOJ is said to be wary of yield target hike even if CPI hits 1%
summary: Bank of Japan officials are cautious about raising their 10-year bond yield target from zero percent, even if consumer price gains reach 1% later this year. They prioritize confirming an improving underlying inflation trend and are mindful of past policy exits that prolonged deflation. The BOJ's Governor Haruhiko Kuroda expects GDP growth of 1.5% for the fiscal year starting in April, and some officials think the central bank could raise its outlook for economic growth. The 10-year yield target is currently at zero percent, with officials aiming to keep it stable even if CPI reaches 1%.

images.alt_text: Bank of Japan officials would rather be late than early in raising their 10-year bond yield target from zero per cent, even if consumer price gains reach one per cent later this year, according to people familiar with the central bank's discussions.

site_title: Mapletree Industrial Trust posts 0.4% rise in Q3 DPU
summary: Mapletree Industrial Trust reported a 0.4% increase in distribution per unit (DPU) to 2.83 Singapore cents for the third quarter ended Dec 31, 2016. Gross revenue grew 1.4% to S$84.45 million, while net property income rose 2.5% to S$63.43 million. The improvement was driven by higher rental rates and revenue from Phase One of the BTS development, but was partly offset by lower portfolio occupancy.

images.alt_text: MAPLETREE Industrial Trust on Tuesday posted a 0.4 per cent rise in distribution per unit (DPU) to 2.83 Singapore cents for the third quarter ended Dec 31, 2016.

site_title: M1's Q4 profit down 27.1% to S$31.8m as traditional telco services take a hit
summary: M1 Singapore reported a 27.1% decline in Q4 net profit to S$31.8 million, driven by a drop in traditional telecommunication services. Revenue grew 1.9% to S$313.9 million. Full-year net profit fell 16.1% to S$149.7 million, and revenue decreased 8.3% to S$1.06 billion. The decline is attributed to over-the-top services disrupting traditional telco services.

images.alt_text: WITH traditional telecommunication services disrupted by over-the-top services, M1 on Tuesday reported a 27.1 per cent fall in net profit for the fourth quarter ended Dec 31, 2016, to S$31.8 million, from S$43.6 million in the year-ago period.

site_title: Frasers Hospitality Group expands footprint in Jakarta with ninth property
summary: Frasers Hospitality Group has expanded its presence in Jakarta with the addition of its ninth property, Frasers Suites Kuningan. The 210-unit serviced residence is part of the Ciputra World 2 Jakarta mixed-use development. This new addition is expected to bring the group's total units in Jakarta to over 1,500 by 2019, meeting its target. The launch of Frasers Suites Kuningan is the latest step in the group's efforts to increase its footprint in the Indonesian capital.

site_title: Singapore interest rates continue heading south, fall to lowest this year
summary: Singapore's interest rates continue to decline, with the three-month swap offer rate (SOR) falling to 0.737% and the three-month Sibor at 0.961%. The SOR's decline is attributed to a weaker US dollar, which has risen to a 1.5-month high against the Singapore dollar. The US dollar index has fallen to 100, with experts predicting the SOR may range from 0.7% to 0.9% in Q1. Analysts say the strong US dollar trend remains intact and interest rates are unlikely to fall further.

site_title: Software giant SAP sees silver lining in global upheaval
summary: Software giant SAP reported strong 2016 results, with net profit at 3.6 billion euros, a 18% increase from 2015. The company forecasts boosted growth due to demand for its cloud services, despite Brexit and geopolitical upheaval. SAP's CEO, Bill McDermott, believes digital transformation is necessary for companies to handle new processes and outcomes, leading to increased confidence in the company's 2020 ambition. The firm increased its underlying profit by 4% to 6.6 billion euros and expects cloud subscriptions to drive future growth, reaching 3.8-4 billion euros in 2017.

site_title: US Dollar ticks up in Asia after sharp losses
summary: The US dollar saw a small recovery in Asia against major peers on Tuesday, but retreated on most other regional units after US Treasury Secretary nominee Steve Mnuchin expressed concerns that a strong currency could hurt the US economy. The comments come amid President Trump's protectionist rhetoric and plans to review trade deals, sparking investor worries about the potential impact on emerging markets.

site_title: Australia shares end higher as weak dollar lifts metals, NZ flat
summary: Australian shares rose 0.7% on Tuesday, driven by gains in materials, as the US dollar hit a seven-week low due to concerns over President Donald Trump's protectionist trade stance. The S&P/ASX 200 index closed at 5,650.1. The weak dollar lifted metal prices, including iron ore, copper, and gold.

site_title: Update: Singapore bunker barge operator New Ocean Maritime fined for operating without licence
summary: Singapore-based bunker barge operator New Ocean Maritime was fined S$81,000 for operating without a licence between Jan. 3, 2015 and March 28, 2015. The company used the license of Seaquest Tanker, which had its permit revoked for erroneous record-keeping. The Maritime and Port Authority (MPA) has a zero-tolerance approach to bunkering malpractices, and the fine is a result of their efforts to maintain port integrity.

site_title: Hong Kong, Shanghai: Stocks close with gains
summary: Hong Kong and Shanghai stocks closed with gains on Tuesday, despite US President Donald Trump's expected protectionist policies. The Hang Seng Index rose 0.22%, while the Shanghai Composite Index gained 0.18%. The Shenzhen Composite Index, however, declined 0.30%. Investors appear to be brushing off the concerns, instead focusing on global trade and market trends.

site_title: Philippines sees big boost in tax revenue as spending supports growth
summary: The Philippines aims to collect a record 1.829 trillion pesos ($52.558 billion) in tax revenue this year, driven by higher infrastructure spending and a 11.6% increase in the government's budget. The budget, which is 3.35 trillion pesos, will support 6.5-7.5% economic growth and is part of President Rodrigo Duterte's infrastructure priorities. The Bureau of Internal Revenue (BIR) has proposed tax reforms to raise an additional $206.8 billion annually, including lowering income tax rates and increasing excise taxes on automobiles and fuel.

site_title: UK's May to find out if she can trigger Brexit without parliament
summary: British Prime Minister Theresa May will learn on Tuesday whether parliament's approval is required to trigger Brexit, potentially giving lawmakers a chance to amend or hinder her plans. The UK Supreme Court will rule on whether May can use "royal prerogative" to invoke Article 50, a move backed by the government but opposed by some lawmakers and the Scottish government. A ruling against the government could lead to a parliamentary bill, potentially delaying the Brexit process, while a ruling in favor of the government could allow her to follow her planned timetable.

site_title: Former Sinopec president gets 15 years for graft
summary: China sentenced former Sinopec president Wang Tianpu to 15.5 years for corruption, with a fine of 3.2 million yuan. The verdict was handed down by the Nanchang City Intermediate People's Court in Jiangxi province. Wang was found guilty of embezzling assets, with the court ordering the illicit gains to be confiscated and returned to Sinopec. This punishment marks the latest in a series of high-profile graft cases in China's oil sector.

site_title: Hong Kong watchdog seeks to ban directors of China's Hanergy
summary: Hong Kong's securities watchdog is seeking to ban the directors of Chinese solar energy firm Hanergy Thin Film Power Group for up to 15 years due to the company's plummeting shares in 2016. The 47% drop wiped US$19 billion off Hanergy's market capitalization, prompting a trading suspension. Company founder Li Hejun stepped down as chairman in May 2016, after being listed as China's richest man. The watchdog's move is aimed at addressing the company's lack of transparency and governance issues.

site_title: Oil rises near US$53 as Iraq says close to full Opec cut pledge
summary: Oil prices rose near US$53 a barrel as Iraq said it's close to implementing its share of pledged output cuts with Opec. Iraq reduced supply by 180,000 barrels a day and plans to cut a further 30,000 a day by the end of the month. Oil inventories in the US are expected to expand for a third straight week, but the market is focused on producers' compliance with cuts.

site_title: Report on the future of Singapore's economy will focus on doing more with less: Ong Ye Kung
summary: Singapore's economic growth will focus on productivity and innovation rather than manpower growth, according to Education Minister Ong Ye Kung. The country's small size and demographic challenges limit manpower growth, and preserving a sense of identity is also a concern. The report highlights the need for Singapore to pursue economic growth through innovation and productivity, rather than relying solely on manpower. This approach will enable the country to achieve sustainable growth despite its limited resources.

images.alt_text: Singapore's economic growth cannot be achieved through manpower growth, but should be pursued based on productivity and innovation, Education Minister (Higher Education and Skills) Ong Ye Kung said on Tuesday as he gave a preview of an upcoming governmental report about how the country's economy will enter its next phase.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks, won finish directionless on Trump policies, holidays
summary: South Korean stocks and the won remained unchanged on Tuesday due to uncertainty over US President Donald Trump's policies and upcoming national holidays. The Korea Composite Stock Price Index (Kospi) closed at 2,065.76 points. Offshore investors sold 12.6 billion won worth of Kospi shares, but domestic investors showed little reaction. The market's directionlessness reflects the ongoing uncertainty surrounding Trump's policies, which may impact global markets and trade.

site_title: New design guidelines for privately-owned public spaces from April 24: URA
summary: Singapore's Urban Redevelopment Authority (URA) will enforce new design guidelines for privately-owned public spaces starting April 24, 2017. The guidelines require public spaces to be at least 50% of the gross floor area, accessible, and provide shade and seating. The move aims to incentivize and guide the development of high-quality public spaces in the city, promoting a better user experience.

site_title: Europe: Stock markets rebound at open
summary: European stock markets rebounded at the open on Tuesday, with London's FTSE 100 up 0.4% to 7,183.48 points. The eurozone's DAX 30 and Paris CAC 40 indexes also gained, with the DAX up 0.1% and the CAC 40 up 0.2%. The gains followed a 5-day rally in Singapore stocks and came despite US President Trump's new threats. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq also edged to fresh records despite tariff uncertainty.

site_title: Malaysia migrant boat death toll rises to 12, some 25 missing
summary: Malaysia reports a death toll of 12 after a boat carrying illegal Indonesian immigrants sank, with about 25 still missing. The bodies of two men, believed to be Indonesians, were found on Tanjung Leman beach near Mersing. A sea search has been suspended due to bad weather. The incident occurred on an overloaded boat, raising concerns about human trafficking and smuggling in the region.

site_title: Dubai airport 2016 traffic up 7.2%, still world's busiest international airport
summary: Dubai International Airport remained the world's busiest international airport in 2016, with a 7.2% increase in annual traffic to 83.6 million passengers. This marked the airport's second slowest growth rate in at least eight years. Despite this, Dubai airport maintained its position as the world's busiest international airport for international passengers.

images.alt_text: Dubai International Airport remained the world's busiest for international passengers in 2016, as existing markets grew and new routes were launched, the airport's operator said.

site_title: Singapore Dec output set to rise 9.5% y-o-y, risks to outlook seen
summary: Singapore's industrial production is expected to rise 9.5% in December from a year ago, according to a Reuters poll of 11 analysts. However, manufacturing output is forecast to shrink 5.8% on a month-on-month and seasonally adjusted basis. Analysts doubt the sustainability of the increase, citing risks from US President Donald Trump's protectionist stance and a potential seasonal pick-up ahead of year-end holidays. The surge is seen as a transitory trend rather than a turnaround in the economy.

images.alt_text: Singapore's industrial production in December is expected to have continued to rise on an annual basis, a Reuters poll showed, though there are doubts over the sustainability of the increase and risks to the outlook from the new US administration's trade policies.

site_title: Samsung warns of political risks as chips boost Q4 profit
summary: Samsung Electronics Co Ltd expects to see profit growth in 2017 despite challenges from political uncertainty and the Note 7 smartphone fiasco. The company's fourth-quarter operating profit jumped 50% to 9.22 trillion won, driven by record chip earnings. However, analysts warn that the outlook is clouded by uncertainty over premium smartphones and the fallout from a graft scandal involving Samsung Group scion Jay Y Lee. The company plans to buy back 9.3 trillion won worth of shares and is counting on the booming chip market to drive growth.

site_title: Australia leads push for TPP without US after Trump exits deal
summary: Australia is leading efforts to salvage the Trans-Pacific Partnership (TPP) after the US formally withdrew as a signatory. Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull discussed the deal with Japanese counterpart Shinzo Abe and held talks with New Zealand and Singapore leaders. Australia's trade minister, Steven Ciobo, stated that a TPP without the US is a "live option." The move comes after US President Donald Trump's withdrawal, leaving 11 remaining countries to consider the future of the agreement.

site_title: Pokemon Go unleashed on game-mad South Korea six months late
summary: Pokémon Go was released in South Korea six months after its global debut due to security concerns over Google Maps, which were limited by the government's national security reasons. The game, jointly developed by Nintendo and Niantic Inc., relies on Google Maps to function, but used publicly accessible data sources to overcome the challenge. The game's launch was met with limited buzz in Seoul, with temperatures well below freezing. Despite a slight hitch with the game being unavailable for download, it officially launched its service in South Korea, marking the country's fourth-largest gaming market.

site_title: Etihad Airways chief Hogan to step down
summary: Etihad Airways' CEO James Hogan will step down in the second half of 2017 after nearly 11 years at the helm, following a transition process initiated by the board and Hogan last year. Hogan, an Australian, took over in 2006. The move comes as the airline continues to grow, with Hogan having overseen significant expansion. Details on the transition process and Hogan's replacement have not been announced yet.

images.alt_text: Abu Dhabi-based Etihad Airways said Tuesday its chief executive officer James Hogan will step down in the second half of 2017 after leading the fast-growing Gulf carrier for more than 10 years.

site_title: Brussels airport bombers targeted US, Jews: probe
summary: Belgian investigators believe the Islamic State bombers who attacked Brussels airport in March 2016 targeted US passengers and Jewish people. A check-in counter for an American carrier was among the targets, and footage shows a bomber pursuing Hasidic Jews before a blast. The investigation also suspects that travelers to Israel may have been targeted. The attacks, which killed 32 people, were the deadliest in Brussels' history.

site_title: Thai court muzzles media as trafficking defence begins
summary: A Thai court barred dozens of journalists from reporting on human trafficking trial proceedings, where dozens of people, including a general, began defending themselves against trafficking charges. The trial is part of Thailand's crackdown on human trafficking, which was launched in 2015. The kingdom has long been a major hub for human trafficking and people-smuggling, with officials accused of complicity. The crackdown led to the discovery of grim camps on the Thai-Malaysia border and dozens of arrests.

site_title: Trump protectionism might help emerging markets, hedge fund says
summary: US President Donald Trump's protectionist moves could benefit emerging markets by forcing them to implement structural reforms, according to a US hedge fund. Trump's actions, including withdrawing from the Trans-Pacific Partnership and imposing a border tax, give developing countries incentives to drive productivity, wage growth, and consumption at home. This could lead to stronger domestic demand and resilience for emerging markets, particularly China, where reforms are expected to continue.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened higher on Tuesday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rising 0.630 points to 1671.940. Gainers outnumbered losers 103 to 77, with a total trading volume of 83.16 million lots worth RM36.24 million.

site_title: South Korea: Stocks flat ahead of long holiday, won firms
summary: South Korean stocks remained flat early Tuesday ahead of the Lunar New Year holiday, with the Korea Composite Stock Price Index (KOSPI) down 0.2% at 2,061.02 points. The move was largely influenced by uncertainties surrounding US President Donald Trump's policies, which affected US stocks. Trading remained thin, and investors held their positions as the market awaited the holiday.

site_title: China outbound property investment seen dropping as capital curbs bite
summary: China's outbound property investment is expected to drop slightly in 2017 due to the government's clampdown on capital outflows. Despite a record $38.3 billion in 2016, deal volume is forecast to decrease slightly, with investment in the US, Hong Kong, and Australia expected to remain strong. The government's measures aim to stem capital outflows following a 6.6% decline in the yuan against the US dollar last year. Investment in the office and hotel markets is expected to remain high, but development sites are forecast to see a decline.

site_title: Police report filed against ousted IHC executive director
summary: A police report was filed against Lim Beng Choo, the ousted executive director of International Healthway Corporation (IHC), a day after she was removed from her position. She was seen leaving the premises with her computer and documents. The company's executive functions and powers have been suspended, and she has been directed to assist the new board of directors. An interim transition committee and data management corporation have been appointed to review the company's affairs and conduct an internal audit.

site_title: Hot stock: SingHaiyi queried over unusual trading activity
summary: SingHaiyi, a Singapore property development group, was queried by the Singapore Exchange over "unusual price and volume movements" of its shares. The counter surged 15% to 12.2 cents after 14.6 million shares traded hands on Tuesday.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks open with gains
summary: Hong Kong shares opened higher on Tuesday, adding 0.30% to 22,968.23, despite a sell-off on Wall Street fueled by concerns over President Donald Trump's economic plans. In contrast, the Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index declined 0.07% and 0.61%, respectively. Traders brushed off the sell-off, citing the US stock market's resilience.

site_title: China's Wanda adds Nordic screens to its cinema empire
summary: China's Wanda Group has acquired Stockholm-based Nordic Cinema Group Holding for US$930 million, expanding its cinema empire. The deal brings Wanda closer to its goal of taking 20% of the world's film-market share. With the acquisition, AMC Theatres will reach 1,000 theatres and 11,000 screens in 15 countries. This move further solidifies Wanda's position as a world-beating cinema giant.

site_title: Australian, NZ dollars hit 10-week peaks as US dollar stumbles
summary: The Australian and New Zealand dollars reached 10-week highs as the US dollar stumbled due to concerns over President Donald Trump's protectionist trade stance. The Australian dollar rose to US$0.7609, while the New Zealand dollar climbed to US$0.7265, amidst uncertainty over Trump's plans for fiscal spending and tax cuts.
