The Aussie has gained 5.4% in January, outperforming major currencies, while inflation data is expected to be released later this week, which will be closely watched for confirmation of the central bank's target range.

site_title: Trump didn't give Ethics Office documentation, Democrat says
summary: President Donald Trump did not provide government ethics officials with documentation to show he had stepped away from his businesses prior to inauguration, unlike every other president since 1978. Office of Government Ethics Director Walter Shaub stated that his agency had not received the final paperwork, despite Trump's lawyers presenting it two weeks earlier. This raised concerns about Trump's blind trust, which was not established as required.

site_title: 7 in 10 Singaporeans use social media on mobile, double global average: survey
summary: In a survey, 7 in 10 Singaporeans use social media on mobile, exceeding the global average of 34% by double. The report, "Digital in 2017", shows 70% of Singaporeans are active social media users, a 22% increase from 2016. Additionally, 800,000 new users joined, bringing the total to over 3.4 million users.

site_title: Japan Jan flash manufacturing PMI shows fastest expansion in almost 3 years
summary: Japan's manufacturing activity expanded at the fastest pace in almost three years in January, driven by a surge in export orders, according to the Markit/Nikkei Japan Flash Manufacturing Purchasing Managers Index. The index rose to 52.8, above the 50 threshold for the third consecutive month, with new export orders increasing at the quickest rate in over a year. This suggests that global trade is picking up, benefiting Japan's export-focused economy. The news may ease concerns about Japan's economic outlook despite US President Donald Trump's potential protectionist trade policies.

images.alt_text: Japanese manufacturing activity expanded in January at the fastest pace in almost three years as export orders surged, suggesting that overseas demand is not as weak as some economists and business leaders had feared.

site_title: Singapore's business confidence remains weak despite slight uptick in Q4: survey
summary: Singapore's business confidence remains weak in the fourth quarter of 2016, despite a slight increase, according to a joint survey by ACCA and IMA. The survey found declining income, shrinking order books, and staff cuts, with confidence levels remaining weak by historical standards. A slowdown in Singapore's labor force growth, linked to lower fertility, aging, and high labor force participation, was cited as a key factor. The survey received 4,551 responses between November 24 and December 13, 2016.

images.alt_text: Business confidence in Singapore remains weak in the fourth quarter of last year despite a slight increase, according to a joint survey by the Association of Chartered Certified Accountants (ACCA) and the Institute of Management Accountants (IMA).

site_title: 'Zoolander 2', 'Batman v Superman' top Razzie nods
summary: Zoolander 2 and Batman v Superman: Dawn of Justice topped the Razzie nominations for worst films of 2016, with nine and eight nominations respectively. Zoolander 2 leads with worst picture, worst actor (Ben Stiller), and worst supporting actor (Owen Wilson), while Batman v Superman: Dawn of Justice is nominated for worst picture, worst director (Zack Snyder), and worst actor (Ben Affleck). The Razzies, Hollywood's anti-awards, will announce winners on February 25, the eve of the Oscars.

site_title: One-off abdication law eyed for Japan emperor
summary: Japan is considering a one-off law to allow its aging emperor to step down, a move that would be the first abdication in over two centuries. Emperor Akihito, 83, has expressed a desire to abdicate due to his advancing age and weakening health. A government panel, set to make a final recommendation in March, has proposed several options, including a one-off bill, revising the law to allow future emperors to resign, or installing a regent. The move has sparked debate over the monarch's role and potential for political manipulation.

images.alt_text: Japan could pass a one-off bill allowing its retirement-ready emperor to step down, a government panel said Monday, in what would be the first abdication in over two centuries.

site_title: China to strengthen market regulation by 2020
summary: China's State Council announced a five-year plan to strengthen market regulation by 2020, focusing on consumer rights, market efficiency, and removing barriers to entrepreneurship. The plan aims to improve market access, enhance consumer protection, particularly for the elderly, children, and rural residents. China will also ensure transparent market access rules and simplify commercial registration. The move aims to address issues such as fake goods, food and drug safety, and lack of consumer protections.

site_title: Singapore shares open flat on Tuesday
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index opened flat on Tuesday, down 0.41 points to 3,025.07, with 79.2 million shares traded worth S$31.4 million. The market had a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data, with gains outnumbering losses 46 to 36.

site_title: Singapore slips to 7th place in ranking for high-end rental accommodation in Asia
summary: Singapore has dropped to 7th place in the ranking for high-end rental accommodation in Asia, according to the Accommodation Survey by ECA International. The average rent for an unfurnished three-bedroom apartment in Singapore is $4,535 per month. This marks a significant decrease in average rents since 2012. The ranking change reflects the shifting rental landscape in Asia, with other cities such as Hong Kong, Shanghai, and Tokyo holding the top spots.

images.alt_text: Singapore has fallen to seventh place in a regional ranking for high-end rental accommodation this year. It was the fourth most expensive location in Asia last year.

site_title: Shui On Development to issue senior notes
summary: Shui On Development has entered into a purchase agreement with Standard Chartered Bank and Deutsche Bank to issue US$500 million senior notes with a 5.7% annual interest rate, due in 2021. The offer price is 99.384% of the principal amount. The estimated net proceeds will be approximately US$492 million, which will be used to repay near-term debt and fund capital expenditures. The notes may be redeemed at 100% of the principal amount prior to maturity.

site_title: US Senate confirms Pompeo to be Trump's CIA director
summary: The US Senate confirmed Mike Pompeo as President Donald Trump's CIA director, with 66 senators supporting him and 32 opposing, mainly from Democrats. The confirmation came after Pompeo's pledge to adhere to the Army Field Manual's interrogation techniques, excluding waterboarding and other "enhanced interrogation techniques" used by the CIA after 9/11. Pompeo was sworn in by Vice-President Mike Pence after the vote.

images.alt_text: The US Senate confirmed Representative Mike Pompeo as President Donald Trump's CIA director on Monday, after a delay tied to some lawmakers'worries he might expand surveillance or allow the use of certain interrogation techniques widely considered torture.

site_title: Brexit is opportunity to pull Europe closer together: EU official
summary: EU Parliament's chief Brexit negotiator Guy Verhofstadt says Britain's decision to leave the EU is an opportunity to reform Europe and avoid further breakdowns between member states. Verhofstadt calls for a unified European government and common market, urging the EU to take action before the 2019 elections. He also views US President Donald Trump's election as a wake-up call for the EU, highlighting the need for reform in light of Brexit and protectionism. Verhofstadt advocates for a clear triggering of Article 50 and a proposal for a future partnership with Britain.

site_title: US dollar retreats as Trump takes over
summary: The US dollar retreated on Monday as Donald Trump began his presidency, with trading floors experiencing uncertainty over his plans. Trump attacked global trade deals, promising to prioritize America first, causing stock markets to fall globally, including Wall Street, London, Frankfurt, Paris, and Tokyo. Analysts warn of potential wild volatility ahead.

site_title: US Senate committee backs Tillerson as Trump's secretary of state
summary: The US Senate Foreign Relations Committee voted 11-10 to approve Rex Tillerson as Donald Trump's secretary of state, with all Republicans supporting him and all Democrats opposing his nomination. This narrow victory is expected to lead to his confirmation from the full Senate.

site_title: Ex-Ferrari technical director Brawn returns to F1 in management role
summary: Former Ferrari technical director Ross Brawn, 62, has returned to Formula One in a management role as managing director for motorsport under Liberty Media. Brawn, a two-time world championship winner and seven-time world champion strategist, will work alongside chief executive Chase Carey and commercial operations director Sean Bratches. Brawn has 40 years of F1 expertise and previously held roles as team principal of Mercedes, Honda, and Ferrari. He expressed enthusiasm for the new opportunity to evolve the sport for teams, promoters, and fans.

site_title: LG Display reports record fourth quarter profit of 904.3b won
summary: LG Display reported a record fourth-quarter operating profit of 904.3 billion won, a 180% increase from last year, driven by a rise in panel prices. Revenue rose 18% to 7.9 trillion won. This surpasses analysts' estimates of 845 billion won.

site_title: Taiwan: Stocks up; trade cautious in last session before holiday break
summary: Taiwan's stocks rose 0.3% to a fresh year-and-a-half high on Tuesday before a holiday break, driven by a strengthened local dollar. The main Taiex index closed at 9,449.85 points, with the electronics subindex and financials subindex also gaining. The Taiwan dollar strengthened to NT$31.336 per US dollar, its highest level in over three months. The stock market will close from January 25 until February 2, with financial markets resuming trade on February 2.

site_title: Australia and New Zealand pledge to salvage TPP after US exit
summary: Australia and New Zealand are working to salvage the Trans-Pacific Partnership (TPP) after the US withdrew from the agreement, citing a desire to renegotiate bilateral trade deals. Australia's Trade Minister Steven Ciobo suggests China and Indonesia could join the remaining 11 countries, including Japan and Australia, to fill the vacuum left by the US. New Zealand's Trade Minister Todd McClay plans to meet with other TPP countries in the coming months to discuss how to move forward, with the agreement still holding value as a free trade agreement.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Ascott Reit, IHC, Cache Logistics Trust, Frasers Commercial Trust (Amended)
summary: Ascott Residence Trust reported a 7% decline in DPU to 1.93 cents for Q4, down from 2.07 cents last year. International Healthway Corp's board was removed in an EGM, while Cache Logistics Trust's DPU fell 10.8% to 1.85 cents. Frasers Commercial Trust maintained a stable DPU of 2.51 cents for Q1. The companies' announcements may affect trading of their shares.

site_title: Australia shares higher on metal prices; NZ falls
summary: Australian shares rose 0.4% on Tuesday, driven by gains in materials and mining stocks, following a weaker US dollar that boosted copper and gold prices. The S&P/ASX 200 index reached 5,634.2 points. BHP Billiton, Bluescope Steel, and Rio Tinto also saw significant gains, with Rio Tinto adding over 1.3% and Fortescue Metals Group adding 1.3%. In contrast, New Zealand's benchmark S&P/NZX 50 index fell 0.2%, led by losses in materials and industrial stocks.

site_title: Eurozone unblocks debt relief for Greece
summary: Eurozone finance ministers approved short-term debt relief measures for Greece, ending a dispute with Germany over surprise Christmas handouts by the Athens government. The measures, agreed in December, include easing the interest burden for Greece. The decision comes after a row sparked by Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras' hike in spending for pensioners and a sales tax break for islands sheltering migrants. The European Stability Mechanism described the measures as an "important step towards improving Greek debt sustainability."

site_title: Pentagon chief vows 'unshakeable commitment' to Nato: spokesman
summary: US Secretary of Defence James Mattis assured his British counterpart Michael Fallon of the US' "unshakeable commitment" to Nato during a phone call, contradicting President Donald Trump's previous statement that the alliance had "problems". This comes after Trump warned Nato had issues before his inauguration. Mattis emphasized the US' dedication to Nato, following a period of uncertainty over Washington's commitment to the alliance.

site_title: Trump advisor reassures Canada not to fear US trade intentions
summary: US President Donald Trump's senior economic advisor Stephen Schwarzman reassured Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau during a three-day retreat in Calgary that Canadians shouldn't be "enormously worried" about US trade intentions. This comes as the US is renegotiating the North American Free Trade Agreement (NAFTA) and has campaigned on securing a new trade deal with Canada and Mexico. Despite protectionist rhetoric, Schwarzman urged Canadians to focus on their demands for the renegotiation, aiming to map out Ottawa's position in the talks.

site_title: Samsung Q4 profit jumps as record chip profit masks Note 7 failure
summary: Samsung Electronics Co Ltd reported a 50% jump in fourth-quarter operating profit to 9.22 trillion won (S$11.23 billion) due to record earnings from its chip business, despite the negative impact of its failed Note 7 phones. Revenue remained flat at 53.3 trillion won. The company's chip business generated record earnings, while the Note 7 failure negatively impacted the company's overall profit.

site_title: Trump trade moves chilling, could hurt US business: trade experts
summary: President Donald Trump's first trade moves have cast a pall over US trade relations, potentially hurting US businesses. Trump withdrew from the 12-nation Trans-Pacific Partnership, vowing to renegotiate or exit other agreements. He also threatened to impose border taxes on imports, shifting away from decades of free trade policy. This shift has trade experts concerned, as it could lead to higher tariffs and trade tensions, affecting US businesses and the global economy.

images.alt_text: President Donald Trump's first moves on trade have cast a pall over US trade relations and could hurt US businesses, trade experts say.

site_title: Trump bans federal funding for foreign NGOs that support abortion
summary: President Donald Trump signed a decree banning US federal funding for foreign NGOs that support abortion, reversing a policy that was in place under the Obama administration. The move is seen as a pro-life stance, respecting taxpayer funding and echoing the president's values. This decision is part of Trump's efforts to stand up for the unborn and align with his campaign promises. The policy change has sparked controversy and is expected to have significant implications for international relations and human rights organizations.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open lower
summary: Tokyo stocks opened lower on Tuesday, with the Nikkei 225 index down 0.24% and the Topix index down 0.29%. The yen rose against the US dollar due to concerns over rising protectionism in the US under President Donald Trump.

site_title: Sale of core Yahoo assets to Verizon delayed
summary: Yahoo's $4.8 billion deal to sell core internet assets to Verizon has been delayed several months. The deal, which would mark Yahoo's end as an independent company, was initially set for this quarter but is now expected to close in the next quarter. The delay comes after two major data breaches were disclosed, raising concerns about the sale's potential impact on the deal's value and Verizon's decision to proceed. Yahoo is working to ramp up security and enhance user protection.

images.alt_text: Yahoo said on Monday that the closing of a US$4.8 billion deal to sell its core internet assets to US telecom titan Verizon has been delayed several months.

site_title: Singapore stocks need a dose of optimism
summary: Singapore stocks may present opportunities as 2017 begins with low expectations, according to the Singapore Exchange. Valuations for the Straits Times Index (STI) are at 13.8 times, slightly below its eight-year historical mean. Earnings multiples, fund flows, and weak Asian currencies suggest that valuations are not overpriced. Improving fundamentals, such as a recovery in crude oil prices and downward revisions to earnings estimates, may lead to increased optimism. Analysts recommend buying quality names in the Singapore market, citing a projected dividend yield of 3.8% and a price-to-book ratio of 1.1 times.

site_title: 80,000 yuan trips abroad replace Chinese New Year treks to Grandma's
summary: China is experiencing a shift in its Lunar New Year (Chinese New Year) celebrations, with more people opting to travel abroad instead of staying at home. The trend is driven by rising incomes and an expanding network of international flights, with over 6 million passengers expected to travel during the 7-day holiday. This year's celebration will see the biggest mass migration of people on Earth, with 414 million Chinese traveling abroad. Many destinations, including Japan, South Korea, and South-east Asia, are offering multiple-year visas to Chinese tourists, making it easier for them to travel.

images.alt_text: Outbound travel for the holiday break is expected to top a record 6 million passengers, with airlines hauling near-full loads to Japan, South Korea and South-east Asia.

site_title: Oil slips as US drilling recovery offsets Opec-led cuts
summary: Oil prices fell 1% on Monday as US drilling recovery offset Opec-led cuts, with Brent crude settling at $55.23 a barrel and US crude futures closing at $52.75 a barrel. Despite Opec and non-Opec producers meeting output reduction goals, US rig counts rose, and investors were rattled by President Trump's protectionist stance on trade. Oil market speculators showed increased optimism about higher prices, but a record high gross long position among money managers leaves the market ripe for a correction.

site_title: Elder Bush out of intensive care, wife Barbara released
summary: Former US President George H.W. Bush, 92, has been transferred out of intensive care and his wife Barbara, 91, has been discharged from hospital after being admitted for bacterial pneumonia and viral bronchitis, respectively. Bush is recovering well and may be discharged as early as Friday or the weekend. Despite his advanced age and Parkinson's disease, doctors say his condition is improving, but a full recovery could take another week or two.

site_title: Europe: Shares close at lowest in three weeks as banks, Fingerprint Cards fall
summary: European shares fell 0.4% on Monday, closing at their lowest in three weeks, due to a protectionist tone in US President Donald Trump's inauguration speech, which weighed on banks, oil stocks, and Fingerprint Cards. The Stoxx 600 index extended last week's drop as investors became disillusioned with Trump's 'America first' policy. Fingerprint Cards fell 7.5% after former CEO and a board member were arrested, while Generali rose 3.9% following a report on potential merger with Intesa Sanpaolo and Allianz.

site_title: Ecclestone ousted as F1 chief: report
summary: Bernie Ecclestone, 86, has reportedly been ousted as Formula One chief executive after being asked to resign by new chairman Chase Carey. Ecclestone, who transformed F1 into a multi-billion dollar business, was initially intended to remain in his role after Liberty Media took over the sport last September. However, Carey has taken control, marking the end of Ecclestone's 40-year tenure. The change in leadership comes as Liberty Media seeks to revamp the sport and improve its financial performance.

site_title: Trump torpedoes Trans-Pacific Partnership
summary: President Donald Trump has formally withdrawn the United States from the Trans-Pacific Partnership (TPP), a major Pacific trade deal. The move was made in accordance with Trump's election campaign promise and aims to counter growing Chinese economic influence. The TPP, which bound the US and seven other allies, represents 40% of the world economy. Trump's decision is expected to have significant economic implications for Asian countries, particularly Vietnam, Australia, and Japan, which had invested heavily in the trade deal. The move is seen as a significant blow to US allies and the global economy.

site_title: Ascott Reit's Q4 DPU dips 7% (Amended)
summary: Ascott Residence Trust reported a 7% decline in its distribution per unit (DPU) for the fourth quarter, to 1.93 Singapore cents, due to a one-off item. Revenue increased 6% to S$126.75 million, while gross profit rose 3% to S$58.2 million. The trust's full-year DPU rose 4% to 8.31 cents, driven by acquisitions in 2015 and 2016. The company is seeking accretive acquisitions and will consider divesting underperforming properties.

images.alt_text: Ascott Residence Trust announced on Tuesday that its distribution per unit (DPU) for the fourth quarter ended Dec 31, 2016, was 1.93 Singapore cents, down 7 per cent from 2.07 cents a year ago, after adjustment for a one-off item.

site_title: Keppel Infrastructure Trust Q4 DPU unchanged despite drop in earnings
summary: Keppel Infrastructure Trust (KIT) reported unchanged fourth-quarter distribution per unit (DPU) of 0.93 Singapore cents, despite a 11.6% drop in net profit to S$7.7 million. Earnings per unit declined to 0.2 Singapore cent from 0.22 cents a year ago due to lower revenue and fair value losses from financial derivatives. The trust also recorded a net loss from fair value movement on financial derivatives, resulting in a loss of S$2.5 million before tax. KIT's Australian subsidiary Basslink continues to face a dispute with Hydro Tasmania over an electricity interconnector outage in 2015.

site_title: US governors want say on Trump's infrastructure plan
summary: US governors are pushing for a say in President Donald Trump's infrastructure plan, citing hundreds of "shovel-ready" projects worth billions of dollars. The National Governor's Association has compiled a list of 300 projects from 43 states and territories, with more expected to be added. Governors see consensus on infrastructure problems, but lack of involvement in the plan is a concern. The White House has requested the list, indicating a potential collaboration between the administration and state governments on the plan.

site_title: May's industrial strategy seeks to pick winning areas for the UK
summary: UK Prime Minister Theresa May has announced an industrial strategy aimed at boosting Britain's productivity by identifying and supporting winning areas in the economy. The plan, set to be announced through sector deals, targets sectors such as biotechnology, artificial intelligence, and mobile networking, and includes a £170 million investment in new institutes and teaching of STEM subjects. The strategy is part of May's effort to define her government beyond Brexit, but some experts warn it may complicate trade deal negotiations with the EU and other countries.

site_title: Emirates stokes ire of US airlines with flights through Greece
summary: Emirates has launched a new daily route from Dubai to the New York area via Athens, Greece, sparking ire from US airlines such as Delta, American Airlines, and United. The route, which began on March 12, is Emirates' second to arrive in the US after Europe, and is seen as a challenge to US airlines' dominance. The move is part of a broader dispute over subsidies provided by the UAE and Qatar to airlines like Emirates, Qatar Airways, and Etihad Airways. The US airlines' lobbying group claims this unfair support harms American jobs and violates the Open Skies agreement.

site_title: Before innovating, one must first imagine - or learn how to
summary: Teaching innovation has evolved over the last 20 years, with a focus on cultivating imagination and a mindset of wonder and curiosity. While methods and tools are essential, they cannot replace the behavior of the innovator. Aristotle's concept of being amazed and taking a new look at the world is similar to the stance innovators must take to imagine new offers. Imagination must be taught and cultivated, and traditional education should be challenged to promote diversity and transdisciplinarity. Initiatives like iMagination Week, which encourages students to imagine the future, are valuable examples of this approach.

site_title: Comedian Stephen Colbert to host Emmys
summary: Stephen Colbert will host the 69th Primetime Emmy Awards on September 17 at the Microsoft Theatre in Los Angeles. Colbert, a late-night talk show host, praised the Emmys as the largest audience to witness an awards show, referencing comments made by White House press secretary Sean Spicer. This marks Colbert's second time hosting the Emmys, following his hosting debut in 2015. The nominations will be announced on July 13.

images.alt_text: Late night talk show host Stephen Colbert will host the 69th Primetime Emmy Awards in September, organisers announced on Monday.

site_title: From jingles to pop hits, AI is music to some ears
summary: A UK-based startup, Jukedeck, is utilizing AI to create background music for various applications, showcasing the technology's ability to produce simple yet effective melodies. The company's AI system can learn from existing songs and adapt to different styles, as demonstrated by Patrick Stobbs during a demonstration. This development highlights the growing potential of AI in music creation and its applications beyond entertainment.

site_title: Chih Bing intends to stay in the pro game
summary: Chih Bing expressed his intention to continue playing professional golf despite missing the cut at the Singapore Open. In a notable moment, he sank a putt on the 18th hole, but ultimately missed the par on the tricky downhill putt. The article does not provide further details on his performance or future plans.

site_title: White House warns China on trade, South China Sea
summary: The White House warned China on Monday that the US will defend "international interests" in the South China Sea and advocate for a "two-way street" in trade. Press secretary Sean Spicer defended the administration's stance, following comments by Secretary of State nominee Rex Tillerson, who suggested preventing China from building islands in disputed waters. The US is expected to take a firmer stance on trade with China, amid concerns over the South China Sea and the US-China relationship.

site_title: Bankers worry post-Brexit transition won't be long enough
summary: Global bankers express concern over the post-Brexit transition period, which they believe will be insufficient at 1-2 years. Brexit Secretary David Davis's estimate has disappointed financial professionals, who are already accelerating plans to adjust to changing trade and regulations. Despite Prime Minister Theresa May's promise of a transitional phase, bankers worry that the time frame will not be enough to prepare for the changes. This raises questions about the impact on London's financial sector and the city's ability to adapt to the new regulatory environment.

site_title: SEC probing Yahoo over previously disclosed cyber breach
summary: The US Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) is investigating whether Yahoo disclosed two massive data breaches, one in 2014 and another in August 2013, to investors sooner, potentially violating civil securities laws. The breaches exposed the email credentials of half a billion and over a billion user accounts, respectively. The SEC's probe follows previous disclosures by Yahoo, which has faced pointed questions about when it knew about the cyber attacks. Other agencies, including the Federal Trade Commission and State Attorneys General, are also looking into the breaches.

site_title: Trump and Tillerson set US and China on collision course
summary: US President Donald Trump's "America First" policy has raised concerns about a potential trade war with China. Trump's choice of economic advisers suggests he may act aggressively against Beijing. The US has a history of supporting Taiwan, which Trump congratulated Taiwan's President Tsai Ing-wen on after his election victory, directly challenging the "One China" policy. This move has sparked diplomatic shockwaves, potentially leading to an armed confrontation in the South China Sea if neither side backs down. The situation is set to escalate further with an EU-China summit later this month.

site_title: Opec and friends agree on how to monitor cuts
summary: OPEC and its allies have agreed on a method to monitor their compliance with the historic supply deal, which has resulted in a 1.5 million barrel daily cut since January 1. This move puts global markets on track to rebalance after two years of oversupply. The countries have already met 80% of their collective target, with Saudi Arabia's Minister of Energy and Industry Khalid Al-Falih stating that the deal is on track. The agreement aims to stabilize oil prices and balance global markets.

site_title: Dubai Duty Free cuts prices as post-Brexit pound hits sales
summary: Dubai Duty Free has cut prices in response to the post-Brexit pound's impact on airport sales, aiming to boost revenue by 5% this year. The retailer, which operates at Dubai International Airport, posted a 3% drop in sales to $1.85 billion in 2016 due to the weaker pound. The company expects revenue growth driven by Chinese travellers, who account for 9% of total spending. This is attributed to the dirham being pegged to the dollar, making travel more expensive for European visitors.

site_title: Wanda's driving too fast down boulevard of broken dreams
summary: Chinese billionaire Wang Jianlin's Dalian Wanda Group faces challenges in its Hollywood ventures, including a failed bid to buy Paramount Pictures. Instead, Shanghai Film Group and Huahua Media formed a deal with Viacom's Paramount, providing the studio with funding and increased access to China's massive market. Wanda's diversification efforts focus on real estate and e-commerce, with its hospitality and shopping mall businesses performing well. Analysts forecast Wanda's real-estate business to become the world's top landlord by rent collection.

site_title: China stocks at their most subdued since 1992 as state tightens grip
summary: China's stock market has reached its most subdued state since 1992 due to government efforts to maintain stability and tighten liquidity. The Shanghai Composite Index fell to a 24-year low at the end of December and has remained relatively stable since. State-owned investors have been buying shares to steady the market, while some funds have been guided not to sell holdings in benchmark indexes. The market slump follows extreme intervention by policymakers in 2015 to stabilize the market amid a US$5 trillion rout.

site_title: Banyan Tree to form JV with property developer China Vanke
summary: Banyan Tree Holdings is forming a joint venture with China Vanke to develop and manage hospitality, senior living, and wellness projects in China. The venture, Banyan Tree China, will have an initial paid-up capital of up to $414 million and be controlled 50:50 by Banyan Tree and Vanke. Vanke will take a 5% equity stake in Banyan Tree and receive an option to further purchase shares, while Banyan Tree will own 40% of its hotel management company in China.

site_title: India's Paytm to launch banking operations within two months
summary: Paytm, an Indian digital payments provider backed by Alibaba Group, plans to launch its banking operations within two months, aiming to reach 200 million customers within a year. The company aims to sign up over a third of India's 1.3 billion population and eventually reach 500 million users. Paytm's payments bank will offer account holders returns on deposits and financial products, bolstering its digital wallet services. The move is part of India's government push to give more citizens access to financial services, with the Reserve Bank of India approving 11 applicants to set up payments banks.

site_title: How AI levels the playing field for SMEs
summary: Small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) can level the playing field with artificial intelligence (AI) solutions, despite resource constraints. AI can translate customer engagement data into actionable strategies, providing personalized customer experiences. AI-powered chatbots can analyze customer data, provide recommendations, and schedule private home tours. Predictive services using deep learning and natural language processing can help businesses anticipate and fulfill customer needs, leading to increased customer retention and growth. By leveraging AI, SMEs can overcome resource constraints and compete with larger companies.

site_title: Frasers Commercial Trust Q1 DPU stable at 2.51 cents
summary: Frasers Commercial Trust (FCOT) reported stable distribution per unit (DPU) of 2.51 cents for its fiscal Q1 2017, unchanged from the previous year. The Reit manager attributed this stability to the acquisition of 357 Collins Street in Melbourne, which has full occupancy and no leases expiring until fiscal 2018. FCOT announced a S$45 million makeover for Alexandra Technopark, set to commence in mid-2017, to create a new campus environment with community-friendly spaces and amenities.

site_title: Chew's Group makes U-turn on plan to allow dual-class shares
summary: Singapore's Chew's Group has made a U-turn on its plan to issue dual-class shares (DCS), a move that appears to have been premature. The Companies Act has been amended to allow such shares, but the Singapore Exchange (SGX) has reminded the company that the scheme has not been approved for listed firms. The SGX may hold a public consultation on the matter soon, and publicly listed companies in Singapore are still awaiting clearance to issue DCS.

images.alt_text: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) has stepped in with a reminder that dual-class shares (DCS) have not been given the greenlight, and that a public consultation on the subject may be held soon.

site_title: After success of women's march, a question remains: what's next?
summary: Over one million people participated in women's marches across the US, following the success of the women's march in January 2017, which protested the Trump presidency. The event demonstrated a strong display of dissent, but the question remains: what happens next? The marches have put pressure on the Trump administration to address issues such as reproductive rights and equal pay, but it is unclear whether these demands will lead to tangible political change.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: UOL Group has secured an option to purchase a 69,858-sq-ft freehold site at 45 Amber Road for S$156 million. The site has a plot ratio of 2.0 and is being sold by Sin Lian Huat Co.

site_title: Oscars promises more diversity this year
summary: The Oscars is expected to unveil its nominees on January 24, addressing the #OscarsSoWhite controversy with a more diverse lineup. La La Land, Moonlight, and Manchester by the Sea are frontrunners for Best Picture, while Damien Chazelle's film is predicted to win several awards. Isabelle Huppert is expected to be a strong contender for Best Actress after her Golden Globe win, and industry pundits say she could become one of the rare actresses to win for a foreign language performance.

site_title: LME's pitch for share of gold market faces bumpy ride
summary: The London Metal Exchange (LME) is facing skepticism from market participants over its new suite of gold contracts, citing concerns over inflexibility, rising costs, and restrictive specifications. Despite partnering with several major banks and gold trading firms, the LME is struggling to gain a share of the market, with Shanghai and New York offering well-established and liquid gold futures. Industry experts expect most volume on the new contracts to come from hedging between banks and brokers, but critics argue the contracts are designed for finance professionals rather than physical traders.

images.alt_text: LME says its contracts, which include spot, futures and options, would bring price-setting out of the back rooms of banks by creating a published forward pricing curve for gold and sliver.

site_title: Samsung pins Note 7 fires on batteries and may delay new phone launch
summary: Samsung Electronics Co Ltd has pinned the cause of fires in its Note 7 devices to faulty batteries from two suppliers, and vowed to enhance product safety following a lengthy investigation. The company has accepted responsibility for asking suppliers to meet certain specifications and will implement an eight-point battery check system to prevent future issues. The Galaxy S8, Samsung's first premium handset since the Note 7, is expected to be launched this year, but its unveiling at the Mobile World Congress has been delayed. The company's reputation took a hit after the Note 7 was withdrawn from sale in October, and it must regain consumer trust.

site_title: Town councils 'must plan finances for HDB infrastructure upgrading'
summary: The Ministry of National Development (MND) in Singapore has urged town councils to plan ahead for HDB estate infrastructure upgrades, ensuring sustainable finances and setting aside 14% of service and conservancy charges for a new lift replacement fund. This comes as HDB's S$450 million lift enhancement programme aims to retrofit 20,000 lifts with safety features by 2026. The move is expected to help town councils prepare for major expenses, including repainting and maintenance.

site_title: Malaysia arrests 4 linked to Islamic State cell in the Philippines
summary: Malaysian police have arrested four individuals, including three foreigners, linked to an Islamic State cell in the southern Philippines. The arrests follow heightened security concerns in Malaysia since the January attack by Islamic State militants in Jakarta, Indonesia. The arrests bring to light the growing threat of terrorism in the region, with Malaysia maintaining a high alert status.

site_title: Still easy to land a job in S'pore; but skill mismatch a big hurdle
summary: Singapore's job market remains tight, with the median period of unemployment for job-seekers at 8 weeks, less than half that of Australia's. Despite potential job cuts, 98% of workers aged 62 were offered re-employment, and the government is focusing on addressing skill mismatches. Experts warn that the issue is not the lack of work, but rather workers' lack of relevant skills. The unemployment rate for Singapore citizens and permanent residents may climb above 3% for the first time since 2010, according to upcoming data.

site_title: Good times seen coming to an end for China's real estate bonds
summary: China's real estate bonds face a correction due to rising yields and regulatory measures to curb a property market bubble. The US$65 billion market for dollar-denominated notes sold by Chinese builders has attracted yield-starved fund managers, but a near-record low yield premium may not cover credit risks. Regulators have taken steps to restrict property sales and increase down-payment requirements, leading to a potential "substantial decline" in property sales volume this year. Some investors believe the government will maintain controls on property bond financing, while others expect yield premiums to widen, potentially leading to liquidity problems for smaller developers.

site_title: New cluster makes 3D printing more accessible
summary: A national cluster, the National Additive Manufacturing Innovation Cluster (Namic), has been set up in Singapore to encourage the growth of the additive manufacturing industry. Companies can team up with local universities to reduce costs and tap into researchers' expertise. 3D printing technology is now considered an essential tool to raise manufacturing productivity, according to Ministry of Trade and Industry officials. The cluster aims to make 3D printing more accessible to businesses, promoting innovation and collaboration between industry and academia.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Singapore Medical Group (SMG) is set for high growth due to its robust expansion of seven key specialities, driven by the new CEO and Tony Tan's efforts to turnaround the company. Analysts forecast a 7% increase in earnings per share and target price of S$0.59. Frasers Centrepoint Trust is expected to see interest pick up after the completion of Northpoint's asset enhancement initiative, with a potential 8% increase in target price. CapitaLand Mall Trust's DPU growth is forecast to remain flat, but its gearing is expected to increase to 38% following the redevelopment of Funan.

site_title: Aussie govt to probe employers seeking to unwind wage deals
summary: The Australian government plans to investigate employers who are terminating or threatening to terminate wage agreements, potentially leading to minimum industry pay. Several companies, including Lanco Infratech, AGL, and Aurizon, have used this tactic to renegotiate pay and conditions. Labour Senator Gavin Marshall is chairing the parliamentary committee, which will examine whether this practice breaks industrial relations rules. The move comes amid slow wage growth in Australia, with wages growing at their slowest pace on record.

site_title: Time will tell if Trump will become more centrist
summary: US President Donald Trump's inaugural address was marked by a fiery and defiant tone, describing America as a nation wrecked by crime and poverty, and promising to challenge the power structure in Washington. Despite his populist and nationalist rhetoric, Trump's speech did not reveal a clear "America First" strategy, instead hinting at a restructure of institutions and alliances to better serve US interests. Trump has pledged to protect the "forgotten men and women" and break with the globalist agenda, but has not specified how he plans to achieve this. The future direction of US foreign policy remains uncertain.

site_title: IHC board removed after heated EGM
summary: The International Healthway Corp (IHC) board was removed after a heated Extraordinary General Meeting (EGM) on January 23, 2017. Shareholders, nominated by Oxley Holdings' Eric Low and his sister Audrey Low, voted to remove the four board directors and appointed three new ones. The move strengthens the duo's reputation as shareholder activists. Oxley Holdings' Ching Chiat Kwong also holds a significant stake in IHC, and the company's deputy CEO, Eric Low, will retain some influence over the board's direction.

site_title: Lower capital distribution, bigger unit base dent Cache Logistics Trust's Q4 DPU
summary: Cache Logistics Trust's Q4 distribution per unit (DPU) declined 10.8% year-on-year to 1.85 Singapore cents due to a lower capital distribution and an enlarged unit base. Despite this, net property income grew 11.3% to S$21.3 million, and revenue climbed 13.5% to S$27.3 million. For the full year, DPU fell 9.1% to 7.725 cents, but net property income rose 15.6% to S$88 million. The Reit's portfolio remains healthy with a weighted average lease to expiry of 3.9 years and a committed occupancy rate of 96.4%.

site_title: Will Alibaba's million-job boast boost employment and sales?
summary: Alibaba aims to create 1 million US jobs by linking small businesses with Chinese online buyers, but critics question the feasibility of this goal. The company has already expanded its online presence in the US, with 650,000 registered companies and over 7,000 brands. However, concerns over marketing costs, intellectual property theft, and logistical challenges may hinder the success of this initiative. Despite these obstacles, Alibaba believes its services, including Taobao Partners and Cainiao Smart Logistics Network, can help US businesses overcome these hurdles.

site_title: From shy young man to private equity titan
summary:
Here's a 100-word summary of the article content:

David Rubenstein's rise to becoming one of the richest men in the world is a story of hard work and smart choices. Born in 1949 in Baltimore, Rubenstein attended Duke University and The University of Chicago Law School, both of which offered him full scholarships. He went on to build a successful career in private equity, becoming a titan in the industry. The article does not provide further details on his personal story or achievements.

site_title: Keppel DC Q4 DPU lower on bigger unit base
summary: Keppel DC Reit reported a 2% year-on-year increase in distributable income to S$14.77 million for its Q4 2016, with a 20.1% decline in distribution per unit (DPU) to 1.31 Singapore cents. The Reit's full-year distributable income rose 6.3% to S$61.05 million, surpassing its IPO forecast of S$58.71 million. This was driven by a one-off net property tax refund, contributions from Intellicentre 2, and lower expenses. The Reit's portfolio expanded with acquisitions in Milan and Cardiff.

site_title: 'India deserves a ratings upgrade,' Aberdeen calls
summary: Aberdeen Asset Management has called for India to receive a ratings upgrade, citing the country's improving economic outlook. Despite being rated lower than Spain and Italy, Aberdeen believes India's transition to a growing economy, coupled with reforms such as tax and bankruptcy laws, warrant a higher rating. The firm's US$7.7 billion Emerging Market Fund has returned 27% to investors, beating peers, and is overweight on India. Moody's Investors Service has expressed skepticism, however, citing concerns over the government's debt burden, before considering an upgrade.

site_title: As couture shows open, Paris steps up with message: The City of Light is safe
summary: Paris has introduced stringent security measures at the start of the January couture shows, forcing attendees to open their handbags, remove furs, and undergo full-body wand checks at nearly every event. This move aims to reassure the City of Light is safe following recent concerns. The new security measures will apply to some of the wealthiest women in the world attending the shows. The measures are part of a broader effort to maintain safety and security in the city.

images.alt_text: In November, Bollywood actress Mallika Sherawat and her French partner were tear-gassed by three masked assailants in a botched robbery.

site_title: Former NSA hacker steps into investment space
summary: Former NSA hacker Ron Gula has transitioned into the investment space. Gula, who joined the NSA in the mid-1990s as a penetration tester, utilized his skills to identify vulnerabilities in government servers. After leaving the NSA, he has leveraged his expertise to invest in various companies, including those in the technology and edtech sectors. Gula's experience in identifying security risks has likely informed his investment decisions, allowing him to capitalize on emerging trends in the industry. His background in cybersecurity continues to influence his investment strategy.

site_title: Former VW chief holds firm during grilling on emissions deception
summary: Former Volkswagen CEO Martin Winterkorn denied being aware of the company's diesel-emissions deception during a grilling by German lawmakers on January 19. He claimed he had not heard the term "defeat device" until September 2015, when the scandal broke. Winterkorn, who resigned over the case, maintained he had not been aware of any wrongdoing, as he has previously stated. The hearing was his first public appearance since his resignation, but he yielded no ground to lawmakers' questions.

site_title: Stocks up after inauguration, oil comments
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index rose 14.4 points to 3,025.48, driven by banks Jardine Matheson and Keppel Corp, following a higher close on Wall Street after US President Donald Trump's inauguration. The local blue-chip index also benefited from Saudi Arabia's oil minister's statement on Opec's crude output compliance. Trading volume was decent, with the week set to feature corporate earnings releases, including Reit and business trust results.

site_title: Chinese banks told to issue more offshore US dollar bonds
summary: China's central bank has encouraged banks to issue more offshore US dollar bonds amid declining foreign reserves, which fell nearly $320 billion last year. The move aims to curb renminbi depreciation by keeping US dollar outflows within the Chinese financial system. Banks will lend the proceeds to corporate clients, offering Chinese investors an alternative to buying foreign securities. The PBOC's guidance follows a 6.6% drop in the renminbi against the US dollar in 2016, and is expected to boost the supply of offshore US dollar bonds this year.

images.alt_text: While the PBOC (above) has not explained its reasons, market participants think it aims to curb renminbi depreciation by keeping US dollar outflows within the Chinese financial system.

site_title: Head of the class with technology
summary: Mind Stretcher, a homegrown tuition chain, has transformed from a small basement operation 15 years ago to a high-tech learning center with state-of-the-art facilities, including large touchscreens, science labs, and seminar rooms. Founder Kristie Lim has invested in technology to enhance the learning experience. Initially, the center operated from six cubicles of toilets, but Lim's marketing efforts helped the business grow from ground zero. Today, Mind Stretcher is a leading education provider, offering a unique and innovative learning environment for students.

site_title: Lendlease adopts WELL building certification at Paya Lebar Quarter
summary: Lendlease's Paya Lebar Quarter in Singapore has become the first in the country to register for the WELL Core and Shell Certification, covering nearly one million square feet of Grade-A workspaces. The WELL Building Standard focuses on increasing occupants' well-being and productivity, featuring green public spaces, enhanced air filtration, and natural daylight. Registration aligns with Lendlease's mission to create a healthier workforce and community, with the potential to improve productivity and reduce absenteeism.

site_title: Outsiders told not to use Asean as 'proxy' for rivalry
summary: The Philippines has urged countries outside South-east Asia not to use the region as a "proxy for their rivalry", particularly in the South China Sea disputes. Philippines Defence Minister Delfin Lorenzana made the call at a security conference in Singapore, where Asean is drawing up a code of conduct to resolve territorial disputes. China has built artificial islands in the exclusive economic zone of the Philippines, and the country is seeking a rules-based solution to the issue, which affects $5 trillion in trade. Asean aims to preserve unity and establish a mechanism to resolve disputes.

site_title: Britain opens bidding for £2.75b high speed train contract
summary: Britain has opened bidding for a £2.75 billion contract to build a fleet of high-speed trains for the HS2 project, set to link London with the north of England. The contract, expected to be awarded in 2019, will cover up to 60 trains that can seat over 1,000 passengers and travel at 225 miles per hour. Construction is due to begin this spring, creating 25,000 jobs and stimulating Britain's economy. The project, Europe's largest infrastructure project, aims to open in phases, with the first phase set to open in 2026.

site_title: Japan threatens India with WTO over steel amid trade fears
summary: Japan is threatening to take India to the World Trade Organization (WTO) over restrictions that nearly halved its steel exports to the South Asian nation. The restrictions, imposed in 2015 and 2016, led to a significant drop in Japan's steel exports to India. Japan is concerned that the move is inconsistent with WTO rules and is also worried about the impact of US President Donald Trump's trade policies. If consultations fail, Japan may ask a WTO panel to adjudicate the dispute, which could escalate global trade tensions.

images.alt_text: Japan is threatening to take India to the World Trade Organization (WTO) over restrictions that nearly halved its steel exports to the South Asian nation over the past year, a step that could trigger more trade spats as global tensions over steel and other commodities run high.

site_title: Unease over Trump sends US$ to 1-1/2 month low
summary: US dollar falls to 1-1/2 month low after President Donald Trump's protectionist tone in his inauguration speech, which included plans to benefit American workers and families, and potential renegotiation of trade agreements. The dollar index dropped half a percent to 100.28, while the yen and euro also fell. Sterling rose to a five-week high as investors await a UK Supreme Court ruling on Brexit. The dollar's decline follows a 4.2% gain since Trump's election in November, with a 2.5% loss since then.

site_title: Costs outpace the benefits of Modi's 'shock therapy' cash crunch
summary: India's Prime Minister Narendra Modi's "shock therapy" cash crunch policy has led to a nationwide commotion and economic fallout. Despite initial hopes of eliminating black money and boosting digitization, the costs of demonetization have outweighed the benefits, with a dramatic drop in business activity and rising layoffs reported. The government's growth forecast for FY2016/17 has been revised downward, and the implementation of key policies, including the goods and service tax, may be delayed due to opposition protests. The ruling party's popularity may suffer in upcoming state elections if the black money issue persists.

site_title: Colombian builder, 27, hopes to build Trump hotel one day
summary: A young Colombian builder, Nicolas Jimenez, 27, is pursuing a $350 million plan to build the Trump International Hotel and Tower Bogota with US investors Yun Capital. Despite lacking credentials, Jimenez has secured meetings with Bogota bankers and property owners, citing Trump's business books as inspiration. The project, which would be one of the tallest in Latin America, is expected to take years to complete, with Jimenez and his partners waiting for the Trump name to become available. Yun Capital's Jung Yun has expressed interest in developing the project, but the company's involvement remains uncertain.

site_title: Anti-globalisation champion Le Pen threatens eurozone future
summary: Marine Le Pen, leader of France's National Front party, has threatened to take France out of the eurozone, NATO, and the European Union if she wins the presidential election. Her far-right populist campaign has gained momentum, and she leads the latest polls, with a realistic shot at victory. The election in France is key, as it could have significant international implications and change the political complexion of the continent. The outcome will also be closely watched in Germany and the Netherlands, where anti-establishment forces are gaining ground.

site_title: Retailers use quiz to help customers choose the right scent
summary: Retailers are testing a new method to help customers choose fragrances, developed by Pinrose, a San Francisco-based startup. The method involves a quiz that uses technology and psychology to recommend scents based on a customer's personality, preferences, and emotional responses. The quiz, which has been taken by over 300,000 people, asks questions such as color and shape preferences to narrow down scent options. Sephora and Nordstrom are currently testing the quiz in their stores, and retailers believe it can be a more effective way to engage customers and increase sales.

site_title: Between 'fake news' and 'alternative facts', where would the truth stand?
summary: US President Donald Trump assumed responsibility for the country's credibility upon taking office, citing its importance to global standing and "American exceptionalism." The administration's irreverence towards fact could damage credibility, contradicting the US's sentimental reverence for truth and press freedoms. The country's credibility is seen as a vital asset, comparable to its military strength and currency reliability.

site_title: Retail malaise puts pressure on US chains to shutter more stores
summary: US retailers face pressure to close stores due to slowing mall traffic and increasing online sales. Over 10% of US retail space (nearly 1 billion sq ft) may need to be closed or converted, building on 5,000 stores shuttered in the past 18 months. This shift is driven by consumers making more purchases online, with mall traffic slowing.

images.alt_text: Macy's reported disappointing sales in the holiday period, and the company announced a plan to slash 6,200 jobs. It previously said it would close 100 stores, with 68 of those shutting down this year. That move will eliminate an additional 4,000 jobs.

site_title: At current high valuations, Carlyle is 'trying to sell a lot'
summary: David Rubenstein, co-founder and co-CEO of The Carlyle Group, is racing against time to give away his wealth as he ages. The firm is exiting investments while stock prices remain high, with Rubenstein citing historically high earnings multiples. Despite this, he believes valuations will come down when interest rates rise and the stock market corrects, and that a 15% net internal rate of return is still achievable for clients. With over $1 trillion in unspent cash in the industry, Rubenstein sees opportunities in areas like energy, tech, and healthcare, and rates China as a top opportunity in Asia.

site_title: Abe voices 'trust' in Trump, vows to defend TPP
summary: Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe expressed trust in US President Donald Trump, saying he understands the importance of free trade. Abe vowed to continue pressuring Trump to ratify the 12-nation Trans-Pacific Partnership (TPP) agreement. This contrasts with other international figures' critical assessments of Trump. Abe's comments come as the US president is expected to pursue the strategic and economic importance of the TPP.

site_title: S Korea's acting president urges swift deployment of THAAD
summary: South Korea's acting president urged the swift deployment of the US THAAD anti-missile system to counter North Korea's accelerating nuclear and missile capabilities. This move has been opposed by China, which fears it will undermine its own ballistic capabilities. The deployment agreement was made last year following North Korea's string of nuclear and missile tests. The president's statement comes as North Korea's nuclear and missile capabilities continue to accelerate, prompting concerns about regional security.

site_title: Trump set to sign executive orders to quit TPP, renegotiate Nafta: official
summary: US President Donald Trump is set to sign executive orders withdrawing the US from the Trans-Pacific Partnership (TPP) trade deal and renegotiating the North American Free Trade Agreement (Nafta), according to an official familiar with the plans. Trump campaigned against the TPP and Nafta, promising to rewrite America's trade policy. The moves fulfill a campaign promise and aim to improve trade conditions for the US and prevent companies from shipping American jobs abroad. Trump's renegotiation of Nafta is expected to begin with meetings with Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau and Mexican President Enrique Pena Nieto.

site_title: China orders more than 100 golf courses shut
summary: China has ordered the closure of 111 out of 683 golf courses nationwide, a sixth of the country's golf courses since 2011. The National Development and Reform Commission cited violations such as using arable land and groundwater extraction. The crackdown aims to curb the sport's association with wealthy elites and corruption. Golf courses in all provinces except Tibet have been affected, with 18 courses ordered to return illegally occupied land and 47 to stop construction. The move follows a 2011 crackdown and a 2015 ban on Communist Party members joining golf clubs.

site_title: ASL Marine's action on notes a good start to O&M debt revamp
summary: ASL Marine secured overwhelming support for restructuring its $150 million medium-term notes, with 98.7% and 100% of votes cast in favor of extending the redemption dates by three years. The move is seen as a positive sign for debt restructuring in the offshore and marine sector, with increasing oil prices fueling hope for industry fundamentals to improve. ASL Marine has also explored diversification opportunities in offshore wind and port infrastructure developments, and its management has clarified that the business plan is premised on further diversification beyond oil-linked segments.

images.alt_text: The year of 2017 seems to be off to a good start for debt restructuring in the beleaguered offshore and marine (O&M) sector with ASL Marine securing overwhelming support for the restructuring of its two medium term notes totalling S$150 million.

site_title: Why the ugly truth sells better for some travel ads
summary: Travel companies are tapping into the current contentious political climate by acknowledging that travel can be cramped, hectic, or disappointing in their ads. This approach, seen in Westin Hotels & Resorts' campaign, builds on the brand's wellness image and has gained traction. Similar campaigns by Hilton Hotels & Resorts and HomeAway feature travelers in unpleasant situations, teasing traditional hotels and rival services. Acknowledging negativity can make a brand seem more credible, but negative ads must be used with a light touch to avoid backfiring.

site_title: Japan Air Commuter takes delivery of first ATR, hopes to woo foreign tourists
summary: Japan Air Commuter has taken delivery of its first European ATR turbo-prop airplane, aiming to attract foreign tourists to Japan's lesser-visited Amami and Ryukyu islands. This marks a breakthrough for ATR in Japan's national market, previously dominated by North American suppliers. The delivery is seen as a strategic move for Japan to place the islands on UNESCO's World Heritage list, boosting the country's tourism industry.

site_title: Historian's new Mao book turns acclaim to censure
summary: Historian Yang Jisheng has released a 1,151-page book, "The World Turned Upside Down", detailing the Cultural Revolution, a highly anticipated and potentially contentious history of the era. Yang's previous book, "Tombstone", examined the famine caused by Mao's policies. China's censors had previously silenced Yang, but he has now broken his silence, sparking a war over remembering or forgetting China's dark past under Xi Jinping. The book is expected to contribute to the ongoing struggle over China's Communist past.

site_title: Modi expected to cut taxes in Feb 1 budget
summary: Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi is expected to cut taxes in the February 1 budget to boost consumption, but this move risks losing short-term revenue. The government has seen a 25% increase in indirect taxes, mainly from excise collections, but this growth may be unsustainable due to rising oil prices. A cut in personal income tax slabs or rates is also being considered to give consumers higher purchasing power. However, this move may come at the cost of a short-term revenue spurt, and the government may need to roll back some excise increases to prevent inflation.

site_title: Revaluation losses pull Soilbuild Reit's Q4 DPU down by 2.7%
summary: Soilbuild Reit reported a 2.7% drop in distribution per unit (DPU) to 1.57 Singapore cents for Q4 2016, mainly due to revaluation losses of S$50.9 million. Gross revenue rose 6.1% to S$21.7 million and net property income increased 8% to S$18.9 million. Deficits in total returns before distribution for Q4 and FY 2016 were S$37.5 million and S$0.6 million, respectively. The Reit's 2016 full-year DPU fell 6.1% to 6.091 cents.

site_title: Toyota chairman says fuel-cell cars need more time to catch on
summary: Toyota Chairman Takeshi Uchiyamada stated that fuel-cell vehicles will take longer to gain popularity due to the need for infrastructure development, unlike hybrid cars. Toyota plans to increase fuel-cell vehicle sales 10-fold by 2020, while also investing $10 billion in the US over the next five years. The company's fuel-cell vehicles are a key part of its plan to reduce carbon dioxide emissions to 90% by 2050. Uchiyamada also expressed confidence in the US market, despite President Trump's criticism of the company's plans to build a Mexico factory, saying Toyota is willing to spend more in the US if it means growth.

site_title: The Trump formula will lead to America's decline
summary: US President Donald Trump's "America First" policy, as outlined in his inaugural address, is expected to lead to America's decline in power and prestige. By prioritizing US interests over global stability, Trump's approach will likely result in other countries acting more aggressively in their own selfish interests, disintegrating post-World War II alliances. This could have severe consequences for the global order, potentially destabilizing international relations and undermining US influence. Trump's policy shift marks a significant departure from previous US foreign policy approaches.

site_title: South Korean ministry apologises for 'blacklist' of artists
summary: South Korea's culture ministry apologized for a blacklist of artists, excluding them from government support, as part of a systematic effort to sideline critics of President Park Geun-hye. The blacklist led to the arrests of her former chief of staff and the culture minister for abuse of power. The apology marks a clear admission of the blacklist, which targeted cultural and media figures critical of the impeached leader. The move is seen as a significant development in the country's ongoing efforts to address allegations of corruption and abuse of power.

site_title: Rig operator's move sparks rush for the exit
summary: UMW Oil & Gas Corporation, a Malaysian drill rig operator, saw its shares plummet to a new low of 68 sen amid investor concerns over steep premiums in its proposed acquisition of Icon Offshore Bhd and Orkim Sdn Bhd. Analysts questioned the deal's value, citing a "sticky point" in valuations and limited operational synergies. The proposed consolidation, which would see UMWOG exit the oil and gas business, has sparked a rush to exit, with investors querying the steep premium accorded to the two companies.

site_title: United resumes domestic flights after resolving computer glitch
summary: United Continental Holdings Inc resumed domestic flights after resolving a computer glitch that caused disruptions on Sunday. The halt occurred at 5:30 pm in Chicago and was resolved by 8:00 pm. The issue resulted in 481 flight delays, the most of any US carrier, according to FlightAware.com. The glitch occurred during a year marked by computer failures at US airlines, stranding thousands of passengers. United serves over 200 domestic airports and has about 4,500 departures globally.

site_title: Investors jump in as oil rebounds
summary: Hedge funds have increased their net-long position on West Texas Intermediate crude prices to a record, betting on rising prices as Opec and non-Opec producers reduce output. The increase in bets reached 14% in the week ended Jan 17, with prices rising 3.3% to $52.48 a barrel. Opec's production fell by 220,900 barrels a day in December, but still leaves output 1.8 million barrels a day higher than the target. This has led money managers to buy oil, with US oil companies hedging their price risk for the next two years.

site_title: Mapletree Logistics posts steady Q3 DPU, higher revenue
summary: Mapletree Logistics Trust reported a steady distribution per unit (DPU) of 1.87 Singapore cents for its third quarter, driven by a 7.4% increase in gross revenue to S$95.5 million. The higher revenue was attributed to four recent acquisitions in Australia, Malaysia, and Vietnam, as well as redevelopment projects in Singapore and Japan. The trust's steady performance is a positive sign for the company.

site_title: McDonald's deal gives 'more flexibility'
summary: McDonald's has secured a majority stake in its China and Hong Kong markets through a deal with The Carlyle Group and state-backed Citic. This partnership is expected to bring more flexibility to the fast food giant, allowing for local menu changes and more incentives for managers. Carlyle co-founder David Rubenstein hinted at implementing different food sourcing methods and local innovations, potentially giving McDonald's a competitive edge in the Chinese and Hong Kong markets. The deal aims to enhance the company's operations in these regions.

site_title: AirAsia denies role in Rolls-Royce corruption scandal
summary: Malaysia-based AirAsia denied involvement in the Rolls-Royce corruption scandal, which allegedly paid millions of dollars in bribes to win contracts in several countries. The Serious Fraud Office (SFO) found Rolls-Royce paid bribes to an AirAsia executive in exchange for favors in purchasing products and services. AirAsia stated it had obtained necessary approval and done nothing wrong in purchasing a private jet, and had no dealings or transactions with Rolls-Royce. The airline's CEO was not named as a suspect in the scandal.

site_title: Anti-speculation property measures have their side effects
summary: Singapore's qualifying certificate (QC) and additional buyer's stamp duty (ABSD) measures aim to curb property speculation, but some developers have found ways to sidestep penalties, including creative financial engineering and delisting. To avoid 8% to 24% extension charges, developers are selling units at discounted prices or injecting properties into private-fund platforms. These tactics may harm the wider economy, and experts suggest studying the side effects of these policies to determine if they need to be addressed.

site_title: Investors gird for impact of Trump healthcare measures
summary: US President Donald Trump signed an executive order that could scale back enforcement of some Obamacare provisions, potentially increasing the number of uninsured individuals and putting pressure on hospitals and Medicaid providers. The order may delay or waive the individual mandate, which could negatively impact insurance stocks and shares of hospitals and Medicaid providers, but some analysts believe it won't significantly affect health insurance stocks. The move could also lead to an increase in unpaid medical expenses for hospitals.

site_title: Blackstone to launch Asia real estate fund with target of at least US$5b: sources
summary: Blackstone Group LP plans to launch a new Asia-focused real estate fund with a target of at least $5 billion, betting on strong returns from property investments in China, India, South-east Asia, and Australia. The fund aims to capitalize on the region's growing urbanization and rising incomes, with global investors showing robust appetite for shopping malls, warehouses, and other property assets. The new fund, which is expected to launch in the next 12-16 months, could potentially exceed the size of Blackstone's first Asia-focused property fund, which closed in 2014.

site_title: Equation Summit unit rolls out anti-theft system at Walmart stores
summary: Equation Summit's subsidiary, Digital Safety (DiSa), has rolled out its anti-theft system, Point-of-Sale Activation (PoSA), at all 4,800 Walmart stores in the US. The system, which locks devices from manufacture to purchase, uses a unique decoder PIN to prevent theft. DiSa partnered with 12 Chinese tablet manufacturers to supply the system to Walmart, which aims to reduce retail shrinkage of $2-3 billion annually. The system is fully integrated into Walmart's systems and is expected to replace RFID tags, offering greater scalability and security.

site_title: German govt holds 2017 growth forecast at 1.4%
summary: The German government has left its 2017 economic growth forecast unchanged at 1.4% despite uncertainties surrounding US President Donald Trump's policies. This marks the third revision of the forecast, with the previous estimate being lowered from 1.5% to 1.4% in October and then to 1.3% in November. The country's economy expanded at 1.9% in 2016, driven by rising private and state spending. The forecast is set to be presented to Chancellor Angela Merkel's cabinet on Wednesday.

site_title: McDonald's earnings edge down; says turnaround on track
summary: McDonald's reported slightly lower fourth-quarter earnings, with net income of $1.2 billion and revenues of $6 billion, down 1.3% and 5% respectively. The US market saw a drop in comparable sales, while international markets, including Britain, Japan, and China, reported strong sales growth. McDonald's CEO Steve Easterbrook stated that the company's turnaround plan remains on track, with international strategy shifts paying off, including a 4.7% rise in high-growth comparable sales and an 11.1% surge in foundational markets.

site_title: French presidential candidate Fillon to meet Merkel in Berlin
summary: French presidential candidate Francois Fillon will meet German Chancellor Angela Merkel in Berlin on Monday, seeking support in the upcoming presidential election. Despite Merkel's conservative leanings, she is unlikely to give Fillon explicit backing, citing their differing views on issues like immigration and Russia. The meeting highlights the importance of the Franco-German relationship in shaping European policy, with Fillon emphasizing the need for a stronger partnership.

site_title: EU warns Britain against pre-Brexit trade talks
summary: The European Commission warned Britain against starting formal trade talks with third countries before its divorce from the EU. European Commission spokesman Margaritis Schinas stated that trade is an exclusive EU matter and negotiations can only begin after the UK leaves the EU. British Prime Minister Theresa May has already begun discussing trade with countries like India and Australia, which may be seen as a breach of EU rules. The warning comes ahead of May's visit to US President Donald Trump, where a possible trade pact may be discussed.

site_title: Starwood said to be selling London Tower project on Brexit
summary: Starwood Capital Group is in talks to sell its interest in the One Braham London tower development, valued at over £60 million, due to concerns over Brexit's impact on office space demand. The 18-storey tower, which will accommodate 3,650 workers, is currently under development in east London. The sale is part of a broader trend of uncertainty in the City of London's development plans, with over 1,900 firms reviewing their office-space requirements following the Brexit vote. The deal is ongoing and Starwood may become a lender to the development after selling its equity stake.

site_title: Canada's Trudeau, ministers to discuss Trump plans for Nafta
summary: Canada's Prime Minister Justin Trudeau will discuss US President Donald Trump's plans to renegotiate the North American Free Trade Agreement (Nafta) with his Cabinet during a two-day retreat. Trudeau's officials argue that the US is focused on trade deficits with China and Mexico, not Canada. Trump's son-in-law, Jared Kushner, is set to hold talks in Calgary, Alberta, on Tuesday. Trudeau is facing challenges at home, including probes and criticism from opposition leader Kevin O'Leary, who says Trudeau is too weak to stand up to Trump.

site_title: Shell's exploration boss Powell to step down
summary: Royal Dutch Shell's exploration head Ceri Powell will step down on February 13 after seven years in the role, marking a shift away from complex exploration projects amid the industry's downturn. Powell, a geologist, will become managing director of Brunei Shell Petroleum. Her departure follows a broad reshuffle of senior positions after the US$54 billion acquisition of BG Group in 2016. Powell's departure caps a period of sharp cutbacks in Shell's exploration budget, now less than US$2 billion a year.

images.alt_text: Royal Dutch Shell's head of exploration Ceri Powell will step down next month, capping seven years in the role marked by sharp cutbacks in the company's search for new oil and gas reserves amid the industry's deep downturn since mid-2014.

site_title: Uber wants court stamp on arbitration win as message to drivers
summary: Uber is seeking a court stamp of approval for an arbitration ruling that denied a driver's bid to be treated as an employee under California law. The arbitrator, retired judge Michael Marcus, found that the driver was correctly classified as an independent contractor. Uber hailed the decision as a defense of its business model, which could influence future litigation and deter lawsuits in other states. This comes after a federal appeals court's decision last year that most Uber drivers can be forced to resolve disputes through binding arbitration.

site_title: Trump to announce US withdrawal from TPP
summary: US President Donald Trump is set to announce the US withdrawal from the Trans-Pacific Partnership (TPP) free trade agreement, a move he had vowed to make during his presidential campaign. The agreement, signed in 2015, aimed to set trade rules for the 21st century but has not yet gone into effect. Trump's decision is seen as a response to China's rising economic influence and a campaign promise to scrap the agreement, which he labeled a "job killer" and "rape" of US interests. The move is expected to have significant implications for the global economy.

site_title: Sprint agrees to buy 33% of Jay Z's Tidal music venture
summary: Sprint Corp has agreed to buy a 33% stake in Jay Z's music streaming service Tidal for $200 million. Marcelo Claure, Sprint's CEO, will join the Tidal board, while Jay Z will continue to run the business. The deal aims to attract more customers in a market dominated by Spotify, Apple, and Pandora. Tidal has struggled to gain traction, and the partnership with Sprint follows larger wireless carriers adding streaming services to their offerings, such as AT&T's DirecTV Now and Verizon's go90 video service.

site_title: Citigroup says this time it's different for Europe profit growth
summary: Citigroup's Jonathan Stubbs forecasts a 10% increase in European profits, ending a three-year dry spell, driven by macro improvement and a weak currency. Unlike previous years, economists are increasing growth forecasts, and analysts are raising profit estimates. Only a global manufacturing contraction and oil price drop could hamper growth, with Citigroup setting a year-end target for the Stoxx Europe 600 Index at 410, implying a 13% gain in 2017, the largest annual advance since 2013.

site_title: Halliburton posts a loss as oil prices recover from slump
summary: Halliburton Co reported a 4th-quarter net loss of $149 million, or 17 US cents a share, due to a slump in oil prices. However, the company's revenue increased 19% as customers in the US and Canada boosted oil and natural gas drilling rigs. This growth is expected to continue, with explorers forecast to boost capital expenditures worldwide by 7% in 2017. Halliburton's profit was 4 US cents a share more than the 2-cent average of 39 analysts' estimates.
