images.alt_text: Halliburton Co reported a fourth-quarter loss as oil prices recover from the worst slump in a generation.

site_title: Keppel Infrastructure Trust Q4 DPU unchanged at 0.93 S cent, despite profit fall
summary: Keppel Infrastructure Trust (KIT) posted unchanged quarterly distribution per unit (DPU) of 0.93 Singapore cents despite a 11.6% fall in net profit to S$7.7 million due to time-lagged gas tariff adjustments and financial derivative losses. Revenue decreased 5.2% to S$152.2 million, and earnings per unit dropped to 0.2 Singapore cent. KIT's distribution policy allows it to pay out from retained cash and residual cash flows, unlike companies which rely on accounting profits.

site_title: Ford seen as 'canary' with record leases spurring used-car glut
summary: Ford is facing a used-car glut due to a surge in leased vehicles, with 3.36 million cars and trucks expected to be returned this year. This trend is expected to intensify, with Ford already shaving $300 million from its financial-services arm's profit forecast. Industry analyst Maryann Keller calls Ford the "canary in the coal mine," indicating a broader industry problem. The glut will likely depress prices, impacting Ford and other carmakers.

site_title: Acesian Star countersues Takenaka for S$22m over proposed Changi Airport T4 work
summary: Acesian Star, a Singaporean subcontractor, has filed a counter-claim against Takenaka Corporation, a Japanese contractor, for damages worth at least S$22 million over work on Changi Airport's Terminal 4. The claim includes S$19.2 million in variation costs, S$3.1 million in prolongation costs, and S$1.7 million in damages from the unlawful termination of the sub-contract. Acesian Star claims Takenaka breached its obligations under the sub-contract, leading to delays and additional costs.

site_title: Oil falls as signs of US output rise overshadow Opec-led cuts
summary: Oil prices fell 1% on Monday as US oil drilling activity showed signs of a strong recovery, outweighing Opec-led output cuts. Global benchmark Brent crude fell 53 cents to $54.96 a barrel, while US West Texas Intermediate crude futures fell 61 cents to $52.61 a barrel. Opec and non-Opec producers agreed to cut 1.5 million barrels per day from the market, but US production rise may offset these efforts.

site_title: Cache Logistics Trust's Q4 DPU down 10.8% to 1.85 cents
summary: Cache Logistics Trust's Q4 distribution per unit (DPU) decreased 10.8% year-over-year to 1.85 Singapore cents, primarily due to a lower capital distribution and an enlarged unit base. This marks a reversal from Q4 FY2015, when a disposal of Kim Heng warehouse boosted capital distribution.

site_title: Struggling UK steel sector needs broad govt support: MPs
summary: A UK parliamentary committee report, "Steel 2020," urges the government to implement 43 actions to revive the struggling steel industry, including cutting energy costs and ensuring British steel is used in public projects. The report highlights a 59% decline in employment in the UK steel industry since 1995 and calls for comprehensive support to prevent further job losses and plant closures. The report's findings come as Tata Steel UK, Britain's largest steel facility, is considering a merger with Thyssenkrupp.

images.alt_text: Britain's steel industry needs a comprehensive new strategy from government to boost the sector, which has struggled with red ink, plant closures and job losses in recent years, according to a report released by a parliamentary committee on Monday.

site_title: Malaysia: Stocks end the day higher
summary: Malaysian shares ended the day higher, with the Kuala Lumpur Composite Index gaining 6.42 points to 1,671.31. A total of 1.52 billion lots were traded, valued at RM1.80 billion, with losers outnumbering gainers 467 to 322.

site_title: China sentences former senior official to life term for graft
summary: China has sentenced former senior official Su Rong to life in prison for corruption, involving millions of dollars in bribes and abuse of power. Su, 66, was a vice chairman of the Chinese People's Political Consultative Conference and accepted 116 million yuan in bribes between 2002 and 2014. He also possessed over 80 million yuan of unknown provenance. The conviction marks the latest high-profile case in President Xi Jinping's crackdown on graft, but analysts argue China's lack of institutional safeguards leaves anti-graft campaigns vulnerable to political influence.

site_title: UOL plans to buy 69,858 sq ft site at 45 Amber Road for S$156m
summary: UOL Group has secured an option to purchase a 69,858 sq ft site at 45 Amber Road for S$156 million. The site, currently a horticultural and gardening retail centre, has a plot ratio of 2.0 and is within walking distance of the upcoming Marine Parade and Tanjong Katong MRT stations. The purchase is expected to be completed in the near future, with no official completion date announced.

site_title: China approves first list of green car models for subsidies this year
summary: China has released its first list of recommended green energy vehicles for subsidies this year, covering 185 car models. The move aims to promote electric and plug-in hybrid cars and reduce urban air pollution. The list includes vehicles from major Chinese automakers such as BAIC Motor and BYD Co Ltd, and includes ternary lithium-ion batteries, previously ineligible for subsidies. The government has stepped up oversight and raised technical standards, requiring previously approved models to reapply for subsidies.

site_title: Emirates airline embarks on "modest restructuring" as growth slows
summary: Emirates, the world's largest long-haul airline, is undergoing a "modest restructuring" amid slower growth and increased competition. The airline reported a 75% decline in half-year profits in January. The restructuring involves staff reassignments, with some employees promoted and others demoted. This move is part of adapting to weaker markets, overcapacity, and a stronger US dollar. A "very small number" of staff have been affected, according to a spokeswoman. The restructuring aims to improve the airline's competitiveness in the industry.

site_title: India to replace coaches on crash-hit rail network
summary: India plans to replace its aging railway coaches with high-tech German-made ones, following nearly 200 deaths in disasters on the network in the last two months. The existing fleet will be phased out by 2018-19, with German-made LHB coaches equipped with "anti-telescopic" technology set to replace them. Experts warn that new coaches alone won't solve safety issues, calling for a multi-pronged strategy to boost standards, including psychological analysis of drivers and staff training.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's inflation rose to 0.2% in December 2016, driven by a stronger pickup in private road transport costs. Consumer prices fell 0.2% in the second half of 2016 compared to the same period in 2015. Town councils must plan their finances to ensure long-term sustainability. AA Group Holdings entered a $25 million acquisition deal, while Procurri formed a joint venture with Congruity to offer maintenance and IT services. Singapore shares closed 0.5% higher on Monday, advancing 14.4 points to 3,025.48.

site_title: India's top court dismisses plea to delay annual budget
summary: India's Supreme Court dismissed a petition to delay the annual federal budget, set to be delivered by Finance Minister Arun Jaitley on Feb 1, citing concerns about potential giveaways ahead of state polls. The petition, filed by lawyer M L Sharma, aimed to delay the budget until after five regional elections, including the critical Uttar Pradesh polls. The court rejected the petition, allowing the budget to proceed as scheduled, amidst fears of budget giveaways to attract votes in the polls.

images.alt_text: India's Supreme Court on Monday rejected a petition to delay the annual federal budget, which Finance Minister Arun Jaitley is scheduled to deliver on Feb 1, dismissing concerns about potential giveaways ahead of critical state polls.

site_title: Mauritius gets new PM, opposition demands new election
summary: Mauritius' Prime Minister Sir Anerood Jugnauth handed over power to his son Pravind Jugnauth, despite opposition calls for new elections. Jugnauth, 86, resigned as PM after 50 years in politics, citing time for the youth. The opposition, led by former PM Paul Berenger, rejected Pravind's "inheritance" and vowed to organize a campaign for general elections. Mauritius, known for its political stability, faces turbulence following the handover, with residents expressing disappointment in Jugnauth's decision to step down.

site_title: Trump looks to steady ship after fraught start
summary: US President Donald Trump begins his first full week in office, signing executive orders to roll out his policy agenda. Despite a tumultuous start, Trump seeks support from lawmakers, business leaders, and unions. The White House faces criticism over Trump's inauguration crowds and the president's speech before a memorial to fallen CIA officers. Trump vows to renegotiate the North American Free Trade Agreement, roll back Obama's health care reforms, and freeze regulations. However, a federal lawsuit is filed against Trump, alleging he violates the Constitution by accepting payments from foreign governments. Trump will meet with business leaders, unions, and Congress members to discuss tax reform and healthcare laws.

images.alt_text: President Donald Trump gets down to work Monday, signing a slew of executive orders to start rolling out his policy agenda after a tumultuous start put his administration on the back foot.

site_title: Revaluation losses pull Soilbuild Reit's Q4 2016 DPU down by 2.7%
summary: Soilbuild Reit reported a 2.7% drop in distribution per unit (DPU) to 1.570 Singapore cents for Q4 2016, due to revaluation losses of S$50.9 million. Despite stronger gross revenue and net property income, the Reit experienced deficits in total returns before distribution for Q4 and FY 2016. This decline was mainly attributed to revaluation losses on investment properties, including Loyang Way, West Park, and Tuas Connection. The Reit's 2016 full-year DPU fell to 6.091 cents, a 6.1% decrease from 2015.

site_title: Singapore shares close 0.5 per cent up on Monday
summary: Singapore stocks rose 0.5% on Monday, advancing 14.4 points to 3,025.48, driven by a higher close on Wall Street following Donald Trump's inauguration. The Straits Times Index saw 2.12 billion shares worth S$973.6 million change hands, with 210 gainers and 230 losers.

site_title: Keppel DC Reit declares distribution of 2.8 cents per unit for H2 2016
summary: Keppel DC Reit has declared a distribution of 2.80 Singapore cents per unit for the second half of 2016, with a book closure date of February 1, 2017, and payments due on February 28, 2017. For the fourth quarter of 2016, the company's distribution per unit (DPU) decreased 20.1% to 1.31 Singapore cents, while distributable income rose 2% to S$14.77 million. The company's full-year DPU was down 5.7% to 6.14 Singapore cents, surpassing its 2016 IPO forecast of S$58.71 million.

images.alt_text: FOR the fourth quarter which ended on Dec 31, 2016, Keppel DC Reit's distribution per unit (DPU) was down 20.1 per cent to 1.31 Singapore cents from the 1.64 Singapore cents achieved in the year-ago quarter.

site_title: Nicholas Chua promoted at Ho Bee Land
summary: Nicholas Chua, 41, son of Ho Bee board chairman and CEO, has been promoted to group director (business development) at Ho Bee Land, a non-board appointment. The promotion was recommended by the executive directors and board chairman in recognition of his contributions to the group's business growth over the past few years. In his new role, Chua will assume higher authority and responsibility in identifying investment and development opportunities locally and overseas.

images.alt_text: NICHOLAS Chua Wee-Chern has been promoted to group director (business development) at Ho Bee Land. He was formerly associate director at the property group.

site_title: FCOT posts 2.51 cents in Q1 DPU
summary: FRASERS Commercial Trust (FCOT) reported a distribution per unit (DPU) of 2.51 cents for the fiscal first quarter ended Dec 31, 2016, unchanged from the previous year. The Reit manager cited stability and diversification in its portfolio, particularly the 357 Collins Street acquisition, as key factors. However, net property income decreased marginally by 0.6% year-over-year due to lower occupancy rates and higher marketing expenses. The CEO noted that market conditions are expected to remain challenging, prompting the Reit manager to explore ways to improve and reposition its properties.

site_title: Singapore's consumer prices fall 0.2% in H2 '16
summary: Singapore's consumer prices fell 0.2% in the second half of 2016, with lower- and middle-income households seeing deeper falls. However, stripping out imputed rentals, prices rose 0.7%. The lowest 20% and middle 60% income groups saw 0.8% and 0.3% declines, respectively, while the highest 20% group saw no change.

site_title: Quick takes: Analysts see gradual rise in Singapore inflation this year
summary: Singapore's headline inflation rose to 0.2% in December 2016, the first positive reading in over two years, driven by higher private road transport costs. This marks a gradual increase after two years of deflation. Economists expect the inflation rate to continue rising, with some predicting a potential peak by mid-2026. The slight increase in inflation is attributed to external factors, including global economic trends and trade policies.

site_title: Europe: Shares down in early trade
summary: European shares fell 0.7% in early trading, weighed down by weaker banks and a profit warning from Essentra. The company's stock dropped 12% after warning that its full-year adjusted operating profit would miss forecasts. US President Donald Trump's protectionist tone in his inauguration speech also impacted the region's equity markets.

site_title: Japan threatens India with WTO action over steel restrictions
summary: Japan is threatening to take India to the World Trade Organization (WTO) over restrictions that nearly halved its steel exports to the country, citing concerns over unfair trade actions and protection of its domestic steel industry. Japan's steel exports to India dropped to 10th-largest on its buyer list in 2016, and the country may ask for WTO adjudication if consultations fail. The move is seen as part of Japan's efforts to defend its industry in a climate of global trade friction, particularly with the incoming US President Donald Trump.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks end slightly higher
summary: Hong Kong stocks ended the day 0.06% higher, edging up 12.61 points to 22,898.52, as investors await US President Donald Trump's economic policy details. The Shanghai Composite Index rose 0.44% and the Shenzhen Composite Index gained 0.87%. Despite global market fluctuations, investors remain optimistic, with Asia's MSCI index up 0.34% for the week.

site_title: Japan finance ministry, BOJ discuss the start of Trump's tenure
summary: Top officials from Japan's finance ministry, Bank of Japan, and financial regulator met on January 23, 2017, to discuss global financial markets amid uncertainty about US President Donald Trump's impact. The meeting came after Trump's inauguration on Friday. Officials declined to comment on the discussion. The meeting's purpose and outcomes remain unclear.

site_title: China's online population reaches 731 million
summary: China's online population reached 731 million in December, a 6.2% increase from 2015, according to the China Internet Network Information Center. E-commerce drives consumer demand, with online payments reaching 475 million and consumers spending $17.8 billion on Alibaba's biggest online shopping promotion. The government is pushing an "internet plus" project to expand online technology's role in the economy, with online consumption contributing to GDP growth.

site_title: Canada's Trudeau, ministers to discuss Trump plans for Nafta
summary: Canada's Prime Minister Justin Trudeau will discuss US President Donald Trump's plans for renegotiating the North American Free Trade Agreement (Nafta) during a two-day retreat with his cabinet in Calgary. Trudeau's officials argue that Trump's concerns about large US deficits with China and Mexico do not apply to Canada. Canadian officials are concerned that the US may target Canada due to its close economic ties with the US, and the retreat aims to persuade the new administration that focusing on Canada is not a priority.

site_title: China steel, iron ore extend losses into 4th day as trading slows
summary: China's iron ore and steel futures fell for a fourth consecutive session on January 23, 2017, as trading slowed ahead of the Lunar New Year holiday. The Chinese markets will be closed for a week, with many participants already on vacation. The government's relaxation of requirements on equities futures is also contributing to the outflow of money from commodities.

site_title: Japan's home-made jet to cost 30% more as delivery delayed
summary: Japan's Mitsubishi Aircraft Corp announced the Mitsubishi Regional Jet (MRJ) will be delivered two years later than estimated, with a 30% increase in cost. The delay is due to revisions of systems and electrical configurations to meet certification requirements. Development costs have tripled to $5.3 billion. The MRJ aims to challenge Embraer and Bombardier in the market for aircraft with fewer than 100 seats, but has faced setbacks and delays. The plane's launch customer, ANA Holdings Inc, will receive the aircraft in 2020.

site_title: Sri Lanka president to probe controversial bond sale
summary: Sri Lanka's President Maithripala Sirisena ordered an investigation into alleged insider trading at the central bank related to a 2015 bond sale to a relative of the then governor. The sale has heightened tensions between Sirisena and Prime Minister Ranil Wickremesinghe. A special presidential commission will be established to probe the issue and recommend actions. This move comes after Sirisena accused Wickremesinghe of attempting to undermine his authority. The investigation is expected to shed light on the controversy and potentially impact the government's stability.

site_title: Banyan Tree forms partnership with China-based Vanke
summary: Banyan Tree Holdings is forming a joint venture, Banyan Tree China (BTC), with China-based real estate developer Vanke. The venture will consolidate Banyan Tree's branded hotels and assets in China, with an initial paid-up capital of up to 2 billion yuan (S$414 million). Banyan Tree will inject its China-owned assets into BTC, while Vanke will invest hotels it owns and future developments. The partnership aims to expand Banyan Tree's presence in China and strengthen its portfolio. Vanke will also take a 5% equity stake in Banyan Tree.

site_title: Xiaomi's Barra leaves phonemaker to return to Silicon Valley
summary: Xiaomi's international chief Hugo Barra is leaving the Chinese smartphone maker after four years to return to Silicon Valley. Barra, a former Google executive, joined Xiaomi in 2013 as its global face and oversaw the brand's rise to the top of its home market. He will depart in February, and Senior Vice President Xiang Wang will take over global operations. Barra did not elaborate on his decision, citing a desire to embark on a "new adventure" in a Facebook post.

site_title: US dollar slips as Trump takes rein, most Asia markets up
summary: The US dollar declined against most Asian currencies on Monday as Donald Trump began his presidency, with shares in most Asian markets rising despite the uncertainty. Trump's inauguration speech reiterated his "America first" stance on trade, citing decisions that would benefit American workers and families. Japan's Nikkei index fell as the dollar slipped against the yen. Despite the volatility, shares in most Asian markets, including Hong Kong, rose following a positive lead from Wall Street.

site_title: South Korea ruling party to change its name
summary: South Korea's ruling party, Saenuri, announced its intention to change its name for the second time in five years, amid the corruption scandal surrounding impeached President Park Geun Hye. The party, formed in 1997, aims to dissociate itself from the scandal and regain voter support. Most members support the name change, which is seen as a way to give the party a "new life." The party's current position in parliament has been eroded, with several lawmakers breaking away to form a new party, Bareun.

site_title: DP World creates US$3.7b investment vehicle with Caisse de dépôt
summary: DP World has partnered with Caisse de dépôt et placement du Québec to create a $3.7 billion investment vehicle focused on ports and terminals in investment-grade countries, excluding the UAE. DP World will hold 55% of the vehicle, while Caisse de dépôt will own 45%. The platform will invest mostly in existing assets but also in greenfield opportunities, with two Canadian container terminals seeded as initial investments.

images.alt_text: Dubai ports operator DP World said on Monday it was partnering with Canadian pension fund manager Caisse de dépôt et placement du Québec to create an investment vehicle worth US$3.7 billion that would invest in ports and terminals worldwide.

site_title: Australia: Shares end at 1-month low
summary: Australian shares ended at a one-month low on Monday, falling 0.8% or 43.75 points to 5,611.0. Industrials, led by Brambles Ltd's 17.6% drop, were the biggest drag on the benchmark, while healthcare stocks, particularly CSL Ltd, also fell. Financials and big four banks were the second biggest drag. New Zealand's benchmark rose 0.3%.

site_title: Supreme Court's Brexit ruling unlikely to end May's legal battles
summary: The UK Supreme Court's ruling on triggering Brexit is unlikely to end Theresa May's legal battles, with at least three more court cases pending. The decision does not settle whether the prime minister or Parliament can start the withdrawal process, and May may face legislation that can be amended by opponents. Other challenges include a Dublin court case on whether the two-year exit process can be terminated, and a lawsuit claiming the June vote did not give May the authority to pull Britain from the single market.

images.alt_text: The UK Supreme Court's ruling on Tuesday over who has the power to trigger Brexit isn't the end of the legal challenges facing Theresa May, and might not even be the end of the beginning.

site_title: China, Philippines agree to cooperate on 30 projects worth US$3.7b
summary: China and the Philippines have agreed to cooperate on 30 projects worth US$3.7 billion, focusing on poverty reduction in rural areas. Chinese Commerce Minister Gao Hucheng announced the deals during a meeting with Philippine Finance Secretary Carlos Dominguez, which was part of a two-day visit by a Philippine cabinet delegation. The agreement comes after Chinese President Xi Jinping's "pro-Filipino" policy shift, welcoming President Rodrigo Duterte's new foreign policy direction.

images.alt_text: China has agreed to cooperate with the Philippines on 30 projects worth US$3.7 billion focusing on poverty reduction, the two countries said after a meeting in Beijing on Monday.

site_title: Yuan firms, interbank rates dip but liquidity still tight
summary: China's yuan strengthened to 6.8572 per US dollar after US dollar slipped following Donald Trump's "America first" policies, which disappointed investors seeking growth and tax cuts. Interbank rates dipped, but remained elevated, despite the People's Bank of China's efforts to ease tight liquidity. The central bank's move last week aimed to stimulate economic growth amid slowing GDP. Despite the yuan's firmness, liquidity remains tight, indicating ongoing challenges for China's economy.

site_title: Smoggy Lunar New Year expected in northern China
summary: China expects a smoggy Lunar New Year in Beijing and northern industrial heartland due to worsening pollution, with middle to high level air pollution predicted from January 28. The air quality is expected to deteriorate again after a slight respite on January 27. Authorities have implemented measures to combat smog, including limiting fireworks sales and banning their use in some cities. The government predicts near 3 billion trips during the Lunar New Year period, with reduced industry and traffic expected to keep pollution levels down, but fireworks may push levels higher.

site_title: Tennis: Early knight puts Federer in dreamland
summary: Roger Federer reached the Australian Open quarter-finals after a hard-fought win over Kei Nishikori, becoming the surprise bookies' favourite to win the tournament. At 35, Federer is on the cusp of winning his 18th Grand Slam title, a feat not achieved since Ken Rosewall in 1972. He will face Mischa Zverev in the quarter-finals, setting up a potential semi-final against Stan Wawrinka or Jo-Wilfried Tsonga.

site_title: Town councils must plan finances as HDB estate infrastructure ages: MND
summary: Singapore's Ministry of National Development advises town councils to plan ahead for aging HDB estate infrastructure, emphasizing the need for sustainable long-term finances and building up sinking funds. The government will assist town councils through a S$450 million lift enhancement programme, which will upgrade 20,000 lifts with features such as obstruction detection and speed regulation.

site_title: Wage tussle escalates in post-boom Australia as long-standing deals expire
summary: Australia's long-standing wage hikes are expiring, with companies like Lanco Infratech and AGL terminating or threatening to terminate agreements, prompting a parliamentary committee to investigate whether this tactic breaks industrial relations rules. The tactic, used by companies like Murdoch University, threatens workers with minimum industry pay if a new agreement isn't reached. Labor Senator Gavin Marshall is examining the issue, citing inconsistent workplace fairness, as wages grow at their slowest pace on record, with Australian wages nearly half of what they were a decade ago.

site_title: China's bitcoin exchanges, eyed by regulators, slap on trading fees
summary: China's three largest bitcoin exchanges, BTCC, Huobi, and OkCoin, have announced they will charge trading fees of 0.2% per transaction, starting Tuesday, to curb market manipulation and volatility. The move follows increased scrutiny from the central bank, which has been monitoring the bitcoin market amid concerns over capital outflows and the yuan's weakening value. The decision aims to cool down the market, which saw a surge in trading volumes and bitcoin prices in the first half of the year. The fees will be flat and will not affect existing trades.

site_title: Hollywood set for Oscars picks with no big surprises
summary: The Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences is set to announce the nominees for the 89th Oscars on Tuesday, with "La La Land," "Moonlight," and "Manchester by the Sea" expected to fare well. The announcement aims to address the #OscarsSoWhite controversy from last year, with a focus on increasing diversity among nominees. Industry watchers predict Damien Chazelle's "La La Land" will triumph, but competition is fierce from films like "Moonlight," "Manchester by the Sea," and "Hidden Figures." Isabelle Huppert is also a strong contender for best actress, following her Golden Globe win for her performance in "Elle."

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks fall after Trump speech
summary: Tokyo shares fell on January 23, 2017, after US President Donald Trump's inauguration, with the benchmark Nikkei stock index losing 1.29% due to a sharp rise in the yen against the dollar. Exporters were particularly affected. Meanwhile, Takata shares plummeted as investors feared a lengthy bankruptcy restructuring. The Topix index also declined 1.23%.

site_title: Japan's JX, Petronas start Malaysia LNG train
summary: JX Nippon Oil & Energy Corp and Petronas have started commercial operations at the ninth liquefaction train at Petronas LNG complex in Bintulu, Sarawak, Malaysia. The train, with a production capacity of 3.6 million tonnes of LNG per year, began operations on January 1. This marks an increase in the complex's total capacity to 30 million tonnes per year. JX Nippon Oil acquired a 10% equity stake in a Petronas subsidiary that developed the ninth train in June last year.

images.alt_text: JX Nippon Oil & Energy Corp said its venture with Malaysian state oil firm Petronas has started commercial operations at the ninth liquefaction train at the Petronas LNG complex in Bintulu, Sarawak.

site_title: Update: United Air lifts halt after computer failure grounded flights
summary: United Airlines lifted a halt on domestic flights after a computer failure grounded flights, resolving the issue by 8:00pm. The halt occurred at 5:30pm in Chicago, affecting about 26% of its daily flights. This incident follows a series of computer failures at US airlines, including Delta and Southwest, which caused disruptions last year. United had 481 flight delays on Sunday, the most among US carriers. The airline apologized for the inconvenience and expects additional delays as flights resume this evening.

site_title: Australian, NZ dollars tick higher, US dollar capped as Trump withholds detail
summary: The Australian dollar reached a 2-1/2-month peak on Monday, near US$0.7589, as US President Donald Trump withheld details on his economic stimulus plans. The Aussie posted its fourth straight weekly gain, up over 5% in January, and is one of the best-performing major currencies this year. The New Zealand dollar also rose, up 0.5% to US$0.7200, while the US dollar was capped due to the lack of economic policy details from Trump.

site_title: Ethics lawyers to sue Trump over foreign payments
summary: A group of ethics lawyers, including former White House attorneys, plans to sue President Donald Trump over foreign payments to his businesses, alleging a violation of the US Constitution's emoluments clause. The lawsuit, filed by Citizens for Responsibility and Ethics in Washington, seeks a court order to prevent Trump from accepting payments from foreign governments. The group cites Trump's business dealings with countries like China, India, and the Philippines, citing a potential conflict of interest. The lawsuit aims to enforce the emoluments clause, which prohibits payments to public officials from foreign governments.

site_title: China orders more than 100 golf courses shut: govt
summary: China has ordered the closure of 111 golf courses, about 16% of the country's total, since 2011 as part of a crackdown on the sport due to its perceived ties to wealthy elites. The National Development and Reform Commission cited violations such as using arable land and groundwater extraction. The move aims to curb corruption and ensure fair access to the sport. In 2015, Communist Party members were banned from joining golf clubs in a corruption crackdown. The closures affect golf courses in all but one provincial-level region, with operators voluntarily closing an additional 11 courses.

site_title: Equation Summit's Disa rolls out PoSA system in US Walmart stores
summary: Disa Digital Safety, a subsidiary of Equation Summit Limited, has rolled out its Point-of-Sale Activation (PoSA) system at all US Walmart stores. The system, fully integrated into Walmart's backroom, checkout, and online sale systems, renders a product unusable until the buyer inputs a PIN printed on their receipt. This move aims to enhance security and digital authentication. The announcement led to a 14.3% rise in Equation Summit's share price to 3.2 Singapore cents.

site_title: Broker's take: Singtel's digital business undervalued, DBS sees buying opportunity
summary: DBS Research believes Singtel's digital businesses are undervalued, with a potential buying opportunity. The cyber security segment is expected to contribute $150-200 million to group EBITDA in FY2019, while digital advertising losses are forecast to decline. DBS recommends a "buy" with a 12-month price target of S$4.46, an upside of 17% from S$3.80. Risks include intense competition in digital advertising and a potential dilutive effect from a strengthening Singapore dollar.

site_title: US SEC probing Yahoo over previously disclosed cyber breach
summary: The US Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) is investigating Yahoo Inc. over a previously disclosed data breach, specifically whether the company should have reported it to investors sooner. The breaches, which occurred in 2013 and 2014, affected over 3 billion user accounts. Yahoo had previously disclosed the breaches in a November 2016 quarterly filing, stating it was cooperating with agencies, including the SEC. The SEC is seeking information and documents about the security incident and related matters.

site_title: Oil edges up after producer meeting, but high US output weighs
summary: Oil prices rose Monday after producers met to discuss production cuts, with Brent crude futures up 8 US cents to $55.57 per barrel. However, US oil production rose further, with drilling activity increasing by 29 rigs, according to energy services firm Baker Hughes. This surge in US output weighed on oil prices, limiting gains from the producer meeting. Despite the increase in US production, oil producers have cut 1.5 million barrels per day in 2017, according to Saudi Arabian Energy Minister Khalid al-Falih.

site_title: Australia's biggest state economy appoints new leader
summary: New South Wales, Australia's most populous state and largest economy, appointed Gladys Berejiklian as its leader after Mike Baird's surprise resignation. Berejiklian, a former state treasurer, vowed to continue infrastructure investment through privatization, maintaining control of the state budget and potentially increasing the number of assets to be sold. She prioritizes a strong economy, more jobs, and better services, while addressing housing affordability in Sydney, where median home prices have surged 10.6% to A$800,000 in the past year.

site_title: China jails two former officials, who fled abroad, for corruption
summary: Chinese courts have jailed two former officials, Wang Guoqiang and Li Huabo, for corruption after they fled abroad to avoid justice. Li was sentenced to life in Jiangxi, while Wang received an eight-year term in Liaoning for bribery and corruption. Both officials had evaded justice for years, with Li returning to China from Singapore in 2015 and Wang turning himself in in the US in 2014. China's anti-graft efforts, dubbed "Operation Fox Hunt," have led to the prosecution of corrupt officials, part of President Xi Jinping's war on corruption.

site_title: Tennis: Serena impresses even herself as title beckons
summary: Serena Williams, 35, impressed herself with her fight to reach the Australian Open quarterfinals, defeating 16th seed Barbora Strycova 7-5, 6-4. Williams, seeking a record 23rd Grand Slam, will face Johanna Konta in the semifinals. The win keeps her hopes of regaining the world ranking and potentially surpassing Steffi Graf's Open-era record. Williams credits her mental toughness and hard work for her continued success, saying she feels like she's "mentally eight and nine" compared to her sister Venus, also competing in the tournament.

site_title: Seoul: Won, stocks edge up on US dollar weakness after Trump's inaugural address
summary: South Korea's won and shares edged up after US President Donald Trump's inaugural address, which highlighted his "America first" policies. The won strengthened 0.2% against the US dollar, while the Korea Composite Stock Price Index (Kospi) rose 0.3%. Investors remain cautious due to Trump's comments, which were seen as lacking specific proposals. Markets in South Korea will be closed from January 27-30 for national holidays.

site_title: Thai SEC warns of risks related to short-term corporate debt
summary: The Thai Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) has warned investors of growing risks related to corporate bills of exchange (BEs), following a spate of defaults in the 262 billion baht short-dated bond market. Five companies have defaulted on BEs in the last two months, but one of the defaulters, Nation Multimedia Group, has repaid the note. The SEC has held discussions with issuers, selling agents, and asset management firms to address the situation and expects the market to adjust. Typically, BEs are sold to institutional and high-net-worth investors, but retail investors are indirectly exposed.

site_title: Malaysian transport minister to meet with MH370 families in Perth
summary: Malaysia's transport minister, Liow Tiong Lai, will meet with MH370 relatives in Perth, Australia, after receiving personal letters from a group representing families of the missing passengers. The meeting comes after the search was called off last week, with Liow reiterating that the underwater search will only resume if "credible new evidence" is discovered. The Boeing 777 jet vanished in 2014 with 239 people on board, sparking a global aviation mystery. Liow expressed hope for a "good discussion" and a potential breakthrough in the search for the plane's whereabouts.

site_title: Singapore inflation up 0.2% on year in Dec, 2016 inflation at -0.5%
summary: Singapore's inflation rose 0.2% in December 2016, driven by a stronger pickup in private road transport costs, including higher petrol prices and car park fees. Services inflation edged up to 1.6%, while food inflation remained stable at 2.0%. Accommodation costs fell 3.8% for the second consecutive month. The overall retail goods inflation eased to 0.0%, and the year-end CPI-All Items inflation came in at -0.5%, marking the second consecutive year of deflation.

images.alt_text: Singapore inflation rose to 0.2 per cent on year in December 2016 from 0.0 per cent in November, due to a stronger pickup in the cost of private road transport.

site_title: Advanced Holdings plans to acquire Agricore Global
summary: Advanced Holdings has entered into a non-binding agreement to acquire Agricore Global for S$180-240 million, subject to negotiations. The acquisition is expected to result in a reverse takeover and transfer Agricore's listing from the mainboard to the Catalist. Agricore holds 23 parcels of agricultural permits in Indonesia for crude palm oil plantations and two forestry concessions for timber management, covering 232,102 hectares. The deal aims to diversify Advanced Holdings from its existing industries and limit exposure to economic risks.

site_title: North Korea nuclear threat means South must not delay anti-missile system
summary: South Korea's Acting President Hwang Kyo-Ahn has stated that the deployment of a US anti-missile defense system, Thaad, cannot be delayed due to North Korea's growing nuclear missile threat. Despite Chinese concerns that Thaad's radar could penetrate its territory, Hwang emphasized the need for protection against North Korea's expanding nuclear capabilities. The deployment is seen as a response to North Korea's nuclear and missile tests, and South Korea is urging China to address its concerns rather than delaying or canceling the deployment.

site_title: Powerful storms kill at least 16 in south-east US
summary: Powerful storms swept through the south-eastern US, killing at least 16 people. The storms destroyed mobile homes and downed trees in Georgia and Mississippi, with 12 fatalities reported in rural Georgia and four in southern Mississippi. Eight people died in southern Cook County, Georgia, with three injured. President Trump offered condolences to Georgia Governor Nathan Deal, who declared a state of emergency in seven counties. Authorities warned of more severe weather threatening parts of the Carolinas and Florida. Extensive property damage was reported, with numerous fallen trees and downed power lines.

site_title: Rare shooting by Chinese official acting out of revenge, say police
summary: A Chinese official, Chen Zhongshu, carried out a rare shooting rampage in Sichuan province after becoming hateful of an investigation against him. Chen, head of the land and resources bureau, opened fire at a meeting of top city leaders on January 4, injuring two before fleeing and committing suicide. The investigation found Chen acted out of revenge, following a bribery case and suspicion of corruption. Gun violence is rare in China, but the incident highlights the country's ongoing fight against corruption under President Xi Jinping.

site_title: China's "Hedge Fund Brother No 1" sentenced to 5-1/2 years in prison: court
summary: China's "Hedge Fund Brother No 1" Xu Xiang was sentenced to 5-1/2 years in prison for market manipulation. Xu, a general manager of Zexi Investment, was found guilty of colluding with 13 listed companies to drive up their share prices using non-public information, resulting in huge profits. The conviction was made in the wake of China's 2015 stock market crash, which saw the market tumble over 40%. Xu, along with two accomplices, pleaded guilty to market manipulation, and his arrest was seen as a major crackdown on illicit activities in the financial sector.

images.alt_text: Xu Xiang, the Chinese hedge fund manager detained in the wake of the country's stock market crash in 2015, was sentenced on Monday to 5-1/2 years imprisonment for market manipulation.

site_title: Foxconn weighs US$7b US factory with Apple: Nikkei
summary: Foxconn Technology Group Chairman Terry Gou announced plans to invest over $7 billion in a US display manufacturing facility with Apple, potentially creating 30,000 to 50,000 jobs. The facility is seen as a response to rising demand for larger displays, and Apple is willing to invest due to the need for panels. This move comes as Foxconn plans to establish new facilities in the US, including a molding facility in Pennsylvania, amid concerns over US protectionism. Gou questioned whether US consumers will be willing to pay higher prices for equipment of equal quality.

site_title: United says domestic flights grounded due to computer disruption
summary: United Continental Holdings Inc grounded domestic flights due to a computer disruption, affecting thousands of passengers. The issue, similar to previous problems at the airline, has caused delays throughout the network. The Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) stated that the ground stop only applies to mainline flights serving domestic destinations. United apologized for the inconvenience and is working on a resolution. This incident follows similar computer failures at other major US airlines, including Southwest and Delta, in recent years.

site_title: South Korea acting president asks businesses to boost investment
summary: South Korea's acting president Hwang Kyo-Ahn urged businesses to boost investment and innovation to drive economic recovery, amid uncertainties due to President Park Geun-Hye's impeachment. With Park's powers stripped, Hwang asked businesses to play a key role in job creation and economic growth. The request comes as the country faces internal and external economic challenges.

site_title: Alibaba's million-job boast reflects slower China growth outlook
summary: Alibaba Group Holding aims to create a million jobs in the US by connecting small businesses with Chinese online buyers, a goal met by President Donald Trump during their meeting. The company's president, Michael Evans, believes the template for US efforts can be found in Alibaba's dealings with 10 million small businesses in China. However, analysts criticize the plan as unrealistic and problematic. Despite challenges, including US-China trade tensions and limited Chinese speakers in the US, Alibaba is undeterred and offers solutions such as Taobao Partners to help US companies succeed in China.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Monday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 1.350 points to 1665.920 on Monday, driven by a higher volume of 34.87 million lots worth RM12.65 million. Gainers outnumbered losers 91 to 51.

site_title: Australia shares hit 1-month low as industrials, healthcare weigh
summary: Australian shares fell to a one-month low on Monday, dropping 0.4% or 22.05 points to 5627.2, as industrial and healthcare stocks weighed on the S&P/ASX 200 index. Brambles Ltd slashed its annual profit forecast, while healthcare stocks, including CSL Ltd, posted significant losses. Energy stocks offered some support, while the gold index rose after a weaker US dollar drove up gold prices.

site_title: Hong Kong shares begin week with a rise
summary: Hong Kong shares rose 0.54% in opening trade on Monday, driven by a pickup in US markets. The Hang Seng Index climbed to 23,008.72, while the Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also edged up. Investors remain cautious ahead of US President Donald Trump's economic plans, despite a 5-day rally in Singapore stocks and a fresh record high for the S&P 500 in the US.

site_title: Australia to boost protection of critical infrastructure
summary: The Australian government is establishing a Critical Infrastructure Centre to protect key assets such as power grids and ports from foreign-led bids that may pose national security risks. The centre will conduct risk assessments and advise on transactions to prevent sabotage, espionage, and coercion. This move comes after the Chinese government labeled Australia "protectionist" following a series of contentious foreign investment rulings. The centre's creation aims to bolster protection of critical infrastructure and counter potential national security threats.

site_title: Taiwan Dec seasonally adjusted jobless rate lowest in 14 months at 3.82%
summary: Taiwan's jobless rate in December reached 3.82% on a seasonally adjusted basis, its lowest level in 14 months. This marks a decrease from the previous month's rate of 3.93%. The rate is also the lowest since October 2015, when it was recorded at 3.81%. However, the average seasonally-adjusted unemployment rate for 2016 was 3.92%, slightly higher than the 2015 rate of 3.78%.

site_title: Taiwan: Stocks higher on buying ahead of long holiday break
summary: Taiwan's main Taiex index rose 0.9% to 9,417.82 on Monday, staying above the 9,400 level ahead of a long holiday break. The electronics subindex and financials subindex also gained, while Hon Hai Precision, also known as Foxconn, rose 0.4%. Foxconn's chairman is considering a US$7 billion display-making plant in the US. The Taiwan dollar strengthened to NT$31.403 per US dollar. The stock market will close on Tuesday for the Lunar New Year holidays and reopen on February 2.

site_title: Procurri to form JV with Congruity to offer maintenance, IT services
summary: Procurri Corporation is forming a joint venture with Congruity LLC to offer maintenance and IT services in the Americas. The joint venture, Rockland Congruity LLC, will be 51% owned by Procurri and 49% by Congruity. Procurri plans to purchase $12 million of maintenance parts and $3.5 million of inventory, using $9.5 million from its initial public offering and $6 million in bank borrowings. Procurri has an option to acquire Congruity's remaining stake in the venture.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open lower on Monday
summary: Tokyo stocks opened lower on Monday, with the Nikkei 225 index losing 0.99% and the Topix index down 1.04%. A strong yen and uncertainty over the US president's economic policies contributed to the decline.

site_title: AA Group in S$25m acquisition deal
summary: AA Group Holdings has entered into a conditional sale and purchase agreement to acquire Engineering Manufacturing Services and its subsidiary Germaxco for S$25 million. The acquisition will be funded through a S$7 million bond, novation of a S$11 million debt, and a cash payment of S$7 million. AA Group believes the acquisition will provide consistent returns and diversify its business and revenue stream. The deal is in the best interests of the company, which views Engineering Manufacturing Services and Germaxco as financially strong and profitable.

site_title: Former US President George H W Bush may be moved soon from intensive care
summary: Former US President George H W Bush may be moved out of intensive care at Houston Methodist Hospital within the next day or two, as his vital signs return to normal after a week-long bout with pneumonia. His wife, Barbara, has chosen to stay overnight to be closer to him, despite having the option to be discharged. The 92-year-old is the nation's oldest living former president, having missed the presidential inauguration of Donald Trump due to health reasons.

site_title: Japan Inc believes Abe, Trump don't want to see excessive yen weakness: poll
summary: Japanese companies believe US President Donald Trump and Prime Minister Shinzo Abe do not want to see the yen weaken significantly, according to a Reuters poll. The poll found that 73% of companies believe the US will not tolerate a dollar rising beyond 120 yen, and 90% see 125 yen as a red line. Japanese firms want Abe to push Trump hard on trade issues, particularly on multilateral trade pacts like the Trans-Pacific Partnership, and to maintain US-Japan security ties. A weaker yen benefits Japanese exporters but could hurt households.

images.alt_text: Japanese companies believe that neither US President Donald Trump nor Japan Prime Minister Shinzo Abe want to see the yen weaken significantly, a Reuters poll showed, a development they worry could spark an unwelcome political backlash.

site_title: Samsung blames Galaxy Note 7 fires on faulty batteries
summary: Samsung blamed faulty batteries for the fires that led to the recall of its Galaxy Note 7 device. Internal and independent investigations concluded that the batteries were the cause of the incidents. The device, originally intended to compete with Apple's iPhone, was discontinued after a chaotic recall saw replacement phones also catching fire. The company acknowledged that the faulty batteries led to the device's discontinuation.

site_title: Trump says will begin renegotiating Nafta pact soon with Mexico, Canada
summary: US President Donald Trump announced plans to renegotiate the 23-year-old North American Free Trade Agreement (Nafta) with Mexico and Canada, starting talks soon with the two countries. Trump, who campaigned on renegotiating Nafta, aims to secure more favorable terms for the US.

site_title: China claims success from 'two-child' policy as 2016 birth rates rise
summary: China's "two-child" policy has led to a 1.4 million increase in births, reaching 17.86 million in 2016, the highest level since 2000. The number of women of childbearing age fell by 5 million, but birth rates rose significantly. China aims to keep birth rates at 17-20 million a year despite expected population decline. The country expects its population to reach 1.42 billion by the end of the decade, up from 1.37 billion in 2015.

images.alt_text: China's decision to allow all couples to have two children instead of one has resulted in birth rates rising to the highest level since 2000, a government official said.

site_title: Optus bags A$75m deal with Flight Centre
summary: Optus, the Australian subsidiary of Singtel, has signed a A$75 million five-year deal with Flight Centre Travel Group to provide collaboration and communication services. The contract will support Flight Centre's transformation strategy until 2021, focusing on global security, data connectivity, and unified communications. Optus will migrate Flight Centre to its virtualised contact centre solution within the next 12 months to enhance customer experience and staff management.

site_title: Samsung burning to regain trust with results of Note 7 fires probe
summary: Samsung Electronics plans to reveal the reasons behind the spontaneous combustion of its recalled Galaxy Note 7 smartphones, as the company works to regain consumer trust. The investigation, conducted by Samsung and independent organizations, is expected to identify the root cause of the fires, which led to a $5.3 billion loss in operating profit. Samsung's reputation is seen as a key factor in the success of its upcoming Galaxy S8 model, with analysts warning that consumers will be skeptical if the company does not provide a clear explanation for the fires.

site_title: Stocks to watch: CIT, AA Group, IHC
summary: Cambridge Industrial Trust (CIT) agreed to sell a 5-storey property in Ubi for S$22.1 million. AA Group Holdings entered into a conditional sale and purchase agreement to acquire Engineering Manufacturing Services and Germaxco for S$25 million. International Healthway Corporation (IHC) will hold an EGM on Monday to consider removing its current directors and appointing new ones.

site_title: IHC to hold EGM; refinancing plans may be affected
summary: International Healthway Corporation (IHC) is holding an extraordinary general meeting on January 23 to consider removing four current directors and appointing three new ones. This may affect the company's refinancing plans, including a proposed 8 billion yen loan. A Japanese financial institution advising on the refinancing has warned it may end its engagement if the board changes in the next week, potentially jeopardizing both the TMK and Japan refinancing plans. Shareholders are advised to exercise caution when trading the company's shares.

site_title: Singapore shares open flat on Monday
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index opened flat on Monday, with a 0.39-point gain to 3,011.47. Volume reached 136.8 million shares worth S$60.7 million, with 94 gainers and 28 losers. This marks the second consecutive day of a flat market, as investors await the release of GDP data.

site_title: US dollar starts week on back foot as details of Trump's policies awaited
summary: The US dollar began the week on a downward trend in early Asian trade, falling 0.2% to 100.52 on the US dollar index, as investors awaited details on President Trump's stimulus policies. The euro rose 0.2% to its highest in over a month, reaching US$1.07270, amidst concerns of a potential economic slowdown. Market participants are waiting for Trump's policy announcements, which may impact currency fluctuations and global economic outlook.

images.alt_text: The US dollar started the week on the back foot in early Asian trade on Monday, with the euro edging up to its highest in more than a month as investors locked in gains on the US dollar's recent rise as they waited for US President Donald Trump to offer details of his promised stimulus.

site_title: Trump vows to cherish a 'beautiful letter' left by Obama
summary: US President Donald Trump expressed gratitude for a "beautiful letter" left by outgoing President Barack Obama in the Oval Office, stating it will be cherished and kept private. The letter, a tradition dating back to 1993, is left by the outgoing president for their successor, with Obama's letter to Bill Clinton being considered particularly elegant. Trump's emotional mention of the letter highlighted the significance of the presidential transition.

site_title: Hong Kong tops survey of world's least affordable home market
summary: Hong Kong retained its top spot as the world's least affordable home market for the seventh year, with a median home price 18.1 times the median annual household income. The city's median multiple has improved slightly from 19 times in 2016, but remains a significant issue. Despite tax and mortgage cap measures, prices of secondary homes have increased 40% since 2012, with a 7.7% rise last year. The report by Demographia highlights a substantial deterioration in housing affordability in Hong Kong since 2010.

site_title: Opec and friends agree on way to monitor oil cuts to end glut grant
summary: OPEC and its allies agreed on a monitoring mechanism to ensure compliance with their historic 1.8 million barrel-per-day production cut agreement, which took effect on January 1. The agreement has already led to a 1.5 million barrel-per-day reduction in global oil supply, with Saudi Arabia, Kuwait, Qatar, Algeria, and Venezuela exceeding their individual targets. A monitoring committee will assess data from each producer country and report to OPEC's secretariat on the 17th day of each month, with the goal of eliminating the global oil glut and re-balancing the market.

site_title: Mortgage lender Quicken Loans under govt fire
summary: Quicken Loans, a mortgage lender, is facing government fire due to allegations of predatory lending practices. However, CEO Jay Farner cites high credit scores of borrowers, parent firm's assets, and regulation by states and agencies as reasons for the company's success. The article does not provide further details on the specific allegations or government actions against Quicken Loans.

site_title: CIT to divest Ubi property for S$22.1m
summary: CAMBRIDGE Industrial Trust (CIT) has agreed to sell its Ubi property for S$22.1 million, excluding costs. The five-storey light property, with 141,135 square feet of gross floor area, has 39 years remaining on its land tenure. The sale is part of CIT's FY2016 business strategy, focusing on divestment of non-core properties. Proceeds will be used for debt repayment, acquisitions, asset enhancements, and working capital. The sale is expected to be completed in May 2017, pending Housing and Development Board approval.

site_title: Singapore's workers have it easier than they might think
summary: Singapore's job market remains tight, with median unemployment for job-seekers at 8 weeks, lower than Australia's and comparable to other developed economies. Despite concerns over skill mismatches and a potential rise in unemployment rates for citizens and permanent residents, the government is optimistic about job prospects. The government hopes to address skill gaps through initiatives and has seen 98% of workers reaching retirement age offered re-employment.

site_title: Trump launches term stirring controversy over popular support
summary: US President Donald Trump sparked controversy after his inauguration, with massive protests in Washington and worldwide. Trump mocked protesters on Twitter, saying they didn't vote. The protests came a day after Trump's inauguration, with demonstrators speaking out against his policies. Trump sought to shift focus to upcoming actions from his office, but the controversy over his popularity persists.

site_title: Del Vecchio: rags-to-riches-to-mega merger
summary: Luxottica, led by 81-year-old Italian entrepreneur Leonardo Del Vecchio, has merged with French company Essilor in a 46-billion euro deal, creating a global powerhouse in the 95-billion euro eyewear industry. Del Vecchio will be the biggest shareholder. The deal is one of the biggest European mergers of recent years, adding to Del Vecchio's rags-to-riches story.

site_title: UK seeks interventionist approach to drive post-Brexit industrial revival
summary: UK Prime Minister Theresa May outlines a new 'Modern Industrial Strategy' to boost post-Brexit industrial production, citing closer industry collaboration in exchange for government support on regulation, trade, and research. The plan includes 'Sector Deals' to address regulatory barriers, increase exports, and support innovation. The strategy aims to create conditions for successful businesses to emerge and grow, and will be underpinned by a new, active role for government in backing business and ensuring more people share in the benefits of its success.

site_title: Majority of Japan firms plan no wage hike, a blow to Abenomics: poll
summary: Nearly two-thirds of Japanese companies, or 63%, plan not to hike their workers' wages this year, according to a Reuters poll. This is a blow to Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's campaign to boost wages and stimulate the economy. The poll found that most wage gains since Abe's election in 2012 have been minimal, with only 26% of firms increasing wages by 2% or more. Companies instead plan to reward employees with one-off bonus payments, citing uncertainty over US President Donald Trump's trade policies.

site_title: Outsider, ex-PM to vie for French leftwing presidential nod
summary: Benoit Hamon, an outsider and former education minister, emerged as the frontrunner for the French Socialist presidential nomination after beating former Prime Minister Manuel Valls in the first round. Hamon scored 35% of the vote, while Valls secured 31%. The Socialist primary runoff will determine the party's candidate for the presidential election, which is expected to be a three-way contest between conservative Francois Fillon, far-right Marine Le Pen, and Emmanuel Macron. Hamon's left-leaning platform has gained traction, and he is seen as a potential candidate to revive the Socialist party.

site_title: Madonna defends 'blowing up the White House' remark
summary: Pop singer Madonna defended her "blowing up the White House" remark, stating she was speaking metaphorically. The comment, made during her speech at the Women's March in Washington, DC, drew criticism on social media, with some calling for an investigation for making terrorist threats. Madonna said she was expressing anger and outrage, and not advocating for violence. The Women's March drew hundreds of thousands of people nationwide, with turnout exceeding projections. Madonna also criticized critics, saying "f*** you" to those who doubted the march's impact.

site_title: Fewer CNY savings deals as deposits pile up at banks
summary: Fewer banks in Singapore are offering Chinese New Year (CNY) savings promotions, with none of the three local banks launching traditional fixed deposit (FD) deals. Current FD rates range from 0.35% to 1.3% and can be found at Chinese and Malaysian banks, as well as Standard Chartered Bank. The poor economy and growing savings deposits are behind the relatively low interest rates, with savings growing five times faster than loans.

site_title: Jammeh 'plundered' Gambia coffers: Barrow aide
summary: Gambia's exiled leader Yahya Jammeh allegedly plundered the country's coffers, stealing millions of dollars in his final weeks in power. Jammeh fled on Saturday and is expected to settle in Equatorial Guinea. A West African military force entered Gambia on Sunday, allowing President Adama Barrow to return and take power. Jammeh's departure marks the end of 22 years of his rule, with Barrow taking the helm in Banjul. The country's economy and future remain uncertain after Jammeh's departure.

site_title: Three tools for young investors
summary: A university economics instructor advises young investors to acquire three essential toolkits: Accounting, Coding, and Economics (ACE). These skills help differentiate data from economic reality, enabling informed and proficient investment decisions in the new economy. Accounting involves understanding financial statements, coding is crucial for building models and automating tasks, and economics provides context for forecasting and valuing assets. By mastering these three areas, young investors can better navigate the complex financial landscape and make informed investment decisions.

site_title: Northern Ireland policeman injured in 'terrorist' attack
summary: A police officer in Belfast was injured in a suspected drive-by shooting at a petrol station on Sunday, described by the Police Federation as a "terrorist gun attack". The incident occurred at around 7:30pm, leaving the officer with an arm injury. This is one of several recent attacks on police officers in Northern Ireland, which have been linked to the region's complex history of violence. The incident is the latest in a series of attacks on law enforcement in the area.

site_title: Trump team said to be discussing post-Brexit trade deal with UK
summary: The Trump administration is reportedly discussing a post-Brexit trade deal with the UK, with President Trump's senior advisers meeting with British officials to prepare for a potential pact. British Prime Minister Theresa May has declared the country "open for business" and plans to pursue new trade accords with the EU and other countries. Trump officials believe their discussions encouraged May's more aggressive approach to exiting the EU, while also considering a deal to reduce barriers between US and British banks.

site_title: Japan could trump the US on TPP with revised Asia-Pacific trade accord
summary: Japan's Parliament ratified the Trans-Pacific Partnership Agreement (TPP) despite US President Donald Trump's vow to withdraw the US from the pact. If the US exits, Japan's Prime Minister Shinzo Abe believes the agreement would become "meaningless," prompting him to push for alternatives, such as a bilateral Japan-US trade agreement or a revised Asia-Pacific trade accord. Japan's trade minister Hiroshige Seko has pledged loyalty to the ideal of free trade and will continue to appeal to the Trump administration to reconsider its decision, while analysts suggest Japan may explore a mega-free trade agreement or a trilateral FTA involving Japan, China, and South Korea.

site_title: Amazon, Netflix back at Sundance in search of more potential award winners
summary: Streaming services Amazon and Netflix are attending the Sundance film festival in search of potential Oscar winners, with Amazon's Manchester by the Sea and Netflix's 13th and The Ivory Game shortlisted for Oscar nominations. Amazon has offered bonuses of up to $100,000 to filmmakers showcasing their movies at Sundance, while Netflix aims to capitalize on publicity and showcase its acquired films after their Sundance premieres. The success of streaming platforms could redefine the film industry, offering independent filmmakers a different model to traditional studios, with the potential for more money upfront and a larger audience.

site_title: 'Trainspotting' returns after 21 years with punchy sequel
summary: The long-awaited sequel to the 1996 cult classic "Trainspotting" has premiered in Edinburgh, 21 years after the original. "T2: Trainspotting" reunites the original cast, including Ewan McGregor, Robert Carlyle, Jonny Lee Miller, and Ewen Bremner, with director Danny Boyle. The film explores themes of betrayal and reconciliation as the characters navigate Edinburgh's gentrification. With a mix of humor and gritty realism, the movie has received largely positive reviews, with critics praising its energy and defiant pessimism.

images.alt_text: T2: Trainspotting reunites Ewan McGregor, Robert Carlyle, Jonny Lee Miller and Ewen Bremner with now Oscar-winning director Danny Boyle.

site_title: Nuclear losses pressuring Toshiba to sell core semiconductor business stake
summary: Toshiba is considering selling a 20-30% stake in its core semiconductor business, worth over US$10 billion, to boost its capital base amid mounting writedowns from its nuclear business. The sale may be complicated by antitrust concerns and potential earnings dilution, which could impact the company's investor appeal. Toshiba aims to offset the nuclear hit and prevent its negative net worth, which could jeopardize its role in public infrastructure projects and Tokyo Stock Exchange listing.

images.alt_text: Following a 2015 accounting scandal, Toshiba is barred from raising fresh funding on equity markets; selling assets could help it win broader financial support from its main banks but may fuel concerns of earnings dilution, while any deal with Western Digital can trigger a time-consuming antitrust review.

site_title: Slower growth for China's property, financial sectors in Q4
summary: China's real estate and financial sectors experienced slower growth in the fourth quarter of 2016, despite a strong service sector and better-than-expected GDP growth of 6.8%. The services sector contributed 58.2% to the country's economic growth, while the property market slowed to 7.7% growth and the financial sector decelerated to 3.8%. Strong consumer spending and record bank lending drove the economic growth, with consumer services and transportation sectors experiencing significant growth. The slowdown in these sectors has raised concerns about the impact on economic growth.

site_title: Manhattan office owners spending to keep tenants
summary: Manhattan office landlords are spending heavily to keep tenants amid falling rents and increased competition. Effective rents slid 7% in the fourth quarter to $57.18 a square foot, while leasing has slumped and tenants are putting more excess space on the market. To compete, landlords are offering more concessions, including tenant-improvement allowances, which soared 12% last year. This trend is expected to continue, with many landlords renovating their spaces to attract and retain tenants, particularly in new skyscrapers like Hudson Yards. The market is seen as being in equilibrium, with new supply putting a cap on rent increases.

site_title: Cuba sends maritime delegation to US
summary: A Cuban delegation of port and maritime officials arrived in the US on January 22, 2017, for talks on business opportunities and foreign investment. The main goal is to promote Cuba's maritime sector, particularly its new deepwater port in Mariel. The visit, the first from Cuba during the Donald Trump administration, will last through February 3 and will take the trade officials to various US ports. The talks aim to foster cooperation and investment in Cuba's maritime sector.

site_title: UK high street retailers throw their weight behind online ops
summary: UK high street retailers are shifting their focus to online operations, with major brands such as Marks & Spencer, John Lewis, and Next investing in technology and logistics to keep up with growing online sales. Online shopping accounted for nearly a quarter of all purchases in December, with fashion retailers experiencing 7% growth in sales. However, traditional retailers face new challenges, including high returns and increased costs, as they adapt to the changing retail landscape.

site_title: May braces for new Brexit battle over court ruling
summary: British Prime Minister Theresa May faces a potential court ruling that could block her Brexit plans, as the Supreme Court decides whether she can use her executive power to initiate the process or must seek parliament's approval. The court is expected to rule in favor of an earlier High Court decision that the process can only be introduced through formal legislation. If the ruling goes against May, the government plans to rush emergency legislation through parliament, but opposition from lawmakers and the Scottish National Party could still cause complications.

site_title: Markets to remain in 'wait and see' mode - for now
summary: US markets have fallen over the past three weeks, contradicting the "reflation play" strategy based on hopes of large fiscal stimulus from the Trump administration. The Nasdaq Composite is the only major index to rise, while the rest have declined. Analysts, including George Soros, believe the rally is over due to uncertainty and lack of clarity on Trump's economic plans. Asian markets, however, remain relatively stable, with Credit Suisse citing robust exports data and stabilizing Chinese economy as reasons for optimism. Investors are expected to remain in "wait and see" mode for the next few weeks, tracking Wall Street for direction.

site_title: Mystery of American Airlines' ailing flight attendants
summary: American Airlines flight attendants are reporting severe health complaints, including skin rashes, sore throats, and wheezing, after wearing new uniforms made by Twin Hill. The Association of Professional Flight Attendants (APFA) has asked the airline to recall the uniforms, which were introduced in September, after 10% of its 2,300 represented flight attendants reported adverse reactions. American Airlines has spent over $1 million on toxicological tests, but the cause of the maladies remains unknown. The airline and union are now conducting further examinations, and the union is seeking reimbursement for its expenses.

site_title: When age is just a number
summary: Singaporean companies are recognizing the value of older workers, with over 16% of FairPrice's workforce being over 60 years old. Many employers, such as Kelly Services and Ademco Security Group, treat older workers equally and offer flexible work arrangements to retain them. Others, like Fujitsu and American Express, value experience and skills over age. The government's revisions to the Retirement and Re-employment Act have encouraged businesses to hire and retain mature workers, with some companies offering wage subsidies and training grants. Experts emphasize the importance of adapting training programs to keep workers' skills up-to-date and recognizing the contribution of older workers to the workforce.

site_title: Opec, Russia say oil cuts deeper and faster than expected
summary: OPEC and Russia are ahead of schedule implementing their oil output cuts, removing 1.5 million barrels a day from the market. Saudi Arabia, Algeria, and Kuwait have made deeper cuts than required, while Russia has reduced supply faster than expected. The producers' agreement aims to boost prices and curb production, with the cuts expected to last for the next four years.

site_title: Way ahead of the pack
summary: Fagerdala Group, a local packaging solutions provider, has grown its business internationally over the past 20 years, with 90% of its revenue coming from abroad. Founded in 1983 as a wholly-owned foreign enterprise in Singapore, the company has expanded to seven countries, establishing a presence in Thailand, China, Shanghai, and other locations. Under the leadership of executive chairman Paul Yeo, the company has undergone significant transformations, including a rebranding exercise to align with Singaporean identity and the introduction of Centres of Excellence to develop subject matter expertise. The company is now looking to fuel its growth through mergers and acquisitions.

site_title: Thousands protest outside Taiwan presidential office over pension reform plan
summary: Thousands of Taiwanese public servants, including military personnel, teachers, and police, protested outside the Presidential Office in Taipei against a proposed pension reform plan. The plan, announced by Vice-President Chen Chien-jen, would delay default payments to retirees by a decade, affecting 12,000 protesters. The plan has been met with anger and criticism from the public servants, who claim it would ruin their retirement plans and demonstrate incompetence by President Tsai Ing-wen. The protesters, estimated to be around 12,000, chanted slogans calling for Tsai's resignation and criticizing the government's handling of the reform.

site_title: Japan enters uncharted waters as emperor's abdication is pondered
summary: Japan is considering a law allowing Emperor Akihito, 83, to abdicate, a move unprecedented in two centuries. The law would enable him to retire by the end of 2018, following his heart surgery and prostate cancer treatment. Experts are examining ancient precedents and foreign monarchs' retirement examples, such as Queen Beatrix and King Albert II, for guidance. Key issues, including the emperor's title, duties, and residence after retirement, remain to be settled. The Japanese government must also decide on the new "imperial era" that will begin with the successor, Crown Prince Naruhito.

site_title: Japan's Takeda on the hunt for new drugs to support growth
summary: Takeda Pharmaceuticals is searching for new treatments to support growth amid rising healthcare costs and increasing demand for medicines in the Asia-Pacific region, which bears 25% of the global disease burden. The company faces a challenge of affordability, with lifestyle-induced diseases and a fast-ageing population in countries like Korea and Taiwan. This issue is expected to intensify the need for innovative treatments, making it essential for Takeda to find new drugs to stay competitive and drive growth.

site_title: Oil prices jump 2% ahead of producers' meet
summary: Oil prices rose 2% on Friday ahead of a meeting of world's top oil producers, who agreed to verify compliance with a 1.8 million barrels per day output cut deal. The Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries (Opec) and other producing countries, including Russia, met in Vienna to establish a mechanism for monitoring the agreement. However, rising US drilling activity limited the gains, and prices were expected to stabilize in the coming days. The meeting aims to demonstrate compliance with the global output cut deal.

site_title: Apple sues chipmaker Qualcomm for abusing monopoly
summary: Apple is suing chipmaker Qualcomm, alleging the company has abused its monopoly in the smartphone industry by charging excessive fees for its essential technology. Qualcomm has mastered complex chip technology and then sold its knowledge to smartphone manufacturers, generating billions of dollars. The lawsuit claims Qualcomm's business strategy stifles competition and harms consumers. This marks a significant move by Apple, which is seeking to level the playing field and protect its business interests.

images.alt_text: Qualcomm's engineers work at a 41-building campus between a park and the University of California, San Diego. In its last fiscal year, the company had a profit of US$5.7 billion.

site_title: Director buying rises, selling flat
summary: Singapore Exchange director buying activity declined in the third week of January, with only 12 companies recording purchases worth S$0.79 million, down from 10 companies in the previous week. However, the selling activity was up, with two firms disposing of shares worth S$4.57 million. Notable insider buys included GSS Energy Limited's CEO purchasing 2 million shares at S$0.09 each, and GP Batteries International's chairman buying 36,000 shares at S$0.81 each. Meanwhile, Singapore O&G Limited's chairman sold 4 million shares at S$1.13 each, reducing his holdings by 15%.

site_title: Being biggest isn't always the best in the solar industry
summary: JinkoSolar Holding Co is poised to become the leading solar-industry company, surpassing Trina Solar and Canadian Solar, with 6.5 gigawatts of panel-production capacity. The company's full-year 2016 shipments may reach 6.7 gigawatts, potentially vaulting it to the top. This comes as the solar industry continues to experience intense competition, with companies vying for market share. Despite being the third-largest supplier, Jinko's success highlights that being the biggest may not always be the best in the industry.

site_title: Snap touts metric of engaged daily users to justify US$20b value
summary: Snap Inc is seeking to convince investors it's worth $20 billion by highlighting its daily engagement metrics. The company disclosed 150 million daily active users, 150 million snaps taken daily, and users spending an average of 34 minutes on the app. Management aims to distance itself from Twitter's valuation issues by focusing on long-term investment and comparing itself to Amazon, which also experiences short-term inconsistencies in performance. Snap's initial public offering could value the company at $20-25 billion and may list as early as the first quarter.

site_title: Tesla absolved of fault in fatal crash involving driverless car
