By embracing innovation, collaboration, and technology, Asian airlines are charting a course for a brighter future, despite forecasts of choppier waters in 2017.

site_title: HSBC, UBS to shift 1,000 jobs each from UK in Brexit blow to London
summary: HSBC and UBS, two major European banks, plan to relocate around 1,000 jobs from London due to Brexit. HSBC will move staff responsible for a fifth of its UK trading revenue to Paris, while UBS may affect 1,000 of its 5,000 London employees. Goldman Sachs is also considering halving its London workforce and moving key operations to New York and continental Europe. The job relocations are a result of expected disruption caused by Britain's exit from the European Union.

images.alt_text: Two of Europe's biggest banks warned on Wednesday that they could each move about 1,000 jobs out of London as they prepare for expected disruption caused by Britain's exit from the European Union.

site_title: STI falls for 3rd day but clings to 3,000
summary: The Straits Times Index fell for the third consecutive day, down 12.55 points to 3,000.22, despite a 20-point rise in Dow futures and a 1.1% rise in the Hang Seng Index. The decline was largely due to selling of banks, with Singtel and Hongkong Land also losing value. The index remains up 4.2% for the year so far.

site_title: Warburg Pincus goes big on S'pore logistics firms
summary: Warburg Pincus has acquired 80% of Cambridge Industrial Trust manager and is leading a buyout of ARA Asset Management, a real estate investment trust and private real estate fund manager. This move is part of the firm's expansion into the logistics sector. The acquisition of ARA is expected to further solidify Warburg's position as a major player in the logistics industry, with both companies managing significant investments in industrial and logistics assets.

images.alt_text: Private equity firm Warburg Pincus is ramping up to become a major logistics player. On Wednesday, its subsidiary announced an acquisition of 80 per cent of the manager of Cambridge Industrial Trust (CIT) for an undisclosed sum.

site_title: German jobless rate falling even with one million refugees
summary: Germany's jobless rate has fallen despite the arrival of over one million refugees, defying concerns it would lift joblessness and hurt growth. Labour remains tight, with output increasing at the fastest pace in five years, bolstered by private consumption and government expenditure on migrants. The country's ageing population and low birth rate also contribute to the low unemployment rate, which is forecast to remain unchanged at 6.1% this year.

site_title: Nissan, Toyota back UK plants despite May's Brexit plan
summary: Toyota and Nissan plan to continue manufacturing cars in the UK despite Prime Minister Theresa May's Brexit plan, which could make exporting from British factories less lucrative. The two companies, along with Japanese rival Honda, have led a revival in UK car manufacturing, relying on EU membership to export cars to other countries in the bloc without tariffs. Nissan has secured assurances from the UK government and will assess its Sunderland factory's competitiveness, while Toyota plans to keep its car- and engine-building plants in the UK and increase competitiveness if necessary.

images.alt_text: Toyota Motor Corp and Nissan Motor Co say they'll keep making cars in the UK despite Prime Minister Theresa May's plan to leave the European Union's single market, which could make exporting from British factories less lucrative.

site_title: Crackdown on budget Chinese tours deals blow to Thai tourism
summary: Thailand's tourism industry has been negatively impacted by a 16% drop in Chinese visitors in December, following the country's crackdown on low-budget tours from China. The decline extends a slide that began in September, with some impact expected to linger in 2017. The drop in Chinese tourists, the largest by headcount, clouds Thailand's economic growth outlook.

images.alt_text: Chinese tourists boarding a sightseeing boat at a pier at Chao Phraya River in Bangkok, October 2016.
Boats waiting for tourists at the same location on Jan 11, 2017.

site_title: Netflix adds a third more subscribers than expected; shares jump 7%
summary: Netflix exceeded expectations by adding 7.1 million new subscribers globally, beating forecasts of 5.2 million, despite higher prices. The company's shares jumped 7% in extended trading. Netflix's original shows, such as Marvel's Luke Cage and The Crown, performed well worldwide. The company plans to release over 1,000 hours of original programming this year, up from 600 hours last year. Revenue rose 35.9% to $2.48 billion in the December quarter, with analysts expecting $2.47 billion.

images.alt_text: Streaming video pioneer Netflix Inc added over a third more subscribers than expected in the last quarter of 2016, a sign of success for its ambitious global expansion that sent its shares up 7 per cent in extended trading.

site_title: Aussie property boom benefits Perpetual
summary: Perpetual, a top-performing fixed income money manager, has cut its real estate debt investments to 2.9% of its portfolio, the lowest level in 10 years, amid concerns over Australia's overheated property market. Head of fixed income Vivek Prabhu warns that the nation's A$7.6 trillion property market is likely closer to the top than the bottom, with risks increasing but credit spreads not moving out. This move comes as Australia's house values rose at the fastest pace in seven years in 2016, driven by record-low interest rates.

site_title: Off-target economic forecasts point to group-think
summary: Economic forecasting is in crisis, with the International Monetary Fund (IMF) acknowledging that its failure to predict the 2008 financial crisis was partly due to group-think. The IMF's forecasts rarely deviate from the consensus, with economists unwilling to stand out and risk scrutiny. This is exacerbated by government pressure on forecasters and the reliance on similar data and short-term models. As a result, forecasters are struggling to accurately predict economic trends, including growth and inflation, and the danger of a more abrupt rise in bond rates is clear.

site_title: Mardan banking on experience to lift his local game
summary: Singaporean golfer Mardan Mamat, ranked No. 1, is competing in the SMBC Singapore Open, his 25th year participating in the tournament. Despite a disappointing 2011 disqualification, Mardan aims to improve his game, particularly around the greens, and perform well in front of home fans. With a career earnings of S$3.1 million, Mardan hopes for divine intervention in difficult situations and relies on his experience to overcome the challenge posed by top golfers such as Adam Scott and Ernie Els.

site_title: Living in mini flats, partitioned spaces is now grim reality in HK
summary: Hong Kong residents, particularly young adults, are facing a grim reality of living in mini flats with partitioned spaces, with nearly 200,000 residents sharing cramped conditions. The issue stems from the unaffordable housing market, which has continued to rise despite outgoing leader Leung Chun-ying's efforts to address the issue in 2012. The situation highlights the struggle to provide affordable housing in the city, leaving many residents, like 26-year-old Kong Ngai-lam, forced to live in unconventional and uncomfortable living arrangements.

site_title: An exit deal referendum could be a fatal political blow for May
summary: Theresa May presented her vision for a hard Brexit, advocating for the UK's exit from the European Union without retaining key EU membership. The speech has been welcomed by Brexiteers, but it is expected to divide the nation, as 48% of the population voted to remain in the EU. The UK government is opposed to an exit deal referendum, which could be a fatal blow to May's leadership. The referendum's outcome will depend on public opinion, which has been shown to be fickle.

site_title: Buffeted by change, US car workers resigned to uncertainty
summary: US car workers at the "Big Three" car plants are facing uncertainty due to job losses and changes in benefits. Many jobs have moved overseas, leaving remaining workers without the security and benefits that once supported the American middle class. A 46-year-old Ford employee, Janet Parker, expressed disillusionment, stating that her working life has "changed for the worse" despite being hired by the company eight years ago. The shift in the US car industry has left workers worried about their future.

site_title: Asahi eyes more deals to grow overseas business to 33% of sales
summary: Asahi Group Holdings Ltd aims to increase its overseas business to 33% of sales through further acquisitions. The Japanese brewer has agreed to buy around $11 billion of SABMiller plc's brands to offset a declining beer market at home. Asahi president Akiyoshi Koji stated that the domestic market is stable, but the company seeks overseas markets as its growth engine. This move is part of Asahi's strategy to diversify its business and expand globally.

site_title: UOB brightens homes ahead of the new year
summary: UOB has distributed gifts to over 370 low-income households in Singapore ahead of the Chinese New Year, including 16 homes with fresh paint and new furniture. Over 100 volunteers, employees, and clients of the bank participated in the event. The bank's charity dinner aims to raise S$800,000 for three local charities. Beneficiaries expressed gratitude for the gesture, with one homeowner saying her home, which had not been repainted in over 20 years, now feels like a "brand new home".

site_title: Straits Trading buys Japan property for 925m yen
summary: Straits Trading Company has agreed to buy a 14-storey rental residential property in Osaka, Japan, Splendid Namba II, for 925 million yen (S$11.6 million). The property has a 95% occupancy rate and is located near the metro line and prime shopping areas. The transaction will be funded by internal resources and bank borrowings, and the company views it as an opportunity to assemble a portfolio of residential apartments in key Japanese cities.

site_title: Davos meeting hears warnings of new emerging-market debt crisis
summary: A new emerging-market debt crisis, similar to the 1990s crisis, may be brewing, warned David Rubenstein, co-CEO of The Carlyle Group, at the World Economic Forum in Davos. The US dollar's surge has raised concerns over a repeat of the 1990s crisis, which forced the US to bail out Mexico. With $4.5 trillion in emerging-market corporate debt, a strong dollar could squeeze countries that have borrowed in dollars, potentially forcing fresh debt bailouts.

site_title: Signs of hope and some positive reviews for the beleaguered ringgit
summary: The Malaysian ringgit, Asia's worst-performing currency in 2016, declined 4.3% last year and reached a low of 4.486 against the US dollar. Despite domestic issues, including a protracted financial scandal, the currency has gained some ground and is undervalued by 10-12%. The Malaysian economy is projected to grow 4-5% this year, and the ringgit's volatility has reduced due to recent intervention measures. A cheaper currency makes Malaysian assets attractive to foreign investors, and stabilizing commodity prices could further support the ringgit.

site_title: Consumer prices rise for fifth month
summary: The US consumer price index rose 0.3% in December, its fifth consecutive month of increase, pushing inflation closer to the Federal Reserve's 2% goal. Energy costs, shelter, and medical expenses drove the gains, with the core CPI measure rising 0.2% and year-on-year prices up 2.1%. The increase strengthens the Fed's case to keep raising interest rates this year, with steady demand allowing companies to regain pricing power and boost inflation.

site_title: AA Reit studying potential investment targets: CEO
summary: AIMS AMP Capital Industrial Reit (AA Reit) is evaluating potential investment targets, including a single property and a portfolio of properties in Singapore. The Reit's CEO, Koh Wee Lih, said the focus is on yield-accretive opportunities that align with the strategy and portfolio, and to ensure the asset delivers long-term benefits to unitholders. AA Reit has underutilized space in its existing portfolio and is expected to benefit from the planned Tuas Mega Port and increased connectivity in the western region of Singapore.

images.alt_text: The Reit manager CEO Koh Wee Lih declined to offer further information on this, except to say that it has not committed to a purchase yet.

site_title: Revlon aims for US$5b in sales with revitalised brands
summary: Revlon aims to reach US$5 billion in sales within five years by revitalizing its brands and stepping up marketing. The company, which owns Elizabeth Arden, plans to reorganize into four teams focusing on its brands, products, fragrances, and labels. This approach differs from competitors, which have been buying up independent brands. Revlon aims to boost sales in China, South Korea, Japan, and Taiwan, with North America accounting for almost 60% of revenue.

site_title: How Indianapolis, long known as a manufacturing hub, is luring tech talent
summary: Indianapolis is attracting tech talent by offering a combination of affordability, mentorship, and a growing tech community. The city is home to companies like Salesforce, Angie's List, and ExactTarget, which have created over 3,700 new jobs in the tech sector. The Indy Tech Fellowship and other programs aim to lure young engineers to the city, with salaries above the state median. Despite a chill in the tech industry due to a contentious law, the city remains optimistic, with a thriving arts, culture, and restaurant scene.

images.alt_text: Ms Zegiestowsky earns less in Indianapolis than she might in Silicon Valley, but she has a much lower cost of living in the state.
As for Mr Dorsey, he has stayed in Indianapolis because he likes the lifestyle and the workforce.

site_title: Qualcomm accused of forcing deal on Apple to fend off rivals
summary: The US Federal Trade Commission (FTC) has filed a lawsuit against Qualcomm, accusing the chipmaker of forcing a deal with Apple to use its chips exclusively in exchange for lower licensing fees, unfairly cutting out competitors. The FTC alleges Qualcomm maintained a monopoly on semiconductors and pocketed elevated royalties, while Qualcomm denies the allegations and claims the deal was based on industry standards. This is the latest regulatory challenge to Qualcomm's technology licensing business, following similar investigations by South Korea, the European Union, and Taiwanese authorities.

site_title: Politics mars policy progress under HK chief executive
summary: Hong Kong's outgoing Chief Executive Leung Chun-ying emphasized the city's economic development in his last policy address, citing moderate growth and low unemployment. However, analysts say his tenure was marked by increased political divisiveness and failure to implement meaningful political reform. Leung's popularity has been declining, and his administration's handling of opposition has been criticized as "divisive, high-handed, and hard-lined." Despite his efforts to address housing woes and social welfare, his legacy will likely be defined by his inability to build consensus and implement significant political reform.

site_title: Optimism reigns in India as CEOs, consumers look beyond China
summary: India's perception of its outlook is improving, closing the gap with China, according to studies and surveys published around the World Economic Forum. Despite slashing India's growth forecast to 6.6%, the International Monetary Fund acknowledges the country's substantial growth rate. Local business leaders and consumers are optimistic about prospects in India, with consumption remaining high despite a cash ban. Policymakers' responses to risk are seen as key to business prospects, and foreigners in India report accelerated progress towards long-term savings and investments.

site_title: Singapore SMEs beat global average in export value per firm
summary: Singapore's small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) have outperformed the global average in export value per firm, with an average annual revenue of US$2.21 million. This surpasses the global average of US$1.5 million. The majority of these SMEs (87%) derive their revenue from exporting, with air transport being the most-used method of export. Despite regional competition and rising production costs, SMEs expect 28% growth in intra-regional and 25% growth in inter-regional exports in 2017.

site_title: AirAsia mulls dividend from proceeds of leasing unit sale
summary: AirAsia is considering using the proceeds from the sale of its aircraft-leasing arm, Asia Aviation Capital, to pay a dividend. The airline's CEO, Tony Fernandes, expects to receive binding bids by March and close the deal by summer. The sale, valued at around $1 billion, could help bolster AirAsia's financials, which have a net debt of $2.8 billion. The board will decide whether to use the proceeds to reduce debt or pay a dividend, with Fernandes preferring to have more cash than less.

site_title: Public healthcare system to be regrouped into three clusters
summary: Singapore's public healthcare system will be regrouped into three clusters from the existing six regional health systems to improve and future-proof healthcare services. The reorganisation, expected to be completed in about a year, will not affect patients or jobs, with existing healthcare arrangements and appointments remaining unchanged. The three clusters will retain the names of NHG, SingHealth, and NUHS, and will have full suites of healthcare services, including medical schools and networked polyclinics.

site_title: Sembcorp inks build-operate-transfer agreement for Myanmar power plant
summary: Sembcorp Industries signed a build-operate-transfer (BOT) agreement with Myanmar's Ministry of Electricity and Energy for its 225MW gas-fired power plant in Mandalay. The US$300m project will generate electricity for 25 years, with the power being sold to Electric Power Generation Enterprise. This marks the company's entry into Myanmar's power sector, with the plant expected to contribute to the country's growing energy needs.

site_title: Land rush in Permian where oil is stacked like a layered cake
summary: ExxonMobil and Noble Energy have inked multibillion-dollar deals in the Permian Basin, a region straddling Texas and New Mexico, amid the US domestic oil production slump. ExxonMobil acquired 275,000 acres for up to $6.6 billion, while Noble Energy bought 120,000 acres for $2.7 billion. These deals, worth $25 billion, represent a significant increase in investments in the Permian, which has become the "crown jewel" of the oil and gas industry due to its rich shale fields and low breakeven price.

site_title: Canadian intelligence warns energy firms of risk of attacks
summary: Canada's main spy agency, CSIS, warned energy companies in May about an increased risk of cyber espionage and attacks on pipelines, oil storage, and power transmission towers. The threat is from foreign state-owned firms seeking confidential information, including valuations and tax records. The warning comes as opposition to pipelines has grown in Canada and the US, home to the world's third-largest oil reserves. Energy companies already use surveillance measures to monitor pipelines, but security experts say it's impossible to lower the threat to zero.

site_title: Yellow rice wine thrives as Chinese tastes turn to ancient booze
summary: Chinese consumers are shifting towards yellow rice wine, a 3,000-year-old beverage, as beer sales decline and liquor consumption slows. The drink, known as "liquid cake," contains eight essential amino acids and is less alcoholic than baijiu liquor. Yellow rice wine sales volume is estimated at 8% in China, with growth driven by an expansion of shop sales and online presence. Producers such as Zhejiang Guyuelongshan Shaoxing Wine Co. and Shanghai Jinfeng Wine Co. are gaining popularity, with prices rising as consumers upgrade to more expensive varieties.

site_title: Brexit drives push for bigger Frankfurt role in exchange merger
summary: Germany and the European Central Bank are pushing for a greater role for Frankfurt in the merger of Deutsche Boerse and the London Stock Exchange, following the UK's withdrawal from the EU. Currently, London is set to host the main holding company and joint board, but Brexit may shift plans in favor of Frankfurt. ECB, German regulators, and politicians are seeking more control of the holding company to strengthen Frankfurt's position in the European financial market.

site_title: China new-home prices surge at fastest pace since 2011
summary: China's new-home prices surged 12.4% in December, the fastest pace since 2011, but cooled in December compared to November. The moderation in prices has eased concerns of a speculative bubble bursting, allowing China's leaders to reassess economic targets for 2017. Beijing is reportedly prepared to accept a 6.5% growth target, down from previous expectations. The slowdown in the property market is seen as a positive sign for the government, which aims to curb excessive price gains and debt.

site_title: S'pore firms remain sanguine despite frequency of cyberattacks: survey
summary: A recent survey by Accenture found that 77% of Singapore organizations remain confident in their ability to protect themselves against cyberattacks, despite the frequency of successful attacks. The average organization in Singapore faces 138 targeted cyberattacks per year, with internal breaches having the greatest cybersecurity impact. However, many prioritize external security issues, and only 8% of respondents plan to increase their cybersecurity investment in the next three years.

site_title: From field to factory: Vietnam's globalisation winners
summary: Vietnam has emerged as one of South-east Asia's fastest-growing economies, driven by exports of cheaply made goods, transforming the lives of millions like Nguyen Thi Thanh Loan, who now works in a Ford factory. The country's free trade policies, initiated in the 1980s, have hauled Vietnam out of poverty and led to large reductions in poverty, with exports accounting for 90% of GDP. Despite US President Donald Trump's vow to dismantle the Trans-Pacific Partnership, Vietnam remains committed to free trade, citing its benefits, including a growing middle class and rising average income.

site_title: US$ recovers some ground after 5 days of falls
summary: The US dollar rebounded 0.8% against the yen on Wednesday after a five-day decline, reversing some of Tuesday's losses. The dollar index rose 0.4% to 100.68, its highest level since December 8. Investors await the Federal Reserve's head speech and US inflation data for clues on interest rates. Sterling retreated 1% after a 3% gain on Tuesday, while the yen hit a seven-week low of 112.57 earlier in the day. Experts attribute the dollar's weakness to US President-elect Donald Trump's policies, citing concerns over trade disputes and policy implementation.

site_title: Tech middlemen helping small US ranchers sell their beef
summary: A tech middleman is helping small US ranchers sell their grass-fed agyu beef, capitalizing on the high demand for this Japanese-bred beef known for its buttery flavor. The middlemen provide marketing, logistics, and sales services to ranchers, allowing them to bypass traditional distribution channels and sell directly to consumers. This new business model has given ranchers a more efficient and profitable way to sell their products, despite the challenges posed by tariffs and market fluctuations. The partnership aims to increase the availability of high-quality, grass-fed agyu beef in the US market.

site_title: HK regulator sues 2 banks, KPMG over China Forestry IPO
summary: Hong Kong's Securities and Futures Commission (SFC) has filed a lawsuit against Standard Chartered Plc, UBS Group AG, and audit firm KPMG LLP over alleged "market misconduct" related to China Forestry Holdings Co's 2009 IPO prospectus and financial statements. The SFC seeks unspecified damages for minority shareholders and is also suing China Forestry, its former chairman, and CEO. The regulator is tightening oversight of banks involved in IPOs after recent losses.

site_title: Don't over-react to the prospects of sector-wide O&G recovery
summary: Analysts OCBC and Deutsche Bank predict a sector-wide oil and gas recovery in 2017, driven by rising oil prices and sanctioned offshore projects. However, Barclays notes that offshore spending may fall 20-25% in 2017, and excess capacity will hinder the recovery of the O&G ancillary industry. Investors should focus on qualitative factors such as management team values and relationships with lenders and creditors to identify survivors and winners in the sector.

site_title: A new sheriff comes to Washington, and the residents are afraid
summary: A new US president, Donald Trump, is set to take office, but unlike previous inaugurations, there is no honeymoon period of love and forgiveness for him. In fact, a recent Washington Post/ABC News poll shows that 54% of Americans have an unfavorable view of Trump, with 40% having a favorable impression. This stark contrast to previous presidents, including Obama, who enjoyed high favorability ratings on Inauguration Day. The president-elect's divisive rhetoric, including attacks on the media and his critics, has fueled public discontent, leading to widespread protests and a boycott of the inauguration ceremony.

site_title: Aramco CEO says oil tax will be cut to attract investors to IPO
summary: Saudi Arabia plans to cut the tax rate for its national oil company, Saudi Arabian Oil Co (Aramco), to attract investors to its 2018 initial public offering (IPO), which is expected to be one of the largest in history. CEO Amin Nasser declined to specify the tax rate, but said the fiscal regime will be changed to align with other listed companies. Aramco pays a 20% royalty and 85% tax on income, and will offer 5% of its shares in the IPO. The IPO is part of Saudi Arabia's Vision 2030 plan to diversify its economy and reduce its reliance on hydrocarbons.

site_title: Swensen's parent firm to acquire catering group
summary: ABR Holdings, the parent firm of Swensen's in Singapore, has announced its proposed acquisition of catering group Chilli Padi. The acquisition aims to enhance ABR's F&B portfolio and expand its revenue base. The deal involves the purchase of Chilli Api Catering, Chilli Padi Nonya Catering, and Chilli Padi Nonya Restaurant, with the consideration to be paid in cash based on the audited net profit of Chilli Padi Group for its financial year ended December 31, 2016. The acquisition is seen as a strategic move to boost ABR's revenue and presence in the market.

site_title: Change money virtually with DBS, Visa scheme
summary: DBS and Visa have launched an overseas payment solution for travellers and online shoppers, allowing customers to hold and convert money in 12 currencies, including the Singapore dollar, using the DBS Visa Debit card and Multi-Currency Account. This feature enables customers to lock in a specific exchange rate and make payments in the local currency, providing greater flexibility and control over their transactions.

images.alt_text: From left: DBS Bank head of cards & unsecured loans Anthony Seow, Visa group country manager for regional South-east Asia Tolan Steele, Visa country manager for Singapore and Brunei Ooi Huey Tyng, DBS head of deposits & secured loans P'ing Lim, and DBS head of consumer banking group (Singapore) Jeremy Soo.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: SIIC Environment maintains a "buy" rating despite possible dilution from a share placement. The company is expanding its water treatment portfolio with good growth potential and grabbing opportunities in the sludge treatment market. DBS Group Research expects the company to continue making progress and maintain its growth momentum.

site_title: Capital curbs push China firms to risky, costly debt
summary: Chinese companies, including state firms, are raising record amounts of foreign-currency bonds in Hong Kong and other offshore locations to support the yuan and cool the hot property market. Despite the yuan's nearly 7% slump against the dollar in 2016, companies like Bank of China raised a record $111 billion in offshore dollar bonds, up from $88 billion in 2015. The government's efforts to bring dollars back onshore and ease depreciation pressure on the yuan are encouraging more issuers to take on extra cost and risk.

site_title: Global growth outlook shaky on trade protectionism fears-Reuters poll
summary: A Reuters poll found the global economic outlook remains shaky due to rising protectionist trade policies, which would hamper growth. Uncertainty is heightened by election changes in major euro zone countries and rising nationalist sentiment worldwide. The poll also highlighted concerns about potential disruptions to the global economy, with the UK economy shrinking for the second month in a row. Economists cited a rise in nationalist sentiment, exemplified by Brexit and Donald Trump's US election victory, as major concerns for the global economic revival.

site_title: A new type of debt crisis is brewing now
summary: A new type of debt crisis is brewing globally, characterized by multiple borrowers succumbing to ultra-cheap credit from central banks. Global debt has reached $217 trillion, or 325% of global GDP, with the heaviest burden in mature economies. As interest rates rise, the cost of servicing debt may outpace borrowers' ability to repay, especially in emerging markets. A new debt crisis could emerge as companies face refinancing needs and credit dries up, with a high risk of downgrade and default.

site_title: PM May's exit strategy holds up pound but political risks loom large
summary: The pound has strengthened against major counterparts following Prime Minister Theresa May's promise to seek a customs agreement with the EU to deliver a "smooth and orderly Brexit". However, strategists and fund managers warn that the currency's 17% slump since the Brexit vote has ensured much of the bad news is priced in, and the UK's widening current-account deficit adds to its vulnerability. Despite predictions of a further 10% weakening, some experts believe the worst is over, while others remain bearish on sterling for the coming months due to ongoing political uncertainty.

images.alt_text: Sterling strengthened against all major counterparts on Tuesday after Ms May pledged to quit the single market and instead seek a customs agreement with the bloc to deliver "a smooth and orderly Brexit".

site_title: HSBC CEO says activities generating 20% of London revenue may move
summary: HSBC CEO Stuart Gulliver said that 20% of the bank's London-based investment bank revenue, approximately 1,000 jobs, may move to Paris due to Brexit. Gulliver praised Prime Minister Theresa May's handling of Brexit, while expressing concerns about a trade war between the US and China, which could harm HSBC. He believes London will remain a global financial center and expects the UK financial services industry to rebound quickly, with some derivatives operations potentially moving.

site_title: CCT flags rental pressure amid stiff rivalry
summary: Capitaland Commercial Trust (CCT) posted a 10.1% jump in quarterly distributable income per unit (DPU) due to higher contributions from CapitaGreen and Raffles City Singapore. However, the company faces negative rental reversions amid a short-term office oversupply and intense competition. Despite this, CapitaGreen is expected to support stable distributions in 2017, according to its trustee-manager CEO Lynette Leong.

site_title: Park Hotel Group to launch new mid-scale brand
summary: Park Hotel Group will launch a new mid-scale brand, Destination, in Singapore in Q2 this year. The 15-story, 300-room hotel, Destination Singapore Beach Road, will be the group's sixth hotel in the city. The brand, positioned as a select-service, mid-scale option, will offer "quality and affordable accommodation" in prime locations. Park Hotel Group plans to expand Destination to major cities across the Asia Pacific, with plans to open a total of four hotels this year, boosting its portfolio to 16 hotels in eight countries.

site_title: ST Electronics to pick up 51% stake in SPTel
summary: ST Electronics to acquire a 51% stake in SPTel, Singapore's fibre optic back-haul infrastructure provider, for S$54 million (up to S$60 million). SPTel will retain a 49% stake. The deal aims to enhance ST Electronics' connectivity offerings and data centre services.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Delong Holdings' subsidiary Aoyu Steel may be required to reduce steelmaking output due to China's plans to reduce Hebei Province's steelmaking capacity. Sino Grandness agreed to sell its own-brand products on a Chinese e-commerce platform, expanding its online distribution network. Delong shares finished unchanged, while Sino Grandness shares rose half a cent.

site_title: UK envoy: Post-Brexit UK will push for better trade pacts with S'pore
summary: British High Commissioner to Singapore Scott Wightman stated that post-Brexit, the UK will pursue better trade pacts with Singapore, likening the UK to a "hungry, daring country" ready to explore deeper collaborations. Wightman identified areas for deeper collaboration, including trade, finance, and innovation. This move aims to capitalize on the UK's newfound freedom to negotiate trade agreements with countries it previously could not due to EU membership.

site_title: Small businesses here looking to hire despite economic challenges
summary: Small businesses in the Asia-Pacific region are expected to grow and hire more staff despite economic challenges. A study by CPA Australia found that 75% of businesses in the region plan to increase their workforce this year. The study also found that businesses are optimistic about growth, with 63% expecting an increase in sales. The Singapore segment of the findings was released ahead of the official release of the report. The study's findings contradict the pessimistic outlook on the economy, suggesting that businesses are resilient and optimistic about the future.

images.alt_text: Singapore was the seventh most optimistic country of the eight markets surveyed, with over half (51 per cent) of the respondents here saying that they expect their businesses to grow in the next 12 months.

site_title: US: Dow on track for fourth straight day of losses
summary: The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell for the fourth consecutive trading day, down 41.37 points or 0.21%, at 19,785.4, ahead of Federal Reserve Chair Janet Yellen's speech. Investors are also awaiting President-elect Donald Trump's inaugural speech for insight into his economic plans. Despite a rally in the S&P 500 and Nasdaq, uncertainty over Trump's policies is causing market fatigue, with some analysts giving him the benefit of the doubt.

site_title: S'pore boosts water security with 5th NEWater plant
summary: Singapore has opened its fifth NEWater plant, adding 228,000 cubic meters of high-grade recycled water to its water supply, mainly for industrial purposes. The plant, built by a 80-20 joint venture between Chinese water utilities company BEWG International and Singapore environmental engineering firm UES Holdings, will meet up to 40% of the Republic's total daily water demand. The project marks the first major contract for BEWG International outside of China and is part of Singapore's efforts to strengthen its water security and sustainability.

site_title: Audiobooks see boom in digital, multitasking age
summary: Audiobook sales have seen a significant boom, with 35,574 titles released in the US in 2015, an eight-fold increase over five years, reaching $1.77 billion in sales. The market is dominated by Amazon's Audible, with around 119,000 audiobooks sold daily in 2016. Most major publishers now have dedicated audiobook teams, and the format is becoming increasingly popular for multitasking and relaxation, with some authors even recording their own audiobooks. Audiobooks account for 10% of print sales, with higher figures for genres like science fiction and self-help.

site_title: Singapore Myanmar Investco warns of potential complaint to Singapore court by its joint venture partner
summary: Singapore Myanmar Investco (SMI) has warned that its joint venture partner, Golden Infrastructure Group (GIG), plans to submit a criminal complaint to Singapore's State Courts against SMI's directors and management over alleged breaches of a joint venture agreement. The complaint centers on SMI's planned divestment of its 97% stake in Myanmar Infrastructure Group to Shining Star International Holdings for US$12.7 million. SMI intends to vigorously refute the complaint and proceed with the share transfer according to contractual provisions.

site_title: Sotheby's spots another Old Master fake
summary: Sotheby's has determined a painting attributed to 16th-century Italian artist Parmigianino is a modern fake. The painting, "St Jerome", was sold at a 2012 auction for $842,500. Testing revealed it contained 20th-century pigments, including phthalocyanine green. This is the second fake found by Sotheby's, following a similar case involving a Frans Hals painting. The buyer will receive a full refund, and Sotheby's is seeking $672,000 in damages from the seller, Lionel de Saint Donat-Pourrières.

site_title: US industrial output rises 0.8 per cent as utilities surge
summary: US industrial production rose 0.8% in December, driven by a 6.6% surge in utilities output, the largest jump since 1989. This rebounded from a 0.7% decline in November. Manufacturing output edged up 0.2%, while mining production remained unchanged. Overall, the 0.6% annual decline in the fourth quarter was lower than expected. The increase in industrial capacity use to 75.5% may signal further economic acceleration before sparking higher inflation.

site_title: Top 4 most expensive cities are in Asia
summary: The top 4 most expensive cities in the world are in Asia, with Hong Kong, Mumbai, Beijing, and Shanghai taking the top spots. It takes over 30 years for a household with the local median income to buy a 90 square meter apartment in these cities. Low rental yields and stretched valuations in these cities suggest a moderation in housing price increases in the coming years, according to Oxford Economics. Rising interest rates and a shift in global economic trends will also put downward pressure on property prices.

site_title: Mastercard preying on 46m consumers sparks £14b lawsuit
summary: Mastercard is facing a £14 billion class-action lawsuit in a London court, alleging the company unfairly charged card fees to over 46 million consumers in the UK between 1992 and 2008. Lawyers claim Mastercard infringed EU competition law by imposing high charges to retailers that accepted its cards. A two-day hearing will decide whether the case goes to trial, which would be the UK's biggest class-action under the Consumer Rights Act 2015.

site_title: Sembcorp inks agreement for gas-fired power plant in Myanmar
summary: Sembcorp Industries has signed a build-operate-transfer (BOT) agreement with Myanmar's Ministry of Electricity and Energy for a 225-megawatt gas-fired power plant in Mandalay. The $300 million project, expected to be operational in the near future, will help meet Myanmar's growing electricity demand. Under the agreement, Sembcorp will build and operate the plant for 22 years before transferring it to the Myanmar government. The signing marks a key milestone for the project and is not expected to impact Sembcorp's earnings.

site_title: Yahoo Japan refuses to put end to ivory sales online, says trade is legal
summary: Yahoo Japan, the country's largest online auction site, refuses to end online ivory sales, citing that the trade is legal. Despite a sharp rise in poaching of African elephants, Yahoo Japan argues that the ivory business does not contribute to the decline in elephant numbers. The company, which earns a tiny fraction of its revenue from ivory sales, claims it wants to provide an internet auction site where people can trade freely. Yahoo Japan's parent company, Yahoo Inc., has met with its CEO to express concerns, but has not taken action to end the trade.

site_title: Earth breaks heat record in 2016 for third year in a row
summary: The Earth experienced its third consecutive year of record-breaking temperatures in 2016, with a global average temperature 1.69°F (0.94°C) above the 20th century average. This surpassed the previous record in 2015, and was confirmed by both NASA and NOAA. The main contributors to this warming trend are the burning of fossil fuels and the Pacific Ocean warming trend of El Nino, with human influence on climate being the primary cause. The effects of this warming include melting sea ice, increased heavy rainfall and drought, and rising sea levels, posing significant threats to global communities and ecosystems.

site_title: Ley Choon receives in-principle approval from SGX for transfer to Catalist board
summary: Ley Choon Group Holdings has received in-principle approval from the Singapore Exchange to transfer from the Mainboard to the Catalist board, subject to shareholders' approval. The move aims to better position the company for attracting investors and aligns with the business, market capitalization, and risk profile of Catalist-listed companies. This decision was made in November last year, with the board citing the need for a more suitable platform to grow and expand. The company's transfer to the Catalist board is expected to be completed once the necessary conditions are met.

site_title: Consumer prices in US rise for fifth month on shelter, fuel
summary: US consumer prices rose 0.3% in December, matching economists' projections, for the fifth consecutive month. The year-over-year increase was 2.1%, the largest since June 2014. Rising energy costs, shelter, and medical expenses contributed to the inflation. The core CPI measure, excluding food and fuel, rose 0.2%. The Federal Reserve is expected to continue raising interest rates, with inflation near its 2% target and unemployment below 5%.

site_title: Deutsche Bank said to scrap senior bankers' bonuses for 2016
summary: Deutsche Bank will inform senior employees that they likely won't receive a bonus for 2016 due to poor performance, which includes a 23% slump in its share price and rising litigation costs. The decision, made at the end of last year, is separate from a $7.2 billion settlement with the US Justice Department. While most junior employees have already transitioned to fixed salaries, top performers will receive retention bonuses. The move is part of CEO John Cryan's efforts to shore up profitability and capital buffers after a tumultuous 2016.

images.alt_text: Deutsche Bank AG will tell senior employees as soon as this week that they probably won't get a bonus for 2016 because of the lender's performance last year, according to a person familiar with the decision.

site_title: Vale's top shareholders weigh unifying stock structure
summary: Top shareholders of Vale SA are discussing merging the company's dual-class stock structure, converting all shares to common shares and extending voting rights to all shareholders. The new agreement could be valid for up to six years, a reduction from the current 20-year period. The discussions aim to renew a shareholder accord set to expire at the start of the next quarter. Vale declined to comment on the negotiations.

site_title: Park Hotel Group to launch new select service brand Destination on Beach Road
summary: Park Hotel Group will launch Destination, a new 300-room select-service hotel, on Beach Road in Singapore's second quarter. The brand aims to offer quality and affordable accommodation in prime locations across the Asia-Pacific. Destination is part of Park Hotel Group's portfolio, which also includes luxury Grand Park and upscale Park Hotel. This marks the brand's expansion into major cities, with plans for Destination to be positioned as a mid-scale brand.

site_title: Share placement to private investors by Ipco International falls through
summary: Ipco International announced that its placement of 1.06 billion new shares to private investors fell through due to the long stop date expiring and remaining placees terminating their agreements. The placement aimed to raise S$1.86 million in net proceeds, with plans to use half for general corporate requirements and the rest for working capital. As a result, Ipco shares closed at 0.2 cent, down 33.3% from the previous day. The company will continue to explore potential fund-raising opportunities.

site_title: Mastercard 'preying on millions' sparked £$14b fee lawsuit
summary: Mastercard is facing a £14 billion class-action lawsuit in the UK, alleging the company unfairly charged card fees to 46 million consumers between 1992 and 2008. Lawyers claim the company infringed EU competition law by imposing high charges on retailers. The case, if successful, would be the UK's biggest class action and one of the first under the Consumer Rights Act 2015. Mastercard disputes the lawsuit, stating that the level of damages is "impossible to assess" and that the awards would not "bear a reasonable relationship to their actual loss."

images.alt_text: Mastercard Inc preyed on more than 46 million unknowing consumers by unfairly charging card fees over a 16-year period, lawyers seeking to bring a £14 billion (S$24.53 billion) class-action lawsuit told a London court.

site_title: Drugmakers in Davos shift focus to chronic diseases of poor
summary: Global drugmakers, including Pfizer and Merck, are investing $50 million over three years to combat chronic diseases such as cancer in poor countries. The Access Accelerated initiative aims to improve treatment and prevention, shifting focus from infectious diseases. Non-communicable diseases, responsible for 70% of global deaths, are a major concern in low- and middle-income countries. The project will work with the World Bank and the Union for International Cancer Control to test new diagnostics and treatments in several cities, with the goal of institutionalizing cooperation and improving healthcare systems.

site_title: India RBI has pumped in 9.2 tln rupees of new notes - source
summary: The Reserve Bank of India (RBI) has injected 9.2 trillion rupees (S$192.2 billion) of new currency notes into the banking system to replace banned 500- and 1,000-rupee notes. The ban, implemented on November 8, 2016, removed 86% of the currency in circulation, but the RBI governor, Urjit Patel, failed to provide a figure for deposited notes and clarity on when the cash situation would normalize. The move aims to unearth unaccounted money, but the ban has disrupted economic activity, leading to a contraction in services industry and manufacturing activity.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: A Deutsche Bank forex trader in Singapore has pleaded guilty to 13 charges of cheating the bank in 2009. The Straits Times Index fell 12.55 points to 3,000.22, marking its third consecutive loss. Meanwhile, Singapore SMEs have the highest average annual exporting revenue of $2.21 million, surpassing the global average of $1.5 million. E-Shang has acquired an 80% indirect interest in Cambridge Industrial Trust manager. The global economy is expected to slow down, with China's GDP growth set to slow and the UK economy shrinking for the second month.

site_title: China Everbright Water divests stake in Qingdao Everbright Water Operating
summary: China Everbright Water sold a 50% stake in Qingdao Everbright Water Operating to Qingdao Water Group Co for 1.1886 million yuan. The stake, previously 99%, now falls to 49%, ceasing to be a subsidiary. The sale's value was appraised at 1.1886 million yuan as of Dec 31, 2015.

site_title: ST Electronics proposes to buy 51% stake in SPTel
summary: ST Electronics proposes to acquire a 51% stake in SPTel, a Singapore-based fibre optic infrastructure provider, from Singapore Power for S$54-60 million. The acquisition will be funded internally by ST Electronics and is subject to regulatory approvals. Upon closing, the parties will enter into a shareholders' agreement to regulate their rights and responsibilities. The transaction is expected to close by the second quarter of this year.

site_title: Philippines' Duterte won't declare martial law, but can if wants to
summary: Philippine President Rodrigo Duterte has ruled out declaring martial law, but maintains the power to do so if he wishes. Despite constitutional requirements, he believes he can override the constitution and has stated that the military disagrees with his decision. Congress and the Supreme Court can potentially revoke his declaration, but Duterte claims he has the authority to make the decision as president. His comments have sparked criticism from media outlets and opposition groups, with some accusing him of acting in an authoritarian manner.

site_title: A legacy challenge
summary: The article highlights several key business and economic news stories. A Japanese company's stock surged 6,000% amid a succession crisis, while Alibaba's stock faces a potential $100 billion rout due to a turf war. China's Xi signals a possible end to deflationary price wars, and Huawei seeks AI chip customers in the Middle East and South-east Asia. The US stock market reached fresh records despite ongoing trade tensions, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq edging higher. Meanwhile, US President Trump unveiled new tariff rates, including a 50% levy on Brazil.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close higher after yen rally stalls
summary: Tokyo stocks closed higher on Wednesday, reversing early losses, as a yen rally stalled. The benchmark Nikkei 225 index gained 0.43% to 18,894.37, while the Topix index rose 0.32% to 1,513.86. The gains were driven by bargain hunting.

site_title: Bangladesh backtracks on plan to cut oil product prices
summary: Bangladesh has reversed its plan to cut oil product prices, citing rising global crude oil markets. The country had initially planned to slash prices by up to 10% in phases after reducing rates by 10% in April. The decision comes as global oil prices have rebounded to around $55 a barrel, despite easing supply glut concerns. Bangladesh's demand for oil is growing due to a natural gas shortage, and the country imports 600,000 tonnes of oil annually for its sole refinery. The government has no plan to cut oil prices at present.

site_title: COE premiums stable
summary: COE premiums remained stable in the final bidding exercise for the November 2016 to January 2017 period, with Category A increasing to S$50,889, Category B decreasing to S$52,807, and Category E falling to S$52,600. Category C and D saw minimal changes. The new COE quota for February to April 2017 has yet to be announced. Overall, the mixed demand led to a stable premium environment.

site_title: Public Accounts Committee urges holistic solutions, stronger leadership to address lapses
summary: The Public Accounts Committee has urged a holistic approach and stronger leadership to address recurring lapses in public fund management. The committee reviewed Auditor-General's reports for 2016 and found issues with handling changes to contracted works despite existing safeguards. It also recommended proper training for officers handling public funds and sharing best practices across agencies. The committee's first report highlights the need for effective leadership and training to prevent such lapses.

site_title: China money market rate surges even as PBOC injects record funds
summary: China's benchmark money-market rate surged 35 basis points to 2.76% on Wednesday, the largest jump in two years, as the People's Bank of China injected a record 410 billion yuan. Demand for cash increased before the Lunar New Year holidays, with corporate tax payments adding pressure. The PBOC aims to maintain liquidity while preparing for potential tightening measures, according to analysts. The overnight repo rate rose to 2.50%, the highest since April 2015, while the onshore yuan strengthened against the US dollar.

site_title: China urges US not to allow Taiwan delegation to attend Trump inauguration
summary: China has urged the US not to allow a Taiwanese delegation to attend President-elect Donald Trump's inauguration, citing the "One China" policy. Trump has broken with precedent by taking a congratulatory call from Taiwan's President Tsai Ing-Wen, and has also expressed openness to negotiating the policy. A Taiwanese delegation, led by former premier Yu Shyi-Kun, will still attend the inauguration, according to Taiwan's Foreign Ministry.

site_title: Singapore's public healthcare system to regroup into three clusters
summary: Singapore's public healthcare system will regroup into three clusters from six regional health systems to improve services and future-proof it, with no impact on patients. The clusters will be: Central, Eastern, and Western regions, retaining existing health system names and retaining the full suite of healthcare services. The transition is expected to be completed by early 2018, allowing for better resource allocation and comprehensive patient care.

images.alt_text: SINGAPORE'S public healthcare system will be regrouped into three clusters from the existing six regional health systems to improve delivery of services and future-proof it.

site_title: Singapore shares close mixed, despite STI falling for 3rd straight day
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) fell for the third consecutive day, down 12.55 points to 3,000.22, due to selling in bank shares worth S$1.1 billion. Despite this, the session was mixed with 241 rises and 197 falls. Total turnover was 1.6 billion units worth S$1.1 billion, with banks accounting for 20.3% of the total.

site_title: Aramco CEO says oil tax will be cut to lure investors to IPO
summary: Saudi Arabia plans to reduce the tax rate for its national oil company, Aramco, to lure investors for its 2018 initial public offering (IPO), potentially one of the largest in history. Aramco's current tax rate is 20% royalty and 85% tax on income. CEO Amin Nasser said the company will maintain its concession, which includes the oil and gas reserves, and will not increase production capacity, but will expand refining capacity. The IPO is part of Saudi Arabia's Vision 2030 plan to diversify the economy and reduce reliance on hydrocarbons.

site_title: Some DBS customers can now skip forex fees, conversion charges for overseas spending
summary: DBS customers with a linked Multi-Currency Account (MCA) can now spend overseas in the local currency, avoiding foreign exchange and conversion fees. The Visa Debit Card holders can cover 11 major currencies. This new feature is available to eligible customers, providing a more convenient and cost-effective option for international transactions.

site_title: Owner of Swensen's to acquire Chilli Padi catering group
summary: ABR Holdings, the owner of Swensen's in Singapore, has announced the proposed acquisition of Chilli Padi catering group. The acquisition aims to enhance the F&B portfolio and expand revenue base. A memorandum of understanding was signed with the target companies' shareholders, Patricia Lee, Lee Boon Hwa, and Lee Cheng Watt, to acquire their entire shareholdings. The acquisition is expected to bring in an established brand into ABR's business and provide a new revenue stream. Details of the acquisition terms have not been disclosed.

images.alt_text: ABR Holdings, the food and beverage (F&B) company which owns and operates Swensen's in Singapore, announced on Wednesday its proposed acquisition of the catering group, Chilli Padi.

site_title: Deliveroo plans to hire 300 more technology workers in London
summary: Deliveroo plans to hire 300 more technology workers in London, expanding its tech team from 125 to 425, as it competes with rival companies in the food delivery sector. The new hires will focus on high-skill roles such as software engineering. This move comes as Deliveroo faces increased competition, including Amazon and Uber's expansion into the London market. The company's global orders grew 650% in 2016, despite posting losses of £18.1 million in 2015.

site_title: Europe: Stock markets rebound at open
summary: Europe's main stock markets rebounded at the start of trading on Wednesday, with London's FTSE 100 rising 0.5% to 7,256.31 points. The eurozone's Frankfurt DAX 30 index and Paris CAC 40 also gained 0.5% and 0.3% respectively. The rebound followed a 1.5% drop in the FTSE on Tuesday, which was driven by a stronger pound after British Prime Minister Theresa May's Brexit plans were outlined.

site_title: Straits Trading to buy residential property in Japan for 925m yen
summary: Straits Trading Company plans to buy a 14-storey rental residential property in Osaka, Japan, Splendid Namba II, for 925 million yen (S$11.6 million). The property has a 95% occupancy rate and is located near the metro line and prime shopping areas. The transaction aims to incorporate an income-producing asset into Straits Trading's portfolio of residential apartments in key Japanese cities.

images.alt_text: Property firm Straits Trading Company on Wednesday said it plans to buy for 925 million yen (S$11.6 million) the rights to a rental residential property in Osaka, Japan.

site_title: Hong Kong 'mini' flats boom as govt fails to rein in record-high prices
summary: In Hong Kong, nearly 200,000 residents live in tiny, partitioned apartments known as "mini flats" due to the government's inability to curb record-high property prices. These units, averaging 62.4 square feet, have become increasingly common, with 100,000 people under 35 occupying them. Median rents surged 10.5% to HK$4,200 in 2015, outpacing private home rent increases. There are no rent control or size restrictions in Hong Kong, allowing landlords to charge high prices.

site_title: China economic growth to slow slightly this year as policymakers focus on risks: poll
summary: China's economy is expected to expand 6.5% this year, a slight slowdown from 6.7% in 2016, as policymakers focus on containing increasing financial risks and excessive debt. The forecast is unchanged from October and marks the seventh straight year of slower growth. The yuan's weakening is complicating policy choices, and analysts expect inflation to average 2.2% in 2017 and 2018. The People's Bank of China is expected to keep interest rates unchanged and may lower reserve requirements to support the currency and curb capital outflows.

site_title: German jobless mystery explained as refugees hide in statistics
summary: Germany's unemployment rate remains low, falling to a quarter-century low despite over 1 million refugees arriving in the past two years. The country's labor market is tight, with output increasing at the fastest pace in five years, driven by private consumption and government expenditure on migrants. Refugees face significant barriers to integration, with many lacking language skills and qualifications, and it may take up to six years for them to complete education and training to become skilled workers. This resilience could be crucial for Chancellor Angela Merkel's re-election bid, with her immigration policy facing criticism from opponents.

site_title: Sino Grandness to expand online sales of food products
summary: Sino Grandness, a Chinese canned food seller, has agreed to sell its full range of own-brand products on the web platform Ji Shi Hui, run by LYZB E-Commerce. The move reflects the company's emphasis on expanding its online distribution network, with Chairman Huang Yupeng stating that online channels may become a key distribution channel in the future.

site_title: Malaysia: Stocks end 1.99 points higher
summary: Malaysia's stock market closed higher on Wednesday, with the Kuala Lumpur Composite Index gaining 1.99 points to 1,665.020. The index saw 1.88 billion lots traded, valued at RM1.64 billion. Gainers outpaced losers 431-366.

site_title: Delong says China unit to be affected by steelmaking cuts
summary: Delong Holdings' subsidiary, Aoyu Steel, may be affected by China's plans to reduce steelmaking capacity in Hebei Province by 31.86 million tonnes, primarily due to the closures of steelmaking facilities in cities such as Baoding. The reduction aims to address overcapacity and stabilize the market. Aoyu Steel, located in Baoding, may face challenges due to the province's plans.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks end sharply higher
summary: Hong Kong shares rallied 1.13% on Wednesday, driven by a pick-up in China's yuan and easing concerns about the world's second-largest economy. The Hang Seng Index closed at 23,098.26, while the Shanghai Composite Index gained 0.14%. In contrast, the Shenzhen Composite Index lost 0.45%. The rally followed recent outflows of cash from China.

site_title: Australia shares drift lower, NZ treads water
summary: Australian shares fell 0.36% to 20.62 points lower, while New Zealand's benchmark S&P/NZX 50 index remained flat at 0.05%. Australian financial stocks declined, with the "Big Four" banks experiencing losses, while healthcare giant CSL Limited and Qantas Airways also fell. In contrast, oil and gas giants Santos and Woodside Petroleum gained, and safe haven assets like gold prices rose. Consumer sentiment in Australia remained flat, while New Zealand's healthcare sector ended in positive territory.

site_title: China may allow foreign firms to launch IPOs
summary: China has granted approval in principle for foreign companies to launch IPOs and issue corporate bonds on its stock exchanges, in a move aimed at widening foreign financing channels. The decision comes as China prepares for the incoming US administration of President-elect Donald Trump, who has repeatedly blamed China for job losses. The State Council said foreign companies will face fewer restrictions in sectors such as services, manufacturing, and mining, in an effort to attract more foreign investment and counter protectionism. The move is part of China's broader liberalization pledges.

site_title: China steps up capital controls, tightens investment rules for state firms
summary: China has tightened controls on outbound investments by state firms, stepping up supervision and establishing a negative list of investment projects that centrally-controlled firms cannot invest in. The move aims to stem capital outflows and stabilize the yuan, which fell 7% last year. Companies must submit annual investment plans by March 10 and strengthen risk management of overseas assets. The regulations follow a series of measures to open the economy to foreign investment and address slowing economic growth.

images.alt_text: China issued regulatory rules on outbound investments by centrally-controlled state firms, the state asset regulator said on Wednesday, the latest move by Beijing to tighten controls on money moving out of the country and stabilise a faltering yuan.

site_title: US lobby says China protectionism fuelling foreign business pessimism
summary: A US business lobby in China reported that over 80% of its members believe foreign companies are less welcome in China than in the past, citing protectionism and restrictive policies. The American Chamber of Commerce in China's survey also found that companies are slowing investments and deprioritizing China as an investment destination due to concerns over barriers to market entry and rising costs. The chamber's members expressed little confidence in China's vows to open its markets, with only 17% expecting improved US-China relations in 2017.

site_title: Seoul: Won rises on Trump's US dollar comments
summary: South Korea's won rose 0.7% against the US dollar on Wednesday following US President-elect Donald Trump's comments expressing concerns about a stronger dollar. The won was quoted at 1,166.7 to the dollar. Meanwhile, South Korean shares fell 0.1% and foreign investors sold 19.2 billion won worth of Kospi shares. The comments and lingering anxiety over Samsung Group leader Jay Y Lee's potential arrest warrant contributed to the won's increase.

site_title: Gold falls with yen as haven-asset flight eases
summary: Gold prices fell for the first time in eight days as the flight to haven assets eased ahead of Donald Trump's inauguration. The yen also declined, while stocks in Hong Kong rallied. The US dollar rose after Federal Reserve comments, and emerging-market assets gained. Traders await Trump's implementation of policies, citing potential volatility. The Chicago Board Options Exchange Volatility Index rose 5.7% to its highest level this year.

site_title: Tennis: Federer wobbles but roars back to reach third round
summary: Roger Federer overcame a late slump to defeat American qualifier Noah Rubin 7-5, 6-3, 7-6(3) in the second round of the Australian Open. The Swiss tennis star, seeded 17th, faced two set points at 5-2 down in the third set but came back to take Rubin to a tiebreak. Federer then won the match on the first set point with a forehand, advancing to a third-round match against 10th seed Tomas Berdych. Federer's win was a confidence booster after a six-month absence from the game.

site_title: Caught red-handed: China province admits faking economic data
summary: A Chinese official admitted to faking economic data in Liaoning province from 2011 to 2014, contradicting long-held suspicions among overseas investors. The province's GDP figures were found to be false, with one county reporting revenues 127% higher than actual figures. This admission comes as China prepares to release its national growth estimates for 2016, highlighting a systemic problem with the country's economic data reporting. Officials and analysts have questioned the accuracy of Chinese economic figures, citing incentives for local bureaucrats to falsify data.

site_title: European officials welcome clarity on May's plan for Brexit talks
summary: European Union officials welcomed UK Prime Minister Theresa May's explanation of her Brexit plan, citing it as a "realistic" approach to the "sad process." German Foreign Minister Frank-Walter Steinmeier said the plan provided "a bit more clarity" on Britain's stance, while EU President Donald Tusk described it as a "realistic" approach. However, other officials expressed concerns over May's plan to pull out of the EU's single market, with Steinmeier's committee set to meet to agree on the UK's negotiating position.

site_title: Hong Kong has "no room" for independence from China, says HK leader
summary: Hong Kong's chief executive, Leung Chun-Ying, stated that the city has "no room" for independence from China in his annual policy blueprint. This comes after growing calls from activists for Hong Kong to become independent. Leung, set to step down after a five-year tenure, emphasized that Hong Kong's autonomy under the "one country, two systems" arrangement is non-negotiable. The city's high degree of autonomy, granted in 1997, is expected to remain intact despite Leung's comments.

site_title: Bollywood's Salman Khan cleared in illegal arms case
summary: Indian court acquits Bollywood superstar Salman Khan of using unlicensed firearms to kill protected wildlife in 1998, after nearly two decades. He was charged under two sections of the Arms Act but cleared due to lack of conclusive evidence. Khan still faces a fourth case on charges of poaching black bucks. The actor had accused the state forest department of framing him in the case, but was acquitted in three out of four cases filed against him.

images.alt_text: An Indian court on Wednesday acquitted Bollywood superstar Salman Khan of using unlicensed firearms to kill protected wildlife almost two decades ago, a lawyer said.

site_title: Australia sells A$9.3b of bonds in biggest-ever sale
summary: Australia sold its largest-ever bond, A$9.3 billion, maturing in December 2021, despite concerns over its credit rating and budget deficit. The sale eclipsed the previous record of A$7.6 billion and was priced to yield 2.24%. The move follows a recovery in investor appetite for debt, which has brought down three-year bond yields to 1.97%. The sale is part of the government's plan to increase its debt to A$498 billion by the end of June and A$600 million in the 2019-20 financial year.

site_title: Trump's UN pick to echo his criticism of world body, offer some praise
summary: Nikki Haley, Donald Trump's UN ambassador pick, will echo Trump's criticism of the UN's treatment of Israel during her Senate confirmation hearing. Haley, a former South Carolina governor, praised some UN work, including aid programs and peacekeeping missions, but criticized the organization's waste, corruption, and failure to prevent the North Korean nuclear threat. Despite her lack of foreign policy experience, Haley expects strong support from Republicans and has fans at the UN, where she will represent the US in the coming years.

images.alt_text: Donald Trump's pick for UN ambassador will echo his condemnation of the world body's treatment of Israel at her Senate confirmation hearing on Wednesday, although offering some praise for an organisation the president-elect has disparaged.

site_title: Singapore SMEs that export have the highest average revenue: survey
summary: Singaporean small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) that export to overseas markets have the highest average annual exporting per-company-revenue of US$2.21 million, surpassing the global average of US$1.5 million. Exports account for up to 87% of SMEs' overall revenue, with intra and inter-regional exports in key sectors driving the highest average annual revenue of US$2.56 million globally.

site_title: Europeans ask May: Where is the give for all this take?
summary: European leaders praised Theresa May for outlining her plan for a "hard Brexit," but expressed concerns about the economic costs of Britain's departure from the EU's single market. May proposed a "global Britain" with a free trade agreement, but EU leaders warned that this would require "give and take" and "compromises" on issues like tariffs and access to the single market. The EU's Guy Verhofstadt said a deal that benefits Britain at the expense of the EU would be unacceptable, while May's finance minister Philip Hammond warned that Britain would do whatever it takes to maintain its competitiveness.

images.alt_text: European leaders applauded Theresa May for providing clarity by finally outlining her plan for a clean break with the EU, but said she needed to be realistic about the price Britain would pay for leaving.

site_title: Asia: Stocks up as Trump's dollar comment boosts exporters; sterling shines
summary: Asian stock markets rose 0.3% near three-month highs on January 18, 2017, following US President-elect Donald Trump's comments on the US dollar, which boosted exporter shares. Hong Kong and Chinese stocks led the gains, while the British pound consolidated its 3% gain from the previous session. Investors remained cautious due to concerns over China's economic growth, with some predicting a slowdown in the second quarter. The US dollar weakened, and gold prices rose to a two-month high.

site_title: Taiwan: Stocks track Wall Street lower; financials weigh
summary: Taiwan's stocks fell 0.2% on Wednesday, tracking overnight weakness on Wall Street and pressure from financials such as Cathay Financial Holding. The electronics subindex dropped 0.1%, while the financials subindex lost 0.5%. The main Taiex index closed at 9,338.14 points.

site_title: e-Shang acquires 80% indirect interest in Cambridge Industrial Trust manager
summary: e-Shang Infinity Cayman Limited, a subsidiary of e-Shang Redwood Limited (ESR), has agreed to acquire an 80% indirect interest in Cambridge Industrial Trust Management Limited, the manager of Cambridge Industrial Trust (CIT), and a 100% indirect interest in Cambridge Industrial Property Management, the property manager of CIT. The transaction is expected to be completed within the week. The deal marks e-Shang's entry into the Singapore real estate market and is seen as a strategic expansion of its presence in the country.

site_title: China's yuan weakens as companies load up on cheaper US dollars
summary: China's yuan weakened against the US dollar, reaching a two-month high of 6.8525 per dollar, as companies bought up US currency amid a broad decline in the dollar. The People's Bank of China fixed the midpoint at this level, nearly 0.7% stronger than the previous fix. This move came after US President-elect Donald Trump's comments that the US dollar may be "too strong", which pressured the dollar index to a six-week low.

site_title: China tells local meteorological bureaus to stop smog alerts
summary: China has suspended local meteorological bureaus from issuing smog alerts, sparking concerns the government is suppressing information about air pollution. The Meteorological Administration notified bureaus to stop issuing smog alerts, replacing them with "fog" alerts for visibility less than 10 km. The move has raised suspicions about the government's intentions amid growing public anger over air pollution issues.

images.alt_text: China is suspending local meteorological bureaus from issuing smog alerts, media reported Wednesday, raising suspicions the government is attempting to suppress information about the country's air pollution as public anger over the issue grows.

site_title: Broker's take: CCT gets boost from higher stake in CapitaGreen, says OCBC
summary: Capitaland Commercial Trust (CCT) reported Q4 2016 results within expectations, driven by increased contributions from its 100% stake in CapitaGreen. Distributable income rose 10.1% to 2.39 Singapore cents, and gross revenues and net property income increased 32.7% and 35.4% to S$89.7 million and S$70.8 million, respectively. OCBC maintains a "hold" on CCT, increasing its fair value estimate to S$1.53.

site_title: New York governor wants to spend more on education, lower taxes
summary: New York Governor Andrew Cuomo proposed a $152.3 billion state budget for 2018, increasing education funding by $1 billion and cutting taxes for 6 million middle-class residents. The budget includes $2 billion for water infrastructure and $650 million for life sciences research. To offset costs, Cuomo plans to keep a 8.82% tax rate on individuals making over $1 million and extend a "millionaire's tax" to pay for education and other initiatives. The budget aims to close a $3.5 billion deficit and sets a 2% spending growth cap.

site_title: Ex-Deutsche Bank forex trader in Singapore admits cheating bank
summary: A former Deutsche Bank forex trader in Singapore, Toh Hway Khuan, pleaded guilty to 13 charges of making false trades to gain preferential rates on the US dollar in 2009. The charges involve buying and selling over $250 million without disclosing his beneficial ownership. Toh faces up to seven years in prison and a fine. The case occurred around the time of a review of foreign-exchange market rigging and led to significant fines for lenders worldwide. Toh will be sentenced at a later date.

site_title: Bayer-Monsanto pledge investment, jobs after Trump meeting
summary: Bayer AG and Monsanto Co have pledged to invest $8 billion in the US and create 3,000 new jobs if their planned merger, the largest in agriculture, receives regulatory approval. The companies, led by CEO Werner Baumann and Hugh Grant, previously committed to keeping Monsanto's headquarters in St. Louis. The new job commitment follows a meeting with President-elect Donald Trump and his aides in New York.

site_title: Jobless dad-of-six welcomes Finland's basic income trial
summary: Finland launched a two-year experiment on January 1, 2017, providing 2,000 unemployed individuals with a monthly unconditional payment of 560 euros. The universal basic income test aims to reduce bureaucracy and encourage people to find work. If successful, the plan could be rolled out nationwide, but details on the exact amount and conditions remain unclear. The trial is part of Finland's efforts to address poverty and provide a fresh start for those struggling to find employment.

images.alt_text: For just one hour of work, Juha Jarvinen had to fill out piles of paperwork only to see his unemployment insurance docked.

site_title: Cash is king for diamond market reeling from India money war
summary: The diamond market is struggling due to India's war on black money, causing a cash crunch and impacting the global industry. De Beers, the world's top diamond producer, is offering concessions to customers to support the market, which has been hit hard with 90% of rough diamonds passing through India. The US$14 billion industry is reeling from the effects of India's currency reforms, which have reduced demand for diamonds.

site_title: Helicopters save NZ cherries for China in Lunar New Year rush
summary: New Zealand cherry producers are using helicopters to dry off raindrops and protect their product from damage as it's shipped to Asia for the Lunar New Year rush. The country's cherry exports, worth NZ$43 million last year, are expected to grow to around NZ$50 million this season, with China becoming the second-largest destination after Taiwan. The increased demand is driven by the growing popularity of cherries in Asia, particularly in China, which takes around 60% of New Zealand's cherry exports.

site_title: One in four targeted cyber attacks succeed, but S'pore companies still confident about security: Accenture survey
summary: Singapore companies remain confident in their ability to protect themselves from cyber attacks, despite one in four targeted breaches succeeding. The average organisation in Singapore faces up to 138 targeted cyber attacks per year, with 35% focusing less on protecting customer information. Only 8% of Singapore companies plan to invest in cyber security training, lower than the global average of 17%. However, 30% of organisations in Singapore plan to increase their cyber security investment "significantly" in the next three years.

site_title: Australian PM resists major cabinet reshuffle as he names new health minister
summary: Australian Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull resisted a major cabinet reshuffle, naming Greg Hunt as the new health minister to replace Sussan Ley, who resigned amid an expenses scandal. Ley claimed expenses for a visit to the Gold Coast, where she purchased an investment property, and taxpayers paid A$13,000 for private flights. Turnbull chose Hunt over a potential return of former PM Tony Abbott, citing Hunt's strategic value to the party. The move is seen as a minor tweak, with recent polls showing the centre-right government trailing the Labour opposition.

site_title: Singapore stocks fall at opening
summary: Singapore stocks fell on Wednesday, with the Straits Times Index down 13.85 points to 2,998.92. Volume was 36.6 million shares worth S$21.4 million. Losers outnumbered gainers 45 to 43. This marks the first decline in five days as investors await GDP data.

site_title: Trump supporters flock to Washington for inaugural
summary: Thousands of Trump supporters are converging on Washington for the presidential inauguration, despite rain and security concerns.
