The deal marks BAT's return to the US market after a 12-year absence, and CEO Nicandro Durante expects it to drive "sustained profit growth and returns for shareholders."

images.alt_text: British American Tobacco agreed Tuesday to pay almost US$50 billion for control of US firm Reynolds American, creating the world's largest listed tobacco company.

site_title: Seoul: Won recovers as firmer Chinese yuan helps mood, stocks rise
summary: The South Korean won strengthened 0.6% against the US dollar, closing at 1,174.5 won per dollar. South Korean shares rose, with Samsung Electronics rebounding 0.8% after a Monday decline. The Korea Composite Stock Price Index (Kospi) closed up 0.4% at 2,071.87 points. Foreign investors sold 8.4 billion won worth of Kospi shares, but overall market sentiment remained positive.

site_title: Australia shares burdened by banks, NZ gives ground
summary: Australian shares declined 0.9% on Tuesday, led by the "Big 4" banks, while New Zealand shares fell 0.2% due to a broader market downturn. The UK's planned exit from the EU, or "Brexit," sparked concerns of a "Hard Brexit" which has negatively impacted global risk assets. Iron ore prices pulled back, affecting mining heavyweights, while gold prices rose as investors sought safe havens.

site_title: Update: Singapore wealth fund said to hit snag on Vietnam deal approval
summary: Singapore's sovereign fund GIC has hit a snag in its planned investment in Vietnam's largest lender, Bank for Foreign Trade of Vietnam JSC, due to government disapproval. The deal, expected to be completed by the end of 2016, has been delayed as the government withheld approval over GIC's proposed stock purchase at a discount. The proposed deal would have given GIC a 7.7% stake in the bank, valued at under $400 million. The Vietnamese government has not made a final decision to block the deal, and GIC may reapply for approval.

site_title: ECB sees euro zone bank lending growing in first quarter
summary: The European Central Bank's quarterly survey found that euro zone banks expect loan demand to rise and credit standards to ease in the first quarter of 2017, driven by expanding economic activity. Lending to companies grew at its fastest pace since the global financial crisis, while household lending reached a multi-year high. The survey also showed that credit standards were broadly unchanged, despite a modest tightening in the Netherlands. The ECB's stimulus measures have been effective, with inflation rising to 1.1% in December, but the central bank will likely keep its policy stance unchanged at its next meeting on January 19.

site_title: Hyundai Motor to boost US investment as automakers respond to Trump
summary: Hyundai Motor Group plans to boost US investment by 50% to $3.1 billion over five years, with a potential new US plant, as President-elect Donald Trump threatens to tax imported vehicles. The move follows similar announcements from Toyota, Ford, and Fiat Chrysler to revive US industrial jobs. Hyundai's president, Chung Jin-haeng, denies the plan is driven by Trump's pressure, citing improved demand for US cars under the new president. The investment will retool existing US factories and boost research on self-driving cars and future technologies.

images.alt_text: The Hyundai Motor Group said it plans to lift US investment by 50 per cent to US$3.1 billion over five years and may build a new US plant - the latest auto firm to announce fresh spending after President-elect Donald Trump threatened to tax imports.

site_title: Canadian small business lending rose after US election
summary: Canadian small business lending increased in November, with the PayNet Canadian Small Business Lending Index rising to 119.9 from 116.5 in October. Lending to medium-sized firms also increased to 218.3 from 211.3. The uptick in lending is attributed to the removal of uncertainty following the US election, with PayNet President Bill Phelan stating that companies feel more confident in their prospects. Despite this, uncertainties surrounding US President-elect Donald Trump's policies remain.

site_title: German investor confidence back on rise in January
summary: German investor confidence rose 2.8 points to 16.6 points in January, defying eurozone uncertainty. The ZEW institute's index improved due to eurozone economy growth and a positive GDP report from 2016. The German economy grew at 1.9% in 2016, its fastest rate since 2011. Despite remaining below its long-run average, the rising index is encouraging, suggesting optimism about the German economy's future.

images.alt_text: Confidence among investors in Europe's largest economy, Germany, picked up in January, a closely-watched survey showed Tuesday, defying political uncertainty across the eurozone.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks rise amid caution before May's speech, Trump inauguration
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose 0.5% to 22,840.97 points on Tuesday, rebounding from the previous day's biggest one-day loss in a month. Investors awaited British Prime Minister Theresa May's Brexit speech and the US presidential inauguration of Donald Trump. Industrial stocks led gains, rising 1.1%.

site_title: Singapore shares finish mixed in thin trading
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) ended Tuesday at 3,012.77, down 0.35 points from the previous day, with thin trading volume of 1.9 billion units worth S$773 million. The mixed performance was attributed to concerns over the US presidential inauguration and the UK's potential hard Brexit. Despite this, the STI has been on a 5-day rally, and investors remain positive despite tariff uncertainty and split Federal Reserve views.

site_title: Indonesia's Pertamina looks to US for LPG imports
summary: Indonesia's state energy company Pertamina plans to import liquefied petroleum gas (LPG) from the US to meet growing demand, with US shipments expected to increase following the Panama Canal's expansion. The company aims to import 5 million tonnes of LPG in 2017, a 13% increase from last year. Indonesia's domestic LPG production has dropped to 2.24 million tonnes, with the majority coming from the Bontang LNG refinery in East Kalimantan province. The increased imports are expected to reduce the proportion of Middle East imports.

site_title: Taiwan simulates China attacks as tension rises
summary: Taiwan began two days of military drills simulating a China attack on January 17, 2017, amid deteriorating relations with Beijing. The drills, which included combat skills with tanks and artillery, aimed to reassure the public. Defence spokesman Chen Chung-chi stated that the military would enhance training throughout the year to address the situation in the Taiwan Strait and South China Sea. The exercises were a response to rising tensions between the two sides.

images.alt_text: Taiwan began two days of military drills Tuesday simulating an attack by China as the government sought to reassure the public in the face of deteriorating relations with Beijing.

site_title: Etihad, Lufthansa in talks to merge airlines: paper
summary: Lufthansa and Etihad Airways are in talks to merge, with Lufthansa potentially taking a 30-40% stake in Etihad. The two airlines aim to create a carrier with 97 million passengers a year. This potential merger could impact loss-making Alitalia, which Etihad owns 49%. The talks follow Lufthansa's integration of 38 leased planes from Air Berlin, also owned by Etihad, and its takeover of Brussels Airlines.

site_title: Philippines defence minister says China arms on islands worrying
summary: Philippines Defence Minister Delfin Lorenzana expressed concern over China's recent installation of weapons on artificial islands in the disputed South China Sea, describing the actions as "very troubling" and contradicting Beijing's peaceful rhetoric. The Philippines had previously sent a note verbale to China's embassy after confirming China's arms buildup in the Spratlys, a disputed territory within the country's exclusive economic zone. The move highlights the Philippines' delicate balancing act between upholding sovereignty claims and maintaining trade and investment ties with China.

site_title: Foxconn billionaire said to assuage China about US plans
summary: Foxconn Chairman Terry Gou has reassured China's government that the company remains committed to China despite expanding US operations under President-elect Donald Trump's administration. Gou told a Chinese official he won't withdraw capital from China and that the US investment plan is dependent on the incoming administration's policies. Foxconn, which hires roughly a million workers in China, will maintain its assembly business in the country, with some high-precision manufacturing potentially shifting to the US.

site_title: Oil prices dip as rising US output could offset Opec cuts
summary: Oil prices fell on Tuesday as rising US output and concerns over global fuel oversupply weighed on the market. Brent crude futures dropped 31 US cents to $55.55 per barrel, while US WTI crude futures fell 7 US cents to $52.30 per barrel. Despite Saudi Arabia's commitment to cut output, analysts remain skeptical about Opec's and Russia's willingness to fully comply with the cuts, citing potential oversupply and declining demand.

site_title: Vietnam seen closer to emerging upgrade with bank opening
summary: Vietnam's Prime Minister Nguyen Xuan Phuc announced plans to raise offshore ownership caps in banks, potentially speeding the country's emergence as an emerging-market economy. The move is expected to boost the stock market, which has surged 15% last year, and support Vietnam's bid to join MSCI's emerging-market index. Key lenders such as Vietnam Joint Stock Commercial Bank for Industry and Trade and Bank for Investment and Development of Vietnam saw significant gains, with the benchmark VN Index nearing a nine-year high.

site_title: K-pop star Rain to ring modest wedding bells
summary: K-pop star Rain, 34, announced his engagement to actress Kim Tae-Hee, 36, in a letter to fans, stating their wedding will be low-key due to South Korea's economic and political woes. The couple, who met in 2011, plans to wed at a Catholic church in Seoul with family members present. Rain, who has starred in several TV dramas and Hollywood films, was previously confined to barracks for sneaking out to meet Kim during his military service. The couple's wedding is expected to be a quiet, holy ceremony amidst the country's unstable national mood.

site_title: Bond market storm builds behind Wall Street's serene yield call
summary: The US bond market is expected to experience minimal change in yields for 2017, with the 10-year Treasury yield projected to rise to 2.75% by year-end, according to a median estimate of 62 strategists and economists. This forecast contrasts with concerns about the impact of President-elect Donald Trump's policies, which some believe will spark a reflation trade, and the US economy's slow growth. The bond market's resilience has been characterized by minimal fluctuations, similar to the 2008 period.

site_title: E.ON net income seen benefiting from nuclear provision transfer
summary: E.ON's transfer of 9.8 billion euros to a state fund to pay for nuclear sector liabilities will boost its underlying net income by 200-250 million euros per year. The German utility's share of the deal includes 7.8 billion euros of liabilities and a 2 billion euro risk premium. After dismantling its nuclear plants, E.ON will apply a lower discount rate, resulting in an additional annual after-tax benefit of about 215 million euros. The company will still be responsible for decommissioning its nuclear plants, for which it has set aside 9.7 billion euros.

site_title: Australia's Qantas grounds 10 aircraft on overdue inspections
summary: Qantas grounds 10 turboprop aircraft due to overdue inspections. The delay is attributed to confusion over inspecting bolts that were replaced following a Bombardier directive. The airline has rebooked affected customers on alternative flights and expects minimal disruption. No safety issues are involved, and the issue is classified as an administrative matter. QantasLink, which operates the 76-seat Q400s, has already begun returning aircraft to service after the problem was reported to the Civil Aviation Safety Authority.

site_title: Insurer Tokio Marine Life rolls out chatbot and app for advisers
summary: Tokio Marine Life Insurance Singapore launched TOMI, the industry's first self-learning chatbot for advisers, to engage customers better through digital and insurtech strategy. Available 24/7 on Facebook Messenger, TOMI uses deep learning for natural language processing to answer questions quickly and accurately. The chatbot aims to enhance internal efficiency and adviser engagement, with plans to expand its functions for customer-facing interaction. Additionally, the insurer launched TM Wave, an app that streamlines administrative processes for advisers, to minimize turnaround time and improve digital capabilities.

site_title: Sweden gains, South Korea reigns in world innovation rankings
summary: Sweden has risen to No 2 in the 2017 Bloomberg Innovation Index, while South Korea remains the top-ranked economy. Finland has cracked into the top five, driven by the rise of high-tech firms. Sweden's improvement in manufacturing value-added and government financing for small firms contributed to its rise. However, a weak krona may pose long-term risks. Russia plummeted 14 spots to No 26, while Japan dropped the most among top 25 economies.

site_title: Australia: Shares lower, banks lead declines
summary: Australian shares declined 0.8% on Tuesday, with banks leading the drop. The S&P/ASX 200 index fell to 5,701.9, as investors awaited cues from US markets. Banks, including the "Big Four," dropped between 1% and 1.7%. Energy shares also fell despite steady oil prices. However, the ASX gold index rose, driven by higher gold prices, while the mining index reached a two-year high due to iron ore price rallies.

site_title: Malaysia to hold rates as policy makers look to steady fragile ringgit: poll
summary: Malaysia's central bank is expected to keep its benchmark interest rate steady at 3.00% due to the fragile ringgit currency, which has dived to near two-decade lows. The currency's volatility makes it challenging for the central bank to implement rate cuts. The ringgit has steadied slightly, but economists predict further volatility due to US interest rate expectations and capital outflows from emerging markets. The central bank has taken measures to boost onshore ringgit trade, but the outlook remains uncertain.

images.alt_text: Malaysia's central bank is expected to keep its benchmark rate steady at 3.00 per cent on Thursday, a Reuters poll showed, as policy makers grapple with the beleaguered ringgit currency after it dived to near two decade lows at the start of the year.

site_title: Greenpeace says HSBC funding Indonesian forest destruction
summary: Greenpeace has accused HSBC of helping to arrange billions of dollars in financing for companies involved in destroying Indonesian rainforests for palm oil operations. The bank allegedly broke its guidelines on supporting unsustainable palm oil companies, with HSBC involved in arranging $16.3 billion in loans and $2 billion in corporate bonds since 2012. The environmental group said six firms received financial services from HSBC and were accused of activities like land seizures, forest fires, and worker abuse. HSBC denied knowingly supporting companies that don't comply with its policies on deforestation.

site_title: Brexit worries push gold to highest in over 7 weeks
summary: Gold prices rose to their highest in over 7 weeks, reaching $1,212.40 per ounce, ahead of British Prime Minister Theresa May's speech on plans for a "hard Brexit". Investors sought safe-haven assets amid Brexit concerns, Chinese currency pressure, and uncertainty over Donald Trump's policies. Analysts expect gold to continue rising due to Brexit and global economic uncertainty.

site_title: Quick takes: Singapore's Nodx beats market consensus again
summary: Singapore's non-oil domestic exports (Nodx) rose 9.4% in December, surpassing market consensus. This follows a 9.4% increase in November and a 12% decline in October. The latest growth suggests a strong recovery in the country's exports.

site_title: Toyota Motor to start testing fuel cell vehicles in UAE
summary: Toyota Motor Corp plans to test its hydrogen fuel cell vehicle in the UAE, partnering with Masdar, Abu Dhabi National Oil Co, and Air Liquide SA to examine hydrogen production and logistics. The Mirai FCV, launched in 2015, will undergo driving and refuelling tests to assess the feasibility of hydrogen as a zero-emission fuel technology in hot, dry conditions. This project aims to foster a "hydrogen society" and marks Toyota's exploration of hydrogen fuel technology in the region.

images.alt_text: Toyota Motor Corp on Tuesday said it would begin testing its hydrogen fuel cell vehicle (FCV) in the United Arab Emirates as the Japanese automaker explores the potential for the zero-emissions fuel technology in hot, dry conditions.

site_title: China halts over 100 coal-fired power projects
summary: China's energy regulator has ordered 11 provinces to halt over 100 coal-fired power projects, totaling more than 100 gigawatts, with an estimated $88.9 billion investment. The projects, mostly in northwestern regions, were suspended due to environmental concerns. The National Energy Administration (NEA) took the action on January 14, citing the need to reduce pollution and meet emissions targets.

site_title: Australia, China, Malaysia say underwater search for MH370 suspended
summary: Australia, China, and Malaysia have suspended the underwater search for missing Malaysia Airlines flight MH370, which vanished in 2014 with 239 people on board. Despite scouring 120,000-sq-km of the Indian Ocean sea floor, no trace of the plane was found. The countries agreed to suspend the search if new evidence wasn't uncovered. Only three confirmed pieces of debris have been found, with many other suspected to be from the plane. The search is now considered one of the world's greatest aviation mysteries.

site_title: In China, alcohol aged in bamboo for a new flavour
summary: A Chinese liqueur manufacturer, Chen Chao, uses live bamboo trunks to age his spirit, a method believed to impart a unique aroma and medicinal benefits. The process involves injecting the liqueur into bamboo trunks via high-pressure techniques. This 30-year-old method replaces traditional oak barrels, allowing for a distinct flavor profile. The aged spirit is said to have medicinal properties, making it a sought-after product in the Chinese market.

site_title: Fed dot plot hints at Yellen plotting three '17 hikes
summary: Federal Reserve Chair Janet Yellen's comments on interest-rate projections for 2017 have sparked speculation that she may favor three rate hikes, contrary to her dovish stance. The dot plot, a graphic layout of policy makers' forecasts, shows a median projection of three increases in 2017. Laurence Meyer, a former Federal Reserve governor, believes Yellen's positive view of the economy and her ability to build consensus on the committee support the three-hike forecast. Other officials, including William Dudley, have also hinted at three hikes, while some economists caution that uncertainty surrounding the Fed's forecasts limits the importance of Yellen's position.

site_title: JPMorgan wants to prove you're getting the best currency trade
summary: JPMorgan Chase & Co. has partnered with a London startup, BestX, to provide independent analysis of its currency trades, aiming to prove clients are getting the best deals. The analysis, set to be available on February 1, comes amid regulatory pressure to prove fair pricing in the opaque currency market. Other market makers, including XTX Markets Ltd, are also rolling out similar services, highlighting the growing importance of transparency in the $5.1 trillion-a-day currency market. This move is expected to push foreign exchange towards greater transparency, following recent market manipulation scandals and flash crashes.

site_title: Asia: Traders on edge ahead of May, Trump event
summary: Asian investors are cautious ahead of a crucial week for Britain's Brexit plans and US President Donald Trump's inauguration. The pound remains low against the dollar due to reports Prime Minister Theresa May plans a clean break from the EU. Forex traders will closely monitor May's remarks, which could impact the pound. Meanwhile, Singapore stocks have rallied for a fifth day ahead of GDP data, while US stocks hit fresh records despite tariff uncertainty.

site_title: China's yuan firms, academics urge Beijing to loosen grip
summary: China's yuan firmed slightly against the US dollar, with the onshore market showing more stability, but traders remain cautious due to weak sentiment and expectations of a potential downward trend. The People's Bank of China set the midpoint rate at 6.8992 per US dollar, and the spot market traded at 6.8971, 34 pips firmer than the previous late session close. The spread between onshore and offshore yuan has narrowed to near 400 pips, and some academics are urging Beijing to loosen its grip on the currency, citing the need for a free float to restore stability.

site_title: Singapore banks will weather further weakening in asset quality: Moody's
summary: Singapore's three largest banks - DBS, OCBC, and UOB - will face downward pressure on asset quality and profitability in 2017, but Moody's Investors Service expects the impact to be manageable due to government support. Problem loans are expected to increase, but new problem loan formation will slow, and the banks' capital ratios will remain stable. Liquidity remains robust due to strong deposit franchises and low reliance on market funding. Moody's does not foresee further downgrades over the next 12-18 months.

site_title: Dutch vote to set off Europe's 'super election year'
summary: Dutch voters will cast ballots in parliamentary polls on March 15, marking the start of a "super election year" in the Netherlands, France, and Germany. The Netherlands is expected to see the anti-Islam Freedom Party (PVV) led by Geert Wilders gain a majority, but analysts believe it will not form a government due to opposition from Prime Minister Mark Rutte's Liberal Party. The Dutch vote will be followed by the first round of French presidential elections on April 23, and Germany will vote for a new parliament in the summer. The elections come amid growing anti-EU sentiment and fears over immigration, boosting far-right parties in all three countries.

site_title: May to rule out 'half-in' EU deal in Brexit speech
summary: British Prime Minister Theresa May is expected to rule out a "half-in, half-out" EU deal in her Brexit speech, signaling a "hard" Brexit. This direction will be welcomed by those seeking to leave the EU but is likely to dismay those concerned about the economic impact. The speech is seen as a further indication of Britain's departure from the EU, which will have significant implications for the UK economy and global trade.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 2.12 points to 1,660.96, with volume reaching 99.2 million lots worth RM19.1 million. Gainers outnumbered losers 63 to 47.

site_title: Poor Mexico workers fear Trump trade effect
summary: US President-elect Donald Trump's proposed trade crackdown is causing concern among impoverished Mexican workers, particularly in the state of San Luis Potosi. Ford's abrupt cancellation of a $1.6 billion car factory project has left thousands of jobs at risk, with many fearing more companies will follow suit. Trump's threats to impose a 35% import tariff on companies shipping jobs to Mexico and renegotiate the North American Free Trade Agreement have led to uncertainty among workers, who rely on the auto sector for growth and employment.

site_title: GM said to plan US$1b US investment in nod to Trump
summary: General Motors plans a $1 billion US investment in US plants as part of a factory retooling for future models. The move aims to create or retain 1,000 jobs at several existing facilities, following similar investments by rivals Ford and Fiat Chrysler. The decision was accelerated due to President-elect Donald Trump's pressure to boost spending and hiring in the automotive industry, with Trump expressing hope that GM would follow suit.

images.alt_text: General Motors Co will invest US$1 billion in US plants as part of a previously announced factory retooling for future models, a person familiar with the matter said, as President-elect Donald Trump pressures carmakers to boost spending and hiring.

site_title: Australia, NZ dollars hover near 2-month highs on sterling
summary: The Australian and New Zealand dollars hovered near two-month highs against the pound due to concerns over a potential "hard Brexit" by Britain. Sterling touched a two-month trough below A$1.60, while the Aussie stood at US$0.7469, benefiting from rising iron ore prices. Analysts expect the AUD/NZD to fall if Donald Trump maintains a protectionist stance, targeting China, as Australia is its largest trade partner.

site_title: Ten things Obama will be remembered for
summary: Barack Obama's presidency will be remembered for several key events and policies. He became the first black US president, ushering in a new era of diversity in the White House. His administration navigated the country through the 2008 financial crisis, implementing stimulus packages and job creation measures. Obama also oversaw the death of Osama bin Laden, a major counterterrorism victory. Additionally, he made significant strides in environmental policy, including the Paris climate accord, and healthcare reform, which expanded coverage to millions. His foreign policy was marked by efforts to improve relations with Cuba, Iran, and other nations. Despite challenges, Obama's presidency will be remembered for its commitment to hope, change, and progress.

site_title: Taiwan: Stocks rise; TSMC, HTC rebound
summary: Taiwan's main Taiex index rose 0.4% on Tuesday, outperforming regional bourses, driven by gains in technology stocks such as TSMC and HTC. TSMC rebounded 0.3% after two sessions of falls, while HTC jumped nearly 1%. The electronics subindex rose 0.5% and the financials subindex gained 0.3%. The Taiwan dollar softened to NT$31.740 per US dollar. The rally followed investors snapping up beaten-down technology stocks amid tariff uncertainty.

site_title: Singapore shares continue to fall
summary: Singapore shares fell 0.15% on Tuesday, with the Straits Times Index (STI) at 3,008.53. Trading volume was 156.6 million shares worth S$69.5 million, with gainers beating losers 76 to 71. This marks the second consecutive day of losses, following a 0.4% gain on Thursday.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks edge up at open
summary: Hong Kong shares rose 0.45% at the open, following a 1% loss on Monday, as investors sought bargains. The Hang Seng Index reached 22,819.87, while the Shanghai Composite Index fell 0.53%. The Shenzhen Composite Index slipped 0.37%. The gains were seen as a response to investors seeking value after the previous day's losses.

site_title: Samsung succession in disarray as Lee criminal case advances
summary: South Korea's Samsung Group is facing uncertainty over Jay Y Lee's succession as prosecutors seek his arrest on bribery and embezzlement charges. If convicted, Lee could relinquish control, prompting a search for a new leader among Samsung Electronics executives, including co-CEOs Kwon Oh-Hyun and Yoon Boo-Keun. Lee Boo-Jin, a hotel executive and Samsung shareholder, is also considered a potential candidate, but her ability to manage the conglomerate is questioned due to her limited shares. A court hearing is set to determine if an arrest warrant will be issued, with potential implications for Samsung's leadership and the nation's economy.

site_title: Vard signs letter of intent to build cruise ship for one billion kroner
summary: VARD Holdings has signed a letter of intent to design and build a luxury cruise vessel for approximately one billion kroner. The 145m-long vessel will accommodate 220 passengers and is scheduled for delivery from a Norwegian yard in 2019. A firm contract is planned for Q1 2017, pending satisfactory financing and other conditions.

site_title: Trump security adviser drops out amid plagiarism claims
summary: Monica Crowley, a conservative author and Trump's chosen National Security Council communications director, has withdrawn from the position amid plagiarism allegations. Crowley had been accused of copying passages from other sources in her book and doctoral thesis. She cited "other opportunities" and wished the Trump administration well. The decision comes after another Trump appointee, Jason Miller, withdrew his name as White House communications director due to personal issues. The controversy raises concerns about the administration's vetting process for key positions.

site_title: GLP signs new leases in China and Japan to cater to higher domestic demand
summary: Global Logistic Properties (GLP) has signed 128,000 sq m of new leases in China and Japan, driven by domestic demand from car parts, e-commerce, and consumer goods industries. The 90% occupied portfolio globally benefits from domestic consumption trends. CEO Ming Z Mei stated that GLP's well-located facilities can capitalize on growth trends. The company is expected to receive first-round offers for a potential $8.6 billion acquisition by Blackstone Group and Warburg Pincus by the start of February.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open lower
summary: Japanese shares opened lower on Tuesday, January 17, 2017, amid investor caution ahead of UK Prime Minister Theresa May's Brexit speech and US President Donald Trump's inauguration. Tokyo's Nikkei index dropped 0.60% and the Topix index fell 0.62%.

site_title: Saudi airline Flynas to seek IPO regulatory approval by mid-2017
summary: Saudi budget airline Flynas plans to seek IPO regulatory approval by mid-2017, aiming to become the first carrier listed on the country's stock exchange. The airline, which announced a deal for 80 Airbus planes, recorded its second profitable year in 2016. Flynas is working with Banque Saudi Fransi and expects to apply for clearance from Saudi Arabia's Capital Market Authority by mid-2017, according to CEO Paul Byrne. This move is part of the country's efforts to diversify its economy amid weak oil prices.

images.alt_text: Saudi budget airline Flynas plans to seek regulatory approval this year for an initial public offering that would make it the first carrier to be listed on the country's stock exchange, part of a broader effort to diversity the economy in the face of weak oil prices.

site_title: Fu Yu to seek shareholders' nod at EGM to merge 2 Singapore-based units
summary: Fu Yu Corporation plans to merge two Singapore-based manufacturing units, Nanotechnology Manufacturing and Solidmicron Technologies, to improve operational efficiencies and financial performance. The merger aims to reduce costs and increase economies of scale. The company will seek shareholder approval for the merger at an extraordinary general meeting. This move is part of Fu Yu's efforts to streamline its corporate structure and operations.

site_title: Automated traders take over Bitcoin as easy money beckons
summary: Automated traders are dominating the Bitcoin market, taking advantage of tiny price discrepancies to profit 24/7. High-speed trader Zhou Shuoji, who runs a bitcoin hedge fund, says it's the "golden age" for traders due to the market's imperfections. Despite skepticism from some, Zhou's firm, Fintech Blockchain Group, has profited from the market's volatility. As the cryptocurrency continues to gain traction, automated traders are increasingly playing a significant role in shaping its price.

site_title: Stocks to watch: CapitaLand, Frasers, Fu Yu Corp
summary: CapitaLand announced plans to develop its first international Grade A office tower with retail units in Ho Chi Minh City, Vietnam, to be completed in 2020. Frasers Centrepoint established a S$5 billion debt issuance program to refinance debts and fund potential acquisitions. Fu Yu Corporation merged with two subsidiaries to continue as one company, with no financial impact on its share capital or earnings per share.

site_title: JPMorgan reverses bearish call that angered Jakarta
summary: JPMorgan Chase & Co has upgraded its assessment of the Indonesian stock market from bearish to neutral, reversing an earlier downgrade that prompted the Indonesian government to stop doing business with the US bank. The upgrade comes after volatility in emerging-market bonds following Donald Trump's US election victory subsided. The move is seen as a positive development for Indonesia, with the government welcoming the new assessment. JPMorgan's analysts cited signs of investors returning to emerging markets and a peak in US treasury yields as reasons for the upgrade.

site_title: Sterling at 3-month low, braces for May's Brexit speech
summary: The British pound dropped to a three-month low of US$1.1983 on Monday, amid concerns over Prime Minister Theresa May's potential speech that may set Britain on course for a "hard Brexit" and loss of access to the European Union single market. Fears of US President-elect Donald Trump's protectionist policies also contributed to the decline, with the yen rising to its highest levels in more than five weeks. May's speech is expected to outline her 12 priorities for Brexit talks, including leaving the single market and regaining full border control.

site_title: Baidu names former Microsoft exec as COO in artificial intelligence push
summary: Baidu Inc has appointed Qi Lu, a former Microsoft executive, as its Chief Operating Officer to focus on artificial intelligence. The move follows a 16% drop in ad customers due to new advertising regulations. Lu will help develop AI as a key strategic focus for Baidu over the next decade. This appointment is part of the company's push into AI as its core search engine business earnings wane.

site_title: Healthway Medical, Yanlord Land, DBS, Frasers Centrepoint to raise funds
summary: Healthway Medical, Yanlord Land, DBS Bank, and Frasers Centrepoint are raising funds through note issues. Healthway Medical has agreed to issue S$70 million in notes, with a two-year maturity period and a conversion price of S$0.03384 per share. The other companies' note issuance details are not specified in the article.

site_title: Oil prices inch up on Saudi commitment to cut output
summary: Oil prices rose 15 US cents to $52.52 per barrel after Saudi Arabia committed to cutting output under a global agreement with Opec and Russia. The move aims to bring supplies back in line with consumption, but analysts warn that higher prices could hit oil demand, citing a decline of 10 basis points for every $10 per barrel increase. Despite this, many countries are cutting output beyond their commitments, and Saudi Energy Minister Khalid al-Falih expressed confidence in the agreement's impact.

site_title: Merkel tells German industry she will fight for free trade
summary: Chancellor Angela Merkel told German industry leaders she will fight for free trade, contradicting US President-elect Donald Trump's comments on border taxes on car imports. Merkel urged industry leaders to remain supportive of the German government in Brexit negotiations and warned against protectionist trade policies, citing their long-term damage. Merkel's comments were seen as a rebuke to Trump's plan to impose a 35% border tax on German cars imported to the US. She emphasized the importance of open markets for growth and principle, echoing Finance Minister Wolfgang Schaeuble's similar warnings.

site_title: Martin Luther King's daughter says 'God can triumph over Trump'
summary: Martin Luther King Jr.'s daughter, Bernice King, stated "God can triumph over Trump" in response to Donald Trump's presidency, while her brother, Dexter King, met with the president-elect, taking a conciliatory tone. The comments came after African-American congressman John Lewis questioned Trump's legitimacy due to Russian interference in the campaign, prompting Trump's scornful response.

site_title: Xi, unlikely champion for business elites, takes Davos spotlight
summary: Chinese President Xi Jinping will address the World Economic Forum at Davos, delivering a speech that could outline China's vision for the global trade order. This comes as US President-elect Donald Trump has questioned America's commitment to free trade, sparking concerns among business elites. Xi's remarks are expected to provide a blueprint for the future of human society, marking a significant shift in his stance as an unlikely champion for the trade-based global order. His speech will take place days before Trump's inauguration, highlighting the importance of international cooperation in the face of growing economic uncertainty.

images.alt_text: When Xi Jinping addresses business elites at Davos, the Chinese president will find himself an unlikely champion of the trade-based global order Donald Trump has derided. His new role could prove to be one of his biggest tests.

site_title: UK PM May to say Britain is leaving EU's single market, customs union: report
summary: UK Prime Minister Theresa May plans to say Britain will leave the European Union's single market and customs union in divorce talks, according to a report. May will outline 12 priorities for Brexit negotiations, prioritizing border control. This stance is seen as a 'Hard Brexit', which has led to Sterling's lowest levels against the US dollar in decades. The move is expected to reinforce investor fears and cause economic uncertainty.

site_title: Trump, Fed headed for clash amid US dollar surge, economists say
summary: US President-elect Donald Trump and the Federal Reserve are headed for a potential clash over the US dollar, with economists predicting a stronger dollar due to Trump's fiscal stimulus, tax reform, and protectionist trade policy. This could lead to higher interest rates, increased inflation, and a trade deficit, undermining Trump's goal of boosting economic growth. Experts warn of a "major clash" in the next year and a half, with the potential for "double-digit" US dollar appreciation, posing risks to the global economy.

site_title: Opec sees market stability in 2017, Venezuela aims for US$70 price
summary: Opec Secretary-General Mohammed Barkindo predicts market stability in 2017, while Venezuelan President Nicolas Maduro aims for a US$70 crude price. Barkindo praises Maduro for his role in the oil-producing pact to cut output, expecting improved economies in 2017 with full implementation. Maduro hopes the price increase will boost Venezuela's economy.

images.alt_text: Opec Secretary-General Mohammed Barkindo forecast on Monday that stability would return to oil markets this year while price hawk Venezuela said it hoped its crude basket would rise to US$70 in coming months.

site_title: Trump threatens German carmakers with 35% US import tariff
summary: US President-elect Donald Trump threatened German carmakers with a 35% US import tariff, targeting BMW, Daimler, and Volkswagen for not producing enough cars in the US. Trump criticized German carmakers for exporting low-cost vehicles to the US, saying they would pay the tariff if they sold cars to the US market. The move drew rebukes from Berlin and hit the automakers' shares. German carmakers have invested heavily in Mexico, but also manufacture in the US, with over 850,000 units produced annually.

site_title: ECB prints money at record pace amid bank bonds bonanza
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) purchased a record-breaking 24.7 billion euros in debt last week, boosting its economic stimulus program. This is the highest amount since 2014, driven by a bumper supply of bank bonds, particularly covered bonds. The ECB took advantage of the ample supply to lower borrowing costs and stimulate growth. Despite initial hopes, the covered bond purchase program has been declining, and economists expect the trend to continue. The ECB's purchases now form the bulk of its 80 billion euros of monthly debt buys, mostly government bonds.

site_title: Kerry tells CNN Trump's criticism of Merkel 'inappropriate'
summary: US Secretary of State John Kerry criticized President-elect Donald Trump for his comments on German Chancellor Angela Merkel, calling them "inappropriate" and defending Merkel's leadership. Trump had criticized Merkel's refugee policy and praised Britain's decision to leave the EU, declaring NATO "obsolete." Kerry defended Merkel, saying she was "extremely courageous" and her policy was not "catastrophic." Kerry warned that Trump's comments could divide the West and undermine relations with Europe.

site_title: CapitaLand to develop office tower in Ho Chi Minh City
summary: CapitaLand, a Singaporean real estate company, plans to develop its first international Grade A office tower in Ho Chi Minh City, Vietnam. The 240m-tall tower will have a gross floor area of 106,000 sq m and be connected to a planned metro station. Construction is set to begin in 2017 and complete by 2020. The project aims to diversify CapitaLand's portfolio and strengthen its presence in Vietnam, which is its third-largest market in South-east Asia.

images.alt_text: CapitaLand announced, prior to the start of trading on Tuesday, that it will be developing its first international Grade A office tower in in the heart of Ho Chi Minh City, Vietnam.

site_title: Venezuela releases new banknotes in cash crisis
summary: Venezuela released new, larger denomination banknotes, including 500-, 5,000-, and 20,000-bolivar notes, to address the economic crisis and alleviate citizens' struggles with unwieldy cash. The notes were initially scheduled for release in December but were delayed, causing anxiety among Venezuelans. The move aims to simplify transactions and ease the cash crisis, which has been exacerbated by high inflation.

site_title: Stocks retreat as pound tanks on Brexit fear
summary: The pound slumped to its lowest level since October's "flash crash" as reports emerged that British Prime Minister Theresa May was ready to take the UK out of the European Union in a "hard Brexit." The FTSE 100 index closed with a slight loss, ending a record 14-session winning streak, while the eurozone's DAX 30 and CAC 40 indices also fell. The decline in the pound has been driven by uncertainty ahead of Ms May's speech on Brexit negotiations and US President-elect Donald Trump's comments on the issue, which failed to reassure investors.

site_title: New Zealand house prices rise 0.4% in December: Reinz
summary: New Zealand house prices rose 0.4% seasonally in December, up 11.8% from last year, according to the Real Estate Institute of New Zealand. Despite a 1.4% drop in Auckland prices, the city's median house prices were still up 9.1% from December last year. This marks a slight cooling of the Auckland market, but overall, the country's housing market remains strong.

images.alt_text: New Zealand house prices rose in December, though the red-hot market of Auckland saw some cooling, the Real Estate Institute of New Zealand (Reinz) said on Tuesday.

site_title: South Korean prosecutors seek arrest of Samsung heir
summary: South Korean prosecutors have sought the arrest of Lee Jae-Yong, the heir to the Samsung empire, over corruption allegations linked to President Park Geun-Hye's secret confidante Choi Soon-Sil. Lee, 48, is accused of bribery and embezzlement for approving payments to Choi. The arrest warrant request could have a significant impact on the economy, as Samsung's revenue is a fifth of South Korea's GDP. Lee faces up to five years in prison if convicted, but some analysts believe the scandal could ultimately benefit Samsung by forcing the company to improve its governance structure.

site_title: UK businesses wary about investment on Brexit doubts: survey
summary: British businesses are increasingly cautious about investment plans due to Brexit doubts, a survey showed. Business confidence remained at its second-highest level since the EU referendum in June, but expectations for investment softened. Only 29% of executives expect investments to increase over the next 12 months, down from 31% in November. The Bank of England has identified a fall in business investment as a potential drag on the British economy, while job postings also indicate uncertainty, with training sector jobs falling by 54% and apprenticeships down 26.5%.

site_title: Facebook moves to head off tougher regulation in Germany
summary: Facebook is taking steps to address concerns over fake news and hate speech in Germany, where lawmakers plan legislation to force the social media giant to remove such content within 24 hours or face fines. Facebook's chief operating officer Sheryl Sandberg met with German officials, and the company announced a partnership with a fact-checking organization Correctiv to reduce the spread of fake news. However, tougher regulation could impact Facebook's lucrative business model and generate significant revenue losses.

site_title: Bankrupt US retailer American Apparel starts layoffs
summary: American Apparel, a US retailer, has started laying off approximately 2,400 workers in Southern California after Canadian apparel maker Gildan Activewear Inc withdrew its initial plan to acquire some of its manufacturing operations. The layoffs follow Gildan's US$88 million bid to acquire American Apparel's brand, with the company set to assume the brand's rights. American Apparel also plans to shut down its 110 stores without another buyer.

site_title: New Zealand business confidence rises to two-year high in Q4
summary: New Zealand business confidence reached a two-year high in Q4, with 28% of firms expecting general business conditions to improve, according to the New Zealand Institute of Economic Research's quarterly survey. This optimism is driven by a booming construction sector and rising global dairy prices. The Reserve Bank of New Zealand is likely to hold interest rates in February, as inflation pressures pick up, with a net 7% of firms reporting price increases, in line with the bank's projections of a 2% annual inflation rate. This suggests a pick-up in inflation across 2017.

site_title: Takata's US$1b settlement removes hurdle to its sale
summary: Takata Corp has agreed to pay US$1 billion to settle a criminal investigation into hiding the risks of its airbags for 15 years, admitting to at least 17 deaths worldwide. The settlement removes a hurdle to the company's sale, which is necessary to complete the largest product recall in automotive history, covering over 100 million airbags. The company faces significant liabilities and uncertainties, with potential buyers including Autoliv Inc and Key Safety Systems Inc. The settlement includes a US$25 million payment to the US and US$975 million to compensate carmakers and injured individuals.

site_title: Gunmen kill 8 Egyptian policemen in southwest Egypt: ministry
summary: Gunmen attacked a police checkpoint in el-Wadi el-Gedid province in southwest Egypt, killing 8 police officers. Two attackers were killed, and 3 security personnel were injured. The Islamic State (IS) claimed responsibility for the attack, which occurred 1 day after a similar attack in the Sinai. This marks the latest in a series of attacks by IS against security forces in Egypt since the 2013 military overthrow of Islamist president Mohamed Morsi.

site_title: Eugene Cernan, last man to walk on moon, dead at 82
summary: Eugene Cernan, the last man to walk on the moon during the Apollo 17 mission in December 1972, has died at the age of 82. He passed away following ongoing health issues, according to a family statement released by NASA. Cernan was a retired naval officer and a passionate advocate for continued human exploration of space. He is survived by his wife, one daughter, two step-daughters, and nine grandchildren.

site_title: Obama warns Trump not to jettison Iran nuclear deal
summary: US President Barack Obama warned incoming President Donald Trump not to jettison the Iran nuclear deal, which has achieved significant results in making the world a safer place. The deal, signed in 2015, has been endorsed by the UN Security Council and over 100 countries, and has led to the lifting of most international sanctions against Iran. Obama emphasized that the agreement was the result of years of work among major powers and represented a safer alternative to war.

site_title: EU 'has no need for outside advice', France's Hollande says of Trump
summary: French President Francois Hollande responded to Donald Trump's criticism of the European Union, saying the EU "has no need for outside advice" on its affairs. Hollande criticized Trump's comments on migrants, Brexit, and NATO, stating that Europe's values and principles would guide its path. Hollande also defended France's commitment to its alliances, including NATO, and emphasized the importance of European unity in response to Trump's remarks. Former French Prime Minister Manuel Valls called Trump's comments a "declaration of war on Europe" and urged European unity to counter Trump's policies.

site_title: Singapore's non-oil domestic exports push upwards by 9.4% year-on-year in Dec
summary: Singapore's non-oil domestic exports (NODX) rose 9.4% in December 2016, driven by electronic and non-electronic exports, following a 11.5% growth in November and a 12% decline in October. This marks the third consecutive month of growth, indicating a positive trend in the country's trade sector.

site_title: Japan's elderly inmates prefer predictable regimen of jail to freedom
summary: In Japan, elderly inmates prefer the structured daily routine of prison to freedom, with one inmate stating he is hesitant to leave due to the certainty and predictability of his life behind bars. The inmates' preference for routine is highlighted as a unique aspect of Japanese prison culture, where discipline and order are valued. This preference raises questions about the appeal of structure and stability in a society often associated with flexibility and change.

site_title: Samurai 2K Aerosol shares soar in Catalist debut
summary: Samurai 2K Aerosol, a Singapore-based spray paint maker, made its trading debut on the Singapore Exchange's Catalist board, with its stock price soaring 40% above the initial public offering (IPO) price of 20 Singapore cents per share. The company issued 100 million shares through its IPO.

site_title: Bank of England's Carney says UK reliant on buoyant consumers
summary: Bank of England Governor Mark Carney warned that the UK's economic growth relies heavily on consumer spending, rather than investment or exports, due to Brexit uncertainties. He expressed concerns that this could lead to a weaker economy in the future. Despite this, Carney stuck to the central bank's neutral monetary policy stance, with no expected changes in interest rates. The UK's consumer borrowing grew 11% in the year to November, its fastest pace since 2005, and inflation is expected to exceed 2.7% by the end of the year.

site_title: Economic restructuring a work in progress: Menon
summary: Singapore's economic restructuring remains a work-in-progress, according to MAS managing director Ravi Menon. The country's macro fundamentals are sound, but it needs to raise productivity amid global financial conditions and stresses. Menon emphasized the importance of upskilling the workforce to thrive in a digitalized economy. Singapore's GDP is expected to rise 1-3% this year, and the property market has shown progress in stabilizing after cooling measures. Menon expressed confidence in the future, citing investments in technology, infrastructure, and skills.

site_title: Chinese capital finds channel in HK stocks via exchange links
summary: Mainland Chinese investors are turning to buying Hong Kong stocks through cross-border exchange links, driven by tightened capital controls and a weakening yuan. This influx of funds could boost the Hong Kong stock market, which has trailed global peers over the past four years. The Shenzhen and Shanghai bourse links remain open, allowing mainland investors to buy Hong Kong-denominated assets pegged to the US dollar, shielding them from yuan depreciation. Net buying of Hong Kong shares through the Shanghai link reached 582 million yuan in January, supporting the Hang Seng Index.

site_title: GSK names new Asia-Pacific head of pharmaceuticals
summary: GlaxoSmithKline has appointed Hervé Gisserot as its head of pharmaceuticals, Asia-Pacific, based in Singapore. Gisserot will oversee the company's commercial operations and product portfolio within the Asia-Pacific region.

site_title: In one of the world's loneliest jobs, Obama found comfort in books
summary: Barack Obama, the 44th US president, has shared his love for reading as a source of comfort and guidance during his eight years in office. He credits books for helping him maintain balance and perspective in a fast-paced and isolating job. Obama often turns to writers like Abraham Lincoln, Martin Luther King Jr., and Nelson Mandela for solidarity, and has read plays by William Shakespeare and novels by VS Naipaul. He reads for about an hour a day, and plans to write his memoir and catch up on reading after leaving office.

images.alt_text: As a great admirer of Abraham Lincoln, the 16th US president, Barack Obama, the 44th, shares with his distant predecessor a passionately felt hobby - for books, and for reading.

site_title: Chip Eng Seng looks poised for take-off
summary: Chip Eng Seng Corporation, a relatively small Singaporean property developer, appears poised for growth despite its small market capitalization of S$400 million. The company has a diverse portfolio of projects, including residential, commercial, and hospitality ventures, both domestically and internationally. Its expansion into modular construction technology and diversification into Vietnam and China also enhance its competitiveness. With a solid business model and a high-caliber management team, Chip Eng Seng is expected to make a splash in the Singapore property market with its upcoming condo launch, Grandeur Park Residences.

site_title: Duet recommends raised offer from HK's Cheung Kong
summary: DUET Group has agreed to recommend a US$5.51 billion bid from Cheung Kong Infrastructure Holdings, a consortium led by Hong Kong's Cheung Kong, for the Australian energy firm. The deal comes after Australia blocked a similar bid for state-owned firm Ausgrid on national interest grounds. Duet's board recommended the offer, citing a lack of precedent for the FIRB's approach to foreign investment. The deal's valuation is considered high, equating to 1.6 times Duet's regulated asset base, and is subject to FIRB approval.

site_title: Noble Energy to buy rival Clayton Williams Energy for US$2.7b
summary: Noble Energy Inc announced a deal to acquire Clayton Williams Energy Inc for approximately US$2.7 billion. The deal includes 71,000 net acres in the Permian Basin, a key US oil field, to enhance Noble Energy's presence. Clayton Williams shareholders will receive Noble Energy common stock and US$34.75 in cash per share. The acquisition is expected to accelerate drilling to three rigs by the end of 2017, and Noble Energy plans to raise over US$1 billion in proceeds through portfolio management.

images.alt_text: Oil producer Noble Energy Inc said on Monday it would buy smaller rival Clayton Williams Energy Inc for about US$2.7 billion in a cash-and-stock deal to enhance its presence in the Permian Basin, the top US oil field.

site_title: Obama's (tentative) legacy
summary: US President Barack Obama's legacy is uncertain due to events that have not yet occurred. Despite this, his administration's greatest achievement was stabilizing the economy during its first year, avoiding a second Great Depression. Obama's record is mixed, with notable successes like the expansion of Obamacare to 20 million Americans, but also setbacks such as handling an ageing society and climate change. His inability to inspire fear as well as respect and construct a working relationship with congressional Republicans has contributed to the dysfunctional US government system. A true verdict on Obama's presidency will take years to emerge.

site_title: Emerging Asia better able to cope with risks of financial tightening: MAS
summary: Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) managing director Ravi Menon says emerging Asia is better equipped to handle the risks of financial tightening, citing strong household, corporate, and banking sector balance sheets. However, he warns that US trade curbs on countries like China and Mexico could trigger "cascading effects" through Asia's integrated production networks. Menon hopes that extreme anti-trade measures won't occur under the Trump administration, but notes that policymakers should stay calm and lean against excessive swings in foreign exchange markets.

site_title: Firms can unlock US$12t via key development goals: study
summary: A study by the Business and Sustainable Development Commission suggests that companies can unlock at least $12 trillion in market opportunities and create up to 380 million jobs by 2030 by implementing key development goals, including reducing greenhouse gas emissions and increasing sustainable practices. The study emphasizes the importance of businesses taking a lead in poverty reduction and sustainable development to achieve the United Nations' Sustainable Development Goals.

site_title: Nintendo takes big gamble with Switch's split personality
summary: Nintendo's new Switch gaming console, set to release on March 3, has received mixed reactions from investors, with shares dropping 5.9% after pricing and details were released. The device's success is uncertain, despite its unique hybrid design, and investors are concerned it won't replicate the success of the Wii console.

site_title: Davos elite focuses on climate change, ignoring Trump's scepticism
summary: The captains of business and finance gathered in Davos for the World Economic Forum's annual meeting, focusing on climate change despite US President Donald Trump's skepticism. The event features 15 sessions on climate change and nine on clean energy, highlighting the potential for billions of dollars in profits and losses. Global business leaders are investing heavily in renewable energy, with $287.5 billion in clean energy investment last year, and experts predict $13.5 trillion in spending through 2030 to meet Paris agreement ambitions. Despite Trump's opposition, the fight against global warming is expected to continue.

site_title: Beijing clears two top HK officials to enter chief exec race
summary: Beijing has cleared two top Hong Kong officials, Carrie Lam and John Tsang, to run in the March 26 election for the city's next leader. Lam, the current chief secretary, and Tsang, the former financial secretary, were approved to resign and contest the election after the Chinese government gave its backing. The decision has thrown the race wide open, with both Lam and Tsang widely expected to be among the top contenders. A recent poll suggests Tsang leads with 27.6% of the vote, but pundits remain divided on who will ultimately win.

images.alt_text: Mrs Lam announced her candidacy for chief executive on Monday while Mr Tsang will give his decision in the next few days.

site_title: Developers to keep playing quantum price game this year
summary: Singapore developers sold 8,136 private homes in 2016, a 9.4% increase from the previous year, with EC sales reaching a four-year high of 4,018 units, up 57.6% from 2015. Realistic pricing is credited as a key factor in the improved sales. This growth reflects improved sentiment and demand in the market.

site_title: Tokyo office rents seen falling as supply glut tilts balance
summary: Tokyo's office market is expected to experience a glut of new space, leading to falling rents as early as next year. Despite a surge in office space additions, Tokyo's workforce is projected to decline by nearly a tenth by 2035 due to Japan's shrinking population. This shift is anticipated to impact the balance between supply and demand, with office vacancy rates expected to rise to around 6% and push down rents from 2019.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: CapitaLand Mall Trust (CMT) disclosed that the National Trades Union Congress (NTUC) has become a substantial shareholder after its stake in the retail Reit crossed 5% following a share purchase of 5 million shares for S$10.07 million on Jan 11. This increase brings NTUC's stake to 5.04%. CMT units closed 0.5 cents lower at S$1.99 on Monday.

site_title: Brexit blues said to hit UK diplomats in Brussels as morale declines
summary: UK diplomats in Brussels face declining morale amid Brexit uncertainty, with some fearing they will be sidelined in negotiations. The resignation of Ivan Rogers, Britain's experienced envoy to the EU, has further eroded morale. Experts warn that the UK's ground-based expertise is crucial for a successful Brexit, but the government's departure preparations may undermine this. A parliamentary report highlights the need for integration between the government's Brexit team and UK officials in Brussels, a prospect complicated by Prime Minister Theresa May's plan to leave the single market.

site_title: Sterling sinks on 'hard Brexit' fears
summary: Sterling plummeted to its lowest level in 32 years, falling 1.5% against the US dollar and 2.5% against the yen, due to fears of a "hard Brexit" from Prime Minister Theresa May. The move shifted market attention away from US President-elect Donald Trump's economic policies. Sterling's decline was triggered by concerns about the UK's potential exit from the EU's single market, which could have significant economic implications.

site_title: Vallianz to get S$7m cash injection from Greatwill Asset
summary: Vallianz Holdings, a Singapore-based offshore marine solutions provider, has received a S$7-million cash injection from Greatwill Asset Global Limited, an investment holding company. The cash injection comes as Vallianz seeks to streamline its operations, having ended non-core business units and ceasing operations at its Singapore shipyard. The new shares will increase Vallianz's share capital, with the directors believing the working capital available to the group is sufficient to fund its intentions and meet its present requirements.

site_title: Oil prices to see more volatility in 2017: IEA chief
summary: The head of the International Energy Agency (IEA) predicts oil prices will experience "much more volatility" in 2017, despite a potential rebalancing of markets in the first half of the year due to OPEC's 1.2 million barrel-per-day output cut. Fatih Birol notes that the agreement could lead to higher prices but also increase US production, weakening global demand. He warns of a potential supply-demand gap in a few years if new investments are not made.

site_title: Benefits of globalised fish farming tempered by hidden costs
summary: Globalized fish farming, which allows for the export of seafood products across borders, has benefits such as increased efficiency and reduced costs. However, it also poses hidden costs, including the spread of disease and new bugs that can be transmitted to different markets. This can lead to significant losses for farmers and the industry as a whole. As the global market becomes increasingly integrated, the risks associated with disease transmission and other issues are likely to increase, affecting the long-term sustainability of the industry.

site_title: Pound tanks as May braces for Brexit
summary: British Prime Minister Theresa May is reportedly preparing to announce a "hard Brexit" from the European Union, sparking a decline in the pound and sending London's FTSE 100 index to a record high. Sterling fell to a 31-year low of $1.1841 and the FTSE 100 hit a record 7,354.14 points. This move has also led to a decline in eurozone and Asian stock markets, with Frankfurt's DAX 30 and Paris CAC 40 indices down 0.6% and 0.5%, respectively.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Singapore Exchange (SGX) upgraded to "Buy" by DBS Group Research with a target price of S$8.30, citing improved market activity and stabilizing derivatives segment. Meanwhile, BEST World International and UOL Group were also upgraded to "Buy" and "Accumulate" respectively, with target prices of S$2.50 and S$7.05, driven by strong fundamentals and growth potential.

site_title: Trump policy calls will be major wild card in growth outlook: IMF
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) has warned that global growth is expected to pick up this year and in 2018, driven by fiscal expansions in the US and China, but is clouded by policy uncertainties under the new US administration. The IMF projects global growth to rise to 3.4% in 2017 and 3.6% in 2018, with advanced economies expected to grow by 1.9% in 2017 and 2% next year. However, emerging market and developing economies are projected to experience slower growth due to tighter financial conditions. A shift towards protectionism and potential changes in US policy are seen as major wild cards to global growth.

site_title: ST Engg's aerospace arm bags S$840m of orders in Q4
summary: ST Engineering's aerospace arm secured S$840m in new orders in Q4 2016, with contracts including line and airframe maintenance, component repair, and overhaul. The company signed agreements with Alaska Airlines for CFM56-7B engine maintenance and multiple landing gear overhaul contracts from airlines. ST Aerospace also expanded its MRO capabilities and developed its aircraft seat business, receiving certification from the Civil Aviation Authority of Singapore. The new contracts are expected to have no material impact on ST Engineering's financial performance.

site_title: Probe finds battery is main cause of Galaxy Note 7 fires: source
summary: Samsung Electronics Co Ltd has concluded that the battery is the main cause of Galaxy Note 7 smartphone fires, according to a source. The investigation comes as the company prepares to launch the Galaxy S8, one of its flagship phones. The Galaxy Note 7 recall was one of the biggest product safety failures in tech history, and Samsung is seeking to put it behind it. The company's investigation is ongoing, but the battery is now identified as the primary cause of the issue.

site_title: World's 8 richest own same as 50% of humanity: Oxfam
summary: Eight individuals, all men, own as much wealth as the poorer half of the world's population, according to Oxfam's report. The wealth gap is "obscene," with the combined assets of these eight individuals equivalent to the wealth of 3.6 billion people. The report calls for action to curb the rewards for the top 1%, citing the need for tax crackdowns and a shift away from "super-charged" shareholder capitalism. The report's findings highlight the widening wealth gap, which has moved up the agenda, sparking concerns about the corrosive effects of inequality.

site_title: S'pore likely to prop up S-E Asia's muted IPO market in 2017: analysts
summary: Singapore is expected to be the hottest spot for initial public offerings (IPOs) in South-east Asia in 2017, with sales of business and real estate trusts reaching $1.7 billion last year. Analysts attribute this to Singapore's stock exchange promoting itself as a center for stable dividend-paying investments, partly offsetting a drop in major share sales in China. Other countries in the region face challenges, including Indonesia's currency volatility and Malaysia's market sentiment, which has been crushed by a slump in commodity prices and a financial scandal.

site_title: Asia's oldest bourse BSE may raise 12.43b rupees in IPO
summary: BSE Ltd, Asia's oldest stock exchange, plans to raise up to 12.43 billion rupees (S$260 million) in its initial public offering (IPO) next week. The IPO, open from Jan 23-25, will value the stock exchange at about 44 billion rupees at the top end of the price range of 805-806 rupees per share. Investors, including Singapore Exchange Ltd and Quantum, will sell up to 15.4 million shares.

site_title: Cathay Pacific to unveil results of key review, job cuts likely
summary: Cathay Pacific Airways is expected to announce job cuts and cost reductions, potentially shifting flights to its short-haul arm, amid growing competition from Chinese carriers. The airline scrapped its second-half profit forecast in October and announced a review of its business. Analysts predict a loss for 2017, its first full-year loss since 2010, due to rising costs and pressure from mainland carriers. Cathay's share price has tumbled to its lowest level since the 2009 financial crisis.

images.alt_text: Cathay Pacific Airways is expected to announce job cuts and cost reductions and to shift flights to its short-haul arm when it unveils the results of a key review this week, as it grapples with growing competition from Chinese carriers.

site_title: Alibaba Cloud partners NUS, EZ-Link to boost data capabilities (Amended)
summary: Alibaba Cloud has partnered with the National University of Singapore (NUS) and EZ-Link to enhance data capabilities in Singapore. The Memorandum of Understanding (MOU) aims to drive cloud computing and data-driven capabilities, serving enterprises and merchants. The partnership will focus on developing cloud computing and data analytics capabilities, improving the business environment for companies in Singapore. This move deepens Alibaba Cloud's commitment to Singapore, its international business hub.

images.alt_text: (From left) Ethan Yu, VP of Alibaba Group and GM of Alibaba Cloud Global, Prof Ho Teck Hua, NUS deputy president (Research & Technology) and EZ-Link CEO Nicholas Lee at the MOU signing.

site_title: World's largest gold fund hit by longest dry spell
summary: The world's largest gold fund, SPDR Gold Shares ETF, has experienced its longest dry spell since November 2016, with no inflow since November 10. The fund, which has over $31 billion in assets, saw $5.7 billion in outflows after a $220 million inflow on November 9, following Donald Trump's US presidential election win. The decline is attributed to the ongoing bearish market outlook and Trump's tariff policies.

site_title: Trump continues to confound Washington
summary: US President-elect Donald Trump continues to confound Washington with his unconventional approach to politics, dominating the news cycle despite still occupying the White House. Trump's public relations strategy focuses on shock and awe, confusing both allies and adversaries. He recently dismissed allegations of compromising material on his business deals and sex life, labeling them "crap" compiled by "sick people" to hurt him politically. Trump's Cabinet nominations, including retired General James Mattis and ExxonMobil CEO Rex Tillerson, have been met with praise for their establishment credentials, contrasting with the president-elect's unconventional style.

site_title: Waiting for the real Donald Trump to occupy the White House
summary: US President-elect Donald Trump is shrouded in mystery, with his unclear positions on major domestic and foreign policy issues. A self-made billionaire with no prior government experience, Trump's past statements on policy issues are contradictory and often impractical. His Cabinet picks have contradicted some of his campaign pledges, but concerns remain about his intentions to overturn current policy agendas. The international community, including America's allies, is waiting to see the "real" Donald Trump and how he will govern the country and engage the world.

site_title: Xi takes Davos spotlight as unlikely champion of trade-based global order
summary: Chinese President Xi Jinping is set to address the World Economic Forum in Davos, Switzerland, where he will become the first Chinese head of state to do so, and deliver a speech that top diplomats say will be a "blueprint for the future progress of human society". Xi aims to cement China's clout in a world dominated by a more protectionist US administration and a disruptive EU exit. Despite facing domestic challenges and US pressure, Xi plans to stress openness and international cooperation, drawing a contrast with US President-elect Donald Trump's economic nationalism.

site_title: Chat with a cat? Ad agency says you can
summary: An ad agency, Temptations Lab, has developed a "talking cat collar" that records a cat's meows, translates them into human language, and plays them back aloud. The collar can be customized with various voices, including French and Australian accents, through a smartphone app. The product aims to provide a unique and entertaining experience for cat owners, capitalizing on the growing interest in animal-human interactions.

site_title: Sharp fall in Japan's machinery orders underlines uncertainty
summary: Japan's core private-sector machinery orders fell 5.1% in November, driven by a drop in business confidence, according to the Cabinet Office. The orders, which exclude volatile sectors, dropped to 834 billion yen, following a 3.3% fall in September and a 4.1% gain in October. The decline was a surprise, with analysts citing uncertainty about the US economy under President Donald Trump. This may lead to a strengthening yen and cautious investment by Japanese companies, despite Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's efforts to boost capital spending.

site_title: Rebooted Mandai precinct to create jobs in hospitality and conservation
summary: Singapore is set to reboot its Mandai precinct, a nature-themed hub that will create jobs in hospitality and conservation. The project, which includes two new nature parks and an eco-friendly education centre, will be completed in phases by 2023. The precinct will attract tourists and create new career opportunities for Singaporeans, with the potential to reach 10 million visitors annually. Efforts will be made to minimize disruption to the local wildlife and businesses, and the government has accepted the project's Environmental Impact Assessment report with changes made to reduce its environmental impact.

site_title: Asia banks seeking tech hires over star bankers this year
summary: Asia-Pacific financial institutions are shifting their focus to hiring technology specialists over investment bankers, with 40% of regional financial-services managers expecting to increase headcount for IT-related roles. This shift is driven by banks' need to enhance product offerings and upgrade systems, with 18% intending to add investment banking jobs and 29% fixed income and equities sales and trading roles. Experts say the "face of banking is changing" with technology, automation, and big data becoming key factors, replacing the importance of investment bankers.

site_title: Davos Man answers Trump call as WEF plans US meeting to discuss jobs
summary: The World Economic Forum (WEF) plans a special meeting in Washington, D.C. to discuss jobs and investment opportunities with US companies, responding to Donald Trump's call to bring jobs back to the US. The meeting will explore ways for companies to engage with the new administration and address issues raised during Trump's campaign. The WEF's annual meeting in Davos will also feature discussions on the rise of populism and solutions to societal problems, with a focus on "responsive and responsible leadership."

site_title: Bundesbank at 60 holds lessons for ECB
summary: The Bundesbank is marking its 60th anniversary, highlighting its lessons for the European Central Bank (ECB). Created in 1957, the Bundesbank was designed with the ECB in mind, sharing many similarities in its mandate and independence. The institution's commitment to price stability and independence from politics has earned it a reputation as one of Europe's most successful central banks. The Bundesbank's past experiences, including its role in maintaining the eurozone's financial plumbing and defending its independence, serve as a model for the ECB, which faces similar challenges.

site_title: Kaisa mystery lingers as Chinese builder delays financial reports again
summary: Kaisa Group Holdings, China's first property developer to default on dollar bonds, has delayed releasing financial reports for the third time, pushing back the expected release to the Chinese New Year holiday. The company's public relations firm cited the need to discuss findings of an investigation into its debts, following a forensic accounting report that revealed former executives used undisclosed borrowing pacts. The delay has raised concerns about lax corporate governance and the risks faced by investors in China's property bond market.

site_title: Oil's cost-squeeze generates output dividend for Norway
summary: Norway's oil industry has seen a production windfall despite a cost-squeeze, with the Norwegian Petroleum Directorate raising its output forecast for 2017-2020 by 8% due to improvements in drilling efficiency and cost-cutting measures. Producers pumped 6% more crude than expected over the past two years, with Statoil ASA reducing production well times by 40% and cutting costs by 30%. This efficiency has allowed the industry to maintain production despite declining investment, with the NPD's director general stating that "there's a great focus among the companies to maintain production, and it's paying off."

site_title: China sovereign wealth fund plans more US investments
summary: China's sovereign wealth fund, the China Investment Corporation (CIC), plans to increase investments in the US, particularly in private equity and hedge funds, due to low returns in public markets. CIC's chairman, Ding Xuedong, aims to boost alternative investments and consider direct investments in US infrastructure and manufacturing projects, estimated to require at least $8 trillion. Ding called for fair treatment of Chinese investors in the US market, stating CIC is willing to accept regulatory scrutiny, and hopes to avoid double standards.

site_title: JPMorgan upgrades Indonesia, lifting call that riled Jakarta
summary: JPMorgan Chase & Co upgraded its assessment of Indonesia's stock market, reversing a bearish call that prompted the Indonesian government to cut business ties with the US bank. The bank's analysts raised their "tactical" view of Indonesian equities to "neutral" due to subsiding volatility in emerging-market bonds following Donald Trump's US election victory. The upgrade was made after the government stopped using JPMorgan as a primary dealer and underwriter for sovereign bonds. The Indonesian government welcomed the bank's new assessment, saying it was more in line with fundamentals.

site_title: Singapore art platform expands into China
summary: Singapore's online art platform The Artling has secured S$2.5 million in funding from Edipresse Media and acquired Chinese art website Artshare.com. This move expands The Artling's reach and client base, which already includes major companies such as Twitter and Google. The Artling, founded in 2013, sells works by over 850 Asian artists, and the acquisition of Artshare.com strengthens its position in the Asian art market.
