The partnership is expected to further grow The Artling's client base and presence in the region.

images.alt_text: Singapore's online art platform The Artling, founded by Talenia Phua Gajardo (above), announced on Monday that it has acquired Artshare.com.
Ai Weiwei's series of photos titled "To Fight With Crossed Arms", created in collaboration with MAP Office, is featured on Chinese art website Artshare.com.

site_title: STI weakens in line with soft Wall Street
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) closed 11.95 points lower at 3,013.12, rebounding from an intraday low of 2,999 due to concerns over US economic worries. Despite this, analysts expect cautious trading ahead of President-elect Donald Trump's office on Friday. Banks were the main driver of the index's decline, with Phillip Capital recommending an "underweight" on the sector due to concerns over rising interest rates and loan-to-deposit ratios. Other blue chips, such as SPH and Best World International, also experienced declines, with SPH's shares falling 3.5% due to a 43.8% drop in net profit.

site_title: It's Merkel vs Facebook in German election year
summary: German Chancellor Angela Merkel's government is pushing Facebook and other social media networks to curb the spread of malicious posts, including hate speech and fake news. A proposed law would require companies to respond to complaints and delete such content within 24 hours or face fines, with penalties potentially reaching $757,000. The move comes as Merkel campaigns for a fourth term as chancellor and her party seeks to protect Germany's democratic process against manipulation. The law is expected to be enacted before the national election in September, with Merkel's party seeking stricter control of online vicious attacks.

site_title: Incoming US first lady has high heels to fill, but few designers will help
summary: Incoming US First Lady Melania Trump faces a challenging fashion landscape as designers refuse to dress her due to her husband's divisive campaign. Despite initial support from some top designers, many are boycotting her, citing incompatibility with their shared values. Melania, a former model, has expressed a desire to emulate traditional First Ladies like Jackie Kennedy, but her European style has been criticized as not representative of American fashion. Her friend and inauguration planner, Stephanie Winston Wolkoff, is urging her to step up and showcase her own style.

site_title: US insurers get inside cars, mouths, grocery carts in profit search
summary: US insurers are increasingly using technology to collect real-time data on their customers, aiming to assess risk more accurately and set rates accordingly. Devices in cars, wearable trackers, and Bluetooth-enabled toothbrushes provide insurers with valuable information. While some consumers welcome the benefits, concerns arise that insurers may cherry-pick profitable customers, hike rates, or deny coverage to those who refuse to participate. Insurers argue that data collection improves risk assessment and attracts high-quality clients, but critics warn that this approach may fundamentally change the insurance business.

site_title: Surbana axes 50 'poor performers'; MOM in talks with unions
summary: Surbana Jurong, a Singapore-based infrastructure consultancy, has cut 50 employees from its payroll, citing performance reasons. However, released employees claim the number is likely higher, with over 200 names on the final list. The affected employees include those who were "unfairly downgraded" at the last performance appraisal. The Ministry of Manpower is investigating the termination of employment involving Surbana employees. The incident has raised concerns about the company's HR practices, with experts saying it's a faux pas to flag an employee's performance as the main reason for letting them go.

images.alt_text: An MOM spokesman confirmed that the ministry was looking into the "termination of employment" involving employees under the Surbana group of companies.

site_title: CapitaLand offloads The Nassim
summary: CapitaLand has sold its 100% stake in Nassim Hill Realty (NHR) to private firm Kheng Leong for S$411.6 million, including 45 unsold units in luxury freehold condominium The Nassim. The sale avoids paying extension charges of S$9.3 million due to be paid if the units remained unsold by August 2017. The developer cited the need to avoid additional costs, including marketing and maintenance expenses.

site_title: Sunpower Group secures 338m yuan project in Shandong
summary: Sunpower Group secured a 338 million yuan (S$70 million) project in Shandong, China, to build and operate a centralized heat transfer oil project. The 30-year concession agreement was awarded to a 75-25 joint venture company between Sunpower Technology and a local company. The project's first phase will cost 250 million yuan and is expected to be completed by the end of this year, with operations starting in the first quarter of next year. The project is expected to have a positive impact on Sunpower's financial position and generate recurring income.

site_title: S'pore tops Asia-Pacific in talent competitiveness: study
summary: Singapore has topped the Asia-Pacific region in talent competitiveness for the fourth consecutive year, according to the Global Talent Competitiveness Index (GTCI). Internationally, it ranked second only to Switzerland in attracting and retaining talent. However, the city-state lagged behind in the "tolerance of immigrants" category. The report highlights the need for education system reforms and a culture of continuous learning to adapt to technological change, with experts calling for a combination of employer flexibility and social protection.

site_title: Corporate Indonesia eyes local debt market as dollar rises
summary: Indonesian companies are turning to local rupiah bonds to refinance dollar debt amid currency volatility. Animal feed manufacturer Japfa Comfeed and tyre-maker Gajah Tunggal are among those considering rupiah bonds to repay US dollar obligations. The trend coincides with efforts by Indonesian authorities to encourage domestic buying of rupiah bonds, which have seen a six-fold year-on-year increase in pension funds' net purchases. The domestic bond market is expected to handle big issues, but some analysts note it is still not deep enough to absorb large deals.

site_title: All aboard for the rail benefits of a high-speed train system
summary: Singapore and Malaysia are investing in a high-speed rail (HSR) link between the two countries, expected to transform regional and economic development. The 350km journey between Singapore and Kuala Lumpur will take just 90 minutes, promising to create 30,000 jobs over 10 years and boost economic growth. The project is part of a larger regional HSR network, with plans to connect Thailand, Vietnam, Myanmar, Laos, and Cambodia. High-speed rail is seen as an attractive solution to Asean's economic development, offering multiple benefits including reduced congestion, increased mobility, and environmental sustainability.

images.alt_text: Singapore Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong with his Malaysian counterpart Najib Razak in Putrajaya on Dec 13 following an official signing ceremony for the Singapore-KL HSR.

site_title: Xi says Chinese economy to continue growing steadily
summary: President Xi Jinping stated that China's economy will continue growing steadily while resisting protectionism, despite global economic headwinds. China's economy is performing steadily, according to Xi.

site_title: UK to use Trump's backing as lever in Brexit talks
summary: The UK government is bolstering relations with the Trump administration, partly as a lever in Brexit negotiations. US President-elect Donald Trump said the US will offer Britain a fair trade deal within weeks of his taking office, calling Brexit a "great thing." The UK appears to be adopting a hardline negotiating strategy, which may lead to a "Hard Brexit" if the EU doesn't compromise on immigration control. Sterling briefly tumbled after the confirmation of the tough negotiating stance, with the market fearing damage to British trade and economy.

site_title: Making technology a friend of Asia's SMEs, not a foe
summary: Asia is poised to become the world's economic centre, with small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) driving Digital Asia. Technology will be the key success factor, enabling businesses to do more with less, introduce new services faster, and improve profitability. The region's "always on" societies demand constant innovation, and technology must keep up with these rapidly changing demands. By developing high standards for end-to-end products and services, technology can become a friend to SMEs, rather than a foe, in this new digital future.

site_title: NTUC emerges as substantial shareholder of CMT
summary: NTUC has emerged as a substantial shareholder of CapitaLand Mall Trust (CMT) after purchasing 5 million shares for S$10.07 million, increasing its stake to 5.04%. This move follows a 0.5-cent drop in CMT units to S$1.99 on Monday.

site_title: India's Jaitley says July 1 rollout of GST "more realistic"
summary: India's Finance Minister Arun Jaitley has revised the rollout date of the Goods and Services Tax (GST) from April 1 to July 1, citing a three-month deadlock on who would administer the tax. The GST, aimed at transforming India's economy into a single market, is expected to have federal and state elements. The new tax overhaul is seen as India's biggest since independence in 1947, with the potential to boost the country's economy.

site_title: Anti-globalisation is No 1 threat facing Asia-Pacific: report
summary: A risk consultancy firm has stated that anti-globalization sentiment in the Asia-Pacific region is the greatest threat to its economic and political security over the next decade. This sentiment is fueled by territorial tensions, particularly with China, and a resurgent China's willingness to press its claims. Countries like Japan and those in South-east Asia, such as Malaysia and the Philippines, are shifting their allegiances to counter US uncertainty. China's slowdown and Western protectionism are also expected to lead to populism in Asia, with elites seeking to shore up their legitimacy.

site_title: High Court places Oriental Group under interim judicial management
summary: The Singapore High Court has placed Oriental Group, a steel trader and manufacturer, under interim judicial management following a creditor's application. Muk Siew Peng of KordaMentha Pte Ltd has been appointed as the interim judicial manager. This move aims to ensure the company's financial stability and protect its creditors. The company's listing on the Catalist has not been affected by this decision.

site_title: Where's the productivity dividend promised by technology?
summary: US retailers Macy's and Sears are struggling due to e-commerce's impact, with Macy's closing 100 stores and Sears selling its Craftsman tools line for $900 million. Despite technological advancements, productivity growth has slowed dramatically, with average labour productivity increasing only 0.4% annually from 2010 to 2015. The author attributes this to "parallel technologies," where companies must invest in both old and new technologies, resulting in offsetting productivity gains. This reallocation of resources has weakened productivity growth, raising concerns about long-term stagnation in wages and incomes.

site_title: Priceline founder raises US$50m for new venture
summary: Jay Walker, founder of Priceline.com, has raised $50 million for Upside.com, a new startup that offers discounts to small business travelers by suggesting alternative travel routes and accommodations. The website, valued at over $200 million, allows users to receive a 10-15% discount and a gift card for being flexible with travel plans. Walker has agreements with 1,200 hotels and targets small business travelers, expecting the model to soon be adopted by larger businesses.

site_title: Saudi pledges adherence to oil cut, confident others will
summary: Saudi Arabia's energy minister, Khalid al-Falih, pledged the country's strict adherence to its oil production cut under the global agreement, expressing confidence that the plan to prop up prices would work. The deal aims to reduce oil output by nearly 1.8 million bpd for six months, with Saudi Arabia having already cut production by more than 486,000 bpd. Al-Falih expects the market to rebalance by the first half of 2017, allowing oil prices to rise to their 5-year average.

images.alt_text: Saudi Arabia will adhere strictly to its commitment to cut output under the global agreement among oil producers, its energy minister said on Monday, expressing confidence that Opec's plan to prop up prices would work.

site_title: Update: 37 killed in Turkish 747 cargo jet crash
summary: A Boeing 747 cargo jet operated by ACT Airlines crashed while attempting to land at Manas airport in Kyrgyzstan, killing at least 37 people, including 4 crew members. The cause of the crash is unknown, and an investigation is underway. The plane was leased to ACT by LCI Freight Ltd and was operated as flight TK6491. ACT Airlines has a fleet of eight 747s, and the company is 49% owned by China's HNA Group.

site_title: IMF boosts US growth estimate on expected stimulus
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) has boosted its US growth estimate to 2.3% for 2017 due to expected stimulus spending by the incoming Trump administration, but keeps global growth forecasts unchanged at 3.4% for 2017 and 3.6% for 2018. The forecasts are uncertain and risk rising protectionism, while China's GDP growth is expected to slow.

site_title: Investors turn wary as Brexit, Trump uncertainty grows
summary: Investors sold sterling and stocks on Monday amid uncertainty over Brexit and US President-elect Donald Trump's policies. The dollar rose, rebounding after a weak week, while investors sought shelter in gold and the Japanese yen. US markets were closed for the Martin Luther King Day holiday, potentially exacerbating price moves. The uncertainty surrounding Trump's inauguration and Brexit's impact on the global economy has investors turning wary, leading to a decline in riskier assets.

site_title: Political instability here to stay in a world still mired in discontent
summary: Global political instability is expected to persist, driven by economic inequality, legacy of the 2008 financial crisis, and pre-existing socio-economic discontent. The past decade has seen unusually high turbulence, with governments voted out of office, protests and revolutions across the world, and the rise of anti-establishment and anti-globalization movements. The role of social media has also been a factor, amplifying discontent and mobilizing action. While economic growth may mitigate some factors, others, such as youth unemployment and long-term damage to earnings potential, will continue to fuel protest.

site_title: Vallianz enters into S$7m subscription agreement for issuance of 350m new shares
summary: Vallianz Holdings has entered into a S$7 million subscription agreement for the issuance of 350 million new shares, valued at S$0.02 each. The shares represent about 9.7% of the company's current issued share capital and are expected to take up 8.9% of the enlarged share capital. The net proceeds, after deducting expenses, will be approximately S$6.8 million, with half used to strengthen alliances and joint ventures and the other half for working capital. The listing of these new shares on the Catalist awaits approval from the Singapore Exchange.

site_title: Ford announces recall of Kuga cars in South Africa after fires
summary: Ford is recalling 4,500 Kuga SUVs in South Africa due to safety concerns over 39 reported incidents of vehicles bursting into flames. The fires were caused by overheating and oil leaks. A voluntary safety recall has been issued, requiring all affected vehicles to be taken to a Ford dealer as soon as possible. The issue is related to poor coolant circulation, which can lead to an oil leak and engine component fire. Ford has confirmed the problem and is taking corrective action to address the issue.

site_title: BMW will open Mexican factory in 2019 despite Trump threat
summary: BMW plans to open a Mexican factory in 2019, despite US President-elect Donald Trump's warning of a border tax on vehicles made in Mexico and destined for the US. BMW executive Peter Schwarzenbauer confirmed the plans, stating the new plant in San Luis Potosi will produce the BMW 3 Series for the global market, adding to existing production facilities in Germany and China. The factory will not be relocated to the US as Trump suggested.

site_title: JPMorgan looks for big payoff from lead in deposit race
summary: JPMorgan Chase has grown its deposits at a faster rate than major competitors over the past five years, with a 11% increase in 2016 and $61 billion in new deposits. The bank's deposits now total $607 billion, setting it up for a potential payoff if it can lend them at higher interest rates in a stronger economy. Analysts say JPMorgan's strategy of maintaining a strong branch network has paid off, but the bank's ability to maintain deposit growth will depend on factors such as loan demand and lending rates.

images.alt_text: Perhaps the most substantial driver of Chase's deposit growth? Sheer size and scale: it has more resources than competitors to spend to build up deposits.

site_title: 'Mind the closing doors': UK railway battle has echoes of Thatcher
summary: A prolonged strike by Southern Rail, a UK railway company, has sparked a bitter dispute over who should open and close train doors. The dispute, which has lasted 10 months, has resulted in 25 days of strikes, with 40% of services being late. The strike, which has cost £300 million, has been fueled by disagreements between the company and unions over the role of train drivers in operating the doors. The government has refused to talk to the unions, with Transport Secretary Chris Grayling accusing them of striking for no good reason, while union supporters claim the government is prolonging the feud to break the labor movement.

site_title: Why 'bringing jobs back' won't - and can't - mean more hiring of workers
summary: US President Donald Trump's efforts to bring jobs back by shifting factories to the US from Mexico may not lead to more hiring of workers. Experts attribute job losses to industrial robots and complex global supply chains rather than countries like China and Mexico. The shift may actually lead to job losses in sectors that rely on automation, making it harder for workers to find employment. The interconnected economy and technological advancements are driving the need for more efficient and automated production processes.

site_title: Emirates to open up Dubai luxury lounges to lower-tier frequent flyers
summary: Emirates is opening its luxury lounges in Dubai to lower-tier frequent flyers, allowing Blue-tier status members to pay $100 for the business lounge and $200 for the first class lounge. The move aims to boost revenues amid a 75% drop in half-year profit. This policy change follows the introduction of fees for advanced seat selection for economy passengers in October and plans to introduce premium economy by 2018. Emirates is also exploring other revenue sources, including fees on bags, to counter the impact of overcapacity and tighter corporate travel budgets.

site_title: German transport minister seeks recall of Fiat cars: Bild
summary: German Transport Minister Alexander Dobrindt is calling for the European Commission to ensure Fiat Chrysler cars that break pollution rules are recalled. Dobrindt claims Fiat uses illegal shut-off devices, while Fiat Chrysler Automobiles denies any wrongdoing. The EU Commission is investigating Fiat Chrysler, which is also under US Justice Department scrutiny for allegedly failing to disclose software that violates emissions standards. The German government is escalating a feud with Italy over vehicle emissions, with Italian authorities cooperating with the EU Commission. A recall of Fiat vehicles is being demanded.

site_title: Sinwa issues profit warning for full-year and Q4 2016
summary: Sinwa Limited, a marine supplies and logistics services provider, has issued a profit warning for its full-year and Q4 2016 financials due to an impairment loss on an asset held for sale. The company expects to record a loss in Q4 2016 and FY2016, with further details to be disclosed in its unaudited financial results.

site_title: Malaysia: Stocks end 13 points lower
summary: Malaysian shares closed 13.66 points lower on Monday, with the Kuala Lumpur Composite Index reaching 1,658.84. The index saw 1.78 billion lots traded, with losers outnumbering gainers 611 to 225.

site_title: Xi says Chinese economy to keep growing steadily
summary: China's President Xi Jinping stated that the country's economy will remain stable and continue growing steadily, despite global headwinds, with a 6.7% GDP growth expected in 2016. Xi emphasized the need to reject protectionism and de-globalization, calling for closer economic cooperation globally. He also expressed confidence in China's ability to upgrade its industries and become more efficient, equitable, and sustainable, with Swiss companies playing a key role in this process.

site_title: SMEs continue to miss the value of insurance for the cost
summary: SMEs in Singapore continue to struggle with financial protection, despite being a vital part of the country's economy. The volatile business environment, caused by global events and local issues such as a manpower crunch and economic downturn, poses a threat to their survivability and profitability. The need for insurance coverage remains unmet, with SMEs often prioritizing costs over protection. Experts warn that without adequate insurance, these businesses may struggle to recover from setbacks, ultimately impacting the economy as a whole.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks down as Takata dives on US deal
summary: Japanese shares fell on Monday as Takata's stock dropped 1.00% following the firm's guilty plea to US$1 billion in settling a deadly airbag scandal. Tokyo's Nikkei index fell 1.00% to 19,095.24, while the Topix index dropped 0.92% to 1,530.64.

site_title: South Korea: Stocks, won end lower ahead of US events; Samsung Elec falls
summary: South Korean shares and the won declined ahead of US events, with the Korea Composite Stock Price Index (KOSPI) closing 0.6% lower at 2,064.17 points. Samsung Electronics fell 3% following news of an arrest warrant for Jay Lee, the company's chairman. Market sentiment cooled as investors awaited Federal Reserve Chair Janet Yellen's speech and Donald Trump's inauguration.

site_title: Greek auditors approve sale of railway operator to Italian railways
summary: Greek auditors have approved the sale of railway operator TRAINOSE to Italian railways Ferrovie dello Stato, paving the way for the deal to proceed. The sale is part of Greece's 2015 bailout deal, aiming for 5.8 billion euros in revenue by 2018. The country expects to receive 45 million euros from the sale this year, helping to offset 750 million euros in state subsidies. The sale will also allow Greece to write off debt to the European Union, with the European Commission expected to approve the debt write-off once the deal is signed.

site_title: Koh Brothers forays into beauty market with South Korea's Koracle
summary: Koh Brothers' subsidiary, K-Skin, has entered into a memorandum of understanding (MOU) with Koracle to form a joint venture for setting up beauty clinics and wellness spas in Singapore and Johor, Malaysia. The new clinics will provide specialized beauty consultation and treatment services. The MOU is not expected to have a material impact on Koh Brothers' financials for the financial year ending Dec 31, 2017. This marks Koh Brothers' foray into the beauty market.

site_title: Oman's Bank Muscat negotiating pricing for loan refinancing, sources say
summary: Bank Muscat, Oman's largest bank, is negotiating a US$550-600 million three-year loan to refinance a 2014 loan. The new loan may offer an all-in pricing of 185 basis points over the London Interbank Offered Rate, down from 140 basis points. The refinancing is expected to close by March and reflects changed market conditions due to lower oil prices. The transaction may offer a discount of 10-15 basis points compared to a similar deal in 2016, despite being larger in size.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's economic fundamentals remain strong, according to MAS's Ravi Menon, despite potential global headwinds. Foreign cars will pay a Reciprocal Road Charge of $6.40 per entry starting February 15. Inflation expectations rose to 2.7% in Singapore, while private homes sales declined to 367 units in December. The Straits Times Index fell 11.95 points due to Dow futures losses. Internationally, the US announced a tariff on Vietnam, the Asian garment industry braced for higher tariffs, and China's GDP growth is expected to slow.

site_title: Singapore shares finish weaker after fall in Dow futures
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) fell 11.95 points to 3,013.12, closing at S$818 million in thin volume. The drop was triggered by a 50-point loss in Dow futures, but the index rebounded from its intraday low. Despite the loss, the STI has been on a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares start week with losses
summary: Hong Kong shares fell 0.96% on Monday, with the Hang Seng Index closing at 22,718.15, amid worries about a rise in fresh listings that could absorb investors' cash. Mainland Chinese markets also declined, with the Shanghai Composite Index down 0.30% and the Shenzhen Composite Index plummeting 3.62%.

site_title: Hong Kong activists declare 'war' after appeal bid snub
summary: Two Hong Kong activists, Baggio Leung and Yau Wai-ching, declared "war" on authorities after a court rejected their appeal bid to take their seats in parliament. The pair, who took part in a swearing-in ceremony with deliberate misread oaths and pro-independence flags, were disqualified due to Beijing's "binding" interpretation of Hong Kong's constitution. The court ruled that the pair would pay costs of HK$167,851 each and ordered them to seek a direct hearing with the court of final appeal.

site_title: Traits of fintech champs
summary: Successful fintech companies share key traits that enable them to scale and succeed, particularly in Singapore's fintech space. These traits include leveraging stakeholder support, collaborating with authorities and industry peers, taking measured risks and pushing boundaries, having visionary leaders with integrity and commercial responsibility, and being outward-looking and globally minded. By exemplifying these traits, fintech companies can discover relevance within the ecosystem, develop innovations with support from regulators and industry peers, and ultimately succeed in the competitive global fintech community.

images.alt_text: Visionary leaders are also inventors. Many would consider Elon Musk and Jack Ma as such, with Tesla forever changing the face of electric vehicles, and Alibaba's Alipay being the most popular online payment service to China's 1.3 billion population.

site_title: Samsung Group says it does not accept bribery accusations
summary: Samsung Group denied accepting bribery accusations against its leader, Jay Y Lee, stating it's difficult to understand the special prosecutors' decision. The special prosecutors accused Lee of paying bribes to further his succession or the merger of two affiliates in 2015. NPS chief Moon Hyung Pyo was indicted on charges of abuse of power and false testimony for allegedly ordering the US$8 billion merger in support of the merger. Moon was arrested after acknowledging ordering the pension fund to support the merger while he was head of the health ministry.

site_title: Europe:Shares open lower but FTSE rally continues
summary: European shares opened lower on Monday, weighed down by banking and auto stocks, but the FTSE rose to a fresh record high due to a weaker pound. The pan-European STOXX index fell 1.3%, while the FTSE added 0.1%. Shares in Luxottica and Essilor surged after agreeing on a 46-billion euro merger deal, while the Italian banking index fell 1.5% after a credit rating cut.

site_title: CapitaLand sells developer of The Nassim project for S$412m
summary: CapitaLand sold its 100% stake in Nassim Hill Realty, the developer of The Nassim condominium, to Kheng Leong Company for S$411.6 million. The sale is subject to post-completion adjustments and was paid entirely in cash. The deal would have increased CapitaLand's earnings per share by 3.8 cents if completed on Jan 1, 2016, but the impact on its net tangible asset per share would not be material if completed on Sept 30, 2016.

site_title: ST Aerospace bags orders worth S$840m in Q4 of 2016
summary: ST Aerospace secured contracts worth around S$840 million in Q4 2016, including a five-year agreement with Alaska Airlines to provide MRO maintenance support for its CFM56-7B engines. The deal is expected to cover over 60 planned maintenance commitments and commences immediately.

site_title: Saudi to launch US $30-50b renewable energy programme soon -minister
summary: Saudi Arabia plans to launch a US$30-50 billion renewable energy programme by 2023, aiming to produce 10 gigawatts of power. The programme will be part of the country's economic reform efforts to reduce reliance on oil and generate foreign exchange. Additionally, Saudi Arabia is working on feasibility studies for two commercial nuclear reactors, totaling 2.8 gigawatts, and plans to connect its renewable energy projects with neighboring countries. The programme is expected to involve significant investment from private companies, both within and outside the kingdom.

images.alt_text: Saudi Arabia will launch in coming weeks a renewable energy programme that is expected to involve investment of between US$30 billion and US$50 billion by 2023, Saudi Energy Minister Khalid al-Falih said on Monday.

site_title: BOJ offers brighter view on regional Japan economies
summary: The Bank of Japan has raised its economic assessment for three of Japan's nine regions, citing a pick-up in private consumption and demand from emerging Asian economies. The upgrades reflect a moderate recovery trend, with the central bank holding off on expanding stimulus. The BOJ Governor Haruhiko Kuroda expressed optimism on the economy, stating it is likely to expand moderately ahead. The report will be reviewed by the bank's board at its Jan 30-31 rate review, with some branch managers warning of risks due to uncertainty over US policies under the new president.

site_title: Burberry's new CEO to join firm next week
summary: Burberry's new CEO, Marco Gobbetti, will join the firm on January 27 as executive chairman, Asia Pacific and Middle East, and take on full responsibilities as CEO in July. Gobbetti, previously chief executive of Celine, was named as Christopher Bailey's successor in July 2016. Burberry faces challenges, including depressed demand in US department stores and exposure to a slowdown in China, but has benefited from the weaker pound and foreign exchange benefits, driving a 46% rise in shares over the last year. Analysts forecast a 25% rise in third-quarter sales.

site_title: Samurai 2K Aerosol up by as much as 37.5% in debut trading
summary: Samurai 2K Aerosol's shares surged 37.5% above its IPO price, reaching a high of 27.5 Singapore cents, on the Catalist. The company, a Malaysia-based aerosol coating specialist, manufactured and distributed products to South-east Asian markets. Its shares began trading at 25 Singapore cents and later fell to 24.5 cents apiece. Established in 1997, Samurai 2K aims to provide coating solutions for the automotive industry.

site_title: Singapore top in Asia-Pacific for talent competitiveness: study
summary: Singapore ranked first in the Asia-Pacific and second globally in the Global Talent Competitiveness Index (GTCI) for the fourth consecutive year, surpassing Australia. The top global spot was held by Switzerland, with Britain and the US placing third and fourth respectively. The countries sharing key traits for talent competitiveness included educational systems, flexible employment policies, mobility, entrepreneurship, and high stakeholder connectedness. The GTCI measures talent competitiveness and aims to help decision-makers develop strategies to boost their competitiveness.

site_title: Sunpower Group wins S$70m contract for heat transfer project in Shandong
summary: Sunpower Group has won a 338 million yuan (S$70 million) contract to build and operate a centralised heat transfer oil project in Shandong, China. The 30-year concession agreement is held with the Liutuan Industrial Park in Changyi City. The project, carried out by a joint venture, will start operations in the first quarter of 2018. Funding for the investment will come from convertible bonds, bank loans, and internal resources.

images.alt_text: SUNPOWER Group has won a 338 million yuan (S$70 million) project to build and operate a centralised heat transfer oil project in Shandong, China.

site_title: Singaporeans' inflation expectation inches up to 2.7% on global trade headwind fears
summary: Singapore's median one-year-ahead inflation expectation has increased to 2.7% from its five-year low of 2.63%, according to a quarterly survey by the Sim Kee Boon Institute for Financial Economics. This is attributed to global trade headwinds, with a principal investigator warning that protectionist policies could hinder economic growth. Despite this, the inflation figure remains lower than the historical average of 3.5%. The survey suggests that Singapore's economy, being trade-dependent, may prepare for possible price increases.

site_title: Japan govt to name underwriters for further Japan Post share sale: source
summary: The Japanese government plans to select underwriters for a further sale of shares in Japan Post Holdings, a government official confirmed. The sale, worth 1.4 trillion yen, would be the country's second major privatization in 30 years. A government panel will meet to decide criteria for selecting lead underwriters, with no clear timeline for the selection. The government previously sold over 16 trillion yen worth of shares in Japan Post and its subsidiaries in 2015.

site_title: Sunac slumps as US$2.2b bet on China tech tycoon questioned
summary: Sunac China Holdings Ltd. fell 10% in Hong Kong, its largest decline in over 16 months, as investors questioned its $2.2 billion investment in LeEco, a cash-strapped Chinese tech tycoon's empire. The investment, which includes stakes in video-streaming and TV giant Leshi Internet and Le Vision Pictures, marks Sunac's first foray beyond real estate. Analysts express concerns about the deal's profitability and potential impact on Sunac's balance sheet, citing a "fairly aggressive" year for acquisitions that strained its balance sheet.

site_title: Ground breaking ceremony for Mandai rejuvenation project
summary: A groundbreaking ceremony marked the start of the Mandai rejuvenation project in Singapore, set to add a Bird Park, Rainforest Park, and nature-themed indoor attraction to the existing Singapore Zoo and other parks. The project, spanning multiple phases, aims to utilize impacted land and will be completed by 2020 and 2021 for the Bird Park and Rainforest Park, respectively.

site_title: Cathay Pacific to revamp fuel hedges, workforce
summary: Cathay Pacific Airways, Asia's largest international airline, plans to shorten its fuel-hedging program and revamp its workforce to halt a decline in earnings. The airline will reassign employees from outdated roles to new jobs with a "digital focus" and considers redundancies. Cathay Pacific lost HK$8.4 billion in fuel hedging over three years and HK$4.49 billion in the first half of last year. The airline will hedge jet fuel for two years, cutting costs and boosting efficiency to become more agile and efficient.

site_title: Australia: Shares up as miners rally; NZ closes at 3-mth high
summary: Australian shares rose 0.5% on Monday, driven by a 1.8% gain in the mining index, its highest in over two years. Iron ore futures surged 8% in China, boosted by strong steel price gains, as global miner BHP Billiton hit a 17-month high. The S&P/ASX 200 index closed at 5,748.4 points.

site_title: Hot stock: SGX queries Perennial Real Estate on high trading activity
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) queried Perennial Real Estate Holdings on unusual trading activity of its stock, with over 420,000 shares traded within half an hour of market opening on Monday. The company responded that it was unaware of any information that might explain the trading volume, confirming compliance with listing rules. The incident occurred on January 16, 2017.

site_title: Tokyo office boom fades with more space, fewer workers
summary: Tokyo's commercial property market is expected to peak due to a glut of new offices and declining office workers. Despite Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's economic policies, including ultra-low interest rates, the market is facing a surplus of space. Rents have risen since 2014, but the number of office workers is expected to decline, leading to a decrease in demand. This trend is a sign of a slowing market, with prices potentially stabilizing or even decreasing. The Tokyo office boom is fading, marking a shift in the city's property market.

site_title: Football: China to cut foreign player numbers on pitch
summary: China's Chinese Football Association (CFA) has introduced new rules for the 2017 season, limiting teams in the top-flight Chinese Super League to three foreign players per match. The move aims to promote the development of Chinese local footballers and curb high transfer fees and salaries. The new rules follow a recent influx of foreign talent, with clubs spending millions on players like Oscar and Carlos Tevez. The decision is seen as a step towards China becoming a major football power, but fans and authorities worry it may come at the cost of developing home-grown talent.

site_title: Indonesian tycoon Tahir says keen to buy StanChart's Permata stake
summary: Indonesian tycoon Tahir expressed interest in buying Standard Chartered's entire stake in Indonesian bank PT Bank Permata Tbk. Tahir stated he wants all of Permata shares, but is targeting StanChart's sale first. Following the announcement, Permata shares surged up to 12.4%. The exact terms of the deal have not been disclosed, and both Standard Chartered and Permata were unavailable for comment.

site_title: China should stop intervening in FX market and let yuan float: researcher
summary: A senior researcher at the Chinese Academy of Social Sciences, Xiao Lisheng, recommends that China stop intervening in the foreign exchange market, devalue the yuan, and let it float freely to restore stability. The yuan lost 6.6% against the US dollar last year, its largest annual loss since 1994. Authorities should allow a one-off adjustment to the currency's exchange rate to achieve a free float, rather than continuing to intervene. This move could help reduce capital outflows and stabilize the yuan.

site_title: Platts launches Middle East LNG price marker as region's demand grows
summary: Commodity pricing agency S&P Global Platts has launched a Middle East LNG price marker, reflecting the growing demand for liquefied natural gas in the region. Demand has grown nearly tenfold since 2010, with Egypt and Pakistan taking the largest shares. The new price assessment aims to reflect the Middle East's increasing role as an LNG import destination, rather than just an exporter. This move comes as Egypt and Pakistan launch or award tenders for short-term and medium-term supplies to capitalize on a global gas glut.

images.alt_text: Commodity pricing agency S&P Global Platts will begin assessing prices for liquefied natural gas (LNG) delivered to the Middle East and Pakistan, reflecting growing imports into a region better known as an exporter, the company said on Monday.

site_title: South Korea prosecutors to seek arrest of Samsung chief
summary: South Korean prosecutors plan to seek a warrant to arrest Samsung Group chief Jay Y Lee as corruption allegations escalate against President Park Geun-hye. Lee was questioned for 22 hours, and a court hearing is likely to take place on Wednesday. Prosecutors investigate whether Samsung supported a merger of two affiliates in exchange for support from Park's friend, Choi Soon-sil, who is accused of abuse of power and colluding with Park to pressure businesses to contribute to non-profit foundations. If the impeachment of President Park is upheld, an election would be held in two months.

site_title: Developers' private homes sales slide to 367 units in Dec
summary: Developers in Singapore sold 367 private homes in December 2016, down from 860 in November, but close to the 384 units sold in December 2015. Including executive condominiums, developers sold 580 units, higher than the 508 units sold in December 2015. The figures were released by the Urban Redevelopment Authority.

site_title: Ex-UN chief Ban narrows gap in opinion poll for South Korean presidency
summary: Former UN Secretary General Ban Ki-moon is narrowing the gap in an opinion poll for the South Korean presidency, currently leading with 22.2% of likely voters. He has made several campaign appearances since returning to the country and plans to visit public areas to gauge public support. The poll shows Moon Jae-in maintaining his lead at 26.1%, with Lee Jae-myung trailing in third place. Ban has not yet made a decision on his future, but is expected to announce soon.

site_title: Gold rises on Trump uncertainty, Brexit concerns
summary: Gold prices rose 0.5% to $1,203.10 per ounce on Monday, driven by uncertainty over US policy ahead of President-elect Donald Trump's inauguration and concerns over Britain's exit from the European Union. Investors are seeking safe-haven assets amid economic uncertainty. Spot silver rose 0.3% to $16.84 an ounce, while platinum prices were firm at $983.85. Analysts expect gold to retest $1,205-$1,207 per ounce, potentially breaching $1,220.

site_title: Samsung Electronics probe finds battery was main cause of Note 7 fires: source
summary: Samsung Electronics has concluded an investigation into the Galaxy Note 7 fires, finding that the battery was the main cause. The company initially blamed a manufacturing process problem at a supplier but later halted sales of the device. Samsung will announce the investigation results and new measures on January 23, ahead of its fourth-quarter earnings results. The company's mobile business head, Koh Dong-jin, will likely make the announcement. The investigation found that the fires could not be explained by hardware design or software-related matters, and Samsung will replicate the fires during its investigation.

site_title: Angry Birds maker Rovio opens new games studio in London
summary: Finnish mobile game developer Rovio Entertainment has opened a new games studio in London to focus on developing new multiplayer games without relying on the Angry Birds brand. The move comes after the company's profits from the franchise dropped, prompting deep job cuts and divestments. Rovio aims to build a team of 20 people to focus on "massively multiplayer" online games with new intellectual property, aiming to grow its business and increase its employee base. The company has around 400 employees across its four game studios in Finland and Sweden.

images.alt_text: Finnish mobile games and animation company Rovio Entertainment said on Monday it was stepping up its hunt for new hit games by opening a studio in London to focus on new multiplayer games that would not rely on the firm's Angry Birds brand.

site_title: Indonesia exports, imports rise for third month in December
summary: Indonesia's exports and imports rose for the third consecutive month in December, with exports growing 15.57% to $13.77 billion and imports increasing 5.82% to $12.78 billion. This resulted in a trade surplus of around $990 million, higher than the revised $830 million in November. The country's total exports fell 3.95% to $144.4 billion, while imports decreased 4.94% to $135.7 billion. This marks the highest export earnings in 24 months, with a trade surplus of $8.8 billion in 2016, compared to $7.7 billion in 2015.

site_title: Foreign-cars to pay reciprocal road charge when entering Singapore: LTA
summary: Singapore will require foreign-registered cars to pay a Reciprocal Road Charge (RRC) of S$6.40 per-entry when entering the country via Tuas or Woodlands Checkpoint starting February 15, 2017. The charge mirrors Malaysia's RM20 per-entry fee. The LTA will collect RRC with tolls, fees, and Electronic Road Pricing (ERP) fees upon departure. Failure to pay may result in penalties, including fines not exceeding S$1,000 or imprisonment for up to three months.

site_title: Asia's oldest stock exchange BSE may raise 12.43b rupees in IPO
summary: Asia's oldest stock exchange, BSE Ltd, is set to raise up to 12.43 billion rupees (S$260 million) through its initial public offering (IPO) next week. The IPO, led by investors including Singapore Exchange and billionaire George Soros, will value the stock exchange at about 44 billion rupees at the top end of the price range. The offering will be open from Jan 23 to Jan 25, and will be the first in Indian markets in 2017, following a successful year for initial share sales in 2016.

site_title: Update: At least 32 dead as Turkish Airlines cargo plane crash destroys Kyrgyzstan houses
summary: A Turkish Airlines cargo plane crashed into a village near Kyrgyzstan's main airport, killing at least 32 people and destroying homes. The majority of the dead were from the village of Dacha-Suu, where the plane crashed at 7:30am local time. Four pilots on the flight were among the dead, and around 43 houses were damaged. The accident sparked fires, but authorities have localized them. The country's Manas airport has been closed and flights cancelled until evening. Kyrgyz President Almazbek Atambayev returned to Bishkek from China to oversee the response.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares open lower
summary: Tokyo shares opened lower on January 16, 2017, with the Nikkei index falling 0.31% to 19,226.76. The decline followed reports that Britain may be heading towards a clean break with the EU, causing the pound to tumble. The broader Topix index lost 0.23%.

site_title: Meet the Trumps: America's new first family
summary: The Trump family is set to become America's new first family, with Donald Trump as the 45th US president and his wife Melania, a former model from Slovenia, as the first foreign-born US first lady in two centuries. Melania, who speaks five languages, will not move into the White House immediately, instead staying in New York with their 10-year-old son Barron. Ivanka Trump, Donald's 35-year-old daughter, will move to Washington and is expected to take on a prominent role, while her husband Jared Kushner will serve as a special advisor to the president.

site_title: Taiwan: Stocks fall; TSMC down again
summary: Taiwan's main Taiex index fell 0.9% to 9,292.48, driven by a decline in Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co Ltd (TSMC) for the second straight session. TSMC forecast a possible revenue decline in the first quarter, weighing on the electronics subindex. The Taiwan dollar softened to NT$31.658 per US dollar, while Singapore stocks rose 0.4% on Thursday.

site_title: Samsung to disclose Note 7 probe results on Jan 23: Yonhap
summary: Samsung will disclose the results of its investigation into the Galaxy Note 7's fire issue on January 23, following a product safety failure that led to the phone's discontinuation in October. The company has been looking into the cause of the issue, which was one of the biggest in tech history, along with third-party researchers. The announcement will provide clarity on the incident and its impact on consumer safety.

site_title: Sterling plunges after Britain hints at 'hard Brexit'
summary: Sterling plummeted to a 31-year low of US$1.1841 after Britain hinted at a 'hard Brexit', pulling out of the single market and EU customs union. The pound tumbled to US$1.1986 in Asian trade, before recovering to US$1.2044. The prospect of a hard Brexit, which would require a new economic model, has raised concerns about Britain's competitiveness. Finance Minister Philip Hammond said the country would be forced to change its economic model if it is shut out from the single market.

site_title: The global chain that produces your fish
summary:
Here's a 100-word summary of the article content:

Global fish farming has transformed the world's seafood industry, with China emerging as the largest exporter and producer of fish products. The process involves importing eggs, fish food, and even raw fish from Norway, Chile, and Scotland, only to have them processed in China. This has significant environmental and social costs, including disease spread and high carbon emissions. Despite these concerns, the global aquaculture market is expected to reach $242 billion by 2022, with two-thirds of seafood consumed coming from aquaculture farms by 2030. The shift towards farmed fish has also changed the employment landscape.

site_title: Australian, New Zealand dollars advance on depressed pound, off 1-month peak on USD
summary: The Australian and New Zealand dollars reached two-month highs against the depressed pound, trading at A$1.6061 and NZ$1.5071, respectively, due to fears of a "hard Brexit". Sterling plummeted 1% to its lowest level since June 2022. The currencies held near recent peaks against the US dollar. A break below A$1.5950 could lead to a retracement to the 2016 trough of A$1.5582.

site_title: Singapore shares trade lower early Monday
summary: Singapore shares fell 0.51% in early Monday trading, with the Straits Times Index at 3,009.63. The decline was attributed to a lacklustre performance in US and European markets. Stocks like Attilan Group plummeted 20% and 757.3 million shares worth S$122.3 million changed hands.

site_title: Singapore's macro fundamentals are sound, will weather storms: MAS's Ravi Menon
summary: Singapore's macro fundamentals remain sound, according to MAS Managing Director Ravi Menon, who stated that the city-state will weather economic challenges. Menon acknowledged that Singapore needs to improve productivity growth and is not immune to global financial conditions and regional corporate sector stresses. Despite these challenges, MAS is confident in Singapore's resilience, citing its strong economic fundamentals.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks open down on Monday
summary: Hong Kong stocks fell on Monday, with the Hang Seng Index easing 0.22% to 22,886.25, while the Shanghai Composite Index slid 0.27% to 3,104.49. The decline was attributed to growing concerns over a flood of new listings draining liquidity from the market. In contrast, Singapore stocks notched a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data, while US stocks reached fresh records despite tariff uncertainty.

site_title: Aussie shares rebound, miners cheered by higher metals prices; NZ up
summary: Australian shares rose 0.6% on Monday, with the S&P/ASX 200 index reaching its highest level in over two years. Miners benefited from higher metals prices, with copper and aluminium hitting their highest levels in five weeks and 20 months, respectively. BHP Billiton and Rio Tinto rose as much as 2% and 1.8%, respectively. Financials also supported the benchmark, with the 'big 4' banks rising between 0.14% to 0.8%. New Zealand's benchmark index gained 0.2%.

site_title: Beijing will "take off the gloves" if Trump continues on Taiwan: China Daily
summary: China has warned US President-elect Donald Trump that it will "take off the gloves" if he continues to provoke over Taiwan, according to a Chinese state-run newspaper. Trump broke with precedent by congratulating Taiwan's President Tsai Ing-wen and questioned the "One China" policy, which China considers non-negotiable. China's foreign ministry said the policy is the foundation of China-US ties and that Trump's comments were "provocative" and "irresponsible". If Trump continues, China will respond accordingly, indicating a potential escalation in tensions between the two nations.

site_title: Oil prices edge up on weaker US dollar, expected crude output cuts
summary: Oil prices rose on Monday, supported by a weaker US dollar and expectations of Opec and other producers cutting output to curb global oversupply. Brent crude futures were trading at $55.55 per barrel, up 10 US cents, while US West Texas Intermediate crude futures were up 9 US cents at $52.46 a barrel. A weakening US dollar makes fuel purchases cheaper for countries using other currencies domestically, potentially spurring demand. Opec and Russia announced crude output cuts, but traders expect compliance to be around 50-80%, keeping prices supported in the mid-$50s per barrel.

site_title: Kaisa mystery refuses to clear as China builder delays again
summary: Kaisa Group Holdings, a Chinese property developer, has delayed releasing its financial reports for the fourth consecutive time, sparking concerns about its corporate governance. The company, which defaulted on dollar bonds in 2015, has faced scrutiny over its use of undisclosed borrowing pacts and alleged attempts to obscure liabilities. Kaisa aims to release the overdue reports before the Chinese New Year holiday at the end of January, but investors remain wary of the company's ability to repay its debt. The delay is seen as symptomatic of lax corporate governance in China's real estate sector.

site_title: Cutting cash would be a boon for the world's poor: economist
summary: A Harvard economist suggests that eliminating cash could reduce inequality worldwide. The poor would benefit from reduced crime and off-the-books labor, as seen in Scandinavian countries that have largely moved to cashless systems. These nations, such as Denmark, have low corruption rates and high financial inclusion, with most people using debit cards. While Rogoff doesn't advocate for a complete end to cash, he believes it could help problems, particularly for the poor, and could be implemented gradually with the right infrastructure.

site_title: UK M&A to drop sharply in 2017 as investors await Brexit clarity: Baker McKenzie
summary: UK M&A activity is expected to drop sharply in 2017 due to Brexit uncertainty, according to Baker McKenzie. The law firm forecasts a two-thirds decline in UK M&A values to $125 billion in 2017, down from a record $340 billion in 2016. The lack of clarity on Brexit's terms could hurt UK activity, while global deal-making is expected to drop slightly in 2017 but rise in 2018.

site_title: London home owners stay put as Brexit damps appetite to sell
summary: London home owners are showing reluctance to sell their properties due to Brexit uncertainty and increased tax, according to Rightmove. New listings have decreased 14% from last year, while the average asking price rose 1.4% to £624,953. This marks a shift from last year when owners rushed to sell, but now are aware of the challenging market conditions, including high stamp-duty costs and Brexit uncertainty.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open flat on Monday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened flat on Monday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 0.08 points to 1672.02. Trading volume was 70.8 million lots worth RM14.6 million. Gainers outnumbered losers 78 to 48.

site_title: South Korea political crisis escalates as Samsung chief awaits fate
summary: South Korean prosecutors will decide on Monday whether to arrest Samsung Group chief Jay Y Lee on influence-peddling charges, amid a growing scandal involving impeached President Park Geun-hye's government. Lee was held overnight for questioning, while National Pension Service chairman Moon Hyung-pyo was indicted on charges of abuse of power. The Constitutional Court is also reviewing Park's impeachment, which could lead to an election in two months. Former UN Secretary General Ban Ki-moon is expected to run, maintaining a lead over opposition leader Moon Jae-in.

site_title: Hot stock: SGX queries Liongold on high trading activity
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) has queried Liongold Corp on unusual high trading activity, marking the third query in the past five months. As of 9:58 am, Liongold's stock was trading at S$0.002, up S$0.001, with over 843 million shares traded. The SGX is seeking an explanation for the share movements, which have raised concerns about the company's market stability.

site_title: Seoul: Won, stocks sag as market cool ahead of Yellen speech, Trump inauguration
summary: South Korean won and shares fell ahead of US Federal Reserve Chair Janet Yellen's speech on Tuesday, which could boost the US dollar. The won dropped 0.3% to 1,178.7 against the US dollar, while the Korea Composite Stock Price Index (Kospi) fell 0.4% to 2,067.49 points. The decline came as investors cashed in on gains made last week, citing uncertainty from US president-elect Donald Trump's inauguration on Friday.

site_title: Trump's team considers moving White House press room
summary: President-elect Donald Trump's team is considering moving the White House press briefing room from the West Wing to the Old Executive Office Building or the White House Conference Center, allowing more media coverage. The move would accommodate more reporters from around the country and address concerns over the current small briefing room. No decision has been made, but the change could impact access for reporters and the scrutiny of the administration. The White House Correspondents' Association has objected to any move that would restrict access to senior officials.

images.alt_text: President-elect Donald Trump's team could move the White House press briefing room from the West Wing to another location that accommodates more media from around the country, incoming White House Chief of Staff Reince Priebus (right) said on Sunday.

site_title: Eight men own half the world's wealth: Oxfam
summary: Eight men, including Bill Gates, Mark Zuckerberg, and Jeff Bezos, own the same wealth as half the world's population, amounting to $1.9 trillion, according to Oxfam. This level of inequality threatens global societies, leading to growing discontent with mainstream politics. The charity's report, "An economy for the 99 per cent," calls for increased tax rates on the rich and a global agreement to end corporate tax rate competition. The World Economic Forum in Davos will address issues of inequality and responsive leadership.

images.alt_text: Eight men, among them (from left) Jeff Bezos, Mark Zuckerberg and Bill Gates, own the same wealth as half the world's population, a level of inequality which "threatens to pull our societies apart", Oxfam said on Monday ahead of the World Economic Forum opening in Davos.

site_title: Nato 'obsolete', says Trump as he praises Brexit
summary: President-elect Donald Trump described NATO as "obsolete" in an interview, citing its age and the fact that member countries aren't paying their fair share. He also praised Brexit and backed a trade deal with post-EU Britain, saying it would be "good for both sides." Trump criticized Chancellor Angela Merkel's decision to open Germany's doors to refugees, calling it "catastrophic." NATO Secretary General Jens Stoltenberg defended the alliance, saying it's essential for transatlantic security and that the partnership between Europe and the US should not be questioned.

site_title: China's big banks, after record write-offs, poised for recovery
summary: China's major state-owned banks, such as ICBC and CCB, are poised to modestly accelerate profit growth in 2017 as interest margins stabilize and government policies help ease the pace of bad loan formation. After record write-offs and shrinking margins in 2016, banks are adopting debt-restructuring measures like debt-for-equity swaps, and investors are gradually becoming more optimistic. Analysts have increased "buy" and "strong buy" recommendations for over 20 Chinese banks, with some predicting a recovery in shares and higher valuations.

site_title: Stocks to watch: USP, Trendlines, EMS Energy, SingPost
summary: USP Group's subsidiary USPI will appeal a court's decision allowing a major shareholder to wind up SG Support Services. Trendlines Medical Singapore received a grant of up to S$2.2 million from Spring Singapore's Incubator Development Programme. EMS Energy received a termination notice and a claim from Jurong Shipyard for S$1.1 million and S$110,000, respectively. Analysts watch SingPost, with its eCommerce logistics collaboration with Alibaba Group, as a key driver of earnings.

site_title: Job cuts, fewer flights? Cathay Pacific set for overhaul
summary: Cathay Pacific Airways is expected to announce job cuts, cost reductions, and shifts to its short-haul arm due to growing competition from Chinese carriers. The airline scrapped its second-half profit forecast and announced a review of its business. Analysts predict a possible first full-year loss since 2010 and a decline in its share price, which has tumbled to its lowest level since the 2009 global financial crisis. Cathay may need to slash its workforce, reduce frequencies on underperforming routes, and cut costs at its short-haul carrier Cathay Dragon.

images.alt_text: Cathay Pacific Airways is expected to announce job cuts, cost reductions and to shift flights to its short-haul arm when it unveils the results of a key review this week, as it grapples with growing competition from Chinese carriers.

site_title: Indonesia Inc looks to refinance debt onshore as dollar rises
summary: Indonesian companies are turning to the domestic debt market to refinance dollar debt amid rising dollar prices, aiming to limit currency volatility. Companies like Japfa Comfeed and Gajah Tunggal are considering rupiah bonds to repay US dollar obligations, with some seeking to raise funds through both dollar and onshore offerings. The move follows efforts by Indonesian authorities to encourage domestic buying of rupiah bonds, which has led to a surge in demand for government and corporate bonds.

site_title: Takata's US$1b air-bag settlement seen removing hurdle to company's sale
summary: Takata Corp has agreed to pay US$1 billion to settle a criminal investigation into hiding the deadly risks of its air bags for about 15 years. The Tokyo-based company has also agreed to plead guilty to one criminal charge. The settlement removes a hurdle to the company's sale, which is needed to complete the largest product recall in automotive history. The recall affects over 100 million air bags and has been linked to at least 17 deaths worldwide. The deal provides some clarity to potential bidders but also raises concerns about future liabilities and the company's ability to overcome its crisis.

site_title: Oil prices will be much more volatile in 2017: IEA
summary: Global oil prices are expected to be highly volatile in 2017, despite potential rebalancing in the first half of the year due to OPEC's output cuts. According to IEA head Fatih Birol, the market will experience increased volatility as the US shale oil production is expected to rise, and global demand weakens with higher prices. The cuts, agreed upon by OPEC and independent producers, aim to remove a global glut and prop up prices, currently at around $56 a barrel, which are half their level of mid-2014.

site_title: Update: Luxottica, Essilor in 45b euro merger deal to create eyewear giant: source
summary: Luxottica and Essilor have agreed to a 46-billion euro merger deal, creating a global eyewear giant. Luxottica, the world's top spectacles maker, will be led by Leonardo Del Vecchio, who will take a 31% stake in the merged group. The deal, one of Europe's largest cross-border tie-ups, is expected to be announced before the market opens on Monday. The merged group will have a combined market capitalization of 46 billion euros and employ over 140,000 people, with headquarters in Paris and listed on the Paris stock exchange.

site_title: Sterling slides to three-month low in Asia on Brexit concerns
summary: Sterling fell to a three-month low in Asia on Monday, sliding 1.6% to US$1.1983, amid concerns over a "hard Brexit" by the British government. The pound's decline was triggered by a report that Prime Minister Theresa May plans to quit the European Union's single market to regain control of Britain's borders. Markets fear this move would hurt British exports and drive foreign investment out of the country.

site_title: Six-hour meeting of Chinese tycoons eases LeEco's cash crunch
summary: Chinese tycoon Jia Yueting secured $2.2 billion in strategic investments from Sunac China Holdings Ltd to alleviate LeEco's cash crunch. The deal, announced Friday, marks a significant turning point for LeEco, with Sunac becoming the company's second-largest shareholder. Jia plans to use the funds to "far surpass" China's top three internet companies, with most of the money going towards non-listed businesses. The investment ends months of capital-raising efforts and ends LeEco's cash crisis, with chairman Sun Hongbin expressing confidence in Jia's strategy and vision.

site_title: OCBC's treat down memory lane in Chinatown for elderly
summary: OCBC bank treated 17 elderly residents of the AWWA Community Home to a visit to Chinatown, where they reminisced about their childhood and purchased new year gifts, including clothes, snacks, and Chinese sausages. The event allowed them to stay connected with their shrinking pool of childhood friends who still live in Chinatown. The visit was organized by OCBC staff volunteers, providing a memorable experience for the elderly residents.

site_title: Taiwan president says Latam trip, with US transit, put island on global stage
summary: Taiwan President Tsai Ing-wen said her recent trip to Central America and transit stops in the US elevated Taiwan's international profile. China criticized US President-elect Donald Trump for his remarks on the "one China" policy, which Taiwan sees as a breakaway province. Tsai met with Central American heads of state and US officials, including Republican lawmakers, to consolidate state friendships and promote Taiwan's international presence. China views the US transit stops as a potential breach of the "one China" policy.

site_title: Jan-Nov visitor arrivals up 8% but growth may be slowing
summary: Singapore welcomed 14.89 million visitors in the first 11 months of 2016, a 8% increase year-over-year, with most growth occurring in the first five months. However, arrivals from August to October showed slower growth, with October experiencing a 0.9% decline. Despite this, the final tally is expected to surpass the Singapore Tourism Board's forecast of 15.2-15.7 million visitors. China overtook Indonesia as the top source of visitors, with arrivals from India and Australia also showing growth.

site_title: Billionaire Li Ka-shing to acquire Australia's Duet Group in A$7.4b deal
summary: Hong Kong billionaire Li Ka-shing's Cheung Kong Infrastructure Holdings Ltd agreed to acquire Australia's Duet Group in a deal worth A$7.4 billion (S$8 billion). The offer includes a special dividend of 3 Australian cents a share, a 29% premium to Duet's pre-offer trading price. The deal, subject to regulatory approvals, would be Li's biggest acquisition in Australia and aims to bolster his global power and gas pipeline assets. It comes after Li's previous attempt to buy a majority stake in state-owned power network Ausgrid was blocked by the Australian government last August.

site_title: Trump offers to end some Russian sanctions for nuclear arms cut
summary: US President-elect Donald Trump announced plans to offer to end some sanctions against Russia in exchange for a nuclear arms reduction deal with Vladimir Putin. Trump expressed desire to reduce nuclear arsenals of the US and Russia, calling for a "reduced very substantially". He also criticized Russia's intervention in the Syrian civil war and reiterated his criticism of President Obama's Iran nuclear deal. Trump expressed enthusiasm for a trade deal with the UK and meeting with Prime Minister Theresa May, stating he believes Brexit will be a "great thing" for the UK.

site_title: Nintendo takes big gamble with Switch's split personality
summary: Nintendo's new Switch gaming console is set to debut on March 3, offering a hybrid gaming experience that combines home and on-the-go play with a tablet and wireless controllers. However, investors are skeptical, with Nintendo shares dropping 5.9% after pricing and details were released. The Switch represents Nintendo's biggest bet in years, aiming to unify gameplay at home and on the go, but its success is uncertain, with many questioning whether it can replicate the success of the Wii console a decade ago.

site_title: China's exiting capital seen finding a home in Hong Kong stocks
summary: Mainland Chinese investors are shifting their focus to Hong Kong stocks through cross-border exchange links as capital controls tighten, providing a boost to Hong Kong's struggling stock market. The Shenzhen and Shanghai bourse links remain unaffected, offering a convenient way for investors to access US-dollar-denominated assets. With the yuan experiencing its worst annual loss in over two decades, mainland investors are looking for alternative channels to invest overseas, potentially supporting Hong Kong-traded Chinese shares and driving up demand for Hong Kong stocks.

site_title: Direct-lending funds moving in with US$50b where banks fear to tread
summary: Direct-lending funds are moving into the European market with $50 billion in funding, filling a liquidity shortage in Italy and other countries. The European Central Bank's (ECB) guidelines on leveraged finance are limiting banks' ability to lend, creating opportunities for direct lenders. Funds such as Pemberton Capital Advisors and Bain Capital LP are targeting companies with speculative-grade ratings, offering more flexible and faster financing options. This shift is expected to continue as banks are discouraged from lending due to ECB limits and risk appetite.

site_title: Prosecutors to decide on Monday whether to arrest Samsung heir
summary: South Korean prosecutors are set to decide on Monday whether to arrest Samsung heir Lee Jae-Yong over alleged bribery, following a week of questioning as a criminal suspect. Lee is accused of approving payments to President Park Geun-hye's secret confidante Choi Soon-sil to secure favorable decisions. The decision comes as part of a major influence-peddling scandal involving Choi and several top Samsung executives, including the merger of two Samsung units in 2015. The outcome will determine whether Lee will be arrested, and could have significant implications for the Samsung group and South Korea's economy.

site_title: Singapore to prop up South-east Asia's muted IPO market in 2017
summary: Singapore is expected to be the hottest spot for initial public offerings (IPOs) in South-east Asia in 2017, driven by its stock exchange promoting business and real estate trusts. The market has seen a fivefold increase in fundraising via IPOs last year, reaching US$1.7 billion. This is partly due to Singapore's stable dividend offerings, which have attracted investors despite currency volatility and weak sentiment in other parts of the region. The growth in IPOs in Singapore is expected to continue in 2017.

site_title: San Francisco's health conference tonic for hotel revenue
summary: At the 2017 JP Morgan Healthcare Conference in San Francisco, hotels charged thousands of dollars per night, with some even charging for sitting. The conference, which drew thousands of investors and executives, saw hotels raise prices due to high demand, with some rooms costing $499-$599 per night and others dropping to under $200 after the conference ended. Industry experts say this is an example of companies maximizing revenue during peak demand, but some have criticized the practice as excessive.

site_title: Britain threatens to undercut EU if Brexit plans fail
summary: Britain has threatened to undercut the EU economically if it cannot obtain both single market access and immigration controls following its Brexit plans. Finance minister Philip Hammond stated that the country would need to "change our economic model" to remain competitive if it is shut out from the single market. Prime Minister Theresa May is set to outline her Brexit strategy in a major speech on Tuesday, with newspapers suggesting a clean divorce from the European Union.

site_title: Bone-chilling winter from Berlin to Davos causes energy scramble
summary: A severe winter storm across Europe has caused a scramble for energy supplies, leading to record-high prices of natural gas and electricity. Blizzards and arctic temperatures have left Eastern Europe without power, resulting in widespread blackouts. The energy crisis has prompted European energy suppliers to hunt for alternative sources, putting pressure on global energy markets. The extreme weather has also led to a surge in gold prices due to market uncertainty.

site_title: US banks to stay in fashion as earnings kick off
summary: US bank stocks rose 2.3% to their highest since February 2008 after top executives expressed optimism about 2017, despite investors waiting for President-elect Donald Trump's campaign promises to materialize. Wells Fargo, JPMorgan Chase, and Bank of America kicked off the earnings season on a positive note, with the S&P 500's banking sub-sector up 0.8%. The positive start suggests US banks will stay in favor with investors as long as earnings reports show an improving profit outlook.

images.alt_text: US bank stocks will stay in favour with investors as long as earnings reports in the coming week show an improving profit outlook while investors wait to see if US President-elect Donald Trump lives up to his campaign promises.

site_title: Trump threatens BMW with border tax on cars built in Mexico
summary: US President-elect Donald Trump has threatened to impose a 35% border tax on BMW cars built in Mexico and exported to the US market. The BMW plant in San Luis Potosi, Mexico, is set to start production of the BMW 3 Series in 2019, with the output intended for the global market. Trump's comments come as BMW plans to expand its production facilities in Germany and China.

images.alt_text: President-elect Donald Trump has warned the United States will impose a border tax of 35 per cent on cars that German carmaker BMW plans to build at a new plant in Mexico and export to the US market.

site_title: Citadel pays SEC US$22.6m to settle charges it misled clients
summary: Citadel Securities, the market-making arm of billionaire Ken Griffin's hedge fund, agreed to pay the US Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) $22.6 million to settle charges of misleading clients about trade prices. The SEC found Citadel used algorithms to execute trades on customers' behalf, often giving investors a worse price, despite knowing better prices existed elsewhere. Citadel will pay $5.2 million in disgorgement and $16 million in penalties. The case highlights concerns over routing practices, including latency arbitrage, and the need for improved regulatory oversight.

site_title: Davos elites look for answers as Trump era dawns
summary: The World Economic Forum (WEF) in Davos, Switzerland, is underway amidst concerns over the US presidency of Donald Trump, which is seen as a threat to globalization and free trade. Despite the global economy being in better shape, attendees are anxious about Trump's impact on the world order, with many fearing a more insular approach and a decline in multilateral cooperation. The forum features discussions on topics such as populism, middle-class crisis, and climate change, with leaders from around the world gathering to address the uncertainty and challenges posed by Trump's presidency.

site_title: India grapples with cyber security concerns amid push for digital payments
summary: India is grappling with growing cyber security concerns amid a push for digital payments, following Prime Minister Narendra Modi's introduction of the Bhim app in December. Despite over 10 million downloads in just 10 days, the app's security has been questioned due to a lack of exhaustive testing and education. Experts say the government's outdated information technology law and central bank guidelines are inadequate to regulate the numerous mobile payment apps and e-wallet companies. The country has seen a significant rise in cyber attacks, with over 39,000 incidents reported in the first nine months of 2016.

site_title: Tata's move to plug hole at top could spring a leak in earnings
summary: Tata Consultancy Services (TCS) head Natarajan Chandrasekaran has been promoted to chairman of Tata Sons, the conglomerate's holding company, filling a critical hole. However, his departure leaves a void at TCS, which accounts for nearly 90% of Tata Sons' revenue. Investors are concerned about the company's future, citing slowing growth and complex industry headwinds, including the Trump administration's visa clampdown and Brexit fallout. Chandrasekaran's promotion is seen as a gamble to address boardroom troubles, leaving TCS with a new CEO, Rajesh Gopinathan.

site_title: Trump rally stalled by Trump
summary: The US stock market, also known as the "Trump rally," has stalled after President-elect Donald Trump's first press conference, which failed to provide specific economic plans. The Dow Jones Industrial Average finished within 250 points of the 20,000 mark for the fourth straight week, despite initial promises of infrastructure investments and regulatory rollbacks. Trump's lack of concrete economic proposals and his focus on contentious issues like the Affordable Care Act and trade disputes with Mexico and China raised concerns among investors and economists.

site_title: Lower-for-longer still expected despite bump from reflation trade: Allianz
summary: Allianz Global Investors (AGI) senior investors maintain the "lower for longer" investment theme, despite US inflationary expectations being revived after the election. They attribute this to few signs of inflation and massive infrastructure spending taking years to affect the economy. AGI fund managers are buying short-maturity bonds to avoid interest rate risk, while positioning for inflation. Experts expect the US economy to remain in the 1-3% growth zone, with tax cuts and higher interest rates acting as dampeners for the housing market.

site_title: In sneaker sales, King James bows to Jordan
summary: Nike has released a limited batch of LeBron 14 shoes, along with his rookie-year Air Zoom Generation sneakers, on the online resale marketplace StockX. The shoes were sold to the highest bidders, with prices ranging from $3,000 to $25,000 per pair. The release aims to generate buzz and tap into nostalgia, as LeBron James seeks to close the gap with Michael Jordan in signature shoe sales. However, the shoes still trail behind Air Jordans in the resale market, dominated by retro releases of 1980s and 1990s models.

site_title: After Downton, affluent Chinese seek butlers
