summary: China's affluent individuals are seeking butlers trained in traditional British manor service, inspired by the TV drama Downton Abbey. Demand for homegrown butlers has grown sharply in recent years, with many Chinese butlers trained at the International Butler Academy China. Despite President Xi Jinping's campaign against corruption and extravagance, China's rich continue to amass fortunes and desire the trappings of respectable refinement. However, many butlers are treated as expensive all-purpose flunkies, violating the traditional idea of a butler as a respected manager of the household.

site_title: More Indians taking to the skies, but there could be turbulence ahead
summary: India's aviation sector is experiencing rapid growth, with a 20% increase in passenger numbers in 2015, driven by the country's burgeoning middle class. However, experts warn that the industry's expansion could be threatened by inadequate infrastructure and high operating costs. Low-cost airlines are expanding their fleets, while the government is reviving disused airports to reduce capacity risks. High fuel import taxes and pilot shortages also pose significant challenges, with the industry being one of the costliest and toughest to operate in.

site_title: Sony Entertainment CEO leaving for a top role at Snap
summary: Sony Entertainment CEO Michael Lynton will step down as CEO on Feb 2 to become chairman of Snap Inc's board, succeeding Evan Spiegel. Lynton will remain co-CEO for six months to help find a successor. This move marks a significant shift for the technology company as it prepares for an initial public offering.

site_title: Trump's targeting of Toyota could set off trade frictions: analysts
summary: US President-elect Donald Trump's targeting of Toyota's Mexico-manufactured cars could lead to wider trade frictions between the US and Japan, potentially triggering a stronger yen and economic damage to Japan. Analysts predict US-China trade frictions will be a focus in 2017, with Japan potentially pushing ahead with a Trans-Pacific Partnership agreement without US participation. The yen has already risen in response to Trump's comments, and analysts warn of potential dollar depreciation and economic consequences for Japan.

site_title: How to retire in 10 years
summary: A person can achieve financial independence in 10 years by saving at least 70% of their income, regardless of their salary or investment yield. Increasing the savings rate can significantly reduce the time needed to achieve financial independence, with a 70% savings rate potentially shaving off 19 years of work. A 2-2.5% yield and a high savings rate can also achieve financial independence in 10 years or less. However, relying solely on a high yield can be risky, and increasing the savings rate is generally a more reliable strategy.

site_title: SGD bond issuance gets off to slow start in 2017
summary: The Singapore bond market has started slowly in 2017, with only one issue sold so far, despite increased investor sentiment and secondary market volumes. This contrasts with the previous year, when five deals worth S$991 million were issued. Experts attribute the slow start to market uncertainty, including the impact of policy changes by the incoming US president and European elections. However, they expect a "lot more supply" after Chinese New Year, with refinancing needs and foreign banks contributing to the growing proportion of non-Singapore-domiciled SGD bond issues.

site_title: China regulator orders app store registration in bid for more control
summary: China's Cyberspace Administration has ordered the registration of app stores nationwide in a bid for more control. The regulator's offices will keep records of the country's many app stores starting Monday. This move is seen as the latest step in the government's efforts to solidify control over mobile apps. The decision is expected to impact app developers and users, potentially limiting their access to certain apps or services.

site_title: Slower growth expected for China's biggest cities
summary: China's largest cities are expected to experience slower economic growth this year, with targets set at around 6.5% for major cities like Shanghai and Beijing. The country's overall GDP growth is likely to slow to around 6.5%, easing from 6.7% in 2016. Despite this, some provinces, such as Chongqing, are targeting growth of around 10% this year. The slowdown is attributed to efforts to restructure the economy from manufacturing to domestic consumption, and increasing uncertainties facing the country's economy this year.

site_title: Insurance disruption fuelling customer-centric innovations
summary: Insurers in Singapore are shifting focus towards customer-centric innovations to retain loyalty and attract new policyholders. Major insurers, including Aviva, AXA, and Allianz, have set up innovation labs in Singapore, driven by technologies like artificial intelligence, blockchain, and open application program interfaces. Insurers aim to improve front-end processes, provide tailor-made coverage, and offer digital experiences. This includes the use of big data and artificial intelligence to underwrite, price, and issue policies in real-time. Insurers are also exploring the use of blockchain and open APIs to create secure and trusted digital contracts, enabling them to provide new offers and services to customers.

site_title: New taxi app books a ride for Ivory Coast middle class
summary: Africab, a locally-owned taxi app, has launched in Abidjan, Ivory Coast, providing a high-tech and reliable travel option for the country's emerging middle class. The app allows clients to book taxis with fixed fares, which tend to be higher than regular taxis, but offer perks such as air-conditioned vehicles and free Wi-Fi. Founded by Vangsy Goma, Africab aims to build an entrepreneurial culture based on technology and respects African identity, with plans to expand to other cities in West Africa.

site_title: Ride-hailing drivers are slaves to the surge
summary: New York City ride-hailing drivers, such as Uziel Santos, rely on surge pricing to earn a living, often working multiple apps and phones to maximize earnings. Surge prices, set by apps like Uber, attract drivers to areas with high demand and limited supply, resulting in higher fares. However, drivers must also invest in insurance, maintenance, and other expenses, which can cut into their earnings. The Independent Drivers Guild, formed by drivers, argues that apps like Uber engage in a "global bait-and-switch" by offering attractive fares while extracting high commissions and investing in autonomous technology.

site_title: Allianz Global Investors ponders 'all-China' products
summary: Allianz Global Investors is developing "all-China" funds, which would focus on the Hong Kong, Shenzhen, and Shanghai markets, aiming to provide a more comprehensive investment option for investors. The move comes as China's economy is seen as a potential separate asset class, with senior executives expressing optimism despite concerns over capital controls and currency fluctuations. The funds may launch an equity-focused product later this year, and experts believe liquidity could shift from the property market to the stock market due to government efforts to cool down the property market.

site_title: Samsonite launches multi-brand online store
summary: Samsonite, the world's largest branded-luggage maker, is launching its multi-brand online store, aiming to reach 5% of its business in the digital space. The move is expected to boost website sales to 30% of the company's total. This strategic move is part of Samsonite's efforts to expand its online presence and increase its digital sales.

site_title: Britain's May to call for national unity in major Brexit speech
summary: British Prime Minister Theresa May will deliver a major Brexit speech this week, calling for national unity and a Britain more open to the world. She plans to kick off the EU withdrawal negotiations by the end of March, but has not disclosed her desired terms. May's speech aims to move beyond the acrimony of the 2016 referendum, seeking to unite Britons around a shared vision.

images.alt_text: Mrs May will stress the need for Britons, who voted for Brexit by 52 to 48 per cent in June's referendum, to unite around common goals such as protecting and enhancing workers' rights.

site_title: Indonesia, Japan agree to discuss Jakarta-Surabaya rail project
summary: Indonesia and Japan agreed to discuss a railway project connecting Jakarta and Surabaya, with both countries planning to develop the Masela gas block and Patimban port. This comes after Indonesia's transport minister invited Japan to submit proposals for the railway line in October. The agreement follows a 2015 setback when Indonesia awarded China a high-speed train project linking Jakarta to Bandung. Japan remains one of Indonesia's biggest investors, and this project could further strengthen their economic ties.

site_title: Minuting the board meeting
summary: The importance of keeping accurate and detailed board minutes was highlighted, as they serve multiple purposes including driving action, measuring progress, and identifying ownership of decisions. Board minutes are considered legal documents and must be prepared, reviewed, and approved with care. The Companies Act requires companies to produce minutes of all board meetings within a month, but they are not open for inspection by shareholders. Effective minutes should include key points of discussions, opposing views, and sufficient background information, and should be edited and approved by the board before finalization.

site_title: FHF provides healthcare support to needy
summary: The Fullerton Health Foundation (FHF) has made significant strides in providing healthcare support and education to the underprivileged in Singapore and beyond. Since its launch in 2016, FHF has organized Project Big Heart (PBH) to provide free services to over 600 residents, with a focus on chronic disease identification and treatment. The foundation also collaborates with The Global Fund to support health programs in Indonesia, the Philippines, and Vietnam. With a network of over 200 medical facilities and 8,000 panel providers, FHF aims to improve access to quality healthcare for those in need.

site_title: Britain's May to call for national unity in major Brexit speech
summary: Britain's Prime Minister Theresa May will deliver a major Brexit speech next week, calling for national unity and a vision of a Britain more open to the world. She aims to kick off Brexit negotiations by the end of March, but has not revealed her stance on single market access or customs union. May will stress the need to protect workers' rights and put an end to divisive language, but her speech has sparked market concerns about a "clean and hard" Brexit.

site_title: Electric cars will impact oil demand less than vehicle efficiency: BP
summary: BP chief economist Spencer Dale says electric cars will have a limited impact on oil demand, with gains in vehicle efficiency expected to reduce oil consumption by up to 15 million barrels a day. Electric vehicles are forecast to reach 70 million by 2035, accounting for less than a tenth of the global car fleet. However, improvements in fuel efficiency in petrol engines will slow oil demand growth, and overall oil demand will still rise, driven by other transport sectors and industries.

images.alt_text: Could growth in electric vehicles dent oil demand growth significantly? Not as much as gains in vehicle efficiency, according to BP chief economist Spencer Dale.

site_title: US dollar mixed as investors digest economic data while sterling steadies
summary: The US dollar traded mixed against major currencies on Friday as investors digested retail sales data, which suggested the Federal Reserve would hike interest rates three times this year. The dollar index fell 0.16% to 101.190. Sterling steadied, recovering from earlier losses, while the euro rose to $1.0640. The pound edged up to $1.2203, still down over 1% for the week, amidst uncertainty over the UK's Brexit plans.

site_title: Personal data protection evolves with technology
summary: Local IT service provider IP Technology Solutions (IPTECH) has strengthened its data protection measures to comply with the Personal Data Protection Act (PDPA) amid evolving technology. The company processes over half a million records annually and faces the challenge of differentiating between business and personal data. IPTECH has implemented regular server testing, data disposal policies, and tightened server settings to reduce risks of accidental exposure of personal data. The company has also invested $30,000 in compliance costs, resulting in increased client confidence and reduced risks, with employees better equipped to handle personal data.

site_title: Thai pilot killed when jet crashes during air show for kids
summary: A Thai military air show for children ended in tragedy when a fighter jet crashed, killing the 35-year-old pilot. The incident occurred during Thailand's annual Children's Day celebration at the Hat Yai airport. No one else was harmed, and the cause of the crash is under investigation. The pilot was flying a Swedish-made JAS 39 Gripen jet. The Thai Prime Minister has expressed condolences to the pilot, his family, and the Royal Thai Air Force.

site_title: Taking the long view pays off in short term too
summary: Three top-performing US mutual funds, the Matthew 25 fund, the Hotchkis & Wiley Small Cap Value fund, and the Oakmark Global fund, maintained investments longer than their rivals, with lower turnover ratios. In contrast, the typical actively managed stock fund tracks by Morningstar replaced nearly 65% of its portfolio annually. These funds' long-term approach paid off in the fourth quarter, with the Matthew 25 fund, Hotchkis & Wiley Small Cap Value fund, and Oakmark Global fund ranking among the top performers. Their patience and lower turnover rates contributed to their success.

site_title: Private-sector financier with a public remit
summary: Temasek-backed Clifford Capital is in talks with the Singapore government to develop infrastructure debt as an asset class for institutional investors. The company, led by CEO Clive Kerner, aims to set up an infrastructure debt takeout facility that would allow banks to recycle their infrastructure project finance loan books. This move is seen as a response to increasing banking regulation that may limit banks' ability to do long-term lending for infrastructure projects. The initiative could provide a new avenue for investors to access infrastructure debt and help make infrastructure projects more viable.

site_title: Governments grapple with globalisation backlash
summary: Governments worldwide are grappling with the backlash from voters who feel left behind by three decades of globalisation. Disgruntled voters, exemplified by Britain's Brexit vote and Donald Trump's US election victory, are demanding action to address growing income inequality. Analysts warn that populist remedies could exacerbate the issue, while experts propose solutions such as taxes on unfair trade practices and re-shoring to level the playing field. However, no consensus has emerged, and the IMF has acknowledged that international trade can deepen inequality.

site_title: What's in a nickname? Plenty, for these MMA fighters
summary: MMA fighters from One Championship showcased their skills at a recent event in Jakarta, Indonesia. Sunoto Peringkat, known as "The Terminator," dominated his opponent Chan Heng with a TKO in the first round. Other notable fighters, including Adrian Matheis ("Papua Badboy") and Martin Nguyen ("Situ-Asian"), also competed in the event. The Jakarta show was part of One Championship's 2017 schedule, which includes at least 18 events in various cities, including Singapore, Kuala Lumpur, and Manila.

site_title: US company recalls boots that leave swastika imprints
summary: A California-based company, Conal International Trading Inc, has recalled its Polar Fox military-style boots after a customer reported that the soles leave swastika imprints. The company apologized and issued a statement after the issue was posted on Reddit and went viral. The recall was made to address customer complaints and prevent further offense. The boots were pulled from sale and the company expressed its sincerest apologies to customers and those offended by the swastika imprint.

site_title: Soft drinks top buy of US food stamp homes: report
summary: US households on food stamps spend a significant portion of their benefits on soft drinks and junk food, with 10% of their monthly allowance going towards sugary beverages. The US Department of Agriculture has denied requests to restrict food stamp purchases to healthy foods, citing fairness and red tape concerns. A report found that households with food stamps bought similar amounts of unhealthy foods as non-Snap households, including candy, ice cream, and potato chips. Experts argue that the program's purpose is to promote public health, and that restricting sugary drink purchases would have a more significant impact on obesity rates.

images.alt_text: Across all households, the report finds, "more money was spent on soft drinks than any other item", reflecting that the US still consumes more sugary drinks than almost any other developed country.

site_title: The American wild card
summary: Key figures express differing views on what they look forward to under President Donald Trump's leadership. Some, like Michael Blake and Ng Shin Ein, expect economic growth and a stronger US presence in Asia, while others, such as Jayaprakash Jagateesan, are concerned about the potential for trade wars and geopolitical instability. Many, including Philip Jeyaretnam and David Emery, emphasize the importance of unity and shared values in achieving lasting gains. Some, like Lim Soon Hock, are optimistic about Trump's potential to deliver a pro-business agenda, while others, such as Annie Yap, caution that his presidency is a "wild card" with uncertain consequences for the world.

site_title: Wanda posts first sales decline in 11 years
summary: Wanda Group, a Hong Kong-based conglomerate, reported its first sales decline in 11 years in 2016, with revenue falling 14% due to a slump in its property business. The decline was more than forecast, with Dalian Wanda Commercial Properties Co's revenue dropping 25% to 143 billion yuan (S$29.6 billion). This marks a reversal from the group's previous growth, primarily driven by its entertainment operations. The decline is attributed to a slowdown in the Chinese property market.

site_title: E-waste rising dangerously in Asia: UN study
summary: A UN study reports that electronic waste in Asia has risen 63% in five years, with serious consequences for human health and the environment. The study warns that many countries in the region lack infrastructure for environmentally sound e-waste management. China, Hong Kong, Singapore, and Taiwan are among the top e-waste generators, while Cambodia, Vietnam, and the Philippines have the lowest rates. Improper disposal of e-waste leads to exposure to toxic chemicals, causing health and environmental problems. The report calls for improved recycling and disposal methods across the region.

site_title: Black Lady Liberty to grace US coin
summary: The US Mint is set to release a commemorative $100 gold coin featuring an African American Lady Liberty, marking the first time the iconic symbol has been depicted as black. The 24-karat gold piece is part of a series honoring the Mint's 225th anniversary and reflecting the country's cultural diversity. The coin's design features a distinctly African-American Liberty with a crown of gold stars, along with other allegorical designs representing Asian-Americans, Hispanic-Americans, and Indian-Americans. The move follows the introduction of Harriet Tubman as the new face of the $20 banknote last April.

site_title: Expect the unexpected?
summary: Renowned hedge fund manager George Soros' saying "stock market bubbles don't grow out of thin air" may be relevant to today's market due to the uncertainty surrounding US fiscal stimulus under President-elect Donald Trump. Despite a lack of mention of the economy during Trump's press conference, the Straits Times Index (STI) has reached a 15-month high. However, the broad market may not have followed, with many daily dollar volume trades occurring in the 30 STI components. Investors are adopting various strategies, including "buy the dips, sell into strength" and "volume usually precedes price," as they await clarity on Trump's economic plans.

site_title: German building boom set to continue as home demand soars
summary: Germany's housing market continues to boom, with a 20% increase in new residential building permits issued in 2016, reaching a record 380,000. The construction sector is expected to maintain its solid performance, driven by housing shortages and low interest rates. This growth is expected to contribute to Germany's economic expansion, with construction industry associations forecasting a 5% rise in sales this year, the highest level since 1995. The shortage of affordable housing is estimated to be around 800,000 units, with experts suggesting that at least 350,000 new homes are needed annually until 2020.

images.alt_text: Property analysts say that at least 350,000 new homes are needed every year until 2020 to cope with Germany's shortage of affordable housing.

site_title: Amazon's Gandhi flip-flops spark anger in India
summary: Amazon's Gandhi flip-flops, selling on its US website, sparked outrage in India, just days after the e-retail giant removed Indian flag doormats from sale. The pink flip-flops, featuring Mahatma Gandhi's face, were described as "professionally printed" and cost $16.99. India's Foreign Minister Sushma Swaraj warned of tough action against Amazon, and users expressed their discontent on Twitter, calling for the company to be banned in India. Amazon removed the flip-flops from its site in response to the backlash.

site_title: Homegrown taxi app books a ride for Ivory Coast middle class
summary: A homegrown taxi app, Africab, has launched in Abidjan, Ivory Coast, offering a high-tech and reliable travel option for the local middle class. The company's sleek vehicles, owned by the company, not the driver, offer fixed fares, air-conditioning, and free Wi-Fi. Africab aims to build an entrepreneurial culture based on technology and respects African identity, with plans to expand to other West African cities. The company has received significant investment and has seen a growing portfolio of business clients, with a monthly turnover of 60 million CFA francs.

images.alt_text: Many of Abidjan's backstreets and alleys have never been named, as is often the case in African towns and cities. To get round this, Africab maps the addresses of clients and familiar landmarks.

site_title: Indian airlines soar but experts warn of turbulence ahead
summary: Indian airlines have experienced rapid growth, with 20% passenger growth in 2015, driven by the country's expanding middle class. Low-cost carriers are expanding their fleets to capitalize on this growth, encouraged by falling fuel prices. However, experts warn that inadequate infrastructure and high operating costs could threaten the industry's expansion. The acquisition by SpiceJet highlights the vast potential of India's aviation market, but experts caution that the industry faces significant challenges ahead.

images.alt_text: A major acquisition by Indian budget airline SpiceJet this week underscored the vast potential of the world's fastest-growing aviation market, but experts say woefully inadequate infrastructure and high operating costs could threaten the industry's rapid expansion.

site_title: Trump aide called Russian ambassador on same day as sanctions
summary: President-elect Donald Trump's national security adviser, Michael Flynn, had a phone conversation with Russian Ambassador Sergey Kislyak on December 29, the same day the Obama administration imposed sanctions on top Russian intelligence officials. The call was to discuss scheduling a conversation between Trump and Russian President Vladimir Putin after Trump's inauguration. The discussion involved exchanging logistical information, with no indication that Flynn disclosed sensitive information about the sanctions. The call was deemed routine and innocuous by a transition spokesman, contradicting earlier reports of frequent contact between Flynn and Kislyak.

site_title: Trump taps country stars for inauguration
summary: President-elect Donald Trump has announced that country stars Toby Keith and Lee Greenwood, along with Broadway singer Jennifer Holliday, will perform at his inauguration on January 19, 2017. The event will be free to the public and take place at the Lincoln Memorial on the eve of Trump's inauguration as the 45th president.

site_title: US judge to issue decision on Hanjin sale of stake in terminal operator
summary: A US judge plans to announce on Wednesday whether to approve the sale of Hanjin Shipping Co Ltd's 54% stake in US terminal operator Total Terminals International LLC for $78 million. The sale, which also includes forgiving $54.6 million in debt, has already been approved in South Korea but faces opposition from US creditors who claim the deal undervalues the stake. Hanjin, the world's seventh-largest container line, filed for bankruptcy in August, and the sale is seen as crucial to raise proceeds and prevent Total Terminals from bankruptcy.

site_title: Beijing sets 2017 air pollution goal at more than double WHO's acceptable standard
summary: Beijing sets an ambitious air pollution goal for 2017, aiming for an annual average PM2.5 level of around 60 micrograms per cubic meter, more than double the World Health Organization's acceptable standard of 20-25 micrograms. The city's air quality likely improved 9.9% in 2016, but hazardous smog has persisted, disrupting daily life. Beijing plans to establish a specialized police force to tackle environmental offenses and crack down on polluters.

images.alt_text: Beijing's air quality target for 2017 is more than double the acceptable standard set by the World Health Organisation (WHO), the mayor announced on Saturday in the wake of weeks of hazardous air pollution in the Chinese capital.

site_title: Vienna's homeless show tourists life on the street
summary: In Vienna, a social start-up called Shades Tours has hired homeless people as city guides to help them reintegrate into society. The initiative, launched last year, aims to break down the stigma associated with homelessness by providing a platform for those in need to share their stories and experiences with tourists. Three full-time guides, including Barbara, have already been able to move from shelters into private housing, with two more employed by the organization. The tours offer a unique opportunity for visitors to learn about Vienna's complex social system and its challenges, with many participants expressing gratitude for the insight into the lives of homeless individuals.

site_title: Chinese leader meets Davos elite as voters revolt
summary: China's President Xi Jinping will attend the World Economic Forum in Davos, where he will deliver a keynote speech promoting Beijing's efforts to negotiate new regional trade deals. The event comes as voters revolt against globalization and open markets, with the rise of populist movements in Europe and the US. The forum aims to address "root causes" of anxiety, but some experts warn that China may try to fill the void left by the US's "isolationist" policies under President Trump. The event will also feature prominent Western figures, including US Vice President Joe Biden and UN Chief Antonio Guterres.

site_title: Boxing: UFC boss offers Mayweather, McGregor US$25m each to fight
summary: UFC president Dana White has offered Floyd Mayweather and Conor McGregor $25 million each to fight in a boxing match, with each fighter also receiving a cut of pay-per-view proceeds. White disputed Mayweather's claim that he offered McGregor $15 million, saying he made a "real offer." Mayweather has said he'd only consider fighting McGregor for $100 million, and McGregor has shown willingness to fight for high pay-per-view buys. The proposed fight has fueled speculation about a potential showdown between the two.

site_title: Anti-Trump protesters head to Washington
summary: Hundreds of thousands of protesters are expected to attend anti-Trump demonstrations in Washington next week, with the Women's March on Washington being the main focal point. Organizers, including celebrity supporters, aim to secure immigrant rights, access to abortion services, and other demands. The event is expected to draw around 190,000 attendees, with nearly 1,200 buses requesting parking permits. Authorities have deployed 28,000 security forces, and protesters plan to use various tactics, including poetry slams and an "Art Strike," to express their opposition to Trump's presidency.

site_title: Australia's Turnbull urges free trade in face of Trump threat
summary: Australian Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull urged resistance to protectionism and reaffirmed his commitment to the Trans-Pacific Partnership trade agreement, which is under threat from the Trump administration. Turnbull met with Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe to strengthen economic and defense ties, amid concerns about China's actions in the South China Sea. The US has campaigned on a pledge to kill the TPP, while outgoing Secretary of State Rex Tillerson has called for US allies to provide backup in blocking China's access to artificial islands in the South China Sea.

site_title: Anger as Mexicans fear higher food prices to follow gasoline hike
summary: Mexicans are concerned about higher food prices following a gasoline price hike, which has already sparked anger and riots. The government has vowed to keep consumer prices in check, but economists fear a spike in inflation due to a record slump in the peso and potential US tariffs. Analysts predict a 1.61% rise in consumer prices in January, the highest in 17 years, which could hurt consumer demand and support growth in Mexico's economy.

site_title: My Favourite Movie
summary: The article discusses various topics, but there's no relevant content to summarize about the Transformers movie.

site_title: Moody's to pay US$864m to settle subprime ratings claim
summary: Moody's Investors Service agreed to pay US$864 million to settle a US investigation into credit ratings on subprime mortgage securities. The settlement resolves allegations that Moody's inflated ratings on mortgage securities at the center of the 2008 financial crisis. The payment is about a third of the US$2.5 billion Moody's earned in the four years leading up to the crisis. The agreement also requires Moody's to implement additional compliance measures for five years.

site_title: Bone-chilling winter from Berlin to Davos causes energy scramble
summary: A severe winter storm has caused energy chaos across Eastern Europe, with blizzards, gale-force winds, and arctic temperatures leading to record-high natural gas prices and widespread blackouts. The cold snap, expected to last at least two weeks, has disrupted energy supplies, with countries struggling to acquire liquefied natural gas and coal. France has issued a warning of a potential power shortage, and Romania's energy minister has warned of a possible coal shortage. The crisis has intensified ahead of the World Economic Forum in Davos, Switzerland, where energy leaders will gather to address the issue.

site_title: Hundreds of cats quarantined in New York City bird flu outbreak
summary: Hundreds of domestic cats in New York City have been quarantined due to a highly contagious avian flu strain, H7N2, that infected at least one veterinarian. The virus, commonly found in birds, causes mild symptoms in cats, including sneezing, coughing, and runny eyes and noses. This is the first reported instance of the virus infecting domestic cats in New York City. The New York City Health Department is monitoring the situation and working to contain the outbreak.

site_title: Ivory Coast mutineers say reach deal amid fears of renewed revolt
summary: Disgruntled soldiers in Ivory Coast reached an agreement with the government late on Friday to resolve a dispute over bonus payments, ending a nationwide army mutiny that had threatened to reignite. The soldiers, most former rebel fighters, had demanded 12 million CFA francs (S$27,650) in bonuses, but received only five million on Monday. The agreement, brokered by the mutineers, will see the rest of the payment made each month, resolving the dispute and preventing a potential relaunch of the mutiny.

site_title: Europe: Banks boost European stocks; Britain's FTSE sets record high
summary: European shares rose on Monday, led by bank stocks, with Britain's FTSE 100 index reaching an all-time high. The European banking index gained 2% and the Stoxx 600 added 0.95% as investors anticipated higher interest rates in the US. However, shares of French media company Technicolor fell 19.7% after a profit warning, and precious metals miners were under pressure due to a stronger US dollar.

site_title: BlackRock CEO says Trump 'tax holiday' may do little for US growth: CNBC
summary: BlackRock CEO Larry Fink criticized US President-elect Donald Trump's proposed "tax holiday" to encourage US companies to repatriate their overseas cash, saying it may do little to boost growth. The tax holiday, proposed at a 10% tax rate, aims to stimulate hiring and business investments. Fink stated he has never believed in the concept that repatriation would stimulate the economy, citing Moody's estimate that US companies hold nearly $1.8 trillion in overseas cash.

site_title: Trump suggests he may do away with Russia sanctions if Moscow helpful: WSJ
summary: US President-elect Donald Trump suggested he may lift sanctions against Russia if Moscow is helpful in battling terrorists and achieving other goals important to Washington. Trump stated that if Russia is "getting along" and doing "really great things," sanctions would be unnecessary. The sanctions, imposed by the Obama administration, were in response to alleged cyber attacks. Trump's comments, made in a Wall Street Journal interview, imply that the US may re-evaluate its relationship with Russia if it sees progress in certain areas.

images.alt_text: US President-elect Donald Trump said in an interview with the Wall Street Journal he would keep intact sanctions against Russia "at least for a period of time," and also said he wouldn't commit to the "one China" policy until he sees progress from Beijing in its currency and trade practices.

site_title: Renault, Fiat darken auto industry outlook after VW settles
summary: Renault and Fiat Chrysler Automobiles (FCA) faced a darkening outlook in the auto industry after Volkswagen AG settled a $4.3 billion fine for cheating on emissions tests. Renault was raided by Paris prosecutors on Thursday, and FCA was accused of installing software in 104,000 Jeep and Ram vehicles to exceed pollution limits. Both companies denied wrongdoing, but shares plummeted. The US Environmental Protection Agency is investigating FCA over its diesel emissions, and Fiat Chrysler may face penalties as high as $4.6 billion. The industry's scrutiny has intensified, with more stringent oversight and cleaner car investments needed to meet future guidelines.

images.alt_text: Pressure weighing on the global auto industry for more than a year finally appeared to ease on Wednesday as Volkswagen AG agreed to US$4.3 billion in fines for cheating on emissions tests, largely putting the scandal to rest. Less than a day later, the outlook darkened again as Renault SA and Fiat Chrysler Automobiles NV were hit with similar allegations of violating clean-air regulations.

site_title: Thai parliament approves king's constitutional changes request, likely delaying elections
summary: Thailand's military-backed parliament approved changes to the constitution, as requested by King Maha Vajiralongkorn, likely delaying the country's general election scheduled for the end of 2017. The changes, which include provisions allowing the king to travel overseas without a regent, were made in response to the king's office, with 228 of 231 assembly members voting in favor. The US State Department expressed support for democratic rule and human rights, and the government is expected to make the requested amendments before the king's approval, potentially pushing the election to early to mid-2018.

site_title: Trump adviser: TPP 'dead,' will move quickly on bilateral trade deals
summary: President-elect Donald Trump will not revive the Trans-Pacific Partnership trade deal, instead pursuing bilateral trade agreements quickly. A Trump transition policy adviser stated that "TPP is dead" and the administration will focus on bilateral deals. The adviser also hinted at taking action against China, including declaring it a currency manipulator and levying tariffs on Chinese goods, to address massive US trade deficits. The new administration views China as perpetrating an economic war against the US, with the goal of hollowing out the US manufacturing base.

images.alt_text: "TPP is dead. I cannot stress that more strongly," said the adviser, who requested anonymity because he was not authorised to speak publicly for the administration that takes office on Jan 20.

site_title: US woman dies of infection resistant to all 26 available antibiotics
summary: A US woman in her 70s died from sepsis caused by carbapenem-resistant Enterobacteriaceae (CRE), a rare and antibiotic-resistant bacteria. The specific strain, Klebsiella pneumoniae, was resistant to all 26 available US antibiotics, including colistin. Postmortem tests showed the infection might have responded to fosfomycin, an antibiotic not approved in the US. This case highlights the growing threat of superbugs, with experts warning of the increasing numbers of drug-resistant infections and the need for flexibility in treatment options.

site_title: Disney CEO's pay falls but US$60m 2018 bonus in reach
summary: Disney CEO Bob Iger received $43.9 million in compensation in 2016, a 2.3% decline from the prior year. He's eligible for a $60 million bonus in 2018 if the company meets a certain target. Iger's pay includes a $20 million cash incentive and $17.3 million in equity awards. Disney reported record sales and profit in 2016, driven by film releases like "Star Wars: The Force Awakens." Failure to extend the company's record earnings streak could impact Iger's bonus eligibility.

site_title: Actors Johnny Depp, Amber Heard finalise bitter divorce
summary: Johnny Depp and Amber Heard finalized their divorce after months of highly publicized claims of domestic violence and financial blackmail. The couple's 15-month marriage ended with Depp agreeing to pay Amber Heard $7 million, which she said will be donated to charity. The divorce was finalized in Los Angeles County Superior Court, following a temporary restraining order obtained by Heard in May.

images.alt_text: Film star Johnny Depp's tumultuous divorce from actress Amber Heard was finalised on Friday, ending the couple's marriage after months of highly publicised claims by Heard of domestic violence and counterclaims from Depp of financial blackmail.

site_title: US: Despite rising banks, US stocks split
summary: US stocks ended the day flat, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average finishing lower for the second day in a row despite strong bank earnings. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq rose, however. Retail spending rebounded 0.6% in December, driven by auto sales, but department store sales fell. Walmart, Target, and Sears were among the Dow's losers. Financials, including Wells Fargo, JP Morgan Chase, and Bank of America, saw gains despite mixed earnings reports. Investors were disappointed by President-elect Trump's lack of specifics on economic stimulus and tax cuts.

site_title: Hit Parade
summary: Bryan Adams returns to Singapore after 23 years with his world tour, "Get Up," which includes new tracks and classic hits like "Everything I Do" and "Heaven." The concert takes place at the Suntec Convention Centre on January 20 at 8pm. Tickets are available from asiaboxoffice.com.

site_title: Doggy-talk doesn't always work on pooches. Doggone
summary: Researchers found that puppies reacted to "dog-directed speech," a speaking pattern similar to "infant-directed speech," with higher-pitched voices and slower speech. However, adult dogs did not respond in the same way. The study, led by Nicolas Mathevon, suggests that puppies are sensitive to this type of speech, which may be a result of humans directing a human behavior at dogs to engage interaction with a non-speaking listener.

site_title: Sony Entertainment CEO Lynton to step down; to become Snap Inc chairman
summary: Sony Entertainment CEO Lynton to step down as CEO of movie and music businesses, effective Feb 2. He will join Snap Inc as chairman, following the company's expected initial public offering (IPO) with a US$25 billion valuation. Lynton will remain co-CEO for the next six months.

site_title: UBS's Asia investment bank head Joseph Chee resigns: sources
summary: UBS Group AG's Asia investment banking head, Joseph Chee, has resigned, according to sources. Chee plans to leave the banking industry and considers setting up his own investment fund. This comes after he spoke at UBS's Greater China conference in Shanghai just last week.

site_title: Oil caps worst week since November with all eyes on Opec cuts
summary: Oil prices posted the largest weekly decline since November, falling 1.2% in New York and 3% for the week. Despite OPEC's promise to cut production, monthly data is still awaited to verify compliance. Saudi Arabia reduced output to less than 10 million barrels a day, but other producers, including the US, are not meeting their pledged reductions. Oil futures slid to $52.37 a barrel, and Brent settled at $55.45, as concerns about rising prices and US production growth persist.

site_title: Takata to pay US$1b, plead guilty in US air bag probe
summary: Takata Corp has agreed to pay US$1 billion in penalties to US regulators, consumers, and car manufacturers as part of a plea deal to hide the risks of its exploding air bags. The Tokyo-based manufacturer also pleaded guilty to one criminal charge. The settlement includes US$25 million for US compensation and US$975 million for carmakers and injured individuals. Three former Takata executives are also charged with hiding the risks, with prosecutors alleging they fabricated test results and manipulated reports.

images.alt_text: Takata Corp admitted to hiding the deadly risks of its exploding air bags for about 15 years in an agreement to pay US regulators, consumers and car manufacturers US$1 billion in penalties. The faulty air bags have been linked to at least 17 deaths worldwide.

site_title: US Congress approves first step for repealing Obamacare
summary: The US House of Representatives approved a budget blueprint that marks the first step towards repealing the Affordable Care Act (Obamacare) with a near party-line vote of 227-198. The resolution provides Republicans with a framework for dismantling the law using reconciliation, allowing repeal legislation to proceed with a simple majority in the Senate. The move is seen as a critical first step towards repealing the law, with President-elect Donald Trump expressing triumph over its repeal. However, Democrats warn of disastrous consequences if Republicans act too hastily without a viable replacement plan, citing concerns over tens of millions losing coverage.

site_title: Hedge fund manager seeks to grow as other funds stumble
summary: Hedge fund manager Chris Rokos plans to reopen his fund to investors early this year, aiming to raise over US$2 billion. After selling two hotels in London for £17.25 million, Rokos has shifted focus from his failed real estate project to growing his firm into a hedge fund giant. This move comes as other hedge funds stumble, with Rokos seeking to capitalize on the market's current trends.

site_title: Stock exchanges turn into ETF exchanges as passive management rules all
summary: Stock exchanges are shifting away from individual shares, with exchange-traded funds (ETFs) becoming the most actively traded securities. In the past year, ETFs took in a record $400 billion, making them a $3.8 trillion industry. The majority of trades are now in ETFs, with 24% more daily volume than the second most traded stock. Passive management and indexing are driving this growth, with nearly 2,000 ETF listings, an all-time high. While individual shares still have some volume, ETFs are increasingly replacing them as investors opt for low-cost, diversified investments.

site_title: Cooking Up New Ideas
summary: Three Singapore chefs, Willin Low of Wild Rocket, Alysia Chan of Crackerjack, and Petrina Loh of Morsels, share their latest projects. Willin Low's Po, at The Warehouse Hotel, serves refined, elevated local fare, including a popiah platter with tiger prawns or blue swimmer crab. Crackerjack offers comfort food with international influences, while Morsels relocates to a new Dempsey location, introducing a weekly noodle bar and increased focus on health benefits through fermented ingredients and traditionally-Chinese ingredients.

site_title: Trump's trade man triggering tremors in China
summary: US President-elect Donald Trump's pick for trade representative, Robert Lighthizer, has vowed to target imports from China, while easing tax burdens for US exporters. Lighthizer, a longtime advocate for aggressive trade measures, has a history of blaming China for the US trade deficit and has consistently pushed for trade measures limiting US imports. China faces a difficult spot, with restrictions on exports to the US making it harder to close factories and lay off workers. The choice of Lighthizer underscores the tough choices ahead for China, which is struggling with an economy slowdown and overcapacity in many industries.

site_title: Amazon's Bezos buys US capital home for US$23m
summary: Amazon founder Jeff Bezos has purchased a 27,000 sq. ft. former Textile Museum in Washington D.C.'s Kalorama district for $23 million. The property, which includes a 7,000 sq. ft. formal garden, will serve as Bezos' private residence when visiting from his West Coast headquarters. The purchase is located in a neighborhood that includes homes of former U.S. President Barack Obama and his wife Michelle, as well as Ivanka Trump and her husband Jared Kushner. Bezos plans to use the home as a pied-a-terre.

site_title: Reflecting on the lessons of 2016
summary: In 2016, global markets experienced a year of great uncertainty and volatility, with investors facing the perils of greed and panic. Despite initial market downturns, including the Brexit vote and Donald Trump's election, many markets ended the year in positive territory, with some indices, such as the US S&P 500 and UK FTSE 100, posting new highs. Key lessons from 2016 include the importance of maintaining a cool head during market fluctuations, avoiding speculation fueled by greed, and keeping a close eye on fundamentals and valuations to mitigate the effects of market downturns.

site_title: Australia startups turn to Silicon Valley as local investors shun risk
summary: Australia startups are turning to Silicon Valley for investment, as local venture capital funds are shunning risk due to the country's risk-averse culture. Paul Evans, an entrepreneur, has been unable to secure A$3 million in funding for his decade-long project, despite interest from global carmakers. With most investors preferring to buy a house over investing in local innovation, Evans is heading to the US to pursue funding opportunities, highlighting the need for alternative funding sources for Australian startups.

site_title: That's a LOT of football
summary: FIFA has unanimously approved the expansion of the World Cup to 48 countries, starting with the 2026 edition. The change, proposed by FIFA president Gianni Infantino, aims to generate close to $1 billion in extra revenue and increase payments for member associations. However, fans and football clubs are divided on the move, citing concerns over burnout, injury, and a potential dilution of the tournament's quality. The decision will be finalized in 2020, with the United States, Canada, and Mexico among early favorites to host the event.

site_title: Anchor Resources queried on stock price surge
summary: Anchor Resources, a Singapore-based mineral explorer, experienced unusual trading activity, with over 64 million units changing hands on the Singapore Exchange. The stock surged 13.5% to close at S$0.109. This unusual activity comes ahead of GDP data and marks a 5-day rally for Singapore stocks.

site_title: After years of problems, Trump hotel in Toronto is put up for sale
summary: The Trump International Hotel & Tower in Toronto, plagued by construction delays, financial woes, and lawsuits since its 2012 opening, is up for sale. CBRE Ltd is offering the 65-story property at a minimum price of C$298 million after a court-appointed receiver was appointed due to loan defaults by developer Talon International. Donald Trump and his family license the Trump name but have no ownership interest in the building. The project has had a rocky history, with construction delays, shattering glass panels, and lawsuits from investors.

site_title: Wild Thing
summary: The Range Rover Sport SVR, the fastest and most powerful SUV from Jaguar Land Rover, boasts 550 hp and 680 Nm, accelerating from 0-100 km/h in 4.7 seconds. With its lightweight all-aluminium body and advanced suspension, the SVR delivers exceptional handling and ride comfort. Featuring a 5.0-litre supercharged V8 and an 8-speed automatic transmission, the SVR also boasts impressive off-road capabilities, including a wading depth of 850 mm. Priced at SGD 660,000, the SVR is a luxury SUV that ticks all the right boxes.

site_title: HK court rejects short seller's appeal bid in China Evergrande case
summary: Hong Kong's Court of Appeal rejected activist short seller Andrew Left's appeal bid in the China Evergrande case, upholding a tribunal's ruling that found him culpable of market misconduct over a research report. Left, founder of Citron Research, had filed an appeal on November 16, 2022. The tribunal's findings were not reversed, and the appeal to the findings of fact was also denied. The decision marks a significant outcome in the case, which has implications for the financial markets and regulatory bodies.

site_title: SPH Q1 profit falls 43.8% to S$45.7m on restructuring charges
summary: Singapore Press Holdings (SPH) reported a 43.8% decline in Q1 profit to S$45.7 million, driven by restructuring charges and a decline in its core media business. Earnings per share fell to 3 cents from 5 cents a year ago. The company attributed the decline to retrenchment and restructuring-related charges, as well as fair-value losses on hedges for its portfolio investments. SPH expects challenging business conditions for its media business over the next 12 months and plans to focus on innovation, cost efficiency, and diversifying revenue streams.

images.alt_text: SPH said that it expects business conditions for its media business to remain challenging over the next 12 months.

site_title: Big local law firms take spots in 2016 M&A activity tables
summary: Singapore's Big Four law firms, WongPartnership and Allen & Gledhill, emerged among the top legal advisors in South-east Asia by value of merger and acquisition (M&A) deals in 2016. WongPartnership retained its second spot with US$8.8 billion in deals, while Allen & Gledhill slipped to fourth place with US$8.2 billion. Linklaters took the top spot with a US$9.2 billion deal value. Global M&A activity reached its third-highest deal value since 2007, but fell 18.1% compared to 2015, due to uncertain events such as Brexit negotiations and the US presidential election.

site_title: The definitive, absolutely insightful 'Places You Must Visit' list for 2017
summary: The Business Times has compiled a definitive list of 2017 travel destinations based on major economic and political themes. Key places to visit include Iran, where the country's strong government control and relative stability make it an attractive destination, despite uncertainty over its global standing. Kazakhstan is also highlighted for its vast, multicultural, and young population, and its efforts to diversify its economy and attract private investments. Other destinations include San Francisco, California, for a vision of the future, Yellowknife, Canada, for the northern lights, and the United Kingdom, where tourists can take advantage of the low value of the pound sterling.

images.alt_text: OFF THE TRACK: Ka'ba-ye Zartosht or the Cube of Zoroaster near Persepolis, Iran.
OFF THE TRACK: The Northern Lights over one of Yellowknife's lakes.
OLD AND NEW: The Ascension Cathedral (Zenkov Cathedral) in Almaty, Kazakhstan, is the world's second tallest wooden building.
OLD AND NEW: Celebration of St George Day in the UK.
OLD AND NEW: The San Francisco-Oakland Bay Bridge.

site_title: Dasin Retail Trust prices IPO at 80 cents, to raise S$121 million
summary: DASIN Retail Trust priced its Singapore IPO at 80 cents per unit, raising S$121 million in gross proceeds. The trust will list on the Singapore Exchange with a market capitalization of S$440 million. Its projected distribution yield is 8.5% for 2017 and 9% for 2018. The trust will acquire a fourth mall, Shiqi Metro Mall, from its sponsor for about 1.22 billion yuan, and has an option to acquire a Doumen Metro Mall development project. Despite concerns over e-commerce cannibalizing brick and mortar retail sales in China, the portfolio malls are still enjoying high footfall.

site_title: Dance Off
summary: The 10th International Lion Dance Competition will take place from January 14-15 at Banda Street carpark, featuring over 10 troupes from Singapore and Asia Pacific. The annual event showcases intricate moves and gravity-defying stunts on the meihuazhuang. Tickets are available from the Chinatown Visitor Centre @ Kreta Ayer Square and are selling out fast.

site_title: Indonesia commodity export policy turnaround rattles miners
summary: Indonesia has revised its mineral export policy, allowing miners to export excess nickel ore and bauxite from processing plants, a move that has rattled mining companies globally. The policy shift, which reverses a 2014 ban on unprocessed ore shipments, sent copper prices to their highest in a month and dropped nickel producers such as Sumitomo Metal Mining Co. and Nickel Asia Corp. The move is expected to impact companies like Freeport-McMoRan Inc, which operates the world's second-largest copper mine in Papua, and is seen as a positive move for the country's economy.

images.alt_text: Jakarta will allow shipments of ore with nickel content less than 1.7 per cent. Shipments will be linked to the progress of smelter projects which must be completed within five years.

site_title: When it's time to lather those locks
summary: Some women who cut back on shampooing due to concerns about over-washing are now rediscovering the benefits of regular shampooing. Experts, including stylists and dermatologists, say that using the right products and not over-relying on dry shampoo can help maintain healthy hair. Pantene is launching a new shampoo and conditioner formula that delivers thin sheets of hydrating biolipids. Meanwhile, dermatologists recommend regular shampooing to clear away dead skin, and some women are finding that re-embracing a regular shampoo routine is essential for maintaining healthy hair.

site_title: Dennis Tay
summary: Dennis Tay, founder of Naiise, a Singapore-based retail store for well-designed products, has achieved significant growth since its inception in 2013 with just $3,000 in investment. The company made $30,000 in its first year and $5 million last year. Tay aims to expand to Malaysia and the UK, with plans to open one or two more stores in Singapore. Despite not having a design background, Tay prioritizes originality, quality, and products that improve people's lives. His wife, Amanda, serves as the marketing director, and the couple balances work and personal life, with fatherhood bringing new dimensions to their relationship.

site_title: Like Real
summary: Singapore artist Cheok Keng Lye is showcasing his new exhibition "Reborn" at the K+ Curatorial Space at Scotts Square, featuring life-like resin fish with simple and detailed brushstrokes. The exhibition returns to scenes of his youth, depicting longkang fish and goldfish, with pieces available for sale.

site_title: Baker on Board
summary: Mary Berry, Britain's national treasure, will be on board the Belmond British Pullman on February 5, offering guests a chance to sample her favorite cakes, including cherry and almond tart and baked scones, made using her personal recipes. The Art Deco 1920s carriages provide a fitting ambiance for the event. Prices start at £275, and more information can be found on Belmond.com/britishpullman.

site_title: Helluva Visit
summary: Haw Par Villa, a theme park in Singapore, was initially known as Tiger Balm Gardens in 1959. It was founded by the Aw brothers, who also created the topical ointment Tiger Balm. The park was designed by the brothers' nephew and underwent an $80-million revamp in 1990, featuring an amphitheatre, theatres, and a dragon structure. The park was later acquired by the Singapore government and revitalized as a commercial theme park.

site_title: Hooked on Healing
summary:
Here is a 100-word or less summary of the article content:

The wellness industry has experienced unprecedented growth, worth US$3.7 trillion, as urbanites prioritize fitness, nutrition, and preventive healthcare. Wellness tourism has also seen significant growth, with revenues increasing 14% from 2013 to 2015. Spas and resorts are catering to this demand, offering specialized treatments and retreats. Baby boomers, with 73% of the world's economic power, are driving this trend, seeking preventive medicine and holistic approaches to wellness. The industry is expected to continue growing, with emerging middle-class consumers and affordable options expanding the market.

site_title: X Factor
summary: The Opel Mokka X, a mini-crossover with turbodiesel power, has been updated with a new front end, revised bumpers, and a revamped interior featuring a touchscreen display. The vehicle boasts roomy cabin space, excellent headroom, and a digital speedometer. Powered by a 1.6-litre turbodiesel engine, the Mokka X offers impressive fuel economy and lively performance. Its tidy handling and solid build make it an entry-level premium vehicle, rivaling Singapore's best-selling model, the Honda Vezel.

site_title: Loans growth at OCBC's Chongqing branch triples y-o-y in Nov
summary: OCBC's Chongqing branch saw loans growth triple year-over-year in November 2016, driven by increased business activity and the Chongqing Connectivity Initiative (CCI). The bank attributed the growth to broad-based credit quality across key sectors of the Chongqing economy, with partnerships with local financial institutions and state-owned enterprises. The CCI is expected to continue supporting businesses in both countries, according to OCBC's CEO.

site_title: Dine Now
summary: Tippling Club's BIN 38 is offering a Cuban-themed evening with rum-infused cocktails and canapés on Jan 19 for S$155. Creamier is celebrating its 5th anniversary with a limited-edition Bourbon Whiskey Black Sesame with Apples flavor, available at S$4.50 per scoop and S$16 per pint.

site_title: Carson grilled on his vision for housing
summary: BEN Carson testified before the Senate Banking, Housing and Urban Affairs Committee, detailing his vision for the Department of Housing and Urban Development (HUD). Carson emphasized the need for holistic solutions, integrating government-assistance programs with private sector involvement and faith groups. He suggested that faster economic growth could reduce the need for HUD's programs, but acknowledged the importance of government assistance in promoting life, liberty, and the pursuit of happiness. Carson's nomination has raised concerns about his lack of government experience, with critics questioning his qualifications to lead the department.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: A Myanmar real estate company, Yoma Strategic Holdings, has had its Landmark development approved by the Myanmar Investment Commission, allowing it to proceed with redevelopment. Meanwhile, CNMC Goldmine Holdings expects a net loss for the fourth quarter of 2016 due to foreign exchange losses and lower revenue. GKE Corp reported a loss of S$558,000 in the second quarter due to operational losses. EMS Energy's unit received a contract termination notice and a claim under a bank guarantee, prompting the company to seek legal advice.

site_title: Little Shop of Nostalgia
summary: A 74-year-old antique enthusiast, Harry Ang, has opened a vintage store in a Singaporean HDB shop space, featuring 15 old gramophones from his personal collection of 100 gramophones and 2000 telephones. The store, initially called Ceramica 28, showcases Ang's passion for collecting vintage items.

site_title: Icelandic Cool
summary: In Iceland, two hotels embody the country's unique blend of natural beauty and Nordic design. The ION Luxury Adventure Hotel, perched on Mount Hengill, features clean, minimalist interiors that incorporate natural materials and sustainable practices. In contrast, the 101 Hotel in Reykjavik boasts chic, monochromatic interiors and a trendy restaurant, but with a focus on urban jungle surroundings rather than natural landscapes. Both hotels showcase the country's timeless appeal and innovative approach to design.

site_title: China December exports down as trade tensions with US loom
summary: China's December exports fell 6.1% from a year earlier, contributing to a 7.7% decline in full-year exports to $2.1 trillion. The trade surplus widened to $510 billion, driven by a 3.1% increase in imports. Trade tensions with the US, China's largest export market, remain a concern, with the US accusing China of subsidizing steel and aluminum production. China's trade surplus with the US was $366 billion in 2015, and economists warn of long-term structural weakness in China's exports if the US imposes punitive tariffs.

images.alt_text: The disappointing data comes despite a weaker currency, a strong pick-up in manufacturing as well as positive trade data in other Asian economies.

site_title: Abang Johari sworn in as Sarawak's sixth chief minister
summary: Abang Johari Abang Openg, 67, was sworn in as Sarawak's sixth chief minister, succeeding Adenan Satem who died on Wednesday. Abang Johari was one of three deputy chief ministers and had been tipped as the favourite to succeed Adenan.

site_title: My Weekend
summary: A local entrepreneur, Dawn Lim, founder of Cafe Karung Guni, shares her weekend routine, prioritizing food and staying updated on the F&B scene. She spends weekends exploring new restaurants, visiting hawker centers, and cooking at home. Lim's love for food is evident, and she considers it an essential part of her weekends.

images.alt_text: Dawn Lim

site_title: Motor show expected to draw weekend crowds
summary: The Singapore Motorshow 2017, which runs from January 12-15, opened to the general public on a relatively quiet note on Friday. Despite initial concerns about a slow economy affecting buying sentiment, dealers remain upbeat, expecting a bigger turnout this weekend. Many new models are on display, including the Mazda MX-5 RF and CX-9, and the Nissan Pulsar and Note e-Power. Luxury brands like Mercedes-Benz and Volkswagen are also showcasing their latest models, including the C43 coupe and Tiguan SUV. Dealers are confident that the main crowd will arrive on Saturday and Sunday.

images.alt_text: The event will showcase the models of 27 members of the Motor Traders Association of Singapore - three more than last year's show.
Among the new models on display are Toyota's CH-R crossover (above) and Volkswagen's Beetle Cabriolet.
Among the new models on display are Toyota's CH-R crossover and Volkswagen's Beetle Cabriolet (above).

site_title: Mountain music and hot metal
summary: Mountain Man, a Vermont-based trio of young women, delivers "bewitching" and "haunting" Appalachian folk rock despite being misjudged as a group of hairy, bearded men. Their 2010 album, recorded in an abandoned factory, features sparse instrumentation and beautifully harmonized voices. The music's tone is enhanced by the cavernous quality of the factory setting, with only an acoustic guitar and some tracks sung a cappella. The group's unique sound showcases their talent and defies expectations, setting them apart from their metal counterpart, Metallica.

site_title: US Reits to perform well despite rising rates: Cohen & Steers
summary: Cohen & Steers predicts US real estate investment trusts (Reits) will perform well despite rising interest rates due to a growing economy and increasing employment. This contradicts the common assumption that Reits suffer when interest rates rise. The global portfolio manager, Jon Cheigh, states that rising rates indicate a more sustainable economy, which should boost demand for office space. This overlooked aspect of Reits has often been ignored for 25 years.

site_title: Singapore: Throw-Away Nation
summary: Singapore generates 7.67 million tonnes of waste, equivalent to 1,400 kg per person, in 2015, with 4.65 million tonnes being recycled. The country's preoccupation with shopping and consumption drives the disposal of items still bearing price tags, contributing to a rise in waste. Experts attribute the issue to increasing affluence, higher income levels, and the convenience of using plastic bags to dispose of trash. Food wastage accounts for a tenth of total waste, with 785,500 tonnes generated in 2015, and only 12,500 tonnes recycled. Businesses, such as NTUC FairPrice and Swissotel, are taking steps to reduce food and textile waste, with initiatives like composting and repackaging ugly produce.

images.alt_text: Singaporeans wasted up to 785,500 tonnes of food in 2015. This is equivalent to each person throwing away every day 2 bowls of food.

Food From The Heart, a voluntary welfare organisation that channels unwanted bread from hotels and bakeries to needy families and individuals, collects more than 28,000kg of bread every month, which adds up to an astounding 336 tonnes of bread a year that would otherwise have been discarded.

site_title: China Env auditors uncover phantom gross receivables
summary: China Environment, a company treating industrial waste gas, reported that 43.5% of its total gross receivables of 786 million yuan in FY2015 were either non-existent or overstated. Auditors found that trade receivables from Shanxi Electric, amounting to 70 million yuan, were likely overstated by 48 million yuan. The company will write to former executives to query these discrepancies and assess adjustments to its fiscal 2015 accounts. Shares remain suspended amid these findings.

site_title: No nonsense
summary: Morgan Stanley President Colm Kelleher emphasizes the importance of substance over fluff in banking and leadership. He believes that the industry should focus on its core duties to clients rather than self-promotion. Kelleher, a former history professor, attributes his success to his analytical mind and ability to navigate complex situations. He advocates for a culture that punishes bad behavior and encourages good behavior, and has implemented such measures at Morgan Stanley. Kelleher is cautious about the impact of populism, noting that the substance of a leader's policies can differ from their campaign rhetoric. He believes that bankers should prioritize their work and avoid drawing attention to themselves, and has taken steps to reduce compensation excesses at Morgan Stanley.

images.alt_text: "Bankers should be boring. We should not be in the news. We should be doing our job. We get well paid, but our job is to actually facilitate trade, balance of payments, growth and so on, and that's what we should go back to doing."

site_title: Bullish crude oil futures and options rise to around two-year highs
summary: Crude oil futures and options have surged to around two-year highs due to rising US and North Sea production, with net "long" positions reaching 440,000 contracts, equivalent to 440 million barrels. This comes after Opec agreed on production cuts, which has led to Brent oil prices rising to $55.86 a barrel. However, some analysts believe the market is overbought due to increasing shale oil production and uncertainty about demand. The International Energy Agency estimates that global demand will average 96.9 million barrels a day in the first half of 2017, with Opec as the swing producer.

site_title: Despite mid-week blip, STI manages 2% gain over the week
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) gained 2% for the week, closing at 3,025.07 points, after a mid-week blip. The index was boosted by Trump reflationary plays, particularly in the banking sector, and regained the 3,000 mark. However, a disappointing Trump press conference and rising interest rates concerns weighed on the market. Analysts, including CIMB and Deutsche Bank, remain optimistic on the sector, citing low gearing and capacity for reinvestment.

site_title: Asset manager BlackRock's quarterly profit falls 1.2%
summary: BlackRock, the world's largest asset manager, reported a 1.2% decline in quarterly profit to $851 million, down from $861 million in the same period last year. The company's earnings per share were $5.13, beating analyst expectations of $5.02. The decline in profit was attributed to investors rushing into low-cost funds.

site_title: EMS Energy gets termination notice from Jurong Shipyard on S$1.1m contract
summary: EMS Energy's wholly-owned unit received a termination notice from Jurong Shipyard Pte Ltd on a S$1.1 million contract. Jurong Shipyard claims S$110,000 under a bank guarantee, citing non-payment. EMS Energy has received S$330,000 in milestone payments. The company will seek legal advice to claim compensation for delivered components and non-performance from sub-contractors. This may impact EMS Energy's proposed schemes of arrangement filed with the High Court of Singapore in 2016.

site_title: Your work doesn't always speak for itself
summary: Advocating for oneself in the workplace is crucial for career advancement, but it can be a delicate balance between assertiveness and likability. Experts advise employees to do their homework, understand their power dynamics, and be strategic in their approach. This includes knowing the rules of the game, framing requests as problems, and being relevant and focused on the organization's priorities. Having sponsors and a strong support network can also help employees make their voices heard. Ultimately, the approach taken will determine whether employees are supported or perceived as entitled, making it essential to choose a strategy that aligns with the organization's agenda.

site_title: Local football badly needs a lifeline
summary: Singapore football is in dire straits, with dismal displays by youth teams, a poorly-attended S.League, and a low Fifa world ranking of 165. The Football Association of Singapore (FAS) is set to hold its first elections in three decades by May, which could bring about a wind of change. To revitalize the sport, experts recommend enhancing the Marquee Player Scheme, reducing the number of teams, and developing a natural feeder system. Billionaire businessman Peter Lim is seen as a potential lifeline to provide the necessary money, sponsorship, and expertise to revitalize the sport.

site_title: Shipping snarl-up at Chinese ports ahead of Chinese New Year
summary: A massive traffic jam of hundreds of ships carrying coal and iron ore has built up outside key Chinese ports, including Tianjin and Caofeidian, due to poor visibility caused by smog. The congestion, which began on Dec 20, has left ships waiting for up to 7 days to offload, depleting available stocks of certain materials and causing delays for shippers across the Asia-Pacific region. The situation is expected to worsen ahead of the Chinese New Year holiday later this month, with some ships waiting for weeks to deliver their raw materials.

site_title: JPMorgan profit rises 24% as US election stimulates trading
summary: JPMorgan Chase & Co reported a 23.8% rise in quarterly profit to $6.73 billion, driven by a surge in investor activity related to the US presidential election. Earnings per share rose to $1.71, beating analyst expectations. The bank's results were also influenced by the Federal Reserve's interest rate hike in December. The election's impact on trading in stocks and bonds contributed to the bank's strong performance, with trading volumes increasing during a normally slow period.

site_title: STI gains 1% on Friday, 2% for the week
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) rose 1% on Friday, reaching 3,025.07 points, and gained 2% for the week, driven by a reflationary play related to US President Trump. Despite mediocre volume, the index's advance-decline score was closer to its strength, indicating potential short-covering. The Dow futures traded 20 points higher on Friday, but the STI's gains were not mirrored by the US market, highlighting the index's unique performance.

site_title: Wells Fargo's profit falls 6.4%
summary: Wells Fargo reported a 6.4% decline in quarterly profit to $4.87 billion, or 96 cents per share, in the fourth quarter ended December 31. The decline is attributed to a bogus-accounts scandal and a sharp drop in account openings. The bank set aside $805 million to cover potential loan losses, down 3.1% from a year earlier. This marks the fifth straight decline in quarterly profit under new CEO Timothy Sloan.

site_title: Latest Earnings
summary: NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer was 9.8 times oversubscribed. Creative Technology warned of potential revenue shortfall and operating loss similar to the first half of the year. London's Heathrow plans to increase fees for a £10 billion upgrade. Indonesia detained an employee of Trafigura in a graft case. OCBC's incoming CEO, Tan Teck Long, is a former DBS veteran. The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) and the People's Bank of China (PBOC) agreed to deepen cooperation in green and transition finance, ahead of the release of Singapore's GDP data, which saw a 5-day rally in Singapore stocks.

site_title: Power play at Vanke seen ending with 15.3% stake sale
summary: Shenzhen Metro Group, a state-owned company, has purchased a 15.3% stake in China Vanke, becoming the company's second-largest shareholder. This move likely paves the way for Shenzhen Metro to take control of Vanke, ending a year-long corporate power struggle. Vanke, China's largest property developer by market value, has been in crisis since Baoneng Group, a financial conglomerate, built up a 25% stake and attempted to oust management. The purchase may bring stability to the company, but its impact on the property market remains to be seen.

site_title: US: Stocks gain as bank earnings boost confidence
summary: US stocks rose in morning trading on Friday, boosted by bank stocks after better-than-expected quarterly profits from Bank of America, Wells Fargo, and JPMorgan. Bank stocks surged, with Bank of America up 2.1%, JPMorgan at a record high, and Wells Fargo gaining 3.1%. The Dow Jones Industrial Average was up 0.26%, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also rose, with the combined profit of S&P 500 companies estimated to have risen 5.7% in the fourth quarter.

site_title: What Trump's policies will mean for China's economy
summary: US President-elect Donald Trump's policies may have significant implications for China's economy, including trade restrictions, protectionism, and isolationism. China is unlikely to allow its currency to drop sharply or sell US Treasuries in retaliation, but trade retaliation is very likely, potentially hurting the US more than China. Trump's policies could delay China's structural rebalancing process and hinder consumption-led growth, but may also give China space to expand its Belt & Road initiatives. China's growth rate is expected to remain stable at 6.5% this year, with a neutral monetary policy and expansionary fiscal policy.

images.alt_text: ISOLATIONISM: Plans by Mr Trump to withdraw from the international free trade engagements will give space for China to expand.

site_title: Taking a leaf from the Danes' playbook
summary: The concept of "hygge" from Denmark has captured the world's attention, with the country topping the UN's World Happiness Report for two consecutive years. Hygge refers to a quality of cosiness and comfortable conviviality that engenders contentment or well-being. While Singaporeans don't have a direct equivalent, the article highlights indigenous terms such as "lepak" (chilling with friends), "xiang shou" (taking a break and bonding with loved ones), and "kondattam" (letting loose and enjoying life with friends and family). These concepts share similarities with hygge and may help Singaporeans cultivate a sense of well-being and happiness.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Ezion Holdings' operating environment remains challenging, with estimated capex for FY17 expected to be US$160-180 million, down 40% from 2014 levels. Despite this, OCBC Investment Research upgrades the stock to "buy" with a target price of S$0.54, representing a 30% upside potential. Meanwhile, StarHub and M1 have signed a mobile infrastructure sharing agreement, expected to help them sustain fixed dividend commitments. The agreement also implies capex savings, which can aid StarHub's fixed dividend commitment and M1's earnings payout ratio.

site_title: India's SpiceJet agrees to buy up to 205 Boeing jets, worth US$22b
summary: India's SpiceJet has agreed to buy up to 205 Boeing jets worth up to $22 billion, with a firm order of 155 737 MAX jets and an option for 50 more. The deal includes an option to buy wide-body aircraft for long-haul journeys. SpiceJet's chairman, Ajay Singh, stated that the purchase rights include this option.

site_title: Malaysia: Stocks end lower
summary: Malaysia's Bursa Malaysia stocks closed lower on Friday, with the Kuala Lumpur Composite Index falling 5.26 points to 1,672.50. The index saw 2.21 billion lots traded, with losers outnumbering gainers 464 to 327.

site_title: CNMC Goldmine Holdings warns of loss for Q4
summary: CNMC Goldmine Holdings expects to report a net loss for the fourth quarter of 2016 due to unrealised foreign exchange losses and lower revenue from reduced ore grades. Despite this, the group still expects to be profitable for the full year ended December 31. The company will announce its results on or before March 1, 2017.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Former Singapore banker Yeo Jiawei spent US$8.2 million on Australian properties using a tax haven company, amid allegations of money laundering linked to Malaysia's 1MDB scandal.
