The US must take a strong stance to prevent China's expansion, Tillerson said during his confirmation hearing with the Senate Foreign Relations Committee. This move could strain US-China relations and escalate tensions in the region.

site_title: Australia's Tigerair blames Indonesia for Bali flight chaos
summary: Tigerair Australia blames Indonesia for the chaos that stranded hundreds of its passengers in Bali, citing a bureaucratic technicality. The airline claims that Indonesian authorities had approved its operation until March 25, but new procedures have resulted in confusion. Tigerair is seeking a grace period to continue flying while working through the new requirements. The airline operates flights under Virgin Australia's licence, and the change in oversight agency has led to more stringent sales requirements, including not selling tickets in Indonesia.

site_title: McDonald's inviting bids for 33% stake in Japan unit: WSJ
summary: McDonald's is inviting bids for a 33% stake in its Japan unit, McDonald's Holdings Co Japan Ltd, with bids due next week. The company owns around 50% of the Japanese business and is looking to sell a portion of its stake. Morgan Stanley is running the sale, which follows McDonald's recent sale of its China and Hong Kong business to state-backed conglomerate CITIC Ltd and Carlyle Group LP.

site_title: StarHub, M1 sign MOU for deeper cooperation on mobile network
summary: Singapore's second and third mobile telcos, M1 and StarHub Mobile, signed a Memorandum of Understanding (MOU) to explore deeper cooperation on mobile network infrastructure. The two companies plan to study collaboration in radio access networks, backhaul, and access assets. This move comes as the industry prepares for a new player's entry. The telcos have previously shared mobile infrastructure, including combined antenna systems and in-building fibre cables. The collaboration aims to improve efficiency and reduce costs.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks ease as 5-day rally peters out
summary: Hong Kong stocks fell 0.5% on Thursday, ending a five-day rally, as investors took a breather. The Hang Seng index dropped to 22,829.02 points, while the Hong Kong China Enterprises Index lost 0.1% to 9,723.05 points. The decline followed a regional rally, with Asia stocks rising due to relief over US President-elect Donald Trump keeping tariffs against Chinese exports off the table in a news conference.

site_title: Vard Holdings privatisation offer turns unconditional
summary: Vard Holdings, a Singapore-listed shipbuilding firm, has had its privatisation offer from parent group Fincantieri Oil & Gas declared unconditional following a reduction of the acceptance condition to over 50%. Fincantieri now holds 55.63% of Vard's shares, with the offer closing on Feb 2 or later. This is Fincantieri's second attempt at privatising Vard, with the company offering to buy out remaining equity at S$0.24 per share.

site_title: India's Tata Sons appoints new chairman
summary: India's Tata Sons appointed Natarajan Chandrasekaran, 53-year-old head of its IT services unit, as new chairman, replacing Cyrus Mistry who was ousted by the holding company in October. Chandrasekaran, a Tata lifer since 1987, will take charge from February 21. The appointment comes amid an ongoing feud between Mistry and group patriarch Ratan Tata, which has threatened the conglomerate's reputation and wiped off around $9 billion from its collective stock market value.

site_title: China puts up Stop sign for Pokemon Go
summary: China has temporarily banned Pokémon Go and other augmented-reality games due to concerns over potential security risks, including threats to consumer and traffic safety and the security of geographic information. The China Audio-Video and Digital Publishing Association (CADPA) informed the move by China's State Administration of Press, Publication, Radio, Film and Television (SAPPRFT). The ban will remain in place until the review is completed.

site_title: Oxley Holdings secures first anchor tenant for Dublin Landings
summary: Oxley Holdings has secured its first anchor tenant for Dublin Landings, a 2.35-hectare development project in Ireland. The National Treasury Management Agency (NTMA) will lease 7,700 square meters of office and retail space in Block D1 for 25 years, starting from February 2018. The project, launched in October 2016, will feature 65,000 sq m of office and retail space, 273 luxury apartments, and five new office buildings expected to be completed by 2020.

site_title: Chaly Mah to join CapitaLand board on Feb 1
summary: CapitaLand appoints Chaly Mah Chee Kheong as an independent non-executive director effective Feb 1. Mr. Mah, 60, is a former Deloitte CEO and chairman of Singapore Land Authority. He currently chairs the Singapore Accountancy Commission and Singapore Tourism Board. The appointment aims to bring expertise and experience to CapitaLand's board, enhancing the company's governance and decision-making capabilities.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Mapletree Investments launched the first Singapore dollar bond sale in 2017, selling perpetual bonds. Tembusu Partners sold a 36% stake in Ednovation to CDH Investments for over S$50 million. GLP extended 3.6 million sq ft of leases with a US customer. Fincantieri's offer to buy Vard Holdings was declared unconditional. The Singapore Budget 2017 wishlist includes measures to encourage innovation, attract new players, and promote health. The STI closed lower, dipping below 3,000 for the second consecutive day.

site_title: Europe: Stock markets fall at open
summary: Europe's main stock markets fell at the start of trading on Thursday, with London's FTSE 100 index down 0.2% to 7,273.56 points. Frankfurt's DAX 30 index and Paris CAC 40 index also declined, with losses of 0.4% and 0.3%, respectively. The decline comes despite a strong rally in Singapore stocks, which notched a 5-day gain ahead of GDP data release.

site_title: ST Electronics secures S$695m worth of contracts for Q4 2016, S$2.33b for 2016
summary: ST Electronics secured S$695m worth of contracts for Q4 2016, bringing the year's total to S$2.33b. Contracts were secured in rail electronics, intelligent transportation, satellite communications, and ICT solutions. About S$529m worth of advanced electronics and ICT contracts came from the private and public sectors, with completion expected by 2023. ST Engineering's share price fell 0.6% to S$3.34 following the announcement.

images.alt_text: THE electronics arm of Singapore Technologies Engineering Ltd (ST Engineering) had secured about S$695 million worth of contracts for the fourth quarter of 2016, bringing the total value of new orders for the year to S$2.33 billion.

site_title: PSA container volume up 5.5% on higher overseas throughput
summary: PSA International reported a 5.5% increase in container volume to 67.63 million TEUs in 2016, driven by higher overseas throughput. Container volume at its Singapore terminals remained flat at 30.59 million TEUs, while terminals outside Singapore saw a 10.6% increase to 37.04 million TEUs. This growth is attributed to the expansion of PSA's port projects worldwide.

site_title: Trump, tech tycoons talk overhaul of high-skilled visa program
summary: President-elect Donald Trump's transition team is considering overhauling the H-1B visa program, which brings foreign workers to the US to fill high-skilled jobs. A possible reform would favour visa petitions for jobs paying the highest salaries, potentially replacing the current lottery system. The proposal has been discussed with tech executives, including those from Google, Facebook, and Apple, who expressed support for the plan. However, significant changes may require Congressional action, and the process could be subject to court challenges.

images.alt_text: President-elect Donald Trump's transition team has been actively considering ways to revamp a temporary visa program used to bring foreign workers to the United States to fill high-skilled jobs, according to sources familiar with the discussions.

site_title: Seoul: Won ends at 1-month high, stocks extend rally
summary: The South Korean won reached a one-month high of 1,184.7 to the dollar, up 1.0% from the previous day, amid US President Donald Trump's unclear economic policies. South Korean shares, led by Samsung Electronics' record high, rose 0.6% to 2,087.14 points. The rally extends a 5-day streak of gains in Singapore stocks, despite US-EU trade talks and tariff uncertainty.

site_title: Ministry of Law calls for feedback on proposed changes to Trustees Act
summary: The Ministry of Law in Singapore launched a public consultation on proposed amendments to the Trustees Act, aiming to enhance transparency of trust ownership and control structures, and prescribe minimum financial record-keeping standards. The proposed amendments, influenced by international recommendations, would empower the Minister of Law to make rules, impose penalties, and designate breaches as offences. The public consultation, running until Jan 31, seeks feedback on the proposed changes.

site_title: Samurai 2K Aerosol receives valid subscription for all 20m placement shares for Catalist IPO
summary: SAMURAI 2K Aerosol Limited announced that its initial public offering (IPO) placement for 20 million new shares at 20 Singapore cents per share received valid applications for all shares. The company received S$4.0 million in application monies, increasing its total issued share capital to 100 million shares and market capitalization to approximately S$20 million.

site_title: Fincantieri's privatisation offer of Vard Holdings declared unconditional
summary: Fincantieri Oil & Gas has had its conditional offer to buy out Vard Holdings' remaining equity declared unconditional by the Securities Industry Council. The offer, which was initially set at more than 50% acceptance, has been reduced to a level of over 50%. The closing date for the offer has been extended to Feb 2 or later.

site_title: Australia: Stocks end the day lower
summary: Australian shares ended the day 0.1% lower, with the S&P/ASX 200 index closing at 5,766.9. The decline was driven by healthcare stocks, which fell after US President-elect Donald Trump's comments on the sector. CSL Ltd and Mayne Pharma were the worst hit, losing 2.8% and 4% respectively. Basic materials and energy shares remained resilient, boosted by a weaker dollar.

site_title: US Senate approves measure launching Obamacare repeal process
summary: The US Senate voted 51-48 to instruct key committees to draft legislation repealing the Affordable Care Act (Obamacare). The resolution now heads to the House of Representatives, where a vote is expected this week. This move aligns with the Republican majorities' top priority of dismantling the program, as President-elect Donald Trump had expressed a desire to repeal it. The outcome sets the stage for a potential overhaul of the healthcare system.

site_title: US indicts six as Volkswagen agrees to pay US$4.3b over diesel scandal
summary: Volkswagen has agreed to pay $4.3 billion in US fines to settle charges of conspiring to cheat on diesel emission tests for nearly 10 years. The German automaker has also agreed to spend up to $22 billion in the US to address claims from owners, regulators, and states. Six current and former senior executives, including Heinz-Jakob Neusser and Oliver Schmidt, have been indicted and charged with their roles in the scheme. The company has also admitted to installing secret software in hundreds of thousands of US diesel cars to cheat exhaust emissions tests.

site_title: Tembusu Partners sells 36% interest in Ednovation for more than S$50m
summary: Tembusu Partners sold a 36% stake in Ednovation to CDH Investments for over S$50 million, representing an internal rate of return of more than 30% for Tembusu's three-year investment. Ednovation operates over 60 pre-schools in Asia under several brands. The disposal marks the end of Tembusu's involvement in the education group, which operates in growth sectors such as education, healthcare, and technology.

site_title: Britain plans to create more independent electricity market operator
summary: Britain plans to create a more independent electricity market operator within National Grid by April 2019, aiming to boost competition and benefit consumers. The new operator will carry out balancing power supplies and manage complex energy flows. This move is intended to make the transition to a lower carbon future and ensure customers get the most out of smart technologies. The plan is a result of collaboration between energy regulator Ofgem and the Department for Business, Energy and Industrial Strategy.

site_title: Singapore shares close lower as STI dips below 3,000
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) fell below 3,000 for the first time since November 2015, closing at 2,993. The decline was attributed to a plunge in Dow futures ahead of a weak US market. Despite earlier gains from Global Logistic Properties, DBS, and UOB, afternoon selling ultimately pushed the STI down. The one-day stay below 3,000 marked a significant reversal from the previous day's 0.4% gain.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks down as drugmakers hit by Trump comments
summary: Tokyo stocks declined 1.19% on January 12, 2017, following US President-elect Donald Trump's comments that drugmakers were "getting away with murder" for overcharging and outsourcing production. The Nikkei index fell to 19,134.70, while the Topix index declined to 1,535.41.

site_title: Federal ethics chief blasts Trump's plan to break from businesses 'meaningless'
summary: Federal ethics chief Walter Shaub criticized President-elect Donald Trump's plan to separate his presidency from his business empire as "wholly inadequate" and said it doesn't meet the standards of his nominees. Shaub suggested Trump should place all assets in a blind trust to avoid potential conflicts of interest. He praised Rex Tillerson's decision to put his retirement package into a trust, but noted Trump's plan is not a blind trust. The ethics office lacks enforcement power, but public outcry can make a difference, according to Norman Eisen.

site_title: Isoteam completes acquisition of Rong Shun Engineering
summary: ISOTEAM completed its acquisition of Rong Shun Engineering & Construction for S$3.68 million in cash. The company has submitted a request to transfer 3.9 million shares to the vendor, with 50% placed under a one-year moratorium. The acquisition marks ISOTEAM's expansion in the engineering and construction sector.

site_title: China pledges support for shipbuilding industry, targets high-end market
summary: China aims to capture 35-40% of the global high-end marine equipment market by 2020, supporting its struggling shipbuilding industry. The government plans to increase spending on research, improve branding, and attract private capital to boost production of high-end products such as offshore equipment. Following a 14% decline in new ship orders in the first 11 months of 2016, the industry is facing its most difficult challenge since the financial crisis. China's efforts aim to restructure and upgrade the industry, which has been hit by a severe global shipping downturn.

site_title: Indonesia says Freeport, other copper miners halt exports
summary: Indonesian mining ministry officials confirmed that Freeport-McMoRan and other copper miners have halted shipments of copper concentrates due to a government ban on unprocessed metal ore exports, which took effect on Thursday. The ban aims to increase processing of minerals in the country.

site_title: Jewellery, watch recovery helps Richemont return to growth
summary: Richemont, a luxury goods group, reported a 5% rise in sales in the quarter to December, beating forecasts with a 5% increase in sales at constant exchange rates. The improvement was driven by strong demand for jewellery and improved watch sales in its own stores, particularly in Asia Pacific, Europe, and the UK. Watch sales, which account for half of Richemont's revenue, started to decline in 2014 but showed signs of recovery. The company's shares were indicated 5% higher in pre-market trading.

site_title: Thai crackdown on budget tours hits Chinese New Year
summary: A crackdown on cheap package tours in Thailand has led to a significant decline in Chinese tourist bookings ahead of the Lunar New Year. Chinese hotel bookings for the holiday period have plummeted from 800 to just 300, with tourism operators citing the government's insistence on a minimum 1,000 baht per night charge as a major factor. Despite this, Thailand forecasts a 7.7% drop in Chinese tourists and expects a 3.9% rise in tourists from elsewhere, with a total tourist revenue growth of 8.5% to nearly $50 billion.

site_title: China should halt yuan intervention, preserve reserves: ex-PBOC adviser
summary: China's central bank should stop intervening in the foreign exchange market to help preserve foreign exchange reserves, according to Yu Yongding, a former PBOC adviser. He recommends setting a "bottom line" of 25% for the yuan to depreciate and abandoning intervention to avoid unnecessary depletion of reserves. This comes as the yuan has lost 6.5% against the US dollar in 2016, its biggest annual drop since 1994. Yu argues that intervention only encourages yuan-sellers and that abandoning intervention will reduce the need for capital controls.

images.alt_text: China's central bank should set a "bottom line" of 25 per cent for the yuan to depreciate, stop intervening to help preserve foreign exchange reserves, Yu Yongding, a former central bank adviser, was quoted as saying by financial magazine Caixin on Thursday.

site_title: Bee placed on endangered list after US habitat loss
summary: The US Fish and Wildlife Service has listed the rusty patched bumblebee as an endangered species due to a 87% decline in its population, primarily caused by habitat loss, disease, pesticides, and climate change. The bee's range has shrunk to 13 states and one province, down from 28 states in the 1990s. Its endangered status aims to prevent extinction and mobilize resources to address the decline. The listing is the first for a bee found in the continental US and follows a similar listing for bees in Hawaii last year.

site_title: Malaysia sees up to $23.5b of company capital raising in 2017
summary: Malaysia's Securities Commission forecasts that companies will raise 90-105 billion ringgit ($28.7-$33.5 billion) of capital in 2017, similar to the 100 billion ringgit raised in 2016. The majority of financing last year came from conventional bonds and sukuk markets.

site_title: Mapletree Investments launches perpetual, first SG$ bond sale in 2017
summary: Mapletree Investments, a 100% Temasek-owned firm, has launched its first Singapore dollar bond sale in 2017, offering perpetual bonds with an initial price guidance of 4.7% per annum. The bonds, known as NC5, have a 100 basis points step-up and reset from year 10. Orders have exceeded S$250 million as of the first update, marking the first perpetual bond issue in 2017.

site_title: Uniqlo operator profit jumps on bargain-shopper focus
summary: Uniqlo's parent company, Fast Retailing, reported a 45% jump in quarterly net profit to 70 billion yen (S$868.2 million) in the fiscal first quarter to November. Revenue edged up 1.6% to 529 billion yen. The company attributed the increase to a focus on attracting bargain shoppers, with same-store sales picking up after unseasonably warm weather in September and October. Fast Retailing left unchanged its annual forecast for a 100 billion yen net profit on revenue of 1.85 trillion yen.

images.alt_text: Uniqlo's parent company said Thursday that quarterly net profit jumped by almost half from a year ago, as it refocused on a strategy aimed at luring thrifty shoppers.

site_title: United Airlines to cut some management positions
summary: United Airlines plans to cut some management positions as part of its restructuring program. The move aims to match margins with Delta Air Lines, the airline's closest competitor. Frontline employees, including pilots, flight attendants, and customer-service agents, will not be affected. The airline expects lower profits due to cheap airfares and higher wages from new contracts. The company has not disclosed the exact number of management positions to be cut.

site_title: Hong Kong no 2 official resigns with eye on becoming next city leader: media
summary: Hong Kong's number two official Carrie Lam has resigned, paving the way for her potential run as the city's next chief executive in a March election. Lam, who has submitted her resignation, has not commented on the move. This step is seen as a significant development in her bid to succeed outgoing leader Leung Chun-ying. Lam's resignation comes ahead of the March election, where she will likely face competition from other candidates.

site_title: Xinhua sets up finance media group to boost influence, Sina says
summary: China's state-run Xinhua News Agency is setting up a finance media group to boost its influence in the financial information industry. The group, to be established on January 19, will consolidate resources from several publications, including China Securities Journal and Shanghai Securities News. The move aims to deepen the reform of the cultural system and improve mainstream media's impact on financial information. This is part of President Xi Jinping's efforts to ensure Chinese media serves the interests of the ruling Communist Party, following recent government efforts to tighten control over online and information industries.

site_title: China issues plans for state investments, speeding up disposals
summary: China's State Council issued guidelines to optimize state investments and reform state-owned enterprises amid an economic slowdown. The focus will be on national security, public welfare, strategic industries, infrastructure, and companies with "core competitive advantages." The guidelines aim to clear obstacles for reforming inefficient assets, promote securitization of government holdings, and accelerate their disposal. This move is part of China's efforts to shore up its bloated state-owned enterprises and address the country's economic slowdown.

site_title: Tesco caps year of recovery with solid Christmas trading
summary: Tesco, Britain's largest retailer, reported a 0.7% rise in underlying Christmas sales in its home market, marking a solid performance during the key festive period. The company has made significant progress in recovering from a decline in sales and profit due to the rise of discounters Aldi and Lidl. Tesco expects to deliver at least £1.2 billion of group operating profit before exceptional items for the full fiscal year, its first rise in profit following five years of decline. The company's shares have risen over 30% in the last year.

images.alt_text: Britain's biggest retailer Tesco reported a 0.7 per cent rise in underlying Christmas sales in its home market, capping a year of recovery with a solid performance over the key festive period.

site_title: Chinese phonemaker Xiaomi aims to exceed 100b yuan sales
summary: Xiaomi Corp, a Chinese technology startup, aims to exceed 100 billion yuan (S$20.7 billion) in sales for 2017. CEO Lei Jun plans to quadruple the company's store network to 200 outlets, expand globally, and deepen research into AI and online finance. Lei acknowledged the company's rapid growth in the past has led to over-expansion, and vowed to slow its pace and overhaul its retail strategy.

site_title: UK bandwidth provider Colt to expand network in Singapore, Hong Kong
summary: UK-based Colt is expanding its network in Singapore and Hong Kong, investing in high-bandwidth capacity and fibre infrastructure. The expansion, starting in April, aims to challenge the market and become the only provider with fully-owned fibre metro networks in key Asian cities and major European cities. This move is part of Colt's plan to invest significantly in Asia over the next three years.

site_title: Japan says its active investment is a source of US-Japan vitality
summary: Japan's Chief Cabinet Secretary Yoshihide Suga stated that the country's active trade investment in the US is a source of "vitality" in the economic relationship between the two nations. Suga also noted that Americans recognize Japanese firms as good corporate citizens in the US. Following US President-elect Donald Trump's comments on trade imbalances, Japan is analyzing his statements and seeking to further develop its economic relationship with the US.

site_title: China makes awkward free trade champion: experts
summary: China is set to proclaim itself the champion of free trade at the World Economic Forum in Davos, despite analysts saying its attitude is more selective. China has benefited greatly from globalization, but experts argue it cannot lead a global trade regime due to its own trade surpluses and the US's large deficits. China's restrictions on foreign companies and its use of trade as a tool to exert influence contradict its free trade stance. Analysts predict a return to protectionism and "beggar-thy-neighbour policies" if the US withdraws from global governance.

site_title: Asia: Most stocks up but Tokyo hit by Trump worries
summary: Asian markets rose on Thursday, with most stocks up, despite Tokyo's 0.9% decline due to Donald Trump's lack of economic detail at his first press conference. Trump's comments on drug companies and conflicts of interest also negatively impacted the pharma sector. Despite this, US markets ended on a high, providing a positive lead for Asia. Hong Kong, Shanghai, Sydney, and Seoul saw gains, while pharmaceutical firms took a hit, with Takeda and Astellas falling almost three and four percent, respectively.

site_title: Gold hits 7-week highs on weaker US dollar after Trump briefing
summary: Gold prices surged to a seven-week high on Thursday, reaching $1,196.06 per ounce, after US President-elect Donald Trump provided little clarity on future fiscal policies. The weaker US dollar contributed to the increase. US gold futures fell 0.2% to $1,193.70 per ounce. The rise in gold prices comes as Trump announces fresh tariffs on Canada and threatens others, keeping markets on edge.

site_title: Australian regulator to review BP purchase of Woolworths' petrol stations
summary: Australia's competition regulator will review BP's A$1.8 billion purchase of 527 petrol stations from Woolworths Ltd. The review was announced after Woolworths and BP announced the deal in January, stating it would not be completed before January 2018. The Australian Competition and Consumer Commission (ACCC) will examine the proposed acquisition, but no further details were provided. The outcome of the review will determine whether the deal can proceed.

site_title: Malaysia sees companies raising up to RM105b of capital in 2017
summary: Malaysian companies are expected to raise RM90-105 billion in capital in 2017, similar to the RM100 billion raised in 2016. This is largely due to the conventional bond and sukuk markets, accounting for a substantial portion of the financing in 2016. The Securities Commission forecasts a moderate increase in capital raising, in line with last year's levels.

images.alt_text: Malaysian companies are likely to raise RM90-105 billion (S$28.8-S$33.6 billion) of capital in 2017, roughly in line with last year, the head of the Securities Commission forecast on Thursday.

site_title: Singapore Budget 2017: More for innovation, new regional players and health among EY's wish list
summary: EY's wish list for Singapore Budget 2017 includes measures to encourage enterprise innovation, attract new regional players, and promote health and wellbeing. The firm cited a tough 2016 economy, with a resident long-term unemployment rate of 0.8%, as a reason for these recommendations. EY's head of tax services, Chung-Sim Siew Moon, emphasized the need to enable local enterprises to thrive through innovation and inject fresh regional players to boost growth sectors.

images.alt_text: More fiscal measures to encourage enterprise innovation, attract new regional players, sharpen enterprise support and sector competitiveness, as well as promote responsibility for health and wellbeing. These are the main themes surrounding Ernst & Young Solutions LLP's (EY) wish list for Singapore Budget 2017.
Angela Tan

site_title: Taiwan: Stocks hit over 18-month highs, TSMC up ahead of Q4 results
summary: Taiwan's stocks rose nearly 1% to their highest in 18 months, driven by a relief rally after US President-elect Donald Trump's news briefing yielded little clarity on his fiscal policies. TSMC, the world's largest contract chipmaker, rose 1.4% ahead of its Q4 results, boosting gains. The main Taiex index reached 9,417.55, its highest since June 2015, with the electronics subindex up 0.7% and the financials subindex up 0.5%.

site_title: Rail reliability up 30% in 2016
summary: Singapore's rail network saw a 30% improvement in reliability in 2016, with the Downtown Line being the best performer. The mean kilometre between failure (MKBF) rose to 174,000 train-km from 2015's 133,000 train-km. This achievement meets Transport Minister Khaw Boon Wan's challenge of reducing MKBF to 400,000 train-km by 2018 for incidents resulting in service delays of over five minutes. Increased investments and intensified maintenance regimes are credited for the improvement.

site_title: Hot stock: GLP surges on renewed takeover speculation
summary: Global Logistic Properties (GLP) shares surged 3.19% on Thursday following a Bloomberg report that Warburg Pincus is forming a group to bid for the Singapore logistics provider. The report states that Warburg Pincus has been speaking with banks and potential bidding partners about an offer for GLP, which has assets in China, Japan, the US, and Brazil. GLP's market value is approximately US$8.5 billion, and the company has asked for first-round offers by early February.

site_title: Seoul: Won firms to 1-month high as US dollar dips, stocks edge up
summary: The South Korean won reached a one-month high against the US dollar after US President-elect Donald Trump's news conference failed to provide details on his fiscal policy plans, leading to a decline in the dollar. The won strengthened to 1,182.5, up 1.2% from the previous day, while South Korean shares edged up 0.2% and the Kospi index reached 2,080.24 points.

site_title: Edelweiss said to seek to wind up Bharati Defence under new law
summary: Edelweiss Asset Reconstruction Co, India's largest bad loan buyer, plans to wind up Bharati Defence & Infrastructure Ltd under the country's new bankruptcy law. Bharati Defence has outstanding debt of about 90 billion rupees, of which Edelweiss holds 85%. Edelweiss aims to file a petition in about a month to restructure the company and recover loans without seeking approval from other lenders. This move could help Edelweiss recover a significant portion of its 85% stake in Bharati Defence.

site_title: EMS Energy says hearing of applications fixed
summary: EMS Energy has fixed the hearing of applications for a special half-day hearing on January 25 at 10 am. The hearing is related to the termination of a contract with Shanghai Shipyard Co and applications by EMS Energy, Koastal Industries, and EMS Energy Solutions to convene a meeting of creditors to consider and approve schemes of arrangement. The applicants had initially sought a three-week adjournment due to ongoing discussions with Shanghai Shipyard Co.

site_title: Something 'fishy' going on at LA sushi restaurants: study
summary: A four-year study by UCLA and Loyola Marymount University found that nearly half of the fish served at 26 highly-rated sushi restaurants in Los Angeles is mislabeled. DNA tests revealed that 47% of 364 samples showed the fish was not what it was claimed to be. Common mislabelings included halibut being substituted for cheaper flounder and red snapper being replaced with sea bream. The study warns that mislabeling poses a health risk, particularly for people with allergies and pregnant women and children. Experts suspect intentional mislabeling in some cases, but it's difficult to pinpoint the source.

site_title: China detains 720, imposes US$21.8m of fines in pollution crackdown: media
summary: China detained 720 people and imposed US$21.8 million in fines for environmental protection law violations in 2016, as part of its "war on pollution" effort. This includes 10,184 cases of pollution fines, with over 10,000 vehicles punished for excessive exhaust emissions. Beijing rejected 11 projects worth 97 billion yuan due to environmental concerns and filed 13,127 environmental protection cases. The crackdown comes as China faces severe pollution alerts, forcing people to stay indoors, and is expected to slow its GDP growth, putting pressure on policymakers.

site_title: China turns to robots as workers age
summary: China is turning to robots to address its ageing workforce, as the country's shrinking working-age population poses a significant challenge to its economy. The robotics industry is expected to grow, with China accounting for 40% of the global industrial robot market by 2019. Companies like Hikvision and Midea are investing in robotics research and developing mechanical solutions, such as robotic parking systems, to reduce driver stress and increase efficiency. However, the high cost and technical challenges of robots mean it will be a long time before they become part of everyday life.

site_title: Australia's Tigerair blames Indonesia for Bali flight chaos
summary: Tigerair Australia blamed Indonesia for a chaotic situation in Bali, where hundreds of passengers were stranded due to a bureaucratic technicality. The airline accused Indonesian authorities of failing to honour an agreement allowing it to operate flights between Australia and Bali. Tigerair cancelled flights and Virgin Australia operated two flights to bring back stranded customers. The airline claims Indonesia changed the agency overseeing its operations, resulting in stricter sales requirements, which Tigerair did not meet. The airline is seeking a grace period to continue flying while working through the new requirements.

site_title: Australia shares up on rally in oil; NZ down
summary: Australia's S&P/ASX 200 index rose 0.3% to 5,791, driven by a rally in oil prices, which jumped 2.5% after the US dollar fell on Donald Trump's media conference. Key gains were seen in materials, energy, and financials, with Woodside Petroleum and Santos Ltd up 1.5% and 1.2% respectively. In contrast, New Zealand's S&P/NZX 50 index declined 0.3% to 7,069, with the healthcare sector experiencing a decline after Trump's comments on pharmaceutical prices.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open lower
summary: Tokyo stocks opened lower on Thursday, with the Nikkei 225 index falling 0.49% and the Topix index down 0.34%. The yen strengthened against the US dollar following US President-elect Donald Trump's lack of details on stimulus plans. The move was seen as a positive sign for the yen, which had been under pressure due to uncertainty over Trump's economic policies.

site_title: Australia, NZ dollars near 1-month peak as Trump stays mum on fiscal plans
summary: The Australian and New Zealand dollars reached near one-month highs as the US dollar fell after President-elect Donald Trump failed to provide details on his economic policy agenda. The Australian dollar rose 0.97% to US$0.7471, its largest single-day gain since September 6, while the New Zealand dollar rose 0.55% to US$0.7088. The lack of detail on Trump's stimulus plan and his criticism of pharmaceutical companies and intelligence agencies triggered volatile moves across asset classes. The Aussie and New Zealand dollars are expected to continue to benefit from USD weakness.

site_title: China Vanke shares suspended from trade in Hong Kong
summary: China Vanke shares were suspended from trade in Hong Kong on Thursday due to a corporate power struggle with its biggest shareholder Baoneng financial conglomerate. The company has also faced increased competition from rival Evergrande Group. The suspension is the latest development in a rare corporate power struggle in China.

site_title: Brooklyn home sales soar as buyers flee hyped Manhattan prices
summary: Home buyers in Brooklyn saw a surge in sales, with purchases rising 22% to 2,582 and median prices climbing 15% to $750,000 in the fourth quarter. This growth is attributed to a record-low number of listings, down 31% to 2,232, as buyers flee to Brooklyn due to high Manhattan prices. In contrast, Manhattan's median home price dropped 8.7% to $1.05 million due to a rising supply and sellers becoming more realistic. Brooklyn's lower prices and increased affordability are drawing buyers away from Manhattan.

site_title: See Kee Oon, Chua Lee Ming appointed as Judges of the High Court
summary: Singaporean judges See Kee Oon and Chua Lee Ming have been appointed as Judges of the High Court, effective January 31. Both are currently Judicial Commissioners of the Supreme Court, with See holding the position of Presiding Judge of the State Courts since 2013. Chua started his judicial career in 1984 and was appointed Judicial Commissioner in 2015. The appointments bring the total number of Supreme Court judges to 16, including four Judges of Appeal and the Chief Justice.

images.alt_text: Judicial Commissioners Chua Lee Ming (left) and See Kee Oon have been appointed as judges of the High Court from the effect on Jan 31.

site_title: Globalisation 'easy scapegoat' for global angst: World Economic Forum chief
summary: Klaus Schwab, founder and executive chairman of the World Economic Forum, has stated that globalisation is an "easy scapegoat" for global angst, amid rising anti-establishment populism. Schwab attributes dramatic shifts in societies to rapid changes in technology, economies, and social structures, rather than solely blaming globalisation. He warns of the dangers of growing isolationism, which could lead to a world based on shared interests alone, rather than shared values. Schwab believes that global cooperation is crucial to address the root causes of global turmoil, and that the Davos forum provides a platform for cooperation across politics, business, and civil society.

site_title: Mexican drivers flood to California for 'gasolinazo' relief
summary: Mexican drivers are flocking to southern California to fill up on gasoline after protests blocking fuel distribution centers near the Mexican border caused stations to run dry. The 20% fuel price hike, known as a "gasolinazo," has led to widespread shortages, prompting drivers to wait four to five hours to cross the border and fill up. As Mexico opens its fuel market to foreign competitors, the government's decision has resulted in chaotic scenes at gas stations in Calexico, with employees reporting a surge in customers.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks open down after win streak
summary: Hong Kong stocks fell on Thursday after a five-day winning streak, dipping 0.18% to 22,895.04. Investors were spooked by a lack of policy detail in Donald Trump's first news conference. The Shanghai Composite Index eased 0.10% and the Shenzhen Composite Index declined 0.09%. The decline comes despite a strong rally in Singapore stocks, which notched a 5-day gain ahead of GDP data.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index opened higher on Thursday, up 0.42 points to 1,675.630. The index saw 55.9 million lots traded worth RM18.8 million, with 130 gainers and 30 losers. The rally follows a global trend, with Asian stocks extending their gains despite US President Trump's new threats. The index has been on a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data release.

site_title: US state secretary nominee: China should be denied access to South China Sea islands
summary: US Secretary of State nominee Rex Tillerson warned China to stop building islands in the South China Sea and to not be allowed access to them, comparing it to Russia's annexation of Crimea. He also reaffirmed the US commitment to Taiwan and criticized China's South China Sea activity as "extremely worrisome" and a threat to global economics. Tillerson called China's actions "illegal" and said the US would consider actions to compel China to comply with UN sanctions on North Korea.

site_title: India solar prices set to drop amid competition, lower costs
summary: India's solar power prices are expected to drop below last year's record lows, driven by plummeting panel prices and falling interest rates. Prices could fall as low as 4 rupees a kilowatt-hour, making solar energy more viable, according to Rahul Munjal, chairman of Hero Future Energies Pvt. The drop in prices is attributed to intense competition among developers seeking a share of India's renewables market. This could lead to increased adoption of solar energy and reduced reliance on fossil fuels.

site_title: US deploys high-tech radar amid heightened North Korea rhetoric: official
summary: The US has deployed a high-tech sea-based radar, the Sea-based X-band radar (SBX), to monitor North Korea's potential intercontinental ballistic missile test launches. The radar, which can track ICBMs and differentiate between hostile and non-threatening missiles, left Hawaii and is expected to reach its destination in the northwest of Hawaii by the end of January. US Defense Secretary Ash Carter stated that the US may gather intelligence from non-threatening missile launches rather than intercepting them, as it may be more advantageous to save interceptor inventory and gather information.

site_title: Roland Ng is SCCCI's 59th president
summary: Roland Ng has been elected as the 59th president of the Singapore Chinese Chamber of Commerce & Industry (SCCCI), a position he will hold for the next two years. Nine senior council members, including immediate past president Teo Siong Seng and vice-president Lau Tai San, have stepped down. The SCCCI has stated that it is a tradition to constantly renew itself to keep up with the times.

images.alt_text: Roland Ng has been elected as president of the Singapore Chinese Chamber of Commerce & Industry (SCCCI).

site_title: Singapore shares open flat on Thursday
summary: Singapore shares opened flat on Thursday, with the Straits Times Index (STI) up 13.88 points or 0.46% to 3,014.82, following gains in Europe and the US. Around 49 million shares changed hands, with gainers beating losers 75 to 35. This comes as investors remain positive despite tariff uncertainty and split Fed views.

site_title: US dollar hits 1-month low vs key rivals after Trump news conference
summary: The US dollar fell to a one-month low against key rivals, including the euro, yen, and sterling, after President-elect Donald Trump's news conference disappointed investors expecting a pro-growth message. Trump attacked US intelligence agencies and denied compromising positions in Russia, sparking market disappointment and a decline in the US dollar index. The euro rose 0.6% against the dollar, while sterling rallied 0.8% after the conference, as investors reassessed their expectations for Trump's economic policy agenda.

site_title: Airbus deliveries rose 8%, orders outpaced Boeing in 2016
summary: Airbus posted an 8% rise in deliveries to 688 aircraft in 2016, beating forecasts and setting a company record, while outpacing Boeing in orders. Airbus delivered 731 net orders, including 98 to Iran, and expects over 700 deliveries in 2017. However, industry analysts warn of a slowdown due to weakening economies and low oil prices. Despite this, Airbus Chief Operating Officer Fabrice Bregier expects deliveries to continue rising for several years as planemakers work through record waiting lists.

site_title: Woody Harrelson joins 'Stars Wars' galaxy
summary: Woody Harrelson joins the cast of the upcoming "Star Wars" anthology film, playing a mentor to young Han Solo, opposite Alden Ehrenreich, Donald Glover, and Emilia Clarke. The film, set before the events of the first "Star Wars" movie, is the second in a series of standalone films. Directors Phil Lord and Christopher Miller expressed excitement to work with Harrelson, praising his unique ability to find humor and pathos in his roles. The film is set for release next year.

images.alt_text: Actor Woody Harrelson will be heading to a galaxy far, far away for his next movie, playing a role in the second anthology "Star Wars" film focused on a young Han Solo.

site_title: US must signal China's access to artificial islands in South China Sea will be denied: Tillerson
summary: US Secretary of State nominee Rex Tillerson stated that the US must send a clear signal to China that its island-building in the South China Sea must stop and that access to those islands will not be allowed. He likened China's actions to Russia's annexation of Crimea, describing them as "illegal actions." Tillerson also emphasized the importance of reaffirming the US commitment to Taiwan and expressed concern over China's economic and military activities in the region. He warned that China's actions could pose a threat to the global economy if left unchecked.

site_title: Stocks to watch: GLP, ISDN Holdings
summary: GLP extended 3.6 million sq ft of leases in the US and signed long-term lease extensions with a global appliance company. ISDN Holdings increased its share count to 394.7 million after allotting and issuing 40 million offer shares at HK$1.25 apiece. The offer shares are expected to be listed on the Singapore Exchange on Thursday.

site_title: South Korea economy likely grew 2.7% in 2016, Trump uncertainty looms
summary: South Korea's economy likely grew 2.7% in 2016, exceeding the government's initial estimate of 2.6%. The growth was largely driven by exports. Finance Minister Yoo Il-Ho attributed the stronger growth to reduced uncertainty from abroad, particularly with the US presidential transition. However, Yoo expressed concerns about the impact of a potential "America first" stance under the Trump administration, which could affect free trade agreements. The economy remains resilient despite the impeachment of President Park Geun-Hye and a plunge in consumer confidence.

images.alt_text: South Korea's export-led economy likely grew by 2.7 per cent in 2016, slightly above the latest government estimate, and felt little impact from the impeachment of its president, the nation's finance minister told Reuters in an interview on Wednesday.

site_title: Samsung heir quizzed as suspect in Park scandal
summary: Samsung heir Lee Jae-Yong was questioned by South Korean prosecutors as a suspect in the Park scandal, becoming the first member of the royal family to be implicated. He is accused of bribery, perjury, and coercion in connection to Samsung's alleged payment to Choi Soon-Sil, a secret confidante of impeached President Park Geun-Hye. The investigation centers on a 2015 merger that Samsung sought to win state approval for, with prosecutors claiming the company bribed Choi to curry favor. Lee's lawyer expressed regret for any concern caused, but the likelihood of a court warrant for his arrest remains high.

images.alt_text: Samsung heir Lee Jae-Yong was grilled by South Korean prosecutors Thursday after becoming a criminal suspect in the corruption scandal engulfing impeached President Park Geun-Hye.

site_title: Buddy Greco, the ultimate lounge singer, dies at 90
summary: Buddy Greco, a renowned lounge singer and pianist, died at 90 on January 10 in Las Vegas. Greco was known for his 80-year career, which spanned jazz, Las Vegas shows, and friendships with Frank Sinatra and the Rat Pack. He was an oft-married ladies' man and had a hot temper, but his talent and tenacity earned him a lasting place in entertainment history. No cause of death was disclosed. Greco's son confirmed the news to the Desert Sun newspaper.

site_title: Trump news conference sets worldwide social media afire
summary: US President-elect Donald Trump held a news conference, sparking widespread social media reaction with harsh criticism of the press and defense of ties with Russia. Trump accused a CNN reporter of peddling "fake news" and refused to answer questions, saying "You are fake news!" The session generated viral moments, including a Twitter reaction to the CNN reporter's exchange.

site_title: Onex explores US$4b sale of USI Insurance Services -sources
summary: Private equity firm Onex Corp is exploring the sale of USI Insurance Services, valuing it at up to $4 billion, including debt. The sale would mark a consolidation in the commercial property and casualty insurance market, where smaller brokerages struggle to grow. Onex is working with Bank of America Corp on an auction for USI, with no deal currently certain. This sale follows a wave of consolidation in the industry, as buyout firms seek to cut costs.

site_title: Europe: Pharma weighs on shares but FTSE sets record-breaking streak
summary: European shares ended the day with a slight 0.2% gain, setting a record-breaking streak for the FTSE 100 for the 12th consecutive session. Despite pharma stocks falling 0.7% due to concerns over US pricing pressure, healthcare stocks were partially offset by gains from retail stocks like Sainsbury's, which rose 1% after beating forecasts. Mining and healthcare sectors also supported shares.

site_title: Trump, rising populism threaten to slow climate action, analyst says
summary: US President-elect Donald Trump's policies threaten to slow climate action, according to a sustainability expert. Trump plans to scrap environmental regulations, which could lead to the US pulling out of the Paris Agreement on climate change. However, the global trend is shifting towards climate action, with countries like China and emerging markets investing heavily in renewable energy. Climate experts predict that US environmental groups will take the government to court to safeguard climate policies, and that the world may see a surge in renewable energy, with the coal industry declining globally.

site_title: As they go electric, auto giants vie for tiny US prize
summary: The US auto industry is racing to capture a minuscule market for electric vehicles, with over 20 new models expected on showroom floors in 2017. Despite high interest worldwide, US consumers are slow to adopt, with only 2.8% of cars sold being electric in 2016. Manufacturers are investing billions in battery technologies and marketing electric vehicles at lower prices, with models like Tesla's Model 3 and Chevrolet Bolt EV gaining attention. However, experts warn that the market may remain small, and the industry's efforts may be driven more by government regulations than consumer demand.

site_title: Highlights of President-elect Trump's first press conference
summary: President-elect Donald Trump held his first press conference, addressing various allegations and controversies surrounding his campaign and presidency. He denied claims of close ties with Russia, dismissing a dossier as "fake news" and "phony stuff." Trump also revealed plans to transfer control of his real estate business to his sons, Don Jr. and Eric, but faced criticism from the Office of Government Ethics for not fully divesting from the company. Trump reiterated his pledge to build a border wall, create jobs, and combat pharmaceutical price gouging, and announced his choice for the Veterans Administration head.

site_title: Alibaba considers European logistics centre in Bulgaria: government
summary: Alibaba is considering setting up a European logistics centre in Bulgaria, according to the Bulgarian government. Representatives from Alibaba, GS-Solar Company, and GoldPoly Group met with Bulgarian Prime Minister Boyko Borisov to explore investment opportunities. No immediate comment was available from Alibaba. This move could mark Alibaba's entry into the European logistics market, although the company has not confirmed any plans.

site_title: Oil rises by most in over a month on weak US dollar after Trump conference
summary: US President-elect Donald Trump's remarks led to a sharp decline in the US dollar, causing oil prices to surge 2.5% as Brent futures rose $1.46 to $55.10 per barrel and US West Texas Intermediate crude gained $1.43 to $52.25 per barrel, their largest daily gains in over a month. This rebound occurred despite a larger-than-expected weekly build in US crude and fuel inventories. Saudi Arabia also announced a slight reduction in crude supplies to Asia.

site_title: GLP renews 3.6m sq ft of leases with US customer
summary: GLP, a mainboard-listed logistics company, has extended 3.6 million sq ft of leases with a US customer at three facilities in Columbus, Ohio, Atlanta, Georgia, and Orlando, Florida. The leases are long-term and offer flexibility to accommodate the customer's growth. The US facilities are strategically located near key distribution channels and transportation networks, enhancing intermodal transportation options. GLP's US portfolio now comprises 173 million sq ft of modern logistics facilities, solidifying its position as the largest provider of modern logistics facilities in China, Japan, and Brazil.

site_title: Italian PM says he's well after surgery on blood vessel
summary: Italian Prime Minister Paolo Gentiloni underwent emergency surgery on a blocked blood vessel and is feeling well, according to a tweet from the premier. The surgery was successful, and he is expected to remain in the hospital for a few days. Gentiloni was taken to the hospital after complaining of discomfort on his return to Rome from a Paris visit. He had planned to meet with French President Francois Hollande and later meet with Palestinian President Mahmoud Abbas in Rome, but the trip has been postponed. Gentiloni is expected to return to work soon.

site_title: Discontent in Malay heartland may spell trouble for PM Najib
summary: Malaysia's Prime Minister Najib Razak faces potential trouble in the Malay heartland of Sungkai, where Felda settlers, a key vote bank for his ruling coalition, are growing discontent over the national palm plantation operator's purchase of a 37% stake in Indonesian palm oil firm PT Eagle High Plantations. The deal, valued at US$505 million, has sparked concerns about Felda's debts and potential financial burden on the settlers. With elections expected by 2018, opposition lawmakers are capitalizing on the issue, and Felda settlers are estimated to be leaning towards the opposition party if the deal goes through.

images.alt_text: The Malaysian plantation district of Sungkai has become an initial - and unlikely - battleground for an election that embattled Prime Minister Najib Razak is expected to call this year.

site_title: US companies have new business risk - being labelled 'anti-American' by Trump
summary: US companies are reviewing business strategies due to concerns of being labeled 'anti-American' by President-elect Donald Trump. Following public rebukes of major companies like General Motors, Lockheed Martin, and United Technologies, others are worried about being Trump's next target, particularly those with significant overseas manufacturing, US job cuts, or price increases for consumers. This has led to potential mergers, job cuts, and reevaluation of manufacturing operations in China.

site_title: Volkswagen pleads guilty to US criminal charges, pays US$4.3b in 'dieselgate'
summary: Volkswagen AG has pleaded guilty to US criminal charges related to the "dieselgate" emissions scandal, agreeing to pay a total of $4.3 billion in fines. The company faces three criminal charges and will pay $2.8 billion in criminal fines and $1.5 billion in civil fines. Six executives, including five in Germany, are believed to be responsible for the conspiracy. The settlement also requires Volkswagen to employ an independent corporate compliance monitor for three years and cooperate with US and German authorities on ongoing prosecutions.

site_title: EU privacy proposal may dent web companies' ad revenue
summary: The European Union proposes new rules requiring online messaging services to obtain users' consent before tracking them online to target with personalized ads, potentially hurting web companies reliant on advertising. The proposal, which must be approved by the European Parliament and member states, would also require web browsers to ask users for permission to place cookies. Companies found in non-compliance could face fines of up to 4% of their global turnover.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Singtel launched Singapore's fastest mobile network with a 450 Mbps 4G LTE-Advanced service, delivering up to 50% faster download speeds than prevailing LTE services. Metro Holdings appointed Yip Hoong Mun as group COO and CEO of Metro China Holdings. Halcyon Agri Corp appointed Liu Hongsheng as non-executive chairman. ISDN Holdings received robust demand for its public tranche of shares.

site_title: Handbag makers cut back on designs
summary: Handbag makers have reduced the number of designs introduced last quarter due to waning demand and markdowns at stores, according to Edited. Luxury brands such as Michael Kors, Prada, and Louis Vuitton have cut back on styles, which may hinder their ability to recapture shopper excitement. Industry expert Milton Pedraza warns that the lack of innovation will make it challenging for the industry to recover.

site_title: Big Four law firms dominate in 2017 Chambers Asia-Pacific guide
summary: The Big Four law firms, including Allen & Gledhill, dominated the 2017 Chambers Asia-Pacific guide, with Allen & Gledhill securing the most Band 1 rankings and 48 lawyers ranked. This solidified their position as the top firms in Singapore. The rankings reflect the firms' expertise in various practice areas.

site_title: US Secretary of State at odds with Trump on trade pact
summary: US Secretary of State-designate Rex Tillerson said he does not oppose the Trans-Pacific Partnership (TPP) free-trade deal, contradicting President-elect Donald Trump's vow to scrap it. Tillerson stated that he shares some of Trump's views on the agreement, but does not oppose it, during his confirmation hearing. This breaks with Trump's campaign promise to withdraw from the TPP on his first day in office, which Japan had ratified in December. The TPP encompasses 40% of the global economy and includes the US, Japan, and other nations.

images.alt_text: Donald Trump's choice for Secretary of State Rex Tillerson said Wednesday he is not against the recently negotiated Asia-Pacific free-trade deal, putting him at odds with the president-elect who has vowed to scrap it.

site_title: Personal computer sales fall for fifth year in a row
summary: Personal computer sales declined for the fifth consecutive year, with 269.7 million units shipped in 2016, a 6.2% drop from the previous year. Market trackers Gartner and IDC attributed the decline to stagnant technology improvements and changing consumer behavior, with people opting to use smartphones instead of replacing traditional computers. However, analysts saw potential for growth in the business and gaming sectors, and noted that the market may be stabilizing as pressure from smartphones and tablets eases. China-based Lenovo remained the leading PC manufacturer, followed by US firms HP and Dell.

images.alt_text: Sales of desk and laptop computers declined last year, extending a slide started in 2012, according to figures released on Wednesday by two market trackers.

site_title: Beijing to crack down on low-grade steel
summary: China plans to eliminate the production of low-grade steel by the end of June, as part of its efforts to tackle smog. The steel, produced in small furnaces using recycled material, is a major pollution and safety hazard. Despite being banned, 63 firms in Jiangsu province were still producing the steel, with a total annual capacity of 12.33 million tonnes. This move is part of China's war on pollution and industrial overcapacity.

site_title: Envisioning the Future Academy
summary: The article discusses the need for the education sector to adapt to the digital natives of today and incorporate new tools and techniques to enhance learning. It suggests that online learning, virtual reality (VR), and augmented reality (AR) can provide students with real-world environments and flexible learning opportunities. The author also emphasizes the importance of design thinking and pedagogy in teaching, highlighting the need for educators to integrate theory into practice and empower students to become active thinkers and problem solvers. The article concludes that the future of education is within grasp, but requires the combined efforts of private institutions and public universities to realize it.

site_title: US: Stocks gain despite Trump hit to pharmaceuticals
summary: US stocks rose despite a hit to pharmaceuticals after President-elect Donald Trump criticized the industry for offshoring production capacity and overcharging for drugs. Pharmaceutical shares fell 2-4% as Pfizer, Celgene, and Mylan plummeted, but energy shares gained 0.5-0.2% and tech stocks rose 0.3-0.2%. The Dow Jones Industrial Average and S&P 500 reached new records, while Merck's treatment for metastatic lung cancer was accepted for review by the FDA. Despite Trump's criticism, investors remain bullish on the new administration's plans, with the market expecting swift action.

site_title: Analyst who foresaw yen fall expects more losses ahead
summary: A strategist at NatWest Markets predicts the yen will slump to 125 against the dollar in 2017, with little chance of a sustained gain past 115, due to the Federal Reserve's policy tightening and the Bank of Japan's loose monetary policy. This forecast contradicts previous estimates, and hedge funds remain pessimistic on the yen, with net-short positions near the highest since August 2015. The yen's decline is expected to continue, with the currency potentially reaching levels last seen in mid-2015.

site_title: China's President Xi to promote globalisation at WEF in Davos
summary: China's President Xi Jinping will promote "inclusive globalisation" at the World Economic Forum (WEF) in Davos, warning that populist approaches can lead to "war and poverty". This comes amid a surge in public hostility towards globalisation and the rise of US President-elect Donald Trump, who will be sworn in on January 20. Xi's message is expected to be a counterbalance to Trump's tough talk on trade, including promises of tariffs against China and Mexico. The event will take place from January 17-20.

site_title: US$1b Star Wars museum finds Los Angeles home
summary: George Lucas has settled on Los Angeles as the home for his US$1 billion storytelling museum, after pulling the project from Chicago last year. The Lucas Museum of Narrative Art will be located in Exposition Park in downtown Los Angeles, according to Los Angeles Mayor Eric Garcetti. The museum will feature exhibitions of Lucas's collection of Star Wars artwork and will be funded by Lucas himself. Lucas sold his Star Wars franchise to Disney in 2012 for US$4 billion, and the museum's board of directors believes the site in Exposition Park will have the greatest impact on the community.

site_title: Ma's million US jobs pledge more PR than substance, say analysts
summary: Chinese e-commerce giant Alibaba's pledge to create one million US jobs has been met with skepticism by analysts, who say the move is more about generating PR than substance. The promise was made by Alibaba founder Jack Ma during a meeting with US President-elect Donald Trump, amid concerns over counterfeits and the company's image. While Alibaba aims to boost international sales and imports of US merchandise, experts believe the impact on US jobs will be minimal, representing less than 1% of all jobs in the country.

site_title: Even Trump building isn't immune to India's real estate woes
summary: India's real estate market is experiencing a downturn, with a significant decline in home sales since the government's demonetisation in November. Property prices are also falling, with Meher Verma's Mumbai apartment being reduced by 10% in an effort to sell. The market slump has led to a decrease in demand, with some buyers, like Verma, considering cutting prices or waiting for the market to improve. The rate of home sales has fallen by about half since the demonetisation, indicating a severe impact on the Indian real estate sector.

site_title: Timing of Republicans' about-face on budget deficits harmful
summary: US Republicans' stance on budget deficits has shifted significantly, with prominent politicians like Paul Ryan now embracing large deficits despite previous warnings of a Greek-style crisis. This about-face comes as the economy nears full employment, where government borrowing can no longer provide a significant economic boost due to competing with private investment. Instead, Republicans plan to blow up the deficit mainly by cutting taxes on the wealthy, which will reduce long-term economic growth and exacerbate income inequality.

site_title: Falcon Bank's ex-branch manager jailed 28 weeks, fined S$128,000
summary: Jens Sturzenegger, a former Singapore branch manager of Falcon Bank, was sentenced to 28 weeks in jail and fined S$128,000 for his role in the 1MDB scandal. Sturzenegger pleaded guilty to six charges related to the movement of funds totaling US$1.3 billion. The court considered mitigating factors, but also noted that Sturzenegger's lies wasted public resources and rendered investigations incomplete. This case is part of Singapore's ongoing money laundering probe into tainted 1MDB funds.

site_title: SFA changes to make it easier for MAS to prosecute market misconduct
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has introduced changes to the Securities and Futures Act (SFA) to make it easier to prosecute market misconduct and insider trading cases. The amendments, which came into effect on Monday, clarify that a false or misleading disclosure can be considered under the SFA even if it didn't affect the company's share price. The changes aim to reduce the burden of proof and provide a more effective framework for enforcing market governance and insider trading laws.

site_title: Carmakers rework plans to bet more on SUVs
summary: Global carmakers are shifting their product strategies to prioritize SUVs and trucks, with forecasts suggesting they could make up two-thirds of US light vehicle sales. Executives from Toyota, General Motors, and Volkswagen are adding more SUVs to their product plans, with profit margins on SUVs and trucks being fatter. The shift has forced carmakers to slash production capacity for small cars and design vehicles that can quickly switch between building cars and SUVs. Luxury brands like BMW and Lexus are also seeing a rise in SUV sales, with some predicting a 50-50 split between SUVs and cars in the US market.

site_title: Refugee decline bolsters Merkel ahead of election campaign
summary: Germany's influx of asylum seekers declined by about two-thirds in 2016, from 890,000 to 280,000, according to Interior Minister Thomas de Maiziere. This drop may help Chancellor Angela Merkel's re-election campaign, as she had promised to reduce arrivals. Merkel's Christian Democratic-led bloc saw a poll boost, climbing to 38% in a January survey, while the Social Democrats, her junior coalition partner, remained at 22%. The decline in asylum seekers also reduces pressure on Merkel to implement a migration cap, as her Bavarian allies in the Christian Social Union had demanded.

site_title: Trump to cede 'complete' control of business to sons
summary: Donald Trump has formally handed "complete and total" control of his business empire to his adult sons, Don Jr and Eric, to avoid conflicts of interest as he enters the White House. The move comes amid accusations of conflict of interest since his electoral defeat. The Trump Organisation, which spans 20 countries, is not listed on the stock market and releases no public statistics. This transfer of control is intended to ensure Trump's sons will manage the business, reducing potential conflicts of interest.

site_title: New year but similar challenges for SIA
summary: Singapore Airlines (SIA) is facing similar challenges in the new year, with declining yields and passenger loads continuing to pressure the airline. Yields have declined 10% and 15% from two and four years ago, respectively, and passenger loads are expected to dip 0.6 percentage points to 79% for FY17. The airline is trying to combat this by rolling out premium economy cabins and new Business Class and Suite products on its A380s, while also leveraging fuel-efficient aircraft to attract premium passengers.

site_title: GM's 2017 profit forecast exceeds analysts'
summary: General Motors (GM) has exceeded analysts' profit forecast for 2017, predicting a net income of $6 to $6.50 per share. CEO Mary Barra attributed the guidance to growth in the US and China, as well as the company's efforts to introduce new models and trim costs. The stock rose 3.7% following the announcement. GM also announced plans to buy back an additional $5 billion in shares and lifted its credit rating to "BBB" by Standard & Poor's.

site_title: Snapchat picks London as global base outside US
summary: Snap Inc, the parent company of Snapchat, has chosen London as its global base outside the US, praising the UK's creative industries. This move comes after major investments from Facebook, Google, and Apple in London, solidifying the city's status as a technology hub. Britain's exit from the European Union also contributed to London's appeal. The decision is seen as a strategic shift for Snapchat, aligning with the growing tech presence in the UK.

site_title: Death of Sarawak chief minister throws up election uncertainties
summary: Malaysia's Prime Minister Najib Razak faces uncertainties after the sudden death of Sarawak chief minister Adenan Satem, who died of a heart attack. Adenan's successor, Abang Johari, is likely to be the new chief minister, but his ability to consolidate power and maintain state politics on an even keel is uncertain. This could affect the ruling coalition's chances in the upcoming polls, which Najib may consider holding this year. The state's popularity for the coalition is expected to be a significant factor, and Najib may rethink snap polls given the situation.

site_title: Singapore sets new record in ship fuel trade
summary: Singapore has set a new world record for bunker sales volume, with 48.6 million tonnes traded at its port in 2016, a 7.7% increase from the previous year. Despite global headwinds and excess capacity, the port's container throughput remained steady at 30.9 million TEU. Analysts attribute the surge in bunker sales to lower oil prices, which encouraged ship-owners to buy more fuel. The port faces challenges in 2017 with soaring oil prices and the introduction of a mass-flow-meter mandate, but has also benefited from increased cargo volumes from South Korea and Malaysia.

site_title: Jumbo sizzles in Wednesday trade
summary: Jumbo, a Singapore food and beverage chain, experienced a significant jump in its stock price on Wednesday, rising over 6% to a high of S$0.75. The stock opened at S$0.705 and traded over 40.3 million shares. The company's 30th anniversary is set to be celebrated this year, and it plans to launch a year-long series of events. Jumbo also announced its first franchise agreement in Vietnam, with plans to open three outlets within two years.

site_title: Fair, inclusive politics can contain globalisation fallout
summary: UK Prime Minister Theresa May is celebrating her six-month anniversary in office, with her premiership likely defined by Brexit. May has indicated a preference for a "harder exit" from the EU, aiming to trigger Article 50 by end-March. A "Great Repeal Bill" will be introduced to scrap the 1972 European Communities Act and translate EU regulations into domestic law. However, non-Brexit issues such as pensions reform, housing crisis, and infrastructure development may be more critical to her success, as she inherited contentious policy decisions upon taking office.

images.alt_text: Mrs May noted on Monday that meeting tough-to-solve, first order challenges is a significant hurdle that democratic institutions and politicians must do better in.

site_title: US charges three former traders in forex rigging probe
summary: The US Justice Department charged three former traders, Richard Usher, Rohan Ramchandani, and Christopher Ashton, for conspiring to manipulate foreign exchange rates at major banks. The traders, who worked at JPMorgan Chase, Citigroup, and Barclays, allegedly schemed to suppress competition from 2007 to 2013. This case follows previous guilty pleas by JPMorgan, Barclays, and Citigroup, resulting in over $10 billion in fines. Usher and Ramchandani were fined $5 million each, while Ashton was banned from working in the US banking industry.

site_title: SMF submits Budget recommendations
summary: The Singapore Manufacturing Federation (SMF) has submitted budget recommendations for the upcoming Singapore Budget 2017, focusing on maintaining existing incentives such as the Productivity & Innovation Credit (PIC scheme) and Wage Credit. The SMF aims to assist the manufacturing industry, which has been struggling due to globalisation, technological disruptions, and the oil-and-gas downturn. The recommendations also include promoting collaboration between bigger and smaller firms and assistance in internationalisation.

site_title: Private home rents down 6.2% in 2016: SRX
summary: Singapore's private home rents dropped 6.2% in 2016, with condominiums and apartments affected by a large supply and corporate uncertainty. Rents for 3-room, 5-room, and executive HDB flats rose month-on-month, but 4-room flats saw a decrease. Experts expect non-landed private residential rents to fall by 5% in 2017 due to corporate downsizing and a cautious macro-economic environment.

site_title: Global sales of French carmaker PSA up
summary: PSA Group, Europe's second-largest carmaker, reported a 5.8% increase in global vehicle deliveries to 3.146 million vehicles in 2016, driven by strong sales of its Peugeot brand in Iran and a recovering European market. This represents PSA's best yearly performance since 2010, with Peugeot being the only brand to see deliveries grow. The company aims to reduce its reliance on European markets by focusing on emerging markets.

site_title: Shares down ahead of Trump speech
summary: Singapore stocks ended the day 0.2% lower, with the Straits Times Index (STI) at 3,000.94, despite expectations of a boost from US President-elect Donald Trump's tax cuts and infrastructure plans. The index remained above the 3,000-point threshold, with losers outnumbering gainers 233 to 206. Trading volume was decent, with Natural Cool rising 0.041 to S$0.164, and Singtel, DBS, and Singapore Press Holdings gaining.

site_title: Local composites industry to get a lift
summary: A Singaporean firm plans to manufacture the world's first composite lift, made from fibreglass and carbon fibre-reinforced polymers, which will be 10 times lighter than traditional lifts, weighing 150kg instead of 1,500kg. This innovative design eliminates the need for a counterweight, reducing the overall weight and increasing efficiency.

site_title: Warburg Pincus forming consortium to bid for GLP: sources
summary: Warburg Pincus is forming a consortium to bid for Global Logistic Properties Ltd (GLP), a Singapore-based warehouse operator, with a market value of US$8.2 billion. The private equity firm has been speaking with banks and potential partners about the offer, which is expected to be submitted by early February. The bid aims to capitalize on the demand for warehouse space from e-commerce companies like Alibaba Group. A consortium led by Chinese firm Hopu Investment Management has also expressed interest in acquiring GLP, with existing management support seen as key to the success of the offers.

site_title: A Siri for your finances? Digit says trust me
summary: Digit, a financial technology company, has helped users save over $250 million in two years by automating small savings transfers every two to three days. The company's algorithm tracks users' income and spending patterns to determine how much to transfer, and its users can communicate with it through text messages or a new Facebook Messenger platform. Digit aims to expand its services to include a goal-setting feature and optimize savings by minimizing fees and maximizing gains. Despite some challenges, including the lack of interest payments and difficulties in connecting accounts, Digit has seen significant growth, tripling its user base in the past year.

site_title: Experts: Trump will lean on Japanese firms to put America first
summary: US President-elect Donald Trump criticized Toyota's plan to export cars from Mexico to the US, leading the company to pledge $10 billion in US capital investments over five years. However, this move is unlikely to pressure Japanese firms to align with Trump's "America-first" policy. Toyota's actions may be seen as a gesture to appease Trump, but experts believe Japanese firms will continue to prioritize their global interests over Trump's demands.

site_title: Energy efficiency standards vary for MNCs and SMEs, say business leaders
summary: Singapore business leaders suggest a differentiated approach to energy efficiency standards for multinational companies (MNCs) and small and medium enterprises (SMEs) amid the government's plan to amend the Energy Conservation Act to meet the country's Paris Agreement commitments. The country aims to reduce its emissions intensity by 36% by 2030. A varied approach to MNCs and SMEs is recommended to accommodate different business needs and promote more effective energy efficiency measures.

site_title: Obama's farewell speech both a tearful goodbye and a call to arms
summary: US President Barack Obama delivered his farewell speech in Chicago, marking the end of his eight-year presidency. The speech was a mix of a tearful goodbye and a call to action, recasting his "yes we can" campaign phrase as "yes we did." Obama reflected on his accomplishments, including the Iran nuclear deal and healthcare reform, aiming to lift supporters shaken by Donald Trump's election. The speech concluded his presidency, which was marked by significant events and policy changes.

site_title: Asian refiners' diesel profit margins set to climb: analysts
summary: Asian refiners' diesel profit margins are expected to rise for the first time in four years due to improving demand in infrastructure, construction, and mining sectors. Crude oil prices and normal winter conditions are also expected to boost margins, with a forecasted average of $11.40 a barrel in 2017, higher than $10.70 in 2016. Diesel demand growth is expected to drive refiners' profit, with global demand rising 500,000 barrels per day in 2017.

site_title: Lian Beng's Q2 net profit down 75%
summary: Construction firm Lian Beng Group posted a 75% drop in Q2 net profit to S$5.72 million, driven by a 62% decline in revenue to S$49.22 million. The half-year period saw a 67% drop in net profit to S$18.4 million, mainly due to lower revenue from the construction and ready-mixed concrete segments.
