site_title: For many people in China, headline inflation of 2% is just a cruel joke
summary: China's inflation rate, measured by the consumer price index (CPI), rose 2.1% in December, but living costs are surging in larger cities, particularly when housing is included. In contrast, rural areas and small towns experience stable living costs. The central bank has switched to tightening mode despite a slow economy, citing rapid increases in bond yields. Civil servants and professionals are feeling the pinch, with rent and food prices rising. Experts warn of regional divergences and call for targeted policies to address the issue.

site_title: Indonesian islands pay price for mining tin as demand for metal rises
summary: Indonesian islands of Bangka and Belitung are the world's largest source of tin, with one-third of global production. However, mining in these islands poses significant risks to the environment and local residents, who face serious injury and death. The extraction process, often conducted beneath the ocean, is hazardous and has devastating consequences for the island's ecosystem. As demand for tin rises, concerns over the environmental and social costs of mining in the region continue to grow. The Indonesian government must address these issues to ensure sustainable development and protect the welfare of local communities.

site_title: Home sale agreements are falling through more frequently across US
summary: US home sale agreements are failing at an increasing rate, with 3.9% of homes reverting from pending to for-sale, nearly double the rate in 2015. This issue affects 96 of the 100 biggest US metros, with higher fail rates in areas with high median home prices, such as Los Angeles and Charleston, and in older homes. Common reasons for failed sales include low appraisals, defects in home inspections, and mortgage rejections. The problem is most acute for cheaper homes and those built in the 1960s.

site_title: Volkswagen set to plead guilty and pay US$4.3b in deal
summary: Volkswagen is set to plead guilty to US$4.3 billion in fines for cheating on vehicle emissions tests, resolving a federal investigation. The deal includes charges of conspiracy to commit wire fraud and violating environmental regulations. The company's guilty plea could weaken its ability to defend against state investigations and shareholder lawsuits. The settlement is the largest corporate scandal in US history, with Volkswagen's total costs estimated at $20 billion. The deal requires approval by the company's management and supervisory boards, with a vote expected on Wednesday.

site_title: Emas Q1 loss narrows to US$2.2m
summary: EMAS Offshore, a unit of Ezra Holdings, reported a net loss of US$2.2 million for Q1 2017, down from US$3.2 million a year ago, due to weak demand for offshore support vessels. Revenue decreased 15% year-over-year to US$42.5 million. The company expects daily charter rates to remain depressed for a considerable period. Total liabilities rose to US$1,147.7 million, and loss per share stayed flat at 0.01 US cent. Emas attributed the decline to the offshore oil and gas industry's lack of significant growth.

site_title: The promises of democracy have been broken
summary: Liberal democracy is facing a crisis as populists on both sides are questioning the legitimacy of institutions and elites. The "broken promises of democracy" must be re-examined and addressed. This comes as globalisation and stagnant middle-class incomes are also being targeted. The article suggests that the problems in democracy are not solely the fault of populist politics, but rather a need to re-examine and redress the underlying issues. This is a call to action to re-evaluate the promises of democracy and work towards a more stable and legitimate system.

site_title: Cool d'etat heating up again at aircon firm
summary: Natural Cool's shares surged 33% on Wednesday after the company received a notice to hold an extraordinary general meeting (EGM) to remove its executive chairman, Joseph Ang. The move, prompted by two shareholders who own over 10% of the company, aims to reconstitute the board. The EGM is the second attempt by these shareholders to oust Ang, who survived a previous attempt in December. The company's market capitalization saw nearly half of its total shares traded, with 122.7 million shares changing hands.

images.alt_text: Call it a cool d'etat. Nearly half of the entire S$41.1 million market capitalisation of airconditioning firm Natural Cool changed hands in a single session on Wednesday, after the company said late Tuesday night that some shareholders had decided to have another go at booting out its executive chairman Joseph Ang.

site_title: Cover your ears, Mr Buffett, a dividend may be one CEO away
summary: Warren Buffett, 86, may consider returning more cash to Berkshire Hathaway shareholders by paying a dividend, a move that would stray from his investment-focused approach. This could ease investor concerns about the company's future under a new CEO, who may face pressure to spend the company's cash hoard on large acquisitions. Implementing a dividend could also support the stock price and appease investors, who may be less lenient with the new CEO's investment decisions.

site_title: Maria Sharapova to return from suspension at April event in Germany
summary: Tennis star Maria Sharapova is set to return to competition at the Porsche Tennis Grand Prix in Stuttgart, Germany on April 26, after being barred for a 2016 doping violation. She will receive a wild card to play the event, where she is a three-time champion, and will be reinstated as eligible to compete on the day of her first-round match. The unusual arrangement was made possible by the WTA and tournament organizers, who allowed Sharapova to be placed in the draw while still serving her 16-month suspension.

site_title: Banks in China told not to reveal curbs on capital outflows
summary: China's State Administration of Foreign Exchange (Safe) has instructed banks to keep its restrictions on capital outflows confidential, as well as prevent research analysts from sharing negative views on the yuan's prospects. The measures, aimed at preventing alarm and further declines in the yuan, include setting limits on banks' currency volumes and requiring approval for smaller transactions. The yuan has lost over 6% against the US dollar last year, prompting the restrictions. Safe's reticence has damaged relationships with clients, who are unaware of the reasons behind the banks' reluctance to conduct business.

site_title: Singapore interest rates fall on seasonal factors
summary: Singapore interest rates have fallen sharply in the second week of the New Year, influenced by seasonal factors and a relatively weak US dollar. The three-month SOR and Sibor rates have decreased, with the three-month Sibor standing at 0.967% on Wednesday, down for the third day. Experts attribute the decrease to traders closing their books and going on holiday, which typically leads to tighter liquidity.

site_title: UOBAM upbeat over global growth in 2017
summary: UOB Asset Management (UOBAM) expects the global economy to experience moderate growth in 2017, driven by potential reflation amid geopolitical uncertainties. Interest rates are expected to rise gradually, and the Purchasing Managers' Index of major economies has shown expansionary trend since the second half of 2016. UOBAM is overweight on equities, particularly developed markets like the US, and underweight in fixed income, focusing on credits over government bonds. The fund house expects high single-digit returns from equities and low single-digit returns from fixed income.

site_title: Commonwealth Capital invests in S$70m integrated food facility
summary: Commonwealth Capital, a Singapore-based investment holding company, has invested S$70 million in a state-of-the-art integrated food facility in Jurong. The 300,000 sq ft facility integrates food logistics, production, and services under one roof, providing economies of scale for the company's 151 cafes and restaurants across 12 countries. The facility features cutting-edge technologies, including automated storage and retrieval systems, and innovations in food manufacturing, enabling the company to expand its international reach and increase its export revenue to 50% within two years.

site_title: Acra getting more teeth to deal with reporting breaches
summary: The Accounting and Corporate Regulatory Authority (Acra) in Singapore is set to introduce tougher measures to combat financial reporting breaches. Starting April 1, companies with serious breaches will be required to restate their financial statements, re-audit, and re-file them, with directors facing public naming and shaming. Those with less serious breaches will be asked to restate comparatives or improve disclosures in the next year's financial statements. The regulator also plans to develop financial reporting indicators to assess companies' financial capabilities and identify areas for improvement.

site_title: With 'Trump trade', get tactical
summary: DBS Private Bank warns of increased volatility in US markets due to Donald Trump's presidency, citing uncertainty around rate movements, fiscal spending, and geopolitical shifts. The bank is "tactically overweight" on US equities and bullish on US banks, expecting a stronger economy to drive growth. However, it also notes the risks of faster-than-expected rate hikes and the challenges of fiscal spending's impact on the stock market. DBS is neutral on the US market for the year, citing weaker global economic fundamentals and the potential for China to fill the power vacuum in Asia.

site_title: SPH Reit grows Q1 distributable income by 3%
summary: SPH Reit reported a 3% increase in distributable income for its first fiscal quarter, driven by a 7% cut in property operating expenses. The trust's income available for distribution grew to S$36.4 million, with 94% distributed as S$34.2 million per unit.

site_title: Less salty diets could save millions of lives
summary: A study suggests reducing global salt intake by 10% could save millions of lives. Researchers estimate that this reduction would save approximately 5.8 million disability-adjusted life years annually, at a cost of $1.13 per person over a decade. Implementing a "soft regulation" strategy in 183 nations could achieve this goal, with the potential to cut mortality and disability caused by salt-triggered heart attacks and strokes for just over 10 US cents a year per person.

images.alt_text: Most adults exceed the recommended maximum salt levels of two grammes per day.

site_title: SIAS urges minorities of China New Town to vote rationally on delisting
summary: Singapore's Securities Investors Association of Singapore (SIAS) urges minority shareholders of China New Town Development Company to vote rationally on the proposed delisting from the Singapore Exchange (SGX). Only independent shareholders in Singapore and Hong Kong can vote, with a 75% majority required to pass the resolution. The company plans a cash exit offer of seven Singapore cents per share, and shareholders can choose to tender their shares or hold onto them for trading in Hong Kong, where the shares trade at a 13% premium.

site_title: Chinese investors losing appetite for bonds in 2017
summary: Chinese investors are shifting away from bonds in 2017 due to rising inflation, a recovering economy, and tightening monetary policy. In 2016, bond funds saw a 142% surge, but in 2017, assets under management dropped 17% as investors seek better returns in shares. Central banks' shift towards tighter monetary policies and concerns over capital outflows and a falling yuan have led to a two-month bond selloff, causing yields to rise 15 basis points to 3.22%. This marks a significant reversal from the previous year.

site_title: Indonesia's first billion-dollar startup races to kill cash
summary: Go-Jek, Indonesia's first billion-dollar startup, is expanding its digital payments service, Go-Pay, to reduce reliance on cash. The service, which accounts for over 50% of the company's transactions, allows customers to pay for rides and other services using e-wallets. Go-Jek is competing with Grab and Uber in the ride-hailing market, and sees digital payments as a way to stand out. The company plans to double its engineers in India to meet growing demand for payments and other services.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Sembcorp Industries' marine segment faces headwinds, but its utilities segment remains positive due to emerging market opportunities. OCBC Investment Research has raised its target price to S$3.36, citing the utilities segment's strong track record and potential for growth. BreadTalk Group is expected to turn around its Food Atrium segment in 2017, driven by cost-cutting measures and expansion plans. Analysts have set target prices for the companies, with Sembcorp Industries at S$3.36 and BreadTalk Group at S$1.45.

site_title: Lian Beng Q2 net profit drops 75%
summary: Lian Beng Group reported a 75% drop in Q2 net profit to S$5.72 million, from S$22.87 million, due to a 62% decline in revenue to S$49.22 million. Earnings per share decreased to 1.14 Singapore cents, from 4.53 Singapore cents last year. The company maintained a tax-exempt interim cash dividend per share of one Singapore cent.

site_title: Nutella maker defends palm oil use after cancer risk study
summary: Ferrero, the maker of Nutella, has defended the use of palm oil in its flagship product after a European study found a potential carcinogenic contaminant. The company claims its industrial process minimizes contaminants, and its advertising campaign aims to assure consumers of the product's safety. Despite the European Food Safety Authority's recommendation for further study, Ferrero is the only major European food firm to publicly defend palm oil use. Other companies, such as Unilever and Nestle, also use palm oil, but are monitoring the contaminant issue. Ferrero's sales of Nutella in Italy have seen a 4% increase in the last four months following the company's advertising campaign.

images.alt_text: The US$44 billion palm oil industry, under pressure in Europe after the authorities listed the edible oil as a cancer risk, has found a vocal ally in the food sector: the maker of Nutella.

site_title: KepLand to sell 80% stake in Indonesian JV for S$57m
summary: Keppel Land, a property unit of KeppeL Corporation Limited, has agreed to sell its 80% stake in an Indonesian joint venture, PT Sentral Tunjungan Perkasa (PT STP), for S$57 million. The sale is expected to yield an after-tax profit of about S$32 million. This move is part of Keppel Land's strategy to recycle assets for higher returns, and the company plans to continue exploring opportunities in Indonesia's key growth market, Greater Jakarta.

site_title: S'pore-based gaming portal Garena picks up Goldman for planned US$1b IPO
summary: Garena, a Singapore-based gaming portal, has selected Goldman Sachs to lead its planned $1 billion initial public offering (IPO) in the US. This deal would be the largest technology IPO from South-east Asia, potentially opening the door for other local startups like Grab and Tokopedia. The IPO would add to the $9.9 billion in first-time share sales by technology companies globally in the past year. Garena, founded by Chinese entrepreneur Forrest Li, has grown its net revenue 13-fold since 2011 and was valued at $3.75 billion after a fundraising round in 2016.

site_title: TIH inks JV to invest S$1.5m in company that invests in Thai start-ups
summary: TIH Limited has inked a joint venture agreement to invest S$1.45 million in K2 Venture Capital Company, a Thai start-up investment firm. The joint venture aims to tap into Thailand's high growth start-up investment opportunities. Stanley Wang, a senior executive of TIH Investment Management, will be seconded to K2 Venture as managing director. The deal is expected to leverage both companies' networks and track records to drive investment growth in the region.

site_title: Yip Hoong Mun joins Metro
summary: Metro Holdings appoints Yip Hoong Mun as group chief operating officer and chief executive officer of Metro China Holdings, part of a plan to enhance its senior management team. Yip, 55, brings 30 years of experience in executive roles, most recently with CapitaLand Group.

site_title: American Apparel's 'made in the US' heritage uncertain after Canadian deal
summary: Gildan Ac-tivewear Inc has acquired American Apparel LLC for about $88 million in cash after winning a bankruptcy auction. The deal does not assume American Apparel's leases, leaving its manufacturing plants' fate uncertain. Gildan plans to decide where to produce the clothing after completing its integration plan, which could impact US jobs. Approximately 3,500 American Apparel employees may be laid off, and existing stores will continue selling the brand's products for 100 days while Gildan decides its strategy.

images.alt_text: Existing American Apparel shops will continue selling clothes for the next 100 days as Gildan, which isn't buying any of the chain's 110 retail stores, decides how to make the products available to consumers.

site_title: US$ gains against yen, euro, pound
summary: US dollar gains against yen, euro, and pound as investors expect pro-growth message from Donald Trump's first news conference, despite concerns over trade and China. The dollar has risen since Trump's victory in November, driven by expectations of increased public spending and repatriation of overseas funds, potentially leading to higher inflation and interest rates.

site_title: From Brexit to Trump, polarisation poses global risk, says WEF
summary: The World Economic Forum (WEF) warns that rising inequality, social polarisation, and climate change pose significant global risks for the next decade, contributing to the Brexit vote and Donald Trump's election. The report highlights the widening gap between rich and poor, exacerbated by quantitative easing, and the erosion of global cooperation. The WEF calls for urgent action to address these trends, which threaten to amplify global risks and erode social solidarity.

site_title: Sundance zooms in on climate change
summary: The Sundance Film Festival, founded by Robert Redford, will focus on climate change with a new subsection called "New Climate" featuring 14 documentaries, short films, and special projects. The festival, opening on January 19, coincides with Donald Trump's presidential oath and responds to his climate change denial. Redford emphasizes the festival's mission to support filmmakers and avoid politics, but top programmers admit the focus is political in nature. The New Climate subsection aims to raise awareness and inspire action on environmental issues.

site_title: Putin should temper hopes of US alliance
summary: US President-elect Donald Trump's Russia policy is set to test the Republican national security establishment, which favors a tougher approach. Trump's ambitions for a "reset" with Russia, similar to President Barack Obama's in 2009, have fractured the Republican establishment. This poses a challenge for Congressional Republicans and Democrats, who may return to their historic posture of standing firm against aggressive authoritarian rulers, as seen under past Cold War presidents. Trump's approach to Russia will be a significant test of his leadership and the party's principles.

images.alt_text: Mr Putin needs America, or its proxy Nato, as an enemy, because friendship with the West would expose Russia under his rule as a military-industrial kleptocracy.

site_title: Boeing internal memo sets details of engineer layoffs in 2017
summary: Boeing has announced plans to conduct involuntary layoffs of engineers and dozens of other job categories in Washington state, southern California, and South Carolina as part of a cost-cutting drive. The reductions, part of a larger restructuring effort, aim to ensure the company's long-term future amid slowing aircraft sales and increasing competition. The layoffs will take place in stages, with voluntary layoff invitations sent on January 13 and involuntary reductions on January 20. Two more rounds of engineering layoffs are planned for later in the year.

site_title: Apple iPhone-maker Hon Hai posts first sales slide on record
summary: Hon Hai Precision Industry Co, the main assembler of Apple's iPhones, recorded its first annual revenue decline of 2.8% in 2016 to NT$4.36 trillion (S$195.5 billion). The decline is attributed to the global smartphone market's worst year on record, with maturing markets and a decelerating Chinese economy. Hon Hai's sales are mostly tied to Apple, which has also reported a revenue decline. Chinese rivals such as OPPO and Huawei have grown global market share at Apple's expense, leading to a perception that Hon Hai is too expensive and biased towards Apple.

site_title: Bitcoin slides as China's central bank launches checks on exchanges
summary: China's central bank launched spot checks on major bitcoin exchanges, including BTCC, Huobi, and OKCoin, amid efforts to stem capital outflows and pressure on the yuan. The PBOC's probe focused on rule violations, including market manipulation and money laundering, but did not confirm any findings. Bitcoin prices slid over 12% against the dollar, with Chinese yuan/bitcoin rates at a discount to dollar-based exchanges. Authorities are tightening regulations on bitcoin trading, potentially impacting the cryptocurrency's popularity among tech-savvy Chinese investors.

site_title: Smog-choked China swapping energy independence for cleaner air
summary: China is increasing its reliance on liquefied natural gas imports due to stagnant domestic production and a push for cleaner fuels to alleviate smog. The country's LNG imports are expected to rise by 30% this year, accounting for approximately 40% of its gas use by the end of the decade. This shift aims to reduce the country's dependence on coal and improve air quality, particularly during the winter months.

site_title: China to merge state media for stronger voice in financial news
summary: China is merging five state media companies to create a "modern financial media group" to strengthen its voice in financial news coverage. The move, announced by the state-run Xinhua news agency, aims to increase the state's influence in economic and financial news. The consolidation, led by Xinhua, will create a new company called China Fortune Media Corporation Group, which will be launched in Beijing next week. This move follows President Xi Jinping's efforts to project China's "soft power" and control the media landscape since taking power in 2012.

site_title: Economic inequality top global risk: WEF
summary: Rising income inequality is seen as the top risk to the global economy in 2017, according to the World Economic Forum's Global Risks Report. Experts believe reforms to market capitalism are necessary to ward off a populist backlash and address growing income and wealth disparities. The report also highlights increasing polarization, national sentiment, and rapid changes in social attitudes, which have led to dramatic political results in 2016, including the UK's Brexit vote and Donald Trump's US presidential election.

site_title: UK government expects to lose Brexit court case, making contingency plans: report
summary: The UK government expects to lose its Brexit court case, which could allow Prime Minister Theresa May to trigger Article 50 without Parliament's approval. In anticipation of the ruling, the government has drafted versions of a Bill to present to lawmakers after the decision. The government had hoped to secure a "one-line" Bill that would allow for a clean break with the EU, but this is unlikely given the Supreme Court's expected ruling. The outcome could lead to a "soft Brexit" as lawmakers seek to amend the plan.

site_title: US: Stocks flat ahead of Trump press conference
summary: US stocks remained flat ahead of President-elect Donald Trump's first news conference, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average up 0.2%, the S&P 500 up 0.1%, and the Nasdaq Composite Index down 0.1%. Trump dismissed unsubstantiated claims of Russian intelligence gathering compromising information on him as "utter nonsense." The news conference could drive market sentiment, and questions about Russia are expected to play a role in the Senate confirmation hearing of Rex Tillerson as secretary of state.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares end higher
summary: Malaysia's shares ended higher on Wednesday, with the Kuala Lumpur Composite Index gaining 3.16 points to close at 1,675.21. The index saw 2.76 billion lots traded, with 467 gainers and 324 losers.

site_title: Instagram adds advertising to Instagram Stories
summary: Instagram is introducing advertising to its Instagram Stories feature, bringing over 30 advertisers on board to boost revenue. The move aims to help Facebook maintain its lead in the digital ad marketplace, with some predicting Instagram could become as strong a revenue component as YouTube. Instagram Stories, launched in August, has 150 million daily active users and will feature full-screen ads intermittently as users swipe through photos and videos. Major advertisers, including General Motors and Nike, are testing the new ad product.

site_title: Trump could unsettle US-Japan relations
summary: US President-elect Donald Trump's relationship with Japan's Prime Minister Shinzo Abe is crucial, with Trump's planned withdrawal from the Trans-Pacific Partnership (TPP) agreement potentially destabilizing their alliance. Trump has threatened to pull out of the TPP on his first day in office, a move that could harm Japan's economic interests. Abe had expected a stronger partnership with Trump, and the US leader's actions may lead to a shift in Japan's role in regional politics, with Abe's country potentially becoming more independent.

site_title: Halcyon appoints Sinochem president as non-exec chairman
summary: Halcyon Agri Corporation has appointed Liu Hongsheng, president of Sinochem International, as its new non-executive chairman, effective January 16. Sinochem International, a unit of Chinese conglomerate Sinochem GroupCorp, acquired a majority stake in Halcyon Agri recently. Liu replaces current non-executive chairman Qin Hengde, who has been reassigned within Sinochem International. The appointment was made following a proposal by Sinochem International. Halcyon Agri's shares rose 3 cents to close at 66 cents per share on the day of the announcement.

site_title: Chinese investors losing appetite for bonds in 2017
summary: Chinese investors are shifting their focus from bonds to shares in 2017, driven by rising inflation, improving economy, and tightening liquidity. After a 142% surge in bond funds in 2016, assets under management have dropped 17% to 1.99 trillion yuan. Yields have risen 15 basis points to 3.22% due to China's intervention to defend the yuan. Experts expect tighter monetary policies and higher yields, making shares more attractive, with forecasts predicting a 6% rise in China's stock market in 2017.

site_title: Airbus bags US$3.8b US deal; sale to Saudi Flynas imminent, say sources
summary: Airbus secured a US$3.8 billion deal with US leasing firm Aviation Capital Group for 30 A320neo planes, two original A320 variants, and three A321s. The European company is also close to securing a major deal from Saudi Arabian carrier Flynas. This marks Airbus's first sale of 2017.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks end at 18-mth high; won slips
summary: South Korean shares reached an 18-month high, closing up 1.5% at 2,075.17 points, driven by foreign investors' anticipation of strong fourth-quarter earnings data. The South Korean won remained flat at 1,196.4 to the dollar.

site_title: Australia shares edge up; NZ ends near 3-month high
summary: Australian shares rose 0.19% to 5,771.5, driven by a strong rally in basic material stocks due to rising iron ore and base metal prices. The metals and mining index gained 2.7% with Rio Tinto and Fortescue Metals increasing 3.9% and 4.5%, respectively. New Zealand's benchmark S&P/NZX 50 index hit a 3-month high, up 0.46%, led by a2 Milk Company's 7% surge.

site_title: SPH Reit Q1 distributable income grows 3%, DPU of 1.34 Singapore cents declared
summary: SPH Reit reported a 3% increase in distributable income for its Q1 2017, driven by lower operating expenses. The trust's net property income rose 3.3% to S$41.4 million, while gross revenue grew 0.9% to S$52.6 million. The company distributed 94% of its available income, or S$34.2 million, representing a distribution per unit of 1.34 Singapore cents. The retail environment is expected to be "challenging" over the next 12 months, but the trust remains confident in its existing portfolio.

images.alt_text: SINGAPORE-BASED mall investment trust SPH Reit posted a 3 per cent increase in distributable income for its first fiscal quarter as lower operating expenses uplifted a modest increase in revenue.

site_title: Keppel Land sells 80% stake in Indonesian venture for S$57m
summary: Keppel Land has sold its 80% stake in an Indonesian joint venture, PT Sentral Tunjungan Perkasa (PT STP), for S$57 million. The sale is expected to yield an after-tax profit of approximately S$32 million. PT STP owns a 23,253 sqm land parcel in Surabaya, Indonesia. The divestment aligns with Keppel Land's strategy to recycle assets for higher returns, and the company plans to continue exploring opportunities in Greater Jakarta.

site_title: Seagate to cut more than 2,000 jobs in China
summary: Seagate Technology Plc is cutting more than 2,000 jobs as part of its restructuring plans to reduce its global manufacturing footprint. The job cuts, announced in July, are part of the company's efforts to close its Suzhou factory in China. This move is the latest in Seagate's efforts to streamline its operations and adapt to changing market conditions. The company had previously announced plans to reduce its global manufacturing footprint, with the goal of improving efficiency and competitiveness.

images.alt_text: Hard-disk drive maker Seagate Technology Plc said it would cut more than 2,000 jobs as it shuts down its Suzhou factory in China.

site_title: North Korea has plutonium for 10 nuclear bombs: South Korea
summary: North Korea has amassed enough plutonium to produce 10 nuclear bombs, according to South Korea, amid reports of plans to test-launch an intercontinental ballistic missile. The isolated nation is expected to pursue a nuclear push in 2017, aiming to develop a system capable of hitting the US mainland. Analysts believe Pyongyang has made significant strides since Kim Jong Un took power in 2011, with the country having conducted five nuclear tests and numerous missile launches.

site_title: ISDN public offer in Hong Kong sees 'robust demand'
summary: ISDN Holdings reported robust demand for its public offering of 40 million shares at HK$1.25 per share. The company initially oversubscribed the offer, with 20 million shares allocated to the public and 20 million to institutional investors. This marks a successful debut for the dual primary listing on the Hong Kong Stock Exchange.

site_title: Vessel owned by Uni-Asia subsidiary involved in collision
summary: A collision involving the MV Inspiration Lake, a bulk carrier owned by Uni-Asia subsidiary Regina Bulkship SA, occurred near the Port of Pohang in South Korea on January 10. The incident resulted in the capsize of a fishing boat, killing two crew members and leaving four others missing. Uni-Asia is investigating the cause and assessing damage to the vessel. There was no oil leakage reported. The company expressed sympathy to the families of the deceased and hopes for the safe rescue of the missing crew members.

site_title: HK stocks rise for fifth-straight day; China ends lower
summary: Hong Kong shares rose for a fifth consecutive day, with the Hang Seng Index increasing 0.84% to 22,935.35, despite China's Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index declining 0.79% and 1.05%, respectively. The rally follows a broad advance across Asian markets, with Singapore stocks also experiencing a five-day gain.

site_title: Suddenly, home sale agreements are falling apart across the US
summary: US home sale agreements are falling apart, with 3.9% of pending sales reverting to for-sale status, nearly double the 2015 rate. This increase in "failed sales" occurred in 96 of the 100 biggest US metros, with significant fluctuations in areas of varying sizes and economic conditions. Los Angeles, Charleston, and San Jose are among the affected cities, highlighting the challenges faced by homebuyers and sellers nationwide.

site_title: Europe: Stocks stable at open
summary: Europe's main stock markets held steady at the start of trading on Wednesday, with the London FTSE 100 flat at 7,277.10 points. The eurozone's DAX 30 index and Paris CAC 40 index remained unchanged. Meanwhile, US stocks edged to fresh records despite tariff uncertainty, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq closing at new highs.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Temasek Foundation Ecosperity has funded S$6 million into four projects to improve Singapore's liveability. Singtel launched Singapore's fastest mobile network with 450Mbps 4G LTE-Advanced service. Singapore interest rates fell due to seasonal factors and a weak US dollar. Commonwealth Capital opened a S$70 million integrated food facility. Jens Sturzenegger, a former Falcon Bank manager, was sentenced to 28 weeks' jail and fined S$128,000 for 1MDB-related charges. Singapore shares closed 0.2% lower, while global markets reacted to US tariffs on Vietnam and the garment industry, and China's slowing GDP growth.

site_title: Singapore interest rates fall on seasonal factors and weaker US$
summary: Singapore interest rates have fallen to 0.868% for the three-month SOR and 0.967% for the three-month Sibor, influenced by seasonal factors and a relatively weak US dollar. The rates decreased from their one-month highs in December, with the US dollar index weakening after hitting a 14-year high. Experts believe the interest rate movements are within expectations and may reverse course, with the US Federal Reserve expected to make its first 2017 interest rate hike in June.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks snap three-day losing streak
summary: Tokyo shares ended a three-day losing streak, with the Nikkei 225 index rising 0.33% to 19,364.67, driven by a drop in the yen and investor anticipation of US President-elect Donald Trump's first news conference.

site_title: Malaysia Nov factory output up 6.2% y-o-y, meets forecast
summary: Malaysia's industrial production in November rose 6.2% year-over-year, matching the median forecast, driven by strength in manufacturing, electricity, and mining sectors. Electricity output recorded the strongest growth at 9.7% year-on-year. This is in line with October's 4.2% rise. The data from the Statistics Department suggests a positive trend in the country's industrial sector.

site_title: HK regulatory ruling not appropriate, Moody's tells court
summary: Moody's Investors Service is appealing a HK$11 million fine from the Hong Kong Securities and Futures Commission for allegedly breaching the regulator's code of conduct in publishing a report on Chinese companies. The report highlighted warning signs of weak corporate governance and opaque business models, but Moody's claimed it was not used as a credit-rating tool. The tribunal ruled that the report should be held to higher standards, but Moody's argues there was a blurred line between regulated and unregulated activities, making the fine unjust.

site_title: Singapore shares close 0.2% down on Wednesday
summary: Singapore stocks declined 0.2% on Wednesday, closing at 3,000.94, amid concerns about US President-elect Donald Trump's upcoming press conference. The Straits Times Index dropped 5.08 points. The market was weighed down ahead of the conference, which is scheduled for late Wednesday night. The 1.75 billion shares traded saw an average unit price of S$0.68 per share.

site_title: Obama tears up during tribute to Michelle, daughters
summary: President Barack Obama delivered an emotional farewell speech in Chicago, paying tribute to his wife Michelle and teenage daughters Malia and Sasha. He praised Michelle as his "best friend" and thanked her for being a role model to their daughters. Obama also addressed the absence of Sasha, who was not present due to a school exam, and expressed pride in the "two amazing young women" they had become. The speech drew a standing ovation and a warm reunion with Michelle and Malia on stage.

site_title: Asia: Markets rise with commodities but crude toils
summary: Asian markets rose on Wednesday, driven by China's strong inflation reading and gains in commodities-linked firms. However, oil prices struggled after two days of sharp losses due to concerns over Opec's plans to cut output. Despite gains in key cities, investors remain cautious ahead of Donald Trump's first press conference, with some questioning his ability to deliver on his plans.

site_title: PSA Group 2016 sales rise 5.8%, boosted by Iran and European recovery
summary: PSA Group reported a 5.8% increase in global vehicle deliveries in 2016, driven by strong sales of Peugeot in Iran and the European market's recovery. The company's global sales rose to 3.146 million vehicles, surpassing the 3 million-vehicle threshold for the first time since 2011. Peugeot deliveries surged 112.8% in the Middle East and Africa, while Citroen reported a 1.72% sales drop. PSA aims to increase Citroen's sales by 30% by 2021 and boost group revenue by 10% by 2018.

site_title: Biggest Indian refiner hunts for oil assets as demand surges
summary: Indian Oil Corp, the country's largest fuel retailer, is seeking to buy oil assets globally to meet India's surging energy demand, which is expected to double by 2040. The company aims to boost oil production 10-fold to 210,000 barrels per day in the next eight years. Indian Oil plans to spend $26.2 billion to expand refining capacity and build new infrastructure, with a goal of owning a tenth of its refining capacity from assets it controls or has a stake in. The company is evaluating offers from global oil companies looking to sell assets.

site_title: Hong Kong anger over China museum project
summary: Hong Kong residents are protesting against plans to build a branch of China's Palace Museum in the city, citing concerns over cultural brainwashing and kowtowing to Beijing. The museum, which features artifacts from multiple Chinese dynasties, will be funded by a HK3.5 billion grant and is set to open in 2022. Critics argue that the public was not consulted and that the project is a political move to impress Beijing, while supporters say it will boost Hong Kong's cultural credentials. Demonstrations have included protesters throwing paper tanks at officials, and the project has sparked concerns over the "mainlandisation" of Hong Kong.

site_title: South Korea special prosecutors to question Samsung leader as a suspect
summary: South Korea's special prosecutors have summoned Samsung Group leader Jay Y Lee as a suspect in a corruption scandal involving President Park Geun-hye. The investigation centers on Samsung's support for a business and foundations backed by Park's friend, Choi Soon-sil, in a 2015 merger decision. Lee is suspected of bribery, but the specifics were not elaborated. This development is part of a widening influence-peddling scandal involving President Park.

images.alt_text: A South Korean special prosecutor's office on Wednesday said it had summoned Samsung Group leader Jay Y Lee as a suspect in a widening influence-peddling scandal involving President Park Geun-hye.

site_title: Obama bids farewell vision to democrats in contrast to Trump
summary: In his farewell address, President Barack Obama blasted "zero-sum" politics and contrasted his vision with that of incoming President Donald Trump, who vowed to undo Obama's achievements. Obama appealed for inclusiveness and preservation of his legacy, warning that a "fear of change" poses a greater threat to democracy than external threats. He also called for political engagement, tolerance, and investment in the country's future, while referencing his plans for post-presidency, including a training center for grassroots organizing and efforts to limit money in politics.

site_title: Taiwan: Stocks flat ahead of TSMC earnings; caution tracking overseas markets
summary: Taiwan's stocks remained flat on Wednesday ahead of Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co.'s (TSMC) earnings report, with investors cautious about overseas markets and President-elect Donald Trump's news conference. TSMC reported 2016 revenue 12.4% higher than expected, but its fourth-quarter net profit results are set for Thursday. The Taiwan dollar softened against the US dollar.

site_title: Jack Ma's million jobs pledge more PR than promise: analysts
summary: Alibaba founder Jack Ma's pledge to create one million US jobs has been met with skepticism by analysts, who see it as more of a PR move to win goodwill from President-elect Donald Trump and hedge against counterfeits on its platform. The figure would represent a small fraction of US jobs, and Ma's efforts to boost international sales and counterfeits issues are likely driven by a desire to improve Alibaba's image and expand its US presence. The move is seen as a strategic attempt to alleviate PR pressure and enhance its business prospects.

site_title: Carnegie Clean Energy sees rapid growth after embracing solar power
summary: Carnegie Clean Energy expects a 17-fold increase in annual revenue to A$30 million by 2018, driven by its recent acquisition of Energy Made Clean, a solar and battery company. The firm's managing director sees the deal as a game changer, allowing the company to diversify and mitigate risk. Carnegie is also partnering with Lendlease Group to develop microgrids, which it expects to grow at 50% a year to $20 billion by 2020. The company aims to tie its wave energy technology into microgrids, along with solar and batteries.

site_title: Commonwealth Capital launches S$70m integrated food facility
summary: Commonwealth Capital, a food and beverage investment holding company, has launched a S$70 million integrated food facility in Singapore. The 300,000 square foot facility will integrate logistics, production, and services under one roof, boosting capabilities for customers and in-house brands. The new facility is part of Commonwealth Capital's expansion plans, which include 151 cafes and restaurants in 12 countries. The facility will utilize cutting-edge technology and economies of scale to enhance operations.

site_title: Tintin takes on Russians in new colour version of original epic
summary: Tintin is being re-released in a colour version of the 1930 comic book "Tintin and the Soviets", which was previously only available in black and white. The book, which was deemed part of the official Tintin canon in 1999, features a rough and thuggish Tintin character who gets into fights and scrapes. Critics, including Herge's biographer, have questioned whether the character is fully developed, and some have criticized the decision to colour the book, saying it alters the original work. The publisher has defended the decision, stating that it is not altering the work, but rather restoring it to its original intended form.

site_title: Indonesian islands pay price for global smartphone rush
summary: Indonesian islands of Bangka and Belitung are struggling due to the global demand for tin, a crucial component in smartphones and tablets. Thousands of miners risk serious injury and death in the mines, with at least one death reported every week. The mining industry has brought riches but also environmental damage and harm to local communities. Electronics firms, including Apple and Samsung, have pledged to improve mining practices and source tin responsibly, but critics argue that more needs to be done to protect workers and the environment.

site_title: Ex-Falcon Bank manager jailed 28 weeks, fined S$128,000 for 1MDB-related charges
summary: A Swiss national, Jens Sturzenegger, former manager of Falcon Bank's Singapore branch, was sentenced to 28 weeks' jail and fined S$128,000 for his role in the 1MDB scandal. He pleaded guilty to six charges related to the movement of funds from the scandal-ridden 1MDB, totaling US$1.3 billion. Sturzenegger is the first foreigner and fifth person charged in Singapore's ongoing money laundering probe.

site_title: Hot stock: Jumbo sizzles in early Wednesday trading
summary: Jumbo, a Singapore-based food and beverage chain, saw its stock jump nearly 5% to S$0.74 on early Wednesday trading, with over 36.5 million shares changing hands. This comes after the company released its 2016 annual report and a shareholder circular ahead of its Jan 26 extraordinary general meeting. The stock's performance is separate from the overall market's 0.4% gain on Thursday.

site_title: Thrill seekers rescued from Australia's Movie World rollercoaster
summary: Rescue crews in Australia's Movie World on the Gold Coast successfully evacuated 20 people from a rollercoaster ride, the Arkham Asylum, after it broke down. The riders were 20m off the ground, but no injuries were reported. The incident occurred just months after four people died at a nearby theme park, prompting a rigorous safety review. The ride's mechanical issue was resolved, and the evacuation process was completed with assistance from the Queensland Fire Brigade.

site_title: Smog-choked China swapping energy independence for cleaner air
summary: China is increasing its reliance on overseas natural gas as it seeks to reduce its reliance on coal and combat toxic smog. The country aims to raise natural gas imports to 40% of its energy mix by the end of the decade, with LNG purchases expected to surge to a record in 2017. Domestic production stagnates, and the government is pushing for cleaner fuels to improve air quality, with a target to raise the share of natural gas to 10% of its energy mix by 2020.

site_title: Singtel launches nationwide 450Mbps mobile data speeds
summary: Singtel has launched Singapore's fastest mobile network, offering nationwide 450Mbps 4G LTE-Advanced speeds. This delivers up to 50% faster download speeds than prevailing LTE services, allowing customers to download an HD movie in under 2 minutes. The service is available to all Singtel 4G customers at no additional charge, with compatible Samsung Galaxy S7 and S7 Edge models already experiencing the speeds.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks touch over 3-month high on optimistic outlook; won eases
summary: South Korean shares rose to a three-month high, with the Kospi index up 0.9% at 2,064.08 points, driven by optimistic expectations of fourth-quarter earnings. Foreign investors snapped up shares, with offshore investors buying 240.4 billion won worth of Kospi shares. Tech giants Posco and Samsung Electronics also made fresh highs, with steelmaker Posco rising over 5% and Samsung gaining 1.3%. The South Korean won eased 0.4% to 1,198.9 to the US dollar.

site_title: Asia: Shares climb amid metals bounce as yen slips
summary: Asian stocks rose amid a metals bounce, with mining companies leading gains, as China's producer prices surged to a five-year high, boosting industrial metals and raw materials. The MSCI Asia Pacific Index climbed 0.1%, while the yen snapped a two-day climb against the dollar ahead of Donald Trump's press conference. The S&P 500 Index closed unchanged, despite a 0.5% rally on Tuesday.

site_title: Japan looks at steps to allow Emperor's abdication
summary: Japan's government is planning to take legal steps to allow Emperor Akihito to abdicate, potentially setting the stage for the first abdication in two centuries. The move comes after Akihito, 83, hinted in August that he wanted to step down due to age concerns. A panel of experts has been discussing the issue, with recommendations expected later this year, and the government may submit a special law to parliament as early as spring 2017. The abdication is expected to take place in December 2018 or January 2019, with Crown Prince Naruhito ascending the throne.

site_title: Temasek unit funds S$6m into 4 projects to improve S'pore liveability
summary: Temasek's TF Ecosperity has funded approximately S$6 million for four projects aimed at enhancing Singapore's liveability. The projects focus on developing treatments and solutions for Zika virus, mosquito vector control, air filtration, and respiratory health for younger children. The initiatives, supported by the non-profit philanthropic organisation, are among the first batch of proposals to bring about enduring solutions against environmental and biological adversities in Singapore and beyond.

site_title: Russians claim to have compromising info on Trump: report
summary: US spy chiefs briefed President-elect Donald Trump on allegations of Russian interference in the presidential election, citing "multiple" unnamed officials. The briefing reportedly included a two-page synopsis of potentially embarrassing information about Trump, including sex videos and lucrative deals with Russian officials. Trump denounced the claims as a "political witch hunt" and tweeted "FAKE NEWS - A TOTAL POLITICAL WITCH HUNT!" The allegations have been circulating in Washington circles for months, and Trump was informed of the dossier's existence last Friday.

site_title: Australian, New Zealand dollars pause after scaling 1-month highs
summary: The Australian dollar paused at a one-month high of US$0.7385, aided by a rally in iron ore and coal prices, and declines in the US dollar. The Aussie is up 2.1% in January, its first consecutive monthly gain in three months. The New Zealand dollar also held steady at US$0.6985, near a four-week high. Analysts expect subdued gains for both currencies due to expected long-term US dollar rallies.

images.alt_text: The Australian dollar stood at US$0.7361 after popping up to US$0.7385, its highest since Dec. 14.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open flat on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened flat on Wednesday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index increasing 0.020 points to 1672.800. The market saw 59 gainers and 36 losers, with a trading volume of 33.83 million lots worth RM7.54 million.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open higher
summary: Tokyo shares opened higher on Wednesday, recovering from three days of losses. The benchmark Nikkei 225 index rose 0.30% to 19,359.03, while the Topix index increased 0.34% to 1,547.55. Investors shrugged off lower oil prices and lackluster overseas market performances.

site_title: Michael Kors, Prada cut back on bag designs in face of slump
summary: Luxury handbag makers Michael Kors, Prada, and Burberry reduced new design introductions in the fourth quarter, citing waning demand and markdowns at stores. This lack of innovation may hinder recapturing shopper excitement. Demand was impacted by a strong US dollar, global economic woes, and terrorism fears. Sales growth in handbags is expected to decelerate to 3.1% by 2020, prompting companies to diversify. Some brands, such as Coach, are focusing on in-store experiences and collaborations to boost sales. The industry's decline is prompting companies to focus on survival and reforming their structures.

images.alt_text: Handbag makers are busy battling waning demand and markdowns at stores, and that may have diverted their attention from what could make them successful in the long run: creativity.

site_title: Hunger for Aussie bank paper shows few signs of slowing
summary: Australian banks continue to fundraise in the local bond market, with Commonwealth Bank of Australia selling A$2.65 billion in notes less than two weeks into the year. This follows a record year of fundraising by the country's four largest banks, and investors remain comfortable with buying their debt despite potential concerns over Australia's sovereign credit rating. The appetite for Australian bank paper shows little sign of slowing, with demand expected to be similar to last year, according to investment managers.

images.alt_text: Westpac Banking Corp, Australia & New Zealand Banking Group Ltd (pictured), National Australia Bank Ltd. and CBA sold a record A$43.7 billion of notes domestically in 2016, Bloomberg-compiled data show.

site_title: Australia shares up on rally in materials; NZ at 12-week high
summary: Australia's S&P/ASX 200 Index rose 0.5% to a two-year high, driven by a rally in commodities, particularly metals and mining stocks. Shanghai steel futures jumped 7%, while copper and zinc reached one-month and three-week highs, respectively. Fortescue Metals Group, Rio Tinto, and BHP Billiton surged, with BHP's chairman and CEO holding talks with US President-elect Donald Trump. New Zealand's benchmark index also reached a 12-week high.

site_title: Taiwan scrambles jets, navy as China aircraft carrier enters Taiwan Strait
summary: Taiwan scrambled its jets and navy ships on January 11, 2017, as China's sole aircraft carrier, the Liaoning, sailed north through the Taiwan Strait. The Chinese warships were not trespassing in Taiwan's territorial waters but entered the island's air defense identification zone. Taiwan's defense ministry described the situation as a "surveillance and control" operation to monitor the passage of the Chinese ships. The incident heightened tensions between Beijing and self-ruled Taiwan.

site_title: Hot stock: Natural Cool surges on yet another ouster attempt
summary: Shares of Natural Cool Holdings surged 14.6% to S$0.141 after the company received notice of another attempt to oust its executive chairman, Joseph Ang, in an extraordinary general meeting. This is the second attempt in two months, following a narrow margin of votes in December. The company's board, except for CEO Tsng Joo Peng, is set to be replaced. The move comes after shareholders Ong Mun Wah and Edi Ng called for the ouster attempt.

site_title: China's US$3.8t wealth products reel as bond binge unwinds
summary: China's bond market is experiencing turbulence as banks scramble to avoid losses on wealth management products (WMPs) worth US$3.8 trillion. WMPs, which use leverage to boost returns, are under threat after corporate notes plummeted in the fourth quarter. The risk of a vicious cycle of bond losses, cash shortages, and further debt-market declines has prompted policymakers to step in, with President Xi Jinping pledging to control financial risk. Banks may be forced to use their own money to repay WMP holders, and small banks are expected to face liquidity problems in the next six months.

site_title: Ezion non-executive director trims interest in company
summary: LIM Thean Ee, an independent non-executive director of Ezion Holdings, has sold 120,000 shares, reducing his stake to 0.1% following the company's 69% decline in net profit to US$9.4 million in the third quarter of 2016. Revenue fell 7.4% to US$79.8 million due to lower charter rates and project delays.

site_title: EMAS Offshore posts US$2.2m net loss for Q1 2017
summary: EMAS Offshore Limited, a subsidiary of Ezra Holdings, reported a net loss of US$2.2 million for Q1 2017, a 15% year-on-year decline in revenue to US$42.5 million due to lower demand for offshore support vessels. Loss per share remained flat at 0.01 US cent. The company attributed the decline to continued weakness in the offshore oil and gas industry, with no dividends declared for the period.

site_title: Singapore shares open flat on Wednesday
summary: Singapore shares opened flat on Wednesday, with the Straits Times Index (STI) up 6.41 points or 0.21% to 3,012.43, tracking wins in Europe and Tokyo. The benchmark STI broke through the 3,000-point level for the first time in 14 months on Tuesday, making it one of the best-performing markets in the world year-to-date. Trading volume was 82.2 million shares worth S$95.6 million, with gainers beating losers 67 to 52.

site_title: US dollar mostly steady as traders await Trump news conference
summary: The US dollar remained steady against a basket of major currencies on Tuesday ahead of President-elect Donald Trump's first news conference, which investors fear could disrupt markets with aggressive trade policy and China relations. The dollar index has risen 4% since Trump's win, but muted moves in currency pairs suggest uncertainty. Analysts expect Trump may suggest a weaker dollar policy to boost US manufacturing, and the Mexican peso hit a record low against the US dollar due to worries over Trump's protectionist policies.

site_title: Trump appears to dial back from vaccine skeptic nod
summary: US President-elect Donald Trump's transition team appears to have backed down from naming Robert F Kennedy Jr to lead a committee on vaccine safety, following a meeting between Trump and Kennedy. Kennedy had agreed to head the commission after Trump expressed interest. The decision comes amid growing concerns over Trump's stance on vaccines, with many scientists and health experts criticizing his skepticism. The move may help ease tensions over Trump's administration's approach to vaccine safety.

site_title: Trump directs Republicans to pass Obamacare replacement 'very quickly'
summary: US President-elect Donald Trump has urged congressional Republicans to pass a replacement for the Affordable Care Act (Obamacare) "very quickly or simultaneously" with its repeal. He emphasized that a delay of up to two years to craft a replacement is unacceptable. Senate Republicans plan to vote on a timeline to draft legislation repealing Obamacare, with the House to follow. However, Democrats are calling for Trump to publish his own Obamacare substitute, citing concerns over the lack of a full replacement plan.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks open higher
summary: Hong Kong shares rose for the fifth consecutive day, with the Hang Seng Index increasing 0.15% to 22,779.09. Investors brushed off US market losses and new Trump threats, extending the rally. The Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also edged up, despite losses on Wall Street.

site_title: Wells Fargo looks to rebuild reputation with new compensation plan
summary: Wells Fargo has introduced a new compensation plan for branch bankers, shifting incentives from sales goals to customer service. The plan, aimed at rebuilding the bank's reputation, is longer-term and includes increased monitoring of sales activities. This follows a scandal in 2016 involving aggressive sales targets, resulting in a $190 million fine and restitution. The bank's new CEO has yet to be named, following the resignation of John Stumpf. The move is part of Wells Fargo's efforts to restore trust with customers and team members.

site_title: Fed's Lacker, a proponent for higher rates, to retire in Oct
summary: Richmond Federal Reserve President Jeffrey Lacker, a proponent of higher interest rates, will retire in October, marking the second Fed policymaker to step down this year. Lacker, 61, has led the Richmond Fed since 2004 and has been known for his dissenting votes on policy, including advocating for interest rate increases. His successor will be chosen by a committee formed by the Richmond Fed, which has hired a search firm to aid the process.

site_title: Boeing internal memo warns of engineers layoffs in 2017
summary: Boeing Co issued an internal memo in 2017 warning of impending engineer layoffs as part of a cost-cutting drive due to decreasing aircraft sales and increased competition. The memo listed dozens of job categories eligible for voluntary layoffs in Washington state, southern California, and South Carolina. The reductions were part of a broader effort to ensure the company's long-term future, with Vice President of Engineering John Hamilton stating that "more changes are needed" to address the challenges. The exact number of layoffs was not disclosed.

site_title: Indonesia's first billion-dollar startup races to kill cash
summary: Indonesia's ride-hailing startup Go-Jek has become the country's first billion-dollar startup by offering digital payments through its Go-Pay service, which accounts for over 50% of transactions. The company is now expanding its digital payments to other merchants and aims to double its engineering staff in India. Go-Jek faces competition from local rival Grab and Uber, which are also offering digital payment services. Despite the competition, Go-Jek's popularity of its app gives it a good chance to win in the digital payment market, where Indonesia has a high dependency on cash.

site_title: iPhone maker Hon Hai posts first sales fall amid smartphone woes
summary: Hon Hai Precision Industry Co, the main assembler of Apple's iPhones, posted a 2.8% decline in 2016 sales to NT$4.36 trillion (S$196 billion), its first annual revenue fall since listing in 1991. The decline is attributed to the global smartphone market's worst year on record, with maturing markets and a decelerating Chinese economy. Hon Hai, which accounts for about half of its sales from Apple, is grappling with the smartphone slowdown, with its fate intertwined with Apple's efforts to regain investor confidence.

images.alt_text: Hon Hai Precision Industry Co, the main assembler of Apple Inc's iPhones, recorded its first annual revenue decline after the global smartphone market went through its worst year on record.

site_title: Less salty diets would save millions of lives: study
summary: A study published in the BMJ found that reducing global salt intake by 10% could save millions of lives. Experts estimate that 1.65 million deaths from heart disease occur annually due to excessive salt consumption. Implementing a national policy to reduce sodium intake by 10% over 10 years could be cost-effective, with an average cost of $1.13 per person. This reduction in salt intake could avoid 5.8 million disability-adjusted life years (DALYs) per year, comparable to the cost of preventing cardiovascular disease.

site_title: George Lucas' US$1b 'Star Wars' museum finds Los Angeles home
summary: George Lucas has settled on Los Angeles as the home of his $1 billion storytelling museum, the Lucas Museum of Narrative Art. The museum, initially planned for Chicago, was pulled due to legal challenges and Lucas has since accepted an offer to locate it in Exposition Park in downtown Los Angeles. The museum will feature exhibitions of Lucas' collection of artwork from the "Star Wars" franchise and aims to inspire, engage, and educate a diverse visitorship. Los Angeles Mayor Eric Garcetti expressed his enthusiasm for the project, stating it will have the greatest impact on the community.

images.alt_text: "Star Wars" filmmaker George Lucas has settled on Los Angeles for the home of his US$1 billion storytelling museum, after pulling the project from Chicago last year.

site_title: China to boost beds, staff to handle healthcare strains
summary: China plans to add 89,000 hospital beds and train 140,000 new healthcare staff to address strains on its healthcare system due to its ageing population and the relaxation of the "one-child policy". The country aims to increase its total number of nurses to 4.45 million by 2020 and reduce infant mortality rates and death rates from diseases like cancer and diabetes. China's average life expectancy is expected to rise to 77.3 years by 2020, and its population is forecast to reach 1.42 billion by the end.

site_title: Oil regains some ground after steep slides, but outlook cloudy
summary: Oil prices rebounded slightly on Wednesday, rising 16 cents to $50.98 a barrel, after steep slides the previous day. However, traders remain under pressure due to concerns over Opec's production cuts being poorly implemented and rising US supply. The US Energy Information Administration reported increased drilling activity, boosting crude oil production by 110,000 barrels per day to 9 million per day. High US crude stockpiles and uncertain Opec compliance also weigh on prices, with inventories set to be released later this week.

site_title: Ford affirms 2017 to be less profitable than 2016
summary: Ford Motor Co confirmed it will be less profitable in 2017 than the previous year, with expected adjusted pretax profit of $10.2 billion. The company attributed the decrease to increased spending on emerging opportunities like self-driving cars and rising costs. In contrast, General Motors Co exceeded Wall Street expectations with a forecast of $6 to $6.50 in earnings per share for 2017. Ford also declared a first-quarter regular dividend and supplemental cash dividend. Despite lower profits in 2017, the company expects profit to improve in 2018.

site_title: Canada's PM picks foreign minister for Trump, Russia challenges
summary: Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau appointed Chrystia Freeland as foreign minister, tasked with handling US trade challenges under President-elect Donald Trump. Freeland, a Russia critic, will also maintain responsibility for Canada-US relations. The move aims to position Canada for a new relationship with its largest trading partner, amid Trump's promise to renegotiate the North American Free Trade Agreement (NAFTA). Freeland's views on plutocrats and her past criticism of Vladimir Putin may create awkwardness with the Trump administration, but she believes her views are not "baggage."

site_title: Labour leader Corbyn says UK government 'unfit' to negotiate Brexit
summary: Labour leader Jeremy Corbyn criticized the UK government, led by Prime Minister Theresa May, for being "unfit" to negotiate Brexit, citing a lack of plan. Corbyn accepted the EU referendum result and would fight for continued access to the single market, prioritizing decent jobs and living standards. He warned against giving the government a "free pass" to implement free market policies, and accused them of blaming migrants for public service issues. Corbyn's comments came as the UK economy shrunk for the second month, adding to the government's woes.

site_title: Secretive biotech unicorn Moderna unveils research pipeline, financials
summary: Moderna Therapeutics Inc, a privately funded biotech startup, unveiled its research pipeline, including experimental vaccines, cancer treatments, and cardiovascular therapy. The company has about $1.3 billion in cash reserves and is valued at approximately $5 billion. This move comes after keeping its research pipeline secret, and the company's presentation at the JPMorgan Chase & Co Healthcare Conference in San Francisco marked a significant step in its growth and development.

site_title: Stocks to watch: EMAS Offshore, Natural Cool Holdings, ITE Electric
summary: EMAS Offshore Limited reported a net loss of US$2.2 million for Q1 2017 due to weakness in the offshore oil and gas industry. Natural Cool Holdings announced an EGM to remove executive chairman Joseph Ang and replace the board, following a failed attempt two months prior. ITE Electric Co entered into a share placement agreement to issue 63.4 million new shares to increase resources and pursue acquisition opportunities.

site_title: VW directors knew of emissions scandal earlier: press
summary: Top Volkswagen officials were aware of the company's "dieselgate" emissions-cheating software as early as July 2015, contradicting previous claims made by former group chairman Martin Winterkorn. The software installed on 11 million diesel cars worldwide reduced emissions under testing but released up to 40 times the permitted levels under real driving conditions. VW agreed to a $4.3 billion settlement and faces additional charges, while current group chairman Herbert Diess also knew about the issue. The scandal affects up to 600,000 vehicles in the US and has raised questions about the company's accountability.

site_title: Snapchat picks London as global base outside US
summary: Snap Inc has chosen London as its global base outside the US, praising the UK's creative industries. The decision comes after major investments from Facebook, Google, and Apple in London. The UK is now home to around 75 Snap staff, with plans to add a nearby site. The move is seen as a boost to the UK's technology sector, with the government welcoming the investment. The UK entity will book revenues from customers in the UK and Europe, and the company has over 150 million daily active users worldwide.

site_title: US would 'not necessarily' shoot down North Korean missile: Pentagon
summary: US Defense Secretary Ashton Carter stated that the US military would not necessarily shoot down a North Korean intercontinental ballistic missile if the country's leader attempts to test one. Carter suggested it might make sense to watch such a test without taking action. North Korean leader Kim Jong Un announced the country is in the final stages of testing the missile.

site_title: Skepticism about Opec deal hits oil prices
summary: Oil prices fell sharply for the second straight session on Tuesday, driven by skepticism about the Opec agreement to cut output. The US oil benchmark West Texas Intermediate lost $1.14 to end at $50.82 a barrel. Analysts expressed concerns that Iraq's record oil exports in December may indicate the country will not adhere to the production cuts, which went into effect on January 1. The decline in oil prices also contributed to a mixed global stock market, with the Dow retreating from a 20,000-point milestone.

site_title: Fed 2016 profits to US Treasury fall as interest to banks jumps
summary: The Federal Reserve's 2016 profits to the US Treasury are expected to fall to $92 billion, down $5.7 billion from 2015, due to a decrease in earnings on Treasury bonds and mortgage-backed securities. The interest paid to major banks jumped to $12 billion, as the Fed's rate hikes boosted reserves held by commercial banks. Lawmakers have criticized the Fed for paying interest to large institutions, while the central bank argues it's the most effective way to raise rates.

site_title: US Marines send F-35 stealth fighter squadron to Japan
summary: The US Marine Corps has deployed a squadron of 10 F-35B fighter jets to Japan, marking the first operational overseas deployment for the aircraft. The deployment comes amid concerns over the aircraft's technical glitches and soaring cost overruns, with the total development and acquisition price tag now at $379 billion. President-elect Donald Trump has also expressed interest in alternative fighter jets, tweeting that he wants Boeing to price out a comparable F-18 Super Hornet. The F-35's lifespan is projected to cost up to $1.5 trillion, despite its touted benefits of speed and advanced sensors.

site_title: Euro may not exist in 10 years, France's Macron says
summary: French presidential candidate Emmanuel Macron warns that the euro may not exist in 10 years if Paris and Berlin fail to reform the single currency union, citing its favoritism towards Germany at the expense of weaker member states. Macron proposes a euro zone budget to finance growth-oriented investments and extend financial assistance to struggling member states, but faces resistance from German Chancellor Angela Merkel and Finance Minister Wolfgang Schaeuble.

site_title: Beijing's diplomatic offensive at risk of backfiring
summary: Taiwan's President Tsai Ing-wen made a phone call to congratulate President-elect Donald Trump on his electoral triumph, despite the US and China having no diplomatic relations. China views this as a provocation, threatening to cut ties with Taiwan if it continues to engage with the US. Tsai made stops in the US during her Central American visit, raising concerns about Beijing's diplomatic offensive being backfired. China's Foreign Minister Wang Yi is currently touring Europe, setting the tone for an EU-China summit later this month.

site_title: Europe: FTSE hits new record as miners help shares inch up
summary: Britain's FTSE 100 index reached a new record high of 7,284.81 points, driven by gains in retailers and mining stocks, which rose 3.3% to offset weaker financials. Retailers Morrisons and Tesco also saw significant gains, while mining stocks such as Anglo American, Rio Tinto, and BHP Billiton benefited from higher copper prices. However, Just Eat fell 6.9% after missing full-year order growth estimates, and the insurance and banking sectors declined.

site_title: Fund that made money on Treasuries says rally is about to end
summary: A fund manager at Eastspring Investments, Nicholas Ferres, has taken his holdings of 30-year US Treasuries off the table due to a potential end to the current rally, citing the Federal Reserve's interest rate tightening and inflation expectations. The rally in Treasuries has been attributed to President-elect Donald Trump's spending plans and forecasts for Fed rate increases. Ferres now favors emerging market currencies and equities, which he believes offer more attractive valuations and will benefit from improving global growth.

site_title: US: GM surges on strong outlook; S&P 500 ends flat
summary: General Motors rose 3.7% on a strong 2017 earnings forecast, boosting the US stock market. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Index ended flat, while the Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 0.2%. Large banks and tech stocks rose, with Illumina and Chipotle Mexican Grill also gaining. The Dow's failure to reach 20,000 points was attributed to cautious investor sentiment, with some analysts citing a "step back from risk-taking."

site_title: Ivanka Trump to step down from businesses
summary: Ivanka Trump, wife of President-elect Donald Trump, will step down from the Trump Organisation and her own company, US Media reported on January 10, 2017. The move is believed to comply with ethics laws as she takes on her role as first daughter and wife of the new White House special advisor, Jared Kushner.

site_title: US indicts Ban relatives with bribery
summary: US prosecutors have indicted the relatives of former UN Secretary General Ban Ki Moon on bribery charges. Joo Hyun Bahn and his father Ban Ki Sang are accused of trying to bribe a Middle Eastern official over a $800 million building sale in Hanoi. US citizen Malcolm Harris is also charged with receiving a $500,000 bribe and pocketing it for personal luxuries. The indictment alleges a complex scheme involving the attempted bribery of a government official.

site_title: FHA to cut fees, lowering rates for first-time home buyers
summary: The US Department of Housing and Urban Development (HUD) announced a 0.25% cut in annual mortgage-insurance premiums for the Federal Housing Administration (FHA), benefiting first-time home buyers with little down payment. The reduction, effective January 27, will lower the annual cost for most borrowers to 0.60% of the loan balance, saving new FHA-insured homeowners an average of $500 this year. The move may ease the burden of rising interest rates, but could also hurt bond investors and private insurers.

site_title: Wheat glut may not last much longer with farmers planting less
summary: A global wheat glut may be ending, with prices expected to rise in 2017 for the first time in five years. Despite record harvests and a surplus of 252.1 million tonnes, farmers are planting less due to low prices and potential weather risks. Global consumption is at an all-time high, and analysts predict a 3.5% increase in global wheat consumption. Prices are forecast to reach US$4.50 a bushel in 2017 and US$4.81 in 2018, according to Bloomberg's survey of 13 analysts.

site_title: Indian online realty services providers PropTiger, Housing.com to merge
summary: Indian online real estate services providers PropTiger and Housing.com will merge to create the country's largest player in the segment. News Corp and SoftBank Group Corp will invest US$55 million in the combined entity. Housing.com has been struggling with losses and a management shake-up, and its CEO Jason Kothari will leave the company after the deal. PropTiger co-founder and CEO Dhruv Agarwala will head the joint entity. The merger aims to accelerate consolidation in the sector.

site_title: SEC toughens Green Label criteria for paper products - and ups certification cost
summary: The Singapore Environment Council (SEC) has updated the Green Label criteria for paper products, increasing certification costs and targeting the causes of the annual haze in Singapore and the region. The new criteria considers how pulp and paper companies manage peatland and fires during operations. This change aims to promote eco-friendliness and sustainability in the industry. The updated criteria will take effect this year, affecting companies that produce paper products.

images.alt_text: It will cost pulp and paper manufacturing companies more to slap the Green Label - a badge of eco-friendliness - on their products from this year, with new criteria unveiled on Tuesday by the Singapore Environment Council (SEC).

site_title: Alps' holiday snow shortage leaves skiing addicts in withdrawal
summary: A severe snow shortage has affected the Alps, leaving skiing enthusiasts in withdrawal. The region experienced its driest December in over 100 years, with many resorts seeing a 25% drop in visitors. However, recent storms have brought snowfall to parts of Europe, and forecasts predict further storms in coming days. Climate change experts warn that this may be a sign of things to come, with snowfall lines expected to rise 500-700 meters and the snow season shortening by four to eight weeks. Some skiers are losing patience, with some considering giving up the sport altogether.

site_title: Norway's biggest life insurer adopts 'scared of everything' stance
summary: Norway's largest pension fund, Kommunal Landspensjonskasse, has adopted a cautious investment strategy, being "scared of everything" due to global uncertainty. The fund, managed by KLP, has a value-adjusted return of 4.4% last year and allocates 67% to fixed income, 20% to stocks, and 13% to real estate to meet its 2.6% guaranteed return. KLP's chief financial officer, Aage Schaanning, believes this approach is paying off, particularly with rising protectionism and a potential US-led trade war. The fund's focus on fixed income and risk management is seen as a smart move in uncertain market conditions.

site_title: ISOTeam bags S$22.7m worth of new projects
summary: ISOTeam, a Singapore-listed building maintenance firm, secured S$22.7 million worth of new projects, including a renewable energy installation job worth S$6.3 million. The projects, which include repairs, redecoration, and addition/alteration works, are expected to be completed by June 2018. This marks ISOTeam's third renewable energy project and its single largest project to date. The company's shares rose 3.797% to close at 41 Singapore cents following the announcement.

site_title: Crowdfunding platform CoAssets sets up real estate subsidiary
summary: Singapore-based crowdfunding platform CoAssets has incorporated a real estate subsidiary, CoAssets Real Estate (Care), to provide a full spectrum of real estate services. The subsidiary will focus on serving CoAssets' 70,000 registered users and attract more real estate crowdfunding projects. Care will also enable companies to liquidate collateralized real estate assets in Singapore and the region. This move is part of CoAssets' growth strategy and venture into secured crowdfunding, aiming to protect users amidst economic uncertainty.
