site_title: Trump's adversarial policy stance a deal-breaker
summary: President-elect Donald Trump's foreign policy stance is seen as a deal-breaker due to its adversarial nature. Trump has unveiled six contradictory strategies, including befriending Russia, challenging China's one-China policy, and antagonizing European allies. His approach is characterized by provocative rhetoric and a tendency to distort facts, raising concerns about his ability to effectively lead the US as a global superpower. Critics argue that Trump's worldview, as outlined in his 2000 book, is flawed and lacks the distinction of character and strategic thinking of former President Franklin D. Roosevelt.

site_title: Smoking costs global economy $1t a year
summary: A study by the World Health Organization (WHO) and the US National Cancer Institute estimates that smoking costs the global economy over $1 trillion annually and is responsible for an estimated 6 million deaths per year. By 2030, this number is projected to increase to 8 million deaths annually, with 80% occurring in low- and middle-income countries. The study concludes that tobacco use is the single biggest preventable cause of death globally and that governments can effectively reduce tobacco use and associated deaths through policies such as hiking tobacco taxes and implementing smoke-free policies.

site_title: Investors talk about 2017 and Trump
summary: Investors are reflecting on the 2016 market performance, which saw a 10% gain in the Standard & Poor's 500 stock index, largely due to Donald Trump's unexpected election victory. Contrarian investors, like Anthony Scaramucci, attribute their success to betting against conventional wisdom and taking advantage of Trump's policies, such as tax cuts and infrastructure spending. Meanwhile, socially responsible investors like Jerome Dodson prioritize companies with strong social and environmental values. Experts, including Damien Courvalin, predict continued oil price gains, driven by strong demand and normalized inventories, despite the impact of Trump's policies, which are expected to take years to affect market supply and demand.

site_title: More benefit if insurer pays out from buffer of guaranteed bonus
summary: A letter to the editor criticizes The Business Times for focusing on Prudential's high buffer of non-guaranteed returns without mentioning life insurers that guarantee payouts. The writer suggests that guaranteed bonuses would provide more certainty for policyholders, as insurers would be required to pay out the guaranteed amount. This approach could be seen as more desirable than Prudential's non-guaranteed buffer, which allows insurers to choose when to pay out.

site_title: Construction trade body hands government its first-ever Budget wish list
summary: The Singapore Contractors Association (SCAL) has submitted its first-ever Budget wish list to the Finance Ministry, seeking fiscal support measures to ease the construction sector's financial pressures. The sector experienced a 1.3% growth in 2016 but entered a technical recession in the second half of the year. SCAL is requesting support to help firms reposition themselves for the future economy, including measures to delay the increase in foreign worker levy and extend the Productivity and Innovation Credit scheme. The association also proposed separate budget provisions for workplace safety and incentives for collaborations between large and small local companies.

site_title: That Dow Jones 20,000 milestone could be a warning sign
summary: The Dow Jones Industrial Average closed at 19,963.80, just shy of the 20,000 milestone. Historically, previous milestones have not been met with enthusiasm, with significant declines following the initial celebration. The Dow reached 100 in 1906, but it took 36 years to sustain the level. The milestone of 10,000 was also met with a subsequent decline, only to be regained after eight years. The author warns investors to be cautious and not to get caught up in euphoria, as the next milestone may mark the beginning of a new, potentially more sober chapter.

site_title: Japan's struggling rural towns lure tax from other wards with beef, beer
summary: Japan's Furusato Nozei (Hometown Tax) system, which allows residents to redirect part of their taxes to support rural areas, has become a lucrative way for municipalities to attract revenue. While intended to help rural towns, the program is driven by the promise of gifts such as local produce, beer, and beef. The system has drawn criticism, with Tokyo's Setagaya Ward estimated to lose 1.6 billion yen in tax revenue, while Miyakonojo in Miyazaki prefecture attracted 4.2 billion yen. The program's popularity has raised concerns about its impact on urban areas and the effectiveness of its rural support efforts.

site_title: STI surges past 3,000 points to 14-month peak
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) broke through the 3,000-point mark for the first time in 14 months, becoming one of the best-performing markets globally in 2017. The index surged due to expectations of a strong earnings season, signs of inflation, and potential easing of monetary policies by the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS). The rally saw 29 out of 30 component stocks gain, with only Golden Agri-Resources falling slightly.

site_title: Core Central Region leads in resale condo market
summary: The Core Central Region (CCR) in Singapore's resale condo market outperformed the rest of the island, with a 1.8% year-on-year price increase in 2016, according to SRX data. Resale volumes jumped 52.5% to 2,048 units, surpassing the 24.2% increase in the city fringe region and 18.2% in the suburbs. This is attributed to increased demand, attractive packages, and developers offering deferred payment schemes. CCR prices are expected to continue showing resilience due to its lower supply, with prices more likely to stabilize rather than rise.

site_title: Top Malaysian banker sees ringgit rebound
summary: Malaysia's ringgit is expected to rebound from a 19-year low as the central bank implements measures to boost demand for the currency. According to Lee Kok Kwan, a top banker, the ringgit can appreciate quickly, with past gains of up to 7.4% in a short period. The currency has lost about 22% since 2015, making it the worst-performing in emerging Asia.

site_title: STI regains 3,000 level despite weak Wall St
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) gained 24.48 points to 3,006.02, marking its sixth consecutive rise and the first time since early November 2015 that it closed above 3,000. Despite a weak Wall Street and sharp oil price fall, the index's gain was not broad-based, with an advance-decline score of 256-201. Analysts attribute the market's resilience to support from banks, and some predict market volatility in 2017 due to US policy changes under President Trump.

site_title: 'Davos of the East' losing its shine in Gujarat
summary: Gujarat's "Vibrant Gujarat" investors meet, once touted as the "Davos of the East," is losing its luster after Narendra Modi left as state chief minister. The event, now in its fourth year, faces questions over implemented investment pledges, with only 8% of proposed investments from 2003-2011 being implemented. The state has lost its top spot in the World Bank's ease of doing business rankings and is no longer the easiest place to do business in India. The summit, which starts this week, is expected to see over $526 billion in investment pledges, but skepticism is growing about how much is actually converted into action.

site_title: Banks a bright spot in dull Singapore stock market
summary: Singapore's banking sector is best-positioned among emerging markets to benefit from rising interest rates, according to Citi Private Bank strategist Ken Peng. The sector is expected to see growth in dividends and interest rates, but the overall Singapore stock market offers limited opportunities. Peng stated that the market "really depends a lot on investors' interest in dividends" and a rising interest rate environment.

site_title: Surprisingly bullish bids swamp year's first housing land tender
summary: Bullish bids flooded the first housing land tender of 2017 in Singapore, with construction company Low Keng Huat beating 10 competitors to secure a residential site along Perumal Road. The unexpectedly high bid, valued at around S$38 million, has sparked debate among property consultants over whether it signals market optimism or developers' need for land. The strong showing by construction companies suggests a need for landbanking, but also points to market optimism.

site_title: Pacific Radiance re-enters Middle East with US$68m in multi-year contracts
summary: Pacific Radiance, a Singapore-listed offshore support vessel owner-operator, has secured US$68 million in multi-year contracts with an undisclosed client, re-entering the Middle East market. The five vessels, previously off-hire, have started work on production campaigns. Despite the recent oil price rebound, industry expert David Palmer cautions that day rates for OSVs will remain soft due to declining offshore rigs in 2017. Pacific Radiance has taken steps to ensure its business remains sustainable, including transferring key operations to a joint venture in Mexico.

site_title: Plunge in crude sends Asian energy chips diving while pound struggles
summary: Asian energy firms suffered losses after a 4% drop in crude oil prices, with PetroChina and CNOOC declining 2% and 1.5% respectively. The decline was driven by concerns over Iraq's commitment to oil production cuts. The losses also affected regional stock markets, with Sydney and Shanghai down 0.9% and 0.3% respectively. Meanwhile, the pound struggled at three-month lows against the dollar due to Brexit concerns, and the yen extended gains against the dollar amid fears of a overdone US dollar rally.

site_title: German utilities face tough 2017 as power rally looks set to stall
summary: German utilities RWE and EON face a challenging 2017 due to a power price rally expected to fade this year, along with a multi-billion-euro nuclear clean-up bill. The companies are under pressure to adapt to the renewable energy revolution, with planned spending cuts and job losses seen as necessary. Analysts expect wholesale electricity prices to stay stable, with cutting costs a priority. RWE and EON have provisioned for unexpected nuclear waste storage costs, and investors are concerned about the impact of Germany's exit from nuclear power by 2022.

site_title: Alibaba takes big step offline with US$2.6b Intime deal
summary: Alibaba is leading a bid to take department store chain Intime Retail Group Co private for $2.6 billion, deepening its integration with brick-and-mortar stores. The deal aims to modernize China's $4.5 trillion traditional retail industry and strengthen Alibaba's foothold in physical retail. Control of Intime will allow Alibaba to explore ways to integrate online and offline shopping. The offer represents a 42% premium over Intime's last closing price, with Alibaba and Intime's founder paying $1.85 each for shares they don't already own.

site_title: Thai king orders charter amendment in rare intervention
summary: Thailand's new king, Maha Vajiralongkorn, has ordered sections of the country's draft constitution to be rewritten due to clauses concerning royal powers. The monarch's private secretary has sent a letter to the government requesting discussion on the issue. This is a rare intervention by the monarch in the kingdom's politics, and the revision process is expected to take several months. The move is seen as a significant development, given the limited formal powers of the constitutional monarchy but its significant political clout behind the scenes.

site_title: EU proposes greater privacy protection to boost digital economy
summary: The European Union proposed broadening privacy protection in electronic communications to promote a digital single market worth tens of billions of euros. The proposal includes covering new providers such as WhatsApp, Facebook Messenger, and Skype under the existing legislation. The EU aims to enact the changes by May next year. This move aims to balance the need for a digital economy with greater consumer protection and data privacy.

site_title: Alibaba's Ma meets Trump, pledges to bring one million jobs to US
summary: Chinese e-commerce giant Alibaba has pledged to bring one million small US businesses onto its online platform, Tmall, over the next five years, aiming to create one million US jobs. Alibaba executive chairman Jack Ma met with US President-elect Donald Trump, discussing ways to support small businesses, particularly in the Midwest. The initiative is part of Alibaba's efforts to tap the Chinese market, which has been a target of Trump's campaign. Despite mixed success for some foreign retailers on Tmall, Alibaba's platform generated $15 billion in sales for US brands last year.

images.alt_text: US president-elect Trump told reporters he and Mr Ma had a "great meeting" and would do great things together. Mr Ma called Mr Trump "smart" and "open-minded".

site_title: China IPO fundraising poised to spike as govt pushes debt reduction
summary: China's domestic initial public offerings (IPOs) are expected to surge in 2017, with fundraising volumes forecast to rise 50% to 225 billion yuan, the highest level in six years. The government's push for debt reduction and increased investor demand for new listings are driving the increase. The China Securities Regulatory Commission is expected to approve more listings, which could help mitigate the rapid post-IPO price surge on Chinese bourses. Analysts predict that the increased supply of new shares will suppress the post-IPO price surge, benefiting investors.

images.alt_text: New listings last year rose an average 430 per cent in their first month of trading, the highest since at least 1999.

site_title: Made-in-America the must-have marque for the moment
summary: US auto executives showcased new models and technology at the Detroit auto show, amid pressure from President-elect Donald Trump to repatriate manufacturing jobs. Top executives emphasized US production credentials to avoid antagonizing Trump, who has threatened to penalize automakers selling Mexican-built cars in the US. Companies highlighted investments in US production, such as Ford and General Motors, to counter Trump's rhetoric and maintain a strong US presence in the automotive industry.

site_title: Xi will be China's first head of state to attend Davos forum
summary: China's President Xi Jinping will become the country's first head of state to attend the World Economic Forum (WEF) in Davos, Switzerland, in January. The forum will focus on public anger over globalization and the upcoming US presidency of Donald Trump. Trump's trade policies and promises to hike tariffs against China and Mexico are expected to dominate the debate. This event marks a significant shift in China's engagement with global economic forums, highlighting Xi's growing influence on the world stage.

site_title: Mediacorp veteran to head mm2 Asia
summary: Mediacorp veteran Chang Long Jong has been appointed as the new group CEO of mm2 Asia Limited, effective April 3, 2017. He will oversee business operations and source new opportunities. Chang will leave his current role at Mediacorp as deputy CEO and chief customer officer. Melvin Ang, executive chairman of mm2 Asia, will continue as CEO until Chang's appointment. The company's counter closed at 49 cents, up 0.5 cent, following the announcement. Chang brings three decades of industry experience, including channel management and content development.

site_title: Sluggish economy? Distributors still upbeat about motor show
summary: The Singapore Motorshow 2017 is taking place from Jan 12-15, with distributors remaining upbeat despite the sluggish economy. The event, organized by the Motor Traders Association of Singapore, features a mix of performances and a large array of brands. Distributors expect a good turnout, citing attractive prices and the popularity of new models, such as the Subaru Impreza and Honda NSX. However, some predict a muted affair due to high COE premiums and the post-Chinese New Year rush.

site_title: Facebook hit with stolen VR technology claims
summary: Facebook is facing a $2 billion dispute over Oculus VR's stolen technology. ZeniMax alleges a star employee recruited by Oculus purloined intellectual property, including the "holy grail" behind the Oculus Rift. Facebook acquired Oculus in 2014 with "full awareness" of the alleged theft. The dispute may involve Facebook co-founder Mark Zuckerberg testifying in a Dallas courtroom. The case centers on Oculus's origin story, which claimed a young entrepreneur developed the technology in his parents' garage, when in reality, it was allegedly stolen from ZeniMax.

site_title: New York City's closest nuclear power plant to shut by 2021
summary: New York Governor Andrew Cuomo announced the shutdown of Entergy's Indian Point nuclear power plant by 2021 due to safety concerns and operational issues. The plant, which supplies about a quarter of New York City's power needs, will be replaced by alternative power sources with negligible carbon emissions. The shutdown is 14 years ahead of schedule, with Unit 2 closing by 2020 and Unit 3 by 2021. Cuomo emphasized the need for a safe evacuation route in the event of a disaster and has been developing contingency plans to replace the power supplied by Indian Point.

site_title: Mars to buy pet hospital company for US$7.7b
summary: Mars Inc. announced a US$7.7 billion acquisition of VCA, a pet hospital company, to expand its petcare business. VCA, with 800 animal hospitals, a lab business, and dog day-care franchises, will operate as a separate business unit under Mars Petcare. The deal adds US$2 billion in revenue and makes Petcare Mars' largest division, contributing 90% of the company's sales. VCA's CEO, Bob Antin, will remain CEO after the acquisition, citing the benefits of joining Mars, including access to technology and resources.

site_title: China's biggest money fund bracing for more liquidity shocks
summary: China's biggest money-market fund, Yu'EBao, is bracing for liquidity shocks in 2017 due to the government's efforts to curb risk in the financial system and support the sliding yuan. The fund's manager, Wang Dengfeng, plans to hold extra cash to protect against rising redemptions and is being more choosy with who it lends to. This comes as China's investors face higher credit risk, with the number of onshore bond defaults quadrupling last year and the central bank tightening monetary policies. The fund's assets stood at 800 billion yuan at the end of September, with a seven-day return of 3.37% and a cash allocation of over 90%.

site_title: Fifa approves 48-team World Cup for 2026
summary: FIFA's ruling council has unanimously approved an expansion of the World Cup to 48 teams in 2026, a major change to the tournament since its 1998 boost to 32 teams. The format features 16 groups of three nations, a tweet from FIFA's official account said. Critics oppose the move, citing concerns over quality of play and player exhaustion. European clubs' association reiterates its opposition, while FIFA president Gianni Infantino believes the expansion will improve the body's finances and boost inclusion in the sport.

site_title: Yahoo to be renamed 'Altaba' after selling Internet business
summary: Yahoo to be renamed 'Altaba' after selling its Internet business to Verizon for $4.8 billion. The company plans to rename itself after the deal closes, with a 15% stake in Alibaba and 35.5% stake in Yahoo Japan remaining. Over half of the current board members, including CEO Marissa Mayer, will step down. The new board will include Jeffrey Smith, Tor Braham, and Eric Brandt, among others. The name change is contingent on the deal's success, which is uncertain due to hacking episodes and Verizon's weighing of options.

site_title: Is Singapore losing its investment shine?
summary: India and Singapore have revised their double tax avoidance agreement, putting Singapore on par with Mauritius in terms of benefits. The new protocol provides for source-based taxation of capital gains, aligning with the India-Mauritius agreement. Investors in Singapore had expected more benefits, such as exemptions for tax residents holding less than 10% investments in Indian companies. The revised agreement also fails to reduce the withholding tax on interest to 7.5%, a rate offered in the India-Mauritius agreement. The changes are seen as a disappointment to the investor community in Singapore, who had hoped for more concessions.

images.alt_text: Skyline of Mumbai. The new tax treaty has Singapore on a par with Mauritius and, in certain scenarios, worse than Mauritius, even though the Republic is a larger trading partner.

site_title: Shipping sector on course for recovery
summary: Container freight rates have started to recover, reaching a 20-month high in January, driven by consolidation within the shipping sector, particularly the bankruptcy of Hanjin. Rates have risen 62% since August, with the Drewry World Container Index reaching a five-year high of $1,770 per 40ft container. Industry experts attribute the recovery to liner companies' efforts to consolidate service provision, redeliver chartered tonnage, and reduce demand for vessels, while charter owners are being forced to take action to recover. A gradual recovery in earnings is expected, but persistent supply-side obstacles and new vessel orders may pull rates back down.

site_title: China's clean air bid scares rivals in duel over dirty fuel
summary: China has imposed new curbs on the amount of sulphur in vehicle fuels, reducing it to about a fifth of the previous standard, putting it on par with Europe. This move is expected to boost China's exports of low-quality diesel to markets with laxer standards, potentially threatening South Korea and Japan's diesel exports to Indonesia and Malaysia. China's diesel exports jumped over 50% in September to a record, while South Korea's sales to the Philippines dropped 33% in 2016. China is likely to overtake South Korea as the region's top diesel exporter by 2020, according to analysts.

site_title: Valeant selling US$2.1b in assets to pay down debt
summary: Valeant Pharmaceuticals International Inc has agreed to sell US$2.1 billion in assets to pay down its US$30 billion debt. L'Oreal SA will purchase three skincare brands (CerAve, AcneFree, and Ambi) for US$1.3 billion, while Sanpower Group Co will acquire Dendreon Pharmaceuticals for US$820 million. Proceeds from the sales will be used to permanently repay term-loan debt. The sales are part of Valeant's efforts to streamline its businesses and ease its debt burden.

site_title: Towards transparency for a clearer picture of the palm-oil supply chain
summary: The palm oil industry, worth an estimated $88 billion by 2022, faces challenges due to deforestation, climate change, human-rights abuse, and community invasion. To address these issues, transparency and traceability within the supply chains are crucial, with certification by the Roundtable on Sustainable Palm Oil (RSPO) being a key step. However, only 17% of Certified Sustainable Palm Oil (CSPO) is RSPO certified due to voluntary certification and low demand. Consumers must demand more information on product origin to drive the adoption of CSPO, and companies must prioritize sustainability to mitigate climate change and unethical labor practices.

site_title: US small-business optimism up the most since 1980
summary: US small businesses reported the highest level of optimism since 1980, with the National Federation of Independent Business's (NFIB) index reaching 105.8 in December, its highest since 2004. The index rose 7.4 points from the previous month, with 73% of the increase attributed to improved views on sales and the economy. Business owners are more likely to expand, increase investment, and hire, driven by optimism over President-elect Donald Trump's economic plans.

site_title: Vard wins deals worth 600m kroner to build ferries in Norway
summary: Vard Holdings secured contracts worth 600m kroner (S$100.5m) to build two LNG-powered ferries for Torghatten Nord in Norway. The ferries, designed for environmentally friendly operations, can accommodate 180 cars and 550 passengers. Construction will take place at Vard Brevik in Norway, with delivery scheduled for 2018. The ferries will feature hybrid gas-electric propulsion to reduce fuel consumption and emissions, meeting energy efficiency requirements. This marks Vard's first deal with Torghatten Nord and its second LNG-powered ferry delivery, following a 2000 model.

site_title: 'Hollyweed' sign prankster arrested
summary: Los Angeles police arrested Zachary Cole Fernandez, 30, on a misdemeanor charge for altering the letters of the Hollywood sign to read "Hollyweed" on New Year's Day. Fernandez voluntarily surrendered to authorities with his attorney. The prank was a notable incident, but no further information is provided in the article.

site_title: Carlyle said to target US$5b for new US real estate fund
summary: Carlyle Group LP plans to raise an eighth US real estate fund targeting $5 billion in the first half of 2017, according to people with knowledge of the matter.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: CapitaLand Mall Asia has signed a shopping mall management contract in Xi'an, China, for La Botanica township, its second in western China within five months. The five-storey mall, with 50,000 sqm of gross floor area, is expected to be operational in 2019. This contract follows CapitaLand's previous mall management deal in Chengdu.

site_title: Abbott releases cyber patches for heart implants after US probe
summary: Abbott Laboratories released a software patch for its St Jude heart implants after a US probe revealed potential cyber attacks on the devices. The patch addresses vulnerabilities that present the greatest risk to patients and reduces the risk of unauthorized access. The FDA and DHS confirmed that St Jude devices were vulnerable to hacking, but no cyber attacks have been reported. The patch was released five months after the government launched an investigation into the issue, and Abbott acquired St Jude in September. A lawsuit against short-selling firms MedSec and Muddy Waters remains pending.

site_title: FX 'cartel' traders said to face charges of rigging
summary: The US Justice Department is poised to charge members of a chat group known as "The Cartel" with colluding to rig the US forex market. The group, which included former top traders at JPMorgan, Citigroup, and Barclays, allegedly used instant messages to share confidential customer information and coordinate price fixing. Senior dealers Richard Usher, Rohan Ramchandani, Chris Ashton, and Matt Gardiner face potential extradition and prosecution. This move follows a long-running investigation into currency rigging and comes as the Obama administration prioritizes holding individuals accountable for corporate crime.

site_title: Chilling fate for polar bears as world warms
summary: US federal wildlife officials warn that polar bears are at risk of extinction due to climate change, citing the need for significant greenhouse gas emissions reduction to combat global warming. A report released by the Fish and Wildlife Service states that polar bears are threatened under the Endangered Species Act and that their long-term prognosis is uncertain without decisive action. The report's message may be met with skepticism by President-elect Donald Trump's administration, which has expressed doubt about climate change and its impact on polar bears.

site_title: World Bank sees global growth improving to 2.7% in 2017
summary: The World Bank forecasts global economic growth to improve to 2.7% in 2017, up from 2.3% in 2016, driven by a modest acceleration in advanced economies. US growth is projected at 2.2% in 2017, but expected to decline to 2.1% in 2018 and 1.9% in 2019. However, uncertainty about policy direction in major economies clouds the outlook.

site_title: Startup funding gets off to robust start in 2017
summary: Three new funds have debuted in Singapore, including Marvelstone Ventures, East Ventures, and InseadAlum Ventures, with a combined total of S$30 million in funding. Marvelstone Ventures has S$20 million in funds and will invest in Smart City technologies, while East Ventures has raised US$27.5 million to back 20 startups in South-east Asia. InseadAlum Ventures has raised S$1 million to invest in global seed-stage startups co-founded by Insead alumni. Meanwhile, Legalese, a startup aiming to automate legal services, has snagged S$600,000 in angel funding to develop its web application.

site_title: Norway prepares for controversial FM radio shutdown
summary: Norway is set to shut down its FM radio network in favor of digital radio, becoming the first country to do so. The move aims to provide better sound quality, more channels, and improved coverage. However, many Norwegians, particularly older generations, are opposed to the switch, citing concerns over cost and the need for new radio equipment. The transition began in Nordland on January 10, 2017, with plans to complete it by the end of the year, making millions of old radios obsolete.

site_title: UOB economists flag two key challenges for Singapore SMEs
summary: Singapore SMEs face two key challenges: changes in the digital space and the rise of the Millennial consumer and labor force. According to UOB economists, these areas are more pressing concerns than the global economic slowdown and policy changes in the West. Despite this, Asia is seen as a promising region for growth, with Asean countries having lower government debt and emerging as a hub for regional integration. UOB expects two main fronts to be addressed in the Committee on the Future Economy report, including structural slowdown and innovation, with a focus on transforming businesses to bring new value and manage costs.

site_title: Felda Global Ventures may well become an election stock - again
summary: Felda Global Ventures (FGV), Malaysia's largest oil palm plantation operator, has seen its stock value plummet by over 60% since its initial public offering in 2012, with the company on track to report full-year losses for 2016. The company's poor performance has raised concerns about its governance and management, particularly after a government-linked fund, Employees Provident Fund (EPF), sold its shares in FGV, suffering losses. However, with the upcoming general election, FGV's new leadership has vowed to rationalize the business and cut costs, aiming to return the company to its former glory and potentially sway key voters, Felda settlers.

site_title: Sales of investment-grade bonds surge despite long-term fears
summary: US investment-grade corporate debt sales surged to nearly $60 billion last week, rebounding from a slow fourth quarter. Despite the strong start, analysts expect sales to fall short of 2016 and 2015 levels. Banks led the rebound, with over $35 billion in sales, while foreign finance firms also made significant issuances. The trend may be short-lived due to uncertainty over the new administration and rising interest rates, which could diminish the appeal for opportunistic issuers. Analysts expect $110 billion in high-grade corporate bond sales in January, with potential for continued strong volume through the first quarter.

site_title: Boustead Projects secures contract for R&D centre
summary: Boustead Projects has secured a contract for a new research and development (R&D) centre, Continental Building Phase 3, in partnership with Continental Automotive Singapore. The centre will be developed for Continental Corporation, a global automotive supplier. The project is part of Boustead Projects' Continental Building Phases 1 & 2, which have been completed. The exact terms of the contract were not disclosed.

site_title: US$ dips as investors eye Trump; sterling slides again
summary: The US dollar edged down for a second day, slipping 0.2% to 101.77 on the dollar index, as investors awaited US President-elect Donald Trump's first news conference, citing uncertainty over his trade policies and potential impact on the economy. Sterling also slid, hitting a 10-week trough against the dollar, while the euro rebounded to its highest levels this year. Analysts attributed the market's risk-off tone to Brexit uncertainty and Trump's press conference, which may affect trade policy and interest rates.

site_title: Wholesale inventories post biggest rise in two years
summary: US wholesale inventories rose 1% in November, the largest gain in two years, suggesting inventory investment will support economic growth in Q4. This increase reverses a 0.1% decline in October, and exceeds the previously reported 0.9% gain. The Commerce Department's revised data indicates a stronger-than-expected rise in inventory levels, which could boost economic growth in the final quarter of 2016.

site_title: US charges VW executive with fraud over emissions scandal
summary: US authorities have charged Oliver Schmidt, a former VW executive, with conspiracy to defraud the US over the company's diesel emissions cheating scandal. Schmidt, who was general manager of VW's environmental office in Michigan, was accused of concealing the cheating device from regulators. He was ordered held pending a hearing and faces up to 30 years in prison if convicted. VW is nearing a $3 billion settlement with the Justice Department and Environmental Protection Agency, with a potential $4 billion fine. The company has been accused of deliberately misleading regulators about the cheating device.

site_title: 'La La Land' sweeps nominations at Baftas
summary: "La La Land" leads the nominations for Britain's Bafta film awards with 11 nods, including best film and actor/actress. "Arrival" and "Nocturnal Animals" also received nine nominations. Ryan Gosling and Emma Stone are nominated for their roles, while Damien Chazelle is nominated for best director and best original screenplay. The awards ceremony will take place on February 12 in London.

site_title: Life-long learning subsidy totals S$400m a year
summary: The Singapore government provides S$400 million annually in direct training subsidies for lifelong learning, with 40% going towards individual-initiated training. Education Minister Ong Ye Kung announced this in parliament, highlighting the shift in funding support from the government to individuals, reflecting the rise of contract workers and freelancers. Singapore's participation in structured training is 62%, higher than the OECD average, and 82% of employers provide training to staff, with the SkillsFuture Credit program promoting lifelong learning.

site_title: IEV Holdings suspends production trial from CLS-1TW in Cilamaya Structure
summary: IEV Holdings has suspended production trials from its CLS-1TW well in Cilamaya Structure due to a need for a change in well completion to enable chemical stimulation and sidetracking to an up-dip location. The production trial, which began on October 30, 2016, has produced 2,191 barrels of oil. The company will suspend the well pending preparation and approval from Pertamina for a workover.

site_title: Old Chang Kee sets up JV to expand brand in UK
summary: Old Chang Kee has entered into a joint venture agreement with 13 Wonders to expand its operations in the UK. The joint venture company, Old Chang Kee UK, will have an initial capital of £500,000 and will focus on food retail outlets and product distribution in London. Old Chang Kee and 13 Wonders will hold 60% and 40% of the shareholding interest in OCK UK, respectively. This move aims to build the brand in the UK market.

site_title: Oil spending up again after 3 years of downsizing
summary: The oil industry is expected to boost spending for the first time in three years after slashing nearly half a million jobs globally during the downturn. According to Graves & Co, more than three-quarters of the eliminated jobs came from oilfield service providers, drilling contractors, and equipment makers. This increase in spending is a significant development, marking the end of a three-year period of downsizing.

site_title: Trump's Indonesia partner deepens bond with theme park, track
summary: Indonesian tycoon Hary Tanoesoedibjo is investing up to $1 billion in two Trump-brand resorts in Indonesia, solidifying his partnership with the Trump Organization. To strengthen the alliance, MNC Group is building a MotoGP course and a Disneyland-like theme park at its 3,000-hectare resort in Lido, West Java. This move aims to fend off potential rivals and is open to more joint ventures given the existing relationship and access. The developments are part of MNC's expansion plans, with Tanoesoedibjo committed to cementing the Trump Organization's presence in Indonesia.

site_title: Share transfer saves HK buyer from local taxes in purchase of HK$670m mansion
summary: A Hong Kong buyer purchased a HK$670 million mansion using a share transfer, avoiding local taxes. The buyer, an experienced Hong Kong resident, acquired the property through an offshore company, saving HK$100.5 million in taxes. This is the latest example of wealthy Hong Kong individuals finding ways to circumvent restrictions on surging property prices. The sale highlights the ongoing issue of property tax evasion in Hong Kong, where thousands of properties remain held in shell companies to avoid taxes.

site_title: Blockchain to shape future of finance
summary: Blockchain, cognitive computing, and cloud technologies are expected to significantly impact the finance industry in the digital age, according to banking and tech executives. IBM's Ginni Rometty and Bank of America's Cathy Bessant emphasized the need for insights and trusted transactions, respectively. Blockchain is seen as a transformative technology, while biometrics and cloud computing will also play key roles. However, cybersecurity risks are a major concern, with executives warning of the potential for up to 50 billion connected devices to pose a threat.

site_title: ITE Electric proposes a S$2.97 million share placement exercise
summary: ITE Electric Co. proposes a S$2.97 million share placement exercise to issue 63.4 million new shares at 4.68 Singapore cents per share to three companies and 17 individuals. The company aims to improve cash flow and pursue business opportunities, aligning with its proposed name change to "Sunrise Shares Holdings Ltd." The placement price represents a 10% discount to the volume weighted average price of 5.2 Singapore cents. The net proceeds will be used for general working capital purposes.

site_title: QAF to invest S$21.5m to expand in the Philippines
summary: QAF Limited plans to invest S$21.5 million to expand its bread production and distribution business in the Philippines. The company aims to spin-off and transfer its existing Cebu plant, set up a new Mindanao plant, and acquire a plot of land in Luzon for a future plant. The projects are expected to be completed by 2018 and this year, respectively. This expansion is driven by growing demand in the Philippines.

site_title: Employers must see the value in hiring and retaining older workers
summary: Singapore has raised its re-employment age to 67, requiring employers to offer older workers re-employment until they turn 67 from July 1. If employers cannot re-employ, they can transfer the worker to another employer or offer an Employment Assistance Payment (EAP) of up to S$10,000. The changes aim to foster a mindset shift that ageing is not a burden but an opportunity, promoting the value of older workers in the workforce. The move is expected to open up new opportunities for workers and address the tight labour market.

site_title: Property agency industry shrinks further in tepid market
summary: Singapore's property agency industry has shrunk by 6.1% to 1,286 licensed agencies as of January 1, 2017, with a 3% drop in registered agents to 28,397. The industry faces intense competition and technological disruptions, leading to consolidation and closures. Despite this, some top agencies saw significant growth in gross commissions, with ERA Realty and PropNex reporting 20% or more increases. Industry experts attribute the decline to a tepid market, with a need for agencies to adapt to changing consumer preferences and invest in technology to stay relevant.

site_title: Mongolia makes no bones about crushing fossil theft
summary: Mongolia is cracking down on the theft of ancient fossils, with the government launching a campaign to reclaim relics held in foreign museums and private collections. The country has lost thousands of fossils since American explorer Roy Chapman Andrews discovered dinosaur eggs nearly a century ago. The Mongolian government has recovered around 30 fossils from smugglers and some collectors have returned their specimens voluntarily. However, the American Museum of Natural History in New York is reluctant to return Chapman Andrews' specimens, citing concerns about Mongolia's ability to manage the collection. The government hopes to one day return the fossils to their original resting place in the Mongolian desert.

site_title: US ready for a trade deal under new administration: UK foreign minister
summary: British Foreign Minister Boris Johnson stated that the US administration under President-elect Donald Trump is eager to negotiate a free trade deal with Britain. Johnson reported finding "huge goodwill" and understanding for the UK in the US, with Trump's team expressing a desire to complete the deal quickly. Johnson's comments follow a meeting with senior US advisers to Trump, where he emphasized the urgency of the situation.

site_title: Xi Jinping to become first Chinese president to attend Davos
summary: President Xi Jinping will become the first Chinese president to attend the World Economic Forum in Davos, Switzerland, from January 15-18. He will attend the forum's annual meeting alongside billionaires and politicians on January 17. China seeks a greater role in global affairs, particularly in reshaping global trade rules amid a more isolated US under President-elect Donald Trump. Chinese Vice-President Li Yuanchao attended the Davos meeting in 2016, while Premier Li Keqiang led the country's delegation in 2015. This visit highlights China's growing global influence.

site_title: Pacific Radiance re-enters Middle East with US$68m contracts
summary: Pacific Radiance, a mainboard-listed OSV owner-operator, secured US$68 million in multi-year contracts in the Middle East. Five of its vessels, previously off-hire, have started work, increasing fleet utilization. This re-establishes the company's presence in the region, with production campaigns in the Arabian Gulf. The contracts add to the group's overall earnings and demonstrate its ability to secure long-term contracts in the market.

site_title: Singapore O&G co-founder sold 4m shares for S$4.5 million
summary: Singapore O&G co-founder Dr Lee Keen Whye sold 4 million shares at S$1.125 each, resulting in a S$4.5 million gain. This sale cut his stake in the company to 17.09% from 18.77%. The counter's price dropped 0.5% to finish at S$1.165.

site_title: Vard wins S$100m contracts to build passenger ferries in Norway
summary: VARD Holdings has secured contracts worth S$100.5 million to build two LNG-powered car and passenger ferries for Torghatten Nord in Norway. The ferries, designed for environmentally friendly operations, can accommodate up to 180 cars and 550 passengers. The contract is valued at approximately 600 million Norwegian Krones, with construction expected to begin soon.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares end higher
summary: Malaysia's Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 4.15 points to close at 1,672.05, driven by 414 gainers and 368 losers. The index saw 2.68 billion lots valued at RM2.11 billion traded.

site_title: US a tough market for foreign carmakers: IHS Markit
summary: Foreign carmakers face significant challenges in establishing a lasting presence in the US market, with only a few companies, such as Kia, having successfully penetrated the market since its entry in the mid-1990s. Despite record sales of 17.5 million units in 2016, foreign brands have struggled to gain traction, with many experiencing declining sales or failure. New entrants, such as Fiat, Volkswagen, and PSA Group, aim to capitalize on the US market's growth potential, but must overcome hurdles including a mature market, limited dealership network, and economic patriotism.

site_title: US: Stocks flat as market awaits earnings
summary: US stocks remained flat early Tuesday as investors await major corporate earnings releases later in the week. Analysts express concerns that earnings growth may not meet expectations, citing tax cuts and other policies. The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 0.2%, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq composite Index lost 0.1% and edged up less than 0.1%, respectively. Notable stocks included Chipotle Mexican Grill's 14.7% sales increase and Valeant Pharmaceuticals' 10.2% jump after selling skincare brands.

site_title: Paytm startup hits goldmine when India junked 500- and 1,000-rupee notes
summary: Paytm, India's largest digital payments company, has benefited significantly from the government's decision to scrap 500- and 1,000-rupee banknotes in 2016. The company has signed up over 20 million users, making it the largest digital payments company in India, and is expected to reach 300 billion rupees (S$6.31 billion) in the mobile wallet market by 2022. Founder Vijay Shekhar Sharma is pushing for growth, despite facing challenges from rivals and security concerns, and is gearing up to collect deposits and sell mutual funds and insurance in March.

site_title: Boustead Projects secures R&D centre contract
summary: Boustead Projects secured a contract to develop an R&D centre for Continental Automotive Singapore, a hub owned by Continental Corporation. The centre will be built adjacent to the existing Continental Building within Kallang iPark. This is the third phase of development by Boustead Projects in the area.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks decline as yen strengthens, Trump speech awaited
summary: Japan's Nikkei share average fell 0.8% to 19,301.44 due to a strengthening yen, which weighed on exporter shares. Despite this, hopes for US President-elect Donald Trump's upcoming speech on stimulus helped curb losses. The broader Topix and JPX-Nikkei Index 400 also declined 0.7% and 0.8% respectively.

site_title: Seoul: Won rebounds, stocks weaken
summary: The South Korean won rebounded by 1.1% to 1,194.6 per dollar after a 1.3% fall the previous session. This follows markets' anticipation of US President Donald Trump's economic policies. In contrast, South Korean shares declined 0.2% to 2,045.12 points.

site_title: SCAL makes recommendations for Budget 2017
summary: The Singapore Contractors Association (SCAL) has submitted recommendations to the Ministry of Finance for Budget 2017, focusing on reducing business costs, workplace safety and health provisions, and preparing the industry for Singapore's future economy. Construction firms face challenges including tightening manpower, rising costs, and stiffer regulatory controls. SCAL's recommendations aim to help the industry navigate these headwinds and prepare for a changing economic landscape.

site_title: China vows to contain corporate debt levels as inflation heats up
summary: China vowed to contain high corporate debt levels and cut excess coal and steel capacity amid rising inflation, aiming for balanced economic growth. The country's credit growth has been "very fast" and poses a risk of a banking crisis or slower growth. China's corporate debt has soared to 169% of GDP, prompting efforts to restructure debts and limit non-financial firms' debt levels. Leaders may accept a growth target of 6.5% this year, giving room to focus on debt reduction and prevent asset bubbles.

site_title: China car sales climb at fastest pace in 3 years on tax cut
summary: China's passenger vehicle sales surged 15.9% in 2016 to 23.9 million units, the fastest pace in three years, driven by a tax cut on small-engine automobiles. The government's move boosted deliveries from automakers like General Motors and Great Wall Motor. However, analysts project a slowdown in demand due to rising protectionist rhetoric and an increase in the sales tax to 7.5% in China. Global automakers face a slowdown in demand in the world's two biggest vehicle markets.

site_title: Metro reports sluggish Christmas sales at Real and Media-Saturn
summary: Metro, a German retailer planning to split into two companies, reported sluggish Christmas sales, with a 0.6% decline in the October-December quarter to 17 billion euros. Weakness at Real hypermarkets and consumer electronics sales fell 1.7% and were flat, respectively. The cash-and-carry business saw a 0.7% rise in sales. This result fell short of analysts' expectations.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary:
Here is a 100-word or less summary of the article content:

Three Singaporean companies received analyst updates. Singapore Medical Group (SMG) is expected to maintain its BUY recommendation despite entering Vietnam's private healthcare market with a US$1.6 million investment. Thai Beverage's spirits segment is expected to remain resilient, and the company is expected to see steady growth in the beer segment. Mermaid Maritime has been upgraded to a BUY recommendation due to the cancellation of its tender rigs and the removal of financing risks, with a target price of S$0.24 implying a 29% upside. Analysts maintain their recommendations for these companies, citing regional expansion strategies and diversification plans.

site_title: Tens of thousands attend Iran ex-president Rafsanjani's funeral
summary: Tens of thousands of Iranians attended the funeral service for former president Akbar Hashemi Rafsanjani at Tehran University, led by supreme leader Ayatollah Ali Khamenei. Despite their differences, the service was attended by high-ranking politicians and featured a special Islamic service. Rafsanjani will be buried inside the crypt of Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini, the founder of the Islamic revolution. The event was marked by a show of unity, with black banners and posters praising both Rafsanjani and Khamenei.

site_title: mm2 Asia names new CEO
summary: FILM production company mm2 Asia Limited has appointed Chang Long Jong as its new group CEO, overseeing business operations and sourcing new business opportunities. He will leave his current role as Mediacorp's deputy CEO and chief customer officer, where he managed major media assets. Chang will be responsible for the production division and business development at mm2 Asia.

site_title: DP World targets inland India with logistics centres
summary: DP World, a Dubai-based port operator, plans to invest $1 billion in India to address logistics issues. The investment will focus on new and upgraded ports and inland logistics centers to improve the transportation of goods across the country. Sultan Ahmed, DP World's chairman, cited poor infrastructure and growing demand as major bottlenecks, stating that India needs more production facilities and ease of connection rather than more ports. The project's timeline was not specified, but Ahmed emphasized the need for the government to streamline project approvals to speed up progress.

site_title: Europe: Stock markets climb at open
summary: Europe's main stock markets rose at the start of trading on Tuesday, with London reaching a record high due to a weak pound. London's FTSE 100 gained 0.3% to 7,257.02 points, while Frankfurt's DAX 30 and Paris CAC 40 indices also increased by 0.2% and 0.1% respectively. The rally was driven by mining and healthcare shares, amid US-EU trade talks in focus.

site_title: VW sales top new record despite dieselgate
summary: Volkswagen sold 10.3 million cars worldwide in 2016, setting a new record despite the ongoing "dieselgate" scandal. Sales increased 3.8% globally, driven by strong growth in China and Europe. The company has set aside €18 billion to cover the scandal's fallout, but experts predict the final bill will be higher. Volkswagen has responded to the crisis by shifting focus to clean-energy vehicles and electric cars, aiming to be a world leader by 2025. Despite the scandal, customers appear to have largely shrugged off the controversy, and sales of its flagship own-brand cars reached nearly 6 million units.

site_title: STI regains 3,000 mark lost in Nov 2015
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) regained the 3,000 mark for the first time since November 2015, closing at 3,006.02 on Tuesday. The six consecutive rise was driven by a 24.48-point gain, with turnover reaching $1.3 billion. However, the advance-decline score of 256-201 indicated the gain was not broad-based. The STI had not managed to regain the 3,000 level since November 4, 2015, when it closed at 3,039.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Resale condo prices in Singapore rose 0.4% month-over-month in December 2016, according to SRX. ISOTeam secured S$22.7m worth of new building maintenance projects. SCAL made recommendations for Budget 2017, including reducing business costs and improving workplace safety. Meanwhile, global news included Vietnam's surprise over US tariff announcements, China's slowing GDP growth, and a UK economy shrinkage.

site_title: Low Keng Huat makes highest bid for popular site at Perumal Road
summary: Low Keng Huat made the highest bid for a residential site at Perumal Road, Singapore, with a tendered sale price of S$174.08 million, exceeding expectations of S$800-850 per square foot per plot ratio. The construction firm's bid surpassed other bidders, including China Construction and Allgreen Properties, which came in second and third with bids of S$166.7 million and S$161.5 million respectively. The site, with a 99-year lease term, offers good transport connectivity and commercial amenities.

site_title: Obama says goodbye with last presidential speech in Chicago
summary: Barack Obama is set to deliver his final presidential speech in Chicago, where he first accepted the presidency eight years ago. The speech, aimed at lifting supporters after Donald Trump's surprise victory, will be attended by the First Lady Michelle Obama, Vice-President Joe Biden, and his wife Jill Biden. The speechwriter notes that the address will focus on Obama's vision for the country's future, rather than being an anti-Trump speech, and will be a "statesman-like" yet true to his personality.

site_title: China 2016 economic growth expected around 6.7%
summary: China's economic growth in 2016 was expected to reach 6.7%, according to Xu Shaoshi, director of the National Development and Reform Commission. The growth was driven by consumption accounting for 71% of China's GDP, boosted by government spending, housing rally, and record bank lending. However, this led to a significant increase in debt. The target of 6.5-7% growth was met, but the country's economic growth is expected to slow, putting pressure on policymakers.

site_title: Taiwan: Stocks down; strong Dec exports data caps losses
summary: Taiwan's stocks fell 0.1% on Tuesday, tracking shaky overseas markets, but rebounded after strong December export data showed a four-year high. The electronics subindex climbed 0.3%, while the financials subindex dropped 0.6%. Taiwan's exports in December reached a four-year high, fuelling hopes for continued strong exports through the first quarter despite global trade protectionism concerns.

site_title: China's coal, steel sectors under more pressure to cut output this year: govt
summary: China's steel and coal sectors will face pressure to cut output this year, with the government aiming to tackle polluting industries and excess capacity. Director of the National Development and Reform Commission, Xu Shaoshi, said the government will ensure stable supplies despite cuts. In 2016, thermal coal prices more than doubled after mines were forced to close or cut output to meet utilities' winter needs. The government's efforts follow a 2016 crackdown on polluting industries, resulting in a significant increase in thermal coal prices.

site_title: Latest Earnings
summary: Singapore's NTT DC Reit's public offer for its data center assets was 9.8 times oversubscribed. US stocks opened lower amid fresh tariff threats from the Trump administration towards Canada. Creative Technology warned of potential revenue shortfall in the second half, mirroring the first half's operating loss. London's Heathrow Airport plans to increase fees for a £10 billion upgrade. Indonesia detained an employee of Trafigura in a graft case worth 285 trillion rupiah. OCBC announced Tan Teck Long as its new CEO, replacing a DBS veteran. MAS and PBOC are strengthening green and transition finance cooperation.

site_title: Market capitalisation
summary: NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer received a 9.8 times oversubscription. US stocks opened lower amid a fresh tariff salvo on Canada by the Trump administration. Creative Technology warned of potential revenue and operating loss for H2, citing H1 losses. London's Heathrow is considering higher fees for a £10 billion upgrade. Meanwhile, Indonesia detained an employee of Trafigura in a 285 trillion rupiah graft case. Singapore's stock market saw a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data, with MAS and PBOC set to deepen cooperation in green and transition finance.

site_title: Australia: Shares hit by first 2017 loss
summary: Australian shares fell 0.8% on Tuesday, marking their first loss of the year, due to profit-booking and poor sentiment from US financial stocks. The S&P/ASX 200 index closed at 5,760.7. Financial shares, including the 'Big Four' banks, were the worst performers, with ANZ recording a 1.5% loss. Energy shares were pressured by weaker oil prices, while miners saw support from a firm Aussie dollar and higher base metal prices.

site_title: Jolie, Pitt to use private judge in divorce: media
summary: Angelina Jolie and Brad Pitt have agreed to use a private judge in their divorce proceedings to maintain the privacy of their children and family. The couple cited "irreconcilable differences" after an incident on a private plane, where Pitt was reported to have lost his temper in front of their children. Jolie sought full physical custody with visitation rights for Pitt, and the split followed their marriage in 2014. The joint statement comes after a judge previously denied Pitt's request to seal all documents and proceedings.

site_title: Philippine exports fall for first time in three months but imports surge
summary: The Philippines' exports declined 7.5% in November, marking the first decline in three months, due to sputtering demand from major markets like Japan and the US. However, imports surged 19.7% in November, the highest in six months, driven by increases in iron and steel, and transport equipment. This resulted in a wider trade deficit of $2.57 billion, despite the country's robust domestic economic activity, which reached an annual 7.1% growth in the third quarter.

site_title: Ryan, Trump team discuss border tax at Capitol Hill meeting
summary: US House of Representatives Speaker Paul Ryan met with President-elect Donald Trump's transition team to discuss a border tax plan, which would tax imports while exempting US export revenues. The meeting examined two provisions: a border-adjustability measure to boost US manufacturing and a "territorial" tax proposal to end US taxation on foreign profits of US-based multinationals. Experts believe the plan could help meet Trump's pledge to boost manufacturing jobs, but it also raises concerns about consumer prices and potential WTO challenges.

site_title: South Korea says consumption sluggish, govt aims to stabilise produce prices
summary: South Korea's finance ministry reported sluggish consumption, potentially slowing economic recovery momentum. To address this, the government aims to stabilize produce prices by expanding supply from existing stockpiles. This move aims to prevent price spikes ahead of the Lunar New Year holiday. The ministry also seeks to import eggs to combat a bird flu shortage, ensuring retail availability before the holiday.

site_title: Seoul: Won recovers, stocks inch down; listening out for Trump
summary: The South Korean won rose 0.5% to 1,202.9 against the US dollar, rebounding from a sharp fall in the previous session. Despite this, South Korean shares remained flat, with the Kospi index down 0.2%. Investors are awaiting US President-elect Donald Trump's press conference on Wednesday, which is expected to reveal his economic stance and impact the won's value. Shares of Hotel Shilla dropped 3% due to concerns over decreased Chinese tourism, while Hyundai Motor gained 1.3%.

site_title: Thousands dash through Japan shrine in "Lucky Man Run"
summary: Thousands of men and women participated in the annual "Lucky Man Run" at a Shinto shrine in Japan, with the winner, 21-year-old Takashi Suzuki, receiving a year's worth of good fortune. The tradition, dating back to the 14th century, involves a 230-meter dash through the shrine's courtyard, followed by a blessing and a barrel of sake. Approximately 5,000 people took part in the event, with Suzuki and two other runners receiving the blessing and prize. The winner's good fortune is believed to last for a year, according to Shinto tradition.

site_title: Gold near 5-week highs on weaker US dollar, Brexit concerns
summary: Gold prices rose to near a five-week peak, driven by a weaker US dollar and Brexit concerns. Spot gold was up 0.3% at $1,184.56 an ounce, while US gold futures remained steady. Analysts attributed safe-haven buying to comments on the UK's potential trade relations with the EU after Brexit. However, longer-term price outlook remains uncertain, with rising US interest rates and geopolitical tensions expected to impact gold prices.

site_title: Xi to lead delegation of China's wealthiest executives to Switzerland
summary: President Xi Jinping will attend the World Economic Forum in Switzerland, becoming the first Chinese head of state to address the event. He will lead a delegation of China's wealthiest executives, including Alibaba Group's Jack Ma and Dalian Wanda Group's Wang Jianlin. The trip comes as China seeks to shape the global economic order, following US President Donald Trump's "America First" platform. Xi aims to tout China's role in the global economy and highlight signature projects such as the Asian Infrastructure Investment Bank and the One Belt, One Road initiative.

site_title: China's Dec producer prices accelerate at fastest pace in over 5 years
summary: China's producer prices surged 5.5% in December, the largest increase in over five years, driven by rising coal and raw material prices. Consumer inflation rose 2.1%, missing expectations, as food prices increased at a slower pace. The acceleration in producer prices suggests the Chinese economy is stabilizing, fuelled by stronger factory activity and domestic demand. This may contribute to stronger global inflation expectations in 2017, prompting economists to raise their forecast for global growth and inflation.

site_title: Blockchain, cognitive computing and cloud to shape future of finance
summary: Blockchain, cognitive computing, and cloud technologies are expected to significantly shape the finance industry in the digital age. IBM CEO Ginni Rometty believes cognitive computing will give finance firms a competitive edge, while Bank of America's Cathy Bessant notes that unlocking insights from vast data is the key to success. Financial institutions are also investing in blockchain technology, which IBM describes as a transformative technology for trusted transactions. Biometrics and cloud computing are also being adopted to enhance customer security and speed up project testing.

site_title: Trump's man in Indonesia to boost ties with theme park, track
summary: Indonesian tycoon Hary Tanoesoedibjo, owner of MNC Group, is developing two resorts in Lido, West Java, in partnership with the Trump Organisation, with plans to spend up to $1 billion. The partnership includes a 700 ha resort, a golf course, and a country club, as well as a new theme park and a MotoGP track. Tanoesoedibjo aims to diversify his business, reducing his reliance on the media sector to 40% of revenue in the next five years. The project is seen as a key move to strengthen ties between Indonesia and the US under President-elect Donald Trump.

site_title: O&M signs 3-year partnership with EDB to enhance modern marketing services
summary: Ogilvy & Mather (O&M) has signed a 3-year partnership with the Singapore Economic Development Board (EDB) to enhance modern marketing services. The initiative includes data analytics, customer engagement, marketing automation, UX design, and digital media. The partnership aims to develop a strong pipeline of Singaporean talent and foster Asia-led innovation from O&M's Singapore office. It also seeks to create solutions for O&M's global clients. The collaboration will run for three years, focusing on enhancing modern marketing services.

site_title: South Korea prosecutor undecided on whether to seek arrests of Samsung execs
summary: South Korea's special prosecution office has not yet decided whether to seek arrest warrants for two Samsung Group executives, Choi Gee-sung and Chang Choong-ki, amid a widening investigation into President Park Geun-hye's political scandal. The executives were summoned for questioning on Monday and are now considered witnesses, not suspects. The prosecution's decision may impact the investigation into the scandal, which has led to widespread criticism of President Park. The outcome of the investigation remains uncertain, with the prosecution's next move expected to be announced soon.

site_title: Asia: Asian energy firms hit by tumble in oil prices
summary: Asian energy firms experienced significant losses after a decline in oil prices, with crude contracts falling nearly 4% on Monday. Iraq's oil minister's statement on record exports and potential non-compliance with OPEC's output cuts raised concerns about the deal's effectiveness. This led to losses for regional energy firms, including Woodside Petroleum, BHP Billiton, Inpex, PetroChina, and CNOOC, with some markets, such as Hong Kong, experiencing gains despite the overall decline.

site_title: China's yuan firms as US dollar broadly weaker
summary: China's yuan strengthened against the US dollar for the second consecutive day, trading 90 pips firmer at 6.9240 per US dollar by midday. The People's Bank of China set the midpoint rate at 6.9234 per US dollar, and traders sold US dollars for yuan amid the euro's rise. Despite this, traders expect the yuan to fall over the year, with a 7-per-dollar level seen as a potential threshold. The offshore yuan traded 0.71% firmer than the onshore spot, but the Thomson Reuters/HKEX Global CNH index fell to 96.28, weaker than the previous day's 96.76.

site_title: Breakaway Senate Republicans push to delay Obamacare repeal
summary: A group of five moderate Senate Republicans, including Senators Bob Corker, Rob Portman, Susan Collins, Bill Cassidy, and Lisa Murkowski, have proposed delaying a bill to repeal Obamacare until March, potentially forcing the party's leadership to reconsider their plan. The delay would give the incoming administration more time to outline its priorities. This move comes as Democrats oppose a straight repeal bill, and Republicans aim to adopt a budget resolution that would allow an Obamacare repeal bill to pass with 50 votes. The proposal could impact the party's ability to deliver on President-elect Donald Trump's campaign promise.

images.alt_text: Senators Bob Corker of Tennessee. A breakaway group of five moderate Senate Republicans pushed Monday to delay a bill repealing Obamacare until March - potentially enough pressure to force the party's leadership to comply.

site_title: Facebook's virtual reality foray derided as 'fanciful story'
summary: Facebook is facing a $2 billion dispute over its acquisition of Oculus VR, alleging the company used stolen technology and promoted a false origin story. The dispute centers on claims that Oculus's groundbreaking headset was developed using misappropriated knowledge. The case, which may involve Facebook co-founder Mark Zuckerberg, has escalated into a messy US court battle.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open flat on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened flat on Tuesday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 0.260 points to 1668.360. Gainers outnumbered losers 69 to 65, and trading volume reached 116.78 million lots worth RM38.77 million.

site_title: Yahoo chief Marissa Mayer to leave company board after Verizon sale
summary: Yahoo chief Marissa Mayer will leave the company's board after its merger with Verizon, but is expected to remain with Yahoo's core business. The merger includes selling Yahoo's internet operations for $4.8 billion, separating it from its stake in Alibaba. Mayer will remain CEO, and the board will be reduced to five members. The company's recent large-scale hacks may affect the deal and Mayer's role, with Verizon awaiting further news on the investigation.

site_title: China graft drive has punished 1.2m: watchdog
summary: China's anti-graft campaign has punished nearly 1.2 million people, with 2,600 fugitives extradited or repatriated and 8.6 billion yuan in assets recovered. The Central Commission for Discipline Inspection (CCDI) aims to continue the campaign, pledging to "keep the crushing momentum against corruption." However, the number of corruption cases reported to the watchdog decreased in 2016, with 57,000 self-confessions and 410,000 officials punished, including 76 at the ministerial level or above. The campaign is seen as a political purge under President Xi Jinping.

site_title: Honda, govts unveil C$492 million in Canada plant upgrades
summary: Honda Motor Co Ltd has announced a C$492 million investment in its Canadian manufacturing plant, with C$408 million coming from direct Honda commitments and C$84 million from government pledges. The three-year project includes upgrades to assembly lines for Civic and CR-V models, a new paint shop with lower greenhouse gas emissions, and loosened rules for the Automotive Innovation Fund to allow non-repayable contributions. The upgrades aim to improve efficiency and reduce emissions at the plant, which produces vehicles for Canada and the US market.

images.alt_text: Honda Motor Co Ltd will spend C$492 million (S$534.3 million) on upgrades to its Canadian manufacturing plant, including C$84 million in government commitments.

site_title: Hong Kong seaside mansion bought for estimated HK$670m
summary: A Hong Kong buyer purchased a 7,891 sq-ft mansion at Repulse Bay for an estimated HK$670 million, avoiding property taxes by using an offshore company. The buyer, described as an experienced local, purchased the property through a shell company to avoid the 15% base stamp duty. This method, which has been used by more than half of Hong Kong's homes worth over HK$20 million, allows buyers to save significant tax when reselling. The sale is the latest example of wealthy Hong Kong residents finding ways to cool surging property prices.

site_title: Australian police say they are helping with 1MDB investigations
summary: Australian Federal Police (AFP) are assisting international law enforcement agencies in investigating companies linked to 1MDB, a Malaysian sovereign wealth fund at the center of a global money laundering scandal. The AFP is evaluating allegations of breaches of proceeds of crime laws by Australian companies, citizens, and residents. The US Department of Justice has filed civil lawsuits seeking to seize $1 billion in assets allegedly siphoned off from 1MDB. Malaysia's Prime Minister Najib Razak has denied wrongdoing, and 1MDB has also denied any wrongdoing.

images.alt_text: The Australian Federal Police (AFP) said on Tuesday they are working with international law enforcement agencies to investigate companies associated with Malaysia's scandal-hit sovereign wealth fund.

site_title: Om Puri, star in Bollywood and the West, dies at 66
summary: Veteran Indian actor Om Puri, 66, died on Friday in Mumbai due to cardiac arrest. He appeared in over 300 films, mainly in India, but gained recognition in the West for his roles in "East Is East" (1999) and "My Son, the Fanatic" (1997). Puri received a BAFTA nomination for his work in the British comedy "East Is East." His contributions to Bollywood and the West will be remembered.

site_title: Malaysia joy at Fifa goal of the year award
summary: Malaysian midfielder Mohamad Faiz Subri won Fifa's Goal of the Year award for his swerving free-kick in the Malaysian Super League in February. The goal received 60% of the global vote, making Faiz the first Asian to win the award. Faiz accepted the accolade at the Zurich ceremony, thanking his coach, team, and family. This achievement is a significant milestone for Malaysian football, showcasing the country's football talent on the global stage.

site_title: Australia, NZ dollars extend rally, sterling on the slide
summary: The Australian and New Zealand dollars rose against the US dollar, with the Aussie dollar at US$0.7380 and the New Zealand dollar at US$0.7037. This follows the British pound's worst selloff in five months due to US profit-taking and political jitters. The Aussie dollar faces chart resistance around US$0.7386, while the New Zealand dollar faces a hurdle around US$0.7060.

site_title: Crowdfunding platform CoAssets incorporates real estate subsidiary
summary: Singapore-founded CoAssets, a real estate crowdfunding platform, has incorporated a wholly owned subsidiary, CoAssets Real Estate (Care), as part of its growth strategy. Care will provide a range of real estate services, including marketing, sales, and valuation, and enable companies to liquidate real estate assets in Singapore and the region. The move is aimed at expanding CoAssets' services and capabilities.

site_title: ISOTeam wins S$22.7m worth of new building maintenance projects
summary: ISOTeam, a CATALIST-listed building maintenance firm, has secured S$22.7 million worth of new projects for 2017-2018. The contracts include repairs, redecoration, and addition projects, as well as a S$6.3 million renewable energy installation job for 150 blocks. The projects are expected to be completed by June 2018 and include notable works at Tekka Centre and 106 Watten Estate Road.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open lower as yen picks up
summary: Tokyo stocks opened lower on Tuesday, falling 0.37% due to a stronger yen and a retreat on Wall Street. The Nikkei 225 index dropped to 19,382.14, while the Topix index of all first-section shares fell 0.27%. This marks a reversal of the previous day's gains, as investors reacted to increased uncertainty over US trade policies.

site_title: Resale prices of condos rose 0.4% m-o-m in Dec: SRX
summary: Resale condo prices in Singapore rose 0.4% month-over-month in December 2016, according to SRX Property. Prices climbed 1.2% in suburbs, eased 0.5% in city-fringe, and remained unchanged in prime areas. The overall resale price index for private apartments was 0.1% higher year-over-year, while resale volumes dropped 21.7% month-over-month to 484 units. This marks the seventh consecutive month of price increases, with prices still 7.8% below the 2014 peak.

images.alt_text: Resale prices of non-landed private homes in Singapore rose 0.4 per cent month on month in December 2016 based on SRX Property's flash estimate. This follows a 0.5 per cent gain in November 2016.

site_title: Singapore shares open flat on Tuesday
summary: Singapore shares opened flat on Tuesday, with the Straits Times Index down 8.61 points or 0.29% to 2,972.93, tracking losses in the US and Tokyo. Around 46.4 million shares changed hands, with losers beating gainers 70 to 40. The decline was attributed to global market losses.

site_title: Asia: Shares track US retreat while bonds climb
summary: Asian stocks retreated amid declines in banks and energy shares, tracking US losses, while bonds climbed. The yen rebounded and gold rose for the fifth time in six days, while the South Korean won rallied following its worst day since November. The Dow Jones Industrial Average failed to reach the 20,000-point milestone, and anxiety over political developments has crept back into markets. The US crude oil price fell, and commodity prices including copper rose, while Australian and New Zealand debt paced Treasury gains.

site_title: Australian retail sales soften in November, still set for strong Q4
summary: Australian retail sales grew 0.2% in November, a disappointing decline from the 0.5% increase in October. Despite this, sales in October and November were 1.5% faster than the previous quarter's first two months, indicating a possible turnaround in consumer spending. This is a welcome sign for the economy, which contracted in the July-September period. The data suggests that consumers are starting to tighten their spending, but overall, the retail sector remains strong.

images.alt_text: Australian shoppers tightened their purse strings in November after three months of splurging, but retail sales were still running well ahead of the previous quarter and pointing to a much-needed pick up in consumer spending.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Natural Cool Holdings, CapitaLand, ISOTeam
summary: Natural Cool Holdings halted trading due to a stock price surge and revoked board's share issuance mandate. CapitaLand secured a shopping mall management contract in Xi'an, China, its second in western China. ISOTeam secured S$22.7 million in new projects, including a renewable energy installation job, for completion between January 2017 and June 2018.

site_title: Trump names son-in-law as senior presidential adviser
summary: US President-elect Donald Trump named his son-in-law Jared Kushner as senior White House adviser, despite concerns over Kushner's lack of political experience and wealth. Kushner, a property developer and publisher, will serve without a salary and will be flouting legal and ethical guidelines. This move raises questions about the administration's transparency and potential conflicts of interest.

site_title: Alibaba takes another step offline with HK$19.8b Intime deal
summary: Alibaba Group Holding Ltd is leading a HK$19.8 billion bid to take department store operator Intime Retail Group Co private, further integrating its online and offline retail operations. Alibaba, led by CEO Daniel Zhang, will pay HK$10 for Intime shares, a 42% premium over the last closing price. This deal follows Alibaba's aggressive expansion into traditional retail, with plans to revamp China's US$4.5 trillion industry by allowing stores to buy directly from suppliers based on real-time demand and inventory.

site_title: Mexico says will negotiate with Trump 'without fear'
summary: Mexico's new foreign minister, Luis Videgaray, vows to negotiate with the US without fear, despite President-elect Donald Trump's anti-immigrant rhetoric and trade threats. Videgaray's comments come after Trump's vow to renegotiate the North American Free Trade Agreement (Nafta) with Mexico and Canada.
