Mexico's exports of cars to the US rose 9.6% in December, despite concerns over Trump's protectionist policies. The Mexican government may take legal action at the World Trade Organization if tariffs exceed 2.5% on light vehicles and 25% on pickup trucks.

site_title: FHA to cut fees, lowering rates for first-time home buyers
summary: The Obama administration reduced annual mortgage-insurance premiums charged by the Federal Housing Administration (FHA) by a quarter of a percentage point, lowering rates for first-time home buyers with little money for a down payment. The change, taking effect January 27, will save new FHA-insured homeowners an average of $500 this year and reduce annual costs to 0.60% of the loan balance. However, Republicans have expressed concerns that the reduction may put taxpayers at risk, and the Trump administration may reverse the change after President-elect Donald Trump takes office.

site_title: Thousands in California and Nevada told to evacuate due to flooding
summary: Thousands of people in California and Nevada have been evacuated due to heavy rains and flooding along rivers, forcing the closure of roads and power outages for over 570,000 customers. The storms, part of the "Pineapple Express" weather system, have brought 10-15 inches of rain to the Sierra Nevada mountains and are expected to continue until Wednesday. Floods have damaged homes and infrastructure, with at least one death reported from a fallen tree in the San Francisco Bay area. California officials are considering opening floodgates to prevent further flooding, and the state's drought-stricken regions are experiencing a rare reprieve from dry conditions.

site_title: CapitaLand signs mall management contract in Xi'an, China
summary: CapitaLand has signed a mall management contract in Xi'an, China, its second in western China within five months. The company will manage a 50,000 sq m shopping mall in La Botanica township, with expected operations starting in 2019. This deal follows CapitaLand's management of Fortune Finance Center in Changsha, China. The company now manages 14 shopping malls in western China, with a combined retail GFA of 1.13 million sq m.

images.alt_text: CapitaLand Mall Asia said on Tuesday that it has inked a shopping mall management contract in Xi'an, its second in western China within a span of five months.

site_title: Europe: Shares slip as bank losses offset tech gains; FTSE hits new high
summary: European shares slipped 0.4% on Monday, with the FTSE 100 index hitting a new high, driven by a stronger tech sector. The pound sank to two-month lows due to comments from British Prime Minister Theresa May on Brexit. Bank stocks fell 1.7%, with Italian lenders down 3.5%, after a strong start to the year. Tech stocks rose 0.7%, led by gains in French retailer Casino Guichard and German software maker SAP.

site_title: Oil down 4% on concerns over rising Iraqi exports, US output
summary: Oil prices fell 4% on Monday due to concerns over record Iraqi exports and rising US output, undermining OPEC's efforts to curb global oversupply. Iraq's oil exports reached a record high of 3.51 million barrels per day in December, while US crude futures settled at $51.96 a barrel. OPEC members agreed to cut oil output by 32.5 million barrels per day starting January 1, but compliance is uncertain, with Iraq's high exports raising concerns about the feasibility of the cuts.

images.alt_text: Oil prices tumbled by 4 per cent on Monday on concern that record Iraqi crude exports and rising US output would undermine Opec's efforts to curb global oversupply.

site_title: US: Weak oil hits Dow; Nasdaq edges to new record
summary: US stocks opened the week with a downcast note, with the Dow shedding 0.4% to 19,887.38, and the S&P 500 falling 0.4% to 2,268.90. The Nasdaq Composite Index rose 0.2% to a new closing record of 5,531.82, driven by gains in pharmaceutical stocks. Oil prices fell, causing petroleum-linked shares to tumble, with companies like ExxonMobil and Halliburton losing over 1%. Despite the downturn, the Nasdaq's record close suggests investor optimism.

site_title: Canada's PM to shuffle Cabinet, set to drop foreign minister
summary: Canada's Prime Minister Justin Trudeau is set to shuffle his Cabinet, with Foreign Minister Stephane Dion likely to be dropped. Dion faced criticism for not defending a reporter and handling of a Saudi arms deal. The move comes ahead of Donald Trump's presidency, where relations with the US will be crucial. Trade Minister Chrystia Freeland is a potential candidate to replace Dion, but her Ukrainian heritage and past criticism of Russia may complicate the appointment.

site_title: Trump, China's Ma hold 'great' meeting on jobs
summary: US President-elect Donald Trump held a "great" meeting with China's billionaire founder Jack Ma in New York, focusing on creating US jobs and enabling trade with Asia. The meeting aimed to create one million US jobs by supporting small businesses selling goods into China and Asia. Ma expressed his commitment to strengthening China-US relations and trade issues, and praised Trump as "very smart" and "very open-minded." The meeting comes after Trump has taken a hard line with China, threatening import tariffs and currency manipulation.

site_title: Billionaire Packer returns to Crown board after China crackdown
summary: Billionaire James Packer has returned to Crown Resorts' board after a Chinese crackdown and reined-in overseas expansion plans. Packer, through his company Consolidated Press Holdings, has been appointed as a Crown director. Robert Rankin, who stepped down as chairman and CEO, will focus on Crown's Australian business. The move comes as Crown adjusts to Chinese authorities' stricter regulations, prioritizing its domestic operations.

site_title: China's biggest money fund is bracing for more liquidity shocks
summary: China's biggest money-market fund, Yu'EBao, is preparing for potential liquidity shocks in 2017 due to the government's efforts to curb risk in the financial system and support the sliding yuan. The fund's manager, Wang Dengfeng, plans to hold extra cash to protect against large redemptions, as the average interbank repurchase rate surged to a 20-month high in December, causing bonds to slump. The fund's assets stood at 800 billion yuan as of September, with an average seven-day return of 3.36% annualized. The PBOC's tightening monetary policies are expected to lead to higher credit risk in 2017.

site_title: Two Fed officials stress gradual approach to raising rates
summary: US Federal Reserve officials, Atlanta Fed chief Dennis Lockhart and Boston Fed President Eric Rosengren, emphasize the need for a gradual approach to raising interest rates in 2017, despite investor optimism about President-elect Donald Trump's economic plans. Lockhart expects inflation to continue to rise, while Rosengren believes a gradual but more regular increase in the federal funds rate will be warranted to achieve the Fed's dual goals of 2% inflation and maximum sustainable employment. The Fed is currently considering three rate increases in 2017, down from two previously estimated.

site_title: More women lawmakers needed in UK as numbers 'shockingly low': report
summary: The UK has a "shockingly low" number of women parliamentarians, with only 30% of 650 MPs being female, ranking 48th globally. A report urges the government to set targets for equal representation by 2030, with at least 45% of parliament and local government positions held by women. The report also highlights the prevalence of sexism, harassment, and violence against female MPs, with many reporting online humiliation campaigns. The government is urged to take action to ensure faster progress towards equality and prevent stagnation of positive trends.

site_title: Trump son-in-law tipped as senior White House adviser
summary: Jared Kushner, Donald Trump's son-in-law, is set to be named a senior White House adviser despite concerns over legal and ethical issues. Kushner, 36, will become the youngest senior adviser in the administration, with his lawyer stating he will resign from his CEO position and divest assets. Despite a federal nepotism law prohibiting presidents from hiring relatives, Trump advisers have indicated there may be more leeway for a White House role. Kushner's influence has been significant, with transition officials saying he should relay foreign policy matters to the president-elect.

site_title: Mexico seeks to contain prices as anger mounts over fuel hike
summary: Mexico's President Enrique Pena Nieto announced an economic plan to contain price increases, following a 14-20% hike in gasoline prices that sparked protests. The plan includes keeping staple goods prices stable, reducing senior government officials' salaries by 10%, and encouraging capital repatriation. However, the proposal was met with criticism from business groups, including the main employers' federation, and lacks clear targets and metrics. The move aims to minimize the impact on families, but analysts predict inflation may exceed the central bank's 4% ceiling.

images.alt_text: Under proposals announced by President Enrique Pena Nieto (centre), business, government and union leaders pledged to keep the price of staple goods stable, cut salaries of senior government officials by 10 per cent and encourage capital repatriation.

site_title: US dollar falls against yen on risk reduction; sterling sinks
summary: The US dollar fell 0.8% against the yen on Monday due to reduced risk appetite, while sterling dropped to two-month lows amid speculation of a drastic rework of trade ties with the EU after Brexit. The decline was attributed to lower US Treasury yields and equities, with no fundamental catalyst identified.

site_title: Obama again defends climate deal
summary: US President Barack Obama has defended the global climate deal, stating that reducing greenhouse gases can boost economic growth. In a journal article, Obama cited his administration's environmental legislation, including the Clean Power Act, as examples of the US's commitment to reducing carbon emissions. Despite Trump's plans to scrap the Paris Climate Accord, Obama's agenda may face sustained assault from the new administration, which is considering options to undermine the Clean Power Act.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: SEMBCORP Marine extends standstill agreement with North Atlantic Drilling to July 6 for the delivery of semi-submersible drilling rig West Rigel. C&G Environmental Protection Holdings declares first interim special dividend of S$0.04 per share. Lum Chang Holdings completes disposal of two subsidiaries, and OEL Holdings receives order to wind up OSEC Shipyard Pte Ltd following an application.

site_title: Smoking costs US$1t, soon to kill 8m a year: study
summary: A study by the World Health Organization and the US National Cancer Institute found that smoking costs the global economy over $1 trillion annually and will kill 8 million people by 2030, with 80% of these deaths occurring in low- and middle-income countries. The economic costs far outweigh global tobacco tax revenues, estimated at $269 billion in 2013-2014. The study recommends policies such as hiking tobacco taxes, comprehensive smoke-free policies, and prominent pictorial warning labels to reduce tobacco use and associated deaths, despite concerns from governments that tobacco control measures may have an adverse economic impact.

site_title: Eng Hen: Detention of Terrex not in compliance with international laws
summary: Singapore's Defence Minister Ng Eng Hen stated that the detention of nine Terrex infantry carriers by Hong Kong customs was not in compliance with international laws. The vehicles were being shipped back to Singapore after a military exercise in Taiwan and cost a total of S$30 million. Ng emphasized that Singapore wants the armoured vehicles returned as soon as possible, and Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong had written to Hong Kong's Chief Executive Leung Chun-ying to seek their swift return.

site_title: Cogent share surge prompts SGX query
summary: Shares of Cogent Holdings surged 12% to 70.5 Singapore cents on Monday, prompting a query by the Singapore Exchange (SGX) on its trading activity. The company cited no new information to explain the price movements, referencing a previous announcement about receiving indications of interest. Cogent reported a 13% jump in net profit in the third quarter, driven by improved performance in its warehousing operations and logistics management services. The company's subsidiary received a letter of offer for a construction project in September.

site_title: Britain's May seeks new trading relationship with EU as £ slides
summary: UK Prime Minister Theresa May stated that the country will need a new trading relationship with the European Union after its withdrawal, as the pound fell to its lowest against the dollar since late October. May emphasized the need for a new relationship across various areas, including trade, as the UK will no longer be a member of the EU. Her comments come as the Brexit deadline approaches, sparking concerns about the country's economic future.

site_title: Police arrest 17 over Kardashian Paris robbery
summary: French police arrested 17 people, most with organized crime records, in connection with the 2016 robbery of reality TV star Kim Kardashian in Paris. The heist, valued at around $13.7 million, was France's largest jewelry theft in over two decades. DNA evidence led to the arrests, with some suspects known for robbery and criminal offenses. Kardashian's driver, who tipped off the robbers about her bodyguard's absence, was also detained. The suspects can be held for up to 96 hours before being charged, with prosecutors considering asking Kardashian to identify her attackers.

site_title: Santa delivered the drone, minus the safety and skill to fly them
summary: Drones have become a popular holiday gift, but with the rise of drone sales, there's also an increase in crashes, losses, and accidents. The US Federal Aviation Administration requires a $5 registration for drones over 250 grams, but many owners are not adhering to safety guidelines, including flying in restricted areas and not following wind and tree obstacles. Experts warn that drone manufacturers are not doing enough to educate consumers, and regulations are struggling to catch up with the rapidly evolving technology. The FAA has created an app and webpage with safety tips, but more needs to be done to prevent mid-air collisions and fatal consequences.

site_title: Tube strike hits millions of Londoners
summary: A 24-hour strike by RMT union members hit most of London's Underground network, affecting 10 of the 11 lines, and causing chaos for millions of commuters. The strike, over job cuts and staffing levels, officially ended on Monday evening, but some stations remained closed and a normal service was not expected until Tuesday morning. Extra buses were laid on to replace Tube services, but long queues and heavy traffic caused frustration among commuters. The strike's impact was compounded by rainy weather, with many passengers facing lengthy waits for buses or packed train carriages.

images.alt_text: Millions of Londoners endured a chaotic start to the week on Monday after a strike shut down most of the Underground network, including many city centre stations.

site_title: Rolls-Royce signs MOU with A*Star to deepen collaboration
summary: Rolls-Royce and the Agency for Science, Technology and Research (A*Star) in Singapore signed a memorandum of understanding to advance digital capabilities and support the growth of the digital ecosystem in Singapore. The partnership aims to establish technology centers for Internet of Things and advanced manufacturing, and will focus on digital manufacturing, cybersecurity, and analytics software. Rolls-Royce chairman Ian Davis said the partnership will benefit all industries, while A*Star chairman Lim Chuan Poh highlighted Singapore's importance as the largest aviation hub in Asia.

site_title: VW to launch electric version of hippie-era Microbus
summary: Volkswagen unveiled a new electric version of its iconic Microbus, the ID Buzz, as part of its strategy to sell 1 million zero-emission vehicles annually by 2025. The concept features a range of 430 km, up to 8 seats, and autonomous driving capabilities. The move aims to rebuild the brand's US reputation, following the emissions scandal in 2015. The ID Buzz is part of Volkswagen's plan to deliver 3 million battery-powered cars annually by 2025, with production starting in 2021.

site_title: Yahoo to shrink board after pending sale to Verizon, change name
summary: Yahoo! Inc will shrink its board after closing its $4.8 billion sale to Verizon Communications Inc, changing its name to Altaba Inc. Five directors, including CEO Marissa Mayer, will leave the board as the new company reduces ties to the iconic brand. The sale comes amid concerns over Yahoo's data hacks, and the new entity will be a shareholder in Alibaba Group Holding Inc and Yahoo! Japan.

images.alt_text: Yahoo! Inc Chief Executive Officer Marissa Mayer is among five directors who plan to leave the board of the investment company that will be left after the closing of the proposed sale of Yahoo's main internet properties to Verizon Communications Inc.

site_title: Samurai 2K Aerosol to list on Catalist on Jan 16 (Amended)
summary: Samurai 2K Aerosol Limited, a Malaysian aerosol spray producer, is set to list on the Catalist board on January 16. The company has received 100% subscription for its initial public offering, offering 20 million new shares at 20 Singapore cents each. Samurai aims to capitalize on the growth of Southeast Asia's motorbike fleet, with a proprietary two-component aerosol container design and a strong market presence in Malaysia and Indonesia. The IPO is expected to raise SGD 2.35 million, with plans to expand production facilities and explore new industry segments.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Triyards Holdings reported a 11.5% gross profit margin in the quarter, down from 18.7% in 1QFY16 and 12.9% in 4QFY16, as management aims to sustain yard utilization and earn decent profits under a tough operating environment. Borrowings increased due to higher working capital required for major projects, with net gearing at 0.66x and interest coverage at 4.1x. The company's core debt is approximately US$12 million.

site_title: Morgan Stanley, UBS said to be in talks to boost China JV stakes
summary: Morgan Stanley and UBS are in talks to boost their stakes in their China joint ventures to 49%, the maximum allowed under current regulations. The move comes as foreign firms seek to increase their presence in the Chinese market, which has seen growth in profits in recent years. UBS currently owns 25% of its China securities firm, while Morgan Stanley holds 33%. The plans are a sign of growing confidence in the Chinese operations and follow a trend of foreign firms increasing their stakes in the country.

images.alt_text: UBS has been in talks with multiple shareholders since last year about buying their stakes through the exercise of call options held by the Zurich-based bank, sources say.

site_title: Revisiting the S'pore-India Double Taxation Avoidance Agreement
summary: Singapore's Double Taxation Avoidance Agreement (DTAA) with India has been revised, following changes made to the Mauritius DTAA. The revised agreement removes the exemption of capital gains taxes for investments from Singapore, introducing source-based taxation. The agreement also includes a "Limit of Benefit" provision to prevent "treaty shopping" and restrict the misuse of the DTAA. The changes aim to reduce tax leakage and promote fair taxation. The revised agreement reflects Singapore's willingness to cooperate with India, but the frequent renegotiations may create uncertainty and impact India's reliability as an economic partner.

site_title: Indonesia revises tax rules on transfer pricing to curb evasion
summary: Indonesia has revised its tax rules on transfer pricing to curb tax evasion, aligning with global standards. A finance minister's decree requires multinational firms with annual turnover of over $1.2 billion to prepare country-by-country reports detailing tax payments and global structure. The new rules, effective since 2017, aim to combat base erosion and profit shifting. Hundreds of multinational companies will be impacted, and the move is endorsed by the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD).

site_title: Existing alliances are best bet for negotiated peace in Syria
summary: A fragile ceasefire in Syria, brokered by Turkey, Russia, and Iran, remains the key to a negotiated peace. The truce has been supported by seven major opposition groups, but violations have occurred. The Russian withdrawal of its aircraft carrier battle group from the Mediterranean Sea suggests Moscow is seeking a resolution to the crisis. The conflict's complexity, involving proxy wars and decades-old alliances, poses a significant challenge to achieving a lasting peace. The Astana peace talks will need to navigate the interests of various factions, including minority groups and regional powers.

site_title: For stocks, just fact-checking may not be enough
summary: The article highlights the importance of considering the broader context when evaluating the performance of local stock markets. Despite Singapore's "bumper" number of privatisations/delistings in 2016, the trend is not unique to Singapore, with the US also experiencing a "shrinking" number of public companies. The article suggests that private funding is becoming more popular, and this trend is observed globally, with the US seeing a decline in the number of listed companies since 1997. Fact-checking is essential, but it may not be sufficient to draw conclusions, as the situation can be influenced by confirmation bias and a narrow perspective.

site_title: Australia forecasts drastic drop in iron ore prices through 2018
summary: Australia forecasts a drastic drop in iron ore prices to $51.60/tonne in 2017 and $46.70/tonne in 2018, a decline from current spot prices of around $80/tonne. The drop is attributed to a temporary lift in Chinese steel production and speculative trading, which will not last. The country's iron ore export forecast is trimmed to 832.2 million tonnes in 2016-17, a 2% decrease from previous estimates.

site_title: China's top coal province sets out consolidation plan
summary: China's top coal-producing province, Shanxi, plans to cap output and consolidate the industry over the next four years. Major producers will focus on thermal, coking, and anthracite coal, while smaller producers will be merged into larger ones. The goal is to boost efficiency and reduce waste.

site_title: Ronaldo, Ranieri scoop top Fifa awards
summary: Cristiano Ronaldo won FIFA's inaugural Best Player of the Year award, beating Lionel Messi and Antoine Griezmann, while Leicester City's Claudio Ranieri received the Best Men's Coach award for leading his team to a Premier League title. Ronaldo praised 2016 as his best year, while Ranieri described the honor as "incredible." US midfielder Carli Lloyd won the Best Women's Player award, and the FIFPro Team of the Year featured Ronaldo and Messi alongside Real Madrid and Barcelona teammates.

images.alt_text: Cristiano Ronaldo claimed Fifa's inaugural best player of the year award on Monday, the latest prize for the Real Madrid and Portugal star after a glittering 2016 for club and country.

site_title: Re-employment age to rise by 2 years to 67 on July 1
summary: Singapore's minimum re-employment age for workers born on or after July 1, 1952, will increase to 67 on July 1. Employers can transfer their re-employment obligations to another company, but cannot cut salaries when staff turns 60. The government will provide an Employment Assistance Payment (EAP) of up to S$10,000 to help workers who cannot find a new job. These changes aim to support elderly workers and encourage voluntary re-employment, with the goal of reducing the country's aging workforce.

site_title: Citic Envirotech bags 650m yuan river restoration project
summary: Citic Envirotech secured a 650 million yuan (S$135 million) river restoration project in Jiangsu, China, under the Sino-Singapore International Innovation Park. The company, a water solutions provider, will own 90% of the project through a joint venture with the Yixing Industrial Park for Environmental Science and Technology Management Committee. The project is the first under the innovation park and is estimated to be worth 3 billion yuan.

site_title: China bitcoin exchange says no govt pressure on outflows
summary: China's major bitcoin exchange BTCC says it has not received explicit pressure from the government to halt outflows of the cryptocurrency. Despite a meeting with the central bank last week, BTCC CEO Bobby Lee stated that no direct pressure was applied. The meeting aimed to highlight risks and remind the exchange to abide by the law. Bitcoin's price took a dive after China's central bank cautioned investors to take a cautious approach to investing in the digital currency, amid efforts to curb capital outflows and slow the yuan's depreciation.

site_title: Baidu joins BAIC in China push for homegrown driverless cars
summary: Baidu Inc has joined forces with state-owned Beijing Automotive Group Co (BAIC) to push for homegrown driverless cars in China. A BAIC-built model equipped with Baidu technology will debut at the Shanghai motor show in April, with road-testing of an autonomous car planned by the end of the year. China aims to have 10-20% of vehicles highly autonomous by 2025 and 10% fully self-driving by 2030. The partnership aims to create sophisticated products and services, following China's push for digitization and Internet connectivity.

site_title: S'pore to match Malaysia's RM20 road charge: Khaw
summary: Singapore plans to match Malaysia's RM20 (S$6.45) road charge, as announced by Coordinating Minister Khaw Boon Wan in Parliament. Malaysia collected RM13.9 million from Singapore-registered vehicles in seven weeks since the charge's introduction on November 1, 2016. The exact details of Singapore's move will be announced soon.

images.alt_text: Malaysia collected some RM13.9 million from Singapore-registered vehicles in the seven weeks from Nov 1 last year, when the road charge was introduced, said Mr Khaw.

site_title: Singapore Power joins global utilities in plan to enlist startups
summary: Singapore Power has launched the Free Electrons accelerator programme, a six-month initiative with seven international utilities to support energy start-ups. The programme, managed by New Energy Nexus and swissnex San Francisco, aims to co-create clean energy and energy efficiency solutions. 12 start-ups will collaborate with major utility firms in Silicon Valley, Lisbon, Dublin, and Singapore, gaining exposure to various markets and pilot project opportunities. The programme is open for applications until Feb 28, with selected start-ups to be announced in April.

site_title: US solar lobby group names 'bridge builder' as new leader
summary: The US solar lobby group, the Solar Energy Industries Association (SEIA), has appointed Abigail Ross Hopper as its new CEO, replacing Rhone Resch. Hopper, a former energy policymaker, pledged pragmatism as she takes the helm amid uncertainty from President-elect Donald Trump's stance on renewable energy. SEIA has been instrumental in garnering federal government support for solar power, and Hopper's appointment aims to build bridges with Trump's administration.

site_title: Dubai's Damac expects to maintain 25% dividend despite falling profits
summary: Damac Properties, a Dubai-based developer, expects to maintain its 25% cash dividend policy despite falling profits in the first three quarters of 2016. The company's board set a minimum dividend target in 2014 and followed the recommendation in 2015. Damac's profit fell 23% to $2.84 billion in the nine months to September, and the company anticipates a 7 billion dirhams in sales for 2017, with a potential market rebound in the second or third quarter of 2019.

site_title: Investors eye Norway's biggest bank over potential shareholder rewards
summary: Norway's largest bank, DNB ASA, has more capital than needed and is likely to use excess funds to buy back shares, attracting investor interest. Following a stress test, the bank topped the European Banking Authority's resilience score, predicting shareholder rewards ahead. Analysts see potential for shareholder rewards as DNB ASA considers using its excess capital for share buybacks.

site_title: Why Asia should embrace natural gas as a power source
summary: Asia is embracing natural gas as a clean and affordable power source, shifting the energy landscape for emerging countries. The region's growing demand for natural gas has increased, with China and Japan among the top global importers. As the industry expands, natural gas offers an opportunity to displace coal-fired power, addressing climate and health concerns. With technological advances making extraction and transportation easier, Asia is poised to become a major player in the global natural gas market, potentially increasing the number of countries importing gas from over 30 to 50 by the end of the decade.

site_title: US housing regulator accuses BOA of discriminatory lending
summary: The US Department of Housing and Urban Development (HUD) filed charges against Bank of America and two employees for allegedly discriminating against prospective Hispanic mortgage borrowers in South Carolina. The case was prompted by a complaint from the National Fair Housing Alliance, which found that Hispanic borrowers were offered less favorable lending terms and were less promptly connected with loan officers. Bank of America has denied the claims, stating it is committed to fair lending principles. The case will be heard in federal court, where a judge could order the bank to pay damages or other relief.

site_title: Fiat Chrysler ups the ante as carmakers respond to Trump threats
summary: Fiat Chrysler Automobiles announced a $1 billion investment to modernize US plants in Ohio and Michigan, creating 2,000 jobs. The move aims to build new Jeep SUVs, including a pickup truck, and potentially move Ram production from Mexico to Michigan. The investment responds to President-elect Donald Trump's threats to impose new taxes on imported vehicles. The announcement highlights the industry's interest in easing fuel economy rules and the potential impact of Trump's tariffs on the US vehicle market.

site_title: From Iceland to Maldives, Chinese seek 'lung cleansing' trips
summary: Chinese residents are seeking "lung cleansing" trips to locations with clean air, such as Iceland and the Maldives, amid a toxic haze over China. Online searches for smog avoidance travel packages have tripled, with terms like "smog escape" and "lung cleansing" seeing significant increases. This trend is attributed to the recent air pollution in China, prompting residents to seek cleaner alternatives.

images.alt_text: Online searches for places with pristine, or at least clean, environments shot up after heavy smog blanketed many parts of the country, forcing 62 cities, including Beijing, to issue health alerts.

site_title: Uber hopes to appease cities with tool showing traffic patterns
summary: Uber is launching a traffic dashboard called Uber Movement, providing anonymized traffic data to cities, including Manila, Sydney, and Washington. The tool aims to help urban planners and civic communities analyze traffic patterns. However, it lacks details on individual trips, vehicles, or passengers, raising concerns over data granularity and potential regulatory issues. Uber's move follows international competitors like Easy Taxi and Grab, which have made more of their data public, and is seen as a response to city leaders' demands for more transparency.

site_title: Aussie banks make strong start in offshore bonds
summary: Australian major banks Westpac and National Australia Bank successfully accessed the US dollar bond market, raising A$1.75 billion and A$3.5 billion respectively in their first bond sales of 2017. The bonds were priced competitively, with Westpac's notes pricing 88 basis points wide of Treasuries and NAB's notes pricing 78-108 basis points wide. The move reflects the banks' substantial wholesale funding requirements and the shallowness of the local bond scene, with up to two-thirds of their totals raised offshore.

site_title: STI enjoys fifth consecutive rise
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) rose for the fifth consecutive trading session, gaining 18.91 points to 2,981.54, in response to a strong US jobs report that raised hopes for a decent Monday on Wall Street. The Dow Jones Industrial Average may close above 20,000 points for the first time ever, according to futures market signals. The STI's five-day total gain is over 100 points or 3.3%.

site_title: Koreans driven crazy as egg prices surge
summary: A serious bird flu outbreak in South Korea has led to the culling of over 26 million birds, resulting in soaring egg prices. The country's egg prices are expected to more than double in the first half of 2017, with costs rising 50% to 1,551 won for 10 standard-sized eggs. The outbreak has also affected other countries, including Germany, France, and Japan, and the South Korean government has removed tariffs on imported eggs to ease the price hike. The nation's egg consumption is expected to increase due to the Chinese New Year, further exacerbating the shortage.

site_title: Obama's presidency far from transformational
summary: US President Barack Obama's presidency has been deemed non-transformational, with historians labeling him as "pro-status quo" for pursuing modest reforms and initiatives. Despite being the first African-American president, his lack of experience with racism and his bi-racial background have led to questions about his connection to the black community. Obama's inability to bridge the racial divide and address economic inequalities, particularly in inner-city areas, has been criticized. His presidency was marked by cooperation with the financial industry and corporate America, rather than radical progressive policies, and his legacy is now being reassessed in the context of rising racial tensions and a divided America.

site_title: Russia cuts oil output by 100,000 bpd in early January
summary: Russia reduced its oil production by 100,000 barrels per day (bpd) in early January as part of an agreement with OPEC to cap global crude output. The country's oil and gas condensate output averaged 11.1 million bpd from Jan 1 to Jan 8, down from 11.21 million bpd in December. Despite the temporary reduction, analysts expect Russian oil production to grow in 2017 to a record high due to new fields coming online, with output expected to reach 11.14 million bpd in 2017.

site_title: Australia offers A$240m aid for crippled Alcoa aluminium plant
summary: Australia has offered A$240 million in aid to repair the crippled Alcoa aluminium smelter in Victoria, damaged by a state-wide blackout. The outage caused molten metal to solidify, disrupting production at the 300,000-tonnes-per-year Portland smelter. The Australian government's support includes A$200 million in state funds over four years and a A$40 million interest-free loan. Negotiations are ongoing with energy provider AGL Energy to agree on cheaper power rates. A deal could be announced on Friday if a power supply agreement can be reached, supporting the local economy and ensuring the smelter's long-term sustainability.

site_title: Asia's rich are funding European football teams in hunt for yield
summary: Wealthy Asian investors are funding European football teams through financing notes backed by television rights. Sales of these notes doubled to $11 million in January, with total assets reaching $40 million. Investors receive a 6% annual coupon, offering insulation against market shocks. PricewaterhouseCoopers estimates sales of liquid alternative mutual funds will surge to $664 billion by 2020. This trend highlights how individual investors are filling a gap in financing soccer clubs, as banks are constrained by Basel III capital rules.

site_title: Collaborative robots offer future to SMEs
summary: Singaporean small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) face challenges in the form of manpower and cost constraints, with 72% identifying manpower cost as their top challenge. To address this, automation technologies such as collaborative robots (co-bots) are being explored as a viable option. Co-bots can work safely alongside humans, assist in repetitive tasks, and are cost-effective, making them a game-changer for various industries. The Singapore Government has introduced schemes to support businesses investing in automation technology, including the Productivity and Innovation Credit Scheme and the Automation Support Package.

site_title: Trump's 'jawboning' on jobs not always good economics
summary: US President Donald Trump's "jawboning" efforts to persuade companies to keep jobs at home are not economically sound, according to a historical analysis. Similar tactics employed by President Lyndon Johnson in the 1960s failed to control inflation and instead led to higher prices and wages. Trump's actions, such as pressuring Carrier and Ford to keep jobs, may save a few thousand jobs but won't create new ones and could actually increase costs for American manufacturers. The underlying causes of job loss, including automation and a strong dollar, are more significant.

site_title: 10 habits of successful entrepreneurs
summary: A successful entrepreneur is built around 10 critical habits, according to the author, who has launched multiple startups and mentored many entrepreneurs. The human factor is key to business interactions, and habits such as good manners, a genuine smile, and humility are essential. Other key habits include being authentic, making change the only constant, asking "why," and challenging one's own biases. By adopting these habits, entrepreneurs can increase their chances of success, as the author notes that the opportunities created by the digital economy mean there are more wannabe entrepreneurs than ever before.

site_title: Obama's farewell speech to take foreign-policy focus
summary: US President Barack Obama is set to deliver his farewell address with a focus on foreign policy, marking the first time a president has returned to their hometown to deliver the speech. Obama leaves office with a 56% approval rating and will likely defend his foreign policy record, highlighting achievements such as US leadership on climate change and the nuclear deal with Iran. Critics of his foreign policy, including the Trump administration, have criticized his handling of various international crises, but Obama is expected to argue that his approach was pragmatic and necessary in a complex and fluid world.

site_title: Michael Ng moves to Chip Eng Seng from UIC
summary: Property industry veteran Michael Ng Seng Tat, 53, has joined Chip Eng Seng Corporation after quitting United Industrial Corporation (UIC). Ng is executive director of CEL Development, overseeing regional businesses.

site_title: CJ urges legal sector to embrace march of technology
summary: Chief Justice Sundaresh Menon of Singapore urged the legal sector to embrace technological advancements, stating that technology will improve service quality and lead to cost savings for law firms and society. He emphasized the need for "receptive openness" as technology transforms practice areas. Menon also endorsed a tech blueprint for the Singapore courts, aiming to implement it over the next five years.

site_title: The Ascott positions itself for growth and tie-ups with global firms
summary: The Ascott, a serviced-residence operator, is positioning itself for growth and expansion. The company aims to reach 80,000 units by 2020, with plans to enter the US and African markets. It has formed partnerships with online vacation rental businesses Tujia and Alitrip, and is exploring new business models with international start-ups. The Ascott has also introduced a new brand, Lyf, targeting millennials, and is expanding its global footprint with 30 new properties launching this year. The company's CEO, Lee Chee Koon, aims to diversify its client base and increase ancillary revenue through services such as food delivery and co-working spaces.

site_title: F&N wants title to Penguin Random House's S'pore, Malaysia units for S$8m
summary: Fraser & Neave (F&N) will acquire the Singapore and Malaysian distribution arms of Penguin Random House for S$8 million. The acquisition aims to add a well-known brand to F&N's loss-making print arm. The deal is subject to post-completion adjustments and will be paid in cash from internal resources. This move is expected to shore up F&N's struggling business segment.

site_title: 13 units in Gemini@Sims industrial project up for en bloc sale
summary: The developer of Gemini@Sims, a freehold industrial project in Kallang, Singapore, is selling the entire ground floor of 13 strata units via an expression of interest. Offers are expected to be above S$900 per square foot (psf) for the combined 40,375 sq ft of strata floor area. The units are similar in layout and size, ranging from 2,626 sq ft to 3,670 sq ft. The sale may appeal to owner-occupiers and investors looking for large ground-floor presence in a zoned "Business 1" area.

site_title: McDonald's sells control of China business to Citic, Carlyle
summary: McDonald's has agreed to sell 80% of its China and Hong Kong operations to a consortium including Citic Ltd and Carlyle Group LP for up to $2.08 billion. The deal includes 20-year mass franchise rights and will value the business at $2.08 billion. The consortium will hold a 52% stake, with McDonald's retaining a 20% shareholding. The sale is part of McDonald's efforts to revamp its ownership structure globally, as it faces declining traffic in the US and challenges from Asian competitors.

site_title: ADB ramps up activity as new lenders enter the fray
summary: The Asian Development Bank (ADB) reported a 17% increase in operations last year, reaching a record high of $31.5 billion. This growth is attributed to rising development needs in the region. The ADB's approvals for loans, grants, technical assistance, and co-financing have been steadily increasing over the years. The bank's operations are expected to continue growing as development needs in the region continue to rise.

site_title: Resurgent Asean stocks may weather Trump-China trade spat: strategists
summary: Asean stocks are expected to weather the US-China trade spat, with strategists seeing the region as a safe haven due to its strong economies and lower reliance on exports. The Philippine Stock Exchange Index has surged 10% and the Jakarta Composite Index has risen 6.1% in recent weeks. Indonesia and Malaysia have also seen significant gains, with the MSCI South East Asia Index rebounding 5.5% since its drop following Trump's election. Experts attribute the region's resilience to its domestic-oriented industries and lower export-to-GDP ratios.

images.alt_text: A rally in South-east Asian stocks may persist even if a Trump-induced trade spat with China erupts, as strategists see the region offering shelter from any global fallout.

site_title: Real estate risks a concern, says Fed's Powell
summary: Federal Reserve Governor Jerome Powell expressed concern over financial excesses, citing commercial real estate as an area of risk. With inflation under control, Powell warned of the need for vigilance against the buildup of risks to the financial system due to the extended period of record-low interest rates. This comes as the US central bank monitors financial markets, particularly in the wake of recent trends such as rising mortgage rates and record-breaking Manhattan rents.

site_title: Mercedes set to become largest premium carmaker
summary: Mercedes-Benz has reached its goal of becoming the largest premium carmaker four years early, selling 2.08 million passenger cars in 2016. The company's focus on stylish high-tech cars and technological superiority has helped revive the brand, surpassing BMW's sales. Daimler CEO Dieter Zetsche credits the company's renaissance to refocusing on technological superiority, adapting to changing consumer preferences, and introducing new designs and digital display technology. Mercedes-Benz is now poised to lead the luxury car market, with plans to expand into pay-per-minute transport solutions with autonomous cars.

site_title: Scania, Toyota come on board to test-bed truck platooning system
summary: Scania and Toyota have partnered with the Singapore Ministry of Transport and PSA International to test-bed a truck platooning system. The trials, starting in 2017, aim to transport multiple truckloads of cargo between terminals using one driver and multiple driverless trucks. The system could alleviate manpower shortages and reduce traffic congestion. The trials will take place in two phases over three years, with the potential to expand to include haulage within the port area and between terminals. Industry estimates suggest the technology could save PSA up to $10 million annually by reducing the number of drivers needed.

site_title: Revised SFA: Tighter definition for accredited investors
summary: Singapore has passed amendments to its Securities and Futures Act, introducing a tighter definition for accredited investors. The new rules require investors to opt-in to the status, in addition to meeting qualifying criteria. The changes were made public in 2014, but went into effect on Monday. The revised definition aims to increase transparency and accountability in the investment process.

images.alt_text: A tightened definition for accredited investors is among the wide-ranging amendments to Singapore's Securities and Futures Act (SFA) passed into law on Monday.

site_title: Affording a dignified exit for all
summary: Ang Chin Moh Funeral Directors, a 109-year-old Singaporean company, provides dignified funerals to those who are alone at the end of their lives, regardless of their background or financial situation. The company, founded in 1912, has a strong corporate giving effort, advocating for businesses to include charity components. Over the past four years, ACMFD has worked with community councils to provide free workshops for senior citizens, promoting discussions about death, funerals, and end-of-life issues. The company's efforts have helped change cultural attitudes towards death, leading to increased interest in the funeral industry and a growing number of employees seeking careers in the field.

site_title: Disruption, not anti-trade, should be S'pore's main concern: StanChart
summary: Standard Chartered economists say Singapore should focus on technological disruption rather than anti-trade concerns amid rising fears of protectionism. The city-state is expected to issue a Committee on the Future Economy report later this month to outline its challenges and how to tackle them. With technological advancements already affecting the economy, Singapore can serve as a model for other economies to learn from its approach to disruptions. The economists also note that a small city-state like Singapore is better positioned to adjust to changes than larger economies.

site_title: La La Land waltzes off with seven gongs at Golden Globes
summary: La La Land dominated the 75th Golden Globe Awards, winning all seven of its nominations, including best director, best screenplay, and best actor and actress for Ryan Gosling and Emma Stone. The film's success was seen as a boost for its Oscar campaign. The ceremony, which lasted three hours, also featured impassioned speeches addressing the anxiety over Donald Trump's election and the importance of hope and creativity. Other winners included Manchester by the Sea, Moonlight, and The Crown, while Meryl Streep delivered a powerful speech criticizing Trump's behavior.

site_title: US$ regains traction, sterling gets Brexit bashing
summary: The pound slid over 1% against the dollar and euro after British Prime Minister Theresa May stated her desire for a bespoke Brexit deal, prioritizing immigration over trade. The dollar rose as interest rate signals lifted US yields to 2.42%, and the euro initially held up before sagging after Germany reported a monthly rise in exports. US interest rates could rise three times this year, according to Chicago Federal Reserve president Charles Evans.

site_title: Air China bans shark fin cargo, reflecting shift in attitudes
summary: Air China has banned shark fin cargo, marking a shift in attitudes toward endangered wildlife trade in mainland China. This decision comes after China also announced a plan to ban its domestic ivory trade, aimed at ending elephant poaching in Africa. The move is seen as a positive step in conservation efforts, helping to protect shark populations threatened with extinction.

site_title: Immigration boosts wealth, does not increase inequality: IMF
summary: The International Monetary Fund's First Deputy Managing Director David Lipton stated that immigration has a generally positive economic impact on receiving countries, increasing GDP per capita in advanced economies by boosting labor productivity and addressing labor shortages. The benefits of migration are shared across all income groups, with no significant negative effects on the middle or lower income groups. Lipton emphasized that effective integration into labor markets is crucial for maximizing economic benefits from migration, and noted that eastern Europeans have integrated rapidly, but policymakers must better understand the assimilation experience of refugees and migrants from the Middle East and Africa.

site_title: Keppel Reit Management appoints Jesline Goh as CEO
summary: Keppel Reit Management announced the appointment of Jesline Goh, 43, as CEO, effective February 1, subject to regulatory approval. She will succeed NG Hsueh Ling, who steps down as CEO and executive director. This move is part of a leadership transition at the manager of Keppel Reit.

site_title: C&G to pay special dividend after getting partial payment for sale
summary: C&G Environmental Protection Holdings announced a first interim special dividend of S$0.04 per share for its 2017 financial year after receiving a partial payment of HK$211.0 million for the sale of C&G Environmental Protection International to Ahead Auto. The special dividend will be paid in cash on a pro rata basis. This follows the sale, which was completed on January 9, 2017.

site_title: Voluntary scheme started to accredit specialist lawyers
summary: The Singapore Academy of Law (SAL) has launched a voluntary accreditation scheme to recognize specialist lawyers. The first practice area to be accredited is building and construction law, with the first batch of specialists to be announced in January 2018. This move aims to help the public identify lawyers with expertise in specific areas, providing a more transparent and trustworthy legal profession.

site_title: Community panel to certify presidential candidates' ethnicity
summary: A new 16-member Community Committee will be established to issue "community certificates" to presidential candidates, requiring them to declare their ethnicity. The committee will be set up by the Prime Minister and will comprise sub-committees for Chinese, Malay, and Indian & minority communities. Candidates must submit a community declaration five working days after the writ of election is issued, with the deadline extended to 10 calendar days. The new rules aim to ensure representation from underrepresented communities in the presidential election.

site_title: China likely to allow companies to issue shares in Frankfurt this year: bourse
summary: China is likely to allow companies to issue shares in Frankfurt this year, enabling them to raise their profile in Europe through "D shares." The Shanghai Stock Exchange is studying the plan with the China Europe International Exchange, which was set up in 2015 to facilitate cross-border trading. This move aims to increase Chinese companies' presence in the European market.

site_title: Toyota to invest US$10b in US over five years
summary: Toyota Motor North America plans to invest US$10 billion in US capital over the next five years, matching its prior five-year investments. The decision is part of the automaker's business strategy to invest in the US, where it has 10 plants in eight states. The move comes after President-elect Donald Trump criticized Toyota's 2015 plan to shift Corolla production to Mexico from Canada, but Lentz stated it was not a response to Trump.

site_title: Trump lashes out at Streep over Golden Globes speech
summary: President-elect Donald Trump lashed out at Meryl Streep, accusing her of being a Hillary Clinton "flunky" after she criticized him at the Golden Globes ceremony. Streep had berated Trump for his divisive rhetoric and infamous campaign speech, in which he mocked a disabled reporter. Trump denied mocking the reporter, claiming he simply showed him "groveling" and stated he never "mocked" a disabled reporter. The exchange sparked criticism, with Trump calling the media "dishonest."

site_title: MM2 Asia redesignates Melvin Ang as executive chairman
summary: MM2 Asia redesignated Melvin Ang as executive chairman following Tan Liang Pheng's relinquishment as non-executive chairman. Ang, who remains CEO and executive director, will oversee overall business operations and provide executive leadership to senior management. The redesignation comes after Tan's appointment as lead independent director. MM2 shares rose 2.1% to close at 48.5 Singapore cents on Monday.

site_title: Michael Ng joins Chip Eng Seng
summary: Michael Ng Seng Tat, 53, has joined Chip Eng Seng Corporation as executive director of CEL Development, overseeing regional businesses. Ng, previously group general manager of United Industrial Corporation, brings experience as managing director of Savills Singapore from 2004 to 2010. His appointment comes after a 15-year tenure at UIC, where he worked from 2010 to 2025.

images.alt_text: MICHAEL Ng Seng Tat has joined Chip Eng Seng Corporation as executive director of the group's fully-owned subsidiary, CEL Development, overseeing its regional businesses.

site_title: OEL Holdings receives winding up order for wholly-owned unit OSEC
summary: OEL Holdings received a winding up order for its wholly-owned unit OSEC Shipyard Pte Ltd from the Singapore High Court on January 6. The court appointed Leow Quek Shiong and Gary Loh Weng Fatt as the joint and several liquidators. Following the announcement, OEL's share price rose 23% to finish at 1.6 Singapore cents.

site_title: US: Stocks mostly lower; McDonald's unveils China deal
summary: US stocks were mostly lower early Monday, following a spate of merger and acquisition announcements. The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 0.3% to 19,902.83, while the S&P 500 lost 0.3% to 2,271.03. McDonald's announced a deal to sell its China and Hong Kong business for up to $2.1 billion, while VCA surged 28.3% after being acquired by Mars for $9.1 billion. The Nasdaq Composite Index gained 0.1% to 5,527.01. Market uncertainty and a strong dollar contributed to the cautious tone.

site_title: Genting HK's unit to buy systems from ABB Group for S$198m
summary: Genting Hong Kong's unit, MVWW, has agreed to buy complete propulsion systems and other marine systems from ABB Group for €131 million (S$198 million) to build five new cruise ships by 2021. The deal is part of Genting's ten-year cruise ship fleet expansion strategy, and MVWW also commits to purchasing additional systems if it builds up to two more vessels by 2018 or 2019. The agreement was signed on Monday and marks a premium-class procurement for the group.

site_title: Fed's Rosengren calls for gradual, but faster interest-rate hikes
summary: Boston Fed President Eric Rosengren called for the US central bank to increase interest rates more quickly to prevent inflation risks. With unemployment at 4.7%, Rosengren believes inflation will reach the 2% target by the end of 2017. He warned that if interest rates do not rise, the unemployment rate could drop below its sustainable level, leading to inflation. The Fed has already raised rates by a quarter of a point and is expected to raise rates three more times in 2017. Rosengren's shift to a more hawkish stance is due to strengthening economic data.

site_title: Oil companies may boost E&P spending after 2 years of declines: Barclays
summary: Global oil and gas companies are expected to raise exploration and production spending by 7% in 2017, marking the first increase in three years, according to Barclays. The recovery in oil prices, driven by Opec's supply cuts, has boosted confidence among operators. North American oil companies are expected to lead spending growth, with a 27% jump, while international spending is expected to increase 2%. However, production is expected to fall due to higher service costs, and offshore projects are expected to decline 20-25% in 2017.

site_title: F&N to buy Penguin Random House units in S'pore, Malaysia for S$8m
summary: Fraser & Neave (F&N) plans to acquire the Singapore and Malaysian distribution arms of Penguin Random House for S$8 million. The consideration is subject to post-completion adjustments and will be paid in cash from internal resources. Penguin Singapore and Penguin Malaysia will enter into exclusive distribution agreements with Penguin Books, The Random House Group, and others for English book titles and products in Singapore and Malaysia. The acquisition is expected to be completed after adjustments are made.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares end lower on Monday
summary: Malaysia's Kuala Lumpur Composite Index ended lower on Monday, dropping 7.59 points to close at 1,667.90. A total of 1.80 billion lots, valued at RM1.45 billion, were traded, with 422 shares losing value and 375 gaining value.

site_title: Sales of much hyped virtual reality gear face tough reality check
summary: Virtual reality technology has faced a tough reality check, with sales of high-end headsets remaining sluggish due to high costs, lack of content, and complexity. Despite initial hype, many technologists and early adopters acknowledge that the technology still needs improvement and time to gain widespread acceptance. The industry is currently in the "trough of disillusionment" stage of the hype cycle, according to analysts, with many startups struggling to survive. Major headset manufacturers, such as Intel, Oculus, HTC, and Sony, report modest sales, with Sony's more affordable headset being a rare exception.

site_title: Singapore shares close higher; STI records fifth consecutive rise
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) rose 18.91 points to 2,981.54, marking its fifth consecutive gain. The rally was likely in response to the US jobs report and hopes for a Dow Jones Industrial Average close above 20,000. The 5-day total gain is 3.3% or over 100 points. Trading volume was weak at 2.1 billion units worth S$881.2 million, with 265 rises and 177 falls excluding warrants.

site_title: Hot stock: Cogent share surge prompts SGX query (Amended)
summary: Shares of Cogent Holdings surged 12% to 70.5 Singapore cents on Monday, prompting a trading query by the Singapore Exchange (SGX). The surge occurred after the company announced that its subsidiary received a letter of offer for a chemical logistics facility. Cogent has yet to respond to SGX's query.

site_title: Parliament: Singapore to raise re-employment age to 67 from Jul 1, 2017
summary: Singapore's Parliament has passed a bill to raise the re-employment age to 67 for locals who turn 65 on or after July 1, 2017. The new law aims to allow workers who wish and are able to continue working to stay employed, and removes the option of employers cutting employees' wages at age 60. It also allows eligible employees to be re-employed by another employer, subject to their express agreement. The changes take effect from July 1, 2017, with the goal of providing more options for employers and employees.

site_title: Malaysia plans mega port project off Port Klang
summary: Malaysia plans a mega port project off Port Klang, Selangor, to capture the rise in container cargo from China's One Belt, One Road initiative. The RM55 billion (S$17.7 billion) project, funded and constructed by China, aims to develop an integrated port, industrial parks, and free trade zones. The project, linked to the East Coast Rail Line, is expected to have an annual capacity of 30 million TEUs and is seen as a strategic move to bypass congested Straits of Malacca. However, port experts caution that success depends on efficiencies, cargo flows, and shipping line support.

site_title: UK house price growth picks up speed again: Halifax
summary: UK house prices rose 6.5% in the three months to December compared to the same period last year, with a 1.7% monthly increase in December, the strongest since March. This follows a 6.0% growth in the previous month. The rise is attributed to a shortage of homes on the market. Halifax expects yearly price growth to slow to 1-4% by the end of 2017, driven by economic uncertainty.

site_title: Parliament: Detention of Terrexes against international law, says Ng Eng Hen
summary: Singapore's Defence Minister Ng Eng Hen stated that the detention of the nine Singapore Armed Forces (SAF) Terrex infantry carriers in Hong Kong is against international and Hong Kong law. He expressed hope for the Terrexes' return, emphasizing Singapore's interest in resolving the matter.

site_title: Seoul: Won slumps as US jobs data supports dollar; stocks flat
summary: The South Korean won declined 1.3% against the US dollar, closing at 1,208.3 won per dollar, as positive US jobs data supported the dollar's strength. South Korean shares were nearly unchanged, with the Kospi index at 2,048.78 points. Offshore investors bought 255.1 billion won worth of Kospi shares, marking the ninth consecutive day of net buying.

site_title: Asia millionaires fund Europe soccer teams in hunt for yield
summary: Wealthy Asian investors are backing European soccer teams through football finance notes, doubling sales to US$11 million last month. Swiss-Asia Holding Pte Ltd, a Singapore-registered firm, has seen total assets in the securities reach US$40 million, with a target of US$100 million in 2017. This trend suggests Asian investors are seeking yield in the soccer market, bypassing direct ownership of teams.

site_title: Structure change in Hyflux's Egypt contract
summary: Hyflux has agreed to restructure its $500 million Ain Sokhna Integrated Water and Power Project in Egypt from an engineering, procurement and construction (EPC) contract to a build operate and transfer (BOT) or build operate and own (BOO) basis. The General Authority for Suez Canal Economic Zone (SCZone) requested the change, and Hyflux has identified partners to develop the project. The company will continue to discuss investment terms with SCZone. The operation and maintenance of the facilities will still be managed over a 25-year period.

site_title: US arrests VW executive on fraud charges: report
summary: FBI agents arrested Oliver Schmidt, a former Volkswagen executive, on conspiracy charges related to the 'dieselgate' emissions-cheating scandal. Schmidt led Volkswagen's US regulatory compliance office from 2014 to 2015. The arrest follows lawsuits filed by New York and Massachusetts accusing Schmidt of concealing emissions cheating from US regulators. Volkswagen has pledged to cooperate with US authorities to resolve the case.

site_title: South Korean leader's friend Choi now charged with bribery
summary: South Korean special prosecutors have filed additional bribery charges against Choi Soon-sil, a close friend of impeached President Park Geun-hye. Choi, 60, faces charges of colluding with Park to pressure big businesses, including Samsung Group, to contribute to non-profit foundations. Choi denies any wrongdoing, while Samsung officials questioned as witnesses have declined to comment. The Constitutional Court will decide whether to uphold Park's impeachment, a process that could take months. This development comes as the country continues to grapple with a corruption scandal that has engulfed the government.

site_title: Chinese police shoot dead three "terror" suspects in Xinjiang
summary: Chinese police shot and killed three suspects in the Xinjiang region, accused of violent terrorism. The suspects were linked to an incident in 2015 and had ties to militants abroad. The government attributes the unrest to separatist groups seeking an independent East Turkestan state, but rights groups blame anger over Chinese controls on Uighur culture and religion. The region had been relatively quiet, but recent attacks have raised concerns about the government's handling of security.

site_title: Beijing launches environmental police force to tackle air pollution
summary: Beijing has launched an environmental police force to tackle air pollution, with the aim of cracking down on persistent polluters. The force will target open-air barbecues, garbage incineration, biomass burning, and dust from roads. Acting Mayor Cai Qi stated that lax supervision and weak law enforcement are contributing factors to these environmental issues. The move is part of Beijing's efforts to clean up its air and improve environmental regulations.

site_title: HK, Shanghai: Stocks close higher
summary: Hong Kong stocks closed marginally higher on Monday, following a record close on Wall Street. The Hang Seng Index rose 0.3% to 22,571.91, while the Shanghai Composite Index gained 0.54% to 3,171.24. The gains were attributed to a strong performance in the US market, where the S&P 500 and Nasdaq reached fresh records despite uncertainty over US-EU trade talks.

site_title: McDonald's sells China operations for US$2.08b
summary: McDonald's sells its mainland China and Hong Kong franchise business to a consortium of Citic Group and the Carlyle Group for up to US$2.08 billion. The consortium will form a company that will act as the franchisee for 20 years. Citic and Citic Capital will hold 52% of the new company, Carlyle 28%, and McDonald's 20%. The sale marks a significant exit for McDonald's in the region, following a decline in sales and profitability in China.

site_title: Thailand expects tourism revenue of nearly US$50b in 2017
summary: Thailand expects tourism revenue to reach nearly US$71.8 billion in 2017, a 8.5% increase from the previous year. This growth is attributed to improved global tourism outlook and investments in infrastructure. Daily tourist spending is projected to rise to 5,200 baht per person, from 5,100 baht last year. Deputy Prime Minister Thanasak Patimaprakorn emphasized the need to focus on quality tourism over quantity.

site_title: Parliament: RM13.9m in toll fees paid to Malaysia in Nov and Dec
summary: Singapore will match Malaysia's RM20 road charge, said Transport Minister Khaw Boon Wan. Since Nov 1, Singapore-registered vehicles entering Malaysia via Woodlands and Tuas checkpoints have paid an estimated RM13.9m in road charges between Nov 1 and Dec 20.

images.alt_text: Singapore will match the RM20 (S$6.40) road charge that Malaysia imposed on Nov 1 last year, said Transport Minister Khaw Boon Wan in Parliament on Monday (Jan 9).

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Lum Chang Holdings' unit completed the sale of interest in two subsidiaries. Singapore Power launched the Free Electrons Global Accelerator programme to innovate clean energy solutions. The Ministry of Transport and PSA Corporation announced trials of an autonomous truck platooning system. Chief Justice urged the legal sector to adapt to technological advancements. Banyan Tree's first Cuban resort, Dhawa Cayo Santa Maria, will open for booking on January 15. The Straits Times Index advanced for the fifth consecutive trading session, closing at 2,981.54 points.

images.alt_text: Lum Chang Holdings said on Monday that its unit Lum Chang Orion has completed the disposal of interest in two subsidiaries.

site_title: 16 arrested over Kardashian Paris robbery: police sources
summary: French police arrested 16 people in the Paris region over the 2016 robbery of reality TV star Kim Kardashian's Paris residence, where she was robbed of jewelry worth around 9 million euros. Kardashian, 36, who was staying during Fashion Week in October, was tied up and feared being killed by the armed and masked men. This is the first time Kardashian has spoken publicly about the incident, which occurred last year.

site_title: Australia shares end at 20-month high; New Zealand up
summary: Australia's S&P/ASX 200 index rose 0.9% to a 20-month high, closing at 5,807.4, driven by gains in financials and healthcare companies. The financial sector, including "Big Four" banks, rose 1.5%, while healthcare stocks led gains, including CSL Ltd's 1.6% increase. Basic material stocks fell, particularly iron ore producers, as the Department of Industry forecast a decline in iron ore prices. New Zealand's benchmark index also rose 0.6% to its highest close since October.

site_title: Australia sees iron ore price heading sharply lower
summary: Australia has forecast a significant decline in the price of iron ore, with an average price of around US$52 a tonne in 2017, down from US$80 a tonne currently. The forecast, made by the Department of Industry, Innovation and Science, comes as major miners are expected to report bumper profits, while smaller rivals are still recovering from a decline in prices last year. Analysts predict a "trainwreck" for smaller producers if the price drops further.

site_title: Indonesia's president moves to rein in "out of control" military chief
summary: Indonesia's President Joko Widodo reprimanded his military chief, General Gatot Nurmantyo, for being "out of control" after he unilaterally suspended defense cooperation with Australia. Widodo's intervention highlights concerns that Gen Nurmantyo is promoting a "proxy war" narrative, which analysts and some aides believe is a groundwork for expanding the military's role in civilian affairs and may have political ambitions. Gen Nurmantyo declared a rupture in military ties after finding "offensive" teaching material while on a language training course in Australia, which mocked Indonesia's state ideology.

site_title: Former bandmates mark David Bowie's birthday
summary: Former David Bowie bandmates gathered in London for a charity concert marking what would have been his 70th birthday, held nearly a year after his death from cancer. The sold-out event featured performances by keyboardist Mike Garson and guitarist Earl Slick, along with other friends and former band members. The concert was organized by actor Gary Oldman, allowing the musicians to come together and celebrate Bowie's legacy.

site_title: Jaguar Land Rover sells record 583,313 cars in 2016
summary: Jaguar Land Rover sold a record 583,313 cars in 2016, a 20% increase from the previous year. The Indian-owned firm aims to reach 1 million vehicles per year by the decade's turn. Sales growth slowed to 12% year-on-year in December, with luxury Jaguar models rising 77% to 148,730 units. Europe remains the biggest market, accounting for nearly a quarter of total demand. The company warns that Brexit tariffs could cut its annual profit by £1 billion by 2020.

site_title: Volvo expects to export half of its future US production
summary: Volvo plans to export half of its US production, with the first plant in North America expected to begin producing S60 mid-size sedans in 2018. The plant, which will have a capacity of 100,000 cars per year, will produce for both the US and international markets. Volvo CEO Hakan Samuelsson stated that the decision was made in 2014, considering factors such as labor costs, transportation, and market size, and that the US is the largest market for the company.

site_title: SP launches Free Electrons Global Accelerator programme
summary: SP launches Free Electrons Global Accelerator programme, a six-month initiative to bring together utilities and startups to innovate clean energy solutions. Eight international utilities, including SP, will support 12 selected startups through three modules in Silicon Valley, Lisbon, Dublin, and Singapore. The programme aims to refine products and services with a global customer base, with applications opening on Jan 9 and closing on Feb 28.

site_title: Citic Envirotech secures first river restoration project in Jiangsu, China
summary: Citic Envirotech has secured its first river restoration project worth 650 million yuan in Yixing, Jiangsu, China. The 90:10 joint venture with Yixing Industrial Park for Environmental Science and Technology Management Committee will undertake the project via Build-Lease-Transfer scheme for 10 years. The project is located in the Yangtze River Delta and is supported by China's Ministry of Science and Technology and Ministry of Environment Protection.

site_title: CEO of Keppel Reit's manager to step down and join Keppel Corp
summary: Keppel Reit announced that Ng Hsueh Ling will step down as CEO and executive director of its manager, Keppel Reit Management Ltd, effective February 1. Jesline Goh will succeed her as CEO-designate on January 10, pending regulatory approval. Ng will assume a new role as director of new business at Keppel Corp.

site_title: China seeks foreign investment in foreign trade five-year plan
summary: China's commerce ministry released its foreign trade five-year plan from 2016 to 2020, aiming to attract foreign investment in manufacturing and support domestic companies going overseas. The plan does not include specific trade targets. Meanwhile, other news includes Vietnam's surprise at US tariffs, Malaysia seizing assets, China's slowing GDP growth, Citigroup's MSCI index target, Thaksin's confidence in his daughter's court case, ASEAN's non-priority on Myanmar's election, and the UK economy's second consecutive month of shrinkage.

site_title: Hair today, hungover tomorrow as young Japanese come of age
summary: Thousands of young Japanese women celebrated their 20th birthdays in elaborate Coming of Age ceremonies, marking their entry into adulthood and the start of legal drinking and smoking. Many spent hundreds or thousands of dollars on hair, makeup, and kimonos, while males opted for more modest attire. The event also served as a reminder of their responsibilities and the first step towards adulthood, with some planning to celebrate with a night of drinking and socializing.

site_title: McDonald's said to sign agreement Monday on China franchise sale
summary: McDonald's plans to sell 80% of its operations in China and Hong Kong to a consortium of Carlyle Group LP and Citic Group Corp for approximately $2 billion, including debt. The US fast-food chain will retain a 20% shareholding. The deal is part of McDonald's efforts to streamline its global operations and revamp its ownership structure in markets such as China, South Korea, and Southeast Asia.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open flat on Monday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened flat on Monday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 0.160 point to 1675.330. Volume was 31.53 million lots worth RM11.91 million. Gainers outnumbered losers 100 to 35.

site_title: Oil halts gain near US$54 as rising US drilling damps Saudi cuts
summary: Oil prices halted a gain near $54 a barrel as US drilling increased, countering Saudi Arabia's planned output cuts. US drillers added rigs for the 10th straight week, reaching a one-year high. Despite Opec members, including Saudi Arabia, sticking to output cuts, rising US drilling damps market stability. Oil prices slid 0.6% in New York, with West Texas Intermediate for February delivery at $53.66 a barrel. The market appears to have found a temporary equilibrium point, with analysts citing anecdotal evidence of Opec production cuts.

images.alt_text: Oil halted its advance below US$54 a barrel as an increase in US drilling countered signs Opec members including Saudi Arabia are sticking to planned output cuts to stabilise the market.

site_title: Thai floods kill 21 and hit rubber production
summary: Widespread flooding in Thailand's south has killed 21 people, affected over 330,000 households, and hit rubber production. Unseasonably heavy rain has shut down infrastructure, including the main airport in Nakhon Si Thammarat, and suspended a rail route from Bangkok. The floods have had a devastating impact on rubber farmers, with prices expected to increase due to a shortage of supply. The region is also facing its worst flood impact in 10 years, with drought and flooding causing a disastrous impact on the industry.

images.alt_text: Widespread flooding in Thailand's south has killed 21 people, hit rubber production in the region and shut down infrastructure, officials said on Monday, as the military government increased aid to flood-affected areas.

site_title: Argentine grandmother revives tennis dream at 83
summary: An Argentine grandmother, Ana Obarrio de Pereyra Iraola, has revived her 1949 tennis dream at the age of 83. Her passion for tennis was put on hold for 20 years to raise her 10 children, but she has now resumed playing.

site_title: MOT, PSA to start truck platooning trials
summary: Singapore's Ministry of Transport and PSA Corporation have signed agreements with Scania and Toyota Tsusho to develop and test-bed an autonomous truck platooning system for use on public roads. The trials, set to run from January 2017 to December 2019, aim to improve freight movement efficiency, alleviate manpower shortages, and reduce traffic congestion. The system will transport containers from one port terminal to another, with a 10 km test route designated along West Coast Highway for phase two trials.

site_title: Samsung executives to be questioned by Korean prosecutors
summary: South Korean special prosecutors have summoned Samsung Corporate Strategy Office vice-chairman Choi Gee-sung and President Chang Choong Ki for questioning amid an influence-peddling scandal that led to President Park Geun Hye's impeachment. Choi and Chang are expected to testify, but their status may change. This move comes as part of a widening investigation into the scandal.

site_title: Chief Justice urges legal sector to embrace technology
summary: Chief Justice Sundaresh Menon of Singapore emphasized the need for the legal sector to adapt to technological advancements, aiming to improve the quality of services and reduce costs. He urged the sector to leverage technology to provide better outcomes for society. This transformation is crucial in response to the disruptions technology poses to the traditional legal process.

site_title: Resurgent Asean stocks may weather any Trump-China trade spat
summary: Southeast Asian stocks have rebounded sharply in the past couple of weeks, with the Philippine Stock Exchange Index surging 10% and Thailand's benchmark gauge reaching its highest since March 2015.
