Strategists attribute the rally to the region's strong economies and corporate earnings growth, as well as a potential shift in foreign investments away from China due to rising trade tensions with the US. The MSCI South East Asia Index has rebounded 5.5% since December 23, with some analysts predicting that the region may be better placed to weather any global fallout.

site_title: Ice-cold dip to cleanse souls for New Year in Japan
summary: About 100 people took an ice bath at a Shinto shrine in Tokyo on Sunday to purify their souls and wish for good health as part of a New Year's ritual. The participants, mostly men, jogged and exercised before taking the ice bath, hoping to stay healthy throughout the year. One participant, Miho Hewa, 48, took the bath after her family fell ill with flu at the beginning of the year, believing it would bring them good health. The ritual is a colorful way to welcome the New Year in Japan.

site_title: Australia: Shares extend gains despite negative iron ore forecast; New Zealand up
summary: Australian shares rose 0.65% to a 19-month high, driven by gains in financials and healthcare sectors, despite a negative forecast for iron ore prices. US employment data boosted sentiment, offsetting losses in basic materials. The S&P/ASX 200 index reached 5,792.3 points, with CSL Limited, Woolworths Limited, and Ansell Ltd leading gains. Index heavyweights BHP Billiton, Rio Tinto, and South32 fell due to declining iron ore prices.

site_title: Banyan Tree's first Cuban resort to open for booking from Jan 15
summary: Banyan Tree Hotels & Resorts announced that its first lifestyle resort in Cuba, Dhawa Cayo Santa Maria, will open for booking on January 15. The 516-room resort features five restaurants, two swimming pools, a fitness center, and a 545-seat theatre. Located in Cayo Santa Maria, a province of Villa Clara, it is a 90-minute drive from Santa Clara International Airport. This is the first and only all-inclusive lifestyle resort with a private beach in the area.

site_title: Australia, NZ dollars off 3-week highs as USD gains
summary: The Australian and New Zealand dollars fell from three-week highs as the US dollar strengthened due to potential inflationary pressure in US December jobs reports. The Australian dollar held at US$0.7322, up 1.7% in January, despite robust data from China, its largest trading partner. Analysts are cautious about further gains.

site_title: Pro-democracy lawmaker attacked at Hong Kong airport
summary: Hong Kong pro-democracy lawmaker Nathan Law was attacked by anti-independence protesters at Hong Kong's airport on January 8, 2017. Law, 23, was met with a crowd of angry pro-Beijing demonstrators who shouted, threw liquid, and attempted to hit him as police struggled to escort him. The incident occurred after Law and other pro-democracy activists were greeted by protests in Taipei. Law is the youngest legislator in Hong Kong.

site_title: Chinese state tabloid warns Trump, end one China policy and China will take revenge
summary: Chinese state tabloid Global Times warned US President-elect Donald Trump that China will take "revenge" if he reneges on the one-China policy, following Taiwanese President Tsai Ing-wen's stopover in Houston. Beijing had asked the US not to allow Tsai to enter and not have formal meetings under the one-China policy. Trump has said he won't meet with foreign leaders before his inauguration, but left room for meeting Tsai after his inauguration. The Global Times editorial stated that China needs to understand that the US will not be swayed by pressure.

site_title: Fall in China's FX reserves 'good news', yuan overvalued: central bank adviser
summary: China's foreign reserves declined by $41 billion to $3.011 trillion in December, marking the sixth consecutive month of declines. Central bank adviser Fan Gang views this as a positive sign, suggesting the yuan is "overvalued" and at a "turning point." The yuan's depreciation is expected to continue, with some experts warning of a potential 25% drop against the US dollar. The Chinese government aims to prevent rapid fluctuations in reserves, but is unlikely to step up capital control measures, instead opting for a gradual correction of the yuan's value.

images.alt_text: "The yuan was maybe overvalued for the last three or four years... it's come to a turning point. This should be corrected," Mr Fan said.

site_title: May signals UK to leave single market to win immigration curbs
summary: UK Prime Minister Theresa May signaled the UK's intention to leave the European Union's single market to regain control over immigration and lawmaking. In her first interview of the year, she stated that leaving the EU will be about "getting the right relationship" rather than keeping bits of membership. This means the UK will have control over its borders and laws, while still seeking the best possible trade deal with the EU.

site_title: Gold edges up, but gains limited by rate hike prospects
summary: Gold prices edged up 0.2% to $1,174.91 an ounce on Monday, rebounding from one-month highs, due to prospects of more interest rate hikes from the US Federal Reserve. The rebound was limited by expectations of higher interest rates, which reduced demand for the non-interest-paying bullion. US employment data showed sustained labor market momentum, increasing the likelihood of further rate hikes this year.

images.alt_text: Gold prices edged up in a technical rebound on Monday after one-month highs hit last week were undercut by the prospects of more interest rate hikes from the US Federal Reserve.

site_title: From Iceland to Maldives, Chinese seek 'lung cleansing' trips
summary: China's severe air pollution has triggered a surge in smog avoidance travel packages to destinations like Iceland and the Maldives, with online searches for terms like "lung cleansing" tripling amid the haze. Heavy smog has forced 62 cities to issue health alerts, with PM2.5 levels reaching hazardous levels in many areas. Chinese officials have vowed to address the issue, with plans to shut down high-polluting factories and restrict vehicles, but the root cause of the problem remains the country's unclean industrial and energy mix.

site_title: Taiwan: Stocks down on profit-taking; ahead of data, earnings
summary: Taiwan's stocks fell 0.3% on Monday as investors booked profits after the previous day's 0.2% gain, ahead of key trade data and earnings. The Taiex index closed at 9,341.78. The country's December exports figures, expected to show solid year-on-year growth, will be released after the market closes. This week's earnings and trade data may influence market sentiment, potentially affecting the index's performance.

site_title: Sportswear retailer Pou Sheng sacks finance chief, stock down 37%
summary: Sportswear retailer Pou Sheng International sacked its finance chief over false sales records, which led to a 37% drop in its shares to HK$1.30. The company also terminated the employment of its CFO, Chen Kuo-Lung, and its CEO, Kwan Heh-Der, had resigned. Pou Sheng attributed the false records to weak financial controls and stated that the incident did not impact daily business operations.

site_title: Modi flying blind into budget as India's GDP a guessing game
summary: India's Prime Minister Narendra Modi's administration is preparing the country's $300 billion budget without a clear estimate of the impact of a cash clampdown on the economy, which is expected to slow to a three-year-low. The Statistics Office has refused to provide any data, citing a lack of information. This means the budget papers will be printed before the effects of the ban are known, indicating a "flying blind" approach. The deadline for the budget presentation is February 1, and the papers will be printed by January 20.

site_title: Seoul: Won falls sharply on US Dec jobs data; stocks steady
summary: The South Korean won fell 0.9% to 1,204.0 to the US dollar following December US jobs data that heightened concerns about a potential earlier rate increase by the Federal Reserve. Despite a rebound in wages, employment increased less than expected. South Korean shares barely moved, with Samsung Electronics rising 3% and Amorepacific dropping 3%. Market analysts predict the won will move between 1,200 and 1,210 levels in the near term, with the focus on Fed Chair Janet Yellen's speech and President-elect Donald Trump's press conference.

site_title: Singapore shares open flat on Monday
summary: Singapore shares opened flat on Monday, with the Straits Times Index up 1.41 points, or 0.05%, to 2,964.04. The market saw 43 million shares worth S$43.2 million change hands, with gainers beating losers 72 to 38. Top gainers included Venture, DBS, and Singapore Exchange.

site_title: Jurong Shipyard further extends standstill agreement with North Atlantic Drilling
summary: Sembcorp Marine's unit Jurong Shipyard has extended its standstill agreement with North Atlantic Drilling to July 6, 2017, for the delivery of semi-submersible drilling rig West Rigel. During the extended period, North Atlantic Drilling will market the rig for a drilling contract, while Jurong Shipyard can sell the rig at an acceptable price. If no employment is secured, the parties will form a joint asset holding company, with Jurong Shipyard owning 77% and North Atlantic Drilling owning 23%.

images.alt_text: Sembcorp Marine on Monday said that a standstill agreement between its unit Jurong Shipyard and North Atlantic Drilling has been further extended to July 6, 2017.

site_title: Australia job ads fall 1.9% month-on-month in December: ANZ
summary: Australian job advertisements fell 1.9% in December, marking four consecutive months of decline, according to a survey by ANZ. The annual growth rate slowed to 3.7% from 6.0% in November. Despite a relatively low 5.7% unemployment rate, employment growth slowed, with hiring skewed towards part-time positions. ANZ economist Jo Masters believes the labour market will continue to support a gradual decline in the unemployment rate this year, driven by elevated business and consumer confidence.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Sembcorp Marine, Lum Chang
summary: Sembcorp Marine and Lum Chang Holdings made announcements affecting their shares. Sembcorp Marine extended a standstill agreement for a drilling rig until July 6, 2017. Lum Chang Holdings sold interests in two subsidiaries for £13.78 million, generating a net gain of £2.6 million.

site_title: East Timor and Australia to tear up sea border treaty
summary: East Timor and Australia have agreed to terminate their 10-year maritime border treaty in the Timor Sea, which controls lucrative oil and gas fields. The treaty, known as CMATS, was signed in 2006 but was disputed due to allegations of spying by Australia. The treaty will cease to be in force three months after formal notification, with both countries committing to negotiate new permanent maritime boundaries. East Timor seeks to gain greater control over its oil and gas resources, while Australia aims to maintain its share of the lucrative fields.

site_title: Yuan, other Asia currencies seen extending slide in 2017 on US dollar rally: poll
summary: Emerging Asian currencies, particularly the Chinese yuan, are expected to extend their fall in 2017 due to the US dollar's rally and expectations of faster rate hikes from the Federal Reserve. The yuan is forecast to weaken by 4% to 7.20 by end-December 2017, marking the lowest level in nearly a decade. The US dollar's appreciation is driven by Trump's fiscal stimulus and the Fed's rate hike assumptions, which will push US bond yields higher and dent currencies globally.

site_title: Four dead after Chile plane crash
summary: A plane crash in southern Chile's Bio Bio region near Laquecahue airfield on Sunday killed four people, according to local officials. The accident occurred due to high winds during a troubled landing. Four passengers - a woman and three men - died in the incident, said Humberto Toro, the governor of Arauco.

site_title: 'La La Land' big winner at Golden Globes
summary: La La Land dominated the 74th Golden Globe Awards, winning seven awards, including best comedy/musical and film for its stars Ryan Gosling and Emma Stone, as well as for director Damien Chazelle, screenplay, score, and original song. The film's director, Damien Chazelle, praised the film as "a film for dreamers," emphasizing the importance of hope and creativity. The ceremony also featured a statement by Meryl Streep criticizing US President-elect Donald Trump, sparking a notable moment in the event.

site_title: Fiat Chrysler announces creation of 2,000 US jobs
summary: Fiat Chrysler announced the creation of 2,000 US jobs, investing $1 billion by 2020 in two US factories in Michigan and Ohio. The move comes as President-elect Donald Trump has publicly criticized automakers for moving operations to Mexico, with Fiat Chrysler demonstrating its commitment to strengthening its US manufacturing base.

site_title: US dollar keeps post-payrolls bounce, but bulls leery
summary: The US dollar maintained a steady start on Monday after the December US jobs report showed signs of wage pressure, pushing up Treasury yields. However, bulls remained cautious due to last week's profit-taking. The dollar index was near 102.26, while the euro stood at $1.0527. Analysts expect more interest rate hikes, citing inflationary pressure, and are watching the Federal Reserve's Janet Yellen for clearer guidance.

site_title: Tokyo: Markets closed for holiday
summary: Japanese financial markets are closed on Monday, Jan 8, 2017, for a public holiday, with trading resuming on Tuesday, Jan 10.

site_title: Mercedes-Benz to overtake BMW as largest premium carmaker
summary: Mercedes-Benz is expected to surpass BMW as the largest premium carmaker four years ahead of schedule, selling 2.08 million branded passenger cars in 2016. The company's shift in focus from chasing market share to creating stylish, high-tech vehicles has helped revive the brand. Under CEO Dieter Zetsche, Mercedes has prioritized innovation, quality, design, and security, leading to a renaissance in the company's design and technology. Zetsche's strategy has paid off, with Mercedes poised to become the best-selling luxury carmaker by 2020.

site_title: Oil prices fall as Iranian crude tanker exports surge, US adds more rigs
summary: Oil prices fell on Monday as Iran increased exports, undermining efforts by Opec members to curb a global fuel supply overhang. Brent crude futures dropped 13 cents to $56.97 per barrel and US WTI crude oil futures fell 20 cents to $53.79 per barrel. Iran sold over 13 million barrels of oil held on tankers, while US drillers added oil rigs for a 10th week, extending the drilling recovery into an eighth month. This surge in US drilling activity is expected to keep prices in check until production levels fall.

site_title: UK factory bosses see worse economy but better sales in 2017: EEF
summary: British factory bosses are pessimistic about the UK economy's prospects in 2017, with 47% predicting a decline in economic fortunes despite expecting improved sales both domestically and internationally. This is an increase from 28% in the previous year's survey. Only 25% of executives foresee an improvement.

site_title: Morgan Stanley, UBS said to plan boosting China JV stakes
summary: Morgan Stanley and UBS Group AG are in talks with local partners to boost their stakes in China's joint ventures from 25% and 33% to 49%, the maximum allowed under current regulations. The move is a sign of growing confidence in their China securities businesses, which have struggled to compete with local players. The banks aim to increase their presence in China, driven by increasing profits and government support for foreign investment. The Ministry of Finance has reiterated its commitment to letting overseas banks own bigger stakes in securities and fund-management joint ventures.

images.alt_text: Morgan Stanley and UBS Group AG are in talks with local partners to boost holdings in their China securities businesses, a sign of growing confidence in those operations, according to people familiar with the matter.

site_title: Lum Chang unit completes sale of interest in subsidiaries
summary: Lum Chang Holdings' unit, Lum Chang Orion, has completed the sale of its interest in two subsidiaries, Pembridge Palace Holdco (PPHL) and Pembridge Palace Propco Limited, to ITC Investment & Technology Group Companies for £13.78 million. The transaction is expected to generate a net gain of £2.6 million, following which PPHL and Pembridge Palace Propco Limited will no longer be subsidiaries of Lum Chang Orion and Lum Chang Holdings.

site_title: UK foreign minister heads to US to meet Trump team
summary: British Foreign Secretary Boris Johnson visited the US to discuss the future of the UK-US alliance under the new presidency of Donald Trump. The trip follows previous visits by British Prime Minister Theresa May's joint chiefs of staff and comes ahead of May's planned visit to Trump in the spring. The talks aim to map out the future of the key alliance under Trump's presidency.

site_title: North Korean nukes may hurt Trump's re-election chances: former US diplomat
summary: A former US diplomat, Christopher Hill, warns that North Korea's potential nuclear capability could hurt Donald Trump's re-election chances within four years. Hill believes North Korea will claim to have a deliverable nuclear weapon, making it difficult for Trump to address the issue in 2020. With six-party talks on the table, Hill thinks negotiations are unlikely to resume soon, and China's influence is waning. Hill advises that Trump's only option might be to slow North Korea's nuclear program, rather than directly negotiating with Kim Jong Un.

site_title: US Senator Ted Cruz meets with Taiwan President Tsai
summary: US Senator Ted Cruz met with Taiwan President Tsai Ing-Wen in Houston, despite Chinese objections, to discuss arms sales, diplomatic exchanges, and economic relations. Cruz stated that the US will continue to meet with Taiwanese officials as it sees fit, defying the 'One China policy'. The meeting comes after President-elect Donald Trump ruled out meeting Tsai, but Cruz's visit underscores the shift in US policy towards Taiwan. Beijing has asked Washington to bar Tsai from flying through US airspace, but the US has not responded.

site_title: Baidu joins BAIC as China pushes for homegrown driverless cars
summary: Baidu Inc has partnered with state-owned Beijing Automotive Group Co (BAIC) to develop autonomous vehicles, as China pushes for homegrown self-driving cars. A BAIC-built model equipped with Baidu technology will debut at the Shanghai auto show in April, with road testing planned by the end of the year. China aims to have 10-20% of vehicles highly autonomous by 2025 and 10% fully self-driving by 2030, with Baidu bringing technology capabilities and BAIC manufacturing expertise to the partnership.

site_title: Londoners face Tube misery as workers set to strike from Sunday
summary: Londoners face disruptions on the London Underground starting Sunday due to a 24-hour strike by the RMT and TSSA unions over staffing levels after ticket office closures. Most central London stations will be closed, with severely reduced services. The strike is part of a wave of British rail and air passenger disruptions. London Mayor Sadiq Khan urged the unions to cancel the strike, while Transport for London agreed to recruit 200 extra staff to address staffing concerns.

site_title: Hollywood parties at glam Golden Globes
summary: The 75th Golden Globe Awards took place on January 8, 2017, with Hollywood's elite attending the ceremony. Damien Chazelle's "La La Land" led the nominations with seven, including best comedy/musical and best actor and actress for Ryan Gosling and Emma Stone. Barry Jenkins's "Moonlight" and Kenneth Lonergan's "Manchester by the Sea" were also major contenders. The ceremony was hosted by Jimmy Fallon and featured live streaming on Twitter. The event marked the start of awards season, with the Oscars to follow in February.

site_title: Heavylift newcomer eyes IPO to take on big boys in the trade
summary: GPO Heavylift Holdings, a Singapore-based company, aims to go public later this year, targeting the global big boys in the heavylift trade. Founded in 2014, the company operates four new semi-submersible heavylift vessels, valued at over $400 million. Despite a multi-year industry downturn, chairman Kenny Cai believes opportunities remain in the heavylift sub-sector, particularly in LNG module transportation. The company has secured a first contract and is evaluating other financing options, including reflagging with the Maritime and Port Authority of Singapore.

images.alt_text: Mr Cai is particularly bullish about prospects for LNG module transportation.
GPO Grace (above), GPO Heavylift's first newbuild vessel.

site_title: For 'intelligent' robot, chess is just a hobby
summary: A robot developed by Taiwan's Industrial Technology Research Institute has been showcased at the Consumer Electronics Show, featuring an "intelligent vision system" that enables it to see its environment and act with greater precision. The robot can perform various tasks, including pouring coffee and moving chess pieces, and can learn on the job with artificial intelligence. Its enhanced vision system allows it to recognize objects and their location with greater precision, making it suitable for tasks such as household chores and industrial settings. The robot is available for work through an investor or partner.

site_title: Fortune hunters flock to Madagascar's sapphire mines
summary: Fortune hunters flock to Madagascar's sapphire mines, drawn by the island's vast deposits of precious stones. However, the informal mining industry is plagued by risks, with miners often facing scuffles with authorities and relying on gem shop owners for food and supplies. Success is rare, with many miners going without wages for months or even years. Those who do find success, like 19-year-old Andry Razafindrakoto, often rely on the support of gem shop owners to survive.

site_title: Obama says he underestimated impact of Russian hacking
summary: US President Barack Obama acknowledged underestimating the impact of Russian hacking on democracies, following an intelligence report on Russian meddling in the US presidential election. In an interview, Obama warned President-elect Donald Trump about the difference between governing and campaigning, advising that the president-elect won't be able to manage the presidency like a family business. The intelligence report, released the same day, stated that Russian President Vladimir Putin ordered a campaign of hacking, leaking, and media manipulation aimed at undermining Hillary Clinton and boosting Trump.

site_title: Rough ride for Uber as cabbies in Morocco sabotage app
summary: Uber drivers in Casablanca, Morocco faced violent protests by local taxi drivers, who forced them from their vehicles and handed them over to the police. The protests, which began after the city's tramway was opened, target the ride-hailing app as an "unauthorised and illegal company." Despite the protests, Uber continues to operate in the city, with over 250 taxis and 15,000 unique users in the last three months. The Moroccan government has yet to clarify Uber's legal status, but the company's director general insists that the incidents are "isolated."

site_title: On the shoulders of giants
summary: Cityneon, a Singapore-based company, has acquired Victory Hill Exhibitions (VHE), gaining the rights to create immersive Marvel and Transformers exhibits. The acquisition has propelled Cityneon ahead of local competitors, with shares soaring 382% since 2015. Cityneon aims to be the largest experiential exhibition company, with a pipeline of upcoming Marvel and Transformers franchises. CEO Ron Tan expects the company to reap the benefits of the VHE acquisition in its earnings this year, with plans to expand into China and other markets.

site_title: Slow new-year start for director trades
summary: Singapore's director trades saw a slow start to the new year, with only nine companies recording purchases worth S$1.51 million and two firms disposing of shares worth S$0.69 million in the week of January 3 to January 6. The number of purchases was unchanged, but the number of firms and buy value were down from the previous week. The majority of significant trades were purchases, with buybacks in CWG International and Roxy-Pacific Holdings and insider buys in Japfa Ltd, Sinostar PEC Holdings, Centurion Corporation, and Wee Hur Holdings.

site_title: Cutting a path to the mainland through the city
summary: Stanley Tee, a 46-year-old Singaporean entrepreneur, has built a successful hair salon chain in Hong Kong with 11 locations and 40 employees. He initially opened the business in 2009 as a side venture while working for a telecommunications company, and after being fired in 2012, he focused on growing the Perfect10 brand. Tee credits his success to perseverance and adapting to the market, and aims to expand to mainland China, where he believes he can establish a stronger presence. His salons generate around HK$12 million in annual revenue.

site_title: Video emerges of Florida airport gunman opening fire
summary: A gunman, identified as 26-year-old Iraq war veteran Esteban Santiago, opened fire at Fort Lauderdale-Hollywood International Airport in Florida, killing five people and wounding six others. Video footage shows Santiago calmly walking through the baggage claim area before removing a gun and firing 10-15 rounds. Authorities are investigating motives, including a possible terrorism angle, and have charged Santiago with firearms offenses. The victims, who were mostly travelers preparing for cruises, have not been identified. Santiago, who had previously shown signs of erratic behavior, was a former member of the Puerto Rico and Alaska National Guard.

site_title: Carmakers, suppliers team up to share costs of self-driving vehicles
summary: Car manufacturers and suppliers are forming alliances to develop self-driving technology, sharing costs and expertise to speed up the development process. Companies like Tesla, BMW, and Intel are partnering with suppliers like Mobileye, Nvidia, and Delphi to create standardized systems for autonomous vehicles. The goal is to reduce costs and accelerate adoption, with a projected wholesale cost of around $8,000 for the Delphi-Mobileye alliance. This collaboration aims to create a standard platform for self-driving systems, with the potential to offer hardware and software sets to multiple companies.

site_title: Paris boosts cycling infrastructure, names 2017 "year of the bike"
summary: Paris is boosting its cycling infrastructure, aiming to double the surface of its cycling lanes by 2020. The city plans to ban cars from outside the Louvre museum and will pedestrianise most of the Marais area. A new 4km bike lane will be constructed along the Rue de Rivoli, connecting major landmarks. The city also plans to introduce a "tram-bus" along the Seine in 2018 to boost public transport infrastructure. The mayor, Anne Hidalgo, declared 2017 as the "year of the bicycle" to combat traffic pollution.

images.alt_text: Paris plans a major boost to its cycling infrastructure and will ban cars from outside the Louvre museum as it steps up its fight against traffic pollution, the mayor said on Sunday.

site_title: Dollar up as solid US jobs report sets stage for Fed hikes
summary: The US dollar rose against major currencies after a solid jobs report showed a slowdown in hiring but an increase in wages, setting the stage for further interest rate hikes from the Federal Reserve. The dollar gained 1.5% against the yen and fell to a low against the euro, while sterling slipped ahead of Brexit negotiations. The dollar index rose 0.7% to 101.92, with investors expecting the dollar to continue strengthening against the euro in the months ahead.

site_title: Clinton will never run for office again: confidante
summary: Hillary Clinton, the former US secretary of state, will never run for office again, according to her confidante Neera Tanden. Clinton lost the presidential election to Donald Trump in November 2016 and has since focused on helping kids and families, Tanden said. Clinton has participated in a few public events and will attend Trump's inauguration with her husband, former president Bill Clinton. Tanden expressed no expectation of Clinton running for any elected office in the future, indicating a shift in Clinton's focus from politics to philanthropy and advocacy.

site_title: Odebrecht bribes were open secret: Panama VP
summary: Panama Vice-President Isabel de Saint Malo stated that bribes by Brazilian construction giant Odebrecht were an open secret in Panama, with the US Justice Department reporting hundreds of millions of dollars paid in bribes to obtain contracts in nine Latin American countries. Odebrecht paid over $59 million in bribes to Panama between 2010 and 2014 to secure $175 million in contracts. De Saint Malo called for the return of the money to state coffers, while the Panamanian government barred Odebrecht from bidding on future tenders and removed the company from existing projects.

site_title: Startups see growing government support
summary: Hong Kong has signed a landmark memorandum of understanding with Shenzhen to build an 87-hectare joint innovation and technology park, marking the city's growing support for startups and entrepreneurship. The park aims to be the largest innovation and technology platform in Hong Kong's history, bolstering the city's innovation ecosystem. This move is seen as a response to Singapore's well-established entrepreneurial ecosystem, with Hong Kong's government introducing measures to support startups, such as the Cyberport Macro Fund and Innovation and Technology Venture Fund.

site_title: McLaren dominates supercar market with global sales up 99.3%
summary: McLaren Automotive reports a 99.3% increase in global sales, with 3,286 cars sold in 2016, surpassing 1,000 North American sales for the first time. The company announces its third consecutive year of profitability and growth across all regions worldwide. This success is attributed to the introduction of the McLaren Sport Series, which offers improved fuel efficiency and comfort features. McLaren aims to produce 5,000 cars annually and plans to invest over £1 billion in research and development, with 15 new models set to be introduced over the next six years, including a fully electric concept car.

site_title: Investing ideas for 2017
summary: Investors can expect volatility to remain elevated in 2017, driven by higher-risk protection costs despite lower actualized real market costs. Equity income is a powerful theme, with gold remaining a hedge against reckless monetary policy. M&A activity in small and mid-size equities is expected to increase due to economic growth in Asia, particularly in Greece and household growth in Asia. Inflation will play a key role in 2017, with infrastructure investment seen as an alternative monetary policy. China's reform plans are on track, and its millennials are driving the country's economic growth, making it an attractive investment theme for 2017.

site_title: South Korea special prosecutors to question Samsung executives
summary: South Korean special prosecutors have summoned Samsung Electronics Co executives Choi Gee-sung and Chang Choong-ki for questioning amid an influence-peddling scandal that led to President Park Geun-hye's impeachment. The two executives, who have not been accused of wrongdoing, are expected to testify on Monday. Their questioning comes as part of the widening investigation into the scandal, which has significant implications for the company and its leadership.

site_title: Ensuring the right culture from the top
summary: A company's board is responsible for establishing a high-standard corporate governance system, but its effectiveness can be undermined by the behavior of its members. A strong corporate culture and risk culture are crucial, with the board playing a critical role in driving these cultures. However, a weak risk culture can be detrimental, as seen in the Enron example. To address this, boards should focus on behavioral and not just structural elements of risk management, and implement measures such as risk management training and cultural assessments to ensure a strong risk culture.

site_title: Taking a big step in the tourism industry
summary: Ski Yeo, a Singaporean entrepreneur, left her stable job to pursue her dream of setting up a walking tour agency in Hong Kong in 2009. She founded Big Foot Tour in 2011 with a $5,000 investment, offering unique, customizable tours that have consistently received high ratings on TripAdvisor. Yeo attributes her success to the city's infrastructure and business-friendly environment, and her focus on providing high-quality guides and tours. Her company has grown from one person to five guides, and she plans to expand further, targeting digitally savvy, affluent customers.

site_title: UK consumer spending seen losing momentum
summary: UK consumer spending is expected to lose momentum in the coming months due to inflation and economic uncertainty. Retailers such as Marks & Spencer and Debenhams will provide business updates, which will be scrutinized for insights into household spending. The UK's decision to leave the EU has already had an impact on the economy, and any signs of weakness in consumer spending could indicate a continued challenging economic outlook.

site_title: Istanbul nightclub attacker an Uzbek jihadist: reports
summary: A 34-year-old Uzbek jihadist linked to the Islamic State (IS) group has been identified as the attacker who killed 39 people at an Istanbul nightclub on New Year's night. The individual, known by the code name Ebu Muhammed Horasani, was part of a Central Asian IS cell. The attack, which occurred 75 minutes into 2017, was the first claimed by IS in Turkey. Despite an intense manhunt, the killer remains on the run.

site_title: Total rethink needed for S'pore economy to stay relevant: business leaders
summary: Singapore's economy needs a thorough rethink to remain relevant, according to business leaders. The Committee on the Future Economy's (CFE) report, set to release later this month, should focus on strategic shifts rather than tactical solutions to deal with disruptions. Corporate chiefs stress the need for Singapore to innovate, adapt to a VUCA environment, and empower SMEs to play a larger role in the economy. They also emphasize the importance of education and skills training for workers and students to remain competitive in the future landscape.

site_title: US oil sector sees tentative recovery
summary: The US oil sector is experiencing guarded optimism as it recovers from a two-year slump, with some low-cost drilling basins showing signs of improvement. Industry insiders describe a tentative recovery, despite depressed basins. The sector's recovery is attributed to the ongoing efforts to adapt to changing market conditions and lower crude prices.

images.alt_text: Sentiment got a boost from the Nov 30 agreement by Opec to cut production to address a supply glut.

site_title: Tillerson disclosure foreshadows knotty confirmations
summary: US Secretary of State nominee Rex Tillerson's disclosure of a $180 million cash payout from Exxon Mobil Corp if he becomes secretary of state has raised concerns about potential conflicts of interest. The payout was made through an independent trust to separate his financial interests from the oil company. Critics argue Exxon deviated from its compensation policies to extend a special arrangement to Tillerson. The arrangement also triggers a two-year recusal period from Exxon-related decisions, which could limit Tillerson's work as secretary of state. Tillerson's ethics filing and confirmation hearings have highlighted the complexity of vetting high-net-worth appointees under the Trump administration.

site_title: Hyperloop One discloses contenders vying for futuristic rail
summary: Hyperloop One has disclosed 35 contenders from a field of 2,600 teams vying to test its near-supersonic rail transit system. The companies are located in various countries, including the US, Australia, and the Middle East, and include projects such as hyperloop links between Sydney and Melbourne, Shanghai and Hangzhou, and London and Edinburgh. The startup aims to start three systems, with a goal of increasing its pipeline of real projects. A hyperloop test system is currently being constructed in the desert outside of Las Vegas, and the company has secured a deal with Dubai to conduct a feasibility study for a potential hyperloop link.

site_title: Patrick Daniel heads SPH Golf Club
summary: The SPH Golf Club has appointed a dynamic team, headed by Patrick Daniel, deputy CEO of Singapore Press Holdings, to manage the club. The bye-laws and constitution have been approved by the Singapore Golf Association. The team will oversee membership growth, which has been increasing rapidly. A programme of events for the year will be drawn up shortly. The club's committee members are comprised of experienced journalists and active golfers.

site_title: Rethinking retirement
summary: The traditional retirement plan of a 30-year accumulation phase followed by 20-30 years of drawdown may be a thing of the past. Experts are rethinking retirement strategies, considering shorter accumulation periods and longer drawdown phases. A survey found that Singaporeans believe they need around $1.39 million to retire comfortably. This shift in thinking may be driven by increasing life expectancy and changing workforce dynamics.

site_title: Shanghai suspends sales of commercial office projects
summary: Shanghai municipal authorities suspended sales of commercial office projects from January 6 to address concerns about irregularities in the property market, including soaring prices and "illegal sales and unauthorized alterations." The suspension comes amid increasing complaints from residents and authorities. This move is part of efforts to crack down on market irregularities and ensure compliance with regulations.

site_title: Fed governor calls for relook of Volcker Rule
summary: Federal Reserve Governor Jerome Powell has called for a reevaluation of the Volcker Rule, which restricts proprietary trading by large financial institutions. He argues that the current law is too burdensome and expensive, requiring a high degree of scrutiny into traders' intentions. Powell's comments come as the US economy shows signs of improvement, but he still urges caution against building up financial risks.

site_title: JTC gives O&M lessees and tenants rental rebates of 3-10% for 2017
summary: JTC has announced rental rebates of 3-10% to O&M lessees and tenants for 2017, marking the first time since the 2009 global financial crisis. The move aims to support the struggling offshore and marine industry. Industry observers welcome the gesture but question its impact on deeper structural problems. The rebate is seen as a step in the right direction, but its effectiveness in reviving the sector remains to be seen.

site_title: Markets to enter "wait and see'' mode
summary: Financial markets are entering a "wait and see" mode, awaiting the start of the new year to reassess their performance. The "January effect" is a phenomenon where prices rise at the start of the year after falling at the end of the previous year. This may be due to investors selling losing positions to realize tax losses and buying back immediately. Markets are reasonably efficient, making it difficult to exploit this phenomenon.

site_title: Personal data protection: An intrinsic priority of Singapore's largest bank
summary: DBS, Singapore's largest bank, has integrated personal data protection into its overall data governance approach, adopting a single framework across all operations. The bank has appointed a data protection officer and uses aggregated data to analyze customer service issues, resulting in more effective implementation of personal data protection policies. The introduction of the Do Not Call Registry has also improved customer experience by allowing DBS to focus resources on marketing efforts. DBS views personal data protection as a key aspect of its business, aiming to provide seamless banking services through responsible use of data analytics.

site_title: Gold futures extend decline while copper steadies as US wage gains fuel rate angst
summary: US wages rose 2.9% in December, the most during the current expansion, fueling concerns the Federal Reserve will continue to raise interest rates, reducing the appeal of gold. Gold futures fell 0.7% to $1,173.40 an ounce, while copper steadied after a 2.6% gain on Wednesday. The strong US payrolls report and speculation on US economic growth have fueled rate angst, with the jobless rate ticking up to 4.7%.

site_title: Robots show their 'personality' at big tech show
summary: Robots with distinct personalities are being showcased at the Consumer Electronics Show (CES) in Las Vegas. Companies like Hanson Robotics and Mayfield Robotics are introducing robots that can be companions, educators, and babysitters, with features such as lifelike facial expressions, emotional responses, and voice commands. The robots can assist with homework, play games, and teach children about maths and science. Several companies are also releasing robots designed for specific needs, including children with special needs and elderly care.

site_title: Trump accepts US intelligence on Russia hacking: chief of staff
summary: President-elect Donald Trump accepts the US intelligence community's conclusion that Russia engaged in cyberattacks aimed at disrupting the US elections. Trump's chief of staff, Reince Priebus, stated that Trump accepts the fact that entities in Russia were behind the intrusions into the Democratic Party organizations and operatives. Trump plans to order the intelligence community to make recommendations on actions to be taken in response.

site_title: Florida airport reopens after shooting rampage
summary: Fort Lauderdale International Airport reopened on Saturday after a shooting rampage by 26-year-old Esteban Santiago, who killed five people, wounded eight, and sent thousands scrambling for safety. Santiago, an Iraq war veteran, allegedly opened fire with a semi-automatic handgun in the baggage claim area of Terminal 2. Authorities are investigating the incident, which may be linked to terrorism, and have taken Santiago into custody. The airport was closed for 11 hours before reopening, with nearly 20,000 pieces of luggage and personal items abandoned by fleeing passengers.

site_title: Staying relevant
summary: Singapore's Committee on the Future Economy must address key issues to stay competitive in a globalized economy. Experts expect the committee to focus on entrepreneurship, innovation, and adapting to the digital economy. Key areas include developing a "Silicon Valley State of Mind" for businesses, leveraging data for growth, and creating a smart and secure workforce. The committee should also prioritize serving Asean markets, fostering a culture of experimentation and innovation, and addressing the skills gap in the labor market. By addressing these issues, Singapore can thrive in the future economy.

site_title: Anbang in talks with Kushner to overhaul building in NYC: source
summary: China's Anbang Insurance Group is in talks with Kushner Companies to redevelop a 41-floor building in New York City's 666 Fifth Avenue. The deal, which has not been completed, involves Anbang investing in a project to revitalize the building, which is owned by Jared Kushner, US President-elect Donald Trump's son-in-law. Kushner is studying how to divest from the family business if he takes a role in the Trump administration, and must also determine if federal anti-conflict of interest laws will prevent him from working in a government run by his father-in-law.

images.alt_text: Mr Kushner is believed to be in consideration for a senior White House role as a trusted confidant to his father-in-law.

site_title: Hollywood set to party at razzle-dazzle Golden Globes
summary: The 2017 Golden Globes ceremony took place on January 8, 2017, at the Beverly Hilton hotel, with La La Land leading the nominations with seven, including best comedy/musical and best actor and actress for Ryan Gosling and Emma Stone. Other top contenders included Moonlight, Manchester by the Sea, and Jackie. Host Jimmy Fallon is expected to bring a lighthearted tone to the ceremony, which also includes performances by various celebrities and live broadcasts of the event.

site_title: Thousands of Mexicans protest gasoline price hikes
summary: Thousands of Mexicans protested gasoline price hikes in Mexico City, with looting in hundreds of stores and over 1,000 arrests reported in Latin America. The 14-20% price increase, part of a year-long price liberalization plan, has fueled outrage among Mexicans facing rising inflation. Protests were reported in multiple states, with no reports of violence in Mexico City. The government's efforts to justify the hike have been unsuccessful, with protesters chanting "No to the gasoline price hike, Pena out."

site_title: Smartphone boom begun by Apple blazes on
summary: The iPhone, introduced by Steve Jobs in 2007, marked the beginning of the smartphone revolution, changing the world with its focus on apps and mobile computing. Ten years later, Apple is under pressure to create a new innovation, as sales decline in a saturated market. Despite this, the iPhone's impact on the industry is undeniable, with analysts crediting it for the widespread adoption of mobile computing and the virtual reality trend. Apple is working to diversify its revenue streams through services and apps, but the company's next "big thing" remains uncertain.

images.alt_text: Insiders at the CES trade show cited the iPhone as the main impetus for the revolutionary shift to mobile computing lifestyles.

site_title: Pakistan's textile sector struggles to bounce back
summary: Pakistan's textile sector struggles to recover after a decade of crippling power cuts, with energy costs doubling from 6 rupees to 11 rupees per kilowatt-hour. The sector, which employs 30% of the working population, has seen a third of its production capacity disappear, with thousands of factories closing. Only manufacturers that invested in their own energy production have survived, with some using multiple sources of electricity. The government has promised to end power cuts by 2018, but the sector remains vulnerable to rising natural gas imports bills and high energy costs.

site_title: Recession flatlines Lagos property projects
summary: Lagos, Nigeria's largest city, is struggling with a construction freeze due to a damaging recession. The city's Eko Atlantic project, billed as the largest real estate project in Africa, has slowed to a snail's pace. Construction projects have been halted due to a shortage of foreign exchange, making it difficult for developers to access funds. The project, expected to house nearly 500,000 people, is now facing uncertainty about when it will resume. Experts predict a long-term slowdown in the Nigerian economy, with limited foreign investment and a lack of housing stock exacerbating the issue.

site_title: US reacting at analog pace to rising digital risk
summary: The US government's slow response to a 16-month digital threat from Russia's president Vladimir Putin has raised concerns about the country's cyberdefenses and deterrence. The report, compiled by the FBI, CIA, and NSA, reveals that the US intelligence agencies failed to escalate the issue despite early warnings from British intelligence and a low-level FBI agent. The delay, which spanned from July 2015 to October 2016, was attributed to a lack of speed and agility in the government's response, with officials prioritizing other threats and being bound by history and tradition.

images.alt_text: Mr Putin played a weak hand skillfully, blending old information-warfare techniques with the echo chamber created by the Internet.

site_title: Speculation of policy and trade wars after Trump's Toyota tweet
summary: US President-elect Donald Trump's tweet to Toyota Motor Corporation, warning against building a new car plant in Mexico to export to the US, has sparked speculation of "Trump trade wars." However, some analysts believe the tweet may trigger a policy war within the US administration, with Speaker Paul Ryan stating that tax reform is the better way to address trade imbalances. Trump's threat has also raised concerns about the future of the North American Free Trade Agreement (Nafta) and the Trans-Pacific Partnership (TPP).

site_title: The madness that's Chase credit card bonus
summary: The Chase Sapphire Reserve credit card is set to end its lucrative sign-up bonus offer, which rewards 100,000 points worth $1,500 for spending $4,000 in three months. The card, which has a $450 annual fee, also offers travel perks, dining rewards, and access to airport lounges. Analysts at Bernstein Research say the offer is likely to end due to the bank's desire to model the card's long-term profitability and mitigate the impact of the $200-300 million hit to its earnings. The move may spark a price war among credit card issuers, but experts believe American Express will not follow suit.

site_title: Carrie Fisher's ashes in big Prozac urn
summary: Carrie Fisher, the late actress and mental health advocate, was buried in a Prozac pill-shaped urn at Forest Lawn Memorial Park in Hollywood Hills. The urn was a tribute to her favorite possession, a giant Prozac pill, and was chosen by her brother Todd Fisher and daughter Billie Lourd. Fisher, who suffered from bipolar disorder, died on December 27 after suffering a heart attack, just a day after her mother Debbie Reynolds passed away due to a stroke. Her legacy as a mental health advocate continues, with many praising her wit and humor in coping with her illness.

site_title: IT courses the most popular with Singaporeans using SkillsFuture credit
summary: Singaporeans have been favoring IT courses under the SkillsFuture program, with information and communications technology being the most popular area of training for all age groups above 25. Younger Singaporeans prefer courses like data analytics, while older ones focus on basic computer skills. These findings were released by SkillsFuture Singapore, indicating a shift in training preferences among Singaporeans.

site_title: Germany's radical Islamist scene growing: security chief
summary: Germany's domestic security chief, Hans-Georg Maassen, warned that the country's radical Islamist scene is growing and becoming more decentralized, posing challenges to surveillance operations. The number of Salafists has risen to over 9,700, up from 3,800 in 2011. Maassen defended security officials who failed to stop the Berlin truck attack suspect, Anis Amri, saying they had done everything they could, but acknowledged that the decentralized nature of the scene makes it harder to monitor. The scene is now characterized by many small clusters of individuals, rather than a unified group.

site_title: Europe: shares close up from lows after US jobs data
summary: European stocks rallied from lows after a stronger-than-anticipated US jobs report, with the STOXX 600 index posting its best weekly performance since December. The report showed less-than-expected job growth but a rebound in wages, indicating sustained labor market momentum and setting up the economy for stronger growth and further interest rate increases.

site_title: Live and Loud
summary: English singer-songwriter Passenger and Mercury Music Prize winner PJ Harvey will perform in Singapore for the first time on January 13. Passenger will play at The Star, while PJ Harvey will perform at the Esplanade Theatre. The concerts will feature Passenger's hits like "Let Her Go" and PJ Harvey's influential music. Tickets are available through Sistic.

site_title: The philosophical failings of forecasting
summary: Investors often miss big gains or sell at lows due to their tendency to stay wedded to predictions. This phenomenon stems from cognitive and philosophical failings, including the human desire to control uncertainty and the tendency to overestimate one's own skills. When predictions are wrong, people tend to double down on their claims rather than admitting error, leading to costly mistakes. By acknowledging the limitations of forecasting and implementing rules such as stop-loss orders, investors can reduce these errors and make better decisions.

site_title: US: Dow misses 20,000 points by a hair; tech shares strong
summary: The Dow Jones Industrial Average closed at 19,963.80, narrowly missing the 20,000-point milestone, but still up 0.3% on a strong day for technology shares. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Index also hit new records. The US economy added 156,000 jobs in December, with average hourly earnings rising to $26.00. Despite mixed early trading, US stocks ended with a positive tone, driven by optimism over President-elect Donald Trump's pro-growth agenda.

site_title: Palestinian plows truck into Israeli soldiers, killing four
summary: A Palestinian driver plowed a truck into a group of Israeli soldiers visiting a tourist spot in Jerusalem, killing four and wounding at least 15 people. The driver, a 28-year-old Palestinian from the east Jerusalem neighborhood of Jabal Mukaber, was also killed. Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu alleged the attacker "supported" the Islamic State group. Chaos erupted at the scene, with hundreds of soldiers arriving as part of a tour for troops about the history of Jerusalem.

site_title: From O levels to chief executive officer
summary: Hong Kong businesswoman Adeline Lee, who completed her O levels and rose to become a marketing director at 21, founded Grey DPI, a retail design consultancy, in 1986. Her company has since expanded to retail design, shopper marketing, and advertising consultancy, with offices in Hong Kong, Guangzhou, Shanghai, Taiwan, and Singapore. Grey DPI was acquired by WPP in 2010 and has since grown to a multimillion-dollar company employing 150 people, with revenue doubling in the last five years. Lee attributes her company's success to setting up in Hong Kong, citing its large market and proximity to mainland China.

site_title: 12 dead as torrential rain submerges Thai south
summary: Heavy rains in Thailand's south have caused 12 deaths and submerged thousands of villages since the flooding started a week ago. The floods, which have affected over 700,000 people, are expected to persist for at least two more days. The capital of Nakhon Si Thammarat province received a record 162.1mm of rain on Friday night, and tourist hotspots such as Samui and Phangan have been disrupted. Meanwhile, severe flooding in Malaysia has left around 12,500 evacuees, down from nearly 23,000 earlier in the week.

site_title: Burgundy stirred, not shaken by sale to US billionaire
summary: US billionaire Stanley Kroenke has acquired an 80% stake in the Bonneau du Martray vineyard in Burgundy, France, for an undisclosed sum. The vineyard, which has been run by the same family for nearly 200 years, produces two highly regarded grand crus wines. Kroenke, who also owns Arsenal football club and vineyards in Napa Valley, has stated that he will respect Burgundy's wine tradition and maintain the vineyard's quality. The sale is rare in Burgundy, where large domains are typically divided among smaller plots.

site_title: Michelle Obama issues emotive parting message
summary: Michelle Obama delivered an emotive farewell speech, urging young Americans to fight for their future, not fear it. As the first African-American First Lady, she focused on promoting healthy lifestyles, education, and supporting military families. She also denounced Donald Trump's attacks on immigrants and Muslims, emphasizing the importance of diversity and freedom. With her husband Barack Obama leaving office on January 20, Michelle Obama's message of empowerment and hope concludes her eight-year tenure as First Lady.

site_title: Virtual reality seeks momentum at CES gadget gala
summary: Virtual reality made its presence at the Consumer Electronics Show, with companies showcasing headsets, content, and tools to deliver immersive experiences. Despite being a hot topic, VR failed to gain mainstream traction, with a focus on what it takes to bring it to the masses. This year's show highlighted the need for more affordable and user-friendly options to make VR accessible to a wider audience.

site_title: Audi sales hit record in 2016, despite losing ground to rivals
summary: Audi reported record deliveries of 1.87 million luxury and SUV vehicles in 2016, despite losing ground to rivals Mercedes-Benz and BMW. Sales increased by 4% in the US and 6.4% in Britain, the brand's second-largest European market. Despite this, Audi is unlikely to maintain its second-place position due to the diesel emissions scandal. The Audi brand attributed its sales growth to luxury car and SUV sales.

site_title: Smartphone revolution blazes on as iPhone turns 10
summary: The iPhone, introduced by Steve Jobs in 2007, has revolutionized mobile computing, changing the world over the past decade. The iPhone's focus on apps led to a proliferation of mobile internet usage, influencing virtual reality, social media, and e-commerce. Apple's trend-setting power is evident in the widespread adoption of "infotainment" systems and smart-home networks. However, the company faces pressure to innovate, with declining iPhone sales and decreasing executive compensation. Analysts believe Apple will continue to thrive through smaller, incremental innovations, rather than relying on a single "big thing."

site_title: Score-settling, trash-talking Trump set in his ways
summary: Donald Trump, set to be sworn in as president, has shown no change in his behavior since his campaign, continuing to engage in score-settling and trash-talking. He has mocked a journalist with a disability and argued with the parents of an Army captain killed in Iraq. Trump's focus on settling scores has been a hallmark of his campaign, and his presidency is expected to continue this trend. This behavior is far removed from what is considered presidential, raising concerns about his ability to lead effectively.

site_title: Thousand fired in new wave of Turkey coup purges
summary: Turkey has dismissed over 6,000 people and ordered the closure of dozens of associations under the state of emergency imposed after the July failed coup. More than 100,000 people have been suspended or sacked, and dozens of media outlets have been shut down. The latest government decrees also ordered the dismissal of 2,687 police officers, 1,699 civil servants, and hundreds of employees from other ministries. The crackdown has been criticized by the European Union and human rights activists, with critics claiming it targets anyone who has dared show opposition to President Recep Tayyip Erdogan.

site_title: Putin sought to help Trump in election: US intel report
summary: US intelligence says Russian President Vladimir Putin ordered a campaign of hacking and media manipulation to undermine Hillary Clinton's presidential campaign and boost Donald Trump's chances. Putin's goals included damaging Clinton's electability and denigrating her, as well as undermining public faith in the US democratic process. The report warned that Russia will likely attempt to influence other elections worldwide, including those of US allies. Despite this, Trump acknowledged cyber-attacks by Russia and China, but declined to single out Russia over US election interference, stating the election's outcome was not affected by hacking.

site_title: SpaceX set to launch again on Monday
summary: SpaceX plans to launch 10 Iridium NEXT communications satellites from Vandenberg Air Force Base in California on Monday, following a successful static test fire. The company had previously experienced a launchpad explosion in September that destroyed a satellite, but has traced the problem to a pressure vessel in the second-stage liquid oxygen tank. SpaceX will redesign its pressure vessels and change its fueling process. This marks the company's second launch since the September incident, after initially aiming to resume flights in November.

site_title: North Korea says can test-launch ICBM at any time: KCNA
summary: North Korea claims it can test-launch an intercontinental ballistic missile (ICBM) at any time and from any location set by leader Kim Jong Un, citing US hostility as the reason for its arms development. The country's nuclear-capable ICBM could threaten the continental United States, approximately 9,000 km away. Despite US President-elect Donald Trump's tweet stating "It won't happen!", the US State Department believes North Korea is not capable of mounting a nuclear warhead on a ballistic missile. North Korea has been under UN sanctions since 2006 over its nuclear and ballistic missile tests.

site_title: Five dead in Fort Lauderdale airport shooting
summary: A gunman opened fire at Fort Lauderdale-Hollywood airport in Florida, killing five people and injuring eight. The suspect, identified as Esteban Santiago, was taken into custody. The shooting occurred in the baggage claim area of Terminal 2, and the motive for the attack is unclear. The incident has sent panicked travelers fleeing for safety, and the airport has been shut down. Governor Rick Scott and President-elect Donald Trump have been briefed on the situation, with Trump offering "thoughts and prayers" to those affected.

images.alt_text: A gunman opened fire on Friday at Fort Lauderdale-Hollywood airport, a major tourist hub in Florida, killing five people and injuring eight, and sending panicked travelers fleeing for safety.

site_title: China Dec forex reserves fall less than expected to US$3.011t
summary: China's foreign exchange reserves fell by $41 billion in December to $3.011 trillion, the lowest since February 2011, as the yuan depreciated 6.6% against the dollar in 2016. Economists had expected a $51 billion drop. The yuan's decline is attributed to US President-elect Donald Trump's vow to label China a currency manipulator and impose tariffs on Chinese goods. China's gold reserves also fell to $67.878 billion. If reserves continue to decline, some strategists believe China may need to sanction another big devaluation, potentially roiling global markets.

site_title: Art Across The City
summary: The Singapore Art Week, a 12-day event, is set to take place from January 11-22, featuring almost 100 visual arts activities. Highlights include the Art Stage Singapore art fair, the Contemporary Printmaking Festival, and the Art After Dark party at Gillman Barracks.

site_title: Amazon's Alexa moves in on Google's Android system
summary: Amazon's Alexa made a significant appearance at CES, with companies like Whirlpool and Ford unveiling products featuring the digital assistant. Huawei, a Chinese firm manufacturing Android smartphones, announced an Alexa app for its US flagship handsets. This marks a rare instance of Alexa appearing on rival Google's Android system. The move signifies Amazon's expanding presence in the Android ecosystem, further solidifying Alexa's position as a dominant voice assistant.

site_title: Putin foe McCain could emerge as bulwark against Trump
summary: Senator John McCain, 80, has positioned himself as a national security hawk opposing President-elect Donald Trump, particularly on Russia. McCain blasts Putin as "a thorn in the side" and calls for stricter sanctions, contrasting with Trump's coziness with the Kremlin. McCain's stance has earned him respect from colleagues, with some lawmakers viewing him as a bulwark against Trump's perceived naivete about Russia. McCain's confrontational strategy may influence Republican leaders in Congress, who are weighing their stance on Russia and national security.

images.alt_text: At 80, John McCain has begun his sixth term in the US Senate by proving to be a thorn in Donald Trump's side even before the president-elect takes the oath of office.

site_title: The home-buying decision
summary: Choosing a home can be emotionally and morally challenging, driven by a mix of aesthetics, aspirations, and psychological factors. The process forces individuals to separate their desires from reality, often prioritizing private spaces over social connections. As the US becomes increasingly fragmented, the decision to buy a home can contribute to self-segregation, damaging open-mindedness and civic fabric. Ultimately, the focus on a house's features can overshadow the importance of social relationships and neighborhood dynamics, leading to a potentially miserable existence.

site_title: Canada competition bureau drops probe of Apple
summary: Canada's Competition Bureau has closed its two-year investigation into Apple's contracts with local wireless carriers, finding insufficient evidence of anti-competitive behavior. The probe, launched in 2014, aimed to determine if Apple's exclusive contracts stifled competition when the iPhone was introduced in 2008. The Bureau concluded that Apple did not engage in an abuse of dominance under the Competition Act, allowing the contracts to stand. The decision marks the end of a lengthy investigation that aimed to balance the interests of Apple and Canadian wireless carriers.

site_title: China home prices, property investment likely to rise in 2017
summary: China's average home prices are forecast to rise 4.1% in 2017, while property investment growth is expected to rise 5.4%. Average home prices will reach 7,435 yuan (S$1,539) per square meter. Despite this, the property market is expected to face downward pressure due to tightening monetary policy and restrictive housing policies. New construction starts are also expected to rise 6.2% to 1.78 billion sq m. The government is urged to develop a long-term mechanism to regulate the property market through reforms in real estate registration and residence permits.

site_title: Triyards Q1 net slumps 66% on lower gross margin
summary: Triyards Holdings, a Singapore-based yard operating arm of Ezra Holdings, reported a 66% slump in Q1 net profit to US$2.07 million, driven by lower gross margin due to a competitive market environment. Despite a 17% increase in revenue to US$91.2 million, the company attributed the decline to a mix of projects on its order book and the absence of contributions from completed liftboats. The company's order book remains strong at US$352 million, with diversification efforts beyond the oil and gas industry.

site_title: US watchdog claims thousands of D-Link users exposed to hacking
summary: A US watchdog, the Federal Trade Commission (FTC), has sued D-Link Corp, a Taiwan-based maker of home-networking equipment, alleging lax security left its products vulnerable to hackers. The FTC claims thousands of American consumers were exposed to targeted online security breaches due to unsecured routers and web cameras. D-Link denies the allegations, but will defend itself in court and publish a question-and-answer note for consumers. The regulator seeks a court order barring the company from engaging in unfair or deceptive acts.

site_title: Tycoon Li Ka-shing sees Hong Kong property prices rising amid curbs
summary: Hong Kong's richest man, Li Ka-shing, expects the city's property prices to rise "a little bit" this year despite government curbs, including a 15% stamp duty increase. Despite initial developer stock declines, private housing prices surged in November, reaching the highest since 1979. Li believes CK Property's recurring income will increase 50% in the next two to three years, but is cautious about the economy in 2017 due to rising interest rates and political tensions.

site_title: 2017 likely to be a year of large M&A deals for Singapore
summary: Singapore's stock market has started 2017 with a flurry of deal-making activity, with two prominent firms, United Engineers and Global Logistic Properties, signaling they are up for sale. Chinese investors and private equity funds are leading the charge, seeking bargains in the market after a protracted period of sliding valuations. Expectations of rising interest rates have also driven companies to seek financial relief, with some owners potentially seeking trade sales of their assets. Analysts predict a busy year of large and mid-cap M&A deals in Singapore.

site_title: Taiwan president heads to US as Beijing watches
summary: Taiwan President Tsai Ing-wen is on a nine-day trip to Central America, with transit stops in Houston and San Francisco. Beijing is closely watching her visit, which comes after Tsai congratulated Donald Trump on his presidency in December, upending decades of diplomatic precedent. The move has heightened cross-strait tensions, with China considering Taiwan a breakaway province. Tsai's trip aims to strengthen ties with Taiwan's ally nations in Central America, but her interactions with US officials, particularly Trump, are expected to be scrutinized.

images.alt_text: Taiwan's President Tsai Ing-wen left for the United States on Saturday on her way to Central America, a trip that will be closely watched by Beijing, incensed by her congratulatory call to Donald Trump.

site_title: Job growth slows, but wages rebound strongly
summary: US employment increased by 156,000 jobs in December, below expectations, but wages rebounded strongly with a 10-cent or 0.4% gain in average hourly earnings, the largest increase since June 2009. The unemployment rate ticked up to 4.7% as more people entered the labor force. Despite a slowdown in job growth, the labor market remains near full employment, setting up the economy for stronger growth and further interest rate increases from the Federal Reserve this year.

site_title: Locally Brewed
summary: Singapore's cocktail bars are incorporating Traditional Chinese Medicine (TCM) into their drinks, blending foraged herbs and TCM brews with fruit infusions. The Library, a bar in Singapore, has launched five TCM cocktails, including the Rice and Shine, which combines gin, ginseng, and chrysanthemum. Forager and bartender Vijay Mudaliar's Native cocktail bar also features foraged ingredients, while Alchemist Beer Lab infuses ingredients into draft beer to create unique flavors. The trend is gaining popularity, with The Library and Alchemist Beer Lab in preliminary talks to expand into Japan, Hong Kong, and China.

site_title: Public sector projects to boost construction demand in 2017
summary: The Singapore government plans to boost construction demand in 2017 with S$28-35 billion worth of public sector projects, accounting for 70% of the total. Major projects include the Circle Line 6 and the Deep Tunnel Sewerage System. Private sector demand is expected to be around S$8-11 billion, with redevelopment projects such as Funan DigitaLife Mall and the CPF Building. The government's efforts aim to counter dwindling private sector building projects.

site_title: Yuan pares record rally as Goldman says now is the time to sell
summary: The offshore yuan pared its record weekly rally as China's central bank raised its fixing rate, narrowing the gap between the offshore and onshore rates. The exchange rate fell 1.1% to 6.8623 a dollar, following a 2.5% surge over the past two sessions. Analysts, including Goldman Sachs, advised clients to sell the yuan, citing concerns over capital outflows and interest rate hikes. The yuan is expected to weaken further this year, with some predicting a decline to 7.16 per dollar by year-end.

site_title: Three parties shortlisted for Jurong Point
summary: Macquarie, Blackstone, and Frasers Centrepoint have been shortlisted for the purchase of Guthrie and Lee Kim Tah's space in Jurong Point mall in Singapore. The three parties have each offered around S$2.2 billion for the 658,000 square foot commercial net lettable area, with Macquarie and Blackstone's offers exceeding S$3,350 per square foot. The sale of the mall, Singapore's largest suburban shopping center, is expected to be finalized after due diligence.

site_title: Singapore landlord finally hears its investors knocking
summary: Singapore's sovereign wealth fund, GIC Pte, is urging Global Logistic Properties Ltd (GLP) to release billions of dollars of trapped shareholder value. GLP, a US$40 billion warehouse landlord, has sent a letter to potential bidders, seeking first-round offers by early next month. The company's shares jumped 9.4% after the announcement. GLP's investors had expected a bigger upside from the fund management business, but the company's return on equity trails the benchmark's average due to low leverage. The window for a slice-and-dice restructuring is closing, and selling all of itself may be a more viable option.

site_title: Mainboard listed Procurri looks to become a global player
summary: Procurri Corp, a Singapore-listed IT hardware and maintenance services provider, aims to become a global player by changing the way technology is bought and sold through a sharing platform. The company, which made its trading debut on the mainboard last year, plans to capture a significant share of the $30 billion industry through acquisitions and expansion into North America, Europe, and Asia. With a market capitalization of $110 million, Procurri seeks to unlock opportunities in the industry by offering cost-effective and quality IT hardware, as well as independent maintenance services, to customers.

images.alt_text: The capital - net proceeds of S$34.6 million from the Singapore IPO - is already in the bag. "From now until 2018, it's an execution story," says Mr Murphy.

site_title: Parliament to discuss Terrex seizure and Singtel Internet outage
summary: Singapore's Parliament will discuss two major issues on Monday, including the detention of nine Singapore Armed Forces armoured vehicles in Hong Kong and the massive fibre broadband Internet service disruption by Singtel. MPs will also ask ministers about Singapore's relations with China, job market projections, and the cause of the Singtel outage. Six Bills, including one to amend the Presidential Elections Bill, are up for second reading and will be debated. The upcoming presidential election is expected to pave the way for Singapore's first Malay head of state in 47 years.

images.alt_text: The first Parliament sitting of the new year takes place on Monday afternoon, with Members of Parliament (MPs) filing 97 questions - 68 for oral answer and 29 for a written response - for various ministers to answer.

site_title: Hong Seh drives Maserati's first SUV into town
summary: Maserati has introduced its first SUV, the Levante, in Singapore, confirming it is not up for sale. The luxury crossover will be available from authorized distributor Hong Seh Motors. The Levante joins other premium SUVs like the Jaguar F-Pace and Porsche Cayenne, tapping into the growing demand for luxury SUVs.

site_title: With manicures and make-up, Japan's 'genderless' blur line between pink and blue
summary: In Japan, a growing number of young men, known as "genderless danshi," are challenging traditional gender norms by adopting androgynous fashion styles, including makeup and brightly colored clothing. They aim to blur the lines between pink and blue masculinity and femininity, rejecting the idea that men and women must adhere to specific dress codes. Social media platforms and television programs have helped these individuals gain popularity, with some becoming TV celebrities. Their fashion choices have also sparked discussions about the limits of traditional gender roles and the importance of self-expression.

site_title: Beijing said to mull closer scrutiny of US firms
summary: Beijing is considering increased scrutiny of US companies, including tax or antitrust probes, in the event of a trade war between the US and China. This move comes after US President-elect Donald Trump's potential punitive measures against Chinese goods. Well-known US companies with large Chinese operations could be targeted. The move aims to protect Chinese interests and counter any potential US retaliation.

site_title: My Weekend
summary: Honey Lee, managing director of Heat Branding, shares her weekend plans, revealing she prioritizes a morning workout before a relaxing evening of dining and socializing. Her weekend includes activities such as wakeboarding, brunch at VLV, and catching a movie.

site_title: New rules on declaring tax residency to financial firms kick in
summary: Singapore has implemented new rules requiring customers to declare their tax residency status to financial institutions, which will be automatically exchanged with at least 15 tax jurisdictions that have signed tax pacts with Singapore under the Common Reporting Standard (CRS) framework. The rules took effect on January 1, 2017, and aim to combat tax evasion. Customers who provide false tax information can face fines of up to S$10,000 or imprisonment for up to two years. The automatic exchange of information is expected to enhance Singapore's reputation as a financial center and simplify cross-border tax information sharing.

site_title: The human touch
summary: Lord Charles Allen, chairman of ISS, emphasizes the importance of recognizing employees through simple gestures like saying "thank you." He believes that this recognition can bring a smile to someone's face and make a significant difference in their work experience. To achieve this, ISS has introduced the Apple Award to acknowledge staff who go beyond the call of duty, reflecting the company's focus on providing a "human touch" in its services.

site_title: Comeback Dance Act
summary: Singaporean dance duo Ah Hock and Peng Yu are making a comeback with their new act Skin Tight, combining dance, zentai, taiji, and butoh. The performance will take place at the Esplanade Theatre Studio from January 13-14 as part of the M1 Singapore Fringe Festival. Tickets are available from Sistic.

site_title: Say Yes
summary: The Shilla Seoul hotel in South Korea is offering two proposal packages for couples, including a "Proposal Table" at its French restaurant Continental, which offers customized menus, flower choices, and ring delivery. The packages include specially decorated rooms, champagne, and chocolates, as well as access to hotel facilities. The goal is to make the proposal experience memorable and special for couples, similar to how Korean celebrities often choose The Shilla Seoul for their weddings.

site_title: Life Improvement
summary: Singaporean lifestyle and health tips are highlighted in this article, focusing on food, home organization, fitness, and personal development. Experts recommend buying local ingredients, investing in furniture with storage, and practicing mindfulness-based stress reduction. The article also touches on nutrition, exercise, and detox programs, as well as music therapy and reading habits. Additionally, it provides advice on relationships, including gratitude, eye contact, punctuality, and letting go of unnecessary conflicts.

site_title: A kaleidoscope of all things dark
