The Affordable Care Act is a regulatory framework, not a public insurance program, that imposes obligations on private insurers and individuals to expand coverage.

images.alt_text: President-elect Donald Trump and his Republican allies have vowed a swift repeal of President Barack Obama's landmark reforms known as Obamacare, a 2010 law which has had a dramatic impact on America's health care system.

site_title: Spanish banks recover from crisis but toxic assets still remain
summary: Spain's banking sector has recovered from the 2008 financial crisis, with problem loans decreasing from an average of 6% in 2016 to 9.2% in 2013. However, toxic assets remain, valued at 350 billion euros, and banks struggle to sell seized properties. Analysts predict further decline in problem loans due to favorable macroeconomic conditions. Despite this, banks have bolstered their liquidity and capital, and international diversification has helped them survive the crisis.

site_title: Possible Fed limits on Wall Street energy bets will be "harmful": US Chamber
summary: The US Chamber of Commerce has criticized the Federal Reserve's proposed plan to limit Wall Street's energy bets and commodities investments, calling it "harmful" and "extremely detrimental" to businesses. The plan, which would require banks to hold more capital against energy infrastructure, would lead to banks offering $4 billion in fresh capital, primarily affecting Goldman Sachs and Morgan Stanley. The Chamber has urged the Fed to withdraw the proposal, citing concerns that it would hinder merchant banking and create barriers to capital formation, ultimately affecting economic growth and financial stability.

site_title: Over-bizarre sci-fi series that is too hard to follow
summary: Netflix's original drama series "The OA" was released with minimal fanfare, sparking online frenzy due to its unique and complex storyline. Created by Zal Batmanglij and Brit Marling, the series follows Prairie Johnson, a blind woman who returns after being missing for seven years, and her quest to find others who have also gone missing. The show's convoluted plot, featuring multiple stories and universes, has left viewers and critics alike struggling to follow, with some praising its boldness and others finding it frustrating.

site_title: China to invest 2.5t yuan in renewable fuel by 2020
summary: China plans to invest 2.5 trillion yuan ($522 billion) in renewable power generation by 2020, with installed renewable capacity expected to contribute to about half of new electricity generation. The investment will create over 13 million jobs and boost capacity five times in solar power. Despite the significant investment, renewables will still only account for 15% of overall energy consumption by 2020, with coal remaining the primary fuel source for more than half of the nation's installed power capacity.

site_title: Samsung's chip, screen sales may drive Q4 profit to 3-year high
summary: Samsung Electronics is expected to forecast its best quarterly profit in nearly three years due to strong sales of mass-produced higher-end 3D NAND chips. The company's memory chip sales have eased the financial impact of a costly smartphone recall and lost sales of the Galaxy Note 7. Analysts attribute the positive outlook to the robust sales of Samsung's chips and screens. This could mark a significant recovery for the company, which had previously warned of a $2.1 billion loss in the fourth quarter of 2016.

site_title: Horse racing offers ample tips for this fund
summary: Hong Kong investor Alex Wong's Ample Capital Ltd has beaten 99% of its peers over 5 years, with a global fund that has returned an annualized 7.3% including dividends over the past 3 years. Wong attributes his success to finding favorable odds and valuations, and is now focused on the US long bond and US financial shares in 2017. He remains optimistic on US stocks, Russia's ruble, and Chinese consumer stocks, while warning of potential risks in emerging markets and the euro. Wong's investment strategy is guided by his "street smarts" and experience in the financial markets.

site_title: Oil and property stocks look interesting this year, says OCBC
summary: OCBC Investment Research head Carmen Lee suggests oil and property stocks are attractive in 2017, citing undervalued oil stocks and depressed property market. Oil stocks trade below book values, offering favorable risk-reward balance, while property stocks have a good dividend yield. Lee expects oil prices to rise, and property prices to recover in the next one to two years. She also notes that interest rates going up will not affect property prices in Singapore, which are at reasonable levels.

site_title: Obama defends legacy in letter to American people
summary: US President Barack Obama defended his legacy in a letter to the American people, highlighting key accomplishments such as the turnaround in the US economy, scaled-back military operations, and the Paris climate agreement. He emphasized the importance of the Affordable Care Act, which he believes will be targeted by his successor, Donald Trump. Obama criticized Trump's vow to repeal and replace the law, arguing it would harm 30 million Americans. The letter comes as Obama prepares to leave office and Trump prepares to take office on January 20.

site_title: 12 Days of art frenzy
summary: Singapore Art Week, starting on Jan 11, features the 7th edition of Art Stage, anchored by top-shelf art fair Art Stage, and supported by nearly 100 events. A new light will be shone on Singapore-based collectors with the introduction of the Collectors' Stage, showcasing works from six private collections, including those of renowned artists Steve McQueen and Jenny Holzer. Despite a smaller fair, Art Stage founder Lorenzo Rudolf remains optimistic about the turnout, citing an unprecedented number of collectors from Indonesia and a focus on quality art with reasonable prices.

images.alt_text: Yoshitomo Nara's Punch Me Harder (220 x 197cm, acrylic on paper) will feature at Whitestone Gallery as part of Art Stage Singapore.
Robert Zhao's Deer Park (84 x 121cm, archival pigment print, edition 5+1 AP) will be featured at Mizuma Gallery at Art Stage.
Mr Rudolf expects strong turnout from regional collectors.
Tintin Wulia's work Untold Movements is a large installation of black cloth equipped with speakers that project stories of people trapped within human-drawn borders.

site_title: Dispute resolution gets boost from Red Dot building
summary: The Ministry of Law in Singapore will take over the Red Dot Traffic building in May to expand Maxwell Chambers, a dispute resolution complex, with a budget of S$25 million. The expansion will add 120,000 square feet of floor space and house international dispute resolution institutions, arbitration chambers, and law firms. The move aims to strengthen Singapore's position as a legal hub in the region and capitalize on the growing demand for international dispute resolution. The expansion is expected to be recouped through rental revenue, with restoration works set to complete in 2019.

site_title: US spy chiefs see 'multifaceted' Russian bid to disrupt election
summary: US spy chiefs say Russia conducted a multifaceted campaign to disrupt the 2016 presidential election, including hacking and propaganda, with senior officials authorizing the attacks. Despite President-elect Donald Trump's skepticism, the intelligence community is convinced that Moscow interfered, posing a "major threat" to the US. The US and China also face cyber threats, with China continuing to conduct espionage against the US government and companies. The US spy chiefs will brief Trump on the evidence behind their conclusion on Russia's election interference and a declassified report is expected to be released next week.

site_title: Baidu family robot a Chinese spin on Amazon Echo
summary: Baidu unveiled 'Little Fish', a family robot voice-controlled virtual valet similar to Amazon Echo or Google Home, at the Consumer Electronics Show in Las Vegas. The robot, a translation of Baidu's Chinese name 'Xiaoyu Zaijia', will be released in China later this year. Baidu's chief scientist Andrew Ng stated that 2017 will be the year of conversational computing, with 'Little Fish' being a key player. The robot's release marks Baidu's entry into the smart home market, further expanding the company's presence in the tech industry.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: IMPERIUM Crown, a Singapore property investor, reported "irregularities" in a dividend payment, potentially breaching company rules. The issue has been reported to authorities, and the company hired legal advisers to investigate. Meanwhile, engineering firm ISOTeam plans to acquire Rong Shun Engineering & Construction for S$6.45 million, expanding its services. The acquisition will be funded by internal resources and a share placement.

site_title: Ascott's plans for luxury London residence hit snag
summary: CapitaLand's luxury London residence, The Cavendish, faces a legal hurdle after the UK Westminster City Council designated the area as a Special Policy Area to protect art galleries, including Franses Gallery. The council's move has blocked Ascott's plans to replace the gallery with retail stores, and the dispute will now be heard by the Royal Courts of Justice. The council's policy aims to preserve the historic character of the district and support the art trade.

site_title: Manhattan home prices fall as sellers concede to slowing market
summary: Manhattan home prices for resale condominiums and co-ops fell 6.3% in the fourth quarter to a median price of $900,000, marking the first annual decline since 2015. Sellers are lowering expectations as inventory mounts and buyers are turning away from listings deemed too expensive. The average discount off the last asking price was 4.7%, up from 3.1% a year earlier. Buyers agreed to pay over the asking price in just 13% of sales, down from 29% last year.

site_title: Govt urged to lead in fairer procurement
summary: The National Trades Union Congress (NTUC) has urged the government to lead in improving procurement practices, particularly in enhancing the Government Procurement Act to ensure reasonable compensation for service lapses. The labour movement suggests introducing the Principle of Proportionality to guide liquidated damages clauses and addressing one-sided contracts. The Association of Small and Medium Enterprises (ASME) has expressed concerns that SMEs are often at the losing end of unfair contracts, and their voices should be heard in any changes.

images.alt_text: Minister for Manpower Lim Swee Say (centre), speaking at the launch of "The Human Capital Movement" on July 31, 2015. Joining him are several SME representatives, and Foo Chek Wee (right), group HR director of Zalora South East Asia and one of Spring's 10 volunteer HR directors.

site_title: Canadian fintechs shine as investments near record
summary: Canadian fintech companies received a record-breaking US$137.7 million in venture capital funding in 2016, a 35% increase from the previous year. This represents a 74% rise from 2015 and is the highest level since 2000. Despite a decline in US and UK investments, Canada's fintech sector continues to attract new venture capital funds and foreign investors, driven by its supportive environment and access to talent. The sector's growth is expected to continue, with Canadian startups poised to expand into international markets.

site_title: HDB resale prices down 0.3% in Dec, 0.2% in 2016: SRX (Amended)
summary: HDB resale prices in Singapore dropped 0.3% in December, with 0.2% decline for the year, according to SRX Property. Prices for bigger flats were the main contributors to the decline. However, most consultants expect prices to stabilize in the second half of 2017, possibly making a positive turn. Resale transactions decreased 13.9% in December, but total transactions rose 3.9% for the full year, reaching 19,591.

images.alt_text: Resale prices in mature estates rose by one per cent for the whole year, compared to the 1.2 per cent drop in non-mature estates.

site_title: Tencent, Warburg lead US$215m funding round for China's Mobike
summary: Tencent Holdings Ltd and Warburg Pincus led a $215 million funding round for Mobike, a year-old Beijing startup, in China's urban bicycle-sharing scene. The round also included investors such as TPG Capital, Ctrip.com International Ltd, and Huazhu Hotels Group. This investment increases competition in the market, which has been growing rapidly.

site_title: Trump's great guessing game
summary: US President-elect Donald Trump is expected to unveil his economic programme, which includes large tax cuts costing $3 trillion and $500 billion in added spending for infrastructure and defence. These measures are predicted to enlarge budget deficits, estimated at $8.6 trillion over the decade. Economists at Nomura Securities have expressed "enormous uncertainty" about Trump's plans, highlighting the uncertainty surrounding his policies.

site_title: GSS Energy's oil thrust: fool's errand or visionary's touch?
summary: GSS Energy is venturing into hydrocarbon production despite the volatility of the oil & gas sector. The firm secured a contract with Indonesian state-owned energy giant PT Pertamina to produce oil from the Trembul field in Central Java, with a cost of production estimated in the low teens. GSS Energy's strategy is to secure low-cost assets and projects, which it believes will remain profitable even in low oil prices. The company's CEO, Sydney Yeung, believes the 15-year contract with Pertamina and guaranteed offtake will mitigate risks, but investors remain cautious due to GSS Energy's past failures in oil production and its uncertain cash reserves.

site_title: Apple to invest US$1b in SoftBank fund
summary: Apple is investing $1 billion in SoftBank Group Corp's $100 billion Vision fund, which will focus on startups globally. This investment follows Apple's $1 billion investment in Chinese ride-hailing company Didi Chuxing in May. The move marks a shift for Apple, which has previously focused on acquiring startups valued at less than $1 billion. SoftBank plans to invest $50 billion in the US, aiming to create 50,000 new jobs.

site_title: UEL said to be assessing bevy of potential suitors
summary: United Engineers Ltd (UEL) is undergoing a strategic review, with its largest shareholders appointing Credit Suisse to advise on potential buyers. At least 10 parties, including property developers, Chinese companies, and private-equity funds, have expressed interest in acquiring the Singaporean property company, valued at S$1.7 billion. The review comes as UEL sells off non-core assets, making the company leaner and more attractive as a takeover target.

images.alt_text: United Engineers Ltd (UEL), one of Singapore's most venerable property companies, is said to be on a beauty parade and has pulled in a strong lineup of suitors looking to acquire it.

site_title: Amazon, Forever 21 vying for bankrupt American Apparel
summary: Amazon and Forever 21 are among companies weighing offers to acquire bankrupt American Apparel, a US-based clothing manufacturer. The bankruptcy auction will determine the future of a major California plant, with labor costs being a significant factor. The sale could impact American Apparel's branding theme of "Made in the USA". Multiple companies are considering the acquisition, with the outcome yet to be determined.

site_title: Trump's new man in Japan is key political adviser
summary: US President-elect Donald Trump is set to appoint William Hagerty as the new US ambassador to Japan, replacing Caroline Kennedy, who will step down on January 20. Hagerty, a close confidant of Trump and a key aide in his transition team, has lived in Tokyo and has ties with the Japanese economic circle. The appointment reflects Trump's priority on the Japan relationship, with some suggesting it indicates Japan is not a high priority for the new president. Hagerty's background as a businessman and lawyer may provide a pragmatic approach to the US-Japan alliance.

images.alt_text: Mr Hagerty has lived in Tokyo for about three years when working for the Boston Consulting Group.

site_title: Bold ways wine will change in 2017
summary: Wine is expected to undergo significant changes in 2017, with a focus on experimentation, exploration, and innovation. Key trends include a wider world of great sparkling wine, a boom in light red wines, and the rise of new packaging formats such as canned wine and mini-bottles. The Loire Valley is expected to become a hot region, with exports to the US increasing. Restaurant wine lists will become more accessible and fun, with a shift towards anti-snob formats such as wine zines. Additionally, wine fountains will become more popular, offering free wine to consumers.

site_title: PAP announces full list of central executive committee members
summary: The People's Action Party (PAP) has unveiled its full list of central executive committee members, with 18 members, including Environment Minister Masagos Zulkifli, Education Minister Ong Ye Kung, and backbenchers Sitoh Yih Pin and Murali Pillai. The committee, led by Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong, remains unchanged in its top seven office-holders, with Coordinating Minister Khaw Boon Wan as chairman and Communications Minister Yaacob Ibrahim as vice-chairman.

site_title: ABN Amro pension fund remains doubtful on hedge funds
summary: ABN Amro's 26.2 billion euro pension fund remains doubtful on investing in hedge funds due to lack of transparency and a "questionable" balance of risk and reward. The fund's CEO, Geraldine Leegwater, expressed concerns over the industry's secrecy and inconsistent returns. This stance is not unusual for retirement funds, which have historically avoided high-risk hedge funds. The trend of pulling funds from hedge funds is attributed to high fees and poor returns, with a record $80 billion being withdrawn in 2024, according to eVestment data.

site_title: Climate action must be part of national plans
summary: Climate-related disasters are intensifying globally, with extreme weather events such as floods, storms, and heatwaves linked to climate change. The 2010s saw a noticeable rise in these events, with scientists attributing them to human actions influencing exposure, vulnerability, and hazard intensity. Climate change has become a consensus issue, with global warming making events like Japan's unusually hot summer 1.5-1.7 times more likely. National plans must incorporate climate action to mitigate these trends.

site_title: China services sector activity hits 17-month high in December
summary: China's services sector activity reached a 17-month high in December, with the services PMI rising to 53.4, the highest since July 2015. New business for services firms increased at the fastest pace in 17 months, while business expectations were at a four-month high. However, employment and input prices remained weak, and companies struggled to pass on higher raw materials costs to customers. The findings suggest the economy is entering the new year with stronger momentum, but risks such as US tariffs and asset bubbles remain.

site_title: Europe must move more aggressively to tackle its property bubbles
summary: The Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD) has warned that property bubbles exist in at least seven European countries, including Australia, New Zealand, the UK, Canada, Sweden, Germany, and Switzerland. The OECD's chief economist, Catherine Mann, says "very high" property prices are not consistent with a stable real estate market, creating vulnerabilities for initial price corrections. The European Central Bank's Systemic Risk Board has also red-flagged property bubbles in several countries, and the UBS Global Real Estate Bubble Index has identified overvalued property prices in European financial centers.

site_title: Dutch, Germans and French will lead Europe in a crisis
summary: Europe is poised to shift in leadership after the Dutch, German, and French elections, which will determine the continent's economic and social direction. The Netherlands, Germany, and France, with 56% of the euro area's economy, have a proven track record of economic growth and social equality, which may serve as a model for the rest of Europe. With rising concerns over immigration and terrorism, the elections will focus on core European values, and the outcome may influence the continent's narrative and response to global challenges.

site_title: Golf facing dual threat of tenure uncertainty and falling interest
summary: Singapore's golf scene is facing a dual threat: tenure uncertainty and falling interest. The government's acquisition of several golf clubs' properties for transportation and infrastructure projects, including the Raffles Country Club, has added to the uncertainty. Additionally, the sport is struggling to attract younger members, with internal market research showing demand coming largely from existing golfers, mostly in their late 40s, 50s, or 60s. This has led to aging membership profiles, with the average membership age at Singapore golf clubs being almost 60 years.

site_title: Experience classic films off-screen
summary: State of Motion 2017, an Asian Film Archive series, will showcase classic films shot in Singapore from the 1960s-80s, highlighting the country's history as a destination for foreign filmmakers. Five films, including Ricochet and Ring of Fury, will be screened, accompanied by exhibitions and tours. The series aims to explore different historical representations of Singapore and its transformation post-independence, with the screenings kicking off at the Pavilion pop-up cinema and exhibition area.

site_title: Chef Oldani's subtle spin on flavours
summary: Chef Davide Oldani's new restaurant, FOO'D, offers a sophisticated and nuanced dining experience with subtle flavors. Located in the Victoria Theatre & Concert Hall, the restaurant features a strong kitchen team and a unique menu that blends Italian and free-style elements. The dishes, such as Frisella with fruit and vegetables and the toasted seeds risotto, showcase the chef's attention to detail and creative approach. While the food may not be for those seeking robust flavors, it is a must-visit for those who appreciate subtlety and nuance, with a rating of 7 out of 10.

site_title: Pence shaping up as powerful VP in Trump team
summary: US Vice President-elect Mike Pence is shaping up as a powerful figure in the Trump administration, following a pattern of influential vice-presidents in recent decades. Pence's close relationships with lawmakers and his experience in the House of Representatives will likely play a key role in domestic policy, while his lack of significant international experience may limit his influence initially. However, his ability to assume the presidency if Trump dies or becomes incapacitated, as well as his potential future presidential run, could elevate his position further. Pence's influence may be reinforced by the Trump administration's focus on conservative activism and his ability to draw on various experiences to assert his views.

site_title: US judge rules that VW, ex-CEO must face investor lawsuit in US
summary: US District Judge Charles Breyer ruled that Volkswagen AG and former CEO Martin Winterkorn must face an investor lawsuit in California over the company's diesel emissions cheating scandal. The lawsuit, filed by US municipal pension funds, claims VW misled investors about emissions standards. The judge rejected a request to dismiss the lawsuit, stating that the US has an interest in protecting domestic investors against securities fraud. VW has agreed to spend up to $17.5 billion in the US to resolve claims from owners and regulators, with potential additional costs in a Justice Department criminal investigation.

site_title: Inherited homes to widen great British social divide as richest benefit the most
summary: A study by the Institute for Fiscal Studies found that inherited wealth in the UK is widening the social divide, with the richest benefiting the most. About 90% of the highest earners in the 1970s will receive significant inheritances, while those with lower incomes will receive less. The wealth gap has grown due to higher home-ownership rates and rising house prices, with the richest half of elderly households holding 90% of the country's wealth. This has led to calls for action to tackle rising inequality.

site_title: Yuan's surge knocks greenback
summary: China's yuan surged to its biggest two-day gain since 2010, driving the US dollar lower and threatening global investors' bets on a stronger dollar in 2017. The yuan rose 3% from lows hit on Tuesday, triggering a broader round of profit-taking on the dollar, which fell more than 1% against the yen and euro. Major asset managers and banks had called for the yuan to fall, but dealers say the moves have squeezed out short-term speculative money, with currency fund Millennium Global's co-head predicting the dollar will struggle to reach parity with the euro or 120 yen.

site_title: TVs grab spotlight at CES gadget show
summary: The Consumer Electronics Show (CES) in Las Vegas saw major TV manufacturers unveil new and innovative products, including ultra-thin TVs, self-driving car technology, and appliances equipped with artificial intelligence. LG Electronics showcased a "wallpaper" thin television, while Sony introduced an A1E series Bravia OLED television with impressive image technology. Other manufacturers, such as TCL and Samsung, also showcased new models with improved high-definition imagery and enhanced audio. Despite a decline in global TV sales, the industry is expected to see growth in 4K high-definition models, with sales projected to reach nearly 82 million units this year.

site_title: US mortgage applications stabilise as loan rates slip
summary: US mortgage applications stabilized at 358.5 in the week ended Dec 30, a 0.1% increase from the prior week, according to Mortgage Bankers Association data. Interest rates on 30-year, fixed-rate conforming mortgages dropped to 4.39%, the lowest since April 2014, as investors bought US government debt amid global bond market sell-off concerns. This easing of borrowing costs led to a retreat in domestic home borrowing costs.

site_title: US jobless claims fall to near 43-year low
summary: US jobless claims fell to near a 43-year low, with initial claims dropping 28,000 to 235,000 for the week ended Dec 31. This is close to the 233,000 level seen in mid-November, the lowest since November 1973. However, the data may be skewed due to the New Year's holiday, and further revisions are possible.

site_title: Detroit car show comes amid uncertain Trump future
summary: The Detroit car show, set to take place this weekend, comes amidst uncertainty over Donald Trump's future presidency and its impact on the US automotive industry. Trump has threatened to impose tariffs on Mexican and Chinese goods, potentially altering trade deals such as NAFTA. In response, US carmakers like Ford are reassessing their Mexico strategies and investing in domestic manufacturing. Despite this, experts warn that increased uncertainty could lead to higher car prices and decreased competitiveness in a global economy.

site_title: May names tough negotiator as EU ambassador, prepares to outline Brexit plans
summary: UK Prime Minister Theresa May appoints Ivan Rogers, a tough negotiator, as EU ambassador amid criticism of her government's Brexit plans. Rogers' resignation was sparked by an email criticizing Downing Street's lack of clarity on the UK's EU exit. May is preparing a speech outlining the government's Brexit intentions, following a tumultuous period for the UK's departure from the EU.

site_title: New York governor's next big project is rebuilding JFK Airport
summary: New York Governor Andrew Cuomo announced plans to rebuild John F. Kennedy International Airport, with a proposed $10 billion budget to modernize terminals and improve highway and transit systems. The project aims to increase the airport's capacity and competitiveness, with potential private funding from airlines. Cuomo's plan comes after the completion of La Guardia Airport's overhaul, and he faces opposition from the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, which operates JFK. The project's details and funding sources have not been disclosed.

site_title: Trump ditches US$250m tower plan in Black Sea town
summary: US President-elect Donald Trump's company has abandoned a proposed $250-million tower project in the Georgian Black Sea resort town of Batumi, citing "housecleaning" ahead of his January 20 inauguration. The project, announced in 2012, was to be a 47-storey residential condominium. The Trump Organization and its local partner, Silk Road Group, have decided to end the development, with Silk Road moving forward with a luxury tower in Batumi. This move comes amid concerns about potential conflicts of interest and US foreign policy.

site_title: In the mood for connection
summary: Singapore artists and overseas artists will be featured in several projects during Singapore Art Week, focusing on relatability and engagement. Photographer Birdhead duo Song Tao and Ji Weiyu, from China, showcased their "Birdhead world" using compulsive photography, blending collage techniques and mixed media. The Bizarre Honour, an investigation into Singapore's relationship with its natural history, features a private collector's cabinet of curiosities. Lock Route, curated by Khairuddin Hori, features public installations, sculptures, and murals, including works by international artists, aiming to engage the public and provoke inquiries.

site_title: Ford expands Alexa use, heating up car personal assistant battle
summary: Ford is expanding its use of Amazon's Alexa personal assistant in its vehicles, allowing drivers to talk to their cars and access various services such as weather forecasts and navigation. The technology marks a significant leap by the Detroit carmaker to incorporate digital services into vehicles. Ford plans to have 10 million vehicles in North America and 20 million globally equipped with embedded modems by 2020, and will use Amazon's Alexa through a new mobile app connected to SmartDeviceLink, an open-source platform.

site_title: Spotlight on collectors
summary: Singapore's Art Stage features a "Collectors' Stage" showcase of works from private collections, highlighting the region's growing interest in contemporary art. Collector Jim Amberson, an American living in Singapore, emphasizes the enriching nature of art collecting, which stimulates creativity and curiosity. Unlike traditional collectors, Amberson seeks works that create a dialogue or frame of discourse, and values engaging with artists about their practices and perspectives. The event aims to redefine art collecting as an accumulation of knowledge about an era, culture, and society.

site_title: Cacola to place out S$638,000 in new shares
summary: CACOLA Furniture International plans to issue S$638,000 worth of new shares to four private investors, representing 142 million shares at S$0.0045 each. The subscription price is a 12.5% premium to the volume average weighted price of Cacola shares. The funds will be used for working capital purposes.

site_title: STI rises for 3rd straight day
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) has risen for the third consecutive day, reaching 2,954.14. This marks a significant turnaround from the 2.7% decline in the first three trading sessions of 2016. Improved liquidity, with Thursday's turnover reaching 2.1 billion units worth S$1.3 billion, is believed to be contributing to the index's upward momentum. Analysts expect the upside resistance of 3,000 to be tested soon, potentially breaking through this level.

site_title: Bad year for equities, but Bursa not quite washed out: analysts
summary: Malaysia's Bursa Malaysia experienced a decline in its fourth-quarter trading volume and value, with a 34% drop in volume and 19% decline in value traded compared to the same period last year. This follows a rough 2016 for the equities market, with average daily volume and value traded declining by double digits in the last quarter. The decline is attributed to a slump in consumer demand.

site_title: Wartime romance with an implausible plot
summary: Brad Pitt and Marion Cotillard star in Allied, a period war drama directed by Robert Zemeckis and written by Steven Knight. The film, inspired by Casablanca, follows Canadian intelligence officer Max Vatan (Pitt) and French resistance fighter Marianne Beausejour (Cotillard) as they fall in love while on a mission to assassinate a German ambassador. Despite sizzling chemistry between the leads, the film's plot becomes implausible as Pitt's character flies around Europe, and the film ultimately falls short of replicating the iconic screen chemistry of Humphrey Bogart and Ingrid Bergman.

site_title: Vancouver home sales dive for 5th consecutive month in Dec
summary: Vancouver home sales declined for the fifth consecutive month in December, dropping 40% from the same period last year and 23% from November. Single-family detached homes saw the largest decline, with sales plummeting 52.4% year-over-year. Despite a 1.8% decrease in benchmark price, the overall year-over-year increase was 18.6%. The foreign buyer tax implemented in August led to a decrease in overseas investor purchases, which fell from 13.2% to 3% in October. The provincial government expects foreign property purchases to settle at around 4-5% of total sales.

site_title: GLP confirms preliminary talks on possible sale of the company
summary: Global Logistic Properties Limited (GLP) confirmed preliminary talks on a possible sale of the company, emphasizing no definitive transaction has been entered into with any party. A strategic review is underway, with no assurance that a transaction will materialize.

site_title: Falcon's ex-S'pore branch manager in the dock over 16 charges
summary: A Singaporean court charged 42-year-old Swiss national Jens Sturzenegger, former branch manager at Falcon Bank, with 16 charges related to money laundering and fund movement in Malaysia's 1MDB scandal. Sturzenegger is accused of conniving with Falcon Bank's compliance head to provide false information to evade scrutiny of financier Jho Low's involvement in bank accounts. This is the fifth person to be charged in Singapore's probe, with Sturzenegger expected to plead guilty to some charges on January 11.

site_title: Opec oil output slides in December
summary: OPEC's crude production fell by 310,000 barrels a day in December, with Nigeria's output dropping by 200,000 barrels due to disruptions. Saudi Arabia and Venezuela also saw production declines. As part of a historic deal with Russia and other non-members, OPEC aims to curb global production by 1.8 million barrels a day, starting this month. The organization's total output, excluding Indonesia, was 33.1 million barrels a day in December, down from 33.41 million barrels in November. Compliance with the production cuts will be monitored independently.

site_title: Four co-opted into PAP's top decision-making committee
summary: Four Singaporean politicians - Minister Ong Ye Kung, Minister Masagos Zulkifli, MP Sitoh Yih Pin, and MP Murali Pillai - have been co-opted into the People's Action Party's top decision-making committee, the Central Executive Committee.

site_title: ISOTeam to buy construction firm for S$6.45m
summary: ISOTeam, an engineering firm, plans to acquire Rong Shun Engineering & Construction for S$6.45 million. The acquisition aims to expand ISOTeam's capabilities to offer a full suite of engineering services and solutions. The deal will be funded by proceeds from a 2015 share placement and internal resources. The acquisition is expected to enhance ISOTeam's services and solutions.

site_title: Washington's Iron Triangle to close in
summary: President-elect Donald Trump's Washington is expected to remain unchanged, with the "Iron Triangle" of officials, lawmakers, and lobbyists maintaining control. Trump's attempts to change policies, such as Taiwan and Russia, may be met with resistance, and his trade policies may face opposition from the Republican establishment. A bipartisan group, led by Vice-President-elect Mike Pence, House Speaker Paul Ryan, and Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell, will likely push through his domestic policy agenda, which includes tax cuts, infrastructure spending, and revoking Obamacare. Trump's inability to achieve significant changes may lead to frustration and tweeting.

site_title: Barclays flags 'black swan threats' to commodities
summary: Barclays warns of potential disruptions in commodities markets in 2017, citing threats such as a default by Venezuela, riots in Chile, and a trade war with China. The report notes that the new politics of populism and protectionist trade policies could disrupt global supply and demand assumptions for various commodities. This comes after commodities advanced in 2016, driven by unexpected political events including the US presidential election and Britain's vote to leave the EU.

images.alt_text: Watch out for the unexpected in commodities in 2017. Barclays Plc said raw materials markets from energy to metals face the high likelihood of disruptions, giving a laundry list of possible threats including a default by Venezuela, riots in Chile and a trade war with China.

site_title: US: Wall St flat as banks, discretionary stocks fall
summary: US stocks remained flat on Thursday as banks and discretionary stocks declined, while technology names rose. The ADP payrolls report showed 153,000 private sector jobs added in December, beating expectations. Investors await the nonfarm payrolls data on Friday, leading to a wait-and-see approach. The Dow Jones Industrial Average was down 0.03%, the S&P 500 down 0.05%, and the Nasdaq Composite was up 0.2%.

site_title: Saudi Aramco explores Feb oil supply cuts of 3-7% to meet OPEC target
summary: Saudi Aramco is exploring a 3-7% cut in February oil supply to meet OPEC production targets. The Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries (Opec) agreed in November to cut production to reduce global oversupply and boost prices. Saudi Arabia will cut output by 486,000 barrels per day, or 4.61% of its October output. Aramco is discussing possible cuts with customers globally and assessing which grades to cut. The company has raised official selling prices for most crude grades sold to Asia and the US, but cut prices to Europe.

site_title: Vanguard's US$305b take from investors in 2016 sets record
summary: Vanguard Group, the world's largest mutual fund manager, set a record for attracting $305 billion from investors in 2016, surpassing its previous record of $276.4 billion in 2015. The majority of the funds went into index-tracking products, while active funds absorbed $50 billion. This success contrasts with other money managers, with 30 of the 50 largest firms experiencing net redemptions in the first 11 months of the year. Vanguard's long-term flows also outpaced BlackRock's, with $93 billion in long-term inflows.

site_title: Bears scramble for yuan as China chokes flows
summary: China's efforts to restrict capital outflows are paying off, with the offshore yuan surging 1.8% in two days, its largest gain since 2010. The currency's scarcity outside China's borders is driving the surge, with the overnight deposit rate reaching a record 100% in Hong Kong. The move is part of Beijing's policy to discourage foreign currency sales by state-owned enterprises.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary:
Here is a 100-word or less summary of the article content:

Raffles Medical Group is expected to benefit from Singapore's aging population and increased medical insurance sophistication, driving 27% net profit growth in 2017. The company's operations at Raffles Orchard and Raffles Holland V malls are expected to improve, while its medical centres are expected to turn a profit. Hutchison Port Holdings Trust's Hong Kong operations are expected to grow, with the company upgrading its rating to a Buy due to its increased flexibility in berth and yard planning. The trusts' high yields and attractive valuations make them attractive investment opportunities.

site_title: Freehold industrial building near Tai Seng MRT sold for S$33.5m
summary: An eight-storey freehold industrial building near Tai Seng MRT Station in Singapore has been sold for S$33.5 million, working out to S$771 per square foot. Developed by Kim Loong & Sons, the building was completed two years ago after leasing out three low-rise detached factories on the site. The sale price is considered a good deal, especially considering it's an en-bloc deal, and the buyer, Chan Rong Fen Building Construction, is expected to occupy some space in the building.

site_title: Indonesia to set up agency to combat fake news
summary: Indonesia is setting up a cyber agency to combat fake news and protect state institutions from hackers. The agency will monitor online news to check for false stories and be overseen by the security ministry. The move comes after a flood of untrue stories on social media, including claims of biological warfare against the country using contaminated chilli seeds. The agency's creation is necessary to balance freedom of speech with obeying the law, according to Chief Security Minister Wiranto. The agency will work alongside other government agencies and aims to prevent the spread of hate and misinformation.

site_title: Austrian bank Bawag eyes Allianz private bank OLB - sources
summary: Austrian bank BAWAG PSK, backed by US investor Cerberus, is bidding for German private bank Oldenburgische Landesbank (OLB), currently 90% owned by Allianz. Bawag is doing due diligence on OLB, which has assets of $13.6 billion. Apollo and Commerzbank have also submitted offers for the bank. The sale process is at an advanced stage, with Bawag's financial position allowing for organic growth and acquisitions.

site_title: Changi Airport to work with firms, startups to improve operations
summary: Changi Airport is launching a 5-year innovation programme, "Living Lab", to improve operations through automation, data analytics, and other technologies. The S$50 million programme will collaborate with companies, startups, accelerators, universities, and research institutes. Areas of focus include queue analytics, autonomous cleaning robots, and automated guided vehicles. The initiative aims to enhance passenger experience, efficiency, and infrastructure capacity, particularly with the upcoming opening of Terminal 4, which will add 16 million annual passengers to the airport's capacity.

site_title: S$ continues to rise on accelerated US$ profit-taking
summary: The Singapore dollar rebounded to S$1.43 against the US dollar, a 1.4% gain from Tuesday, amid dollar profit-taking and correction. The dollar's index against a basket of six major currencies slipped to 102.20 after hitting a 14-year high on Tuesday. The offshore yuan gained 1.3% on Wednesday, reaching a one-month high. DBS Bank forecasts four Fed hikes in 2017 and a 1.8% Singapore growth rate, with the Singdollar expected to fall to S$1.48 by the fourth quarter.

site_title: Saudi builder Khodari secures 69m riyal government contract
summary: Saudi Arabian construction firm Khodari and Sons secured a 69 million riyal (S$26.3 million) contract with the Ministry of Environment, Water and Agriculture for 36-month maintenance of water networks. The contract's financial impact began in the third quarter of 2016, amid delays in recovering payment and stalled projects due to the government's budget deficit. Despite a recent promise to pay private sector bills within 60 days, contractors still face funding shortages and slow visa issuance.

site_title: Ex-ST Marine president pleads guilty, sentenced to 14 days' jail
summary: Former ST Marine president Chang Cheow Teck has been sentenced to 14 days' jail for breaching section 157(1) of the Companies Act, after pleading guilty to failing to use reasonable diligence in discharging his duties between 2008 and 2010. He had ignored information pointing to criminal wrongdoing at the company and failed to take steps to ascertain the legality of cash payments. This is the fifth sentence handed down to one of seven former ST Marine senior executives implicated in a corruption scandal that erupted in 2014.

site_title: India to produce less sugar than expected as drought wilts cane crop
summary: India's sugar production is expected to fall to 22 million tonnes in 2016/17, down 4.3% from an earlier estimate, due to a cane shortage in Maharashtra, the country's top sugar producer. This could lead to a rise in local prices, prompting the government to allow duty-free imports of sugar, which could support global prices near their highest level in 1-1/2 months. The drought has severely impacted Maharashtra's cane crop, with the state's production expected to be around 4.5 million tonnes.

site_title: Princess Diana notes to former palace steward to be auctioned
summary: Princess Diana's handwritten notes to former palace steward Cyril Dickman will be auctioned at Cheffins auction house in Cambridge. The six notes, written between 1984 and 1992, reveal personal anecdotes about her sons, including Prince Harry's constant misbehavior at school and his affectionate relationship with Prince William. The collection, which also includes letters and photographs from other royal family members, is expected to raise around £15,000.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore prosecutors charged a 42-year-old former branch manager of Swiss bank Falcon with 16 charges related to the 1MDB probe. HDB resale prices dropped 0.3% in December and 0.2% for 2016. Passenger car COE premiums rose in the first bidding exercise of 2017. The Singapore dollar continued to rebound, reaching S$1.43. Global Logistic Properties (GLP) confirmed talks on a possible sale. CapitaLand faces a legal dispute with a London art gallery.

site_title: Ex-ST Marine president gets 14 days' jail for breaching Companies Act
summary: A former president of Singapore Technologies Marine Ltd (ST Marine) has been sentenced to 14 days' jail for breaching the Companies Act by failing to act honestly and use reasonable diligence in his duties. Chang Cheow Teck, who served as ST Marine president from 2008 to 2010, pleaded guilty to the offence. He was among seven former ST Marine senior executives prosecuted for corrupt payments related to ship-repair contracts. The prosecution withdrew three corruption charges against Chang in December 2014.

site_title: Scientists link higher dementia risk to living near heavy traffic
summary: Scientists in Canada found a link between living near heavy traffic and a higher risk of developing dementia. A study in The Lancet medical journal discovered that people within 50 meters of high-traffic roads had a 7.0% higher chance of developing dementia compared to those living 300 meters away. Air pollutants may lead to inflammation, contributing to neurological problems, according to researchers. The study suggests that air quality could be a factor in dementia cases, with implications for public health worldwide.

site_title: Malaysia's 1MDB appoints Parker Randall as auditor
summary: Malaysia's 1Malaysia Development Bhd (1MDB) has appointed Parker Randall as its auditor, marking the fourth firm to review the company's books since its establishment in 2009. Deloitte and KPMG were previously fired as auditors in 2015 and 2016, respectively. The appointment was confirmed to the Companies Commission of Malaysia on January 3. This move comes after 1MDB submitted forms 11 and 52 to the commission.

site_title: Imperium's ex-directors may have run foul of law over 'irregularities' in dividends
summary: IMPERIUM Crown, a Catalist-listed property investor, reported "irregularities" in a 2015 dividend payment to regulators. The issue was first reported in August 2016. Legal advisers were hired to investigate, and the company's board believes previous directors may have breached Section 403 of the Companies Act. The directors involved are Mark Lim Chuan Lam, Bay Cheow Guan David, Pao Kiew Tee, Tan Chin Tiong, and Leong Koon Weng. The board has reported the matter to authorities and is seeking legal advice on the company's recourse.

site_title: Global Logistic Properties said to seek bids by next month
summary: Global Logistic Properties (GLP) has begun seeking bids for a potential sale, with first-round offers due by early February. The Singapore-based company, valued at $40 billion, attracted interest after announcing a strategic review in December. A deal would be one of the largest in Asia Pacific, adding to $215 billion of regional property deals in the past year. GLP's largest investor, Singapore sovereign wealth fund GIC, owns 37% of the company, and a spokeswoman declined to comment on the sale process.

site_title: China hit with record retaliatory trade measures in 2016
summary: China was hit with a record 119 trade remedies in 2016, worth $14.34 billion, as countries retaliated against cheap steel and other products. The move follows US President-elect Donald Trump's protectionist stance on global trade, with China wary of potential tariffs on its exports. China will increase capacity cuts in steel and coal in 2017 to address overcapacity in industries such as cement and glass. The increase in trade remedies reflects China's growing concerns about its global market presence.

site_title: GLP confirms talks on possible sale
summary: Global Logistic Properties (GLP) has confirmed preliminary talks on a possible sale of the company as part of its strategic review. The discussions were initiated after the company sent out information letters to targeted bidders at the end of December. GLP shares surged 7.1% on the news before trading was halted. No definitive transaction has been entered into, and the company's shares will resume trading on Friday.

images.alt_text: Global Logistic Properties (GLP) is in preliminary talks on a possible sale of the company, the warehouse developer announced on Thursday, confirming media reports.

site_title: Obama defends legacy in letter to American people
summary: US President Barack Obama defended his legacy in a letter to the American people, highlighting the accomplishments of his administration, including a turnaround in the economy, scaled-back military operations, and the Paris climate agreement. He also emphasized the importance of the Affordable Care Act, which he views as a key achievement, despite Republican efforts to repeal it. Obama argued that repealing the law would harm middle-class Americans and warned against over-hasty action, urging Republicans to allow it to "fall of its own weight."

site_title: OCBC, Great Eastern to review UE, WBL stakes with appointed adviser
summary: OCBC Bank and Great Eastern Holdings have appointed a financial adviser, Credit Suisse, to review their combined stakes in United Engineers and WBL Corporation. The review is ongoing and no certainty exists that a transaction or other options will be completed. This strategic review aims to assess the potential for a deal, but no further information is available at this time.

site_title: Hot stock: SGX queries GLP on trading activity after price surge
summary: Singapore Exchange queries Global Logistic Properties (GLP) on heavy trading activity after its shares surged 6.25% to S$2.38, with 24.5 million shares changing hands. This is the second query issued to GLP in three months, following a US$26 million cash injection into a fund established to hold a US$1.1 billion logistics portfolio.

site_title: Europe: Stock markets fall at open
summary: Europe's main stock markets fell at the start of trading on Thursday, following Federal Reserve signals on potential US interest rate rises. London's FTSE 100 index dropped, while Frankfurt's DAX 30 and Paris CAC 40 also declined. The US central bankers hinted at faster interest rate hikes due to uncertainty linked to Donald Trump's fiscal stimulus plans. Despite this, Wall Street stocks gained solidly on Wednesday, and Tokyo shares ended flat.

site_title: Japan's 'Tuna King' wins annual auction for US$636,000
summary: Japan's "Tuna King" Kiyoshi Kimura won the annual auction at Tokyo's Tsukiji fish market for a bluefin tuna, paying US$636,000 for a 212-kilogramme fish. This is his sixth consecutive win and marks the highest price ever paid for a tuna at the auction. The sale price is roughly 25 times the cost of a piece of fatty tuna sushi sold at his 51 stores across Japan. Kimura's annual purchases at the auction have raised concerns about the sustainability of bluefin tuna, a threatened species.

images.alt_text: Japan's self-styled "Tuna King" has done it again - paying more than US$600,000 for a single fish.

site_title: China services sector activity rises to 17-month high in Dec
summary: China's services sector activity rose to a 17-month high in December, with a PMI of 53.4, beating expectations and mirroring improvements in manufacturing surveys. The sector's new business and business expectations also rose at the fastest pace in 17 months. However, an employment sub-index remained weak, and input prices rose the fastest in nearly two years, putting pressure on profit margins. The findings suggest the Chinese economy is entering the new year with stronger momentum, but risks of an economic hard landing and asset bubbles remain, leading to expectations of tighter financial and monetary conditions this year.

site_title: Uber drivers are "eligible for company social security contributions"
summary: Uber drivers in Switzerland are considered employees, not freelance contractors, according to a ruling by the Swiss insurance agency Suva. This means Uber must pay social security contributions for them. The ruling contradicts Uber's claim that drivers are independent contractors. Uber's Swiss boss, Rasoul Jalali, has vowed to appeal the decision if an agreement cannot be reached with Suva. The ruling is a blow to Uber's efforts to avoid labor protection standards and collective negotiation with drivers worldwide.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares close up
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose 1.46% to 22,456.69, while Shanghai climbed 0.21% to 3,165.41. The gains were attributed to oil shares benefiting from government reforms. The Hang Seng Index reached its third consecutive higher close for the year, while Singapore stocks extended their 5-day rally.

site_title: Xiaomi's India sales pass US$1b as Chinese brands hold sway
summary: Xiaomi surpassed $1 billion in annual India revenue, growing shipments by 150% in 2016. Chinese brands dominate the Indian market, accounting for 51% of smartphone shipments in November. Local players like Micromax saw their share drop to less than 20%. Xiaomi assembles over 75% of its Indian smartphones under the "Make in India" program. Oppo plans to invest $312.5 million in an Indian industrial park, while OnePlus opens its first store in Bangalore.

site_title: Car COE premiums rise
summary: Singapore passenger car COE premiums rose in the first bidding exercise of 2017, with Category A increasing by S$50,051 to S$50,101 and Category B by S$1,999 to S$53,106. Category E, the open category, surged by S$2,611 to S$53,001. The price hikes are attributed to increased demand and the need to manage supply.

site_title: Malaysia: Stocks end 12 points higher
summary: Malaysian shares closed higher on Thursday, with the Kuala Lumpur Composite Index gaining 12.35 points to 1,659.820, driven by a gain of 601 stocks compared to 291 losers.

site_title: Oil dips on doubts over touted production cuts
summary: Oil prices dropped on Thursday due to doubts over OPEC's promised production cuts, despite strong US automobile sales and falling crude stocks. Brent crude futures fell 17 cents to $56.29 per barrel, with traders questioning OPEC's compliance. Goldman Sachs expects Brent prices to peak at $59 per barrel by mid-2017, but technical indicators suggest a potential test of support at $55.43 per barrel. US crude inventories fell 7.4 million barrels, and car sales hit a record 17.55 million in 2016.

site_title: Singapore shares close higher for third straight day
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) has gained 74 points or 2.6% in the first three trading sessions of 2017, surpassing the 3,000 mark. This marks a significant contrast to the previous year, when the STI plummeted 2.7% in its first three trading sessions. Improved liquidity, with a 2.1 billion-unit turnover, is seen as a contributing factor to the recent rally. Despite ongoing tariff uncertainty and split Fed views, investors remain positive, driving the STI higher.

site_title: Singapore dollar rally continues on profit taking
summary: The Singapore dollar continued its rally on Thursday, reaching S$1.43, a 1.4% gain from its low on Tuesday. The rally is attributed to profit taking due to the US dollar's struggles since the end of 2016 and the expectation of three more interest rate hikes in 2017. The US dollar's decline is also linked to reflation hopes and data showing a growing US economy.

site_title: Bankruptcy filing deepens woes for cocoa firm hit by Brexit
summary: The US unit of Transmar Group, which supplies cocoa products to companies including Nestle, has filed for bankruptcy in Manhattan, owing over $400 million to creditors. The filing comes after the company's German unit declared insolvency in December, citing a cash crunch and delayed payments to suppliers. The Brexit vote weakened the pound and drove up prices for London cocoa futures, exacerbating the financial woes. The company plans to operate during the bankruptcy proceedings.

site_title: JPMorgan lashing by Indonesia signals global threat to analysts
summary: Indonesia has punished JPMorgan Chase & Co for a bearish analysis of its stock market, cutting business ties with the US bank and stopping it from conducting sovereign bond business. This move signals a global threat to analysts, with other emerging markets, such as Turkey and Brazil, also cracking down on negative research. Governments are becoming increasingly sensitive to critical analyst opinions, potentially undermining investor confidence in market research. The risk of retaliation against banks and analysts is growing, with the potential to chill free speech and stifle market analysis.

site_title: Long-suffering iron ore miner Atlas heads for the black
summary: Australian miner Atlas Iron, near-bankrupt a year ago, expects to become net-cash positive by mid-2017 due to higher iron ore prices. The company finished the fiscal quarter ending Dec. 31 with A$134 million in the bank, up from A$95 million the previous quarter. Atlas Interim Managing Director Daniel Harris attributed the turnaround to the company's major restructuring last year.

site_title: Australia shares end higher for third consecutive session; NZ flat
summary: Australian shares closed 0.3% higher, mirroring US gains, driven by financials and basic materials stocks. The S&P/ASX 200 index ended at 5753.3. Copper prices surged, powering gains in mining stocks like Oz Minerals and BHP Billiton. The financial index reached its highest in over 17 months, with the "Big Four" banks leading the rally. New Zealand's benchmark index ended flat.

site_title: United Engineers to seek bids for century-old company
summary: United Engineers Ltd, a century-old Singapore property group, is seeking bids from potential buyers. The company's largest shareholders have been assessing buyer interest since December, with at least 10 parties showing interest, including regional developers and private equity firms. First-round bids are due by the end of the month, following a 4.3% intraday gain in shares. The move comes as the company's market value stands at S$1.7 billion.

site_title: China's offshore yuan hovers around one-month high, funding cost surges
summary: China's offshore yuan hovered around a one-month high at 6.8918 per US dollar, driven by surging funding costs and a shrinking yuan pool in Hong Kong. The overnight borrowing rate in Hong Kong reached a one-year high of 38.34% and the People's Bank of China set a stronger-than-expected yuan daily midpoint. Despite this, yuan short sellers were forced to square positions, resulting in losses, and investors are still under pressure to wait for profits as the yuan is expected to weaken further.

site_title: Nasa announces two missions to study early solar system
summary: NASA has announced two new missions, Lucy and Psyche, to study the early solar system. The Lucy mission will launch in 2021 and will explore Jupiter's Trojan asteroids, while the Psyche mission will launch in 2023 and will study a unique metal asteroid, 16 Psyche. The missions aim to learn more about the history of the solar system and the formation of planets, with potential discoveries including insights into the separation of planetary cores, mantles, and crusts.

site_title: Singapore private sector firms see more business in Dec, hire more part-timers
summary: Singapore private sector firms reported more business and new orders in December, but to cope with caution, they hired a record 34,900 part-timers. This marks a significant increase from previous months. The Nikkei Singapore Purchasing Managers Index (PMI) survey, which began in 2012, showed this hiring trend.

images.alt_text: Private sector companies here saw more orders and new business in December, but in a sign of the cautionary mood they coped by hiring more part-timers, the latest Nikkei Singapore Purchasing Managers Index (PMI) out on Thursday showed.

site_title: Top poultry exporter BRF sees US$1.5b halal unit IPO by late March: sources
summary: Brazilian food exporter BRF SA plans to raise $1.5 billion through an initial public offering (IPO) of its halal unit, One Foods Holdings Ltd, by late March or early April. One Foods, which controls 45% of the poultry market in Saudi Arabia and other Muslim nations, aims to expand into Asian markets. The IPO will be listed in London, and the company estimates its enterprise value to be around $6.5 billion. The halal meat industry market is expected to grow to $60 billion by the end of the decade.

site_title: Australia expresses regret for offending Indonesia's military
summary: Australia expressed regret for offending Indonesia's military after the Indonesian President suspended defense ties between the two countries. The suspension followed the discovery of "insulting" teaching material at a west Australian military base. An investigation into the incident is underway, with Australia promising to present the findings to Indonesia's government and military. The two countries have had a rocky military relationship in recent years, with tensions over issues such as Papua and immigration policy.

images.alt_text: "We have indicated our regret that this occurred and that offence was taken. I think that's appropriate when a significant counterpart raises their concerns with you," Ms Payne told reporters in Sydney.

site_title: Taiwan ATM heist linked to European hacking spree: security firm
summary: A cyber security firm, Group-IB, has linked a Taiwan ATM heist to an ATM hacking spree in over a dozen European nations. The "Cobalt" group, consisting of Eastern European men, used malware to steal over $2 million from First Commercial Bank in Taiwan and similar hacks in European countries. Three suspects were arrested in Taiwan, but investigators are unaware of any links to the Cobalt group. The defendants maintain their innocence, claiming they were not part of an international crime organization.

site_title: China's insurance ownership proposals seen blocking riskier use of premiums
summary: China's insurance regulatory commission has proposed limiting individual ownership of insurance companies to 33% to curb conglomerates like China Evergrande Group and Baoneng Group from using insurance premiums to fund acquisitions and riskier investments. The limit aims to prevent non-financial owners from exploiting insurance customers' premiums, potentially weakening the risk-control capacity of insurers and putting customers at risk. The proposal, unlikely to apply to large, state-backed insurers, will be implemented after industry consultation and is part of a broader effort to curb risky practices in the insurance sector.

site_title: Audi poised to approach luxury leaders in US if Trump allows
summary: Audi's US sales increased 4% in 2016, surpassing declines by luxury leaders Mercedes-Benz, Lexus, and BMW. The brand is poised to continue gaining ground if President-elect Donald Trump allows. Audi's US deliveries rose 14% to 23,195 in December, with the outgoing Q5 model having a record month. The redesigned Q5 model arrives in March or April. Audi's president, Scott Keogh, believes the brand is "conquering a lot more" from the Big Three in luxury, but notes that any growth will have to come from someone else.

site_title: CapitaLand to appear before London courts over dispute with UK art gallery
summary: CapitaLand, a Singapore property giant, is set to appear before the Royal Courts of Justice in London to dispute an eviction notice from a 100-year-old art gallery, Franses Gallery, from its premises at The Cavendish hotel. The gallery, which has occupied the space for a quarter of a century, is fighting to maintain its presence and continuing business and archive services. CapitaLand claims that Franses's leases have expired and seeks immediate eviction, while the gallery argues that it has grounds to renew its lease under the Landlord and Tenant Act 1954.

images.alt_text: Singapore property giant CapitaLand is locked in a legal dispute with a 100-year-old London art gallery - in a case that has been described as one that pits profits against the arts.

site_title: Why some artists no longer want to be famous
summary: A growing number of artists, including Banksy and Elena Ferrante, are rejecting fame and seeking anonymity. Some, like Ferrante, have made a conscious decision to liberate themselves from the anxiety of notoriety, while others, like Banksy, are using their secrecy to maintain their artistic integrity. This trend is seen as an act of resistance in an era obsessed with celebrity and transparency, with sociologist Stephane Hugon calling it a "small but significant gesture" to reinject mystery into a world that needs it.

site_title: Toyota plans years of building human-controlled cars
summary: Toyota plans to spend years developing human-controlled cars, contradicting the idea of fully autonomous vehicles due to safety concerns. The company's CEO, Gill Pratt, states that achieving true Level 5 autonomy is not possible, requiring extensive machine learning and testing. Toyota will focus on Level 2 autonomy, where humans remain in command, and may skip to Level 4 autonomy, where computers retain control on approved roadways. The company aims to sell Level 4 vehicles to ride-sharing fleets, potentially generating revenue.

site_title: Falcon Bank's ex-Singapore branch manager slapped with 16 1MDB-related charges
summary: Singapore authorities have charged Jens Sturzenegger, former manager of Falcon Private Bank's Singapore branch, with 16 1MDB-related charges. He is expected to plead guilty on January 11. This is the second bank to be closed down by Singapore regulators over 1MDB connections, following BSI in May.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares finish flat on yen strength
summary: Tokyo shares closed flat on Thursday as the benchmark Nikkei 225 index lost 0.37% due to a stronger yen. The broader Topix index rose 0.08% despite the early losses. The Nikkei 225 index closed at 19,520.69, while the Topix index closed at 1,555.68.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open slightly higher on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened slightly higher on Thursday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rising 1.120 points to 1647.990. The market saw 91.17 million lots traded worth RM31.67 million, with 141 gainers outnumbering losers 44-1.

site_title: South Korea may be named currency manipulator, think tanks warn
summary: South Korea may be labeled a currency manipulator by the US, think tanks warn, following its inclusion on the US Treasury Department's currency watch list in October. The Korea Institute for International Economic Policy suggests a "high possibility" of South Korea being tagged a manipulator due to its significant bilateral trade surplus with the US and material current account surplus. Finance Minister Yoo Il-ho expressed skepticism, stating that the nation does not target a specific exchange rate direction or level.

site_title: LG Display in talks to supply LCD TV panels to Samsung Elec
summary: LG Display is in talks with Samsung Electronics to supply LCD TV panels. The deal, if agreed, would be a long-term supply agreement, according to LG Display's CEO Han Sang-Beom. This comes after a joint venture between Taiwan's Hon Hai Precision Industry and Sharp Corp is set to halt LCD panel supply to Samsung Electronics in 2017. The move could help Samsung avoid buying components from LG Group firms, which competes with LG Electronics in various markets, including smartphones and televisions.

site_title: Gold hits 4-week high on weaker US dollar, technical upswing
summary: Gold rose to a 4-week high on Thursday, reaching $1,172.96 per ounce, as the US dollar weakened and investors locked in gains from its recent rally. The US dollar index fell 0.4% and the greenback's value against other currencies made commodities more expensive for holders of other currencies. This move is attributed to investors' concerns about potential US President-elect Donald Trump's policies, which could boost inflation and affect the US Federal Reserve's stance.

site_title: Hong Kong up, Shanghai flat at open
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose 0.47% to 22,237.41, while Shanghai flatlined at 3,157.91. Market sentiment remained muted ahead of economic data release next week. The Shenzhen Composite Index eased 0.02% to 2,008.34. Dealers attributed the muted sentiment to uncertainty over US-China trade tensions and conflicting Fed views.

site_title: Changi Airport launches 'living lab' programme to develop new solutions
summary: Changi Airport has launched a "living lab" programme, investing up to S$50 million in innovation partnerships. The five-year programme aims to develop and test new technology solutions in areas such as automation, data analytics, security, and smart infrastructure. Prototypes include autonomous cleaning robots and a system using sensors to estimate taxi queue wait times, providing better advice to travellers. The initiative is a collaboration between Changi Airport Group and the Singapore Economic Development Board, focusing on driving innovation and improving passenger experience.

site_title: Singapore's arbitration hub status to receive boost with Maxwell Chambers expansion
summary: Singapore is expanding Maxwell Chambers to boost its position as an international dispute resolution hub. The expansion will add 120,000 square feet of floor space, supporting the growth of institutions with significant increases in caseload. Senior Minister of State for Law Indranee Rajah emphasized Singapore's key strengths as a neutral and stable legal system with high-quality jurisprudence. The move aims to capitalize on Singapore's reputation as a trusted center for dispute resolution, enhancing its arbitration hub status.

site_title: Seoul: Won jumps to 2-week high after Fed minutes; stocks weaker
summary: The South Korean won jumped to a two-week high against the US dollar after the Federal Reserve's December meeting minutes suggested no definitive rate hikes this year. The won rose 1% to 1,194.3, with other currencies like the Japanese yen and Chinese yuan also strengthening. South Korean shares were slightly weaker, with the Kospi down 0.2%. Market players will focus on US employment data scheduled for release on Friday.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Sino Grandness, Trek 2000
summary: Sino Grandness Food Industry Group has entered into an agreement with Wechat Food to distribute its products through a mobile Internet platform. Trek 2000 International has appointed Tan Kuok Keong as its new chief financial officer, effective January 5.

site_title: US obtained evidence after election that Russia leaked emails: officials
summary: US intelligence agencies have obtained conclusive evidence that Russia leaked hacked emails from the Democratic National Committee to WikiLeaks through a third party after the November election. This evidence increases certainty about the full role of the Russian government in the hacking and leaks. The additional intelligence informed President Barack Obama's decision to retaliate by expelling suspected Russian spies and sanctioning Russian spy agencies and companies. President-elect Donald Trump has questioned the US intelligence community's conclusion, and WikiLeaks founder Julian Assange has also raised doubts about the source of the leaked emails.

site_title: Taiwan: Stocks hit near 3-week high tracking Wall St; flat panel makers up
summary: Taiwan's stocks rose 0.4% to a near-three-week high, tracking gains on Wall Street, with flat panel makers Innolux and AU Optronics leading the gains. The main Taiex index reached 9,322.10, a level not seen since Dec 16. Asian stocks also edged higher, underpinned by a firm Wall Street overnight. The Taiwan dollar strengthened to NT$32.099 per US dollar.

site_title: Living close to major roads increases dementia risk: study
summary: A large-scale study published in The Lancet found that people living near major roads in Ontario, Canada, have a 7% higher incidence of dementia. Those living within 50 meters of a busy road had the highest risk, with 4% and 2% higher risks for those living 50-100 meters and 100-200 meters away, respectively. Long-term exposure to nitrogen dioxide and fine particulates were associated with dementia, suggesting other factors may also play a role. The study suggests busy roads could be a source of environmental stressors contributing to dementia.

site_title: From cakes to slippers, Slovenia stirs 'Melania' hype
summary: Slovenia is capitalizing on its connection to Melania Trump, the incoming US First Lady, by promoting the country as a tourist destination. The number of American visitors increased by 11% to 80,000 between January and October 2016. Entrepreneurs in Melania's hometown of Sevnica are selling "Melania" cakes, slippers, and other products, with some even planning guided tours. However, Melania's parents have expressed that she rarely returns to Slovenia, fueling criticism that the hype is a marketing ploy.

site_title: Asia: Stocks rise for eighth day on strong PMIs, Wall Street gains
summary: Asian stocks rose for an eighth consecutive day, driven by strong PMIs, Wall Street gains, and an overnight bounce in oil prices. The MSCI Asia-Pacific index gained 0.6% as Australia and Hong Kong led gains, while Japan's Nikkei slipped 0.3%. The US dollar edged up against the yen, and China's offshore yuan posted its biggest daily gain against the US dollar in a year. Despite concerns over inflation, global growth forecasts were raised, and valuations remain at moderate levels, suggesting institutional inflows.

site_title: NRF, Israel's Tel Aviv University grant awards to 4 cybersecurity research projects
summary: The National Research Foundation (NRF) and Tel Aviv University (TAU) have granted awards to four cybersecurity research projects in Singapore, focusing on improving cybersecurity through modelling human behavior, policy design, and quantifying cyber risk. The projects, undertaken by Nanyang Technological University (NTU) and Singapore Management University (SMU), aim to create impact in Singapore's Smart Nation and Internet of Things initiatives. The collaboration complements local universities' research and supports high-quality, cross-disciplinary research in cybersecurity.

site_title: China to invest 2.5t yuan in renewable power in 2016-2020
summary: China plans to invest 2.5 trillion yuan in renewable power generation between 2016 and 2020, aiming to create over 13 million jobs and achieve 15% of overall energy consumption from renewable energy by 2020. The National Energy Administration outlined its five-year plan, which includes a goal of 580 million tonnes of coal equivalent of renewable energy consumption. This move is part of China's shift away from coal power, with the country seeking to reduce its reliance on fossil fuels.

images.alt_text: China will invest 2.5 trillion yuan (S$520.9 billion) in renewable power generation between 2016 and 2020, the National Energy Administration (NEA) said on Thursday, as the world's largest energy market pushes to shift away from coal power.

site_title: Singapore prosecutors charge 5th person in 1MDB probe
summary: Singapore prosecutors have charged 5th person in the 1MDB probe, Jens Sturzenegger, a 42-year-old former branch manager of Swiss bank Falcon, with 16 charges related to the massive fund flows. Sturzenegger, a Swiss national, was arrested in October and is expected to plead guilty on January 11.

site_title: Australia new vehicle sales hit a record for 2016: Vfacts
summary: Australia's new vehicle sales reached a record 1.178 million in 2016, a 2% increase from 2015. The market shifted towards pick-up trucks and SUVs, with light commercial vehicles taking 18.5% of the market, up from 17.2% the previous year. Business sales increased by 13%, while private sales fell 5.8%. Toyota's Hilux topped the sales charts, and Toyota Motor Corp retained the top spot for the year with 17.8% market share. Mazda held second place with 10% market share, and Ford held 6.9%.

site_title: Australian shares inch up as oil jumps, NZ down
summary: Australian shares rose 0.33% to 5,755, driven by a jump in oil prices and gains on Wall Street. The move reflects potential interest-rate hikes following Donald Trump's presidency. The S&P/ASX 200 index is on track for its third straight session of gains.

site_title: Trek 2000 appoints new CFO
summary: Trek 2000 International has appointed Tan Kuok Keong as its new chief financial officer, effective January 5, 2017. He previously held positions at Renewable Energy Asia Group Limited and KPMG Singapore. Tan's appointment comes at a time when the company is seeking to strengthen its financial leadership.

site_title: Amazon, Forever 21 vying for bankrupt American Apparel
summary: Amazon.com Inc and Forever 21 Inc are vying for American Apparel LLC, a bankrupt US clothing manufacturer. The Los Angeles-based company's bankruptcy auction will determine the future of a major US manufacturing plant. Keeping jobs in the US has become a key issue, following Ford's reversal of plans to build a factory in Mexico. The winner of the auction will secure the plant and its 1,100 jobs, which are among the most expensive in the US due to labor costs. The deal could also impact US labor laws and the country's manufacturing landscape.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares open higher
summary: Tokyo shares opened higher on Thursday, following overnight gains in New York, driven by continued optimism for the global market.
