The Nikkei 225 index rose 0.05% to 19,604.53, while the Topix index gained 0.21% to 1,557.67. This follows a 5-day rally in Singapore stocks and a strong performance in the US, where the S&P 500 and Nasdaq edged to fresh records despite trade uncertainty.

site_title: HDB resale prices dip 0.3% in Dec, 0.2% for 2016: SRX Property
summary: HDB resale prices in Singapore slipped 0.3% in December from the previous month, mainly due to declines in larger flats. This translates to a 0.2% drop for the year, with resale prices falling 10.9% from their peak in 2013. Mature estates saw a 1% drop, while non-mature estates fell 1.2% in the year. December transactions also decreased 13.9% from the previous month to 1,364 flats, a 3.9% decline from last year.

site_title: Australia denies trying to 'recruit' Indonesian soldiers
summary: Australia has denied attempting to "recruit" Indonesian soldiers, contradicting comments from Indonesia's military chief, General Gatot Nurmantyo. The claim sparked a bilateral row after teaching materials deemed offensive were found at an Australian army base, including posters of West Papua. Australian Defence Minister Marise Payne denied targeting Indonesian soldiers, saying the concerns were taken seriously and an investigation into the materials is almost complete. Relations between the two neighbours have been strained in recent years over disputes such as the execution of Australian drug smugglers and Canberra's hardline policy on migrant boats.

site_title: TVs grab spotlight at CES gadget gala
summary: LG Electronics unveiled a "wallpaper" thin television, measuring 2.57 mm thick in a 65-inch screen model, at CES. The TV, branded "W", can be attached to walls with magnetic brackets. TCL showcased 25 new Roku-enabled TV models with improved high-definition imagery and enhanced audio. Samsung unveiled a new 75-inch QLED TV model and a gaming laptop. Despite declining global TV sales, sales of 4K high-definition models are expected to increase to nearly 82 million this year, with US$105 billion spent on TVs.

site_title: Google moves into augmented reality shopping with BMW, Gap
summary: Google is launching a real-world application for its augmented reality shopping technology, Tango, in partnership with BMW and Gap Inc. The technology uses cameras and sensors to overlay digital images in physical space, allowing shoppers to see what they might buy without leaving home. Google has also announced new hardware and software developments, including a mobile app that displays car models and a new app for testing clothes from Gap. However, the technology is still in its infancy, and challenges with realistic rendering and hardware compatibility limit its reach and effectiveness.

site_title: Fed officials see gradual rate hikes as upside risks debated
summary: Federal Reserve officials discussed potential fiscal stimulus and its impact on inflation, with many warning of upside risks to economic growth. The minutes of the December policy meeting revealed that officials were concerned about the potential for faster growth due to expansionary fiscal policies, but most still expected a gradual pace of interest-rate increases. The committee reiterated its forecast for a modest fall in the unemployment rate, with some members incorporating assumptions about expansionary fiscal policy into their forecasts.

site_title: US dollar eases off 14-year peak as market braces for Trump reality check
summary: The US dollar eased off its 14-year peak against a basket of currencies as investors braced for President Donald Trump's reality check. The dollar had soared after Trump's election on plans to boost fiscal spending and cut taxes, seen as inflationary. However, uncertainty about his presidency is prompting traders to lock in gains, with the dollar slipping to 102.20 after hitting a 14-year high of 103.82. The euro rose to US$1.0524, while the Australian dollar hit a two-week high of US$0.7303.

site_title: Australia, NZ dollars gain as global growth pulse quickens
summary: The Australian and New Zealand dollars rose to their highest in over two weeks as the US dollar retreated amid a round of profit-taking. Global economic data showed China's services sector activity surged to a 17-month high in December, supporting commodity prices. The Aussie dollar was flat at US$0.7285, while the NZ dollar also gained. The gains were attributed to upbeat data on the global economy, which underpinned commodity prices and curbed the US dollar.

site_title: Alibaba sues sellers of fake Swarovski watches in crackdown
summary: Alibaba Group Holding Ltd sued two Taobao vendors for selling counterfeit Swarovski watches, seeking 1.4 million yuan in damages. This is part of Alibaba's efforts to root out counterfeit goods on its sites. Despite previous claims of high counterfeiting, the US Office of the Trade Representative named Taobao a "notorious" market, prompting Alibaba to reiterate its commitment to combating fakes. The company has taken down 380 million product listings and closed 180,000 stores on its platform since August.

site_title: UK economy keeps momentum but inflation pressures mount: BCC survey
summary: The UK economy maintained momentum in the final months of 2016, with sales and hiring improving modestly, but inflation pressures mounted at the fastest pace since records began. A record number of manufacturers expect to raise prices due to the weak pound, while businesses in the services sector plan to increase prices more than at any time since early 2011. The British Chambers of Commerce (BCC) expects growth to continue in 2017, albeit at a more modest pace, and warns of rising inflation concerns.

site_title: Singapore shares open 17.8 points higher on Thursday
summary: Singapore shares rose 17.82 points, or 0.61%, to 2,939.13 at 9:02am on Thursday, driven by continued optimism in the US stock market. The banking sector, including UOB, OCBC Bank, and DBS, continued its rally. Gainers beat losers 92 to 37, with 43.1 million shares worth S$67.2 million changing hands. The Straits Times Index reached a 5-day high ahead of GDP data release.

site_title: SunEdison settles contract fight to help close US$150m sale
summary: Bankrupt renewable energy company SunEdison Inc has reached a deal with a spinoff company to help clear the way for a $150 million sale of its solar materials business to a Chinese buyer, GCL-Poly Energy Holdings Ltd. SunEdison had filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection in April after debt-fueled acquisitions proved unsustainable. The company has resolved an objection and will extend a services agreement with its affiliate at reduced rates. A hearing to approve the settlement will be held on January 24.

site_title: US retailers Macy's and Kohl's slash 2016 profit forecasts citing weak holiday sales
summary: US department stores Macy's and Kohl's cut their 2016 profit forecasts due to weak holiday sales, with Macy's citing declining store traffic and Kohl's noting volatile sales throughout the season. Macy's will close 68 stores, resulting in layoffs of approximately 3,900 employees, while Kohl's cut its adjusted profit forecast by $0.15 per share. The retailers' shares plummeted, with Macy's down 9.7% and Kohl's down 14.7%. The decline in sales is attributed to increased competition from online rivals and a shift in consumer spending towards big-ticket items.

site_title: Apple to invest US$1b in SoftBank fund to support tech
summary: Apple plans to invest $1 billion in SoftBank's $100 billion Vision fund, a technology investment vehicle that aims to support emerging technologies. The investment is part of a growing list of interested parties, including Qualcomm, Foxconn, and Oracle chairman Larry Ellison. The fund, based in London, will make investments in startups globally. This move marks a shift for Apple, which has focused on acquiring startups valued under $1 billion. The investment is seen as a way for Apple to tap into new technologies and potentially reduce its dependence on the iPhone.

site_title: Taiwan's military may be first casualty in pension crisis
summary: Taiwan's military pension fund may default by 2020 due to widening deficits and unsustainable large payouts, raising concerns about the island's defense stability. The government plans to overhaul the pension system, which could lead to longer wait times and smaller payments, affecting 120,000 military pension beneficiaries and 200,000 civil service employees. The pension crisis is linked to Taiwan's aging population and low birth rate, with under-funded liabilities expected to reach a record NT$18 trillion by 2016.

site_title: Boeing wins US$8.8b in 737 MAX orders, still short of goal
summary: Boeing has secured 80 firm orders for 737 MAX 8 aircraft, valued at $8.8 billion, bringing its 2016 net jetliner sales to at least 536. This falls short of the company's goal of selling as many commercial jets as it delivers, which was between 745 and 750. Boeing has orders equivalent to about seven years of production, with the majority being single-aisle 737 planes. The company's shares rose 1% after the announcement, despite a below-target book-to-bill ratio of 0.79.

site_title: Oil prices firm on US crude inventory fall, record car sales
summary: Oil prices remained firm on Thursday, boosted by a 7.4 million barrel decrease in US crude inventories and record US car sales. US West Texas Intermediate crude oil futures traded at $53.26 per barrel, unchanged from the previous day. A cheaper US dollar also supported Brent futures, as a cheaper greenback makes US dollar-traded fuel purchases cheaper for countries using other currencies. Oil prices rose 2% on Wednesday, driven by the API report and record car sales, which hit 17.55 million in 2016.

images.alt_text: Oil prices were firm on Thursday, buoyed by data showing a fall in US crude inventories and by record car sales in the United States.

site_title: BMW launches first augmented reality dealerships
summary: BMW launches the world's first augmented reality dealerships, allowing customers to view and interact with virtual hybrid and electric cars using a smartphone. The technology provides a next-best solution when the desired product isn't available. BMW executive Andrea Castronovo stated that this visualisation is ideal for situations where the product isn't available on the spot.

site_title: Lawsuit in US says Coca-Cola downplays risks of sugary drinks
summary: A US lawsuit alleges Coca-Cola and the American Beverage Association downplayed health risks from sugary drinks to boost sales. The Praxis Project claims the companies used euphemisms like "balance" and "calories in, calories out" to mislead consumers. The lawsuit seeks to stop misleading marketing and require more consumer warnings. Despite this, Coca-Cola has pledged to reduce added sugar in beverages, with over 200 reformulation initiatives.

images.alt_text: Coca-Cola Co and the American Beverage Association trade group were sued on Wednesday for allegedly misleading consumers about the health risks from consuming sugary beverages.

site_title: Ex-Barclays trader pleads guilty in US in forex probe
summary: A former Barclays trader, Jason Katz, pleaded guilty to US charges in a foreign-exchange price-fixing probe, becoming the first person to admit criminal wrongdoing. Katz, who worked at Barclays and BNP Paribas, conspired with other traders to manipulate currency prices from 2007 to 2013. As part of his plea deal, Katz agreed to cooperate and face a lifetime ban from the banking industry, and was released on a $150,000 bond. This case is the third person to face US criminal charges in the probe, which also involves other major banks including HSBC, Citigroup, and JPMorgan Chase.

site_title: UK's May taps career diplomat to replace EU envoy after scathing resignation
summary: British Prime Minister Theresa May has appointed Tim Barrow, a senior career diplomat, as envoy to the European Union to replace Ivan Rogers, who quit with a scathing resignation letter criticizing the government's approach. Rogers' letter exposed frustration among officials over May's strategy, putting rare strain on the civil service's neutrality. Barrow will take up the post next week, following a period of tension over the government's EU policy.

site_title: Europe: Shares finish slightly lower as Next slumps
summary: European shares finished slightly lower on Wednesday, reversing a one-year high, as UK retailer Next slumped 14.4% after cutting its profit guidance and warning on future trade. The Stoxx 600 index closed 0.1% down, with Next being the biggest percentage faller. The stock has lost nearly 40% over the past year, dragging the index back from its highest level since December 2015.

site_title: Bond managers expect unconstrained funds to find favour in 2017
summary: Bond managers expect unconstrained funds to gain favor in 2017 due to rising interest rates and inflation. The funds, which invest in bonds without constraints on maturity, geography, or credit quality, could benefit from the shift. Despite past struggles, some managers, such as Goldman Sachs' Jona-than Beinner and BlackRock's Rick Rieder, believe the funds can deliver returns in a rising rate environment. However, others, like TCW Group's Stephen Kane, are cautious, citing risks in emerging markets and corporate defaults.

site_title: Indonesia suspends military cooperation with Australia
summary: Indonesia has suspended military cooperation with Australia after teaching materials deemed offensive to Jakarta were found at an Australian army base. The materials, reportedly related to posters of West Papua, sparked concerns among Indonesian officials. The suspension, announced by Indonesian military spokesman Wuryanto, is the latest row between key allies and neighbours, following disputes over Jakarta's execution of Australian drug smugglers and Canberra's hardline policy on migrant boats.

site_title: Trump to choose Hagerty as the next US ambassador to Japan
summary: US President-elect Donald Trump plans to appoint William Hagerty as the next US ambassador to Japan, according to a transition team adviser. Hagerty, a Tennessee native, previously spent several years in Japan with the Boston Consulting Group and served in the White House under former president George HW Bush. The announcement is expected to be made soon, according to the adviser.

site_title: Container vessel collision causes oil spill on Singapore-Malaysia border
summary: A container vessel collision on the Singapore-Malaysia border resulted in a 300-tonne oil spill into the East Johor Straits. There were no reported injuries, and 12 anti-pollution craft were deployed to clean up the spill. The incident occurred after a collision between the APL Denver and Wan Hai 301 off Pasir Gudang Port in Johor, Malaysia, causing damage to the APL Denver's fuel tank. The spill was contained off the western side of Singapore's Pulau Ubin island, with no impact on traffic or port operations.

site_title: US car sales set new record in 2016
summary: US car sales reached a new record in 2016, surpassing the previous year's record with 17.55 million vehicles sold. December sales contributed to the total, with a 3.1% rise in the US market. Light trucks and SUVs saw an 8.3% increase, while passenger cars declined 4.7%. The strong sales were driven by a busy December shopping period and year-end discounts.

site_title: US: Stocks gain as December auto sales surge
summary: US stocks rose on Wednesday as December auto sales exceeded expectations, with General Motors and Ford leading the gains. The Dow Jones Industrial Average gained 0.3%, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Index rose 0.6% and 0.9%, respectively. Retailers and pharmaceutical stocks also performed well, driven by improved holiday sales sentiment and expectations of a pro-growth administration.

site_title: US office vacancy rate falls in fourth quarter
summary: The US office vacancy rate fell to 15.7% in the fourth quarter, the lowest level since 2009, according to Reis Inc. Asking and effective rents decelerated, growing 0.3% and 0.4% respectively. Construction activity increased, with 8.53 million square feet of new office space completed. The vacancy rate is expected to decline further in 2017, with rent growth accelerating to a 3% annual rate, driven by employment growth.

site_title: Apple pulls New York Times app from iTunes store in China
summary: Apple has removed the New York Times news apps from its iTunes store in China, following a request from Chinese authorities. The move aims to prevent Chinese readers from accessing independent news coverage by the New York Times. This action is part of the Chinese government's efforts to control and limit access to foreign news sources.

site_title: JFK Airport to get US$10b 'world class' upgrade
summary: John F Kennedy International Airport in New York is set to receive a US$10 billion upgrade, aiming to improve the passenger experience and accessibility. The upgrade, proposed by Governor Andrew Cuomo, will include creating a unified airport, new terminals, and highway improvements. The goal is to maintain JFK's status as a major transportation hub, generating US$140 million in wages and US$400 million in sales for the region with each million passengers accommodated. The project is expected to hit 100 million passengers by 2050, addressing issues of overcrowding and outdated infrastructure.

site_title: Bitcoin hits all-time high as currency controls drive fear
summary: Bitcoin reached an all-time high of $1,140.64 on January 4, 2017, driven by capital controls in countries such as China, India, and Venezuela, where people purchased the digital currency to protect their savings. This surge in adoption, combined with increased investor interest, pushed bitcoin's total market capitalization to over $16.1 billion, surpassing its previous high. The digital currency's value beat that of traditional currencies, stocks, and commodities as an investment in 2016.

site_title: France orders massive duck cull to contain bird flu
summary: France has ordered a massive cull of ducks in three regions to contain the H5N8 bird flu outbreak, affecting around 800,000 birds, in an effort to quickly kill the species most affected by the virus. The cull, set to take place between January 5 and 20, is aimed at controlling the spread of the highly contagious virus, which has reported 89 outbreaks in France, mostly in the Gers region. The move could cost the foie gras industry around 80 million euros.

site_title: Things will get worse for the Malaysian ringgit: BMI Research
summary: Malaysia's ringgit is expected to continue its downward trend, with BMI Research forecasting it to average 4.50 US dollars per ringgit this year and 4.40 in 2018, down from previous estimates of 4.00 and 3.88. The currency's decline is attributed to the yuan's downward pressure, narrowing real interest-rate differentials between the US and Malaysia, and further weakness in the global bond market. This is partly due to the fact that 40% of Malaysian bonds are held by foreigners, making it vulnerable to market fluctuations.

site_title: Evergrande boss's excesses earn him 'China's Trump' moniker
summary: Evergrande Group's founder and chairman, Hui Ka Yan, has drawn comparisons to US President Donald Trump due to his business model, which relies heavily on debt and property investments. Despite net worth of $7.4 billion, the company has struggled financially, with many of its acquisitions resulting in losses. Hui has started to dispose of non-core assets, refocusing on property development, but the company's high debt levels and lavish spending habits remain a concern.

site_title: Deutsche Bank to pay US$95m to end US tax fraud case
summary: Deutsche Bank AG has agreed to pay US$95 million to resolve a US tax fraud case, admitting to using "insolvent" shell companies to hide significant tax liabilities from the Internal Revenue Service in 2000. The settlement resolves a lawsuit filed in 2014 seeking to recoup over US$190 million in taxes, penalties, and interest. The case involves Deutsche Bank's acquisition of Charter Corp, which was sold to shell companies, resulting in a US$52 million tax liability that the shell companies could not pay.

site_title: Credit Suisse moves to block Jefferies bid to hire bankers
summary: Credit Suisse is attempting to block Jefferies' bid to hire senior bankers, including Jonathan Moneypenny, who had agreed to join Jefferies as global co-head of leveraged-finance capital markets. Five of eight Credit Suisse bankers who had been in talks to join Jefferies have instead agreed to stay with the Swiss lender. This is the second time in less than a year that Jefferies has sought to poach senior managers from Credit Suisse, leading to a lawsuit and a Financial Industry Regulatory Authority case against Jefferies.

images.alt_text: Credit Suisse Group AG is seeking to thwart an attempt by Jefferies Group LLC to lure away a group of senior bankers.

site_title: Bond market volatility offers opportunities too: Schroders
summary: Global bond yields are expected to rise due to higher economic growth and inflation, as well as greater policy uncertainty. Investors should watch for opportunities in Asia's bond markets, particularly in Malaysia and Indonesia, which rely on foreign financing. The US dollar is forecast to strengthen, leading to higher yields and a more hawkish bias from the Federal Reserve, potentially impacting emerging markets. Greater policy uncertainty, including protectionist measures and misunderstandings with China, also pose risks.

site_title: Vancouver home sales plunge for fifth consecutive month in December
summary: Vancouver home sales plummeted 40% in December, marking the fifth consecutive month of decline, due to a tax on foreign buyers. Single-family detached homes saw a 52.4% drop in sales compared to 2015, while the benchmark price for detached homes fell 1.8% from the previous month. Despite this, year-over-year prices rose 18.6%. The tax has led to a decrease in foreign purchases, with overseas investors making up 3% of home sales in October, down from 13.2% before the tax took effect.

site_title: Trump Organization says it has no plans to build Buenos Aires tower
summary: The Trump Organization has stated it has no plans to build a tower in Buenos Aires, contradicting previous speculation and a city government announcement that it had declined to authorize a permit. The project, linked to US President-elect Donald Trump, was reportedly discussed during a congratulatory call between Argentine President Mauricio Macri and Trump, but Macri's administration denied the claim. The Trump Organization's spokeswoman confirmed that no plans exist for the project, following a city government clarification that new paperwork would be required for it to be reconsidered.

site_title: Bitcoin price soars, fuelled by speculation and volatile currencies
summary: The price of bitcoin has surged to near-peak levels, reaching $1,025 per coin, driven by speculation and interest from countries such as Venezuela and India. Speculators, particularly from China, are fueling the price increase, with automated software trading on Chinese exchanges contributing significantly to the price movement. Analysts believe that bitcoin's value is driven more by hope of future use than real-world transactions, and its price is less similar to a currency than to a commodity like gold.

site_title: More than 100 hurt in New York train derailment
summary: A New York commuter train derailed in Brooklyn's Atlantic Terminal, leaving over 100 people with minor injuries. The incident occurred around 8:30am, with passengers reporting chaotic scenes and smoke filling the tunnel. Officials say the causes of the derailment are unclear and an investigation is underway. No one was seriously hurt, but 11 people were taken to hospital. The train was carrying 600-700 people, and the first two cars were damaged. The incident comes less than four months after a fatal crash in New Jersey, where a speeding train derailed and crashed into a station.

images.alt_text: A New York commuter train derailed Wednesday during the morning rush at a station in Brooklyn, sparking chaotic scenes and leaving more than 100 people with minor injuries.

site_title: Turmoil on 1st day of Republican-controlled Congress
summary: The US Congress, now controlled by Republicans, opened with turmoil on its first day, as the Senate moved to repeal President Barack Obama's signature health care law and the House descended into chaos over an independent congressional ethics office. Despite the rocky start, Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell unveiled a legislative language that could decimate the Affordable Care Act, with a deadline of January 27 for House and Senate committees to produce legislation. The move has sparked a dueling over the health law's fate, with both the departing and incoming White House administrations involved.

site_title: Eurozone inflation in December hits 3-year high
summary: Eurozone inflation rose to a 3-year high of 1.1% in December, exceeding expectations, driven by surging oil prices. This marks a significant boost to the bloc's fragile economic recovery, but still falls short of the European Central Bank's 2% target. Energy inflation, at 2.5%, was the primary contributor to the increase. Despite this, core inflation remains subdued, and analysts predict the ECB's stimulus program will continue well into 2018. Eurozone business activity also showed a significant increase in December, but remains uncertain due to ongoing political developments.

site_title: Indonesia's bid for faster growth stumbles on high loan rates
summary: Indonesia's President Joko Widodo's goal of achieving single-digit interest rates for borrowers has not been met, with lending rates remaining double-digit and above his 9% target. Despite the central bank cutting interest rates six times last year, banks cite liquidity conditions as a major obstacle to lowering rates. The situation threatens to undermine economic growth, which is struggling to reach 7% from 5%. Regulators and officials hope that 2017 will see an improvement in lending rates, but factors such as US interest rate hikes and global trade uncertainty pose challenges.

site_title: Raffles Country Club faces its final tee-off next year
summary: The Singapore government will take over the Raffles Country Club's premises in Tuas by July 31, 2018, to build the Kuala Lumpur-Singapore High Speed Rail tracks. The decision comes after "extensive reviews" and is deemed the most suitable location for the HSR tracks, which will run at-grade on the RCC site. The government will acquire the 143-hectare land at a lower cost than buying individual factories in the vicinity, and the number of jobs affected is likely to be fewer. Members will receive compensation based on the market value of the land.

site_title: Facebook sleuths help bring back India's stolen idols
summary: A group of Indian art enthusiasts, the India Pride Project, has helped recover stolen Hindu idols using social media, including a $5 million bronze statue of Shiva returned by the National Gallery of Australia. The idols were allegedly trafficked by former art dealer Subhash Kapoor, who is on trial in India for conspiring in their theft and sale. The India Pride Project's efforts have brought attention to the issue of art theft in India, where many temples lack protection, and have helped recover hundreds of artifacts through grassroots documentation and advocacy.

site_title: Malaysia floods force 23,000 to leave homes
summary: Malaysia is experiencing severe flooding in the northeast states of Kelantan and Terengganu, forcing nearly 23,000 people to evacuate their homes. Heavy rain has caused widespread damage, with 101 schools closed and many roads impassable. Despite no reported deaths, relief centers have been opened to provide food, drink, and medical aid to those affected. The floods are a recurring issue in the region, with mass evacuations happening every year, and the situation is expected to worsen as the rain continues.

site_title: Tencent shares' US$35b loss shows depth of China gloom
summary: Tencent Holdings Ltd., a Shenzhen-based technology giant, has seen its US$35 billion in shares wiped off due to foreign investors' pullout from Hong Kong and Chinese equities. The company's large weighting on the Hang Seng Index contributed to the index's 5.6% decline in the fourth quarter. Despite this, analysts remain optimistic, citing Tencent's 43 "buy" ratings and expected continued growth in profit for at least three more years. The stock has rebounded after sell-offs, making new highs during its 12-year listing.

site_title: Megyn Kelly leaving Fox News for NBC
summary: Megyn Kelly is leaving Fox News for NBC, where she will host a daily daytime show and a Sunday newsmagazine program. The move raises questions about the future of Fox News and NBC News, and comes as the media landscape prepares for the inauguration of Donald Trump on January 20. Kelly's departure marks a shift in her television career, as she seeks to connect with a broader audience in a different format. The change also highlights the evolving television news industry, with implications for news organizations and the broader media landscape.

site_title: Macao casinos fall on China's currency scrutiny
summary: Macao casino operators Galaxy Entertainment Group Ltd and Sands China Ltd fell over 3% in intraday trading after China's currency regulator announced extra requirements for citizens buying foreign exchange. This move is seen as a sign of increased scrutiny on capital outflows, potentially curbing spending in Macau's casinos. The news comes as Macau's gambling revenue is recovering from a two-year slump.

images.alt_text: Macau casino operators just cannot catch a break. Just as gambling revenue in the tiny enclave starts to recover from a two-year slump, concern is building that China's increased scrutiny on capital outflows will once again curtail spending in Macau's casinos.

site_title: China moves to support yuan again as Trump inauguration nears
summary: China strengthened the yuan by setting a higher daily trading midpoint and state banks selling US dollars, amid speculation that it aims to stabilize the currency ahead of US President-elect Donald Trump's inauguration. The moves helped the yuan inch up 0.1, despite global US dollar strength, and the offshore yuan hit a two-week high. Analysts say China is intervening to prevent a trade war and protect its currency from breaching the seven yuan per US dollar level, with borrowing rates rising to their highest level in over three months.

site_title: LSE selling clearing arm to Euronext to pave way for Deutsche Boerse merger
summary: LSE's clearing arm, LCH Clearnet SA, is selling to Euronext NV for 510 million euros, aiming to pave the way for a Deutsche Boerse merger. The deal, worth 767 million SGD, will diversify Euronext's revenue streams and provide access to new asset classes. The sale comes as the EU considers a 12 billion USD takeover of LSE by Deutsche Boerse, which could create Europe's dominant operator in markets and clearing. The deal is expected to be completed by the end of the second quarter, pending shareholder and regulatory approvals.

site_title: Confluence of seemingly unrelated factors heralds demise of jobs
summary: A decade ago, global employment was not a concern, but now a confluence of factors is driving a decline in jobs. Anaemic global growth, high wages in first-world economies, and industry shifts are accelerating job losses. Traditional industries are giving way to new ones, with technology companies employing fewer people despite massive revenue. Small and medium enterprises, fintech, and medtech are creating new jobs, but workers may need to re-skill themselves to remain employable, with "skill obsolescence" affecting those aged 45-plus. Re-skilling and protectionism may alleviate the pain, with new private investors, crowdfunding, and peer-to-peer financing emerging as solutions.

site_title: Tillerson to cede control in Exxon
summary: Former Exxon Mobil Corp CEO Rex Tillerson, President-elect Donald Trump's pick for US secretary of state, will relinquish control of approximately $240 million in company shares if confirmed. Tillerson will sell over 600,000 shares and transfer the value of over 2 million deferred shares to an independently managed trust. He will also surrender entitlement to $4.1 million in cash bonuses and $7 million in lost compensation. Tillerson's confirmation hearing may begin as soon as next week to comply with conflict-of-interest requirements.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: ComfortDelGro, a Singapore-based transportation company, acquired the remaining 49% stake in ComfortDelGro Cabcharge for S$195 million. The company is shifting its taxi operations to a revenue-sharing model, which may impact its rental rates. Despite competition from Uber and Grab, ComfortDelGro's Singapore taxi business has remained steady, with revenue growth. Analysts expect the company to benefit from rail ridership growth and fare increases, but note risks such as lower bus business margins and taxi hire-out rate declines. The target price is S$2.95.

site_title: SGX electricity futures an enabling factor for new competition
summary: Singapore's new electricity futures on the Singapore Exchange have enabled independent retailers to hedge their risks, contributing to new competition in the market. However, liquidity remains a concern, with incumbents warning that new entrants may struggle to survive without effective hedging. This could pose risks to consumers and dent confidence in the overall market. The futures market's emergence has marked a significant development in the Singaporean electricity market, but further growth and stability are needed to ensure its long-term success.

site_title: Beijing should end impasse over HK chief's election
summary: Beijing is urging Hong Kong to end its impasse over the election of a new chief executive, 20 years after the city's transfer to China. The "one country, two systems" policy, which allows Hong Kong autonomy, was established to prevent China from exerting too much control. Hong Kong's economy, once considered one of Asia's "four tigers," has struggled to keep pace with China's growth, and the city's government is facing pressure to resolve the impasse. A resolution is seen as crucial to maintaining stability in the city.

site_title: Iron's blockbuster rally under threat
summary: Iron ore prices are expected to decline in 2017 due to increased supply from Vale's S11D project in Brazil and slowing demand. Supply concerns re-emerge as the industry's biggest project and holdings at Chinese ports reach record levels. Analysts predict a gradual decline in prices, with some forecasting a drop to US$61 or US$50-US$60 by mid-year, as supply balances with demand. The top four miners are expected to boost supply 19 million tonnes next year, mostly from S11D.

site_title: Ringgit tumbles to 4.50 to US$; expected to slide to 4.70 by mid-2017
summary: The Malaysian ringgit plummeted to 4.50 to the US dollar on January 4, 2017, with forecasts predicting it will slide further to 4.70 by mid-2017. Analysts attribute the decline to the country's weak foreign reserves and capital outflows. The central bank's attempts to stabilize the currency have been met with skepticism, with experts arguing that curbing foreign exchange markets is counterproductive. The ringgit's slide poses significant challenges for businesses, particularly those with imported costs, and has raised concerns about the country's economic stability.

site_title: Mar-a-Lago resort: Trump's future winter White House
summary: US President-elect Donald Trump spent the New Year's Eve at Mar-a-Lago, his 118-room private club in Palm Beach, Florida. The exclusive resort has become Trump's winter White House, where he has hosted high-profile guests, including celebrities and politicians. Trump has been seated in an ornate couch, surrounded by chandeliers and gold accents, and has engaged in conversations with guests about his future cabinet appointments and policies. The club's membership, initially limited to wealthy developers, has been opened up to Jews, African-Americans, and openly gay individuals, sparking controversy over exclusivity.

site_title: Why German banks stand firm against Basel's capital limits
summary: Germany is resisting a proposed global standard by the Basel Committee on Banking Supervision to set a floor for banks' risk-weighting of assets, which could affect Deutsche Bank and Commerzbank. The two German banks have lower risk-weighting of assets compared to US banks, citing their less risky assets. The Basel committee proposes a floor of 60-90%, but Germany and Sweden object, arguing it could stifle variation in risk weightings. A compromise of 75% is being considered, which could raise risk weightings for Deutsche Bank and Commerzbank.

site_title: Japanese stocks in for a bull market this year, say analysts
summary: Japanese stocks are predicted to enter a bull market in 2017, driven by the weakening yen and Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's economic priorities. Abe pledged to focus on the economy, using "three arrows" of monetary, fiscal, and growth strategies to beat deflation. Analysts at Citigroup predict a 1,150 target for the MSCI global equity index by mid-2026. This optimism is reflected in Tokyo's sharp rise amidst Abe's new-year press conference, signaling a promising year for the country's economy.

site_title: Property bubbles may burst, OECD warns
summary: The Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD) has warned that property bubbles in key member nations, including the UK, Australia, and Canada, could burst, posing a risk to economic stability. The OECD notes that "very high" commercial and residential property prices are not consistent with a stable real estate market, and that a jump in bond yields could lead to a decline in inflated property prices. London prime property prices have already begun to fall, with the average price per square foot in prime central London decreasing by 6% in the third quarter of 2016.

site_title: Opec's production deal faces multiple challenges
summary: Opec's production deal, implemented in November 2016, is set to take effect as the oil cartel and its allies reduce daily production by 1.8 million barrels over six months. The deal aims to tighten supplies and boost prices, which have more than doubled from their lowest point a year ago. Brent prices have jumped by a fifth since the deal, reaching $60 per barrel, and demand is expected to improve by at least 1.2 million barrels per day. The move is seen as a test of Opec's ability to manage global oil markets.

site_title: ANZ's Elliott picks wrong target in retreat from Asia
summary: ANZ CEO Shayne Elliott's attempt to sell off Asian banking assets may be hitting its limits. The bank has sold a 39% stake in PT Bank Pan Indonesia and a 24% stake in Malaysia's AMMB Holdings, but progress has been slow. Elliott's focus on exiting Asian retail units, which underperformed, may be misplaced, as the institutional banking business, which is one of the region's biggest, is also struggling with low returns. The bank's deposits exceeded loans by A$38.4 billion, contributing to poor returns on risk-weighted assets.

site_title: Can the American Pacific Century survive Trump?
summary: President-elect Donald Trump's hawkish agenda is brewing a new Pacific Cold War, potentially undermining President Barack Obama's goal of the American Pacific Century. Trump's vision for an American Pacific Century, "Making America great again," differs from Obama's, but both aim to ensure US supremacy. The US is facing economic decline, making its continued dominance uncertain. Trump's foreign policy shift poses challenges to Obama's legacy and the region's fragile stability.

images.alt_text: The challenge confronting Mr Trump is to turn China away from its present inflammatory course of using military power to occupy territory.

site_title: Hard Brexit looms large with resignation of UK's EU envoy
summary: The UK's permanent representative to the EU, Ivan Rogers, has resigned, citing concerns about the government's lack of experienced negotiators and a "muddled thinking" approach to Brexit. His departure has raised concerns about the UK's ability to navigate the Brexit negotiations, with some warning of a "hard Brexit" that prioritizes sovereignty over economic integration with the EU. The UK's new envoy will face significant challenges in negotiating a free-trade deal with the EU, with some experts predicting a decade-long process.

site_title: Gone in 2.39 seconds: Faraday claims world's fastest electric car
summary: Faraday Future unveiled its FF91 electric car, claiming the world's fastest electric car with a 0-60mph time of 2.39 seconds, surpassing Tesla's Model S P100D. The 1,050-horsepower car has a range of over 378 miles and features a personalized interface and self-parking capabilities. Backed by Chinese billionaire Jia Yueting, Faraday Future aims to revolutionize mobility and is seeking to raise funds from investors. The company plans to start production in 2018 and deliver the first cars in 2018, with a reservation price of $5,000.

site_title: New landscapes being drawn on Singapore's innovation canvas
summary: In Singapore, a record number of businesses have launched initiatives to co-innovate with startups, with over 15 enterprises launching corporate accelerator programs or venture capital funds in the past year. While observers praise the efforts, many corporates remain uncertain about how to innovate, with some citing a fear of disruption and a lack of understanding of how to connect with startups. Despite government support, the vast majority of corporates are still hesitant to engage in corporate innovation, with many waiting for mandates or incentives to mitigate their risks.

site_title: McDonald's opens near Vatican City despite protests from cardinals
summary: McDonald's has opened a new outlet near Vatican City, despite protests from cardinals, who opposed the location citing concerns about the spread of unhealthy food. The Vatican backed the US fast food giant in the dispute. The restaurant is situated at the foot of Saint Peter's Square, allowing customers to enjoy Big Macs with a view of the iconic landmark. The move marks a victory for McDonald's, which has been expanding its global presence.

images.alt_text: While it lies outside the Holy See's walls, those popping in for a burger and chips at the new McDonald's outlet now have a good view of the papal apartment windows.

site_title: Pressure on Sibor and SOR continues with spectre of Fed hikes
summary: Singapore's interest rates remain under pressure, with the three-month Sibor rising to 0.96918% and the three-month SOR remaining unchanged at 1.01175%. This pressure is attributed to potential US Federal Reserve hikes, which could impact the region's economic outlook. Meanwhile, OCBC's incoming CEO Tan Teck Long, a former DBS veteran, will replace retiring CEO Helen Wong, and Singapore's affluents have set a target of $1.39 million to retire comfortably.

site_title: New power transmission lines to cost India US$10b a year
summary: India plans to spend US$10 billion annually on new power transmission lines to meet growing demand in under-served areas. The central government may spend US$6 billion, with the rest coming from states. The country lacks sufficient transmission infrastructure to link its increasing generation capacity to areas of burgeoning consumption. Demand is driven by Prime Minister Narendra Modi's goal of supplying affordable, continuous power to the whole country by 2019. The government expects to spend US$7.6 billion a year over the next five years to add 100,000 circuit kilometers of transmission lines and 200,000 mega volt ampere of transformation capacity.

site_title: China's credit engine is running out of gas as debt risk goes up
summary: China's credit engine is slowing down due to rising debt risk, with the People's Bank of China (PBOC) tightening monetary policy to reduce risks and stabilize the yuan. Funding levels are expected to decline, posing a risk to 2017's economic growth, particularly for smaller companies. The PBOC's selective tightening aims to curb shadow banking and regulate wealth management products, which could lead to tighter financial conditions and slower economic growth.

site_title: Universal basic income - Europe's latest social experiment
summary: Finland launched a two-year social experiment providing a monthly basic income of 560 euros to all working-age citizens, including the unemployed. The universal basic income (UBI) scheme is part of a broader European trend, with pilot schemes underway in four Dutch cities and two Scottish councils. Critics argue that UBI is a costly policy idea that could kill the work ethic, while proponents believe it could strengthen work incentives and address poverty and unemployment. The experiment will be closely watched globally to assess its impact on work incentives and government support for citizens.

site_title: Market picks up on US stocks' rally
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index rose 22.34 points or 0.77% to 2,921.31 on its second trading day of 2017, driven by a rally in local banking stocks, including OCBC, DBS, and UOB. The gains followed renewed optimism in the US Trump administration, with US stocks rising 0.9% on Monday. The local market's performance was also boosted by data showing an improvement in US manufacturing activity and a strong greenback.

site_title: China regulator sets rules to curb property insurance products risk
summary: China's insurance regulator has introduced new rules to curb risks associated with property insurance products, aiming to ensure reasonableness in premiums and prevent insurers from earning overly high premiums. The guidelines state that insurers cannot issue products covering profit-making risks and premiums must be calculated based on actual risk and insurance liability. The move follows previous measures to address overbearing shareholders and funding term mismatches. The regulator aims to prevent improper transfer of benefits and ensure fairness in the insurance market.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close higher on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index closed higher on Wednesday, up 11.9 points to 1,647.470, with 564 gainers outweighing 270 losers. The index saw a volume of 1.64 billion lots worth RM1.98 billion.

site_title: US: Wall St opens higher as banks, discretionary stocks rise
summary: US stocks rose on Wednesday, driven by gains in consumer discretionary and bank stocks, extending gains into the second trading day of the new year. Investors await the Federal Reserve's minutes from its December meeting, citing strength in the labor market and slight inflation as reasons for the interest rate hike. With President-elect Donald Trump's proposed policies, such as tax cuts and higher fiscal spending, also under scrutiny, investors remain optimistic about the market's prospects.

site_title: Huawei launches Honor 6x smartphone globally
summary: Huawei has launched the Honor 6x smartphone globally, targeting young consumers with dual-lens camera technology. Priced at $249-$299, the device will be available in 13 new markets, including the US. The company aims to sell 20 million units, with improved battery life and software for better low-light photography. Huawei seeks to expand its presence in the US market, competing with top brands Apple and Samsung. The launch comes as the company aims to become the world's number one smartphone maker, competing with other Chinese firms like Lenovo and Xiaomi.

site_title: Global sulphur cap may boost O&M infrastructure
summary: A global sulphur cap set for 2020 is expected to boost investments in offshore and marine (O&M) infrastructure, particularly for liquefied natural gas (LNG) bunkering. The International Maritime Organization (IMO) has set a 0.5% limit on sulphur content in ship fuel, prompting ports to prepare for LNG refuelling. Classification societies report 26 ports with confirmed LNG bunkering plans and 57 LNG supply locations worldwide. While LNG bunkering infrastructure development is speeding up, its long-term impact on cutting greenhouse gas emissions is uncertain, with some arguing that it's not a sufficient solution.

images.alt_text: IE Singapore in its recently published insights on the LNG market identified this as an opening for O&M players seeking to tide over a drastic decline in contracting opportunities in the upstream oil & gas sector.

site_title: Blumont exposes chink in watch-list rules
summary: The Singapore Exchange's (SGX) watch-list rules assume a company with multi-year losses and low share price will struggle to maintain high market capitalization. However, Blumont Group, a loss-making mining and investment holding company, has successfully avoided delisting by issuing 23 billion new shares in 2016, increasing its market cap despite trading below one Singapore cent. The company's issuance rendered it invulnerable to the watch lists, highlighting a potential loophole in the rules, which may require further calibration.

site_title: US$ retreats from high as traders await cues
summary: The US dollar retreated from a 14-year high against a basket of currencies on Wednesday, falling 0.1% to 103.08, as investors awaited fresh clues on the US economy and timing of interest rate hikes. The dollar had surged to its highest levels since 2002 on Tuesday after US manufacturing data beat expectations, but analysts say they need more evidence of growth and inflation before putting on more bets on the dollar. The euro rose 0.3% to $1.0435, with some forecasts predicting it could reach parity with the dollar this year.

site_title: China search engine Sogou targets US$5b IPO
summary: China's No. 3 search engine, Sogou, is planning a US$5 billion initial public offering (IPO) to raise cash and close the gap with leader Baidu. The company, backed by Tencent Holdings and Sohu.com, plans to sell about 10% of its shares and use the funds to improve search results with artificial intelligence and machine-learning technologies. CEO Wang Xiaochuan predicts Sogou can match Baidu in mobile search within three years, despite Baidu's massive data advantage.

site_title: PMI plunge adds to evidence India cash ban is hurting growth
summary: India's dominant services sector is expected to contract for a second straight month, according to the Nikkei India Services Purchasing Managers' Index (PMI) at 46.8 in December, below the 50 threshold indicating contraction. This adds to evidence that Prime Minister Narendra Modi's surprise cash ban is hurting growth, with the services sector being a key contributor to India's economy. The ban, implemented in November, has disrupted businesses and led to a decline in economic activity.

site_title: Eurozone economy hits near 6-year high
summary: The Eurozone economy reached its highest rate since May 2011 in December, with business activity showing a 54.4 points reading on the Composite Purchasing Managers Index, up from 53.9 points in November. This indicates solid growth, but political uncertainty, including the Trump election and Brexit turmoil, casts doubt on the outlook for 2017. Economic growth is expected to be 0.4% in the last three months of 2016, supported by a weaker euro and the European Central Bank's stimulus program, but domestic demand may remain subdued due to political uncertainty.

site_title: Credit Suisse appoints new Singapore CEO, makes other management changes
summary: Credit Suisse has appointed Benjamin Cavalli as its new Singapore CEO, replacing Lito Camacho. Cavalli, with over 20 years of experience in wealth management and investment banking, will report to Francesco de Ferrari. The bank also appointed a new deputy Singapore CEO, Tan Kuan Ern, and made other management changes, including Jacky Ang as branch manager. Singapore is the largest booking centre for Credit Suisse's private banking business and a hub for its investment banking franchise in South-east Asia.

site_title: Statoil boosts exploration as cost cuts give more bang for buck
summary: Statoil, a Norwegian oil company, is increasing exploration efforts for the first time since 2013. The company plans to drill 30 exploration wells in 2017, up from 23 last year, with a focus on the Arctic Barents Sea. Cost cuts and lower fees from suppliers have allowed Statoil to get more work done for less, with executive vice president Tim Dodson stating that the company is taking advantage of improved conditions to increase its exploration investments.

site_title: China Bank sells more of riskiest wealth management products
summary: Guangzhou Rural Commercial Bank, a Chinese bank preparing to list in Hong Kong, sold 93 billion yuan of its riskiest wealth management products in the nine months ended September, accounting for a third of its sales. This surge in demand for "relatively higher return and higher risks" products, which were channeled into money market instruments, debt securities, and equity products, has raised concerns about the risks posed to individual banks. The People's Bank of China plans to increase oversight of these products amid a bond market rout.

site_title: Asia shipping firms mull mergers amid bleak 2017
summary: Asia's container shipping firms are expected to continue consolidating amid a prolonged trade slowdown and depressed freight rates. The region's top shipping companies, including Maersk and Hyundai Merchant, are mulling mergers and acquisitions to cut costs and improve efficiency. Japan's biggest shipping companies have already agreed to combine their container-moving businesses, while China's China Cosco Shipping Corp, the region's largest container line, was formed last year. Industry experts predict further consolidation as companies try to adapt to the changing market, with a possible merger between Taiwanese shipping companies or a buyout of Hyundai Merchant.

site_title: Dubai Islamic Bank requests proposals for dollar sukuk
summary: Dubai Islamic Bank (DIB) has requested proposals from banks to issue a US dollar-denominated sukuk, with a planned debt transaction of benchmark size, reportedly over US$500 million. This move follows other Gulf banks seeking to raise debt internationally to improve liquidity amid low oil prices. DIB's decision is part of a broader trend in the Islamic finance sector to diversify funding sources and mitigate the impact of low oil prices. The bank's spokesman declined to comment on the request for proposals.

site_title: Manhattan home prices fall as sellers concede to slowdown
summary: Manhattan home prices plummeted 6.3% in the fourth quarter to a median of $900,000, marking the first annual decline since 2015. Sellers are adjusting to a slowing market with inventory rising, and buyers are walking away from listings deemed too expensive. The average discount from the last asking price was 4.7%, up from 3.1% last year. This shift is attributed to buyers becoming more aggressive in making low offers, with only 13% paying over the asking price, down from 29% last year.

site_title: Gender pay gap halves for millennials, but will widen with age
summary: The pay gap between men and women in their 20s has halved to 5% in a generation, according to a British think-tank's analysis. This marks the first time the gap has fallen for every generation of women since those born between 1911 and 1925. The gap has narrowed from 16% for baby-boomers to 9% for Generation X and 5% for millennials. However, the study predicts the gap will widen as millennials grow older.

site_title: Net capital flows to EMs at their lowest since global financial crisis: IIF
summary: Net capital flows to emerging markets (EMs) hit their lowest level since the global financial crisis in 2016, according to the Institute of International Finance (IIF). This decline is attributed to a combination of the "Trump trade" and the US Federal Reserve's more hawkish policy stance. Capital outflows have been most severe in debt markets, particularly in China and India, with China experiencing severe net outflows following its demonetization initiative.

site_title: A trip to the land of endangered ancient olive trees
summary: Spain's ancient olive trees, some over 1,000 years old, are increasingly protected after being seen as a vital part of the country's heritage. Farmers like Amador Peset tend to the trees, which were once dug up and sold for luxury items. The trees are now protected, and some are even used to produce high-value oil, with prices reaching up to 90 euros per liter. Efforts to conserve the trees have led to a decrease in their removal, with hundreds of trees having been ripped out in the past. A petition has been launched to ban the trade in ancient olive trees, which has garnered 154,000 signatures.

site_title: Potential for competition electrifies power market
summary: Singapore is set to fully liberalize its electricity market by mid-2018, allowing consumers to choose their electricity retailer. Independent retailers, such as Red Dot Power and iSwitch, are entering the market, offering competitive pricing and smart meter technology to reduce peak demand and consumption. Power-generation firms, which have been struggling with overcapacity, are adapting by adding retail teams and exploring new services, including renewable energy and energy-solutions businesses. The move is expected to bring benefits to consumers, including lower prices and increased competition, ultimately transforming the electricity sector.

site_title: La La Land,Manchester by the Sea and Moonlight sweep NY Critics Circle awards
summary: The 82nd New York Film Critics Circle awards honored top films of the year, with La La Land taking the top prize for Best Picture. Damien Chazelle's musical love story is considered an Oscar front-runner. Casey Affleck won Best Actor for Manchester by the Sea, while Isabelle Huppert took Best Actress for Elle and Things To Come. Moonlight won multiple awards, including Best Supporting Actor for Mahershala Ali, Best Director for Barry Jenkins, and Best Cinematography for James Laxton. The awards are seen as a bellwether for the Oscars.

site_title: China goes on 177.4t yuan commodity binge as shortages seen
summary: Chinese investors traded a record 177.4 trillion yuan in commodity futures in 2016, driven by bets on looming shortages due to government efforts to cut industrial capacity. Trading volume on Shanghai, Dalian, and Zhengzhou exchanges jumped 27% from 2015 levels, with prices of steel, coal, soymeal, and zinc surging to multi-year highs. Authorities introduced curbs on excessive speculation to quell the market frenzy, but the Chinese bourses remain behind international rivals in terms of turnover.

site_title: Panel calls for third growth engine and broad-based support for SMEs
summary: The Singapore Business Federation's SME Committee has submitted 21 recommendations to the government for the 2017 budget, focusing on creating a new growth engine through globally competitive companies (GCCs) and providing broad-based support to small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs). The recommendations include setting up a private bourse for innovative companies, developing local businesses through Industry Transformation Maps, and introducing incentives to attract foreign companies to anchor in Singapore. The committee also proposed measures to help SMEs with manpower issues, lower compliance costs, and enhance financing options. The government has welcomed the recommendations and will study them before delivering the budget on February 20.

site_title: Asia's ultra-rich families dropping hedge funds for alternative assets
summary: Asia's ultra-rich families are shifting away from hedge funds and towards alternative assets, such as private equity and technology companies, due to mediocre returns and high fees. This trend is expected to hit regional hedge funds hard, with family offices already pulling out US$1.6 billion in withdrawals through November. The shift is driven by the ultra-rich families' desire for control over their assets and better returns, with many opting for direct investments in companies like Uber and Magic Leap. As a result, new hedge funds in Asia face significant challenges in attracting institutional investor capital.

site_title: Fire at China nursing home kills seven
summary: A fire at a private nursing home in China's Jilin province killed seven people on January 4, 2017. The blaze broke out at 4:10am and was extinguished 17 minutes later. Firefighters rescued 32 others. The incident is the latest in a series of deadly fires in China's elderly care facilities, prompting concerns about the country's aging population and safety record.

site_title: Deutsche Bank crime fighter said to step down after six months
summary: Deutsche Bank's global head of anti-financial crime, Peter Hazlewood, is stepping down after six months, a move reportedly due to unconfirmed reasons. Hazlewood, who joined Deutsche Bank in July, will likely stay with the bank in a different role. His departure comes after a significant overhaul of the bank's anti-money laundering efforts. No official comment has been made by Deutsche Bank, and Hazlewood could not be reached for comment.

site_title: British Airways faces strike from Jan 10 as crew members spurn pay deal
summary: British Airways flight attendants, represented by the Unite union, will go on strike starting January 10, affecting 2,500 of the airline's 4,500 mixed-fleet cabin crew members. The strike comes after the airline declined to extend the strike mandate in response to the rejection of a proposed pay deal. The Unite union had previously agreed to scrap calls for a walkout over the Christmas and Boxing Day holiday. The airline aims to ensure customer safety and has proposed contingency measures to mitigate the disruption.

site_title: Louis Vuitton senior designer to take lead at French label Chloé -sources
summary: Chloé is set to name Natacha Ramsay-Levi as its new creative director, replacing Clare Waight Keller, who is leaving the label due to her family's relocation. Ramsay-Levi, a senior designer at Louis Vuitton, will bring a modern aesthetic to Chloé, which may disrupt the brand's traditional flowing silhouettes. Industry analysts see the appointment as an opportunity for Chloé to boost sales and attract consumers' attention, following a year of reshuffles in the fashion industry.

site_title: Singapore shares end 22.34 points higher on banking stocks rally
summary: Singapore shares rose 22.34 points, or 0.77%, to 2,921.31, led by a rally in banking stocks. Trading was firm with 280 rises versus 151 falls, excluding warrants. The benchmark Straits Times Index extended gains from the previous day.

site_title: BMW to deploy fleet of self-driving 7-series on roads this year
summary: BMW plans to deploy a fleet of 40 self-driving 7-series sedans in US and European cities by the end of 2023, as part of its partnership with Mobileye and Intel to introduce fully autonomous vehicles by 2021. The goal is to gather data for the iNext model, set to replace the 7-Series, which will achieve full autonomy four years later. This move aims to accelerate research and development, reduce costs, and stay competitive with companies like Google and Tesla.

site_title: KFC's return to Malaysian bourse heralds rebound in deal volumes
summary: KFC's planned relisting on the Malaysian bourse is expected to boost fundraising for initial public offerings (IPOs) in the country. After 16-year lows in 2016, first-time share sales in Malaysia are projected to reach at least US$2 billion this year, driven by receding uncertainty and rising commodity prices. This rebound is seen as a positive sign for the region's IPO market, which had seen a decline in 2016.

images.alt_text: Companies that have been waiting for better market conditions may proceed with listing plans now, as borrowing costs are rising, says James Lau, investment director at Pheim Asset Management.

site_title: Sino Grandness partners Wechat Food to distribute food products online
summary: Sino Grandness Food Industry Group has partnered with Wechat Food to distribute its full range of products online through a mobile platform. The products, including house brands such as Garden Fresh beverages, Grandness canned food, and Hao Tian Yuan snack food, will be sold online. The partnership aims to capitalize on China's growing retail e-commerce sales, which are driven by improved internet speed, coverage, and smartphone adoption. The collaboration is in line with the PRC government's initiatives to promote the new economy and achieve synergies between online and offline business models.

site_title: Trump tariff on GM would violate NAFTA
summary: President-elect Donald Trump's threat to impose a "big border tax" on General Motors for building cars in Mexico under the North American Free Trade Agreement (NAFTA) is unlikely to be enforced. Trade experts say targeting a single company with a tariff would violate NAFTA and could prompt a Mexican response, hurting US exports and raising prices. Trump could instead impose 15% duties for 100 days on GM's cars, but a 35% tariff would require Congressional approval. The move could harm US consumers and US companies that buy or sell goods abroad, and is seen as an unprecedented use of trade authority.

site_title: Update: Indonesia says military acted alone to suspend cooperation with Australia
summary: Indonesia's military suspended cooperation with Australia's armed forces last week after insulting teaching materials were found at a base in Western Australia. The Indonesian military acted alone in the decision, with Defence Minister Ryamizard Ryacudu stating that there was no discussion with President Joko Widodo. Australian Defence Minister Marise Payne said only some activities had been postponed, with cooperation expected to resume once the issues are resolved. This suspension marks the second time in 10 years that military ties have been strained between the two countries, with the first incident occurring in 2013 over revelations of Australian spy taps.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks snap 4-day winning streak on outflow worries
summary: Hong Kong stocks snapped a 4-day winning streak due to outflow worries triggered by a stronger US dollar. The Hang Seng index closed 0.1% lower at 22,134.47 points, while the Hong Kong China Enterprises Index fell 0.2%. Industrial stocks led gains, but energy majors declined due to oil price drops. Investor anxiety eased, with the HIS Volatility Index falling 4.7%.

site_title: Insurers paid out US$50b for natural disasters in 2016
summary: Insurers paid out approximately US$50 billion in 2016 for natural disaster claims, marking the costliest year for natural catastrophe losses in the last four years, according to Munich Re's annual review. This surpasses the 10-year average of US$45.1 billion and exceeds the US$27 billion registered in 2015.

site_title: Europe: Stock markets rise at open
summary: Europe's main stock markets rose at the start of trading on Wednesday, with London's FTSE 100 index gaining 0.1% to a record high, and Frankfurt's DAX 30 index and Paris CAC 40 also increasing. The gains followed a rally across Asia.

site_title: Indonesia's bid to get faster growth stumbles on high loan rates
summary: Indonesia's interest rates remain double-digit, frustrating President Joko Widodo's efforts to boost economic growth. Despite the central bank cutting rates six times last year, lending rates remain above 9% due to liquidity conditions and banks' concerns about bad debts. The situation threatens to undermine the government's target of raising annual growth to 7% and could be impacted by anticipated US interest rate hikes and uncertainty about world trade.

site_title: Investment banking fees fall 7 per cent in 2016 dragged down by equity raisings
summary: Investment banking fees worldwide fell 7% in 2016, mainly due to a 23% decline in equity capital market fees. European and Middle Eastern banks were particularly affected, with a 20% drop in total fees. US banks, such as JP Morgan and Goldman Sachs, maintained their positions, while boutique firms like Evercore and Rothschild saw increases in fees. Debt capital markets underwriting fees rose 6% to 29% of overall fees, and post-Soviet states, including Russia, experienced a resurgence in fees.

site_title: US mortgage activity stabilizes as loan rates slip
summary: US mortgage activity stabilized in December, with loan applications rising 0.1% to 358.5, according to the Mortgage Bankers Association. Interest rates on 30-year fixed-rate mortgages dropped to 4.39%, the lowest since April 2014. Refinancing activity increased 1.7% as domestic home borrowing costs retreated. The refinance share of overall loan activity rose to 52.2%. Despite a dip in home-buying applications, the stabilization in mortgage activity suggests a slowdown in the decline of US home prices.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: The Singapore Land Authority (SLA) has acquired the Raffles Country Club site to make way for the KL-Singapore High-Speed Rail. The benchmark three-month Sibor rose to 0.96918% due to pressure on the Singapore dollar. A container vessel collision caused an oil spill on the Singapore-Malaysia border. Credit Suisse appointed a new CEO for Singapore, while Sino Grandness partnered with Wechat Food to distribute food products online. The Straits Times Index (STI) rose 22.34 points or 0.77% due to a banking stocks rally, amidst international news including Vietnam's surprise to Trump's tariff announcement and China's slowing GDP growth.

site_title: South Korea vows US missile system as opposition lawmakers head to China
summary: South Korea has reaffirmed its commitment to deploying the US Terminal High Altitude Area Defence (Thaad) missile defense system by the end of 2017, despite opposition from China. The decision was made in response to North Korea's nuclear and missile tests. Defence Minister Han Min Koo stated that Thaad deployment is part of efforts to bolster defence against North Korean threats. Opposition lawmakers are currently in China to express concerns over the deployment.

site_title: Australia: Shares inch up to fresh 19-month high
summary: Australian shares reached a 19-month high, closing 0.06% up at 5,736.4 on the S&P/ASX 200 index. Financials led the gain, with the "Big Four" banks rising between 0.5% and 0.9%. Real estate stocks, however, declined, with shopping centre operator Scentre Group falling nearly 2%. The rally was driven by gains in materials, gold miners, and energy stocks, despite a decline in mining stocks.

site_title: Pressure on Sibor, SOR continues in the New Year, rising to around 1%
summary: Singapore's key interest rates continue to rise in the New Year, with the 3-month Sibor at 0.96918% and the 3-month SOR at 1.01175%. Experts expect the rates to track higher as the US Federal Reserve normalizes monetary policy, with DBS Bank predicting four rate hikes in 2017. The rates are converging around one percent after the Fed's December hike, with the SOR rising 35 basis points over the past quarter. Expectations for rate hikes are increasing, with DBS and OCBC Bank projecting higher rates in the coming months.

site_title: Chinese official shoots two, kills self at party meeting: reports
summary: A high-ranking Chinese official, Chen Zhongshu, 54, shot and killed two city officials, Mayor Li Jianqin and city party secretary Zhang Yan, before killing himself at a government meeting in Panzhihua, Sichuan province. Chen, known for his stubborn personality and explosive temper, had no apparent motive for the attack. Gun violence is rare in China, and private citizens are banned from owning firearms. The incident highlights the pressures faced by Chinese officials, with Chen reportedly complaining that the party chief picked on him.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares jump higher on weaker yen
summary: Tokyo shares surged 2.51% on the first trading day of 2017, with the Nikkei 225 index closing at 19,594.16. A weaker yen boosted investor sentiment, contributing to the gains. The broader Topix index also rose 2.36%. The market momentum follows a rally in Singapore and the US, where stocks edged to fresh records despite tariff uncertainty.

site_title: Indonesia suspends military cooperation with Australia
summary: Indonesia has suspended military cooperation with Australia due to technical matters, reportedly over training materials deemed offensive. The suspension comes after an Indonesian instructor found materials disrespecting his country and armed forces during an exchange program. This is the latest in a series of tensions between the neighbors, with previous suspensions in 2013 and 2017. The Indonesian military hopes the issue will be resolved soon and maintains communication with the Australian forces.

site_title: Thailand's deputy PM Prawit says 2017 general election on track
summary: Thailand's Deputy Prime Minister Prawit Wongsuwan confirmed that a general election will be held this year, despite initial doubts raised by a member of the National Legislative Assembly. The election, which will restore civilian rule after a 2014 coup, has a set time frame and cannot be delayed. The National Legislative Assembly's request to delay the election until 2018 was deemed irrelevant by Prawit, who stated that the decision is not his problem.

site_title: WikiLeaks urges leaks of White House docs before Obama leaves office
summary: WikiLeaks urged the public to leak White House documents before President Barack Obama's departure, offering a $20,000 reward for information leading to the arrest or exposure of Obama administration agents destroying records. Founder Julian Assange denied Russia's involvement in hacked Democratic party emails that hurt Hillary Clinton's presidential bid. Assange also gave an in-depth interview to Fox, further emphasizing WikiLeaks' appeal for leaked documents.

site_title: SLA buys back Raffles Country Club site to make way for KL-Singapore High-Speed Rail
summary: The Singapore Land Authority (SLA) has acquired the land occupied by the Raffles Country Club to make way for the Kuala Lumpur-Singapore High-Speed Rail (HSR) and the Cross Island Line (CRL). The site will house HSR facilities, including tracks and a siding facility, and the CRL's western depot for stabling and maintenance. The acquisition is part of the governments' plan to commence HSR operations by December 31, 2026. SLA will work closely with the RCC management throughout the process.

site_title: Sinopec mandates six banks to advise on unit revamp ahead of IPO
summary: Sinopec has mandated six banks - China International Capital Corp, China Merchants Securities, CITIC Securities, Citigroup, Goldman Sachs, and Morgan Stanley - to advise on restructuring its fuels distribution unit ahead of a planned Hong Kong IPO. The unit, Sinopec Marketing, will transition from a limited liability company to a corporation. The IPO could raise approximately $12 billion, subject to market conditions.

site_title: China issues 2017 fuel import quotas for state oil firms
summary: China has issued 2017 fuel import quotas for its state-owned oil firms, allowing them to import 3.3 million tonnes of naphtha and 50,000 tonnes of jet kerosene. The naphtha quota is 36% higher than the previous year. The gasoline and diesel quotas are significantly lower, at 240 tonnes, primarily for a car-racing event. The quotas were issued on December 19, according to an official document.

site_title: Tencent shares losing US$35b shows depth of China gloom
summary: Tencent Holdings Ltd. saw a 13% decline from its September record, wiping US$35 billion off its shares, due to foreign investors' bearish stance on Chinese stocks. The company's large weighting on the Hang Seng Index contributed to Hong Kong's worst quarterly performance. Despite this, analysts remain optimistic, citing Tencent's fundamentals, such as its 43% jump in third-quarter net income and expected continued growth. The stock has rebounded after each selloff to make new highs during its 12-year listing.

site_title: Gold prices steady as US dollar holds near 14-year peak
summary: Gold prices remained steady on Wednesday, following a three-week high the previous day, at US$1,159.05 an ounce. The US dollar hovered near a 14-year peak, curbing demand for commodities priced in the greenback. Strong US economic data, including a two-year high in factory activity and a 10-1/2-year high in construction spending, led to expectations of faster interest rate hikes, which could dampen gold's appeal.

site_title: Turkey has identified Istanbul nightclub attacker: foreign minister
summary: Turkey's foreign minister, Mevlut Cavusoglu, announced that the gunman responsible for the New Year's Eve nightclub attack in Istanbul has been identified. The assailant, who killed 39 people, including 27 foreigners, claimed by the Islamic State group. The attacker rented a flat in Konya and moved to Istanbul before carrying out the attack, reportedly well-trained in arms and having fought for IS in Syria. Authorities are still on the hunt for the gunman, who has been on the run since escaping the club.

site_title: Suspected IS scout for Berlin attack sites goes on trial
summary: A 19-year-old Syrian national, Shaas Al-M, goes on trial in Germany for allegedly scouting potential targets for an Islamic State attack in Berlin, including the Brandenburg Gate and Reichstag building. Al-M is accused of membership in a foreign terrorist organization and military weapons law violations, carrying up to 10 years in jail. He was arrested in March 2016 and has been in pre-trial detention since, and the trial will be held under tight security.

site_title: Oil prices rise on tighter supply outlook, but strong dollar weighs
summary: Oil prices rose on Wednesday due to an expected tightening of physical oil supplies as major producers like Opec plan to cut crude output. US West Texas Intermediate crude futures rose 17 cents to $52.50 per barrel, while Brent crude futures increased 21 cents to $55.68 per barrel. Saudi Arabia is expected to raise its official selling price for crude to Asia in February, reflecting a tightening market. However, a strong US dollar weighed on gains, making it more expensive for countries to import dollar-traded fuel.

site_title: China's money rate down, but Hong Kong borrowing cost up
summary: China's primary money rate fell to 2.2895% on Wednesday as seasonal factors faded, but offshore borrowing costs rose amid a shrinking yuan pool in Hong Kong. The People's Bank of China drained 295 billion yuan from the money market through open market operations, while the CNH Hong Kong Interbank Offered Rate benchmark reached 16.95%, its highest level in over three months. Analysts expect pressure on liquidity to remain due to a shrinking yuan pool and efforts by the Chinese authorities to control capital outflows ahead of the US President-Elect's inauguration.

site_title: Container vessel collision causes oil spill on Singapore-Malaysia border
