summary: A container vessel collision on the Singapore-Malaysia border caused a mid-sized oil spill, with nearly 300 tonnes released into the East Johor Straits. No injuries were reported, and 12 anti-pollution craft were deployed to clean up the spill, which was contained off the western side of Singapore's Pulau Ubin island. The collision occurred between the APL Denver and WAN HAI 301 vessels near Pasir Gudang Port in Johor, Malaysia.

site_title: Credit Suisse appoints new Singapore CEO, makes other management changes
summary: Credit Suisse appoints Benjamin Cavalli as its new Singapore CEO, replacing Lito Camacho. Cavalli will report to Francesco de Ferrari, head of Asia Pacific private banking. Tan Kuan Ern takes over Edwin Low as deputy Singapore CEO, while Jacky Ang is appointed branch manager and senior corporate officer. These changes come as Singapore remains a key hub for Credit Suisse's private banking and investment banking businesses in South-east Asia.

images.alt_text: In an announcement on Wednesday, the Swiss bank said that Benjamin Cavalli, head of Southeast Asia and head of Singapore for private banking, has been appointed as its Singapore CEO.

site_title: Forget Latin America, Asia is the biggest US LNG buyer
summary: Asia is becoming the largest US LNG buyer, with nine tankers leaving Cheniere Energy's Sabine Pass terminal in Louisiana since December 1 headed for Asian countries. This marks a significant shift from the US LNG market, which has historically been dominated by Latin American exports. The shift is driven by increased demand for heating and power-plant fuel in Asia due to winter's chill, fulfilling analysts' predictions that the region would become a major importer of US supply.

site_title: China credit engine is running out of gas as debt risk rises
summary: China's credit engine is slowing due to rising debt risks, with traditional financing and shadow banking expected to cool. The People's Bank of China is signaling tighter monetary policy to reduce risks, following a slowdown in economic expansion and rising inflation. The PBOC has cut language from its quarterly statement on reducing lending costs, and restrictions on property markets and bond market turbulence are expected to weigh on mortgage issuance and corporate issues. Policymakers aim to address these concerns and maintain economic stability.

site_title: China state banks step in to support yuan for second day
summary: China's central bank set a stronger-than-expected daily midpoint rate for the yuan, helping it inch up 0.1% against the US dollar despite global investors' concerns over the currency's value ahead of US President-elect Donald Trump's inauguration. State banks also sold US dollars, supporting the currency's trade. The yuan has lost 6.6% against the US dollar last year, prompting Beijing to intervene to stabilize it.

site_title: China: Stocks end higher as sentiment improves, liquidity fears ease
summary: China's stock market rallied, with the CSI300 index rising 0.8% to 3,368.31 points, and the Shanghai Composite Index gaining 0.7% to 3,158.79 points. Improving liquidity and moderating interest rates lifted market sentiment, with banks granting more loans after receiving fresh lending quotas. Growth stocks outperformed, with liquor maker Kweichow Moutai reaching a record high. Despite ending 2016 down 11%, the market has climbed 17% from its February trough.

site_title: Taiwan: Stocks hit two-week high; HTC jumps
summary: Taiwan's stocks reached a two-week high, with the main Taiex index closing at 9,287.38, a 0.2% gain. HTC Corp led the gains, jumping 4.4% in technology shares. The Taiwan dollar softened to NT$32.285 per US dollar. The electronics subindex rose 0.3%, while Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co gained 0.3%. The rally follows regional bourses and comes despite tariff uncertainty.

site_title: Global launch by Huawei of new mid-range smartphone
summary: Huawei has announced the global launch of its mid-range Honor 6x smartphone, featuring dual-lens camera technology, in 13 new markets including the US. The device will be available at a price of $249 to $299. The Honor 6x is a successor to the Honor 5x, which sold 11 million units last year, and is expected to sell even more.

site_title: China said to consider options to support yuan, curb outflows
summary: China is studying possible scenarios to support its yuan and curb capital outflows, amid pressure from a resurgent US dollar and concerns over US President-elect Donald Trump's trade policies. The country has used stress tests and models to prepare contingency plans, including ordering state-owned enterprises to convert foreign currency holdings into yuan. China may also sell US Treasuries to keep the yuan's exchange rate stable, with its currency stockpile expected to shrink further after hitting a five-year low in November, with capital outflows accelerating in recent months.

site_title: Smog-hit Beijing slapped with top "fog" alert for second day
summary: Beijing, China issued its highest red fog alert for the second consecutive day due to severe smog, with visibility of less than 50 meters in some areas. The alert prompted the closure of highways and the cancellation of flights at several airports. Over 2,000 tourists were stranded on a cruise ship near Tianjin due to the smog. The city's pollution alert is at the orange level, raising concerns among residents, and China's war on pollution efforts have shown little effect. Hebei province ordered polluting firms to shut down and plans to build the world's largest dust prevention barrier.

site_title: Malaysia floods force 23,000 to leave homes
summary: Malaysia's northeast states have been hit by severe floods, forcing nearly 23,000 people to evacuate their homes. Heavy rain over the past five days has caused 101 schools to close, and many roads are impassable. No deaths have been reported, but authorities have opened 139 relief centers providing food, drinks, and medical aid. The floods, which are a seasonal occurrence, are being closely monitored as a general election approaches, with Prime Minister Najib Razak expected to visit the affected areas to oversee evacuations.

images.alt_text: Floods in two northeast Malaysian states have now forced almost 23,000 people from their homes and extra relief centres have been opened, rescue officials said Wednesday.

site_title: Faraday Future unveils electric vehicle in Las Vegas to kick off CES
summary: Faraday Future unveiled its luxury electric SUV, the FF 91, at CES in Las Vegas, touting its technological advancements and modular architecture. The vehicle, set for production in early 2018, boasts a range of 608 km per charge and 1,050 horsepower. Advance reservations for the $180,000 car are being taken for $5,000, despite cash shortages and executive departures raising questions about the company's prospects. CEO Jia Yueting, also backing LeEco and Lucid Motors, aims to prove Faraday's legitimacy.

site_title: Australia dollar inches up on new China capital rules, NZ slips
summary: The Australian dollar rose 0.12% to US$0.7227, aided by China's tighter capital controls, while the New Zealand dollar slipped 0.28% to US$0.6895 due to weaker dairy prices. China's controls ease concerns of a repeat of last year's yuan meltdown, boosting the Aussie. The Aussie also rose against other currencies, including the yen, while the euro and pound slipped.

site_title: Power-to-people link seen costing India US$10b a year
summary: India plans to spend US$10 billion annually on new power transmission lines to meet growing demand in under-served areas, driven by Prime Minister Narendra Modi's goal of supplying affordable power to the whole country by 2019. The country lacks sufficient transmission infrastructure, and demand is being driven by rural electrification plans and the increasing focus on renewable power. The government and states are expected to spend about US$6 billion annually on transmission, with the rest coming from private companies like Sterlite Power Transmission Ltd.

site_title: Panama looks to talks with France to get off tax haven list
summary: Panama will hold talks with France to discuss its removal from the blacklist of tax havens, following its inclusion due to the Panama Papers leak. France had previously removed Panama in 2012 but reinstated it in April. Panama claims to have made progress in boosting transparency, but France demands stricter standards, including automatic tax information sharing and detailed offshore company registers. The talks aim to highlight Panama's efforts to improve its image and address French concerns.

site_title: Samsung's chip, screen sales to drive Q4 profit to 3-year high
summary: Samsung Electronics Co Ltd is expected to forecast its best quarterly profit in nearly three years, driven by robust memory chip sales and organic light-emitting diode screen sales. The company's operating profit is likely to rise to 8.4 trillion won (S$10 billion) in the October-December period, up 37% from a year ago. Memory chip prices have surged on demand for mobile devices, with Samsung's semiconductor profit expected to surge to a record 4.5 trillion won for the fourth quarter.

site_title: Obama moves to stop Trump gutting signature healthcare law
summary: US President Barack Obama is set to meet with Senate and House Democrats to discuss countering the Republican objective of repealing the Affordable Care Act, his signature healthcare reforms. This comes ahead of Trump's inauguration on January 20, when Republicans will hold majorities in both houses of Congress. The meeting is seen as a preemptive strike to stop Trump from gutting the healthcare law.

images.alt_text: US President Barack Obama will make a short but politically charged trip from the White House to Capitol Hill Wednesday, calling allied lawmakers to arms in defence of his signature healthcare reforms.

site_title: Former Exxon CEO Tillerson to cede control of US$240m in shares
summary: Former Exxon CEO Rex Tillerson will relinquish control of approximately $240 million in shares if confirmed as US Secretary of State. He will sell over 600,000 shares and transfer the value of 2 million deferred shares to an independently managed trust. Tillerson will also surrender $4.1 million in cash bonuses and about $7 million in lost compensation. The move aims to comply with conflict-of-interest requirements and avoid potential conflicts with Exxon, his former employer. His confirmation hearing may begin as soon as next week.

images.alt_text: Rex Tillerson, former Exxon Mobil Corp chief executive and President-elect Donald Trump's pick for US secretary of state, will relinquish control of about US$240 million in company shares if confirmed as he severs ties to comply with conflict-of-interest requirements.

site_title: Armed men storm prison in southern Philippines, freeing more than 150 inmates
summary: Armed men linked to the Moro Islamic Liberation Front (MILF) stormed the North Cotabato District Jail in the southern Philippines, killing a guard and freeing over 150 inmates. The escapees used blankets as a getaway method. Four inmates were recaptured, and a manhunt operation is underway. The incident occurred on January 4, 2017, in a region plagued by insurgencies, despite a 2014 peace deal between the government and the MILF.

site_title: Trump to hold press conference on Jan 11
summary: President-elect Donald Trump announced he will hold a press conference on January 11 in NYC to unveil plans to avoid conflict of interest between his business dealings and the White House, his first press conference since July.

site_title: Seoul: Won weakens slightly on US dollar strength; stocks shaky
summary: The South Korean won weakened 0.4% to 1,208.3 won per US dollar, as a stronger US dollar offset support from positive economic data from Asia's leading economies. Shares in South Korea were shaky, with the Kospi index little changed, while offshore investors purchased 58.6 billion won worth of Kospi shares. Web portal Naver Corp gained 3%, while chipmaker SK Hynix Inc lost 1.6%.

site_title: Debbie Reynolds, Carrie Fisher to get joint funeral
summary: Debbie Reynolds and her daughter Carrie Fisher, Star Wars legend, will be buried side by side at Forest Lawn Memorial Park in the Hollywood Hills. A private memorial service for family and close friends will take place on Thursday, with a possible public memorial event also being discussed. Reynolds, 84, died after a stroke on January 1, a day after Fisher's death from a heart attack. Fisher, 60, was a key figure in the original Star Wars trilogy and had a close relationship with her mother, which was documented in the upcoming HBO documentary Bright Lights: Starring Carrie Fisher and Debbie Reynolds.

site_title: Tech spending to slip in world of political uncertainty
summary: Global consumer technology spending is expected to slip to $929 billion in 2017 due to factors such as a strong US dollar and political uncertainty from Brexit and President-elect Donald Trump. The Consumer Technology Association forecasts that nearly half of the spending will go towards smartphones, accounting for 47% of device spending. The uncertainty will impact discretionary spending, business investment, and government investment, according to senior director of market research Steve Koenig.

site_title: Australia shares range-bound as commodities weaken; NZ hits near 5-wk high
summary: Australian shares remained range-bound on Wednesday, holding at 5,733.8 after a slight upside bias. Weaker commodity prices offset overnight gains from Wall Street, which rose sharply on Tuesday on expectations of Trump Administration stimulus. The S&P/ASX 200 index was up 0.6 points or 0.01% at 1245 GMT. Market strategist Michael McCarthy expects increased volatility this year, citing significant global risks despite a mostly positive outlook.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened higher on Wednesday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rising 3.450 points to 1638.980. Gainers outnumbered losers 89 to 49, with volume reaching 44.07 million lots worth RM10.42 million.

site_title: Hong Kong, Shanghai: Stocks flat at open
summary: Hong Kong and Shanghai stocks opened flat on Wednesday, following gains the previous day. The Hang Seng Index dipped 0.05% and the Shanghai Composite Index edged down 0.07%. However, the Shenzhen Composite Index rose 0.03%. The flat opening comes after a 5-day rally in Singapore stocks and a strong performance in the US, where the S&P 500 and Nasdaq reached fresh records despite ongoing trade uncertainty.

site_title: May's Brexit plans hit turbulence as UK envoy to EU quits
summary: UK Ambassador to the EU Ivan Rogers unexpectedly resigned, adding to confusion over Prime Minister Theresa May's Brexit planning. Rogers, appointed by David Cameron, was set to step down in November but will leave in mid-January. His departure raises concerns about the UK's ability to negotiate a smooth Brexit. May's Brexit plans have already faced challenges, and Rogers' resignation is the latest setback.

site_title: Qualcomm's newest smartphone chip aimed at PC breakthrough
summary: Qualcomm unveiled its latest smartphone chip, the Snapdragon 835, designed to enable thinner, more power-efficient handsets with larger batteries. The chip, made using the 10 nanometre manufacturing process, is the industry's most advanced. It's aimed not only at high-end smartphones but also at the PC market, marking Qualcomm's entry into the latter. The Snapdragon 835 will power thinner, more efficient devices, potentially disrupting the smartphone industry and expanding Qualcomm's product line.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares start 2017 on higher note
summary: Tokyo shares opened higher on the first trading day of 2017, following overnight US stock rises driven by optimism about the US economy. The benchmark Nikkei 225 index rose 0.96% or 184.31 points to 19,298.68, while the Topix index added 0.96% or 14.65 points to 1,533.26. This marked a positive start to the year, with investors returning after the new year break.

site_title: South Korea's finance minister says will press Korea's case if US makes 'irrational' trade demands
summary: South Korea's finance minister, Yoo Il Ho, vowed to vigorously argue the country's case if the US makes "irrational" trade demands. The government plans to strengthen communications with the US after Donald Trump's inauguration and promote the economy by meeting with global investors next week. The minister emphasized the need to improve regulations to facilitate the fourth industrial revolution, despite potential US trade demands.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Jumbo Group, Genting Singapore, Midas Holdings, Kitchen Culture, ISR Capital
summary: Jumbo Group entered its first franchise agreement in Vietnam, granting rights to operate Jumbo Seafood restaurants in Ho Chi Minh City and Danang. Genting Singapore disposed of its stake in a South Korean integrated resort for US$411.1 million. Midas Holdings secured two metro train car supply contracts worth S$369 million. Kitchen Culture plans to raise up to US$20 million through convertible notes. ISR Capital's CEO Quah Su-Yin ceased to be CEO and executive director to focus on family business.

site_title: Tsunami threat passes after 7.2-magnitude quake off Fiji
summary: A 7.2-magnitude earthquake struck off Fiji's coast, triggering a tsunami warning but later lifted. The quake, 15km deep, had no reported damage, and residents felt a slight shake. The Pacific Tsunami Warning Centre initially reported hazardous waves but later stated the threat had passed. Geoscience Australia said structural damage was possible only within an 110km radius, far from land. The area is on the Pacific "Ring of Fire", a highly active tectonic zone prone to earthquakes and volcanic eruptions.

site_title: BlackRock sees shift to emerging-market bonds resuming in 2017
summary: BlackRock's Sergio Trigo Paz and Pablo Goldberg predict emerging-market bonds will resume their "great migration" in 2017, driven by improving fundamentals and low global yields compared to pension liabilities. Despite rising US interest rates and potential trade curbs, they forecast emerging-market sovereign debt to return over 4% in 2017, reversing the 3.4% losses since Donald Trump's election. The duo attributes the appeal of emerging-market debt to negative yields in developed economies and expects money to pour into emerging-market bond funds, despite headwinds for developing nations.

site_title: Chrysler's new tech-rich concept car aims young
summary: Fiat-Chrysler unveiled the Chrysler Portal concept car, a tech-rich, electric-powered minivan designed for Millennials. The vehicle features a modular "third space" that can be adapted for passengers or cargo, and can operate in semi-autonomous mode. It uses sensors and facial recognition to monitor conditions and customize settings. The car is designed to grow with the user, with features such as interchangeable seats and LED lighting that can change colors. Production plans have not been announced, but the vehicle is expected to incorporate emerging safety technologies and partner with companies like Adient and Panasonic Automotive.

site_title: China jails former drug regulatory official for taking bribes
summary: A former Chinese official, Yin Hongzhang, was sentenced to 10 years in prison and fined 500,000 yuan for taking bribes from vaccine manufacturers in exchange for approval and speed-up of approvals for vaccines. Yin accepted 3.56 million yuan in bribes from 2002 to 2015, including gifts such as ivory products. His wife and son also received prison sentences for their involvement. The sentencing comes amid China's ongoing campaign against corruption, led by President Xi Jinping, following a 2016 scandal involving illegal vaccines.

site_title: Wall Street lawyer Jay Clayton emerges as Trump's top SEC choice
summary: Jay Clayton, a Wall Street lawyer, is a leading candidate to head the US Securities and Exchange Commission in the Trump administration. Clayton, a partner at Sullivan & Cromwell, specializes in public and private mergers and offerings, requiring expertise in securities regulations and corporate governance. He has worked on high-profile initial public offerings, including Alibaba Group. Clayton's nomination is subject to confirmation by the Senate.

site_title: Qualcomm to invest in SoftBank's new technology fund, WSJ says
summary: Qualcomm plans to invest in SoftBank's $100 billion technology fund, joining Apple Inc, which has also considered investing $1 billion. SoftBank CEO Masayoshi Son pledged to create 50,000 new US jobs with the fund. The fund has gathered $100 billion in commitments and is set to formally launch in the coming weeks.

site_title: North Korea nuclear threat Trump's first challenge
summary: US President-elect Donald Trump has taken a hardline stance against North Korea's pursuit of a nuclear-tipped missile capable of hitting the US mainland, with Kim Jong-Un announcing plans to test launch an intercontinental ballistic missile. Trump vowed to halt Pyongyang's progress, sparking concerns about limited diplomatic options and the possibility of war. The US military has stepped up planning for any eventual operation, while China, a key player, opposes stronger measures that might destabilize its neighbor. Experts fear a pre-emptive war, but some argue the pursuit of nuclear missiles is a strategic choice to deter aggression.

site_title: Janet Jackson gives birth to son at age 50
summary: Janet Jackson, 50, gave birth to her first child, a son named Eissa, on January 3, 2017. The singer had a "stress-free" delivery and is resting comfortably. This marks a significant milestone for Jackson, who had kept her pregnancy private and was 50 years old, making natural pregnancies highly unusual for women past their mid-40s.

site_title: Singapore shares open 2.7 points higher on Wednesday
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index rose 2.74 points, or 0.09%, to 2,901.71 at 9:02am on Wednesday, with 34.7 million shares changing hands. The three major banks on the index, DBS, OCBC Bank, and UOB, all opened higher.

site_title: Oil dives 2%, strong US dollar knocks crude off 18-month high
summary: Oil prices slid 2% on the first trading day of 2017, knocking off 18-month highs, due to a strong US dollar and profit-taking. US oil prices fell to $52.33 a barrel, while Brent futures dropped to $55.47 a barrel. The US dollar's rally to its highest level since 2002 and WTI hitting $55 a barrel contributed to the decline. A deal between Opec and other big oil exporters to cut production, which kicked in on Sunday, had previously pushed oil prices to their highest levels since July 2015.

site_title: US dollar hits 14-year highs after strong US manufacturing data
summary: The US dollar reached a 14-year high against major currencies after strong US manufacturing data showed a two-year high in factory activity and construction spending at a 10-1/2 year high in November. The dollar index rose to 103.820, its highest level since December 2002, with analysts expecting increased interest rate tightening from the Federal Reserve and a rosier outlook for the US economy. The euro fell to a 14-year low against the US dollar, while the yen and Mexican peso also declined against the dollar.

site_title: Oil prices edge up as US dollar retreats from 14-year high
summary: Oil prices edged up on Wednesday, recovering from losses after the US dollar retreated from a 14-year high. US West Texas Intermediate crude oil futures rose 25 cents, or 0.5%, to $52.58 per barrel. The increase is attributed to a decline in the US dollar, making dollar-traded fuel purchases cheaper. Analysts expect the dollar to remain strong, but a potential cut in Opec crude supplies and rising official selling prices in Saudi Arabia could contribute to a tightening market.

site_title: Israeli government said to oppose China purchase of insurers
summary: Israel's Finance Ministry opposes a Chinese company's bid to buy insurance company Phoenix Holdings Ltd due to concerns over managing pension funds. The government is hesitant to put pension money in the hands of Chinese investors with unclear track records. This stance could hinder Fujian Yango Group Co's bid and affect other financial assets held by Israeli companies. The government is more inclined to approve Chinese investments in industrial assets, where pension money is not at risk.

site_title: McDonald's opens near Vatican, upsetting some purists
summary: McDonald's has opened a franchise near the Vatican, sparking outrage among some purists due to its presence in a historically significant area. The restaurant, located behind St Peter's Basilica, was met with criticism from Cardinal Elio Sgreccia, who deemed it a "disgrace" to Roman gastronomic traditions. However, some locals welcomed the new arrival, citing its potential to boost the local economy. The restaurant was fully adapted to respect the historical environment, and its location is outside the Vatican, on Holy See property.

site_title: Swim or sink outlook prompts Asia shipping lines to face mergers
summary: Asia's shipping lines face a "swim or sink" outlook as they navigate a prolonged trade slowdown and depressed freight rates. Mega mergers are expected to continue, with companies like Maersk and Hyundai Merchant Marine cutting costs and improving efficiency. The industry's capacity crisis, fueled by overly optimistic trade forecasts, has led to a decline in freight rates and losses. Experts predict a possible merger between Taiwanese shipping companies or a buyout of Hyundai Merchant to reduce competition and improve profitability.

site_title: Asia's richest families are abandoning 'complacent' hedge funds
summary: Asia's richest families are shifting away from hedge funds, with some firms experiencing redemptions at a four-year high. Disappointed with mediocre returns and high fees, wealthy families are instead investing in private equity and technology companies. The trend is more pronounced in Asia, where family offices set aggressive performance goals. Hedge funds in the region are facing significant outflows, with $1.6 billion withdrawn through November, as they struggle to compete with other asset classes. The shift is expected to further destabilize the region's hedge fund industry.

site_title: China's Sogou targets US$5b IPO to chase rival Baidu
summary: China's Sogou search engine plans to hold a US$5 billion initial public offering (IPO) to raise funds and close the gap with leader Baidu in the mobile market. The company aims to improve search results by backing artificial intelligence and machine-learning technologies. Sogou's CEO, Wang Xiaochuan, expects the company to match Baidu in mobile search within three years. The IPO will be held this year, with about 10% of shares to be sold, and is seen as a strategic move to boost the company's market share in the face of a scandal affecting Baidu.

site_title: EU regulators delay ChemChina/Syngenta merger decision to April 12
summary: European Union regulators have delayed a decision on ChemChina's proposed $43 billion acquisition of Syngenta by 10 working days to April 12. The European Commission initiated an in-depth investigation in October, citing concerns over the deal. ChemChina and Syngenta have asked for the extension to discuss remedy proposals, stating they remain committed to the transaction. The companies had initially expected a decision by January 13.

site_title: Europe: Shares rally as FTSE starts 2017 by setting record high
summary: European stocks rallied on Tuesday, with the FTSE 100 reaching a record high, driven by gains in financials, commodity-related stocks, and Italian banks. The Stoxx 600 closed 0.7% higher, while the basic resources sector and oil & gas saw significant gains. Banks benefited from concerns about a tighter regulatory environment being pushed back, and Italian banks, such as Banco BPM, surged. The rally was also boosted by a deal to sell London Stock Exchange's French clearing business to Euronext.

site_title: Rough start for US Republicans on first day of Trump-era Congress
summary: The US Republican-led Congress had a rough start on its first session of the Donald Trump era, overshadowed by a public outcry over weakening an ethics watchdog. The House of Representatives had planned to defang the Office of Congressional Ethics, but President-elect Trump tweeted his disapproval, prompting lawmakers to backtrack. Despite this, Trump is set to move swiftly on his agenda, including tax reform, repealing Obamacare, and rolling back regulations. The Senate, controlled by Republicans, has not addressed Obamacare, while Democrats warn of a fierce battle over the issue.

site_title: Indonesia penalises JPMorgan for negative report in latest emerging markets skirmish
summary: Indonesia has penalized JPMorgan Chase & Co for a negative report on the country, cutting ties with the bank as a primary bond dealer and revoking its special designation. The move follows a similar controversy in Brazil, where JPMorgan downgraded its investment recommendation on Indonesian stocks to "underweight" from "overweight". The bank's research analysts cited higher risk premiums for emerging markets after Donald Trump's US presidential election victory. Indonesia's finance minister stated that JPMorgan's analysis "did not make sense" and that the bank needs to maintain stability in the country.

site_title: Canadian fintechs shine as investments near record
summary: Canadian fintech companies received a record $137.7 million in venture capital investment in 2016, a 35% increase from the previous year. This is the highest level of investment in Canadian fintech since 2000. In contrast, investments in the US and UK declined by at least 30% and 25% respectively. The growth in Canadian fintech investment is attributed to the country's supportive startup environment, low costs, and cluster of universities producing engineers and developers. Foreign investors, including Lightspeed Venture Partners and Goldman Sachs, are also taking note of the Canadian fintech scene.

site_title: US: Stocks begin 2017 with gains
summary: US stocks began 2017 with gains, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average up 0.6% to 19,881.76, the S&P 500 up 0.9% to 2,257.83, and the Nasdaq Composite Index up 0.9% to 5,429.08. Analysts attributed the optimism to expected tax cuts, regulatory reform, and initiatives under the Trump administration. Key stocks, such as Ford and pharmaceutical companies Merck and Biogen, also saw gains, while restaurant shares fell due to predictions of stagnant traffic in 2017.

site_title: Errant drones get in crosshairs of startups
summary: A surge in consumer drone sales has spawned a counter-industry of startups, developing techniques to disable or knock out unwanted drones that can be used for smuggling, spying, or violating privacy. Dozens of firms are working on methods such as deploying birds of prey or using gas to take down drones, with some aiming to deploy anti-drone systems in public spaces.

site_title: ANZ sells Shanghai bank stake in latest move to unwind Asia expansion
summary: ANZ Banking Corp has agreed to sell its 20% stake in Shanghai Rural Commercial Bank Co for A$1.84 billion, marking the bank's latest move to unwind its Asian expansion and simplify its business. The sale will increase ANZ's Tier 1 capital ratio by about 40 basis points, allowing the bank to focus on its Asian institutional business. This deal follows previous sales of retail and wealth management businesses in Asia and is part of ANZ CEO Shayne Elliott's strategy to improve capital efficiency.

site_title: Greek justice minister vows speedy corruption inquiry
summary: Greece's justice minister, Stavos Kontonis, vowed a "swift and thorough" investigation into suspected corruption by civil servants and Swiss pharmaceutical giant Novartis. The inquiry follows denunciations of bribes paid to functionaries by Novartis, with around 178 people questioned and anti-corruption prosecutors gathering evidence. A Novartis manager attempted suicide on New Year's Day, and the company has cooperated with authorities. The investigation is the latest in a series of corruption probes in Greece, with the US Justice Department previously fining Novartis $390 million for bribes in 2014.

site_title: A nice new-year present, but headwinds ahoy
summary: Singapore's economy delivered a 1.8% year-on-year growth in the fourth quarter, beating forecasts and exceeding the government's 1-1.5% projection. However, this growth is largely attributed to the manufacturing sector, which expanded by 6.5% but was concentrated in two clusters. The services sector and construction sector showed slower growth, raising concerns about the sustainability of this growth. External factors, including US protectionism and China's economic slowdown, could impact Singapore's economy, making it challenging to sustain growth. The government will need to focus on policy adjustments, including reducing business costs, improving access to skills, and incentivizing companies to internationalize.

site_title: S'pore in prime position to be China's partner
summary: China is positioning Singapore as a key partner in its Belt and Road Initiative, aiming to strengthen regional economic ties despite global protectionism concerns. The initiative, launched in 2013, focuses on infrastructure development and trade. China's roadmap for global economic growth emphasizes coordination, structural reform, and improved multilateral trade and investment. The partnership will extend beyond the Singapore-Malaysia high-speed rail link, with Singapore seen as an important hub for Chinese trade and investment in South-east Asia.

site_title: VW faces first legal test case over emissions in Germany
summary: Volkswagen faces its first legal test case in Germany over emissions, filed by consumer rights champion myRight, which claims the carmaker breached EU law by selling cars with banned software. MyRight, which has gathered over 100,000 affected owners, is seeking to force VW to repurchase the vehicles at the original price, rather than compensation for a decline in value. This case aims to act as a model for other related cases, and Hausfeld, a US law firm, is pursuing the claims on behalf of the affected owners.

images.alt_text: German consumer rights champion myRight filed the first legal test case against Volkswagen in Germany on Tuesday, raising pressure on the carmaker to compensate customers in Europe over the emissions scandal.

site_title: Vietnam Airlines valued at US$2.1b after shares soar 40% on debut
summary: Vietnam Airlines' shares soared 40% on their debut, valuing the firm at US$2.1 billion, as investors sought exposure to the South-east Asian nation's strong air travel growth. The airline is 86% owned by the government, with limited shares available for trading. A strong stock market showing could benefit the government's stake divestment plan, which aims to sell off its holdings in state firms. This growth follows Vietnam's airline market, which is expanding at one of the fastest rates in the Asia-Pacific region.

site_title: Malaysia's factory output slump continues its run amid rising costs
summary: Malaysia's factory output continues its slump, with nearly two years of depressed production due to declining demand. Higher materials costs, largely attributed to the weak ringgit, exacerbate the issue. The country's manufacturing sector faces significant challenges, with no clear end in sight.

images.alt_text: Malaysian manufacturers are not in a good place.

site_title: Midas JV firm wins 2 contracts worth 1.77b yuan
summary: Midas Holdings, a Singapore-based company, announced that its joint venture company, CRRC Nanjing Puzhen Rail Transport Co Ltd (NPRT), has secured two metro train car supply contracts worth 1.77 billion yuan. The contracts, valued at 1.05 billion yuan and 720 million yuan, were awarded for two projects in China and are expected to contribute positively to Midas' financial performance for the 2018-2019 fiscal years.

site_title: Melbourne is having a shitty beach season
summary: Melbourne's beaches are facing a pollution crisis due to heavy rains that have caused faecal contamination in Port Phillip Bay. The Environment Protection Authority has advised against swimming at 21 beaches due to poor water quality. The pollution is attributed to rivers, creeks, and drains overflowing with sewage. This threatens the annual beach pilgrimage during Melbourne's summer season, raising concerns about public health and water safety.

site_title: Wall St eyes Fed minutes for light on rate outlook, fiscal policy risks
summary: The Federal Reserve's minutes from its December meeting, scheduled for release on Wednesday, are expected to provide insight into the central bank's interest rate outlook and fiscal policy risks. The minutes may indicate that officials are considering additional rate hikes in 2017 without significantly upgrading their economic forecasts. The release comes as investors and economists await guidance on the timing of the next policy move, which is likely to be less revealing than expected. The minutes are expected to provide some clarity on the Fed's stance, but the details are expected to be limited.

site_title: Tesla deliveries miss forecast on production delays; shares fall
summary: Tesla reported 22,200 vehicle deliveries in the fourth quarter, short of its forecast of 25,000 units, sending shares lower. Production delays, including challenges with the Autopilot system, contributed to the shortfall. The company's full-year total of 76,230 vehicles fell below its guidance of at least 80,000 units. Elon Musk urged workers to deliver every car possible, but the Model 3's delayed production, expected in late 2017, may be contributing to softening demand for the Model S.

site_title: Firms clock 5-year low in 2016 for promptness in paying bills
summary: Singaporean firms experienced a 5-year low in 2016 for promptness in paying bills, with only 45.87% of total bills paid on time. Slow payments accounted for more than half of total transactions, with the construction sector leading the way. Payment performance improved slightly in the fourth quarter compared to the third quarter, but still deteriorated year-over-year. Factors contributing to the poor performance included bad debts in the construction sub-sector and weak trading activities in the wholesale sector.

site_title: High volatility + low returns = the 'new normal'
summary: Financial markets are expected to experience high volatility and low returns in 2017 due to uncertainty over US economic policy under Donald Trump's administration and rising geopolitical risk. The prospect of faster-than-expected US interest rate hikes amid a slowing global economy will cap upside for many asset classes. Investment professionals recognize the need for active management, with 73% of institutional firms surveying at the end of 2016 agreeing that the current market environment favors active management. The Trump administration's "America first" policies, including heavily taxing imports, pose significant uncertainty and potential for a trade war with China.

site_title: Fashion forward
summary: Two fashion brands are leading the industry, leaving global footprints despite rapid changes and competition. The article does not provide further details on the brands.

site_title: Solar trounces coal as cheapest form of power
summary: Solar power has become cheaper than coal in some parts of the world, with deals to generate electricity from sunshine for less than three cents a kilowatt-hour. In 2016, countries like Chile and the UAE broke records with these deals. Saudi Arabia, Jordan, and Mexico are now planning auctions to drop prices further. Economies of scale and technology advancements are driving this trend, making solar power the likely lowest-cost option almost everywhere in less than a decade.

site_title: Are you ready?
summary: Singapore's Small and Medium-sized Enterprises (SMEs) face changes in accounting for leases under FRS 116, potentially affecting those who own or lease premises. Meanwhile, a specialist healthcare centre is set to open in Tokyo or Osaka after Japan's Sojitz takes control. Researchers at NUS aim to halve the price of sustainable marine fuel. In other news, Hao Mart's Taste Orchard struggles with poor footfall, vacant units, and OCBC targets S$5 billion in loans for serial entrepreneurs by 2028. Shatec shuts its Orchard campus and training restaurant, cutting 42 staff.

site_title: Trump risks throwing the baby out with the bathwater
summary: US President-elect Donald Trump's inauguration may lead to increased short-term thinking in economic policymaking, potentially harming long-term goals. This approach, driven by a private-sector background, may prioritize speed and quick deals over institution building and long-term policies. If unchecked, it could result in short-term gains being lost in the long run, as seen in past examples of protectionism and tax cuts without accompanying revenue increases. Credible, independent central banks and transparent procurement processes have proven to be valuable assets in promoting long-term thinking.

site_title: Evergrande to raise 30b yuan for its Shenzhen backdoor listing
summary: Evergrande Group plans to raise 30 billion yuan (S$6.3 billion) by selling 13.16% of its enlarged shares in a property subsidiary to eight investors. This is part of its Shenzhen backdoor listing plan, aiming to boost valuation and raise funds. The deal will dilute Evergrande's shareholding to 86.84% and will be used to repay debt, develop projects, and maintain working capital. The listing is expected to increase Evergrande's market value to $33.7 billion, making it easier for the company to raise funds amid heavy debt.

site_title: Big stars and bigger money fail to revive China's box office sales
summary: China's box office sales slowed to 3.7% growth in 2016, the weakest pace since 2008, with December ticket receipts falling 3.9% to 4.06 billion yuan. Despite the release of high-profile films like The Great Wall and See You Tomorrow, box office growth was underwhelming, with critics and fans showing selectivity. This trend has dragged down shares of exhibitors, with Wanda Cinema Line Co sliding 55% in 2016. The market is expected to face a challenging quarter due to the previous year's hit film, The Mermaid.

site_title: Record US$375b moved to ETFs in 2016: BlackRock
summary: US investors funneled a record $375 billion into exchange-traded funds (ETFs) in 2016, according to BlackRock Inc. This surpasses the $348 billion invested in 2015 and includes a record $286 billion in the US market. The surge in ETF investments is attributed to low management fees and cost savings, driving assets away from rival financial products, including actively managed funds. This trend is also seen in the growth of "smart beta" products, which attempt to beat the market using rules-based investment strategies.

site_title: Going against the grain in managing assets
summary: Dimensional Fund Advisors (DFA) has maintained a strong track record of historical returns and a loyal following by sticking to a solid philosophy of low costs and factor-based investing. Founded in 1981, the US-based firm has generated significant assets, currently managing $445 billion, through a passive approach to markets. Co-founder David Booth attributes the firm's success to its ability to avoid making drastic changes to its investment strategy, despite market fluctuations, and its focus on empirical research to inform investment decisions. DFA's approach has become mainstream, with low-cost vehicles gaining popularity in the industry.

site_title: Court says UOB infringed patent, but rejects bulk of remedial claims
summary: A 12-year patent infringement case between Singapore's United Overseas Bank (UOB) and Irish currency conversion provider Main-Line Corporate Holdings was resolved with a court ruling. UOB was found to have infringed Main-Line's patent for a currency conversion system, but escaped the full extent of claims. The court awarded Main-Line S$4.795 million in damages from FCC, a Singapore company that had also infringed the patent. UOB was found liable for S$1.962 million in commissions, with the majority of the damages awarded to FCC.

site_title: China imposes extra forex rules on citizens to stem capital flight
summary: China has introduced new rules to curb capital flight, requiring citizens to provide detailed information under bank forms when converting yuan into foreign currencies. The rules, effective January 1, include pledges to use funds for legitimate purposes and confirm compliance with anti-money laundering and tax evasion restrictions. Violators will face penalties, including being added to a watch-list and denied foreign exchange quotas for three years. The move aims to stem a significant outflow of US$689 billion in the first 10 months of 2016, amid a steep annual slump in the yuan.

images.alt_text: China's currency regulator has warned citizens of potential risks from investing in foreign assets, adding that yuan deposit rates are higher than overseas equivalents.

site_title: Thank tiny bugs and China's hungry pigs for agriculture winners
summary: Agriculture investors had a mixed year in 2016, with orange juice and soya bean complex being the biggest winners, with price gains of 34% and 12% respectively. US exports to China surged, driving up demand for soya beans. In contrast, cocoa and wheat saw significant losses, with cocoa tumbling 34% and wheat futures falling 13%. Despite a lacklustre year, Goldman Sachs predicts gains for 2017, citing rising demand and low commodity prices.

site_title: Mermaid cancels US$298m rig order
summary: Mermaid Maritime has cancelled a $298 million construction order for two drilling rigs due to the depressed oil and gas market. The order was placed with China Merchants Industry Holdings, with Mermaid having paid a $44 million pre-installment. The rigs will be retained by China Merchants, but Mermaid has the right to buy them back at the original price. This move comes after Mermaid recorded an asset impairment on the pre-paid instalment in its 2015 financial statements.

site_title: Beauty in the eye of the beholder
summary: Karine Estelle Cheong, founder of local skincare brand Klarity, aims to change the perception of Singaporean beauty products. After struggling in her first two years of entrepreneurship, Cheong realized the need for innovative, affordable skincare products. She developed Klarity, a functional skincare line with multiple benefits in one product, catering to busy Singaporeans. Despite initial challenges, the company has grown and is now expanding into China's domestic market, with a focus on halal standard formulations to tap into the Muslim consumer market.

site_title: Ex-Apple employees revamp its culture at new high-tech startup
summary: Ex-Apple employee Brian Latimer has founded a new high-tech startup in California, focusing on revamping the culture of innovation and secrecy. Latimer, who previously oversaw the protection of Apple's secrets, aims to create a similar environment at his new venture. The company's mission is to foster a culture that encourages innovation and collaboration while maintaining confidentiality and security. Latimer's experience at Apple has provided him with the expertise to create a similar system for tracking and managing prototypes, ensuring the success of his new startup.

images.alt_text: Employees of Pearl Automation socialising during a casual lunch meeting at its California headquarters. Founded and staffed by ex-Apple employees, Pearl makes high-tech accessories for cars.

site_title: UOB reaches out to millennials to spend, save and invest
summary: UOB is targeting millennials in Singapore to bank with one in two millennials by 2019. The bank has introduced a service to channel interest from One Account savings and rebates from YOLO credit card spending into a low-volatility fund, reducing upfront fees and minimum investment requirements. The move aims to lower resistance to investing and make it easier for young affluent millennials to start saving for investments. UOB's millennial customer base already accounts for 20% of total card spend and 67% have a UOB current or savings account.

site_title: TPG Telecom has to juggle capex between Singapore and Australia
summary: Australian telco TPG Telecom has won the right to be Singapore's fourth telco, beating MyRepublic with a bid of S$105 million for 60MHz of spectrum. The 18-month window allows TPG to roll out island-wide services, with a forecasted spend of S$200-300 million. Despite paying three times the reserve price, analysts believe the quality of the spectrum is high, and the bid is in line with market prices. TPG plans to fund the network rollout from existing debt facilities and cash from its Australian operations, with a focus on broadband services and potential bundle plans with mobile services.

site_title: Right to disconnect from work e-mail and other laws take effect in France
summary: France has implemented several new laws, including a "right to disconnect" from work-related emails outside of work hours, a streamlined divorce process, and stricter regulations on tobacco packaging, plastic bags, and pesticides. The "right to disconnect" requires companies with over 50 employees to negotiate a protocol to prevent work from spilling into personal time. Other new laws include labeling requirements for prepared foods made with French ingredients and a ban on thin plastic bags. The country also aims to reduce its environmental impact with the ban on pesticides in public areas.

site_title: Britain to build 17 towns to ease housing squeeze
summary: Britain's government plans to build 17 new towns and villages across the English countryside to ease a chronic housing shortage. The "garden" communities, including 3 newly announced towns, will provide up to 200,000 new homes. The government aims to loosen planning restrictions and provide £7.4 million in funding to support the development. The new towns, which will have 1,500-10,000 properties, will be built near Aylesbury, Taunton, and Harlow, among other locations.

site_title: UK courts' Brexit ruling could nudge May into snap polls
summary: The UK Supreme Court is set to rule on whether the government needs an act of Parliament to trigger Article 50 and commence formal EU exit negotiations. A potential landmark decision could lead to a "softer Brexit" if Parliament gets involved in the process, potentially blocking a hard Brexit. If the court rules that legislation is needed, it could delay triggering Article 50, give Parliament a vote on the final deal, and increase the chances of a softer Brexit. The ruling could also prompt Prime Minister Theresa May to consider a snap election in 2017 to secure a mandate for her Brexit strategy.

site_title: Electronics, biomed clusters spur Q4 manufacturing growth
summary: Singapore's manufacturing sector expanded 6.5% year-on-year in Q4 2016, driven by the electronics and biomedical clusters, according to the Ministry of Trade and Industry. However, transport engineering and general manufacturing continued to contract. The sector's growth is expected to moderate in the first quarter of 2017, with economists attributing the strong showing to external factors rather than sustainable growth. The services sector also saw growth, with a 0.6% year-on-year expansion, while the construction sector declined 2.8% due to cooling measures and market sentiments.

site_title: Not good enough
summary: Singapore is establishing a centre to advance sustainable aviation in Asia-Pacific. The government also announced plans for DPM Gan to visit the US for trade talks, and a new grant of up to S$100,000 for businesses hit by tariffs. Additionally, a study suggests Singapore has the potential to become a global hub for advanced chip packaging. Experts advise graduates to stay calm despite early data showing better employment rates, while workers are encouraged to future-proof their careers before a crisis strikes. The government is also providing assistance for training workers with limited resources.

site_title: Business as usual, for now
summary: Singapore SMEs can breathe a sigh of relief as the consolidation of industrial space between Housing Development Board (HDB) and JTC Corporation is expected to be business as usual, with no immediate changes in rental costs or property policies. Existing leases and contracts will remain unchanged, and about 160 HDB officers will transfer to JTC to ensure minimal disruptions during the transition. Analysts predict that rents are unlikely to rise unreasonably, and the consolidation is intended to benefit SMEs by providing a one-stop government channel for industrial space needs and better support for growth and competitiveness.

site_title: France to launch inaugural 'green' bond this month
summary: France plans to launch its first "green" bond by the end of January, aiming to make Paris a center for financing environmentally friendly projects. This move follows France's role as the host of the 2015 Paris Agreement to combat global warming. The government hopes to be the first sovereign borrower to venture into the growing green bond market, demonstrating its commitment to environmentally friendly financing.

site_title: Going a month without sugar for better health
summary: A month-long elimination of added sugars can lead to permanent changes in eating habits, according to a writer who has done so in the past two years. Research suggests that an overabundance of simple carbohydrates, particularly sugar, is the No. 1 problem in modern diets. Cutting out added sugar can reduce the risk of diabetes, obesity, and other health issues. The writer recommends a 30-day sugar-free challenge, eliminating added sugars from all products, and relearning how a diet without sweeteners tastes.

site_title: Changing times
summary: Singapore's next-generation industrial facilities are being built and redeveloped with shared infrastructure and services to meet changing business needs. A specialist centre, Royal Healthcare, is set to open in Tokyo or Osaka after Japan's Sojitz takes control. Researchers at NUS are working on a startup to halve the price of sustainable marine fuel. Meanwhile, some businesses are struggling, such as Hao Mart's Taste Orchard, which is facing poor footfall and vacant units. OCBC aims to provide S$5 billion in loans to serial entrepreneurs by 2028, while Shatec shuts its Orchard campus and puts a building up for sale.

site_title: Greenback racks up biggest rise in 2 weeks
summary: The US dollar experienced its largest two-week gain in 2017, rising to within 1% of its December highs in London's European trading. This surge was partly driven by a bullish survey of manufacturing purchasing managers in China, which also boosted the Australian dollar. The yuan remained stable in its offshore markets.

site_title: Swiss firm in S$35m vote of confidence for Singapore specialty chemicals sector
summary: Bertschi, a Swiss specialty chemical logistics firm, is investing S$35 million to build a second facility on Jurong Island in Singapore, expanding its services and workforce to 100 employees. The new facility will cater to the growing demand for specialty chemicals in the region, with Singapore's government pushing to develop the sector. Bertschi expects to operate at full capacity by the fourth quarter of this year, driven by a strong sales pipeline and increasing demand from the chemical industry.

site_title: New York still the apple of foreign property investors' eyes: survey
summary: New York maintained its position as the top choice among foreign investors in commercial real estate, ranking as the prime US city for the seventh consecutive year and the top global city for the third year. Washington dropped to No 15, marking the first time it fell out of the top five US cities. The Association of Foreign Investors in Real Estate (AFIRE) conducted the survey, which found New York's enduring appeal among foreign investors.

site_title: Q4 growth beats forecasts, but fails to stir economists
summary: Singapore's economy experienced a strong 1.8% growth in Q4 2016, beating forecasts, but economists say this is not a sustainable indicator. The growth is largely driven by manufacturing, which may not last, and the services sector is in poor health. Economists are calling for fiscal and monetary easing to support the economy, citing external challenges such as rising protectionism and global uncertainty. While the strong data may give the central bank some time to make policy decisions, economists warn that the domestic economy may be dislocated from a global pick-up, and policy support is needed to prop up growth.

site_title: US tech acquisitions: Old-school giants join fray
summary: Industrial giants such as General Motors and General Electric are acquiring tech startups, reflecting the impact of new technology on traditional businesses. In 2016, non-tech companies made over $125 billion in acquisitions, a record high. This trend shows how technology is disrupting industries, with companies like Walmart, Roper Technologies, and Daimler investing in e-commerce, software, and ride-hailing applications. The number of tech companies acquired by non-tech companies surpassed those acquired by tech companies for the first time since the Internet era began, according to data compiled by Bloomberg.

site_title: HDB resale prices stabilising, with 0.1% dip in Q4
summary: Singapore's HDB resale prices have stabilized, with a 0.1% dip in Q4 2016, resulting in a 0.1% full-year decline. Experts attribute this to effective cooling measures, with prices expected to remain stable or show a small increase in the second half of 2017. However, prices of larger HDB flats may still come under pressure due to declining private property prices, with more owners considering upgrading to private addresses.

site_title: STI kicks off 2017 on firm note in thin trade
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) began 2017 on a positive note, rising 18.21 points to 2,898.97, driven by a 120-point surge in Dow futures and jumps in the Jardine group. Trading was relatively quiet, with 1.8 billion units worth S$798 million changing hands. Analysts predict a challenging year for Singapore's economy, with forecasts including a decline in GDP growth rate and a slowdown in export growth. Despite this, some analysts remain optimistic, citing potential for small upside in the market and individual stocks, with Raffles Medical and CapitaCommercial Trust among their top picks.

site_title: Singapore Budget on Feb 20
summary: Singapore's budget will be delivered on February 20 by Minister for Finance Heng Swee Keat, marking a key event in the country's fiscal planning. The budget will be live-streamed on the Ministry of Finance's website and other media platforms. This news comes as global economic trends continue to evolve, with concerns over US tariffs, China's slowing GDP, and the UK economy's contraction. The Singaporean government will likely address these issues in its budget statement.

site_title: Majority shareholder vote saves APW from wind-up
summary: AIMS Property Securities Fund (APW) will not be wound up after a majority shareholder vote saved the fund. AIMS Capital Management, with a 38% stake, successfully voted against the motion, with 46.24% of unitholders rejecting the motion. The move was initiated by minority investors unhappy with the fund's trading discount and fees. The fund's chairman, George Wang, stated that the majority of unitholders endorsed the fund's strategy and intend to continue managing its assets, focusing on value-add opportunities to grow its net asset value.

site_title: Ex-Deutsche Bank chief to join Cantor Fitzgerald as president
summary: Ex-Deutsche Bank chief Anshu Jain is set to join Cantor Fitzgerald as group president, 18 months after stepping down from Deutsche due to regulatory concerns. Jain, 53, will oversee Cantor's various businesses and provide strategic insights, becoming a partner to CEO Howard Lutnick. The appointment comes as Cantor expands its global footprint and drives momentum. Jain's return to the finance industry follows his three-year tenure as Deutsche's leader, marked by setbacks and damaging reputations.

site_title: Australian home values rise the most in 7 years on low rates
summary: Australian house values increased by 10.9% in 2016, the largest rise in seven years, driven by record-low interest rates. Despite warnings of unsustainable price increases, the Reserve Bank of Australia's rate cuts boosted the housing market. However, a two-speed market emerged, with cities like Perth experiencing declines and others like Melbourne seeing significant gains. Experts predict house price growth will slow in 2017 due to rising mortgage rates and concerns over oversupply.

site_title: Biggest economies face US$7.7t bond tab as bull run fades
summary: Governments of the world's top economies, including the US, face a $7.7 trillion debt maturing in 2017, with borrowing costs expected to rise as a three-decade bond bull market shows signs of ending. This represents an 8% increase from 2016, with the Group of Seven nations plus Brazil, Russia, India, and China facing higher debt obligations. The looming debt crisis may pose significant challenges for policymakers as global economic growth slows and interest rates rise.

site_title: Ford cancels US$1.6b Mexican plant
summary: Ford Motor Co canceled a planned $1.6 billion factory in Mexico, instead investing $700 million at a Michigan factory to expand its electric vehicle and hybrid offerings. The move comes after criticism from President-elect Donald Trump regarding the Mexican investment. This decision aims to shift production to the US, potentially creating new jobs.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Singapore stocks remain cautious due to a soft economy and mixed sectors. Analysts at various firms, including DBS and OB Kay Hian, expect a modest 4.1% upside for the FSSTI index in 2017, with some favoring blue-chip companies with earnings visibility and dividend yields. Key picks include OCBC, Singtel, ComfortDelGro, and Venture. The consensus 2017 index EPS estimate has declined, but some analysts, like HB, estimate 3.5% EPS growth, citing asset monetization and cost-cutting efforts.

site_title: German inflation hits highest level since July 2013
summary: German inflation rose 1.7% in December, the highest level since July 2013, exceeding expectations. The European Central Bank's inflation target of nearly 2% is likely to be met in the coming months, potentially leading to calls to reverse its bond-buying program. However, rising prices may dent real incomes growth in Germany, where the economy has been relying on private consumption and government spending for growth. The jobless rate remains at a record low, with unemployment falling more than expected in December.

site_title: Factory data, construction spending show solid growth
summary: US factory activity accelerated to a two-year high in December, with new orders and employment surging amid fading oil-related drag. Construction spending hit a 51/2-year high in November, boosting fourth-quarter economic growth. The Institute for Supply Management's index rose to 54.7, the highest since December 2014, and new orders jumped 7.2 percentage points. Construction spending increased 0.9% to $1.18 trillion, the highest level since April 2006, potentially prompting economists to raise GDP estimates for the fourth quarter.

site_title: Trump surprises may revive gold as haven
summary: US President-elect Donald Trump's presidency may revive gold as a safe-haven asset, with prices potentially rallying 13% in 2017, according to a Bloomberg survey of 26 analysts. The risk of chaos on multiple fronts, including a trade war with China, Brexit, and elections in Europe, has fueled the bullish outlook. However, some analysts predict a decline in gold prices to $1,000, citing an improving US economy and higher interest rates. Despite these risks, a majority of analysts remain optimistic about gold's prospects in 2017.

site_title: British manufacturing index hits 2 ½-year high
summary: British manufacturing experienced its fastest growth in 2.5 years in December, with the Markit/CIPS UK Manufacturing Purchasing Managers Index rising to 56.1, its strongest reading since June 2014. This follows a strong end to 2016 despite the Brexit shock. The increase was driven by orders from home and abroad. This positive manufacturing data adds to signs that the UK economy ended 2016 on a strong note.

site_title: Trump picks China critic Lighthizer for US trade representative
summary: President-elect Donald Trump has chosen Robert Lighthizer, a lawyer and former Reagan-era official, as the US Trade Representative. Lighthizer is known for his protectionist views and has previously criticized China's trade practices. Trump praised Lighthizer's ability to strike agreements that protect American industries and vowed to make smarter deals and slap punitive tariffs on countries violating trade rules, particularly China. The choice aligns with Trump's "Reagan-esque" economic plan, which aims to promote American industry and take a tougher line on China.

site_title: Looking up?
summary: Shipping confidence has improved for the third consecutive quarter, with an average confidence level of 5.6 out of 10.0 in the third quarter of 2016, according to Moore Stephens' Shipping Confidence Survey. Despite the industry's challenging market and economic climate, respondents believe the bottom of the cycle has been reached and that the only way is up, with many expecting freight rates to increase. Research firm Maritime Strategies International also notes that the oil and tanker markets are undergoing a rebalancing process, with excess capacity and low earnings supporting the expectation of sharp tanker scrapping in 2017.

site_title: Indonesia ends all JPMorgan partnerships after downgrade
summary: Indonesia's government has terminated all business partnerships with JPMorgan Chase & Co after the US bank downgraded its assessment of Indonesia's equity market by two notches to underweight following Donald Trump's election win. The downgrade was seen as a "tactical response" to the Trump election, and JPMorgan also downgraded Brazil. The move reflects the challenges in producing balanced research reports, with Indonesia's Finance Minister calling on banks to take responsibility for economic reports that could influence fundamentals and psychology.

site_title: Driverless cars finally on their way to a showroom near you
summary: Delphi Automotive, a car electronics supplier, is shifting its focus from showcasing self-driving technology to selling it to carmakers, ride-hailing companies, and consumers. The company will give test rides of its autonomous Audi Q5 vehicles at CES in Las Vegas, aiming to secure deals for its self-driving system. Several major companies, including Tesla, BMW, Ford, and Volvo, have promised to have fully autonomous cars on the road within five years, with Alphabet's Waymo unveiling its driverless Chrysler Pacifica minivan. The autonomous vehicle market is expected to reach $42 billion by 2025 and account for a quarter of global sales by 2035.

site_title: Singapore private housing prices down 3% in 2016
summary: Singapore's private housing prices fell 3% in 2016, marking the 13th consecutive quarter of decline. This is smaller than the 3.7% and 1.6% declines in 2015. The government's flash estimates show private home prices easing downward pressures, with the 0.4% decline in the fourth quarter being milder than the previous quarter. The HDB resale prices also declined 0.15%, with the full year decline being smaller than the previous year. The slowdown in the economy is expected to continue, with the landed segment perceived as a short-term blip.

site_title: Property data
summary: A specialist centre, Royal Healthcare, is set to open in Tokyo or Osaka after Japan's Sojitz takes control. Meanwhile, researchers at NUS aim to halve the price of sustainable marine fuel. Tenants at Hao Mart's Taste Orchard express concerns over poor footfall and vacant units. OCBC targets S$5 billion in loans to serial entrepreneurs by 2028. Shatec shuts its Orchard campus, cuts 42 staff, and puts the building up for sale. An otah business rebrands heritage for the younger generation, while Munchi Pancakes modernizes traditional min jiang kueh as a 'national snack'.

site_title: Regal signs RM90m offtake deal with Angkasa
summary: Regal International Group has signed a residential unit offtake deal with Angkasa, a Malaysian cooperative organization, worth RM90 million for 276 strata-titled homes in its Airtrollis project in Negri Sembilan, Malaysia. The deal, inked on Dec 30, provides an "upfront guarantee" on sales and reduces financial and developmental risks. The third phase of the project will begin construction in 2017 and be completed in 2020, with a total of 1,024 homes.

site_title: Quah Su Yin ceases to be ISR Capital CEO
summary: Quah Su Yin, 48, has stepped down as CEO and executive director of ISR Capital, effective December 2016, to focus on family business. She held the key position since April 2011. Chen Tong, executive chairman, made the announcement to the Singapore Exchange.

site_title: Manufacturing in US expands at fastest pace in two years
summary: US manufacturing expanded in December at the fastest pace in two years, with the Institute for Supply Management's index increasing to 54.7, its fourth straight advance. Orders growth surged 7.2 points, and prices paid for materials reached a 6-year high. This jump in bookings, including export orders, will help factories maintain a solid footing early in 2017. The increase in production, employment, and inflation also contributed to the Federal Reserve's decision to raise interest rates last month.

site_title: India banks cut lending rates after surge in deposits
summary: Indian banks led by State Bank of India (SBI) cut lending rates by 45-90 basis points after receiving record deposits following the government's ban on high-value cash notes. The rate cuts aim to boost credit growth and private investments, with SBI expecting a 8-9% credit growth for the fiscal year. Analysts predict more lenders will follow suit, easing concerns about the economy's revival. The move comes after Prime Minister Narendra Modi's government announced incentives to channel more credit to the poor and middle class.

site_title: Taking advice
summary: Singaporean SMEs should prioritize active litigation management as a core business plan component. Meanwhile, Japan's Sojitz is set to acquire a stake in Royal Healthcare's specialist centre in Tokyo or Osaka. Researchers from NUS aim to halve the price of sustainable marine fuel. OCBC targets $5 billion in loans for serial entrepreneurs by 2028. Shatec has shut its Orchard campus and training restaurant, cutting 42 staff, and putting the building up for sale. Several businesses, including Hao Mart's Taste Orchard and Munchi Pancakes, face challenges due to low footfall and vacant units.

site_title: Creator of Old Master Q comic Alfonso Wong dies
summary: Hong Kong comic artist Alfonso Wong Kar-hei, creator of the beloved Old Master Q series, has died at 93 (or 92 according to different reports) due to organ failure in the US. Wong, who moved to Hong Kong in 1956, used his son's name as a pseudonym to create the series in 1962, featuring a cast of characters including Old Master Q, Big Potato, and Mr Chin. The comic strip was widely popular among Hong Kong people and fans abroad, entertaining readers with its blend of humor and traditional Chinese culture.

site_title: The year ahead
summary: Luxury watch brands are expected to showcase more women's novelties at the upcoming Salon International de la Haute Horlogerie. Meanwhile, NUS researchers have developed a startup to halve the price of sustainable marine fuel. OCBC targets S$5 billion in loans to serial entrepreneurs by 2028. Shatec has shut its Orchard campus and training restaurant, cutting 42 staff and putting the building up for sale. Chinatown Business Association is seeking S$77,700 from Nanyang Old Coffee over the use of its outdoor area. OCBC has announced its new CEO, Tan Teck Long, replacing Helen Wong.

site_title: Here's to a good year
summary: The SME Magazine published a New Year's message, emphasizing the importance of rejuvenation and quality time with loved ones. Meanwhile, various business and economic news emerged, including: Royal Healthcare's plan to open a specialist centre in Tokyo or Osaka, NUS researchers' startup aiming to halve the price of sustainable marine fuel, and OCBC's target of providing S$5 billion in loans to serial entrepreneurs by 2028. Additionally, several local businesses faced challenges, such as Hao Mart's vacant units and Shatec's campus closure, while others found innovative ways to rebrand heritage and modernize traditional snacks.

site_title: Newly registered companies
summary: Singapore SMEs and newly registered companies were highlighted, including Specialist centre Royal Healthcare's expansion plans in Tokyo or Osaka and OCBC's target of S$5 billion in loans for serial entrepreneurs by 2028. NUS researchers launched a startup to halve the price of sustainable marine fuel. Local businesses faced challenges such as vacant units at Hao Mart's Taste Orchard and Shatec's campus shutdown. Meanwhile, innovative food businesses rebranded traditional snacks, like Munchi Pancakes' modernised min jiang kueh, and a Chinatown Business Association sought compensation for Nanyang Old Coffee's use of outdoor area.

site_title: When corporate governance reaches a dead end
summary: Corporate governance in Singapore has reached a dead end, with many companies adopting a "box-ticking" approach to the Code of Corporate Governance. Independent directors, remuneration, and directorships are key areas of concern. Companies have failed to comply with guidelines on limiting directorships and disclosing these limits. The independence of directors from key officers and business relationships is also questionable, with instances of conflicts of interest and unclear reporting lines. Furthermore, long-tenured directors and companies' reliance on sponsors to conduct "rigorous reviews" of their independence raise concerns about the effectiveness of corporate governance. It is time for a more prescriptive approach to corporate governance, with fewer contentious criteria and more emphasis on transparency and accountability.

site_title: Approval of banking rules postponed after disagreement over capital
summary: Global banking regulators postponed the approval of long-awaited Basel III rules due to disagreements over capital requirements. The rules aimed to prevent a repeat of the financial crisis, but European regulators worried higher capital demands would curb bank lending. The meeting, initially set for January 8, was rescheduled as regulators failed to agree on the minimum capital amount banks must hold.

site_title: Hanks, Kidman honoured as 2017 awards season starts in Palm Springs
summary: Tom Hanks and Nicole Kidman were honored at the 2017 Palm Springs International Film Festival, marking the start of awards season. Hanks received the "Icon Award" for his portrayal in "Sully," while Kidman took the "International Star Award" for her role in "Lion." Other notable winners included Andrew Garfield, Natalie Portman, Casey Affleck, Amy Adams, and Mahershala Ali. Actor Ryan Gosling paid tribute to the late Debbie Reynolds, who received the "Vanguard Award" for the film "La La Land." The festival honored several actors for their outstanding performances.

site_title: Regal International inks RM90m property offtake deal with Malaysia's Angkasa
summary: Regal International Group has signed an RM90 million offtake deal with Angkasa, a Malaysian cooperative organization, to sell 276 residential units in its Airtrollis project in Negeri Sembilan. The deal allows Angkasa to market and sell the homes, with the option to purchase unsold units upon completion. The third phase of the project, set to begin construction in 2017, is estimated to be completed in 2020.

site_title: Kitchen Culture plans to raise up to US$20m via US investor
summary: Kitchen Culture plans to raise up to US$20 million through the issuance of convertible notes to US investment firm Crede Capital Group. The company intends to use 20% of the net proceeds to repay debts and shareholders' loans, while the remaining amount will be used for capital expenditure, growth expansion, and general working capital. This fundraising plan was first announced in September 2016.

site_title: China regulator sets rules to curb property insurance products risk
summary: China's insurance regulator has introduced new rules to curb the risks associated with property insurance products. The guidelines prohibit insurers from issuing products that can make a profit as well as a loss, and require premiums to be determined based on actual risk and insurance liability. The aim is to ensure reasonableness and prevent insurers from earning overly high premiums. This move is part of the regulator's efforts to curb risks and prevent improper transfers of benefits. The rules follow previous measures to address overbearing shareholders and funding term mismatches.

site_title: Jumbo Group expands brand into Vietnam through maiden franchise pact
summary: Jumbo Group has entered into its first franchise agreement with Nova Bac Nam 79 Joint Stock Company, granting rights to operate Jumbo Seafood restaurants in Ho Chi Minh City and Danang, Vietnam. The first outlet is expected to open in Ho Chi Minh City in mid-2017, expanding the brand into Vietnam.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares close up in first trading day of the yr
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose on the first trading day of the year, with the Hang Seng Index increasing 0.57% to 22,126.01. The Shanghai Composite Index gained 1.04%, while the Shenzhen Composite Index rose 0.86%. The gains were attributed to a positive market sentiment, despite global economic uncertainty.

site_title: Singapore marine sector boosted by licensing of bunker surveying firms
summary: Singapore has become the first port nation to license bunker surveying firms, boosting its marine sector. The Maritime and Port Authority of Singapore (MPA) issued 51 companies with bunker survey licences, valid from January 2017 to December 2017. The move aims to raise standards and enhance regulatory oversight, solidifying Singapore's position as the world's top bunkering hub. Industry bodies welcome the initiative, citing its importance in ensuring the integrity of the bunker trade, which is a critical cornerstone of Singapore's position.

site_title: Consumer staples sector reigned in 2016
summary: Singapore's consumer staples sector led the way in 2016, surging 25.8% overall with the top 10 stocks averaging 28.9% returns.
