Japfa, Super Group, and Golden Agri-Resources were the top performers. The sector's success was driven by strong gains in food, beverage, and non-durable products. Energy was the weakest performer, with a 0.9% gain. The sector's growth was driven by factors such as rising demand and improving profit margins.

site_title: Inflation prospects, oil surge push up euro zone bond yields
summary: Euro zone government bond yields rose as investors returned from holidays, driven by sharply rising oil prices and data indicating higher inflation in Germany. Euro zone inflation expectations rose to their highest level since 2015, bolstered by US President-elect Donald Trump's fiscal policies and China's faster growth. German 10-year bond yields rose 6 basis points to an 11-day high, with other euro zone equivalents also increasing.

site_title: Britain's EU envoy Ivan Rogers resigns - FT
summary: Britain's EU envoy, Ivan Rogers, has abruptly resigned just months before Prime Minister Theresa May's expected start of formal Brexit negotiations. Rogers, appointed in 2013, did not explain the reasons for his move. This comes as May plans to trigger Brexit talks with the EU by the end of March. The Foreign Office did not immediately comment on the resignation.

site_title: Singapore shares finish higher in low volume; Jardine stocks main index gainers
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) rose 18.21 points to 2,898.97 on January 3, 2017, in low trading volume, amid a 120-point jump in Dow futures. The index traded within a narrow band, with 242 rises and 158 falls excluding warrants. This marked a positive start to 2017, contrasting the market's decline in 2016.

site_title: Designing a business
summary: LAUD Architects, a Singapore-based SME, has expanded its portfolio beyond traditional housing and church projects to include industrial buildings, educational centers, and healthcare institutions. Under the leadership of managing director Joseph Lau, the company prioritizes teamwork, inclusivity, and professionalism. Despite facing challenges in the competitive industry, LAUD Architects has achieved notable success, including being finalists at the World Architectural Festival 2016. The company plans to continue its growth trajectory, both domestically and internationally, with a focus on taking on bold, new concepts and working with international firms. Lau aims to build a lasting legacy for the company, citing the importance of succession planning.

site_title: US:Wall St opens 2017 with big gains as banks surge
summary: Wall Street opened 2017 with significant gains, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average trading just 0.46% shy of the 20,000 mark. The Dow rose 13.4% in 2016, its best performance in three years, driven by banks, oil prices, and upbeat China factory data. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite indexes also rose, with the Dow up 143.1 points, or 0.72%, at 19,905.7.

site_title: US construction spending hits 10-1/2-year high
summary: US construction spending reached a 10-1/2 year high in November, increasing 0.9% to $1.18 trillion, according to the Commerce Department. This is the highest level since April 2006, driven by gains in private and public sector investment. Private construction projects, including single-family home building and home renovations, rose 1.0% in November, while federal government construction spending surged 3.1%. The upward revisions and increase in November's spending could prompt economists to raise their GDP estimates for the fourth quarter.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close lower on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's shares closed lower on Tuesday with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 6.2 points to 1,635.530, following a 1.67 billion lots worth RM1.07 billion. Gainers outnumbered losers 446 to 361.

site_title: Trump threatens GM with hefty tariffs
summary: President-elect Donald Trump threatened General Motors with hefty tariffs if it continues to build the Chevrolet Cruze compact in Mexico. Trump criticized GM for not producing the car in the US, saying it should make the model in the US or face a big border tax. GM started producing a hatchback version of the Cruze in Mexico, which Trump claimed would be tax-free and sold at a loss. The move could impact 1,200 GM workers in Ohio who were recently furloughed due to weak demand for small cars.

site_title: Istanbul nightclub attacker fought for IS in Syria: report
summary: An attacker who killed 39 people at an Istanbul nightclub on New Year's night had fought in Syria for Islamic State and used techniques learned in the civil war, a report said. The attacker, yet to be formally identified, showed signs of being well-trained in the use of arms and used street fighting techniques to carry out the attack. The IS extremist group claimed responsibility, and investigators are focusing on identifying the attacker, who is believed to be from Central Asia. The authorities are prioritizing detaining the assailant and neutralizing the cell that backed him.

site_title: Travel agency goes the extra mile to protect personal data
summary: Chan Brothers Travel, a travel agency, implemented measures to protect its customers' personal data, ensuring compliance with the Personal Data Protection Act (PDPA). The company formed a data protection team, enhanced IT security, and notified customers of data collection purposes. Customers can opt-out of marketing promotions, and the agency has a dedicated email account for access and correction requests. This approach increased customer confidence, improved online user experience, and more effective internal handling of personal data. The company also trained employees on data protection policies and reviewed procedures quarterly to maintain data security.

images.alt_text: Adequately respecting and protecting personal data complete the user-experience and ensure great holidays for customers, says Ms Janet Chan of Chan Brothers Travel

site_title: Asia: Markets up on first trading day of year
summary: Asian markets rose on the first trading day of the year, driven by a manufacturing activity expansion in China and expectations of US interest rate hikes. China's Shanghai Composite Index gained 1.04%, while Hong Kong, Sydney, and Seoul also closed up around 1%. Oil prices rose as major producers cut output. Analysts expect the US dollar to remain strong in 2017 due to expected interest rate hikes and economic growth.

site_title: Europe: FTSE kicks off 2017 on a record high
summary: Europe's FTSE 100 index opened 2017 at a record high, rising 0.4 to 7,174.00 points. The pan-European STOXX 600 index climbed 0.7%, its highest level since December 2015. Italian banks, including Banco BPM, saw significant gains, while British retailer Next faced downward pressure after a downgrade by Deutsche Bank. The European banking index rose 1% amid strength in financials and commodity-related stocks.

site_title: Pound drop boosts UK manufacturing, pushes up factories' costs
summary: UK manufacturing saw its fastest growth in 2 1/2 years in December, driven by the pound's depreciation since the Brexit referendum. The IHS Markit Purchasing Managers Index rose to 56.1, the highest reading since June 2014, and new orders also increased. This recovery is attributed to the weak exchange rate, which has boosted competitiveness, and suggests improved capital spending and corporate demand.

images.alt_text: UK manufacturing grew at the fastest pace in 2 1/2 years in December, helped by the pound's depreciation since the vote to leave the European Union.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's economy surprised with a 1.8% full-year growth in 2016, according to the Ministry of Trade and Industry. The manufacturing sector grew 6.5% in Q4 2016, while the construction sector contracted. The Singapore Budget will be delivered on February 20 by Minister for Finance Heng Swee Keat. In contrast, global markets were mixed, with the Dow futures rising and the Straits Times Index (STI) finishing higher on its first day of 2017.

site_title: Midas' joint venture firm wins 2 contracts worth 1.77b yuan
summary: Midas Holdings' joint venture firm, CRRC Nanjing Puzhen Rail Transport Co Ltd, secured two metro train car supply contracts worth 1.77 billion yuan. The first contract, worth 1.05 billion yuan, was awarded for Changzhou Rail Transit Line One project, while the second contract, worth 720 million yuan, was awarded for Xuzhou Urban Rail Transit Line One project. Delivery is scheduled between January 2018 and November 2019 for the first contract, and May 2018 and August 2019 for the second contract. Midas holds a 32.5% equity stake in the joint-venture firm.

site_title: German inflation hits 3-year high in Dec, good news for ECB
summary: German inflation rose 1.7% in December, the highest level in over three years, exceeding expectations. This uptick is a welcome sign for the European Central Bank, suggesting that price pressures in Europe's largest economy are rising. The increase was driven by higher consumer prices, with the highest annual inflation rate since July 2013.

site_title: Oil prices rise as markets eye Opec, non-Opec production cuts
summary: Oil prices rose on the first trading day of 2017, driven by hopes that a deal between Opec and non-Opec members to cut production will be effective. International Brent crude oil prices increased 16 cents, or 0.3%, to $56.98 a barrel. US benchmark West Texas Intermediate crude oil prices rose 22 cents, or 0.41%, to $53.94 a barrel. The deal, agreed in November, aims to reduce output by 1.8 million barrels per day, starting January 1. Market watchers expect the deal to stick, with anecdotal evidence expected to confirm production cuts in early stages.

site_title: Genting Singapore completes disposal of stake in South Korea-based integrated resort
summary: Genting Singapore has completed the disposal of its 100% stake in Callisto Business, a South Korea-based integrated resort, for US$411.1 million. The disposal resulted in a gain of about S$96.3 million for the group. The integrated resort, called Landing Jeju Development Co, is being developed by a joint venture between Happy Bay and another company, with Genting Singapore holding a 50% stake in Happy Bay. The transaction marks the end of Genting Singapore's involvement in the project.

site_title: Floods hit Malaysia, thousands evacuated
summary: Malaysia is experiencing severe flooding in east coast states, particularly in Terengganu and Kelantan, due to heavy rain. Thousands of villagers have been evacuated, with over 1,000 people in Terengganu and 4,906 in Kelantan displaced. Emergency services are deploying boats and trucks to evacuate residents to relief centers, with the number of flood evacuees expected to rise. The floods have forced the closure of dozens of schools and roads, with many rural areas impassable. The situation is being closely monitored by authorities.

site_title: Trump names Lighthizer as US trade representative pick
summary: US President-elect Donald Trump named Robert Lighthizer, a veteran steel industry trade lawyer, as his chief trade negotiator to "fight for good trade deals that put the American worker first." Lighthizer, a former deputy US trade representative during the Reagan administration, will lead the agency after nearly three decades representing US steelmakers in anti-dumping cases, helping reduce Chinese steel imports by billions of dollars. Trump stated Lighthizer's selection will help achieve better deals and reduce US trade deficits.

site_title: China: Stocks start 2017 firmer, aided by stronger factory growth
summary: China's stocks started 2017 on a solid footing, with the CSI300 index rising 1.0% to 3,342.23 points and the Shanghai Composite Index gaining 1% to 3,135.92 points. Strong factory growth, led by a private business survey showing a near six-year high, and improved liquidity from banks' willingness to lend, boosted the market. This comes after the CSI300 index ended 2016 with an 11.3% loss, its worst performance in five years.

site_title: South Korea: Stocks end at 10-week high; won edges up
summary: South Korean shares ended at a 10-week high, with the Korea Composite Stock Price Index (KOSPI) rising 0.9% to 2,043.97 points. Samsung Electronics led the gain, hitting a record high and driving the main bourse up. Foreign investors bought 171.2 billion won worth of KOSPI shares. The South Korean won also rose, standing at 1,203.5 to the dollar.

site_title: China starts freight train to London as Xi boosts trade ties
summary: China launched a freight train to London, marking the 15th European city added to its freight train services. The 18-day journey will cover over 12,000km, carrying goods such as garments and suitcases. The move is part of President Xi Jinping's efforts to strengthen trade ties with Europe, following the Belt-and-Road initiative, which aims to create a modern Silk Road. China has set aside $40 billion to finance roads and railways abroad, with expected trade reaching $2.5 trillion in a decade.

site_title: Indonesia's 2016 budget deficit narrows after huge spending cuts
summary: Indonesia's budget deficit narrowed to 2.46% of GDP in 2016, thanks to significant spending cuts, including a 133.8 trillion rupiah reduction. The finance minister attributed the improvement to cutting and delaying spending, despite missing revenue targets from a tax amnesty program and other tax revenue sources. Total government expenditure was 223.4 trillion rupiah below its earlier plan, while total revenue came in at 1,551.8 trillion rupiah. The budget deficit was seen as a positive sign, with the finance minister expressing optimism about the country's economic growth prospects for 2017.

site_title: Australia: Shares hit 19-month high led by miners, financials
summary: Australia's shares hit a 19-month high on Tuesday, closing at 5,733.2, driven by gains in miners and financials. The S&P/ASX 200 index rose 1.2% with materials ending at their highest close since March 2015. BHP Billiton, South32, and Fortescue Metals rose, while the "Big Four" banks led the rally. Energy stocks also gained, and the benchmark closed 2016 up 7%, the best annual performance since 2013.

site_title: South Korea central bank chief: low growth may continue, policy to stay accommodative
summary: South Korea's central bank chief, Governor Lee Ju-Yeol, stated that low growth may continue, and monetary policy should remain accommodative. The Bank of Korea will maintain its benchmark rate at a record low of 1.25% until economic recovery is achieved. This decision aims to keep financial markets and household debt stable, potentially leaving the benchmark rate unchanged at its policy meeting on January 13. The central bank forecasts 2.8% economic growth for South Korea this year, despite concerns over rising interest rates and debt-service capacity for households.

site_title: Germany plans security overhaul after Berlin attack
summary: Germany's interior minister, Thomas de Maiziere, plans an overhaul of the country's security apparatus in response to the Berlin truck attack. The overhaul aims to give federal powers on domestic intelligence, enforce migrant expulsions, and expand the scope of federal police. De Maiziere also calls for a crisis management centre and wider oversight. The plans come after the attack's perpetrator, Anis Amri, slipped through the security net due to a lack of coordination and paperwork. The proposed changes aim to address security gaps and improve coordination between federal and local authorities.

site_title: Vietnam Airlines shares soar 40% on debut, giving it US$2.1b value
summary: Vietnam Airlines shares rose 40% on their debut, valuing the airline at $2.11 billion, as investors sought exposure to the country's flagship carrier amid strong regional air travel growth. The airline, majority-owned by the government, saw 1.3 million shares traded at a price of 39,200 Vietnamese dong. Japan's ANA Holdings owns 8.8% of the airline.

images.alt_text: Shares of Vietnam Airlines surged 40 per cent on their stock market debut on Tuesday, valuing the firm at US$2.11 billion, as investors sought exposure to the country's flagship carrier amid strong growth in regional air travel.

site_title: Seoul: Won steady, stocks edge up; Fed minutes, US data in focus
summary: The South Korean won remained steady, trading at 1,206.9 against the US dollar, as the US dollar regained strength globally. Chinese factory activity exceeded expectations, and analysts expect US economic data and Federal Reserve meeting minutes to influence the won's movement.

site_title: Singapore Budget to be delivered on Feb 20
summary: Singapore's Budget will be delivered by Minister for Finance Heng Swee Keat on Feb 20, live on television, radio, and a webcast on the Ministry of Finance's website. A pre-Budget Q&A session will be held on Jan 4, and the public can subscribe to a mailing list to receive the Budget Statement after its delivery.

site_title: More protests in Mexico over petrol price hike
summary: Protests erupted in Mexico over a 20% hike in petrol prices, with demonstrators blocking roads in 10 states. The government, led by President Enrique Pena Nieto, refused to reverse the price increase, citing a 2014 energy reform that aims to end subsidies and let the market dictate prices. The price hikes, which took effect on New Year's Day, have sparked widespread anger, with the business federation Coparmex calling them inflationary and bad for consumers. Pena Nieto's popularity has plummeted to below 25% due to the government's failure to curb violence and economic growth.

site_title: Indonesia Dec inflation eases slightly more than expected
summary: Indonesia's annual inflation rate eased to 3.02% in December, slightly more than the 2.95% expected, according to the statistics bureau. This is the lowest reading for December monthly inflation since 2010, with consumer prices rising 0.42% on a monthly basis.

site_title: Taiwan December exports to show solid growth, CPI to edge up: poll
summary: Taiwan's export growth in December is expected to remain strong, with a 10.4% increase from the previous year, driven by year-end demand for technology goods. This growth supports the island's factory activity, which reached its best level in six years. The central bank kept its key policy rate unchanged, citing uncertainties in 2017, including trade protectionism. The consumer price index is expected to rise to 2.11% in December, indicating a slight edge up in inflation. This growth reflects Taiwan's significant role as a major exporter of technology goods and a key gauge of global demand.

images.alt_text: Taiwan's export growth in December probably stayed in the double digits, underpinned by year-end demand for the island's technology goods, a Reuters polled showed.

site_title: Ex-Hong Kong leader Tsang pleads not guilty to bribery charge
summary: Hong Kong's former leader, Donald Tsang, has pleaded not guilty to a bribery charge related to the refurbishment of an apartment he was renting. The charge, carrying a maximum HK$500,000 fine and seven years in jail, is part of the city's highest-ranking official to face corruption charges. Tsang, 72, was accused of violating the Prevention of Bribery Ordinance and is the first former top leader to be charged.

site_title: South Korea president stays away from impeachment hearing
summary: South Korea's President Park Geun Hye stayed away from the Constitutional Court's hearing on her impeachment, despite being ruled not required to appear. The nine-minute hearing was the first full session, following preparatory court sessions, and will proceed regardless of Park's attendance. Park has been suspended from executive duties and faces corruption allegations, including colluding with her friend Choi Soon Sil, who is on trial for coercion and abuse of power. The Constitutional Court has up to six months to decide whether to confirm Park's impeachment, which could lead to a presidential election within two months.

images.alt_text: South Korea's Constitutional Court on Tuesday held its first full hearing on whether to confirm the impeachment of President Park Geun Hye but she stayed away from the session.

site_title: Taiwan: Stocks edge up; TSMC, Innolux, AU Optronics rise
summary: Taiwan's main Taiex index rose 0.2% to 9,268.46 on January 3, 2017, driven by gains from tech companies like Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co (TSMC) and Innolux. This follows a 1% increase on Friday, which led to an 11% year-end gain. The electronics subindex rose 0.2%, while the financials subindex fell 0.4%. The rally extends momentum from the previous session, with tech companies leading the way.

site_title: Facebook sleuths bring home India's stolen idols
summary: A group of art enthusiasts, the India Pride Project, used Facebook to identify and secure the return of stolen Hindu idols from temples in India. Led by Arvind Venkatraman, a software engineer and international art detective, the team has helped bring back valuable antiquities. Art theft is a significant issue in India, particularly in Tamil Nadu, where centuries-old idols are stolen and sold in the West. The India Pride Project's efforts demonstrate the power of social media in combating art theft and recovering cultural heritage.

site_title: US customs computer collapse leaves thousands of travellers waiting
summary: A nationwide US customs computer outage has left thousands of passengers waiting in line at airports, including Miami International, Atlanta Hartsfield, Boston Logan, and Fort Lauderdale, due to a disruption in the technology system. The outage, which began on January 3, 2017, has caused frustration among travelers, with some reporting that people are starting to argue and get frustrated. Customs and Border Protection officials are working to restore the system, but no immediate timeline has been provided for when it will be back online.

site_title: As smog returns, Beijing says skies are getting cleaner
summary: Beijing experienced the second-highest orange smog alert in January, with air quality improving overall in 2016, according to the Beijing Municipal Environmental Protection Bureau. PM2.5 concentrations dropped 9.9% to an average of 73 micrograms per cubic meter, with a total of 198 "blue sky days." Despite progress, smog returned to hazardous levels on Tuesday, with an orange alert expected to last until Wednesday. China continues its "war on pollution," with emergency response systems and regulations in place to restrict traffic and shut down factories during smog.

site_title: China's factories, services cap year of gains as prices rise
summary: China's factories and services ended 2016 on a strong note, with manufacturing and non-manufacturing purchasing managers' indices (PMIs) stabilizing near post-2012 highs. The manufacturing PMI edged down to 51.4, while the non-manufacturing PMI slipped to 54.5, indicating improving conditions. Factory prices surged to a five-year high of 69.6, and the economy is on pace to meet its official growth target of 6.7% for the year. This robust performance signals growth is strong enough for policymakers to push for economic reforms in 2017.

site_title: Indonesia Nov foreign tourist arrivals up 18% y-o-y
summary: Indonesia recorded 855,545 foreign tourist arrivals in November, up 18.32% from the previous year, with a total of about 1 million visitors. This growth aims to reduce the country's reliance on raw commodities and reach 20 million visitors annually by 2019. The first 11 months of 2016 saw 10.41 million foreign visitors, with November's growth surpassing October's 15.62% pace.

site_title: Gold starts 2017 on positive note, edges up despite firm US dollar
summary: Gold starts 2017 on a positive note, rising 0.4% to $1,156.75 per ounce, despite a strong US dollar. This follows a 7.1% gain in 2016. Analysts expect US interest rate hikes to pressure gold this year, but a lower-than-expected non-farm payrolls data could spark a rebound. Spot silver rose 0.7% to $16.04 per ounce, while platinum and palladium also gained.

site_title: China navy confirms carrier conducted drills in South China Sea
summary: China's sole aircraft carrier, Liaoning, conducted drills in the South China Sea, according to the People's Liberation Army Navy. The drills, which included flight and helicopter exercises, took place in "complex sea conditions" and were deemed routine by China. The move comes amid heightened tensions with Taiwan, which Beijing claims as its own, following a recent US presidential call. The carrier's presence near Taiwan raised alarm in Japan, with one of its ships spotting six Chinese naval vessels, including the Liaoning, traveling through a strategic passage.

site_title: China's economy could grow 6.5% in 2017; devaluation could stabilise yuan: think tank
summary: China's economic growth is forecasted to slow to 6.5% in 2017, down from 6.7% in 2016, according to a government-run think tank. The think tank suggests a one-off devaluation of the yuan could help stabilize the currency, which has fallen nearly 7% against the dollar last year. Industrial output is expected to grow 5.9% this year. Authorities are advised to increase market role in yuan exchange rate and flexibility, and consider a one-off devaluation to maintain yuan stability.

site_title: China launches rural assets reforms to boost farmers' incomes
summary: China has launched rural assets reforms to boost farmers' incomes by allowing them to turn assets into shares in various ventures. Agriculture Minister Han Changfu said the reforms will safeguard farmers' property rights and help increase their property-related incomes. The government will verify and evaluate collectively owned rural assets over the next 3 years, then quantify and allocate assets as shares or allotments over the next 5 years. China's villages have accumulated total assets of 2.86 trillion yuan, and the reforms aim to promote more efficient, large-scale farms.

site_title: Indonesia ends JPMorgan partnerships on downgrade, Okezone says
summary: Indonesia's government terminated all business partnerships with JPMorgan Chase & Co after the US bank downgraded its assessment of the country's economy following Donald Trump's US election win. The downgrade, announced on November 13, shifted Indonesia's status from "overweight" to "underweight". The move was deemed potentially destabilizing to Indonesia's financial system, prompting the finance ministry to end the partnerships from January 1. The decision comes as foreign investors sold a net $2.8 billion of Indonesian stocks and bonds following Trump's victory.

site_title: China confirms human bird flu case in Guizhou province
summary: China has confirmed a new human case of H7N9 avian influenza in Guizhou province, bringing the total number of human infections to 19 this winter. The 49-year-old man, a chicken trader, is being treated in hospital. This winter's total includes at least three fatalities, with regional fears of a major bird flu outbreak raised by outbreaks in South Korea and Japan. China has culled over 170,000 birds and closed live poultry markets since October, and the Ministry of Agriculture says the recent outbreaks have been handled effectively without spreading to chicken products.

site_title: Hong Kong, Shanghai: Stocks flat in first trade of year
summary: Hong Kong and Shanghai stocks remained flat on the first trading day of the year, with the Hang Seng Index dipping 0.2% and the Shanghai Composite Index edging up 0.05%. The Shenzhen Composite Index also rose 0.17%. The lack of significant market movement was attributed to the holiday season and the uncertainty surrounding US-China trade relations.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index opened lower on Tuesday, down 4.24 points to 1,637.490. Trading volume was 31.8 million lots worth RM11.6 million. Gainers outnumbered losers 65 to 48.

site_title: Singapore firms' 2016 payment performance hits five-year low: credit bureau
summary: Singapore firms' payment performance in 2016 hit a five-year low, with prompt payments accounting for less than half of total payment transactions and slow payments making up over two-thirds. The fourth quarter saw a 7.23 percentage point decline in prompt payments to 45.87%, while slow payments rose 7.85 percentage points to 43.28%. Despite this, some slight improvements were seen on a quarter-on-quarter basis, with firms taking a more proactive stance in enforcing payment terms and exercising greater control over cash flow planning.

site_title: Peru demands cash from Odebrecht ahead of plea deal talks
summary: Peru has demanded a "significant sum" of cash from Brazilian builder Odebrecht before negotiating a plea deal that would reveal bribes paid to Peruvian officials over three presidencies. Odebrecht, at the center of Brazil's biggest graft scandal, signed a plea deal in the US last month. The Peruvian attorney general's office says Odebrecht must pay a bigger sum later in a final agreement after providing details on crimes committed in Peru. Negotiations are expected to begin once the initial payment is made.

site_title: No North Korea missile will be capable of reaching US: Trump
summary: US President-elect Donald Trump stated on Twitter that North Korea will not develop a nuclear missile capable of reaching US territory. The claim comes after North Korean leader Kim Jong Un announced his country is in the "final stages" of developing an intercontinental ballistic missile. Trump's comments are seen as a vow to prevent North Korea from achieving its goal of developing a nuclear warhead capable of hitting the US mainland, despite his lack of a clear policy on the isolated state.

site_title: Trump picks Lighthizer to serve as trade representative: sources
summary: US President-elect Donald Trump is expected to pick Robert Lighthizer as his US Trade Representative, a seasoned trade negotiator with a history of representing US clients in antidumping cases. Lighthizer, a partner at law firm Skadden Arps, served under President Ronald Reagan in the 1980s and will play a key role in enacting a tough trade policy that could heighten tensions with China and other US trading partners. However, billionaire investor Wilbur Ross, chosen as Commerce Secretary, is expected to be the main architect of Trump's trade policy, which includes renegotiating international trade deals like Nafta.

site_title: Australia, NZ dollars start new year on firmer footing, still vulnerable
summary: The Australian and New Zealand dollars started the new year on a firmer footing, with the Australian dollar rising 0.5% to US$0.7219 and the New Zealand dollar climbing 0.3% to US$0.6952. This comes after China's factory activity picked up faster than expected, boosting the Aussie. However, analysts expect the Aussie to remain vulnerable due to the expected US interest rate hikes and a strong US dollar. Both currencies are still at risk of falling due to global economic uncertainty.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Mermaid Maritime, Sunmoon, Eucon
summary: Mermaid Maritime cancelled a $298 million construction order for two rigs due to low demand in the oil and gas market. Sunmoon Food Company agreed to issue $15 million of new shares to Shanghai Yiguo E-Commerce to boost working capital. Eucon Holding Limited acquired a China-based media company while disposing of its existing business as part of its diversification strategy.

site_title: Australia: Shares rise to 17-month high in strong start to 2017
summary: Australia's benchmark S&P/ASX 200 index rose 58.9 points, or 1%, to a near 17-month high on the first trading day of 2017, reaching 5,724.7. The index climbed 7% in 2016, driven by gains in commodity prices and the financial sector, which saw Australia and New Zealand Banking Group reach a 16-month high. The gains were broad-based, with miners, retail giants, and oil majors also rising.

site_title: White House to test Trump's leadership chops
summary: The White House is preparing for life under President Donald Trump, who enters office with a 48% disapproval rating and a complex global landscape. Trump's leadership style is uncertain, with some advisors citing his impulsive nature and mercurial personality. He has assembled a diverse team, including family members and billionaires, to help him navigate the presidency. The White House will face numerous decisions, from policy reforms to diplomatic visits, and managing these choices will be crucial to Trump's success.

site_title: Singapore shares open 2.9 points higher on Tuesday
summary: Singapore shares opened 2.9 points higher on Tuesday, rising 0.1% to 2,883.66. The gain was driven by strong manufacturing reports in Europe, boosting sentiment. Gainers beat losers 77 to 30, with DBS and Ezion Holdings among the big gainers. The rally marks the first trading day of the year.

site_title: HDB resale prices fall 0.1% in Q4 2016: flash estimates
summary: HDB resale prices in Q4 2016 fell 0.1% compared to the third quarter, according to flash estimates. This marks the first decline in two quarters, following a 0.15% drop in Q4 2015. Full data and more detailed public housing information will be released on January 26, 2017. HDB plans to launch approximately 17,000 new flats for sale in 2017, with the first build-to-order exercise launching in February offering around 4,100 flats.

site_title: Private residential prices slip 0.4% in Q4, 3% for full year: URA flash estimates
summary: Singapore's private residential prices slipped 0.4% in Q4 and 3% for the full year, according to URA flash estimates. Non-landed properties declined 0.7% in Q4, with the RCR experiencing a 2% drop. Landed homes, however, rose 0.9% in Q4. The overall decline is smaller than the 3.7% drop in 2015. Prices in the Core Central Region and Outside Central Region fell by 1.3% and 3.1% respectively in 2016.

site_title: Oil prices rise as markets eye Opec, non-Opec production cuts
summary: US oil prices rose 35 US cents, or 0.7%, to $54.07 per barrel on Tuesday, following a deal for Opec and non-Opec production cuts that started on Sunday. The agreement aims to reduce output by 1.8 million barrels per day, with Opec and non-Opec countries including Russia. Libya, one of the exempt countries, increased production to 685,000 barrels per day, while Oman plans to cut its crude term allocation volumes by 5% in March. The deal's effectiveness will be tested in January, with oil prices near last year's high of $54.51.

site_title: Twitter China head Kathy Chen leaves company
summary: Twitter Inc executive Kathy Chen, who led efforts to attract Chinese advertisers, announced her departure from the company. Chen stated that with the Twitter APAC team now working directly with Chinese advertisers, it was the right time for her to leave. Twitter grew its Greater China advertiser base nearly 400% over the past two years, making it one of the company's fastest-growing revenue markets in Asia Pacific. Chen's departure comes after Twitter cut 9% of its global workforce in October to reduce costs.

site_title: Mermaid Maritime cancels US$298m order for two rigs with China Merchants Industry
summary: Mermaid Maritime has cancelled a US$298 million construction order for two drilling rigs with China Merchants Industry Holdings due to the depressed oil and gas market. The company had pre-paid US$44 million and will retain this amount, as well as materials and equipment. This decision follows an asset impairment previously recorded in 2015. In a separate announcement, Mermaid's Indonesian unit secured a one-year charter contract for a remotely operated vehicle and air diving support vessel, expecting continued demand for subsea services in Indonesia and the South-east Asia region.

site_title: Quick takes: Singapore economy dodges tech recession but still in slow motion
summary: Singapore's economy grew 1.8% in 2016, narrowly avoiding a technical recession with a 9.1% Q4 quarter-over-quarter growth. However, economists predict the economy will remain in a "slow-mo" phase in 2017, citing concerns over a potential protectionist trade policy, uncertain drivers of growth, and structural external demand drags. The 2017 outlook is seen as tentative, with GDP growth likely ranging from 1-2%, amid uncertainties such as the Trump presidency and China's slowdown.

site_title: Medtecs sells Philippines properties for US$2.2 million
summary: Medtecs International Corporation is selling five properties in the Philippines' Free Port Area of Bataan for US$2.2 million, with US$1.6 million already paid. The properties, valued at US$1.99 million, are considered non-core assets that will increase efficiency in the Philippine operations. Medtecs expects a net gain of US$208,251 and US$2.2 million in net proceeds, which will be used to repay bank borrowings and general working capital.

site_title: South Korea pushes for extradition of daughter of President Park's friend
summary: South Korea's special prosecutor's office announced plans to proceed with the extradition of Chung Yoo-Ra, the 20-year-old daughter of Choi Soon-Sil, a friend of President Park Geun-Hye accused of colluding with the president. Chung is being held in Denmark after being charged with economic crimes in South Korea. She has denied any wrongdoing and expressed willingness to return to South Korea in three days if released. A passport cancellation letter has been delivered to Chung, making her passport invalid after January 10. The extradition process could take several months.

site_title: Asia: Stocks see subdued start to 2017, US dollar resumes climb
summary: Asian stocks began 2017 on a flat note, with the MSCI's Asia-Pacific index little changed. Australian shares jumped 1% and South Korea added 0.2%, while Japan was closed for the New Year holiday. The US dollar index rose 0.6%, its biggest one-day gain in two weeks, and is expected to gain another 10% over the next 18 months. China's manufacturing sector expanded in December, but growth slowed slightly, and the yuan faces scrutiny from the central bank. Oil prices rose on the historic Opec production cut deal, while gold was sluggish.

site_title: Singapore GDP surprises with 1.8% full-year growth in 2016
summary: Singapore's economy surprised with a 1.8% full-year growth in 2016, avoiding a technical recession in the fourth quarter. Manufacturing output surged, growing 9.1% annually and 6.5% year-over-year in Q4. The government had forecast 1-1.5% growth, and Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong had predicted 1.1% growth. The better-than-expected results are a positive start to 2017, with the Ministry of Trade and Industry forecasting 1-3% growth for the year.

site_title: FLASH: Singapore GDP grew 1.8% in 2016, Q4 growth at 1.8% y-o-y, 9.1% q-o-q: MTI
summary: Singapore's GDP grew 1.8% in 2016, with a 1.8% year-over-year growth in Q4 and 9.1% quarter-over-quarter growth. This follows recent announcements, including the establishment of a sustainable aviation centre in Asia, plans for US trade talks, and a new grant for tariff-hit businesses. A study suggests Singapore has the potential to become a global hub for advanced chip packaging. Experts also emphasize the importance of workers future-proofing their careers before a potential economic crisis.

site_title: France finds bird flu in new part of country
summary: France has confirmed an outbreak of severe bird flu, specifically the H5N8 strain, in the Deux-Sevres administrative department in western France. Laboratory tests have identified the disease among backyard birds and a poultry farm, marking a new area affected by the highly contagious strain. This is the latest in a series of bird flu outbreaks in Europe and Asia, which has led to the slaughtering of millions of birds and human infections in some cases. France, with the largest poultry flock in the EU, has already reported over 80 cases of H5N8 bird flu.

site_title: Streaming subscription boom boosts US music sales
summary: US music sales experienced solid growth in 2016, despite declining album sales, with song streaming on subscription services more than doubling to 4.9% growth. Total streams through subscription services reached 191 billion, with 76% of audio streams coming from subscriptions, up from 62% the previous year. Album sales by download and CD tumbled, while vinyl album sales jumped 26%. The music industry forecasts robust future growth, with some artists expressing concerns about the sustainability of streaming proceeds for mid-tier artists.

site_title: SpaceX aims for Jan 8 return to flight with Falcon rocket
summary: SpaceX plans to resume flying rockets on January 8 with a Falcon 9 rocket launch from California's Vandenberg Air Force Base. The company had suspended flights after a rocket burst into flames on a launch pad in Florida in September due to an explosion of a helium canister inside the rocket's upper-stage oxygen tank. Investigators concluded that accumulation of oxygen in a void or buckle in the liner led to the explosion. SpaceX will revamp its fuelling procedures and implement design changes to prevent similar incidents in the future.

site_title: Around 60 killed as drug gangs clash in Brazil prison massacre
summary: A prison riot in Brazil's Amazon jungle city of Manaus resulted in around 60 deaths, with decapitated bodies of drug gang members thrown over prison walls. The bloodiest violence in over two decades, it was sparked by a fight between rival drug gangs. Authorities are still counting prisoners to determine the number of escaped inmates, with reports that up to 300 may have fled. The overcrowded prison system has been criticized for its medieval conditions, with watchdog groups accusing Brazil of failing to address the issue.

site_title: Manufacturing sector grew by 6.5 per cent year-on-year in Q4 2016
summary: Singapore's manufacturing sector experienced a 6.5% year-on-year growth in Q4 2016, with the sector also rising from 1.7% in the previous quarter. The services sector grew 0.6%, while the construction sector contracted 2.8% year-on-year. For the year, manufacturing grew 2.3%, while the construction and services sectors grew 1.3% and 0.9%, respectively.

site_title: New US Congress prepares to undo Obamacare, weigh Trump personnel picks
summary: The US Congress, now controlled by Republicans, is set to repeal major portions of the Affordable Care Act (Obamacare) and roll back environmental and financial regulations. Despite President-elect Donald Trump's promise to unite the country, Democrats warn of a fierce fight over the healthcare law, which has 13.8 million people enrolled. Republicans will use procedures to pass legislation without Democratic support, with repeal bills expected to postpone the law's actions for two to three years. Trump's Cabinet choices, including Rex Tillerson and Jeff Sessions, are also expected to face opposition from Democrats.

site_title: US dollar resumes its ascent, Asia keeps wary eye on yuan
summary: The US dollar resumed its upward trend, steady at 117.36 yen and firm against a basket of currencies at 102.80, driven by expectations of rising US interest rates this year. This follows a brief wobble last week. Meanwhile, the yuan remains under scrutiny from Asian markets, and China's GDP growth is expected to slow, putting pressure on policymakers.

site_title: Anshu Jain joins Cantor Fitzgerald as president in post-Deutsche Bank restart
summary: Former Deutsche Bank co-CEO Anshu Jain is joining Cantor Fitzgerald LP as president, marking his return to Wall Street after leaving Germany's largest bank amid mounting legal and regulatory issues. Jain will help expand Cantor in fixed-income and equities trading, prime brokerage, and other areas, capitalizing on changing financial landscape. The move is seen as an opportunity for Cantor to grow its business, particularly in the US and Europe, where stiff regulations are forcing global investment banks to pare businesses and pull back from clients.

site_title: Sunmoon places out S$15m of shares to Chinese online group Shanghai Yiguo
summary: Sunmoon Food Company agreed to issue S$15 million of new shares and 166.7 million warrants to Shanghai Yiguo E-Commerce at a 55% discount to its average share price. The proceeds will be used to boost the group's working capital. The new shares will be issued at 4.5 Singapore cents and the warrants will be exercisable at 5.4 cents each for a period of three years.

site_title: Korea halts some Nissan, BMW models' sales in emissions probe
summary: South Korea banned the sale of 10 models from Nissan, BMW, and Porsche due to fabricated documents related to emission tests. The investigation found the automakers falsified documents, resulting in a total fine of 7.17 billion won (S$8.6 million) for 4,523 vehicles. The certifications for these models have been withdrawn, affecting 6 models currently on sale and 4 discontinued models. This decision follows similar actions taken against Volkswagen, Takata Corp, and Mitsubishi Motors Corp, highlighting increased scrutiny on car manufacturers worldwide.

images.alt_text: South Korea banned the sale of 10 models built by Nissan Motor Co, BMW AG and Volkswagen AG's Porsche after an investigation found the automakers fabricated documents related to emission tests.

site_title: Proposed reverse takeover for Saizen Reit delayed
summary: A proposed reverse takeover (RTO) deal between Saizen Real Estate Investment Trust and Sime Darby Property Singapore has been delayed. The transaction process, which began in August, is taking longer than expected, resulting in the failure to convene an extraordinary general meeting by December 31, 2016. Work on the deal remains in progress, and Saizen Reit will make updates on significant developments and the transaction timeline as necessary. The RTO, which would inject Sime Darby Property's Australian assets into Saizen Reit, remains ongoing.

site_title: Goldman sees Indonesia less vulnerable to selloff than in 2013
summary: Goldman Sachs' chief Asia-Pacific economist Andrew Tilton says Indonesia is less vulnerable to currency volatility and capital outflows due to its improved economic fundamentals, such as a narrower current-account deficit and higher foreign-exchange reserves. The rupiah, Asia's best-performing currency last year, may not depreciate significantly, and the country is expected to expand 5.3% in 2017. The government's tax amnesty program and plans to boost spending on infrastructure also support economic growth, with Fitch Ratings raising Indonesia's outlook to positive.

site_title: Investigators question Israel's Netanyahu over alleged receipt of gifts
summary: Israel's Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu was questioned for three hours under caution at his official residence on suspicion of receiving gifts from businessmen in breach of his role as a public servant. The investigation, authorized by Attorney General Avichai Mandelblit, is the second case opened against Netanyahu, with the first focusing on misuse of state funds. Netanyahu has denied any wrongdoing, but the questioning has sparked concerns about his leadership and the country's trust in its government.

site_title: Modi's speech spurs meme, pub drinking games in India
summary: India's Prime Minister Narendra Modi's New Year's Eve speech sparked a meme and pub drinking games, with pubs offering Modi-themed drinking games and discounts on beer. The move was seen as a reaction to the government's recent decision to withdraw 86% of currency in circulation, which left many Indians without cash. The speech did not address concerns about corruption and the economic impact of the move, with Modi instead offering easier loans and cash for pregnant women. The move was seen as a way to fuel a booze binge, with many Indians using social media to mock the government's actions.

site_title: Australian home prices boast best year since 2009, rise nearly 11%
summary: Australian home prices saw their largest annual increase since 2009, rising nearly 11% in 2016. The CoreLogic index of home prices for combined capital cities climbed 1.4% in December, with Sydney and Melbourne leading the charge with 0.9% and 3.1% gains, respectively. Annual growth accelerated to 10.9%, taking it close to 2015's 11% peak. This growth poses a challenge for the Reserve Bank of Australia, which had hoped for a cooling market, and may encourage more borrowing among already heavily indebted households.

images.alt_text: Australian home prices boasted their biggest increase last year since 2009 as December ended on a high note for the red-hot markets of Sydney and Melbourne.

site_title: ANZ bank to sell Shanghai Rural stake for A$1.84b
summary: ANZ Bank sold its 20% stake in Shanghai Rural Commercial Bank for A$1.84 billion, marking the latest move to simplify its Asian retail presence. The sale, valued at A$2 billion in 2015, will increase ANZ's tier one capital ratio by 40 basis points. The transaction involves China Cosco Shipping Corp and Shanghai Sino-Poland Enterprise Management Development Corp buying 10% stakes each in the Chinese bank, allowing ANZ to focus on its Asian institutional business and improve capital efficiency.

site_title: Hedge funds see gains in commodities continuing
summary: Hedge funds expect commodities to continue their gains in 2017, with a 9.7% increase in their combined net-long position in December. This follows a 11% rise in the Bloomberg Commodity Index in 2016, with zinc being the best performer. Investors are optimistic about metals and energy, but less so about corn, cocoa, and wheat. Citigroup and Goldman Sachs predict strong performance in 2017, citing global economic growth and stimulus spending in China.

site_title: Daughter of South Korean leader's friend arrested in Denmark amid graft probe
summary: South Korean President Park Geun-hye's friend Choi Soon-sil's daughter, Chung Yoo-ra, a 20-year-old equestrian competitor, has been arrested in Denmark on an Interpol request from Seoul. Chung was charged with extensive economic crime in South Korea and will remain in custody for four weeks. The arrest comes amid a graft probe that led to Park's impeachment and could result in her becoming the first democratically elected South Korean leader to leave office early. Chung denied any wrongdoing and claimed she signed documents at her mother's request.

site_title: Start-ups take aim at errant drones
summary: Start-ups are developing techniques to counter rogue drones, which have been used for smuggling, spying, and other malicious activities. Despite slow government regulation, the consumer drone market is expected to reach $5 billion by 2021. Start-ups are using various methods, including deploying birds of prey, firing gas, and jamming drones' signals, to disable unwanted drones. Companies like DroneShield and TeleRadio Engineering are developing technology to track and control drones, while others, like DroneVision, are creating anti-drone guns. The demand for counter-drone technology is expected to grow, with London hosting the world's first counter-drone conferences next year.

site_title: US scrambles to clear egg exports to bird flu-hit South Korea
summary: US officials are negotiating with South Korea to allow imports of American eggs amid a severe bird flu outbreak in the Asian country. The ban on US table egg imports was lifted in 2015, and a deal could bring relief to South Koreans facing soaring egg prices and rationing. US farmers would benefit from the oversupply, and the shipments could help alleviate the shortage. The US could reach an agreement as early as this week, with the USDA working around the clock to finalize the deal.

site_title: Plenty of billionaires, but few are women
summary: Women have made progress in the workforce, but their representation in the top 1% of earners has stalled. Only 16% of top earners are women, and only 11% are in the top 0.1%. The number of female billionaires is growing, but at a slower pace than men. The "diamond ceiling" appears to be getting harder to break, with it taking nearly 100 years for women to reach 50% of the top 1% earners at current pace. The wealth gap between men and women is still significant, with women making up only 11% of self-made female billionaires.

site_title: Germany arrests Syrian over alleged car bomb plot
summary: German authorities arrested a 38-year-old Syrian man on terror financing charges over an alleged car bomb plot. The man, with refugee status, asked the Islamic State group to fund an attack using explosives-packed vehicles in Germany, France, Belgium, and the Netherlands. He planned to re-paint the vehicles to resemble police patrol cars. The suspect had previously entered Germany in 2014 and obtained a residency permit. Police say there is no concrete threat to New Year's Eve events, and the man admitted contact with the IS but denied terrorist motives.

site_title: Used gadgets find new lease of life
summary: CompAsia, an IT asset disposition company, is revolutionizing the industry by refurbishing and reselling used electronic devices. Founded in 2012, the company has grown to over 30 employees and has established partnerships with major telcos and retailers. Its smartphone programme, ReNew+, allows customers to trade in their used phones for a new iPhone 7 at a monthly fee of S$65. CompAsia aims to expand into emerging markets, including Indonesia, Thailand, and Vietnam, and has set its sights on an SGX listing. The company's mission is not only to reduce electronic waste but also to promote sustainability and education on refurbished products.

site_title: Tech show looks beyond 'smart', to new 'realities'
summary: The Consumer Electronics Show (CES) will showcase new devices and technologies beyond "smart" devices, focusing on augmented and virtual realities. The event will feature new robotics, connected cars, and a range of gizmos, including drones and smart home technologies. Industry experts expect virtual reality to transform industries such as healthcare, agriculture, and business, with applications in fields like education and entertainment. CES will also highlight advancements in artificial intelligence, autonomous vehicles, and robotics, with over 600 startups and major industry names in attendance.

site_title: Daughter of Park's friend arrested in Denmark
summary: Danish police have arrested Chung Yoo Ra, 20, daughter of a woman at the center of South Korea's influence-peddling scandal involving President Park Geun Hye. Chung was arrested for alleged criminal interference related to her academic record and other charges. The arrest is part of South Korea's efforts to extradite Chung, who is suspected of ties to the scandal. Chung had been staying in Denmark for equestrian-related work, but authorities claim she was staying illegally. The arrest comes as President Park faces impeachment proceedings and hundreds of thousands of protesters have been demonstrating in Seoul.

site_title: Oil price rebound may boost O&G contracting
summary: Oil prices rebounding towards $50 may boost offshore and marine contracting activity linked to conventional upstream oil and gas projects. However, yard groups are diversifying into adjacent markets, including liquefied natural gas (LNG) bunkering, offshore wind, and ballast water treatment systems. Analysts expect at least $10 billion of upstream O&G contracts to be awarded by the end of 2017, with opportunities in FPSO projects, EPC contracts, and large offshore production facilities. Despite geopolitical risks, Singapore yards are well-positioned to benefit from growth in these adjacent markets.

site_title: Maintaining a hotel's patina of opulence
summary: New York City's luxury hotels rely on specialized staff to maintain their opulence, including glass attendants, scent sommeliers, mural restoration specialists, and others. These individuals take pride in their work, with tasks ranging from polishing crystal goblets to creating bespoke fragrances and artwork. Their dedication and attention to detail elevate the hotel experience, making it more special for guests. For example, a glass attendant at the Baccarat Hotel spends about $100,000 worth of stemware per night, while a mural restoration specialist at the Carlyle Hotel painstakingly maintains the hotel's artwork.

site_title: US auto sales growth seen drawing to an end
summary: US auto sales are expected to decline in 2017, with analysts projecting a drop of 200,000 vehicles, marking the first significant decline in eight years. The decline is attributed to higher expenses working against less well-heeled buyers, despite luxury vehicles continuing to be in high demand. The industry has seen rapid growth for several years, but the era of that growth appears to be coming to an end.

images.alt_text: The industry has entered 2017 with analysts projecting the first significant decline in eight years - a drop of 200,000 vehicles - to 17.3 million cars and light trucks.

site_title: Madrid stems out pollution from cars that are a legacy of Spain's slump
summary: Madrid has taken measures to combat traffic pollution, which is partly attributed to the country's economic slump from 2009-2013. The city council temporarily restricted cars with even-numbered licence plates, imposed speed and parking restrictions, and addressed the issue of ageing vehicles. Ricardo Conesa, head of the Automotive Enterprise Programme, stated that the increased age of Spain's car fleet contributed to the pollution problem. The measures aim to reduce fumes from high-pressure weather conditions.

site_title: Dollar recovers from two-week low
summary: The US dollar recovered from a two-week low against a basket of six major currencies on January 2, 2017, due to market expectations of potential rate hikes and President-elect Donald Trump's fiscal expansion. The dollar index rose to 14-year highs in December and finished the year with a 4% annual gain. The euro edged down to $1.0513, while speculators increased their bets on the dollar, increasing long positions for the first time since October.

images.alt_text: The dollar recovered from a two-week low against a basket of six major currencies on Monday, though trade was thin due to many markets being closed for the New Year holiday.

site_title: Europe: Shares hit highs as PMI data comes as New Year's gift
summary: European shares hit new highs on the first trading day of 2017, boosted by strong manufacturing reports. The euro zone's manufacturing Purchasing Managers' Index reached 54.9 in December, its highest since April 2011, with Germany and France also seeing significant growth. Italy's FTSE MIB index rose 1.7% and the pan-European Stoxx 600 held at one-year highs. Analysts attribute the boost to a brighter macroeconomic picture and the cheap euro, despite warning of political risks ahead.

site_title: Myanmar detains police officers over Rohingya abuse video
summary: Myanmar's government has detained several police officers over a video showing Rohingya civilians being beaten, a rare admission of potential abuses. The video, filmed by Constable Zaw Myo Htike, shows police hitting a young boy and beating a villager with a stick. The move comes amid reports of widespread human rights abuses against the Rohingya minority, with tens of thousands fleeing to Bangladesh. The government has also acknowledged that around 600 people have been detained, including six who have died in police custody.

site_title: World's highest-paid expats toil in land of fondue and watches
summary: Switzerland ranks as the world's best destination for expats, with an average salary of US$188,275 a year, surpassing the global average by almost twice. The country tops HSBC's expat career ranking for a second year, with 69% of expats reporting improved work-life balance and 61% praising the work culture. Germany and Sweden rank second and third, despite lower salaries, due to benefits such as job security and work-life balance.

site_title: Banks hope for warmer Asean ties to brace anti-trade chill
summary: Asian banks are optimistic about strengthening ties within the region despite anti-trade sentiment post-Brexit and US elections. Indonesia is seen as a key market, with DBS aiming to add 400,000 customers through its acquisition of ANZ assets. OCBC and UOB also plan to invest in digital banking and strategic alliances in Indonesia, while Standard Chartered will digitize its operations with a $100 million investment. Analysts expect growth in emerging economies, with Indonesia and India being key areas of focus, despite China's economic transition.

site_title: Islamic State claims New Year's massacre at Istanbul nightclub
summary: Islamic State (IS) claimed responsibility for the January 1, 2017, New Year's massacre at the Reina nightclub in Istanbul, where 39 people, including 25 foreigners, were killed. An assailant killed a police officer and then opened fire on the crowd, escaping before being identified. The attack occurred as violence from Syria spilled into Turkey, highlighting the country's struggle to contain the conflict. The incident marked another grim reminder of terrorism in Turkey.

site_title: Cash ban hurts, but graft-weary India grits its teeth
summary: India's Prime Minister Narendra Modi's cash ban on 500 and 1,000 rupee bills appears to be paying off, despite initial concerns about its impact on the country's most vulnerable people. The ban, aimed at reducing corruption, has sparked widespread support, with many Indians viewing it as a necessary step to combat a culture of corruption. While the poorest have struggled with cash shortages, many continue to support Modi's initiative, citing the need to fight "black money". Economists believe the move could pave the way for further measures to discourage bribery and restructure the economy.

site_title: Tesla makes Reno a critical stop on the way to Las Vegas and CES
summary: Tesla is hosting an investor event at its Gigafactory 1 in Reno, Nevada, on January 4, ahead of the Consumer Electronics Show (CES) in Las Vegas. The event will focus on the company's battery and energy storage production, rather than CES, which will feature self-driving technology. This marks a departure from Tesla's typical practice of skipping large industry trade shows. The move is seen as a strategic move to connect with investors and analysts while showcasing the company's production capabilities.

site_title: Recovering Russia lures investors, even after bumper year of returns
summary: Foreign investors are optimistic about Russia's economic recovery in 2017, driven by factors such as a manufacturing expansion, rising oil prices, and potential sanctions relief under the Trump administration. Analysts predict a growth phase, with Goldman Sachs forecasting a move from a recovery to growth. Despite concerns over corruption and a reliance on oil exports, Russia's asset prices remain low, and some see structural changes such as inflation targeting and a floating currency as positive. Experts expect at least 10% returns on Russian rouble bonds this year.

site_title: Beijing enjoys brief respite, but choking smog likely to return on Tuesday
summary: Heavy smog in northern China has partially cleared, with flights returning to normal in Beijing, but is expected to return on Tuesday. The pollution index dropped to over 100 micrograms per cubic meter from over 500 on Sunday night. Authorities have been issuing smog alerts since mid-December, with a ban on heavy-duty construction trucks and restrictions on motorists. The World Health Organization recommends a safe level of 10 micrograms per cubic meter, which is not being met. The smog is expected to persist until Thursday in surrounding provinces, amid concerns over the government's effectiveness in addressing pollution.

site_title: Brews brothers: Norman monks revive ancient beer tradition
summary: Monks at the Abbey of Saint-Wandrille in northern France have revived an ancient beer tradition, producing France's only truly monastic beer. The abbey, founded in 649, had previously brewed beer but stopped production in 1935. Two monks, Brother Matthieu and Brother Christian, took up the challenge in 2014 and experimented with a brewing kit before launching their definitive brew in December. The beer, sold at 4.50 euros per half-litre, has already sold 25,000 bottles and received positive feedback in the craft beer market.

site_title: Trump's extreme oligarchy
summary: US President-elect Donald Trump is assembling a Cabinet dominated by wealthy individuals, sparking concerns of an oligarchic government. His proposed economic policies, dubbed "Trumponomics," include drastic tax cuts, tariffs on imported goods, and deregulation, which could lead to increased national debt and job losses. Critics argue that these policies disproportionately benefit the rich and harm the middle class and the environment. The Trump administration's protectionist stance is seen as a betrayal of the Republican party's long-held support for free trade, and its impact on the US economy and global trade is uncertain.

site_title: Mariah Carey's New Year's Eve nightmare in Times Square
summary: Mariah Carey's New Year's Eve performance in Times Square was marred by malfunctions, leaving her struggling to reach notes and sync lyrics and music during her hit songs Emotions and We Belong Together. Despite her efforts to recover, she stopped singing after a malfunction, and a pre-recorded version of We Belong Together continued to play. Carey's representatives dispute the audio producer's claim that there were no malfunctions with the sound equipment, and a spokeswoman for Carey says the singer was not at fault. The cause of the problem remains unclear.

site_title: South Korea mulls over electric car rule as Tesla readies showroom
summary: South Korea is considering eliminating a rule that denies subsidies for electric vehicles with high-capacity batteries, potentially opening the market to Tesla's long-range models. The move comes as Tesla is set to enter the market with its showroom. The country is a major market for premium cars and has seen high demand for Tesla's Model 3, despite the US carmaker not entering South Korea until early 2017. The change could benefit Tesla and other electric vehicle manufacturers.

site_title: BT's most popular stories in 2016
summary: In 2016, BT's most popular stories included refinancing home problems due to Total Debt Servicing Ratio (TDSR), Singapore Airlines' near-collision at South Korea's Incheon airport, and Amazon's 100,000 sq ft facility at Mapletree. The year also saw significant developments in the property market, with over 100 agencies closing and 3,500 agents leaving the industry. The UK's Brexit vote and the rise of fake goods were also major news stories. These rankings were compiled based on online analytics from BT's digital platforms from January 1 to December 30, 2016.

site_title: As US living costs soar, DC homelessness doubles national average
summary: Washington D.C. has seen a doubling of its homelessness rate, with 124 homeless people for every 10,000 residents, surpassing the national average. The city's median home prices have soared to record highs, making affordable housing unattainable for many residents. Transitional housing complexes, such as Valley Place, struggle to provide stable housing for vulnerable families, with many residents facing eviction and returning to homelessness. The city's wealth gap is stark, with neighboring communities boasting some of the highest median household incomes in the nation, while D.C. residents face a generational homelessness crisis.

site_title: In banning ivory trade, China saw benefits for itself
summary: China has banned its commercial ivory trade by the end of 2017, a move welcomed by environmentalists and activists as a turning point in the fight against poachers. The ban reinforced President Xi Jinping's campaign against corruption and strengthened China's influence in Africa, while also boosting its global environmental image. China's decision came after years of resistance, as the country's economic boom led to a surge in demand for ivory and smugglers brought the illicit trade into the country. The ban is seen as a significant step forward for China, which now faces the challenge of enforcing the ban and preventing the ivory trade from resurfacing.

site_title: Samsung warns of slowing growth, seeks to recover from costly Note 7 failure
summary: Samsung Electronics Co. warns of slowing growth due to key market uncertainties and costly failures. The company's vice-chairman, Kwon Oh Hyun, urged employees to focus on product quality and safety inspections after the Note 7 smartphone's global recall cost over $6 billion. Samsung seeks to recover from the 2016 debacle and widen its technology leadership through innovation and business enhancements, despite its rivals' investments in emerging technologies like artificial intelligence and big data.

site_title: Scientists loved and loathed by an agrochemical giant
summary: A scientist, James Cresswell, at the University of Exeter, studied the decline of bee colonies and found evidence that pesticides, not varroa mites, may be the cause. However, his research was commissioned by Syngenta, a pesticide giant, and he accepted funding, raising concerns about the influence of the company on his work. The scientist acknowledged that he was pressured by his university to accept the funding, and he had to navigate confidentiality agreements that limited his ability to disclose his findings. Cresswell's experience highlights the close relationships between academia and agrochemical companies, where scientists may be pressured to produce favorable outcomes.

site_title: The new world order, 2017
summary: The post-World War II international order, dominated by the US, is experiencing a decline. Economies have slowed globally, and democratic disillusionment has paralleled economic disappointment. The US's sole superpower status is also in question, with China and Russia emerging as important powers. The nuclear consensus is fraying, and the US's military strategy is being questioned. American leaders have contributed to the decline, and President-elect Donald Trump's trade policies may exacerbate the issue, potentially leading to a global trade war and chaos.

site_title: S Korea considers 'measures' as China blocks charter flights
summary: South Korea's government and airlines will meet to discuss China's rejection of charter flights between the two countries, which comes ahead of a traditional surge in Chinese New Year travel. China's decision is believed to be related to the deployment of the US THAAD system in South Korea, which China objects to. The South Korean carriers Asiana Airlines, Jeju Air, and Jin Air had their charter flight applications rejected, with no reason given. The transport ministry will consider "measures" to address the issue, which may impact South Korean airlines and the tourism industry.

site_title: What's in store for Asia's fintech in 2017?
summary: Asia's fintech sector is expected to grow in 2017, driven by increased funding and innovation in areas such as private wealth management and banking. Fintech companies can offer solutions to banks at a fraction of the cost, freeing up relationship managers to focus on investment advice. However, the sector faces challenges, including high valuations and the potential for consolidation. Despite these risks, experts believe that fintech innovations will create new investment opportunities and improve returns for investors. The sector's growth is expected to be bolstered by the adoption of regulatory sandbox approaches in jurisdictions such as Singapore and Hong Kong.

site_title: Technologies to keep the customer happy
summary: Customer expectations have evolved with technology advancements, leading to shorter timeframes, greater efficiency, and personalized service. Small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) face challenges in meeting these expectations due to limited budgets and flexibility. To address this, technologies like analytical tools, predictive analytics, and live chat enable businesses to understand customers better, respond quickly, and provide personalized service. Self-service solutions, such as website articles and online communities, also boost efficiency and reduce costs. By leveraging these technologies, businesses can improve customer satisfaction and experience, ultimately benefiting both the business and customer.

site_title: Startups in spotlight last year for driving record venture capital outlay in S'pore
summary: Singapore's startup ecosystem saw a record-breaking year in 2016, with US$3.5 billion in private equity and venture capital investments, driven by tech startups. Notable investments included Alibaba's acquisition of Lazada and Softbank's investment in Grab. Local startups also made headlines through acquisitions, IPOs, and exits, such as Pie's acquisition by Google and Luxola's buyout by LVMH. The government recognized startups as vehicles for disruption and innovation, and coworking spaces proliferated, with prominent sectors like fintech and cybersecurity seeing activity. However, some startups faced challenges, including sustainability concerns and high burn rates, with several closing down or failing to return profits to investors.

images.alt_text: 2016 was a heartening year for startups, which were propelled into the limelight for driving record venture capital (VC) investments in Singapore, being recognised as vehicles for disruption and innovation, and invoking concerns about their sustainability and burn rates.

site_title: Quotation of taxable book-entry Singapore Government Bonds
summary:
Here's a 100-word or less summary of the article content:

Multiple financial news stories were reported on July 11, 2025. NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer was oversubscribed 9.8 times. US stocks opened lower due to a fresh tariff salvo on Canada. Creative Technology warned of potential revenue and operating loss in the second half of the year. London's Heathrow plans to increase fees for a £10 billion upgrade. Indonesia detained an employee in a 285 trillion rupiah graft case. Singapore's MAS and PBOC are set to deepen cooperation in green and transition finance. Singapore stocks rallied for the fifth consecutive day ahead of GDP data.

site_title: CFE expectations need to be set right
summary: Singapore's Committee on the Future Economy (CFE) report, set to be released in January, is expected to temper expectations for a "big bang" of economic reforms. Experts say the mature economy faces constraints, including an ageing population, anaemic productivity, and foreign labor restrictions, making quick cures unlikely. Instead, the report is expected to focus on long-term strategies, such as technology and Smart Nation ambitions, and targeted industry restructurings, like the S$4.5 billion Industry Transformation Programme. Economists warn that expectations should be tempered, and the government's efforts will likely be incremental, rather than transformative.

images.alt_text: Singapore's Finance Minister Heng Swee Keat. The CFE recommendations may cast seeds for future growth, but there will unlikely be quick cures for the economy.

site_title: Modi speeches spur memes, pub drinking games in India cities
summary: India's Prime Minister Narendra Modi's New Year's speech sparked a nationwide pub drinking game, with pubs offering discounted drinks and social media memes. The move came after his previous speech, which cancelled 86% of currency in circulation, leading to widespread chaos. The pub chain Social offered a special deal, charging 31 rupees ($0.5) for a drink whenever Modi used the word "mitron." The move was seen as a lighthearted response to the tense atmosphere surrounding Modi's speeches.

site_title: Trump's Indonesian business partner 'eyeing presidency'
summary: Donald Trump's Indonesian business partner, Hary Tanoesoedibjo, is considering running for president in Indonesia's 2019 elections. Tanoesoedibjo, a 51-year-old billionaire and media mogul, has built two Trump Organization projects and has his own political party. If successful, it could raise concerns about potential conflicts of interest related to Trump's business empire. Tanoesoedibjo has denied any conflict of interest, stating that his family's business dealings will be arm's length and unrelated to the presidency. He aims to bring a solution to Indonesia's problems if no other leader can.

site_title: US shale firms to increase E&P spending in 2017
summary: US shale drillers plan to increase exploration and production spending in 2017 due to recovering oil prices. This comes as banks extend credit lines for the first time in two years, providing greater capital for shale drillers to boost market share. With major oil producers aiming to cut production in 2017, US shale drillers are well-positioned to capitalize on higher prices. The increased spending is expected to make it easier for US shale drillers to gain market share.

images.alt_text: US shale drillers are set to ramp up spending on exploration and production this year as recovering oil prices prompt banks to extend credit lines for the first time in two years.

site_title: Global tax outlook: take stock to stay ahead
summary: The global tax landscape is undergoing significant changes, driven by the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development's (OECD) Base Erosion and Profit Shifting (BEPS) project. This project aims to promote tax transparency and good governance, with a focus on multinational companies (MNCs) and cross-border transactions. Digital tax compliance is also becoming increasingly important, with tax authorities adopting digital methods to collect and analyze data. Businesses must adapt to these changes by reviewing their data management and analytics capabilities and implementing IT solutions to meet tax reporting requirements.

site_title: Diminished in 2016, what lies ahead for Malaysia?
summary: Malaysia faces significant challenges in 2017, with a declining ringgit, waning public confidence, and ongoing 1MDB scandal. Despite Prime Minister Najib Razak's party, Umno, expected to retain a majority in the 222-seat parliament, the opposition is gaining strength, and voter disillusionment with PAS is high. A deteriorating economy and rising unemployment are expected to impact the country, and the international community's perception of Malaysia is at risk. With the US presidency and European elections set to shape global politics, Malaysia's leaders must address these issues to restore credibility and avoid further regression.

site_title: Tesla gives UK buyers two weeks to dodge brexit price increase
summary: Tesla has postponed a planned 5% price increase in the UK by two weeks, from January 1 to January 15, due to exceptionally high demand at the end of the year. The move allows customers who ordered before December 31 to finalize their purchase without the price hike. The price increase was initially announced in response to the pound's plunge since the UK's Brexit referendum. Vehicles ordered after the new deadline will face new fees for the Supercharger battery network.

site_title: Tech show looks beyond 'smart,' to new 'realities'
