site_title: Canada offers temporary home to those stranded by Trump order
summary: Canada will offer temporary residence to individuals stranded in the country due to US President Donald Trump's travel ban, which restricts entry to the US for 90 days for people from seven Muslim-majority countries. The ban affects approximately 7 countries, including Syria, Iran, Iraq, Libya, Somalia, Sudan, and Yemen. Canada has a history of welcoming refugees, having accepted over 39,670 Syrian refugees since 2015. The Canadian government has assured dual-nationals with affected countries will not be affected by the US ban.

site_title: Rise in resident unemployment, redundancies in Singapore a concern: NTUC
summary: Singapore's resident unemployment rate rose to 3.2% in December, with redundancies increasing to 19,000 in 2016. This is a concern, with NTUC Assistant Secretary-General Patrick Tay urging companies to be responsible in handling redundancies. Employment growth was 0.4% in 2016, the lowest since 2003. The labour market will need to adapt to future changes, with a focus on re-skilling and up-skilling workers to remain employable. Tripartite partners will work together to support workers affected by job loss.

images.alt_text: The increase in resident unemployment and redundancies in Singapore is a concern, NTUC Assistant Secretary-General Patrick Tay posted on Facebook following the advance release of the 2016 labour report.

site_title: OUE Hospitality Trust's Q4 DPS falls to 1.36 cents
summary: OUE Hospitality Trust reported a 20% decline in distribution per stapled security (DPS) to 1.36 Singapore cents for the fourth quarter of 2016, due to an enlarged number of stapled securities from a rights issue in 2016. Despite this, net property income (NPI) increased 2.5% to S$29.56 million, driven by higher master lease income from Crowne Plaza Changi Airport. Full-year DPS fell to 4.61 Singapore cents, and the trust's CEO noted that Singapore's low interest rates may hinder acquisitions, but overseas markets like London present opportunities.

site_title: South Korea, Malaysia agree to extend currency swap agreement
summary: South Korea's central bank agreed with Malaysia's to extend a currency swap agreement, valid from January 25, 2017, to January 24, 2020. The arrangement, unchanged from the previous pact, allows for the exchange of 5 trillion won (S$6.094 billion) for 15 billion ringgit (S$4.801 billion). The renewal is expected to boost bilateral trade and financial cooperation between the two countries, as officials had agreed to extend the swap in working-level talks last year.

site_title: China's shadow banking crusade risks bond market crash
summary: China's efforts to curb its massive shadow banking sector, estimated at $3 trillion, may inadvertently trigger a bond market crash. The government's new rules aim to regulate wealth management products (WMPs), a key component of shadow banking, but analysts fear this could lead to a drastic deleveraging in the sector. This, in turn, could put pressure on the banking sector, which is heavily reliant on WMPs for growth. The move has already led to a slowdown in WMP sales and a decline in bond prices, raising concerns about the stability of China's fragile bond market.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open higher tracking rally in US
summary: Tokyo stocks opened higher on Wednesday, following gains on Wall Street as investors remained optimistic about President Donald Trump's policies. The benchmark Nikkei 225 index rose 1.54% and the Topix index gained 1.36%, tracking the US rally.

site_title: Thai Dec exports rise 6.2% y-o-y, ending three years of contraction
summary: Thai customs-cleared exports rose 6.2% in December, ending a three-year streak of contraction. The growth was driven by higher oil prices, boosting exports for the second consecutive month. Total 2016 shipments increased 0.45% and are expected to rise 2.5-3.5% in 2017 due to improved commodity prices. A trade surplus of $0.94 billion was recorded in December, with a record high of $20.7 billion for 2016. This marks an encouraging sign for Thailand's trade-reliant economy, which has struggled with sluggish global demand and structural issues.

site_title: Technology holds key to better reach and efficiency in healthcare
summary: Singapore's healthcare industry faces significant challenges due to its aging population, with 610,000 people aged 65 and above by 2020. The government has invested in infrastructure, including new polyclinics, hospitals, and community care beds, and introduced SkillsFuture initiatives to attract healthcare professionals. The government is also leveraging technology, such as telehealth, to improve access and efficiency. With 1,300 patients monitored online through telehealth, the government aims to provide better outcomes for patients, especially the elderly and infirm, at reduced cost.

site_title: Goldman Sachs files US$1b countersuit against Indonesian businessman
summary: Goldman Sachs has filed a US$1 billion counter lawsuit against Indonesian businessman Benny Tjokrosaputro, who is seeking damages for "unlawful" trades in the shares of PT Hanson International Tbk. Tjokrosaputro claims to own 425 million Hanson shares that Goldman traded, seeking 15 trillion rupiah (S$1.56 billion) in compensation. Goldman counters that its unit, Goldman Sachs International, is the legal owner of the shares and is seeking damages for reputational damage and negative business impact caused by Tjokrosaputro's actions.

site_title: East Timor, Australia set date for new sea border deal
summary: Australia and East Timor are set to agree on a new sea border in September 2017, following the expiration of a contentious maritime treaty in April. The two countries have been in dispute over oil and gas fields since 2006, with East Timor accusing Australia of spying to gain a commercial advantage. After going to the Permanent Court of Arbitration in The Hague, both sides have expressed commitment to reaching an agreement on maritime boundaries, ensuring stability and certainty for petroleum companies operating in the Timor Sea.

site_title: Hong Kong securities brokers hit by cyber attacks, may face more
summary: Hong Kong's Securities and Futures Commission warned that securities brokers in the city have been targeted by cyber attacks, including distributed denial of service (DDoS) attacks, resulting in service disruptions. The attacks have caused significant growth in detected cyber attacks, with a 969% increase between 2014 and 2016. The SFC urged licensed firms to implement protective measures, including IT system reviews and DDoS mitigation plans, to prevent similar incidents across the securities industry.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong's securities regulator said brokers in the city had suffered cyber attacks and warned of possible further incidents across the industry.

site_title: Magnus Böcker appointed SIAS chairman
summary: Magnus Böcker, former CEO of Singapore Exchange, has been appointed as the fourth honorary chairman of SIAS (Securities Investors Association Singapore), effective February 1, 2017. Böcker's appointment follows a three-year term by Lim Hwee Hua, who oversaw SIAS becoming a charity and public institution. Böcker's experience in capital markets will be an advantage to SIAS and its members, according to SIAS founder David Gerald.

site_title: Merkel faces more Russian disinformation ahead of poll: source
summary: German Chancellor Angela Merkel is set to face a broader Russian disinformation campaign ahead of elections this year, according to EU findings. The East StratCom Task Force, established to combat Russian disinformation, found that Merkel was under increasing attack over her migrant policy, while France and the Netherlands are also likely targets due to their populist, anti-EU leaders. Over 2,500 examples of disinformation stories were found in 18 languages, contradicting publicly available facts, and the task force aims to counter their impact by demonstrating fake stories.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks dip on Trump protectionism fears
summary: Tokyo stocks declined 0.55% on January 24, 2017, due to concerns over President Donald Trump's withdrawal from a global trade deal. The benchmark Nikkei 225 index fell 103.04 points to 18,787.99, while the Topix index lost 8.30 points to 1,506.33. The yen rally fueled by these concerns negatively impacted exporters.

site_title: Cock of the walk: Trump to thrive in Year of the Rooster
summary: US President Donald Trump is expected to thrive in 2017, according to Hong Kong geomancers, who attribute his success to the Year of the Rooster. The animal's characteristics, including aggression and arguments, combined with the year's fire element, may lead to rocky times in the western world. Trump's inauguration was met with mass protests, and he has already riled China, sparking fears of a trade war. Feng shui masters predict strikes, riots, and a volatile year, but also note Trump's "bazi" element of earth will help him personally.

site_title: China, Philippines agree to cooperate on 30 projects worth US$3.7b
summary: China and the Philippines agreed to cooperate on 30 projects worth $3.7 billion, focusing on poverty reduction in rural areas. The projects, which are part of an initial batch, were announced after a meeting in Beijing between Chinese Commerce Minister Gao Hucheng and Philippine Finance Secretary Carlos Dominguez. The deal comes three months after President Rodrigo Duterte's visit to China, which aimed to strengthen commercial ties and loans. Chinese officials pledged $15 billion of investment to the Philippines during the visit, and relations between the two countries have "fully recovered".

site_title: US government scientists go 'rogue' in defiance of Trump
summary: US government scientists have established unofficial Twitter accounts in defiance of President Donald Trump's attempts to muzzle federal climate change research. Over 14 agencies, including the EPA, NASA, and Interior Department, have created rogue Twitter feeds using agency logos and names to protest restrictions on public information. The accounts aim to provide unfettered platforms for information curtailed by the new administration, with many carrying hashtags #resist or #resistance. The move is seen as a resistance to Trump's climate change skepticism and efforts to limit publicly available research.

images.alt_text: Employees from more than a dozen US government agencies have established a network of unofficial "rogue" Twitter feeds in defiance of what they see as attempts by President Donald Trump to muzzle federal climate change research and other science.

site_title: Euro zone starts year with solid economic growth, but risks ahead
summary: The euro zone started 2017 with solid economic growth, driven by a weaker currency boosting orders for goods and services. Germany's private sector growth slowed slightly, while France's activity rose to levels not seen in over 5-1/2 years due to expected business-friendly policies from the upcoming presidential election. However, rising political risks, including support for populist parties and elections in Germany, the Netherlands, and Italy, could undermine the bloc's momentum. Despite this, the European Central Bank welcomed signs of ongoing inflationary pressures, which could help stimulate the economy.

site_title: Surbana Jurong says its dismissal of 54 workers 'could have been better managed'
summary: Surbana Jurong, an infrastructure consultancy owned by Temasek Holdings, has acknowledged that the dismissal of 54 workers could have been better managed. The company is working closely with union bodies to provide an equitable arrangement for the affected workers and help them find new employment. Surbana Jurong has expressed regret over the situation and is committed to supporting the workers.

site_title: New Australian body to probe foreign bids for key assets
summary: The Australian government has announced the creation of a new Critical Infrastructure Centre to assess foreign investment bids for key assets, including power grids and ports, to prevent national security risks. The centre will evaluate risks, advise on transactions, and help prevent sabotage, espionage, and coercion. This move follows the government's blocking of Hong Kong and Chinese firms bidding for Ausgrid and Endeavour Energy on national security grounds, and comes ahead of a US$5.5 billion acquisition of DUET Group by a consortium led by Hong Kong's Cheung Kong Infrastructure Holdings.

site_title: Nike and Ford caught in crossfire of Trump's trade overhaul
summary: US President Donald Trump has signed documents to overhaul US trade policy, including pulling out of the Trans-Pacific Partnership and renegotiating the North American Free Trade Agreement. This move is expected to significantly impact global companies such as Nike and Ford, which rely heavily on international supply chains. Analysts predict increased costs, reduced savings, and uncertainty for these companies, potentially leading to reevaluation of their strategies and investments. The renegotiation of Nafta could have far-reaching implications for the auto industry, with idle investments and added costs expected to make it riskier for carmakers.

site_title: Denmark's financial regulator to get tough with banks
summary: Denmark's financial regulator plans to take aggressive action against banks that fail to meet minimum requirements, with the goal of protecting taxpayers. Director General Jesper Berg says the regulator needs to act earlier, citing Denmark's own experiences during the financial crisis and Italy's plight with Banca Monte dei Paschi di Siena. The Financial Supervisory Authority will consider transferring institutions to a "bad bank" if they breach recapitalization buffers, rather than waiting for government bailouts. This approach aims to avoid "messy" unwindings in bankruptcy court and ensure compliance with the EU's plan to avoid government bailouts of banks.

site_title: US: Wall Street pares losses after Trump meets US company execs
summary: US stocks pared losses after President Donald Trump met with top US company executives, outlining plans to reduce regulations by 75% or more and offer advantages for US manufacturing. Investors sought clarity on Trump's agenda, including tax and regulatory reforms and infrastructure spending. The meeting provided some reassurance, allowing US stocks to recover from earlier lows, but the market remains cautious due to tariff uncertainty and split Federal Reserve views.

site_title: One-off abdication law eyed for Japan emperor
summary: Japan is considering a one-off bill allowing its emperor to step down, a first in over two centuries. The proposal comes after Emperor Akihito, 83, expressed a desire to abdicate due to his advancing age and weakening health. A government panel is set to make a final recommendation in March. This would be the first abdication in the country's nearly three-decade history.

site_title: Oil prices jump 2% ahead of producers' compliance meeting
summary: Oil prices rose 2% on Friday ahead of a meeting of top oil producers to review compliance with a 1.8 million barrel-per-day production cut deal. Brent crude ended at $55.49 a barrel, while US crude rose to $52.42 a barrel. However, rising US drilling activity limited gains, and analysts warned that swelling oil stockpiles and rising shale production could threaten market rebalancing. The meeting in Vienna aims to establish a mechanism to verify compliance with the output cut deal.

site_title: Trump signs executive decree against Obamacare health law
summary: President Donald Trump signed an executive decree on January 21, 2017, aimed at limiting the "burden" of the Obamacare health law, which he has vowed to repeal. The order, signed in the Oval Office, seeks to "minimise the economic burden" of the 2010 Affordable Care Act. The move is a priority for Republicans controlling both Congress and the White House, and is part of their effort to repeal the law. The decree does not attempt to repeal the law immediately but instead aims to limit its economic impact pending repeal.

site_title: Children saved in Italy avalanche hotel miracle
summary: A rescue operation in Italy's Rigopiano hotel, where an avalanche buried the building two days earlier, has saved four children and six other survivors. The children, including a 7-year-old boy, were pulled alive from the rubble, while five others remain under the snow with at least one injured. Two bodies have been recovered so far, and 13 people remain unaccounted for. The rescues were considered a miracle, with survivors praising the firefighters for their efforts.

site_title: Trump gives FBI's Comey a handshake and hug amid investigations
summary: President Donald Trump gave FBI Director James Comey a handshake and hug at a White House reception, amid investigations into possible ties between Russia and Trump associates. The gesture comes as the FBI investigates a 35-page dossier of unverified allegations against Trump and as Trump's 10-year term as director of the FBI is set to expire in 2023. Trump had previously criticized Comey for his handling of the Hillary Clinton email investigation, but the gesture suggests a possible attempt to keep Comey on or ease tensions.

site_title: Destination: Cuba
summary: Singapore's Banyan Tree resort, Dhawa Cayo Santa Maria, has opened in Cuba, offering an all-inclusive lifestyle experience with private beach and 516 stylish rooms. The resort focuses on environmental conservation, particularly with flamingo birds near a lake, aligning with the Banyan Tree group's sustainable tourism ethos. Guests can enjoy unique activities while contributing to the conservation of the area. Bookings can be made at dhawa-cuba.com.

site_title: Kate Spade said to attract interest from Coach, Michael Kors
summary: Luxury handbag maker Kate Spade & Co is attracting interest from high-end retailers Coach Inc and Michael Kors Holdings Ltd as it pursues a sale. The companies are discussing a potential bid with their boards, while Kate Spade has also drawn interest from other luxury-brand companies. The company planned to kick off a formal auction process this month and has six potential bidders, aiming to quadruple revenue to $4 billion annually. This move comes as the luxury industry faces sluggish mall sales and markdowns from excess inventory.

site_title: WHO urges health authorities to step up bird flu reporting
summary: The World Health Organization (WHO) is urging countries to closely monitor outbreaks of deadly bird flu in birds and poultry, and to report any human cases promptly. Nearly 40 countries have reported fresh outbreaks since November, with a "sudden and steep increase" in human cases of H7N9 in China, where limited human-to-human spread has been detected. The WHO is on high alert due to the rapidly expanding geographical distribution and co-circulating virus strains.

images.alt_text: The World Health Organization (WHO) called on all countries to monitor closely outbreaks of deadly avian influenza in birds and poultry, and to report any human cases promptly, warning: "We cannot afford to miss the early signals".

site_title: Trumponomics may be wrong medicine for US economy today
summary: The US economy may not benefit from the Trump administration's proposed tax cuts, deregulation, and increased federal spending, according to economists and Fed officials. A "small-bore surgery" approach, focusing on depressed regions, is preferred to stimulate growth without risking inflation and recession. The current jobless rate of 4.7% is near "full employment," and rapid rate hikes could lead to labor shortages and unsustainable wage hikes. A Reuters analysis suggests that stimulus could boost demand for workers in tight labor markets, but may also stoke inflation.

site_title: Elder Bush and wife both doing better in Houston hospital
summary: Former US President George HW Bush and his wife Barbara, both 92, are recovering in a Houston hospital. George HW Bush can now breathe unaided after having a breathing tube removed, while his wife Barbara is expected to remain in the hospital over the weekend for precautionary measures. The couple watched the Trump inauguration on TV, with Bush's son George W Bush attending the event in Washington. Both are in stable condition and will continue to be monitored in the intensive care unit.

site_title: Tennis: Serena, Nadal set sights on week two
summary: Serena Williams aims to join her sister Venus in the Australian Open last 16 on Saturday, facing Nicole Gibbs. Rafael Nadal faces Alexander Zverev, seeking to demonstrate his dominance. Williams, seeking a 23rd major and Open-era record, has won two comfortable matches so far.

site_title: Apple sues chipmaker Qualcomm for abusing monopoly
summary: Apple has sued chipmaker Qualcomm, accusing the company of abusing its market power to demand unfair royalties. Apple claims it has been overcharged "billions of dollars" by Qualcomm's "illegal scheme" and is owed $1 billion. The lawsuit charges Qualcomm with building a business model on using legacy technology to jack up royalties, and Apple is seeking a jury trial and damages, including excessive royalties. This follows a similar lawsuit filed by the US Federal Trade Commission, which Qualcomm has rejected as "significantly flawed".

site_title: Chinese warships tour Gulf Arab states for first time since 2010
summary: Chinese warships have completed a six-year tour of Gulf Arab states, visiting Qatar and Saudi Arabia. This move signals China's desire to play a bigger role on the global stage, particularly in the Middle East, where it relies on oil imports. The visit comes as the US shifts its focus under President Donald Trump, with a senior Chinese diplomat suggesting China may assume a role of world leadership if others step back. This marked the first time Chinese warships have toured the region since 2010, with China's navy regularly patrolling international waters and participating in anti-piracy operations.

images.alt_text: Chinese warships have embarked on a tour of Gulf Arab states for the first time in six years as Beijing has signaled a desire to play a bigger role on the global stage.

site_title: Fewer airline chiefs upbeat about profit growth for the year
summary: Airline chiefs are less optimistic about profit growth for the year, with 40% expecting profits to increase, down from 60-70% in previous years. Higher fuel prices and falling yields have made operating conditions tougher, with 74% expecting passenger volumes to rise despite ongoing disruptions in certain markets. Air freight volumes are also expected to increase, with 52% reporting annual gains in Q4 2016. Despite this, nearly two-thirds of respondents expect lower passenger yields, and more than three-quarters expect cargo yields to stay unchanged or fall further.

site_title: Inaugural address: Trump's full speech
summary: In Donald Trump's inaugural address, he emphasized the transfer of power from Washington, DC to the American people, vowing to restore the country's promise and prosperity. He criticized the establishment for reaping the rewards while the people suffered, and promised to prioritize American workers and families. Trump pledged to "Make America Great Again" by focusing on domestic issues, such as jobs, borders, and infrastructure, while maintaining a strong military and seeking friendship with other nations. He also emphasized the importance of unity and patriotism, and vowed to protect the country and its citizens.

site_title: US: Wall Street ends higher as Trump takes office
summary: US stocks rose on Donald Trump's first day as President, with the S&P 500 gaining 0.3% and the Dow Jones Industrial Average closing up 0.48%. Despite concerns about potential protectionist trade policies, investors welcomed Trump's comments on buying and hiring American. The rally is one of the best performances for the American stock market during a presidential transition period, surpassing the 2008 financial crisis period under President Obama.

site_title: Trump says will renegotiate, may exit Nafta
summary: President Donald Trump announced he will renegotiate the 23-year-old North American Free Trade Agreement (Nafta) with Canada and Mexico, seeking a "fair deal" for American workers. He warned that the US may withdraw from Nafta unless a deal is reached, citing job losses and economic decline. The White House stated the administration's "pro-growth" plan aims to create 25 million jobs and double economic growth, contrasting with former President Barack Obama's handling of the sector.

site_title: 2017 may turn out better than expected: Deloitte report
summary: Deloitte's report suggests 2017 may be better than expected due to a stabilizing world economy, a global pick-up in trade, and a consumer boom in Asia. Asia, particularly, is expected to lead the way, with Asean nations poised to benefit from increased manufacturing exports and commodity price recoveries. Despite US protectionist rhetoric, Deloitte predicts global trade will strengthen, with consumer booms in China and India providing a cushion. However, significant risks remain, including global financial market stresses and the potential depreciation of the Chinese yuan.

site_title: US dollar falls as investors unpack inauguration speech
summary: US President Donald Trump's inauguration speech failed to impress investors, who had been looking for concrete policy reforms on fiscal spending, tax cuts, and regulatory reforms. The speech's focus on "America first" policies was seen as short on specifics, leading to a 0.3% decline in the US dollar index. Investors are now waiting to see actual policies, rather than potential or proposed ones, as the market seeks cues from the president's actions. The dollar fell against major currencies, including the euro, Japanese yen, and British pound, amidst growing concerns about protectionism and trade wars.

site_title: Fed's Williams says need to raise rates before economy overshoots
summary: US Federal Reserve Bank President John Williams stated that the US economy needs to reduce monetary stimulus before it overshoots employment and inflation goals, and the Fed must "slam on the brakes." Williams attributed the US economy's growth limitations to an aging workforce and low productivity growth, predicting an annual growth rate of about 2%. This contradicts President Donald Trump's promise to boost growth to 4%.

site_title: UK retail slump in December hints at consumption slowdown in 2017
summary: The UK retail sector experienced its largest decline in five years in December, with a 1.9% drop in sales, exceeding forecasts. This slowdown may signal a broader consumption slowdown in 2017, partly due to higher inflation and currency depreciation. The UK Chancellor of the Exchequer attributed the decline to consumers scaling back purchases after Black Friday discounts and mild weather affecting clothing sales. This could lead to reduced growth in the economy, which relies heavily on consumer spending, and may hurt real incomes.

site_title: Europe: Shares ease ahead of Trump inauguration
summary: European shares fell, posting their biggest weekly loss since before Donald Trump's US presidential election, as investors became cautious ahead of his inauguration. The Stoxx 600 closed 0.1% lower, with Britain's FTSE slipping 0.1% and the pan-European index gaining around 7% over the last two months. Disappointing earnings updates and merger talk supported the telecoms sector, while energy stocks rose. The healthcare index fell 0.8% and banking stocks were firmer, with Commerzbank rising 2.8% after a price target upgrade.

site_title: Ria Bintan Golf Club renovated
summary: Ria Bintan Golf Club in Bintan, Indonesia, has undergone renovations after being consistently rated as one of the best golf courses in the region for 20 years. The Keppel Land Limited-owned club aims to maintain its high standards with the renovation. No further details on the renovation's specifics or timeline were provided.

site_title: When Serapong bares its fangs
summary: The Sentosa Golf Club's challenging Serapong course has turned top players into also-rans, with many struggling to keep up with its undulating greens and bunkers. Ernie Els and Adam Scott, among other favorites, have fallen short, with Els leaving early due to the course's venomous nature. Ernie Scott is currently in joint-second spot, two shots behind leader Han Seungsu, who is seeking to create history with a professional career victory.

site_title: Boustead, SWF to co-invest S$250m in new industrial facilities here
summary: Boustead Development Partnership, a joint venture between Boustead Projects and the Abu Dhabi Investment Council, has agreed to invest S$250 million in new industrial facilities in Singapore. The investment, when fully leveraged, will result in a portfolio worth over S$800 million. The project aims to develop and redevelop industrial facilities, enhancing Singapore's industrial capabilities.

site_title: Trump leads standing ovation for Hillary Clinton
summary: US President Donald Trump led a standing ovation for defeated Democratic rival Hillary Clinton during a Congressional luncheon, expressing his respect for her and her husband. Clinton, who has largely retreated from public view since Trump's inauguration, was seen hand in hand with Bill Clinton at the event. Trump acknowledged their past clashes during the campaign, but praised their attendance and said he had a lot of respect for them. The ovation marked Clinton's first high-profile public outing in months.

images.alt_text: US President Donald Trump on Friday led a standing ovation for his defeated Democratic rival Hillary Clinton, saying he was "honoured" she and her husband had attended his inauguration.

site_title: Lyn makes sen-se of age-group golf
summary: Lyn, a 58-year-old golfer, highlights the importance of age-group golf, citing the decline of local golf courses due to the closure of Raffles, Keppel, and Jurong Country Clubs. The impending loss of playing population poses a significant threat to the sport.

site_title: Fun At Sea
summary: Tens of thousands gathered at Clifford Pier in 1961 to celebrate the new year with a sea sports carnival, featuring kolek races, tub races, and other activities. The event, which originated in 1834, was attended by then Yang di-Pertuan Negara Yusof Ishak. Fast forward to the present, the regatta has been replaced by New Year's Eve pyrotechnics at Marina Bay, a change that reflects the evolution of Singapore's celebrations.

site_title: My Weekend
summary: Ricky Ng, owner of Blue Lotus Concepts International, shares his weekend routine. He spends mornings at golf courses or walking at Punggol Waterway, and afternoons at shopping malls, restaurants, or his own restaurant in Sentosa. On Sundays, he attends a pre-Chinese New Year lunch celebration at VLV in Clarke Quay, where he'll catch up with former colleagues. Ng enjoys trying new foods, especially truffle sea salt, and values his flexible schedule, allowing him to engage with different markets and people.

site_title: Dine Now
summary: A Singaporean bar, Nutmeg & Clove, has introduced seasonal cocktails inspired by Chinese New Year goodies, priced at S$18 each. The one-Michelin-starred restaurant, BENI, has reopened at the Mandarin Gallery with a newly-renovated space and menu that changes seasonally, offering lunch and dinner options starting from S$68++ and S$178++.

site_title: HSBC sees stronger dollar, US rate hikes working against Asia
summary: HSBC's co-head of Asian economic research, Frederic Neumann, predicts a challenging economic landscape for Asia in 2017 due to a strengthening dollar and Federal Reserve rate hikes. Despite recent indicators of improvement, Neumann believes exports have not rebounded convincingly for most Asian countries, citing external headwinds.

site_title: Trump takes office with 'America first' vow
summary: US President Donald Trump launched his presidency with a nationalistic vow to prioritize "America first," marking a new era in US politics. Trump delivered a populist and angry call-to-arms, vowing to make America strong, wealthy, proud, and great again. His inauguration followed the improbable rise to power of a Manhattan real estate magnate who had never held elected office. Trump signed a waiver for the civilian head of the Department of Defense and vowed to re-examine long-running alliances, including with Europe and Asia.

site_title: FCT posts 0.7% rise in DPU for 1st quarter (Amended)
summary: Frasers Centrepoint Trust (FCT) reported a 0.7% rise in distribution per unit (DPU) to 2.89 cents for the first quarter of 2017, driven by higher management fees payable in units. However, net property income fell 5.7% to S$31.64 million due to lower contributions from Northpoint, which is undergoing renovation works. The Reit manager expects Northpoint's occupancy to recover after May 2017, with plans to improve average gross rents by 9% upon completion of an asset enhancement initiative.

images.alt_text: Causeway Point achieved an average 10.6 per cent increase in rents and accounted for 52.8 per cent of FCT's net property income during the quarter.

site_title: Gold extends 2016 gains amid rising political, economic uncertainty
summary: Gold prices have regained their 2016 gains due to rising uncertainty over politics and economies, including US President-elect Donald Trump's policies and the UK's EU departure. A weaker yuan and capital outflows from China also contribute to the surge in gold prices.

site_title: China 2016 property investment rises 6.9% y-o-y, sales jump to 7-year high
summary: China's real estate investment rose 6.9% in 2016, the highest in seven years, with national sales reaching a seven-year high. The growth is attributed to a property boom in top-tier cities, driven by low inventories and firm demand. Analysts remain optimistic about the housing market, despite policy controls and softer price growth, citing a lack of investment options in China. The government faces a dilemma in balancing demand-side controls with local governments' interests in garnering land revenue.

site_title: Gym Buddy
summary: VisionBody, a German-based EMS system, offers a 20-minute, personal trainer-guided workout session that can sculpt and tone the body quickly and effectively, promising visible results within three weeks with two 20-minute sessions a week. This technology condenses four hours of conventional gym training, providing an alternative for those looking to cut their workout time.

site_title: LTA unveils improvements for rail network in 2017
summary: The Land Transport Authority (LTA) in Singapore unveiled improvements for its rail network in 2017, including replacing wooden sleepers with concrete ones on the North-South and East-West lines. The 4-year effort improved commuter experience, and the LTA announced plans to replace first-generation trains and upgrade the power supply system. The authority also invested in technology to improve rail operation and maintenance. This year, new lines, including the Tuas West Extension and Downtown Line 3, will be opened, adding 15% to the rail network, and tunneling works for the Thomson-East Coast Line are progressing.

site_title: Cosying up to Netflix
summary: Singapore's internet-based video-on-demand service Netflix has formed an alliance with local pay TV services StarHub and Singtel, offering its content through their platforms. The partnership aims to complement cable TV and provide access to Netflix's original content, which has gained popularity in the country. Despite this, pay TV operators are facing challenges, with subscriber numbers declining. StarHub's pay TV subscriber base fell from 536,000 to 507,000, and Singtel TV saw a 12,000 decrease in residential subscribers. The uneasy alliance between Netflix and local pay TV services may face strain as the market continues to shift towards streaming services.

site_title: Two China real estate consultancies halt monthly home price data
summary: Two major Chinese real estate consultancies, China Index Academy and E-house China, have halted monthly home price data distribution, citing sensitivity around the issue. The China Index Academy has suspended distribution indefinitely, while E-house China has also stopped publishing data, citing current market conditions. This move comes as economists debate the impact of China's red-hot property market on the economy in 2017. The government has implemented curbs on buying and ownership to rein in soaring prices.

site_title: Violence flares in Washington during Trump inauguration
summary: Violence erupted during US President Donald Trump's inauguration in Washington, with anti-establishment activists setting fires and clashing with police. Protesters threw rocks and bottles, while police responded with tear gas and concussion grenades. A police van was vandalized, and several businesses, including a Bank of America branch and McDonald's, were attacked. The clashes occurred as hundreds of protesters marched through downtown streets, highlighting America's deepening political divisions.

site_title: Act Two in the life of the Great British Spy
summary: Former British spies often leave their jobs in the intelligence services after a few years due to the low starting salaries and high-stress environment. Many agents transition into the private sector, where they can utilize their skills in corporate intelligence, such as investigating former employees or future acquisitions. The field offers higher pay and a better work-life balance, making it an attractive option for those who have thrived in high-pressure situations. Headhunters often place former intelligence officers in high-paying positions, with some seeing a significant increase in salary, up to £20,000 on day one.

site_title: To all women who are independent
summary: In Singapore, single women above 28 face annual "shaming" during Chinese New Year, where relatives pry into their personal lives, questioning their worth and marital status. The pressure stems from societal expectations that women are tied to the approval of a man for social acceptance. Single women are often judged on their appearance, education, and career, with a ticking clock on their wombs. However, statistics show that time and children do not necessarily make marriages better, and more women than men initiate divorce proceedings. The article advocates for single women to reject societal pressure and instead celebrate their independence and inner peace.

site_title: Housing sector helps China beat Q4 growth forecasts with 6.8% expansion
summary: China's economy grew 6.8% in Q4, beating forecasts, driven by higher government spending and record bank lending. However, policymakers face debt risks and structural reforms could weigh on near-term growth. The cooling housing market and slowdown in exports, particularly if the US imposes protectionist measures under a Trump administration, could also impact growth. China's central bank may slightly tighten credit conditions to encourage debt-laden companies to deleverage.

site_title: Just a page flip away - a journey down memory lane for car lovers
summary: A retired travel agent, Steve Hayes, is auctioning off his collection of 13,500 vintage car marketing brochures, amassed since 1946, at a Connecticut gallery on April 1. The brochures, which chronicle the evolution of motorcars through the 20th century, include promotional items for iconic American and foreign car brands. Hayes, who started collecting brochures at age 9, is selling 99.9% of his collection, with estimated proceeds over $100,000, but remains sentimental about the items, including a 10-year-old Studebaker Champion Starlight Coupe he briefly owned.

site_title: Gold miner CNMC agrees to buy Pulai Mining stake
summary: CNMC Goldmine Holdings has agreed to subscribe to 51% of Pulai Mining for RM13.8 million, increasing its mining concession area in Kelantan, Malaysia by nearly five times. The group plans to start geological exploration work immediately after Chinese New Year, with plans to mine alluvial gold and transfer experience from its Sokor project. Pulai Mining has 11 gold mining licenses, and CNMC expects to be profitable for the full year despite a net loss in the fourth quarter of 2016.

site_title: Don't let a cluttered work desk mess up your career
summary: A cluttered work desk can negatively impact one's career, despite being a teachable skill. Professional organizers, such as Nathalie Ricaud and Haw-San Au-Yong, emphasize the importance of maintaining organization to boost productivity and reduce stress. They advocate for daily maintenance, using the "three-minute rule" to put back items at the end of each workday. Key principles include investing in compartments, keeping papers upright, and only keeping essential items on hand. Marie Kondo's approach, which focuses on keeping only items that "spark joy," has gained a cult following, but her methods are rooted in science, including warehouse methodology and behavioral psychology principles.

site_title: Makeover Magic
summary: Mercedes-Benz has introduced a facelifted CLA Coupé for 2017, featuring minor cosmetic upgrades such as LED headlamps and chrome accents. The updated model retains its 1.6-litre turbocharged engine and 7-speed dual clutch transmission, but with improved performance in Sport mode. The CLA 200 also features a new Dynamic Select button for customizable driving modes, Apple CarPlay integration, and Parking Pilot automatic parking function. The updated model's features and performance enhancements make it a notable upgrade to the already stylish compact saloon.

site_title: Sunny Sanya
summary: Sanya, a Chinese city on Hainan Island, is rapidly becoming a popular tourist destination, boasting sun, sand, mountains, and tropical forests. The city has undergone significant transformation since 1987, with the opening of luxury resort hotels and the aggressive push by the local tourism board. Must-see attractions include Bing Lang Gu, Yanoda Rainforest, and Phoenix Island, as well as the city's thriving food scene, featuring fresh seafood and local specialties. The city's five major bays, including Haitang Bay, offer stunning beaches and upscale accommodations, making Sanya a contender for the "Hawaii of China."

site_title: Competition Commission seeks public feedback on F&N bid for Penguin Random House units
summary: The Competition Commission of Singapore is seeking public feedback on Fraser and Neave's (F&N) proposed acquisition of Penguin Random House's distribution arms in Singapore and Malaysia. The deal, valued at S$8 million, will see F&N's Time Publishing unit buy the distribution units and enter into exclusive distribution agreements with several major publishers. The CCS will review the deal for potential competition issues, citing a highly competitive book distribution market with strong bargaining power held by publishers, retailers, and dealers. The public consultation will close on February 6, 2017.

site_title: My favourite album
summary: Paloma Faith's album "A Perfect Contradiction" (2014) resonated with the artist during a difficult time in her life. The album features soulful songs that speak to her emotional state. Faith's unique voice is highlighted, showcasing her musical talent.

site_title: S'pore would have done well if it grows 2-3% a year for next decade
summary: Singapore's economy is on a "steady path" with stable growth, according to Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong. The government is closely monitoring the growth numbers, with a goal of achieving 2-3% growth per year for the next decade, a significant improvement from the 1.8% growth in 2016. The PM emphasized that this would lead to steady improvements in the standard of living and incomes. Despite concerns about the high cost of living in Singapore, the PM stated that businesses still find it worthwhile to operate in the country due to its competitive business environment and quality of life.

site_title: Credit Suisse resolves US mortgage probe for US$5.3b
summary: Credit Suisse has agreed to a US$5.3 billion settlement with the US Justice Department over its sales of toxic mortgage debt before the 2008 financial crisis. The bank will pay a US$2.5 billion civil penalty and US$2.8 billion in consumer relief over five years. Credit Suisse conceded it sold investments containing loans it knew were likely to fail and misrepresented their quality. The settlement doesn't preclude criminal charges against the company or executives, and the bank plans to take a pre-tax charge of about US$2 billion.

site_title: Th3 rule$ are chang÷ing
summary: Nike Golf's growth ceiling was expected to be high due to the Woods deal, but the market is shifting. The rise of high-priced contracts is changing the landscape of golf, where players now follow their own form of free agency by changing equipment companies. This trend is altering the traditional team structure, similar to baseball, football, and basketball.

site_title: From Wall Street to National Mall
summary: Wall Street women are joining a street march in Washington, D.C. to protest the incoming Trump administration, defying industry norms. Dozens of women from banks, hedge funds, and private equity firms are expected to attend the march, citing concerns over gender equality, abortion rights, and freedom. Despite potential backlash from colleagues and clients, some women are prioritizing their values over professional consequences. The event marks a rare moment of public activism for Wall Street women, who are typically associated with professionalism and discretion.

site_title: Author who turns classics into children's books gets sued
summary: Swedish author Fredrik Colting is being sued by four literary estates and major publishers over his unauthorized use of material from classic works. Colting, who previously faced a lawsuit from J.D. Salinger's estate, has released illustrated children's books based on authors such as Arthur C. Clarke, Jack Kerouac, Truman Capote, and Ernest Hemingway. The estates claim the books are derivative works that infringe on copyrighted material, and the publishers are standing with the authors to protect their reputations and integrity. Colting argues that his books bring added value as educational guides, but the estates and publishers disagree.

site_title: Hong Kong property getting more out of reach
summary: Hong Kong's housing market is becoming increasingly unaffordable, with Chinese buyers driving up prices. The median-income household would need to wait 35 years to buy a 90-square-meter apartment, making Hong Kong the world's least affordable city. A stamp-duty hike has not deterred buyers, with secondary home prices surging 40% since 2012. Mainland Chinese buyers are outbidding domestic buyers, and developers are taking advantage of the low funding costs to invest in the market. The trend is expected to continue, with prices potentially increasing 10% by 2019.

site_title: A Year to Watch
summary: Officine Panerai has released a limited edition watch, the Luminor 1950 Sealand 3 Days Automatic Acciaio, to celebrate the Year of the Rooster. This marks the brand's ninth year of releasing watches with animal motifs inspired by the Chinese Zodiac calendar, following previous designs featuring an ox, tiger, rabbit, and dragon. The new watch features a 44mm case and is available in a special edition. The release follows a year of notable watch releases from other luxury brands, including Vacheron Constantin's 270th anniversary and celebrations from Franck Muller, Hublot, and Jaeger-LeCoultre.

site_title: Open up, or sit back and watch a slow death
summary: Golf in Singapore is experiencing a decline, with the sport's popularity dwindling among locals and younger generations. According to recent data, the number of golfers in Singapore has been steadily decreasing, with some courses reporting a 30% drop in membership over the past few years. The main reasons cited for this decline include rising costs, increasing competition from other recreational activities, and a lack of new golf courses being built in the country. The decline of golf in Singapore poses a significant challenge for the sport's governing body, the Singapore Golf Association, to adapt and revitalize the sport.

site_title: Highway to Fun
summary: A one-night-only event, "Highway to Fun", will transform the gravel pavement under the West Coast Viaduct into a night art market from 7pm to 1am on Jan 21. The event, organized by The Local People and the Singapore Land Authority, will feature Singapore-made or designed wares, music sessions, food, and a screening of eight films from the Singapore Heritage Short Film Competition. The party location is diagonally opposite The Cheese Prata Shop at 18 Clementi Road.

site_title: Sales of luxury residences in Greenwich quicken in Q4
summary: Luxury residences in Greenwich, Connecticut, sold at a quicker pace in Q4, with top-tier homes taking 164 days to sell, down from 281 days the previous year. The median price of luxury homes rose 2.4% to $4.56 million, and the number of luxury homes on the market fell 4.2% to 204. Sellers were more amenable to negotiating prices, with an average 6.4% discount off the asking price. This positive change suggests the market is recovering, with the highest-priced home selling without a price cut.

site_title: Do leave home without it - the handphone, that is
summary: A Singaporean writer expresses concern over the over-reliance on modern communication devices, citing how they can disrupt personal space and disturb others. The author recalls past experiences with noisy phones and texting in public, and how it can lead to a loss of control over life. Recently, France introduced a law allowing workers to opt-out of work emails outside office hours, and the writer notes the rise of cybercrime as a significant threat. With the constant availability of devices, the writer urges people to consider setting boundaries and taking breaks from screens to maintain a healthier work-life balance.

site_title: Lian Beng-led consortium in S$207m deal to sell 79,500 sq ft space at Prudential Tower
summary: A consortium led by Lian Beng Group has sold 17 strata office units at Prudential Tower in Singapore for S$206.59 million, or S$2,600 per square foot. The buyer, managed by One Tree Partners, owns 32% of Epic Land Pte Ltd, which also owns the remaining space at the 30-storey office building. This sale marks the latest in Epic Land's efforts to offload space, with approximately 60,000 sq ft remaining.

site_title: He changed the way we wear jewellery, and left it behind
summary: Tom Binns, a former celebrated jeweller, has shifted his focus to creating art after his business closed due to competition and his own reluctance to commercialize his designs. Binns' unconventional approach to jewellery, characterized by Dadaist assemblages and irreverent use of materials, influenced the fashion world and inspired women to wear bold, statement pieces. He now views jewellery as a limiting medium, and his art pieces often incorporate found objects and ephemera. Binns hopes to exhibit his work in the future, but for now, he continues to make a few jewellery pieces for loyal supporters.

site_title: Hollywood mogul's estate purchase tops Hamptons list
summary: David Geffen's US$70 million oceanfront estate purchase in the Hamptons topped luxury home sales in 2016, followed by a US$63.8 million sale to liquefied natural gas entrepreneur Michael Smith. However, subsequent sales dropped below US$30 million for the first time since 2012, according to Town & Country Real Estate. The market declined, mirroring Wall Street's fortunes, with the lowest ranking on the annual list being US$15.99 million, the lowest since 2010.

site_title: Get Glowing
summary: Top beauty brands and spas in Singapore offer exclusive treatments for Chinese New Year. Sulwhasoo's premium beauty lounge at Ion Orchard features a Timetreasure Renovating Treatment ($300 for 80 minutes), while Auriga Spa in Capella Singapore offers a Detox and De-stress treatment ($325++ for 135 minutes). La Mer at The Ritz-Carlton Spa provides a Miracle Broth Facial ($480 for 90 minutes), and L'Occitane en Provence at Four Seasons offers a 90-minute anti-aging facial ($299). These treatments incorporate traditional Korean and Asian ingredients, as well as modern advancements, to provide a holistic care experience.

site_title: Edmund Wee
summary: Edmund Wee, publisher and CEO of Epigram Books, aims to open a London arm to increase chances of Singaporean novels winning the prestigious Man Booker Prize. Wee, 65, believes in promoting Singaporean literature and has launched the Epigram Books Fiction Prize to encourage writers. Despite initial struggles, the prize has seen sales of over 7,100 copies for shortlisted and longlisted titles. Wee hopes to sustain Epigram Books, a six-year-old imprint, and believes that Singapore needs its own stories, with many aspiring and established writers now focused on writing full-time.

site_title: S$2.8m academy for port workers' skills upgrading opens in Jurong
summary: Singapore's Jurong Port launched a S$2.8 million academy to train 1,900 port and stevedoring workers for the evolving multi-purpose port industry. The academy, which includes online modules, simulator training, and hands-on experience, aims to enhance skills and prepare workers for new technology, mechanization, and automation. The program is advised by a Learning Council and will cover 700 general cargo workers from 18 stevedoring companies, as well as Jurong Port staff. The academy's goal is to improve productivity, efficiency, and safety standards, and attract younger workers to the industry.

site_title: How a S$50m investment spells hope
summary: ASM Pacific Technology, a Hong Kong-listed semiconductor giant, has invested over S$50 million in two new facilities in Yishun, Singapore. The company, which is the largest semiconductor assembly and packaging equipment supplier in the world, aims to consolidate its business segments and create an innovation centre for its customers. The investment is seen as a significant boost to Singapore's economy, which has transformed into one of the wealthiest nations in the world through foreign multinational companies setting up shop in the country.

site_title: Picture-perfect New Tanjong is a course for everyone
summary: Singapore's Sentosa Golf Club has introduced the New Tanjong course, a 6,479m par-three layout designed to be accessible for golfers of all skill levels. The course, which opened six weeks ago, features contrasting colors, water hazards, and bunkers, making it a challenge for even experienced players. The redevelopment was necessary due to the aging of the original Tanjong course, which faced infrastructure issues. The course is now a spectator-friendly championship venue and has been endorsed by the HSBC Women's Champions and the Asian Amateur Championships for future events.

site_title: Cautious trading as players wait for clarity from Trump
summary: Singapore stocks have traded within narrow bands with a slightly downward bias, mirroring the uncertain trading on Wall Street, following US President Donald Trump's inauguration. The Straits Times Index rose 2.86 points to 3,011.08, cutting its weekly loss to 0.5%. Turnover declined, with a year-low of S$773 million on Tuesday. Analysts warn of potential negative impacts from Trump's trade rhetoric, including a possible trade war with China, which could weigh on the market.

images.alt_text: External developments of note included Britain's Prime Minister Theresa May outlining on Monday her plans for withdrawing from the European Union, US Federal Reserve Janet Yellen's speech on Wednesday that provided some clues on interest rates, and Friday's inauguration of new US President Donald Trump.

site_title: Dasin Retail Trust debuts above IPO price
summary: Dasin Retail Trust, a Singapore-based business trust, made its debut on the Singapore Exchange's main board, surpassing its initial public offering (IPO) price of 80 Singapore cents. The IPO raised S$121 million, with shares opening at 80.5 cents and remaining steady throughout the first day. The trust's principal investment mandate is to own retail properties in Greater China, with a focus on the Pearl River Delta region. This listing brings the total number of SGX-listed Reits and property trusts to 43, with a combined market capitalisation of about S$70 billion.

site_title: Advantage Levante
summary: Maserati's first SUV, the Levante, combines Italian style with everyday usability. The Levante features a sleek design, with a huge grille and frameless door windows, and a spacious interior with a new infotainment system. Available with three V6 engine options, the Levante offers a comfortable long-distance cruiser, ideal for trips, with a range of over 1,000 km. The Levante Diesel boasts 600 Newton-metres of torque and a rear-biased all-wheel-drive system, ensuring acceptable off-road capability. With a starting price of S$355,000, the Levante Diesel is a distinctive and welcome addition to the Maserati lineup.

site_title: Rock of Ages
summary: Metallica is set to perform in Singapore on January 22 at the Singapore Indoor Stadium, supporting their latest album Hardwired... To Self-Destruct as part of their WorldWired Tour 2017. The concert is less than four years after their last visit in 2013. Meanwhile, the St Jerome's Laneway Festival will take place on January 21 at Gardens by the Bay, featuring local and international acts.

site_title: Lagarde warns of "race to bottom" on trade, regulation, taxes
summary: IMF Managing Director Christine Lagarde warns of a "race to the bottom" on taxes, regulations, and trade, citing potential devastating effects on the global economy if disruptions in 2017 are all negative. This indirect reference to the US administration's policy plans is seen as a concern.

site_title: Taiwan president says aspires to create "new era" of peace with China
summary: Taiwan President Tsai Ing-Wen has expressed her aspiration to create a "new era" of peace with China, stating that military action cannot resolve problems. In a letter to the Pope, Tsai emphasized the need for goodwill and communication to uphold peace. China views self-ruled Taiwan as a province to be reunified under its control. Tsai's comments come as the cross-strait relationship remains tense.

site_title: ASL Marine gets three-year breather from noteholders
summary: ASL Marine, a mainboard-listed Singaporean company, has received a three-year extension from noteholders to redeem outstanding notes valued at S$150 million. In exchange, noteholders agreed to higher coupon rates. The company, which has been struggling due to the oil price collapse, plans to use the extra time to unlock a US$99.9 million club loan to fund working capital needs. ASL Marine aims to expand its revenue streams from non-oil and gas sectors and is exploring new funding sources.

site_title: GuocoLand Q2 bottom line boosted by profit contribution from associate
summary: GuocoLand reported a 46% year-on-year jump in net profit to S$57.12 million for Q2 2017, driven by profits from an associate. Revenue decreased 3% to S$231.98 million, while earnings per share rose 55%. The company's six-month net profit fell 85% to S$82.77 million due to a decline in revenue. The significant profit contribution from an associate, mainly from the disposal of a parcel of land in Malaysia, was the main factor behind the Q2 improvement.

site_title: It's Crunch Time
summary: For Chinese New Year, various eateries and bakeries offer unique treats, such as salted egg yolk cookies and crispy roast pork. Sinpopo offers savory salted egg yolk cookies, while Simple Indulgence Patisserie offers sweet salted egg yolk blossoms. Sheraton Tower's Li Bai Cantonese Restaurant offers fresh green tea nian gao, while Peony Jade offers durian-layered nian gao. Other options include Kuih Bingka Ubi from Nonya Classics and pineapple tarts from Two Bakers. Meaty mains like roast duck and suckling pig are also available for pre-order from Kam's Roast and Selfish Gene Cafe.

site_title: Hot stock: Dasin Retail Trust shares up slightly on debut
summary: Dasin Retail Trust shares rose slightly above its IPO price of 80 Singapore cents on its first day of trading on the Singapore Exchange main board. The business trust, which holds three shopping malls in Guangdong province, saw its international placement units subscribed 149.77 million times and its public offer subscribed 7.6 times. The IPO price ended unchanged at 80.5 cents, marking a slight increase from its opening price. This is the first mainboard listing on SGX this year.

site_title: Hedge funds struggling but still charging investors for travel and drinks bills
summary: Hedge funds are charging investors for luxury expenses such as trader bonuses, marketing dinners, and office space through "pass-through" fees. These fees can add up to more than double the industry's standard 2% of assets and 20% of investment gains, often leaving investors with lower returns. Powerful firms like Citadel and Millennium have been accused of using pass-through fees to maintain elite talent and generate profits, sparking frustration among investors who prefer no pass-through expenses. Investors have pulled billions of dollars from multi-strategy funds in recent years due to high fees.

site_title: Fairfax may sell 25% of India's ICICI Lombard in up to US$1b deal: sources
summary: Fairfax Financial Holdings is in talks to sell 25% of India's ICICI Lombard, a joint venture with ICICI Bank, in a deal worth up to $1 billion. Fairfax owns 35% of the venture and has seen its investment value surge 16% compounded annually over the past five years. The sale would allow Fairfax to cash out and start a new insurance joint venture.

site_title: HSBC begins cutting around 100 senior bankers globally: sources
summary: HSBC has begun cutting around 100 senior banker jobs globally, primarily in its investment banking division. The cuts affect managing director and director level bankers worldwide. The bank cited annual performance reviews and a need to "strengthen and grow the business" as reasons for the changes. The move is part of HSBC's efforts to adapt to a changing market.

site_title: Vietnam to allow casinos in 3-year project
summary: Vietnam's government has published a decree allowing Vietnamese citizens to gamble in approved casinos under certain conditions as part of a three-year pilot project. Eligible individuals must be 21 years old and have a monthly income of at least 10 million dong. Casinos must be part of an entertainment and hotel complex with a minimum investment of US$2 billion. The move aims to generate revenue and stimulate economic growth.

site_title: Taste of Tradition
summary: Singapore's Chinese New Year reunion dinner is a celebration of cultural heritage, where various dialect groups bring distinct culinary traditions to the table. Despite blurring lines, each group maintains its unique flavors and techniques. Chefs from Teochew, Cantonese, Hakka, and Hainan cuisines share their stories and recipes, highlighting the essence of each culture. At the reunion table, every dish is proudly labeled with its ethnic identity, showcasing the significance of ancestral heritage and the blending of traditions.

site_title: Crowning Glory
summary: The article highlights various items that can add a touch of the Rooster to one's home for the Year of the Rooster. Items include a limited edition Lalique Crystal vase, TWG Summer Palace collection tea set, Bijofu rooster bottle, and a set of Rooster five stones. Additionally, decorative items like a toy rooster, Aaron Gan's A Chicky painting, and a Rooster & Hen Chopstick Set are also featured. These items are available at various prices, ranging from $5.90 to $2,800, and are meant to bring good fortune and prosperity to those born in the year of the Rooster.

site_title: Shanghai stocks end higher, HK retreats
summary: Shanghai stocks rose 0.70% on Friday, ending a week on a high note, driven by data showing a pick-up in China's economy at the end of last year. The Shenzhen Composite Index also surged 1.52%. However, Hong Kong's Hang Seng Index fell 0.7% as investors awaited the inauguration of Donald Trump. The gains were despite concerns over Trump's presidency.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Keppel Corporation has signed a 25-year water purchase agreement with PUB for Singapore's fourth desalination plant, set to be operational in 2020. The plant, built under a design, build, own and operate model, will produce 137,000 cubic meters of fresh drinking water per day. It will be the first in Singapore to treat both seawater and fresh water from the Marina Reservoir using reverse osmosis and advanced membrane technology.

site_title: S'pore will have done well if it grows 2-3% a year over next decade: PM Lee
summary: Singapore Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong stated that the country will have done well if it grows by 2-3% annually over the next decade. The economy, which grew 1.8% in 2016, is on a "steady path", according to Lee. This growth rate is considered a positive indicator for the country's economic stability.

images.alt_text: Singapore will have done well if it continues to grow by 2 per cent to 3 per cent every year for the next 10 years, said Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong on Friday (Jan 20).

site_title: CMT's rental reversion keeps sliding
summary: CapitaLand Mall Trust (CMT) posted a flat distribution per unit (DPU) of 2.88 Singapore cents for Q4 FY2016, despite a challenging retail market. Rental reversion rates have been sliding, down from 3.7% in FY2015 and 6.1% in FY2014. CEO Wilson Tan attributes this to the opening of new malls near CMT's properties, but the trust is working to reposition and strengthen its assets through asset enhancement. CMT's gross revenue and net property income were flat in FY2016, but distributable income increased 0.6% to S$394.32 million.

site_title: Asean to focus on cruise tourism, with 4.5m passengers expected by 2035
summary: ASEAN is planning to boost cruise tourism, aiming for 4.5 million passengers by 2035, through infrastructure development, improved on-shore activities, and staff training. The joint declaration on cruise tourism is part of the region's efforts to support the industry's growth. This initiative is expected to increase the number of cruise passengers in the region by 10-fold by 2035.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks rise ahead of Trump inauguration
summary: Tokyo stocks rose 0.34% ahead of US President-elect Donald Trump's inauguration, with the Nikkei 225 closing at 19,137.91. Airbag maker Takata fell due to bankruptcy restructuring fears. This follows a 5-day rally in Singapore stocks and a record close for the S&P 500 and Nasdaq in the US. Investors seem to be brushing off Trump's new threats, instead focusing on the ongoing US-EU trade talks and economic data.

site_title: Japan's Abe hails US ties ahead of Trump inauguration
summary: Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe pledged to boost ties with US President-elect Donald Trump's administration ahead of his inauguration. Abe stated that the Japan-US alliance is the cornerstone of their diplomacy and security policy. He plans to visit the US soon and strengthen the alliance further with Trump. In November, Abe met with Trump, who expressed concerns about Japan's pacifism and suggested punitive tariffs on Japanese firms.

site_title: Fruitless search for MH370 could mean bountiful catches for fishermen
summary: The search for Malaysia Airlines Flight MH370, which ended after a $150 million, three-year hunt, has provided fishermen in the Indian Ocean with detailed sea-floor maps. The underwater search, led by Australia, Malaysia, and China, has yielded valuable information on the habitats of valuable species, including toothfish. The maps will help fishermen locate areas with high-priced fish, such as tuna and orange roughy, and could result in bountiful catches. The information gathered will also aid in the detection of illegal fishing operations.

site_title: Lord of change
summary: IBM's Chief Digital Officer Bob Lord emphasizes the importance of transformation and change in the digital landscape. He believes that a startup culture can benefit big companies, allowing them to be more agile and innovative. Lord, who took over the role in April, aims to grow IBM's digital business, including operations, sales, and marketing. He plans to make IBM's solutions available online for entrepreneurs and startups to use, and will focus on change management to help the company adapt to the digital world. Lord is optimistic about IBM's potential to impact the world through emerging technologies such as AI and hyperimaging.

site_title: AsiaMedic to acquire medical services company LuyeEllium
summary: AsiaMedic has entered into a binding term sheet to acquire LuyeEllium Healthcare Co for S$42.17 million. LuyeEllium provides hospital management services in South Korea and China. The acquisition will broaden AsiaMedic's healthcare services and geographical reach, offering non-clinical support and consultancy services. The consideration will be fulfilled via the issuance of 527.1 million new shares at S$0.080 per share, representing a 6% premium to AsiaMedic's shares.

images.alt_text: Asiamedic has entered into a binding term sheet to acquire LuyeEllium Healthcare Co for some S$42.17 million.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Deloitte predicts 2017 growth may exceed expectations, driven by Asia's strong performance. Singapore plans to expand its rail network by 15% in 2017. The Competition Commission seeks public feedback on F&N's acquisition of Penguin Random House units. VGO Corporation reduces its share capital by S$27.9 million. Airline profitability remains unchanged in Q4. Singapore shares close lower in cautious trading amid market uncertainty.

site_title: Singapore Dec headline CPI seen up 0.1% y-o-y on higher oil: poll
summary: Singapore's December consumer price index (CPI) is expected to rise 0.1% year-over-year, driven by higher oil prices, according to a Reuters poll. This marks a reversal from a record 24-month decline in all-items CPI. A hike in car parking fees is also contributing to the increase. The Monetary Authority of Singapore's core inflation measure is forecast to remain steady at 1.3% year-over-year. The inflation rise is seen as a positive sign for the economy, following a period of decline.

site_title: Hongbaos as a branding tool: Firms pull out the stops
summary: Companies in Singapore are handing out corporate hongbaos, or red packets, to promote branding and goodwill ahead of the Chinese New Year. These packets, traditionally used to give money to family and friends, have become a marketing tool. Businesses invest in custom designs to make a lasting impression. The practice has become increasingly popular, with companies competing to outdo each other with elaborate designs and generous giveaways.

site_title: Taiwan Q4 GDP growth seen picking up on export boost: poll
summary: Taiwan's economy is expected to grow at its fastest pace in over a year in the fourth quarter, driven by strong demand for tech exports, according to a Reuters poll. Analysts project a 3.1% growth rate for the October-December quarter, the fastest since 2015. The economy is also expected to grow 1.35% in 2016 and 1.87% in 2017. This growth is attributed to global demand for smartphones and other hi-tech gadgets, which helped Taiwanese manufacturers.

site_title: Singapore to expand rail network by 15% in 2017: LTA
summary: Singapore's Land Transport Authority (LTA) announced plans to expand the city-state's rail network by 15% in 2017, with the addition of 228km of track length. The expansion includes the opening of the Tuas West Extension (TWE) and Downtown Line 3 (DTL3). LTA is also studying options to extend the Thomson East Line (TEL) to serve Changi Airport and integrate it with the East-West Line. The authority aims to improve the rail network with shorter waits, smoother rides, and more comfortable journeys.

site_title: Keppel signs contract with PUB to build Singapore's fourth desalination plant
summary: Keppel Corporation has signed a 25-year water purchase agreement with PUB to build Singapore's fourth desalination plant in Marina East. The plant, expected to be operational in 2020, will produce 137,000 cubic meters of fresh drinking water per day using reverse osmosis and advanced membrane technology. It will be the first desalination plant in Singapore to treat both sea water and freshwater from the Marina Reservoir.

site_title: Indonesia 2017 current account deficit will be less than 2.4% of GDP: central bank
summary: Indonesia's central bank expects the country's current account deficit to widen in 2017, but it will be smaller than 2.4% of GDP, according to Governor Agus Martowardojo. This is slightly below the earlier forecast of 2-2.5% of GDP. The 2016 current account deficit was 1.8% of GDP, smaller than the 2.04% deficit in 2015.

images.alt_text: Indonesia's central bank expects the country's current account deficit to widen in 2017 but it will be smaller than 2.4 per cent of gross domestic product, its governor said on Friday.

site_title: Europe: Stocks steady at open
summary: European stock markets opened steady on Friday, unaffected by Donald Trump's inauguration, as investors await further details on his economic policy. London's FTSE 100 remained unchanged, while the eurozone's DAX 30 and CAC 40 indices declined 0.2% and 0.1%, respectively. Markets are focusing on US-EU trade talks and the potential impact on mining and healthcare shares.

site_title: GE profit up 36%, sales slow; affirms 2017 forecast
summary: General Electric Co reported a 35.7% jump in quarterly profit to $3.48 billion, driven by strength in its power and renewable energy businesses. Despite a 2.4% decline in total revenue to $33.1 billion, the company reaffirmed its 2017 growth and profit forecasts, citing organic growth of 3-5%. Earnings per share rose to 39 cents from 26 cents, while adjusted earnings fell 2% to 46 cents per share, matching analyst estimates.

images.alt_text: General Electric Co reported a 35.7 per cent jump in quarterly profit on Friday, helped by strength in its power and renewable energy businesses, and affirmed its growth and profit forecasts for 2017.

site_title: Japan to conduct simulated drills for China-Taiwan clash: report
summary: Japan will conduct tabletop exercises from January 23-27 to simulate its response in a potential military clash between China and Taiwan. The US military will participate as an observer. The drills, which do not involve actual troop deployments, assume a US and Japanese response to a conflict. China's foreign ministry has urged Japan to stay out of the issue, calling it an "internal affair". The exercises test Japan's military capabilities under a new law that expanded its powers beyond self-defense.

site_title: Competition Commission seeks feedback on F&N's bid for Penguin Random House units (Amended)
summary: The Competition Commission of Singapore is seeking public feedback on Fraser and Neave's (F&N) proposed acquisition of Penguin Random House's Singapore and Malaysia distribution arms for S$8 million. F&N argues that even with exclusive distribution rights, publishers and retailers retain strong bargaining power, and the market for book distribution is highly competitive with multiple vertically integrated publishers and independent distributors. The public consultation will close on Feb 6, 2017.

images.alt_text: The Competition Commission of Singapore (CCS) is studying Fraser and Neave's (F&N) proposed acquisition of the Singapore and Malaysia distribution arms of global publisher Penguin Random House, and is seeking public feedback on the deal.

site_title: Shipper Orient says not aware of any bids for OOCL, shares dive
summary: Hong Kong-listed shipping company Orient Overseas International said it has not received any bids for its subsidiary OOCL, despite media reports suggesting China COSCO Shipping and others were interested in acquiring the company. Orient Overseas clarified that it had noted the reports but is not involved in any bid. Shares in Orient Overseas fell 10% after the news, following a strong rise earlier in the week on potential buyout rumors.

site_title: Ivanka Trump asks US to give her dad a chance
summary: Ivanka Trump urged Americans to give her father, President-elect Donald Trump, a chance as he prepares to be sworn in. In an interview, she admitted to advising him to cut out controversial tweets and emphasized the importance of giving him time to prove himself. Ivanka is stepping down from her family business and fashion label to avoid conflict of interest accusations. She also denied speculation that she will become de facto first lady, praising her stepmother Melania as an "incredible first lady." Ivanka's focus will be on traveling and listening to feedback on how she can add positive value in Washington.

site_title: Philippine central bank tightens anti-money laundering rules
summary: The Philippine central bank has tightened its anti-money laundering rules, requiring money-remittance firms to register and report suspicious transactions. New regulations aim to prevent dirty money and terrorist financing, with classifications and minimum capital requirements for firms. The rules also limit cash transactions and cap foreign currency sales by money changers. The move follows the revocation of a remittance company's license after it was linked to a $81 million heist from the Bangladesh central bank. The central bank's deputy governor said the updated framework would combat terrorist financing and slow down shadow banking activities.

images.alt_text: The Philippine central bank is tightening its surveillance of money-remittance firms to ensure they would not be used to launder dirty money and facilitate terrorist financing.

site_title: Malaysia: Stocks end lower
summary: Malaysian shares closed lower on Friday, with the Kuala Lumpur Composite Index losing 1.62 points to 1,664.89. The index saw 1.58 billion lots traded, with losers outnumbering gainers 428 to 300.

site_title: ASL Marine's note issues extended
summary: ASL Marine has successfully passed a motion to extend two note issues worth S$150 million, with the first issue, a S$100 million bond due in March 2017, proposed to pay a 5.5% coupon rate until March 2018.

site_title: Australia: Shares end lower ahead of Trump's inauguration; NZ declines
summary: Australian shares ended 0.7% lower, mirroring Wall Street, ahead of Donald Trump's inauguration. The S&P/ASX 200 index fell 37.38 points to 5,654.80, with financials and materials dragging the index down. Safe-haven buying pushed up gold prices, while miners dropped 1.8% to their biggest intraday loss since December 2016. New Zealand's benchmark index also fell 0.2% as utilities declined.

site_title: Impact of job-stealing robots a growing concern at Davos
