summary: Global CEOs at the World Economic Forum in Davos warn that job-stealing robots and technological advancements are a growing concern, with 86% of US manufacturing job losses attributed to productivity gains. The shift to skilled workers widens income gaps and fuels inequality. CEOs, including Microsoft's Satya Nadella, call for long-life training of workforces to keep up with technological advances. Economists estimate that 86% of US manufacturing job losses are due to productivity, rather than trade policies.

site_title: EC World Reit manager appoints deputy chief executive
summary: Alvin Cheng, a 25-year veteran in corporate finance and Reit management, has been appointed executive director and deputy CEO of EC World Asset Management, the manager of EC World Real Estate Investment Trust (Reit). Cheng will oversee business direction and strategy, while Johnnie Tng has been appointed CFO to replace Huang Jian. This move aims to strengthen the senior management team, with Cheng bringing experience in logistics and real estate management.

site_title: China cuts reserve ratios for five big banks temporarily amid cash squeeze: sources
summary: China's People's Bank of China has temporarily lowered the reserve requirement ratio (RRR) for its five largest banks by 1% to 16% to ease seasonal liquidity tightness ahead of the Lunar New Year holiday. The move aims to support the market as households and companies withdraw large amounts of cash. The RRR will be restored to its normal level after the holiday. This is China's first RRR cut since February 2016.

site_title: Singapore shares close lower in cautious trading; market waits for Trump policies
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) shares declined in cautious trading, mirroring Wall Street's uncertain performance. Despite breaking through the 3,000 level, the STI has drifted within narrow bands with a slightly downward bias. Turnover declined this week, with the average trading volume at S$914 million, down from last week's S$1.1 billion. The market waits for US President Trump's policies to take shape, which could impact global markets and reflation plays.

site_title: "Build Bridges Not Walls" - London's Tower Bridge draped with Trump protest banners
summary: A "Build Bridges Not Walls" banner was draped across London's Tower Bridge on January 20, 2017, as part of global protests against Donald Trump's presidency. The protest, organized by the "Bridges not Walls" campaign, aimed to express opposition to Trump's divisive policies. The event followed similar protests in cities worldwide, including Washington, Toronto, and Sydney, as Trump prepared to take office as the 45th US president.

site_title: Taiwan: Stocks rebound, techs up
summary: Taiwan's stocks rebounded 0.2% on Friday, driven by gains in technology shares, as investors awaited US President-elect Donald Trump's inauguration. The electronics subindex rose 0.3%, with Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co. and AU Optronics leading the gain. The Taiwan dollar strengthened against the US dollar. Despite the rebound, market sentiment remained cautious due to Trump's election.

site_title: New Zealand court lets Low family replace trustees in 1MDB-linked case
summary: A New Zealand court approved the replacement of Swiss trustees with New Zealand and Cayman Islands trust services companies to fight the US government's seizure of assets linked to the 1MDB scandal. Relatives of Malaysian businessman Low Taek Jho stand to lose US$260 million in assets, including a private jet and luxury real estate. The court ruled that the replacement is necessary to safeguard trust assets and ensure proper legal steps are taken in the California proceedings. The decision does not address the merits of the US government's allegations.

site_title: FCT posts 0.7% rise in Q1 DPU on higher proportion of management fees paid in units (Amended)
summary: FRASERS Centrepoint Trust (FCT) reported a 0.7% rise in Q1 distribution per unit (DPU) to 2.89 Singapore cents, driven by higher management fees received in units. Gross revenue fell 6.4% to S$44.08 million, mainly due to lower contributions from Northpoint, while net property income declined 5.7% to S$31.64 million.

site_title: Bin Laden documents: worry over IS tactics, 'aging' Al-Qaeda
summary: US intelligence documents released by the CIA reveal Osama bin Laden's concerns about the Islamic State's violent tactics and Al-Qaeda's decline in influence. In 2011, bin Laden fretted about keeping his followers aligned against the US, and expressed worries about potential electronic tracking. The documents also show bin Laden's personal life, including a warning to his sons about electronic tracking and advice to soldiers in Northern Africa on personal behavior. The findings provide insight into bin Laden's thinking before his death, highlighting his concerns about the evolving global jihadist landscape.

site_title: Hot stock: Civmec responds to SGX queries on trading activity
summary: Civmec Limited responded to Singapore Exchange (SGX) queries on its trading activity, attributing the recent high volume to previously announced project awards and shipbuilding facility expansion plans. The company received a signed memorandum of understanding (MOU) from a Singaporean/Australian defence initiative, but noted it is at a preliminary stage. Civmec's shares opened at 65.5 Singapore cents and fluctuated slightly, with 1.37 million shares changing hands on January 20, 2017.

site_title: Chow Tai Fook targets young Chinese with lower-priced bling
summary: Chow Tai Fook, the world's largest jeweller, is targeting young Chinese shoppers with lower-priced stores, introducing Monologue outlets with jewellery priced at 2,000 yuan (S$414) on average. The move aims to shore up sales, which are expected to fall for a third-straight year, amid economic slowdown and anti-corruption crackdowns. The company plans to open six more Monologue outlets in 2017, and will also launch a store specialising in wedding jewellery in April, as it attempts to revive flagging sales with new business models.

site_title: China extends Hollywood push with US$1b Paramount investment
summary: Viacom's Paramount Pictures receives a $1 billion cash investment from Chinese film companies Shanghai Film Group and Huahua Media, financing 25% of all Paramount films for the next three years. This deal aims to boost Paramount's growth and follows a trend of Chinese investors supporting US studios in the film industry. The partnership gives Paramount access to China's growing film market and may lead to future film productions in the country.

site_title: VGO shareholders approve plan to reduce share capital
summary: VGO Corporation has approved a plan to reduce its share capital by S$27.9 million, resulting in a paid-up share capital of S$4,000. This move is part of a reverse takeover that will give Malaysia's Hatten Group a backdoor listing in Singapore. As part of the deal, VGO will issue 1.2 billion new shares in exchange for full ownership of Sky Win Management Consultancy, Hatten's property development arm.

site_title: 'Dump Trump', say Philippine protesters
summary: Hundreds of Filipino protesters gathered outside the US embassy in Manila, denouncing Donald Trump's presidency and accusing him of sexism, racism, and xenophobia. The protesters, from leftist groups, expressed concerns about Trump's impact on Filipino immigrants in the US and symbolically dumped photos of him in a trash bin. The protesters also burned an American flag and reiterated demands for US troops to leave the Philippines and the tearing up of "unequal" military agreements.

site_title: Seoul: Won up on Yellen comment, stocks down as focus turns to Trump
summary: South Korea's won rose 0.7% to 1,169.2 won per US dollar following Federal Reserve Chair Janet Yellen's comments that were seen as less hawkish, supporting the currency's gains. The move came as stocks declined globally due to increased focus on US President Donald Trump's comments on the economy. Despite the negative impact, the won's gains were seen as a positive sign, while US stocks continued to edge towards fresh records despite uncertainty surrounding US trade policies.

site_title: Japan trade minister says not considering Toshiba rescue plan
summary: Japan's trade minister, Hiroshige Seko, stated that his ministry is not considering a rescue plan for Toshiba Corp, amid pressure from a potential US$6 billion writedown for its US nuclear business. Seko vowed to monitor Toshiba's management steps, but did not rule out assistance. Toshiba faces significant financial challenges, including a potential writedown and declining profits, but a rescue plan is not currently being explored by the Japanese government.

site_title: Shippers avoid new "pirate hotspot" in waters west of the Philippines
summary: Shipowners are diverting vessels through other waters to avoid piracy hotspots west of the Philippines, where 16 attacks have occurred since March, affecting US$40 billion worth of cargo annually. The Sulu and Celebes Seas have become the world's fastest-growing piracy hotspot, with crew members being held hostage by Abu Sayyaf militants. Shipping companies are incurring additional fuel costs of around US$300 per day, adding to the industry's already low profit margins, and are opting for routes east of the Philippines to prevent pirate attacks.

images.alt_text: A surge in piracy to the west of the Philippines is forcing shipowners to divert vessels through other waters, stoking their costs and extending the time it takes to transport goods such as Australian iron ore to key Asian destinations.

site_title: Las Vegas Sands pays US$7m to end US criminal bribery case
summary: Las Vegas Sands Corp agreed to pay a $6.96 million criminal penalty to end a US Department of Justice probe into alleged bribery of a consultant to secure business in China and Macau. The company admitted to failing to set up accounting controls and properly record payments, totaling $60 million, with $5.8 million paid without a legitimate business purpose. The resolution follows a related civil settlement with the SEC last year and reflects the company's cooperation and remedial measures. The fine is 25% below the minimum recommended under federal guidelines.

images.alt_text: The casino operator run by billionaire Sheldon Adelson on Thursday also entered a non-prosecution agreement, in which it admitted that executives knowingly failed to set up accounting controls to ensure that the payments were legitimate, and were properly recorded in its books and records.

site_title: Gold rises on weaker US dollar, caution over Trump
summary: Gold prices rose 0.3% to $1,207.80 per ounce, driven by a weaker US dollar ahead of Donald Trump's inauguration, which has sparked safe-haven buying. Trump's protectionist statements and mixed promises of tax cuts and infrastructure spending have increased demand for gold. The metal has risen 7% since December, approaching resistance at $1,219 per ounce. US Federal Reserve Chair Janet Yellen suggested the central bank may raise interest rates this year, but at a slow pace, potentially impacting gold prices.

site_title: China investors see silver lining for stocks as bonds tumble
summary: China investors are shifting their focus to stocks due to the recent decline in bond yields, which have risen 25 basis points to their highest in six years. This increase is attributed to the People's Bank of China's efforts to boost borrowing costs and curb speculative trading. As a result, stocks are seen as offering relative value, with improving corporate earnings and inflation concerns driving the shift. The Shanghai Composite Index has edged 0.5% higher, while government bonds have declined, with the 10-year yield reaching a 16-month high of 3.37%.

site_title: Update: Three dead, 20 injured after car hits pedestrians in Australian city Melbourne
summary: A man deliberately drove into pedestrians in Melbourne, Australia, killing three and injuring 20 in the city's central business district. The incident, which occurred in the Bourke Street mall, was not terror-related, police said. The driver, who was taken into custody, was seen driving recklessly before deliberately plowing into people. Authorities have locked down the city and suspended tram services, but the Australian Open tennis tournament continued to operate normally.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open flat on Friday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened flat on Friday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index up 0.18 points to 1665.16. Volume reached 76.06 million lots worth RM21.3 million, with gainers outnumbering losers 69 to 59.

site_title: Asian stocks, US dollar slip as Trump caution outweighs China GDP
summary: Asian stocks slipped as US President-elect Donald Trump's inauguration loomed, outweighing China's fourth-quarter GDP growth of 6.8%, beating forecasts. The US dollar fell after Federal Reserve Chair Janet Yellen took a less hawkish stance on monetary policy. Concerns about Trump's protectionist policies and China's debt risks also weighed on markets, with Asian stocks down 0.2% and the US dollar index slipping 0.2%.

site_title: US presidents pen gracious letters to their successors
summary: US Presidents Bill Clinton and George W. Bush have written heartfelt letters to their successors, offering words of wisdom and encouragement. Clinton's 2001 letter to Bush emphasized the importance of leading during a time of change, while Bush's 2009 letter to Barack Obama highlighted the challenges and support available to the new president. Both letters concluded with messages of hope and support for the incoming leaders. The tradition of presidential succession letters is expected to continue with President Obama's note to Donald Trump.

site_title: China asks foreign diplomats for closer cooperation in anti-graft war
summary: China has asked foreign diplomats to cooperate in its anti-graft war, seeking greater international assistance in combating corruption. Chinese President Xi Jinping has vowed to fight graft, warning of the party's future if corruption is not addressed. China has recovered $476.3 million in losses from graft in 70 countries and is publishing a list of 100 most-wanted suspects. However, China's under-developed legal system has hindered cooperation from foreign nations, and diplomats were briefed on efforts to update supervision mechanisms and seize overseas assets.

site_title: South Korea: Stocks tread water ahead of Trump inauguration; won firmer
summary: South Korean stocks declined 0.2% ahead of US President-elect Donald Trump's inauguration, with Samsung Electronics falling nearly 1%. A court dismissed an arrest warrant for Jay Y Lee, leader of Samsung Group, amid a graft scandal. The South Korean won strengthened 0.4% against the dollar. Despite this, analysts expect the KOSPI to gain in the coming days due to Trump's economic policies and upbeat fourth-quarter results from companies.

site_title: Singapore shares open lower on Friday
summary: Singapore share prices opened lower on Friday, with the Straits Times Index down 1.27 points to 3,006.95. Volume was 28.2 million shares worth S$28.9 million. Gainers outnumbered losers 44 to 41.

site_title: Trump arrives for inauguration with promise to unify the nation
summary: Donald Trump arrived in Washington for his inauguration, promising unity after a divisive election. He addressed thousands of supporters at the Lincoln Memorial, reiterating his campaign promises and saying he wants to make America great for everyone. Trump will be sworn in as the 45th US president on Friday, with his family and Vice President-elect Mike Pence in attendance. The inauguration events include a reception at Trump's hotel and a black-tie dinner at Union Station. The Senate will vote on confirming at least two of Trump's Cabinet secretaries, including Defense Secretary James Mattis, on Friday.

site_title: Trump wants to ditch 'Obamacare' but keep the gains
summary: US President-elect Donald Trump plans to repeal the Affordable Care Act (Obamacare) but aims to keep its gains, including expanded health coverage for millions of Americans. Trump has promised to leave no one out in the cold, despite concerns about the feasibility of universal coverage. Republicans propose a replacement plan with new refundable tax credits, high-risk pools, and no individual mandate, but critics warn of gaps in coverage and potential harm to pre-existing conditions. The plan faces significant challenges, including its complexity and the need for bipartisan support.

site_title: China Q4 GDP grows 6.8% y-o-y, slightly better than expectations
summary: China's economy grew 6.8% in Q4 2016, slightly better than expected, driven by higher government spending and record bank lending. This is the slowest pace in 26 years, but within the government's target range. Despite this, concerns remain about an explosive rise in debt and potential pressures from a more protectionist US stance under President Trump. China's sluggish exports and yuan currency depreciation could further weigh on its foreign exchange reserves, posing challenges for policymakers.

site_title: Australia shares fall, wary before Trump inauguration; NZ edge down
summary: Australian shares fell 0.6% on Friday, pressured by a weak US market ahead of President-elect Donald Trump's inauguration. Financials and resources sectors led losses, with the S&P/ASX 200 index on track to fall 1.1% for the week. The decline followed a 10.4% gain since November 9, as investors cut back on riskier assets. Meanwhile, New Zealand's benchmark index eased 0.1% as financials and industrials led losses.

site_title: A-listers join anti-Trump protest in hometown
summary: A-list celebrities including Robert de Niro, Alec Baldwin, and Cher joined thousands of protesters in New York City on the eve of Donald Trump's inauguration, protesting against the incoming Republican president. The protest took place near the Trump International Hotel on Central Park South, with a crowd gathering at Columbus Circle and Central Park West. The demonstration marked a show of opposition to Trump's presidency, with the celebrities' participation drawing attention to their stance against the new administration.

site_title: China 2016 property investment rises 6.9% in 2016
summary: China's real estate investment rose 6.9% in 2016, driven by a property boom in top-tier cities, according to official data. This growth contributed to China's overall economy expanding 6.7% in 2016, meeting expectations. Property sales increased 22.5% year-over-year, with national sales posting their strongest annual growth in seven years. The 6.9% increase in real estate investment is considered crucial for the economy, and the data suggests a robust property market in China.

site_title: Mystery 600b rupees in cash with Indians after Modi's shock ban
summary: India's surprise ban on high-denomination currency bills has led to a significant mismatch in cash supply, with 600 billion rupees withdrawn from circulation in the two months following the ban. As of January 13, Indians withdrew 9.7 trillion rupees, exceeding the 9.1 trillion rupees in circulation. Economists attribute the discrepancy to the sudden withdrawal of cash, with some speculating that the ban may not be effective in curbing black market activities. The Reserve Bank of India has yet to reconcile and publish final figures, leaving the full impact of the ban unclear.

site_title: These automakers could be Trump's next targets
summary: US President-elect Donald Trump may target Canadian automakers, including Fiat Chrysler, Ford, and General Motors, due to their significant presence in the country's Windsor, Ontario, and assembly plants. A 35% tariff on vehicle imports could have a chilling effect on the US auto industry, particularly in regions with high trade balances with Canada and Asia. The US trade gap with Canada is larger than with Mexico, and a widespread tariff could lead to job losses and higher vehicle prices, with estimates suggesting 37,000 jobs would be lost.

site_title: MH370: what's next in hunt for missing airliner
summary: The official search for Malaysia Airlines' missing airliner MH370 has been called off, but experts believe it will be found in the future. Despite spending nearly three years and $150 million on a deep-sea hunt, no conclusive evidence has been found. Treasure hunters and private firms may be involved in the search, potentially driven by a multi-million-dollar prize. Oceanographer Erik van Sebille suggests that deep-sea mining could lead to the discovery of MH370's wreckage. Investigators are reassessing evidence and exploring new leads, including the possibility of a rogue pilot or mechanical failure.

images.alt_text: The official search for MH370 may have been called off but experts believe the missing airliner will one day be found, perhaps either by deep-sea miners or treasure hunters lured by a huge cash reward.

site_title: 2017 growth may be better than expected with Asia to lead the way: Deloitte report
summary: Deloitte's report suggests that 2017 global growth may exceed expectations, driven by Asia's stabilizing economy, picking up trade, and consumer boom. Asia, particularly China, India, and ASEAN, is expected to lead the way, while the US economy is expected to stabilize. Consumer booms in China and India provide a defensive line against potential global growth slowdowns. However, significant risks remain, including financial market stresses and protectionism, and Asian economies are better positioned to mitigate these risks.

images.alt_text: The year 2017 may be better than expected despite protectionist rhetoric from the US and nervousness in the financial markets, according to Deloitte.

site_title: The most peaceful place on Earth may be in the middle of Tokyo
summary: The Hoshinoya Tokyo, Japan's first luxury ryokan in the city, offers a unique and peaceful experience amidst Tokyo's frenetic Otemachi financial district. The hotel features traditional Japanese-style rooms, communal hot-spring baths, and a serene atmosphere, making it a tranquil oasis in the midst of the bustling city. With a focus on cultural immersion and personalized service, the Hoshinoya provides an unparalleled experience for travelers, despite some language barriers and strict adherence to Japanese etiquette.

site_title: Australian dollar gets China boost, NZ up as S&P affirms AA rating
summary: The Australian dollar surged to a 2-1/2-month high, reaching US$0.7589, after China's economy expanded at a faster-than-expected pace in the fourth quarter of 2016. As Australia's No 1 trading partner, China's growth boost has a direct impact on the Aussie. The S&P affirmed Australia's AA rating, further supporting the currency's rise.

site_title: China default storm brewing as record junk debt comes due
summary: A default storm is brewing for China's lower-rated corporate bonds with a record amount maturing as borrowing costs surge. Regulators are curbing leverage, adding to challenges for weaker borrowers. In January, two companies missed payments, and 29 notes defaulted last year, up from seven in 2015. Analysts warn of huge redemption pressure for bond issuers, with investors at risk. The situation highlights the impact of China's regulatory efforts on the corporate bond market.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 1.71 points to 1666.90 on Thursday, driven by a 97-36 gain-to-lose ratio. Volume reached 54.6 million lots worth RM11.68 million.

site_title: WeChat suddenly looks like a threat to the iPhone
summary: WeChat, China's leading social media app, has launched a new platform called "mini programs" that embed third-party features within its app, eliminating the need for downloads and registrations. This concept solves two major problems plaguing the app model: large app sizes and tedious registration processes. With 768 million daily users, WeChat is poised to revolutionize smartphones, potentially threatening the iPhone and other operating systems, as users increasingly rely on the app for various services and commerce.

site_title: Fed's Yellen says global growth, fiscal policy key to outlook
summary: Federal Reserve Chair Janet Yellen stated that global growth and fiscal policy will be key factors in determining US interest rate policy. Despite uncertainty surrounding the Trump administration's spending policies, Yellen emphasized that monetary policy will depend on various factors, including global growth and fiscal policy. The Fed is expected to raise interest rates three times this year, but Yellen cautioned against allowing the economy to get too hot, warning that rapid rate hikes could disrupt financial markets and lead to recession.

site_title: Brexit destination for bankers may hinge on school for the kids
summary: Theresa May plans to trigger EU exit negotiations by March, potentially leading to a shift in the UK's financial hub. Cities competing for finance jobs may focus on educational institutions, as a skilled workforce could attract top talent. This could influence the UK's banking industry, particularly in terms of talent retention and relocation. The outcome may impact the country's ability to maintain its financial sector post-Brexit.

site_title: Stocks to watch: CMT, Oxley, SGX, Dasin Retail Trust
summary: Key companies announced significant changes before market opening on Friday, January 20, 2017. CapitaLand Mall Trust (CMT) declared a 2.88 Singapore cents quarterly distribution, unchanged from last year, resulting in an annualized yield of 5.82%. Oxley Holdings reported a net profit of S$123.75 million for the second quarter, up from S$47 million a year ago, due to revenue recognition from Oxley Tower. The Singapore Exchange (SGX) expects more new listings in the next six months, while Dasin Retail Trust's public offer was subscribed 7.6 times, starting trading on SGX on Friday.

site_title: US dollar steadies ahead of Trump inauguration, euro rebounds
summary: The US dollar steadied ahead of Donald Trump's inauguration, holding at 101.17 on the US dollar index, despite earlier gains due to upbeat US job and housing data. The euro rebounded after the European Central Bank maintained policy steady. These moves came as investors prepared for Trump's inauguration, with no significant changes in monetary policy announced.

site_title: Brazil housing starts jump 76% in November: report
summary: Brazil's housing starts surged 76.1% in November, according to a real estate research report. This marks a significant increase from the same month in 2015 and a 26% rise from October. Home sales rose 10.1% to 10,100 units, while sales cancellations fell 20.2% from last year. The Abrainc-Fipe index indicates available inventory would cover 12.6 months' worth of demand, suggesting a positive outlook for the country's economy.

site_title: Oil rises from 1-week low, US inventory data in focus
summary: US oil prices rose from a one-week low, with Brent crude up 51 US cents to $54.43 a barrel. US West Texas Intermediate crude oil traded up 46 US cents to $51.54 a barrel. The market awaits weekly US inventory data, which has been delayed due to a US public holiday. Opec said producer cuts should help stabilize the oil market in 2017, but a rebound in US output amid higher oil prices is possible. The global oil market is expected to move into a deficit in the first half of 2017.

site_title: GM plans US$1b US investment in latest bow to Trump
summary: General Motors (GM) plans a $1 billion US investment in new models and plant updates, adding or retaining approximately 7,000 salaried and hourly workers, including 2,000 in domestic factories. This move follows pressure from President-elect Donald Trump to create jobs, with GM already planning to bring axle production to Michigan operations and add 1,500 workers. The investment is part of GM's annual $9 billion capital expenditures, and the company has previously announced $2.9 billion in US investment in 2016.

site_title: Trump soaks up Washington pageantry on inauguration eve
summary: Donald Trump arrived in Washington on Thursday, embracing patriotism and unity on the eve of his inauguration as 45th US president. The 70-year-old leader traveled from New York to a military base near the capital with his wife Melania. Trump's inauguration marks the beginning of a new era for the nation, as he takes the reins from President Barack Obama at noon on Friday.

site_title: Business trusts need to adopt new financial framework: MAS
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has announced that registered business trusts listed in Singapore must adopt a new financial framework, while authorised collective investment schemes (CIS) will continue to use existing accounting practices. This decision aims to enhance transparency and consistency in financial reporting.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's non-oil domestic exports rose 9.4% year-on-year in December 2016, according to trade data. Moody's expects Singapore's three largest banks to face downward pressure on asset quality and profitability in 2017, but the impact will be manageable. Fourteen financial institutions are participating in a debt consolidation plan, while CapitaLand is developing an office tower in Ho Chi Minh City. Several companies, including Healthway Medical and DBS Bank, are raising funds through note issues.

site_title: Hanjin Shipping shares soar a day after exchange calls stock 'trash'
summary: Hanjin Shipping shares rose 15% after a Korean stock exchange official called them "trash" on January 17, 2017. The company, on the verge of bankruptcy, is popular among retail investors seeking double-digit profits. Foreign investors sold 2 billion won of shares, while individual investors bought 1.9 billion won. Volatility is high, with the stock being the most-traded on the Kospi index over the past two days.

site_title: Boutique investment bank LionTree to open Paris office
summary: LionTree, a boutique investment bank specializing in media, technology, and telecommunications, plans to open a Paris office led by Fatine Layt. The new office aims to provide in-market insights and expertise to clients seeking opportunities in France and the European Union. Paris is considered a key market for LionTree, with a focus on sectors such as financial technology, mobile apps, and sports. The move follows LionTree's existing operations in New York, San Francisco, and London.

site_title: South Korea: Stocks rise on Samsung Electronics rebound; won edges down
summary: South Korean stocks rose 0.5% on Tuesday, driven by a rebound in shares of major companies like Samsung Electronics and SK Hynix. The Korea Composite Stock Price Index (KOSPI) reached 2,075.15 points. Samsung Electronics gained nearly 2% after falling 2.1% the previous day, while SK Hynix rose 1%. The sub-index for electric and electronics companies rose 1.7%. The won edged down against the US dollar.

site_title: Europe: Stock markets drop before key Brexit speech
summary: Europe's main stock markets dropped on Tuesday, with London's FTSE 100 index falling 0.3% to 7,308.49 points, and the eurozone's DAX 30 and Paris CAC 40 indices also losing 0.3% and 0.4% respectively. British Prime Minister Theresa May was set to deliver a speech on Brexit strategy, favoring a "clean break" from the European Union, potentially signaling a hard Brexit. The speech may limit its impact on stocks and the pound.

site_title: Inflation expectations rise to 2.7%: SMU survey
summary: Inflation expectations in Singapore rose to 2.7% from 2.63% in September 2016, according to a December 2016 survey by Singapore Management University. This is lower than the historical average of 3.5% and the fourth quarter average of 2.72%. The new median inflation rate is a five-year low.

site_title: Asean an important 'life raft' in uncertain climate: PM Lee
summary: Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong described the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (Asean) as a crucial "life raft" in uncertain global times, citing recent global events such as the UK's Brexit and US presidential election. He urged Asean member states to boost air links, tap tourism potential, and develop talent to strengthen regional cooperation. This comes as the global environment becomes increasingly uncertain, with rising economic pressures and geopolitical shifts.

site_title: Sunac's US$2b LeEco injection making investors nervous
summary: Sunac China Holdings' investment of US$2.2 billion in LeEco, a cash-strapped Chinese tech giant, has raised concerns among investors. The investment, part of a larger deal, has led to a 10% decline in Sunac's stock price, the largest intraday drop in over 16 months. Analysts question the synergy between Sunac's real estate business and LeEco's tech holdings, and worry about the impact on Sunac's net gearing. Chairman Sun Hongbin expects rapid growth for Sunac, but acknowledges concerns about the investment's viability.

site_title: Berkshire unit buys NYC-area property firm
summary: HomeServices of America Inc, a unit of Warren Buffett's Berkshire Hathaway Inc, has purchased Houlihan Lawrence, a New York City-area residential real estate firm, its second NYC-area acquisition this month. Houlihan Lawrence, established in 1888, has 1,300 employees and 30 offices in New York and Connecticut, with a sales volume of $6.7 billion last year. The deal does not disclose terms, but CEO Ron Peltier notes that millennials and first-time buyers have shown interest in buying homes in the New York area despite softness in the luxury housing market.

site_title: Coal burns bright for top exporter Indonesia as demand gets hot
summary: Indonesia is expected to exceed its coal production target for the third consecutive year, with an estimated 489 million tonnes produced in 2017, 18% above the government-mandated target. The country's coal prices have recovered from a five-year collapse, with prices reaching a seven-month high of $101.69 a tonne in December. Despite efforts to preserve resources for future generations, Indonesia's coal output remains high due to resurgent prices tempting producers to maximize output.

site_title: Public Accounts body urges holistic solutions, stronger leadership to address lapses
summary: The Public Accounts Committee of Singapore has urged the government to adopt holistic solutions and stronger leadership to address recurring lapses in public finance management. The committee found issues with changes to contracted works, lack of reasonable cost assessments, and inadequate financial controls. It also identified a need for proper training for officers handling public funds and the sharing of knowledge across agencies. The committee called for heads of agencies to set a good governance tone and for the Ministry of Finance to improve knowledge sharing across the public sector.

site_title: Singapore retail sales up 1.1% in Nov on surge in car sales
summary: Singapore retail sales rose 1.1% in November 2016 compared to the same month a year ago, driven by a 17% increase in motor vehicle sales. However, excluding motor vehicle sales, retail sales declined 2.1%. The total retail sales value was estimated at S$3.6 billion, similar to the previous year.

site_title: SIAS urges shareholders to vote rationally on China New Town's delisting from SGX
summary: The Securities Investors Association of Singapore (SIAS) has urged independent shareholders of China New Town Development Company to vote rationally on the company's delisting from the Singapore Exchange (SGX). The delisting proposal ensures the rights of independent shareholders are preserved, as majority shareholders cannot vote. SIAS president David Gerald emphasized the importance of understanding the company's fundamentals, business strategy, and benefits of leveraging controlling shareholder CDB Capital's support.

site_title: CIA chief urges Trump to temper impulses amid Russia claims
summary: CIA Director John Brennan warned President-elect Donald Trump to temper his impulsive style amid allegations of Russian interference in the 2016 US election. Brennan stated that Trump's words have significant impact on national security, and urged him to be disciplined in his public statements. US intelligence agencies claim Russia interfered in the election to boost Trump and harm Hillary Clinton, with evidence including hacked Democratic Party computers and media manipulation. Brennan expressed concerns that Trump's spontaneity could put national security at risk.

site_title: Samsung heir is a suspect in corruption scandal: prosecutors
summary: Samsung heir Lee Jae-yong has become a suspect in a corruption scandal involving impeached South Korean President Park Geun-hye. Prosecutors accuse Lee of bribery and coercion in connection with the scandal, which centers on Park's secret confidante Choi Soon-sil. Lee is to be questioned as a suspect in connection with bribing Choi to secure state approval for a 2015 merger that benefited Samsung. Prosecutors have raided multiple Samsung offices and the National Pension Service, a major Samsung shareholder, in connection with the scandal. Lee's arrest is possible, but not confirmed, by prosecutors.

site_title: Gold hovers below 7-week top; copper touches 5-week high
summary: Gold prices hovered below a 7-week high on Friday, rising 0.2% to $1,197.99 an ounce, as the US dollar weakened and Treasury yields fell. The metal is on track for a third straight weekly gain. Analysts attribute the price increase to a weakening US dollar and expectations of a potential Federal Reserve rate hike. Copper reached a 5-week high, while aluminium and other metals also rose due to strong demand from China and expectations of increased infrastructure spending under President-elect Donald Trump.

site_title: As London softens on pace of Brexit, Brussels appears to harden
summary: London appears to be softening its stance on a temporary transitional agreement with Brussels to facilitate its exit from the European Union, while European leaders seem to be hardening their positions. Despite economic logic favoring a transitional deal, senior EU officials question the feasibility of such an agreement, citing concerns about Britain's willingness to accept terms. Prime Minister Theresa May intends to set a two-year clock for exit negotiations, and any hint of accepting a transitional arrangement could make headlines.

site_title: Britain's goals may end in a bigger, perhaps stronger EEA
summary: British Prime Minister Theresa May's ambiguous statements on the UK's post-Brexit trade relationship with the European Union may be a calculated move to gain time and strengthen the UK's negotiating position. May is aiming for a deal that allows the UK to maintain two-way trade access to the single market without accepting EU rules on free movement of people. This could potentially lead to the UK joining a larger and more powerful European Economic Area, which may gain traction as European governments move to the right in upcoming elections.

site_title: Australia job vacancies highest since mid-2011: ABS
summary: Australia's job vacancies have reached the highest level since mid-2011, with a 2.1% increase to 182,000 seasonally adjusted in the September-November quarter. Vacancies in the private sector climbed 2.4% to 164,700, while public sector vacancies remained steady at 17,300. Analysts value the vacancies series as a reliable leading indicator of labour demand and turning points in employment growth, suggesting an improvement in labour demand.

site_title: Hunger for Aussie bank paper shows few signs of slowing
summary: Australia's banks continue to seek funding in the local bond market, with Commonwealth Bank of Australia selling A$2.65 billion of notes in the first week of 2017. This follows a record year of fundraising by the country's four largest banks, and investors remain comfortable with buying their debt despite potential concerns over a possible downgrade to Australia's sovereign credit rating. The appetite for bank debt is driven by yield-starved buyers from Asia and Europe, attracted to higher yields on Australian corporate notes compared to global company bonds.

site_title: China hikes anti-dumping duties on US DDGS in final ruling
summary: China has increased anti-dumping duties on US distillers' dried grains (DDGS) to 42.2-53.7% and anti-subsidy tariffs to 11.2-12%, following a probe that found the domestic industry suffered substantial harm due to subsidized US imports. The move affects US ethanol industry companies such as Archer Daniels Midland Co and Valero Energy Corp, potentially escalating a trade spat between the world's two largest economies. The rates will take effect from Thursday and remain in force for five years.

site_title: Tesla taps Apple engineer for Autopilot software
summary: Tesla has hired Chris Lattner, a former Apple engineer, as vice-president of Autopilot software, marking a significant win for the electric carmaker. Lattner, who led the development of Swift programming language, will oversee Autopilot's software efforts. The move comes after SpaceX's Jinnah Hosein took over the interim role, and follows a fatal crash in Florida where Autopilot was examined by federal safety regulators. Lattner's hire is seen as a boost to Tesla's Autopilot system, which allows self-driving in some situations but requires driver attention.

site_title: Trump's choice for US attorney general says he can stand up to him
summary: US President-elect Donald Trump's nominee for attorney general, Senator Jeff Sessions, has promised to stand up to Trump and enforce laws he disagrees with, including a 2015 law against waterboarding. Sessions said he would oppose a ban on Muslims entering the US, enforce the law, and not support a Muslim travel ban. He also expressed support for investigations into Hillary Clinton's email practices and expressed opposition to a path to citizenship for immigrants. Despite protests from human rights groups, Sessions is widely expected to be confirmed by the Republican-controlled Senate.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks open lower as energy firms sink
summary: Hong Kong stocks fell in the opening minutes of trade, tracking losses on Wall Street due to a sharp drop in oil prices. The Hang Seng Index decreased 8.63 points to 22,550.06, while the Shanghai Composite Index slid 0.12% to 3,167.57. Energy firms led the decline, contributing to the overall drop.

site_title: Australia bank rally leaves fund managers breathless
summary: Australian banks have experienced a 20% surge in value since November 9, driven by optimism over global growth. The largest banks in Australia, including Westpac, Commonwealth, National Australia, and Australia & New Zealand Banking, have reached their highest levels since August 2015. Despite concerns over valuation, investor bearishness has declined, and short interest has decreased. Fund managers, such as T Rowe Price, are cautious, but some, like Contango Asset Management, believe the rally has passed and banks are now at "fullish value".

site_title: To stay relevant, critical for banks to jump on the digital train
summary: Banks must adapt to the digital age by embracing new technologies to stay relevant to younger consumers. The use of mobile devices and digital channels is driving changes across industries, with Asia Pacific expected to reach 3.1 billion mobile subscribers by 2020. Fintech startups, such as coins.ph, are attracting customers with affordable financial services, forcing traditional banks to transform quickly. Cloud computing is enabling banks like DBS and Capital One to scale, innovate, and provide personalized digital experiences, reducing costs and increasing resilience.

site_title: China inflation eases but producer prices spike
summary: China's inflation eased in December with the consumer price index (CPI) rising 2.1% year-over-year, below expectations. However, producer prices reached a five-year high due to strong commodity prices. Mild winter temperatures kept food prices in check. Despite the easing inflation, China's GDP growth is expected to slow, putting pressure on policymakers.

site_title: Europe: Stock markets rise at open
summary: Europe's main stock markets rose at the start of trading on Monday, with London hitting a new record high. London's FTSE 100 climbed 0.4% to 7,237.99 points, while Frankfurt's DAX 30 index and Paris CAC 40 also edged up 0.1% each. The gains were attributed to mining and healthcare stocks, while US-EU trade talks were also in focus.

site_title: Companies race to turn data into digital gold
summary: Big tech companies are racing to turn data into a valuable resource, as governments consider regulating data collection and use to prevent monopolies. Companies like Google, Facebook, and Microsoft are investing heavily in data-driven services, using machine learning and artificial intelligence to analyze and distribute data. This trend is expected to continue, with companies like IBM and Amazon also betting on data-driven strategies. Experts warn that if not regulated, data collection could become a barrier to new entrants and innovation, potentially stifling competition and limiting consumer choice.

site_title: HK stocks close higher, China ends down
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose for a fourth-straight session, boosted by data showing Chinese factory gate prices rose at their fastest pace in over five years. The Hang Seng Index rose 0.83%, while the Shanghai and Shenzhen Composite Indices fell 0.30% and 0.24%, respectively.

site_title: Ancient craft of book repair set to die out as few people are picking up the skill
summary: The ancient craft of book repair is on the verge of extinction due to the decline in book maintenance and handling by the public. Automated sorting machines and conveyor belts at public libraries can cause damage to books, shortening their lifespan. As a result, book repair skills are no longer being passed down to new generations, putting the art at risk of disappearing.

site_title: British PM May denies her Brexit strategy is 'muddled'
summary: British Prime Minister Theresa May has denied being "muddled" in her Brexit strategy, stating she will outline her approach over the coming weeks. May's comments come amid growing pressure from business leaders and lawmakers for more detail on her plan to leave the EU. Despite this, she pledged to secure the best possible deal, offering little beyond that.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks open higher after Wall St record
summary: Hong Kong stocks opened higher on Monday, tracking a record close on Wall Street after data showed a healthy increase in US jobs and wages. The Hang Seng Index gained 0.31%, while the Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index fell 0.18% and 0.12% respectively. This follows a record close on Wall Street, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq edging to fresh records despite tariff uncertainty.

site_title: Asia: Stocks bounce on US cues though US dollar gains may clip wings
summary: Asian stocks rose on Monday, driven by a strong US market, despite concerns over the US dollar's impact on Asian markets. The US dollar strengthened after payrolls data showed sustained wage growth, increasing the likelihood of more rate hikes in 2017. Hong Kong shares rose 0.4% and Australia's S&P/ASX200 rose 1%, while the MSCI ex-Japan Asia-Pacific shares index gained 0.3%. Despite growing worries over President-elect Donald Trump's stance on trade, capital flows into Asia remained positive, with nearly $600 million invested in the week ending January 4.

site_title: After banknote ban, India sees 7% growth in first half of 2017/18
summary: India's economy is expected to experience 7% growth in the first half of the 2017/18 fiscal year, exceeding initial projections. Despite Prime Minister Narendra Modi's decision to abolish large banknotes, the economy has shown resilience. The government plans to cut its fiscal deficit to 3% of GDP and allocate funds for investments and infrastructure spending. Tax incentives for individuals and firms may be announced to boost consumer demand. A rise in farm subsidies and spending on infrastructure could also support growth, particularly in the second half of the year.

site_title: LuxLeaks whistleblowers to hear appeal result
summary: A Luxembourg court will decide on an appeal by two whistleblowers in the "Luxleaks" tax scandal on March 15. Former PricewaterhouseCoopers employees Antoine Deltour and Raphael Halet were originally sentenced to 12 months and 9 months respectively. Prosecutors now recommend reduced sentences, while Deltour's lawyer argues for complete acquittal. The LuxLeaks scandal exposed Luxembourg's tax breaks for major international companies, prompting global action against tax avoidance and changes to EU tax policies.

images.alt_text: Former PricewaterhouseCoopers employee Antoine Deltour (right) was given a 12-month jail sentence and colleague Raphael Halet (left) nine months at the original trial in June.

site_title: Oil prices dip on lingering doubts of supply cut commitments
summary: Oil prices fell on Friday due to lingering doubts about producers' commitment to announced production cuts. Brent crude futures dropped 13 US cents to $56.76 per barrel, while WTI crude futures fell 11 US cents to $53.65 per barrel. Analysts say current prices are near break-even levels, with little reason for further rises unless unforeseen outages occur. Doubts remain about OPEC's ability to deliver on its production cuts, with some countries potentially cheating or not complying.

site_title: Highest-paid US executives supervise doctors, not bankers
summary: US executives in healthcare and pharmaceutical businesses earned the highest average pay packages at $37 million, surpassing those in financial services ($33.8 million) and information technology ($35.3 million). Notable outliers include Patrick Soon-Shiong ($329.7 million) and Paul Taubman ($164 million). The Bloomberg Pay Index, which ranks executives based on disclosed compensation, found that severance payments and equity awards contributed to the high earnings of executives in energy, particularly Atlas Energy Group CEO Edward Cohen ($73.5 million).

site_title: Portuguese private bank BCP hikes capital, Chinese stake rises
summary: Portugal's largest private bank, BCP, announced a share sale of 1.33 billion euros to pay off 700 million euros in debts to the state and strengthen its balance sheet. Chinese conglomerate Fosun Industrial Holdings, which already owns 16.7% of BCP, will nearly double its stake to 30% after buying more shares. The funds will also be used to bring the bank's capital adequacy ratio to 11.4%. This move is part of a larger bailout plan for Portugal's banking sector, which has been saddled with debt and bad loans.

site_title: Service industries in US expand at faster pace than forecast
summary: US service industries expanded at a faster pace than forecast in December, with the Institute for Supply Management's non-manufacturing index holding at 57.2, the highest level since October 2015. This signals growth in industries making up nearly 90% of the economy. Bookings at service producers were the strongest since August 2015, and the ISM's measure of service-related business activity was near the highest in over a year. The strong finish to 2016 suggests the economy will gain momentum in 2017, with President-elect Donald Trump aiming to boost economic growth and increase hiring.

site_title: Cheating death can cost US$200,000 as cancer tops pharma sales
summary: Cancer treatments are expected to dominate the US$519 billion global pharmaceuticals market this year, with prices surpassing US$200,000 a year for some revolutionary new treatments. This is stoking patients' distress and creating a rift between manufacturers, health authorities, and payers. Oncology medicines are poised to take the biggest share, eclipsing cardiovascular and metabolic diseases. The high costs are forcing doctors to question whether the benefit is worth the cost, and some patients are struggling to afford treatment, with Express Scripts and CVS Health Corp starting to push back against brand-name oncology drugs.

site_title: China Mengniu offers to buy out Modern Dairy for US$826m
summary: China Mengniu Dairy Co Ltd has offered to buy out China Modern Dairy Holdings Ltd for US$826 million, securing a stable supply of raw milk. The offer, valued at HK$1.94 apiece, represents a 7-per cent premium to the previous day's close. China Mengniu will fund the purchase through internal resources and external debt facilities, with the deal expected to enhance business collaboration and ensure a continuous supply of high-quality and safe raw milk. The acquisition will boost China Mengniu's stake in Modern Dairy to 91 per cent.

site_title: Oil higher as Opec delivers on output cuts, US dollar dives
summary: Oil prices rose on Tuesday as the Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries (Opec) achieved 82% compliance with its production cuts, exceeding market forecasts. The weak US dollar also contributed to the price increase. However, month-end profit taking limited the gains, and prices closed marginally higher. The higher oil prices are a positive sign for the industry, but the market remains volatile due to ongoing global economic and geopolitical uncertainty.

site_title: Bond trading's the star at Wall Street banks
summary: Wall Street's five biggest banks reported a 46% year-over-year increase in revenue from bond trading, contributing $11.7 billion to their collective top line. The surge in trading volumes was driven by investors reworking their portfolios in response to the US presidential election and interest rate hike. Despite regulatory restrictions, bank executives attribute the gains to more clients doing more trading and a shift towards a more team-like atmosphere on trading floors. This marks a significant departure from the risk-taking culture of the past, with banks adapting to a new environment and learning to operate without taking on excessive risk.

site_title: Pranksters change iconic Hollywood sign to 'Hollyweed'
summary: Thieves altered the iconic Hollywood sign to read "Hollyweed" on New Year's Eve, covering two "O"s with tarps to make them resemble "E"s. The stunt, which required considerable athleticism, may be linked to California's new marijuana legalization law. The move is not the first such incident, with a similar change made 41 years ago by a college art student, and comes after increased security measures were put in place to prevent similar pranks. Police are treating the incident as misdemeanor trespassing and are reviewing surveillance footage to identify the culprits.

site_title: 2017 markets await Trump's pro-business policies
summary: US stock markets await President Trump's pro-business policies in 2017, following a 14% gain in the Dow Jones Industrial Average in 2016. Trump's cabinet, comprising business executives, may push for tax cuts and infrastructure spending, potentially boosting economic growth. However, foreign policy risks, including relations with Russia and the potential for a trade war with China, could impact the market. The dollar's strength and volatility in oil prices also pose challenges. Analysts expect Trump to move quickly on tax cuts, but the path forward remains uncertain.

site_title: Hong Kong, Shanghai: Stocks slip in opening trade
summary: Hong Kong and Shanghai stocks opened lower on January 20, 2017, ahead of Chinese economic growth figures and the US presidential inauguration. The Hang Seng Index fell 0.61% to 22,910.44, while the Shanghai Composite Index dropped 0.18% to 3,095.82. The decline was attributed to market nerves over the economic figures and US presidential transition.

site_title: Trump talks to US automakers, pushes for new American plants
summary: US President Donald Trump met with the CEOs of the Big Three automakers, General Motors, Ford, and Fiat Chrysler, to push for new American plants and discourage investments in Mexico. Trump urged the companies to cut regulations and taxes to make it more attractive for businesses to operate in the US, promising to impose 35% tariffs on imported vehicles if they don't comply. The meeting came as US automakers have been expanding operations at existing US plants and adding jobs, but also cutting production of small cars.

site_title: Joshua, the Hong Kong teen taking on the might of China
summary: Hong Kong teenager Joshua Wong, 20, is hailed as a hero for leading a movement demanding elections free from Beijing's interference. At 17, he spearheaded mass blockades in 2014, sparking a global interest in social movements. Wong's activism began at 13, and he was arrested in 2014 alongside 77 others. Despite facing backlash, he remains optimistic, vowing to continue fighting for a referendum on Hong Kong's future. The award-winning Netflix documentary "Joshua: Teenager vs Superpower" showcases his journey, highlighting his determination to bring about change.

site_title: Plane with expelled diplomats leaves US: Russian media
summary: A plane carrying 35 Russian diplomats expelled from the US, along with their families, departed from Washington on January 1, 2017. The diplomats were given 72 hours to leave the country after President Barack Obama's sanctions package was announced. The US claims the Kremlin ordered a hack-and-release of Democratic Party emails to influence the presidential election. Russia denies the allegations, and President Vladimir Putin has ruled out sending home US diplomats in retaliation, instead seeking closer ties with President-elect Donald Trump.

site_title: The essentials for a sharing economy
summary: Singapore needs to establish regulations for the sharing economy to ensure safety and trust, while being business-friendly. The government should develop and implement a framework for overseeing sharing and trust activities, including identity verification and data analytics. A government agency, such as the Smart Nation Programme Office, could coordinate and promote sharing and trust economy activities. The government may also need to provide more useful data and information for businesses to move the sharing and trust economy forward.

images.alt_text: As more data is collected, through ride-sharing apps for example, the authorities should develop the infrastructure and analytics to protect this data and let it be used meaningfully to help businesses grow.

site_title: Europe: Stocks Advance as data confirms manufacturing strength
summary: European stocks advanced, erasing earlier losses, after Italy's better-than-expected economic data confirmed a trend of stronger manufacturing in the euro area. The Euro Stoxx 50 index rose 0.4%, while the DAX index in Germany jumped 0.8%, its best day in almost three weeks. Manufacturing PMI in Italy and Germany reached 53.2 and 55.6, respectively, marking the fastest expansion since 2011. This data suggests the euro area's recovery is intact heading into 2017, with the Stoxx Europe 600 Index up 0.5%.

site_title: Citigroup punished for treasury market spoofing by five traders
summary: Citigroup has been fined $25 million by the US Commodity Futures Trading Commission for allegedly engaging in 2,500 instances of treasury market spoofing between 2011 and 2012. The traders involved were not named, and the bank neither admitted to nor denied the allegations. The fine is the largest spoofing settlement to date, and regulators have stepped up their policing of the practice, which involves entering fake orders to manipulate market prices.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Hotung Investment Holdings is one of the pioneers in venture capital, operating in Taiwan, China, and Silicon Valley, with 200 companies listed globally. Despite a 30% decline in net profit in 2016, the group is expected to support a dividend of 12 cents, representing an 8% yield. Trading at 0.5 times price to book, Hotung is considered undervalued. Viva Industrial Trust has completed a logistics acquisition for S$87.3 million, but its distribution per unit is forecast to drop.

site_title: 'Trumponomics' threatens to disrupt supply chains, and trade
summary: US President Donald Trump's "Trumponomics" is disrupting global trade and supply chains, threatening to slow world trade growth and economic growth in the medium to long term. The Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development, International Monetary Fund, and others have noted global trade's decline, citing factors such as slowing economic growth and changing supply chains. Trump's border-tax threat to companies like Toyota Motor Corporation will further complicate global supply chains, potentially leading to a "zero sum" or "beggar thy neighbour" game, where one country's gain is another's loss.

site_title: Gold rises to two-month high on Trump policy uncertainty, US dollar drop
summary: Gold prices rose to a two-month high on January 23, 2017, amid uncertainty around US President Donald Trump's economic policies and a decline in the US dollar. Spot gold rose 0.7% to $1,217.81 per ounce, while US gold futures gained 1.1% to $1,218.20. Investors sought safer assets due to concerns about protectionist trade policies, with the US dollar index falling 0.4% to 100.310.

site_title: Philippines Q4 farm output shrinks 1.11% y-o-y on strong typhoons
summary: The Philippines' agricultural output decreased 1.11% in Q4 2016 compared to the previous year, primarily due to strong typhoons affecting crops and fisheries production. The sector experienced a full-year contraction of 1.41%, with crops accounting for the largest decline of 3.32%. The paddy rice harvest fell 2.9% to 17.63 million tonnes, below the government's forecast of 17.91 million tonnes.

site_title: US: Stocks gain across sectors ahead of Trump inauguration
summary: US stocks rose ahead of Donald Trump's inauguration as the 45th president, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average up 109.18 points, or 0.55%, at 19,841.58. Investors are waiting to see Trump's economic policies, with a calm day expected due to the inauguration. The dollar index edged up and energy stocks rose 2% on oil price gains. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also increased, with the Nasdaq up 0.6% at 5,573.53.

site_title: Local pro game needs a lift
summary: Singapore's professional golf scene is struggling due to lack of corporate sponsorship, with only 15 playing pros. Quincy Quek, ranked No. 2, is under pressure to perform to raise the country's golf profile. The past year has seen no Singaporean pro win a Tour event, no local golfer qualify for the Rio Olympics, and a slump in overall support. Quek must work hard to secure spots on regional Tours and revive the women's pro game, which is in near-oblivion, to attract sponsors and revive the sport.

images.alt_text: While Quek has made major strides since he turned pro in 2009, the professional game in Singapore has stagnated because of a lack of overall support.

site_title: US: Wall Street dips on Trump protectionism, Qualcomm drag
summary: US stocks declined on Monday, edging lower due to President Donald Trump's protectionist stance on trade, as he signed a formal withdrawal from the Trans-Pacific partnership trade deal and vowed to renegotiate the North American Free Trade Agreement. The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 27.4 points, and the S&P 500 lost 6.11 points, as investors gauge the potential impact of Trump's approach to trade, economics, and regulation. The US dollar hit a seven-week low, while energy stocks declined 1.1%, and Qualcomm tumbled 12.7% after Apple filed a $1 billion lawsuit against the chip supplier.

site_title: Valiram eyeing further expansion in 2017
summary: Valiram, a Malaysia-based retail and lifestyle group, plans to expand its network in 2017 by adding New Zealand to its geographical portfolio and deepening its presence in existing markets. The group aims to open up to 100 new stores across its various markets, with a focus on core brands such as Bath & Body Works, Tumi, Michael Kors, Victoria's Secret, and Kate Spade. Valiram's executive director, Mukesh Valiram, believes that despite a tough retail environment in Singapore, brands offering good value and creative concepts will succeed, and the group is keen to expand into sportswear and food and beverage.

images.alt_text: "We're still growing, we're profitable. (In three to five years) ... the company would be quite sizeable to warrant a listing status," says Mr Mukesh Valiram.

site_title: Small projection that's big on content
summary: Skullmapping, an artistic collective founded by Filip Sterckx and Antoon Verbeeck, has created a virtual reality culinary experience called Le Petit Chef, where a projected animation chef cooks a meal at a table for four diners. The duo, known for their artistic and fine art backgrounds, aims to create poetic and artistic projects, rather than massive visual spectacles. They believe that strong content is key to engaging audiences, citing Pixar's Toy Story as an example. The project straddles between art and entertainment, with the goal of bringing magic and wonder to a wide audience, rather than seeking to impact the contemporary art world.

images.alt_text: What sets Le Petit Chef apart from other projection mapping projects is first of all the scale.
Skullmapping is an artistic collective founded by Filip Sterckx (right) and Antoon Verbeeck.

site_title: India's steel ministry seeks lower import taxes on key raw materials
summary: India's steel ministry is seeking lower import taxes on key raw materials, including nickel, to protect the domestic industry from rising costs. Finance Minister Arun Jaitley may announce measures, including scrapping the 5% import duty on nickel, in the upcoming budget. The ministry is also seeking lower dividend payouts from state-owned steel companies and relief from banks. Additionally, the steel ministry has requested a budget allocation of 400 million rupees for research and development, with South Korean steel maker Hyundai Steel showing interest in investing in India.

images.alt_text: India's steel ministry wants lower import taxes on a number of key steelmaking raw materials, including nickel, to protect the domestic industry from the rising costs of basic resources, a senior government official said on Tuesday.

site_title: German factory growth reaches close to three-year in Dec
summary: German manufacturing growth reached its highest level in almost three years in December, driven by rising demand from Asia and the US, according to a survey. The Markit PMI rose to 55.6, surpassing the 50 line separating growth from contraction. This suggests the sector will contribute to an expansion in the fourth quarter. Companies reported solid improvement in domestic demand and new business wins, with output and new orders driving the overall improvement. The survey also noted rising inflationary pressures and a stronger euro.

site_title: US condemns Pyongyang missile plan, warns against 'provocative' actions
summary: The US has sharply condemned North Korea's plan to test-fire an intercontinental ballistic missile, warning Pyongyang against "provocative actions" and stating that any unlawful actions would have "consequences". The statement, issued by the Pentagon, urged North Korea to "refrain from provocative actions and inflammatory rhetoric" that threaten international peace and stability. The US reaffirmed its "ironclad commitment" to defend its allies, using "the full spectrum of US extended deterrence capabilities". North Korea claims to be close to testing such a missile, capable of reaching American shores.

images.alt_text: The United States on Sunday sharply condemned a North Korean plan to test-fire an intercontinental ballistic missile and warned Pyongyang against "provocative actions".

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Sunmoon Food Company has agreed to raise S$23 million through the issuance of new shares and warrants to Shanghai Yiguo E-Commerce, aiming to secure working capital and shift towards an asset-light consumer-centric business model. Saizen Reit's reverse takeover deal with Sime Darby Property Singapore has been delayed. Genting Singapore has sold its stake in a Jeju, Korea resort for US$411.1 million, generating a gain of about S$96.3 million.
